“你认为——”他迟疑了一下，首次用一个陌生的词不免有些腼腆。“主题怎么样？”他问。 “What did you think of the—” He hesitated, abashed at his first attempt to use a strange word.“Of the motif?” he asked.
“不很清楚，”她答道，“就大处而言，这是我唯一的批评意见。故事我听懂了，可是夹了不少别的东西。用词太繁琐。你引进了这么多题外的东西，把情节的发展也拉慢了。” “It was confused,” she answered.“That is my only criticism in the large way.I followed the story, but there seemed so much else.It is too wordy.You clog the action by introducing so much extraneous material.”
“那就是主要主题啊，”他急忙解释说，“这是个潜在的大主题， 具有宇宙性的东西。我试图使它与故事本身同步发展，说到底，故事不过是表面文章而已。我的路子是对的，可是我觉得表达得不好。我未能把主旨暗示清楚。不过我会慢慢学会的。” “That was the major motif,” he hurriedly explained, “the big underrunning motif, the cosmic and universal thing.I tried to make it keep time with the story itself, which was only superficial after all.I was on the right scent, but I guess I did it badly.I did not succeed in suggesting what I was driving at.But I’ll learn in time.”
她没听懂他的话。她是位文学士，可是他已经超越了她的深度。这一点她不能理解，还以为不理解是由于他讲话不连贯。 She did not follow him.She was a bachelor of arts, but he had gone beyond her limitations.This she did not comprehend, attributing her incomprehension to his incoherence.
“你真会说话，”她说，“不过小说是美，至少在某些地方。” “You were too voluble,” she said.“But it was beautiful, in places.”
在他耳鼓里她的声音似乎来自远方，因为他正在斟酌要不要把《海洋抒情诗》也念给她听。他躺在那里，心头一片钝痛似的失望，她目光炯炯地打量着他，一边又在沉思那无法摆脱的古里古怪的婚姻想法。 He heard her voice as from far off, for he was debating whether he would read her the “Sea Lyrics.”He lay in dull despair, while she watched him searchingly, pondering again upon unsummoned and wayward thoughts of marriage.
“你想成名吗？”她突然问道。 “You want to be famous?” she asked abruptly.
“是啊，有一点儿，”他承认，“这也是这场冒险的一部分。名声倒并不怎么样，我看重的是成名的过程。而且毕竟，成名对于我也只是为了达到其他目标的一种手段。我很想成名，说起来正为了那个目标。” “Yes, a little bit,” he confessed.“That is part of the adventure.It is not the being famous, but the process of becoming so, that counts.And after all, to be famous would be, for me, only a means to something else.I want to be famous very much, for that matter, and for that reason.”
“为了你，”他很想补充说，如果她听了这些作品以后能显示出一点儿热情，他很可能就会说出口了。 “For your sake,” he wanted to add, and might have added had she proved enthusiastic over what he had read to her.
可是她正在忙着盘算，想为他设计出一条他走得通的路，没顾上问他所暗示的最终目标究竟是什么。文学方面他没有前途。对此她很有把握。他今天已经证明了这一点，他的作品一股业余味，就像一个大二学生写的。他很会说话，可是说出话来没有文学味。她拿丁尼生、勃朗宁和她喜爱的散文大师与他比较，看出他希望渺茫，前途不定。然而她并没有把心里话全掏出来。她对他产生了一种奇怪的兴趣，因此并不想过于认真。毕竟，他写作的愿望只是某种小小的弱点，将来他会明白过来的。到那时他就会致力于生活中更为严肃的事业。而且他能成功。她清楚这一点。他是如此强劲有力，他不可能失败——只要他放弃写作。 But she was too busy in her mind, carving out a career for him that would at least be possible, to ask what the ultimate something was which he had hinted at.There was no career for him in literature.Of that she was convinced.He had proved it to-day, with his amateurish and sophomoric productions.He could talk well, but he was incapable of expressing himself in a literary way.She compared Tennyson, and Browning, and her favorite prose masters with him, and to his hopeless discredit.Yet she did not tell him her whole mind.Her strange interest in him led her to temporize.His desire to write was, after all, a little weakness which he would grow out of in time.Then he would devote himself to the more serious affairs of life.And he would succeed, too.She knew that.He was so strong that he could not fail—if only he would drop writing.
“伊登先生，我希望能看到你所有的作品。”她说道。 “I wish you would show me all you write, Mr. Eden,” she said.
他高兴得脸都红了。她产生了兴趣，这点可以肯定。至少她没有给他一张退稿条。她说他作品里有些部分写得颇美，这还是他从别人口中听到的第一声赞许话。 He flushed with pleasure.She was interested, that much was sure.And at least she had not given him a rejection slip.She had called certain portions of his work beautiful, and that was the first encouragement he had ever received from any one.
“一定，”他激动地说，“我向你保证，莫尔斯小姐，我一定会成功的。我明白，我已经走了不少的路，还有不少的路要走，可是即使我趴在地上爬也要爬到目的地。”他举起一叠稿件。“这是《海洋抒情诗》。你回家以后，我把它交给你，你有空的时候念一念。你一定要把你的意见告诉我。知道，我最需要的是批评意见。请你务必直言相告。” “I will,” he said passionately.“And I promise you, Miss Morse, that I will make good.I have come far, I know that; and I have far to go, and I will cover it if I have to do it on my hands and knees.”He held up a bunch of manuscript.“Here are the ‘Sea Lyrics.’ When you get home, I’ll turn them over to you to read at your leisure.And you must be sure to tell me just what you think of them.What I need, you know, above all things, is criticism.And do, please, be frank with me.”
“我一定非常坦率。”她答应道，心里却惴惴不安地想，自己刚才就不够坦率，她也怀疑下次见面时能不能对他直言不讳。 “I will be perfectly frank,” she promised, with an uneasy conviction that she had not been frank with him and with a doubt if she could be quite frank with him the next time.
第十五章 CHAPTER XV
“第一场战斗打过了，也结束了。”十天之后马丁对着镜子说道，“但还会有第二场、第三场战斗，一直要战斗到时间的尽头，除非——” “The first battle, fought and finished,” Martin said to the looking-glass ten days later.“But there will be a second battle, and a third battle, and battles to the end of time, unless—”
他没把这句话说完，而是扫视了一下这个寒酸的小房间，目光黯然停留在那一大叠退回来的稿件上。这些稿件仍装在长信封里，躺在地板的一个角落里。他已经买不起邮票来让它们继续旅行了，而这一个星期以来退稿还一直堆积着。明天还会有更多稿件被退回来，后天也是如此，大后天也是，一直到所有的稿件都被退回到这里来为止。而他也没法让它们再次上路了。他已经拖了一个月没交打字机的租金了，他实在交不起了，剩下的那点钱勉强只够支付这一周该交的膳宿费和职业介绍所的费用。 He had not finished the sentence, but looked about the mean little room and let his eyes dwell sadly upon a heap of returned manuscripts, still in their long envelopes, which lay in a corner on the floor.He had no stamps with which to continue them on their travels, and for a week they had been piling up.More of them would come in on the morrow, and on the next day, and the next, till they were all in.And he would be unable to start them out again.He was a month’s rent behind on the typewriter, which he could not pay, having barely enough for the week’s board which was due and for the employment office fees.
他坐了下来，若有所思地看着桌子。桌上墨迹斑斑，他忽然发现自己很喜欢这张桌子。 He sat down and regarded the table thoughtfully.There were ink stains upon it, and he suddenly discovered that he was fond of it.
“亲爱的老桌子，”他说道，“我曾和你一起度过了一些快乐的时光。说到底，你才一直是我的好朋友。你从来没有拒绝过我，从来不会用一张冷漠的退稿条来打发我，对于超时工作也从没有怨言。” “Dear old table,” he said, “I’ve spent some happy hours with you, and you’ve been a pretty good friend when all is said and done.You never turned me down, never passed me out a reward-of-unmerit rejection slip, never complained about working overtime.”
他将两只胳膊往桌上一撂，把脸埋了进去。他喉咙干疼，很想哭。这让他想起了自己第一次打架，那时他才六岁，满脸带泪地挥着拳头，而那个比他大两岁的男孩连捶带打，揍得他精疲力尽。马丁终于倒下了，疼痛难受得扭成一团，鼻血汨汨淌着，眼泪哗哗地从青肿的眼睛流出，而这时他看见了围成一圈的男孩们像野蛮人一样嚎叫着。 He dropped his arms upon the table and buried his face in them.His throat was aching, and he wanted to cry.It reminded him of his first fight, when he was six years old, when he punched away with the tears running down his cheeks while the other boy, two years his elder, had beaten and pounded him into exhaustion.He saw the ring of boys, howling like barbarians as he went down at last, writhing in the throes of nausea, the blood streaming from his nose and the tears from his bruised eyes.
“可怜的小伙子，”他低声自言自语道，“现在你可被揍得够惨的。都被打成一滩肉泥了。你倒下了，出局了。” “Poor little shaver,” he murmured.“And you’re just as badly licked now.You’re beaten to a pulp.You’re down and out.”
但第一次打架的那一幕仍然在他眼皮底下逗留着，当他定睛一看时，它就消散而去，然后又化作往后的一系列打架。六个月之后，奶酪脸（即跟他打架的男孩）又打了他。不过这次他把奶酪脸的眼睛打青了。这可真够了不起的。他看见了所有打架，打了一次又一次，每次被揍的都是他，而奶酪脸还在他面前幸灾乐祸。但他从来没有临阵脱逃。想到这个他便感觉自己变强大了。每次挨揍他都挺着，忍受着。奶酪脸打起架来简直跟个小恶魔一样，从来也没对他手下留情过。但是他都挺住了！他挺过去了！ But the vision of that first fight still lingered under his eyelids, and as he watched he saw it dissolve and reshape into the series of fights which had followed.Six months later Cheese-Face (that was the boy) had whipped him again.But he had blacked Cheese-Face’s eye that time.That was going some.He saw them all, fight after fight, himself always whipped and Cheese-Face exulting over him.But he had never run away.He felt strengthened by the memory of that.He had always stayed and taken his medicine.Cheese-Face had been a little fiend at fighting, and had never once shown mercy to him.But he had stayed!He had stayed with it!
接着，他看见了一条窄窄的小巷，两边是摇摇欲坠的建筑。一间一层楼高的砖房挡在了小巷的尽头，房子里传出印刷机有节奏的轰隆声，印出了第一期的《探询者》。他那时十一岁，奶酪脸十三岁，他们俩都去派送《探询者》。因此两人都在那里，等着拿报纸。很自然地，奶酪脸又去找他的麻烦，于是两人又干了一架，不过未分胜负，因为三点三刻印刷车间的门便敞开了，一堆报童挤了进去叠自己的报纸。 Next, he saw a narrow alley, between ramshackle frame buildings.The end of the alley was blocked by a one-story brick building, out of which issued the rhythmic thunder of the presses, running off the first edition of the @Enquirer@.He was eleven, and Cheese-Face was thirteen, and they both carried the @Enquirer@.That was why they were there, waiting for their papers.And, of course, Cheese-Face had picked on him again, and there was another fight that was indeterminate, because at quarter to four the door of the press-room was thrown open and the gang of boys crowded in to fold their papers.
“我明天再好好揍你。”他听见奶酪脸向他保证。然后他噙着眼泪，听见自己用尖细而颤抖的声音同意明天还会来这里。 “I’ll lick you to-morrow,” he heard Cheese-Face promise; and he heard his own voice, piping and trembling with unshed tears, agreeing to be there on the morrow.
第二天他如约去了，从学校里赶过来抢在前头到了，两分钟后就跟奶酪脸开打了。其他的男孩说他好样儿的，给他出谋划策，指出他打斗时出现的纰漏，还向他保证只要照着他们的话做就能赢。不过他们也给奶酪脸出主意。这场架给他们带来多大的乐趣啊！有好大一会儿，他停下了回忆，羡慕起那些孩子能够欣赏到他和奶酪脸制造的壮观场面。然后打斗继续，打得难分难解，一直持续了三十分钟，直到印刷车间开门。 And he had come there the next day, hurrying from school to be there first, and beating Cheese-Face by two minutes.The other boys said he was all right, and gave him advice, pointing out his faults as a scrapper and promising him victory if he carried out their instructions.The same boys gave Cheese-Face advice, too.How they had enjoyed the fight!He paused in his recollections long enough to envy them the spectacle he and Cheese-Face had put up.Then the fight was on, and it went on, without rounds, for thirty minutes, until the press-room door was opened.
他看着这个年轻的自己，日复一日地从学校赶到《探询者》巷。他没法走得很快。因为没完没了地打架，他身子僵硬，腿也瘸了。他的前臂也因挡了无数的拳头给弄得从腕部到手肘都是青一块紫一块的，到处都疼，还开始化脓。他的脑袋、胳膊还有肩膀都在疼，后腰一小部分也疼——他哪儿都疼，脑袋很沉很晕。他在学校玩不成。他也学习不了。 He watched the youthful apparition of himself, day after day, hurrying from school to the @Enquirer@ alley.He could not walk very fast.He was stiff and lame from the incessant fighting.His forearms were black and blue from wrist to elbow, what of the countless blows he had warded off, and here and there the tortured flesh was beginning to fester.His head and arms and shoulders ached, the small of his back ached,—he ached all over, and his brain was heavy and dazed.He did not play at school.　Nor did he study.
即便是在课桌边一动不动地坐上一整天（他的确也这么做），也是种折磨。自从他开始了那一连串的每天一架，仿佛过了几个世纪，时间延伸成一场噩梦，每天打架便是无限的未来。奶酪脸为什么就不能被揍一顿呢？他常常在想，这会叫他马丁脱离不幸。 Even to sit still all day at his desk, as he did, was a torment.It seemed centuries since he had begun the round of daily fights, and time stretched away into a nightmare and infinite future of daily fights.Why couldn’t Cheese-Face be licked? he often thought; that would put him, Martin, out of his misery.
但是他从没想过要停战，让奶酪脸揍他一顿。 It never entered his head to cease fighting, to allow Cheese-Face to whip him.
于是，他缓慢而吃力地把自己拖到《探询者》巷去，身心交瘁，但得学着长久地忍耐，去对抗他永远的敌人，奶酪脸。他，也正像他一样身心交瘁，要不是因为有那一伙围观的报童让他不能不去争那痛苦的面子，他也有点想罢手了。一天下午，按照定好的规矩，不许踢打腰带以下部位，对方倒下时不许再打，两人不顾一切地搏斗了二十分钟之后，奶酪脸喘着气摇摇晃晃地提出停手。而马丁，头靠在胳膊上，看见在很久以前的一个下午他自己的样子，他激动得发抖，那时的他摇摇晃晃，气喘吁吁，嘴唇被打破，血流进嘴里灌进喉咙，噎得他说不出话来；他踉跄着走向奶酪脸，吐出一口血才能说话，叫喊着即使奶酪脸肯让步，他也决不会罢手。而奶酪脸没有让步，于是打斗继续。 And so he dragged himself to the @Enquirer@ alley, sick in body and soul, but learning the long patience, to confront his eternal enemy, Cheese-Face, who was just as sick as he, and just a bit willing to quit if it were not for the gang of newsboys that looked on and made pride painful and necessary.One afternoon, after twenty minutes of desperate efforts to annihilate each other according to set rules that did not permit kicking, striking below the belt, nor hitting when one was down, Cheese-Face, panting for breath and reeling, offered to call it quits.And Martin, head on arms, thrilled at the picture he caught of himself, at that moment in the afternoon of long ago, when he reeled and panted and choked with the blood that ran into his mouth and down his throat from his cut lips; when he tottered toward Cheese-Face, spitting out a mouthful of blood so that he could speak, crying out that he would never quit, though Cheese-Face could give in if he wanted to.And Cheese-Face did not give in, and the fight went on.
次日又次日，没有尽头的日子目睹了每个下午的打斗。每天，当他举起胳膊开打的时候，它们便剧烈地疼起来，而开头那几拳，不论是打出去的还是被打回来的，都让他痛到心底；渐渐麻木以后，他便闷头瞎打一通，仿佛在梦中一般，看着奶酪脸庞大的嘴脸和野兽般冒着火的眼睛在他面前晃来晃去。他将注意力集中在那张脸上；他周围所有的一切都成了一个旋转的空间。世上除了那张脸再没有别的，他永远都不要休息，让人幸福的休息，直到他用他流血的拳头把那张脸打成肉酱，或是直到属于那张脸的流血的拳头把他打成肉酱。然后，不管怎样，他都可以休息了。但是罢手——对于他马丁而言，罢手——是不可能的！ The next day and the next, days without end, witnessed the afternoon fight.When he put up his arms, each day, to begin, they pained exquisitely, and the first few blows, struck and received, racked his soul; after that things grew numb, and he fought on blindly, seeing as in a dream, dancing and wavering, the large features and burning, animal-like eyes of Cheese-Face.He concentrated upon that face; all else about him was a whirling void.There was nothing else in the world but that face, and he would never know rest, blessed rest, until he had beaten that face into a pulp with his bleeding knuckles, or until the bleeding knuckles that somehow belonged to that face had beaten him into a pulp.And then, one way or the other, he would have rest.But to quit,—for him, Martin, to quit,—that was impossible!
直到那一天，当他拖着脚步走到《探询者》巷时，没有看到奶酪脸。奶酪脸终于没有来。孩子们恭喜他，告诉他奶酪脸已经被他打垮了。但是马丁并没有心满意足。他并不曾打败奶酪脸，奶酪脸也没打败他。问题并没有解决。直到后来他们才知道奶酪脸的父亲就是在那一天突然死了。 Came the day when he dragged himself into the @Enquirer@ alley, and there was no Cheese-Face.Nor did Cheese-Face come.The boys congratulated him, and told him that he had licked Cheese-Face.But Martin was not satisfied.He had not licked Cheese-Face, nor had Cheese-Face licked him.The problem had not been solved.It was not until afterward that they learned that Cheese-Face’s father had died suddenly that very day.
马丁掠过好几年来到了大戏院楼座看戏的那一晚。他十七岁了，刚从海上回来。一场争吵开始了。有谁在欺负人，马丁上前干涉，碰到了奶酪脸一双冒火的眼睛。 Martin skipped on through the years to the night in the nigger heaven at the Auditorium.He was seventeen and just back from sea.A row started.Somebody was bullying somebody, and Martin interfered, to be confronted by Cheese-Face’s blazing eyes.
“散场之后我再修理你。”他旧日的敌人向他发出嘘声。 “I’ll fix you after de show,” his ancient enemy hissed.
马丁点点头。楼座的保安朝骚乱的地方走来。 Martin nodded.The nigger-heaven bouncer was making his way toward the disturbance.
“等最后一幕完了，我们外边见。”马丁低声说道，同时他的脸表现得自己正专注于台上的踢踏舞。 “I’ll meet you outside, after the last act,” Martin whispered, the while his face showed undivided interest in the buck-and-wing dancing on the stage.
那保安瞪了瞪眼走开了。 The bouncer glared and went away.
“有帮手吗？”那一幕结束时，他问奶酪脸。 “Got a gang?” he asked Cheese-Face, at the end of the act.
“当然。” “Sure.”
“那我也得找一伙。”马丁宣布。 “Then I got to get one,” Martin announced.
幕间，他召集了他的帮手——三个钉子厂认识的人，一个铁路上的锅炉工，六七个大麻帮的，还有更多可怕的十八市场帮。 Between the acts he mustered his following—three fellows he knew from the nail works, a railroad fireman, and half a dozen of the Boo Gang, along with as many more from the dread Eighteen-and-Market Gang.
戏院散场后，两帮人马毫不显眼地在街道两边一个跟一个走。走到一个僻静的角落时，他们便集合起来，开了一个作战会议。 When the theatre let out, the two gangs strung along inconspicuously on opposite sides of the street.When they came to a quiet corner, they united and held a council of war.
“地点就在八街桥吧，”奶酪脸那帮的一个红头发家伙说，“你们在桥中间打，在电灯底下，管他警察从哪头来，我们都能从另一头溜掉。” “Eighth Street Bridge is the place,” said a red-headed fellow belonging to Cheese-Face’s Gang.“You kin fight in the middle, under the electric light, an’ whichever way the bulls come in we kin sneak the other way.”
马丁跟自己帮派的头目商量之后说：“我同意。” “That’s agreeable to me,” Martin said, after consulting with the leaders of his own gang.
八街桥，跨过圣安东尼奥河口的一道海湾，长度有三个城市的三个街区长。桥的中间和两边都有电灯。警察只要出现在桥头的灯光下就会被发现。就那一场复活在马丁眼前的打斗而言，这是个安全的地方。他看见两帮人马，咄咄逼人，怒气冲冲，壁垒森严地彼此分开，支持各自的同伙；他看见自己和奶酪脸在脱衣服。望风的安置在不远处，他们的任务是望着灯光照亮着的两边桥头。一个大麻帮的兄弟拿着马丁的外衣、衬衫、帽子，做好准备万一警察介入就跟他们一起跑到安全的地方。马丁看见自己走到桥中间，面对着奶酪脸，听见自己一边警告地举起手来，一边说： The Eighth Street Bridge, crossing an arm of San Antonio Estuary, was the length of three city blocks.In the middle of the bridge, and at each end, were electric lights.No policeman could pass those end-lights unseen.It was the safe place for the battle that revived itself under Martin’s eyelids.He saw the two gangs, aggressive and sullen, rigidly keeping apart from each other and backing their respective champions; and he saw himself and Cheese-Face stripping.A short distance away lookouts were set, their task being to watch the lighted ends of the bridge.A member of the Boo Gang held Martin’s coat, and shirt, and cap, ready to race with them into safety in case the police interfered.Martin watched himself go into the centre, facing Cheese-Face, and he heard himself say, as he held up his hand warningly:—
“这一架不会和解。懂吗？没别的，就是打架。不许认输投降。这是一场积怨已久的搏斗，要打到底的。懂吗？总要有一个被打败的。” “They ain’t no hand-shakin’ in this.Understand?They ain’t nothin’ but scrap.No throwin’ up the sponge.This is a grudge-fight an’ it’s to a finish.Understand?Somebody’s goin’ to get licked.”
奶酪脸想表示反对——马丁能看出来——但是在两帮人马面前奶酪脸一贯的危险的自尊心被触动了。 Cheese-Face wanted to demur,—Martin could see that,—but Cheese-Face’s old perilous pride was touched before the two gangs.
“哦，来吧，”他答道，“光嚼舌头有啥用？我奉陪到底。” “Aw, come on,” he replied.“Wot’s the good of chewin’ de rag about it?I’m wit’ cheh to de finish.”
于是，他们两人便打在一起，像两只小公牛，凭着年轻这点资本，赤手空拳，满怀仇恨，要把对方打伤，打残，甚至打死。人类千万年来在创造的过程中，在向上发展的进程中所得的所有煞费苦心的收获，完全失掉了。只有电灯，人类伟大的冒险历程中的一座里程碑，还在那里。马丁和奶酪脸是两个野蛮人，属于石器时代，野处巢居时代。他们在泥泞的深渊里越陷越深，退回到生命开端时的混沌状态，盲目地以化学方式争斗着，像原子一样，像满天星尘一样争斗着，碰击，避开，再碰击，直至永远。 Then they fell upon each other, like young bulls, in all the glory of youth, with naked fists, with hatred, with desire to hurt, to maim, to destroy.All the painful, thousand years’ gains of man in his upward climb through creation were lost.Only the electric light remained, a milestone on the path of the great human adventure.Martin and Cheese-Face were two savages, of the stone age, of the squatting place and the tree refuge.They sank lower and lower into the muddy abyss, back into the dregs of the raw beginnings of life, striving blindly and chemically, as atoms strive, as the star-dust if the heavens strives, colliding, recoiling, and colliding again and eternally again.
“天啊！我们是牲畜！残忍的牲畜！”观看这场打斗的时候，马丁大声咕哝着。对于他而言，由于他丰富的想象力，这就像是通过电影放映机在看。他是旁观者，同时又是当事人。长时间的文化教养使他在这种景象面前感到恐惧；于是，现在从他的意识中一笔勾销了，过去的幽灵控制着他，而他便是那个刚从海上回来的马丁·伊登，正在八街桥上跟奶酪脸打着架。他忍着疼痛，吃力地挣扎、淌汗、流血，而当他赤裸的拳头打中对方的时候，他便狂喜起来。 “God!We are animals!Brute-beasts!”Martin muttered aloud, as he watched the progress of the fight.It was to him, with his splendid power of vision, like gazing into a kinetoscope.He was both onlooker and participant.His long months of culture and refinement shuddered at the sight; then the present was blotted out of his consciousness and the ghosts of the past possessed him, and he was Martin Eden, just returned from sea and fighting Cheese-Face on the Eighth Street Bridge.He suffered and toiled and sweated and bled, and exulted when his naked knuckles smashed home.
他们是两团仇恨的旋风，凶狠地绕着彼此旋转。时间流逝，那两帮敌对的人马变得极为沉默了。他们不曾见过如此极度的凶残，他们被吓坏了。那两个斗殴者比他们残忍多了。最初的年轻力壮、血气方刚被磨掉，他们打得越发谨慎、越发用心了。双方都不曾占到上风。“谁输谁赢可说不准。”马丁听到谁在说。接着，他来了一个佯攻，一左一右，却遭到了狠狠地反击，觉得脸颊被打破了，都见到骨头了。赤手空拳是不能打成这样的。他听到那可怕的伤口引起人们惊愕的抱怨声，他自己被血浸透了。但他却不动声色。他变得非常警惕，因为对于他那类人下流的狡猾与肮脏的卑鄙，他非常了解。他留心观察着，等待着，直至他假装一个猛冲，又中途停下，因为他看见了金属的闪光。 They were twin whirlwinds of hatred, revolving about each other monstrously.The time passed, and the two hostile gangs became very quiet.They had never witnessed such intensity of ferocity, and they were awed by it.The two fighters were greater brutes than they.The first splendid velvet edge of youth and condition wore off, and they fought more cautiously and deliberately.There had been no advantage gained either way.“It’s anybody’s fight,” Martin heard some one saying.Then he followed up a feint, right and left, was fiercely countered, and felt his cheek laid open to the bone.No bare knuckle had done that.He heard mutters of amazement at the ghastly damage wrought, and was drenched with his own blood.But he gave no sign.He became immensely wary, for he was wise with knowledge of the low cunning and foul vileness of his kind.He watched and waited, until he feigned a wild rush, which he stopped midway, for he had seen the glint of metal.
“举起你的手！”他大声叫道，“那是铜指套，你戴着它打我！” “Hold up yer hand!” he screamed.“Them’s brass knuckles, an’ you hit me with ’em!”
两帮人马都涌向前，咆哮着，咒骂着。一秒之内，就会发生一场混战，那他就丧失了报仇的机会了。他像发了狂一般。 Both gangs surged forward, growling and snarling.In a second there would be a free-for-all fight, and he would be robbed of his vengeance.He was beside himself.
“你们这些家伙都滚开！”他声音嘶哑地大声叫道。“懂吗？听着，你们懂不懂？” “You guys keep out!” he screamed hoarsely.“Understand?Say, d’ye understand?”
他们退了回去。他们是残忍的人，而他却是头号残忍的人，是胜过他们并且能支配他们的一个可怕的人。 They shrank away from him.They were brutes, but he was the arch-brute, a thing of terror that towered over them and dominated them.
“这是我的事，他们别掺和。把铜指套交出来。” “This is my scrap, an’ they ain’t goin’ to be no buttin’ in.Gimme them knuckles.”
奶酪脸自知理亏，有点害怕了，便把那暗器交了出来。 Cheese-Face, sobered and a bit frightened, surrendered the foul weapon.
“是你递给他的，你这个红毛溜到人群后面给他的，”马丁继续叫道，一边把铜指套丢进水里，“我早看见你了，我一直怀疑你在搞什么鬼。要是你再敢搞这一套，我就揍死你。懂吗？” “You passed ’em to him, you red-head sneakin’ in behind the push there,” Martin went on, as he tossed the knuckles into the water.“I seen you, an’ I was wonderin’ what you was up to.If you try anything like that again, I’ll beat cheh to death.Understand?”
他们接着打，打到精疲力竭还不停手，直到疲惫到不可估量、难以想象的地步，直到那帮残忍的人，他们嗜血的欲望满足了，为他们所见的情景吓坏了，才不含偏私地请求他们住手。奶酪脸，马上就要倒地而死，或是站着死掉，一个貌似奶酪脸的可怕怪物被打败了，摇摇晃晃站立不稳；但马丁一跃上前，把他狠狠地打了又打。 They fought on, through exhaustion and beyond, to exhaustion immeasurable and inconceivable, until the crowd of brutes, its blood-lust sated, terrified by what it saw, begged them impartially to cease.And Cheese-Face, ready to drop and die, or to stay on his legs and die, a grisly monster out of whose features all likeness to Cheese-Face had been beaten, wavered and hesitated; but Martin sprang in and smashed him again and again.
接着，在仿佛过了一个世纪之后，奶酪脸正迅速衰弱下去，在一阵混乱的打斗声中只听啪的一声，马丁的右臂垂了下来。这是骨头断了。每一个人都听到了而且知道；奶酪脸也知道，便乘人之危，一头老虎似的冲过来，拳头如雨点般落下。马丁的人马涌上前来干涉。被那一顿紧密的拳脚打晕了的马丁，用肮脏并且当真的咒骂警告他们退后，自己在极度凄凉与绝望中呜咽着、呻吟着。 Next, after a seeming century or so, with Cheese-Face weakening fast, in a mix-up of blows there was a loud snap, and Martin’s right arm dropped to his side.It was a broken bone.Everybody heard it and knew; and Cheese-Face knew, rushing like a tiger in the other’s extremity and raining blow on blow.Martin’s gang surged forward to interfere.Dazed by the rapid succession of blows, Martin warned them back with vile and earnest curses sobbed out and groaned in ultimate desolation and despair.
只用他那只左手，他继续猛击，当他顽强地，只是半清醒地猛击的时候，仿佛从遥远的地方传来似的，他听到那帮人害怕地窃窃私语，其中有一个声音颤抖地说：“这不是打架，兄弟们。这是谋杀，我们该拦住他们。” He punched on, with his left hand only, and as he punched, doggedly, only half-conscious, as from a remote distance he heard murmurs of fear in the gangs, and one who said with shaking voice: “This ain’t a scrap, fellows.It’s murder, an’ we ought to stop it.”
但是没有人来拦，他很高兴，用一只臂膀疲惫却不断地搏斗着，连续猛击他面前那个血肉模糊的东西，那已经不是一张脸孔了，而是一件恐怖的东西，一件摇摆着的、丑陋的、口齿不清、不可名状的东西，总是在他眩晕的眼前不肯走开。他继续打着，越打越慢，最后的一点儿精力慢慢地从他体内渗出，经过了千万年的时光流逝，直到朦朦胧胧地，他意识到那不可名状的东西在倒下，慢慢地倒在那粗糙的桥板上。下一个瞬间，他站在那东西上面，双腿打颤，摇摇晃晃站立不稳，凭空乱抓想找个支撑，用自己也辨认不出的声音说道： But no one stopped it, and he was glad, punching on wearily and endlessly with his one arm, battering away at a bloody something before him that was not a face but a horror, an oscillating, hideous, gibbering, nameless thing that persisted before his wavering vision and would not go away.And he punched on and on, slower and slower, as the last shreds of vitality oozed from him, through centuries and aeons and enormous lapses of time, until, in a dim way, he became aware that the nameless thing was sinking, slowly sinking down to the rough board-planking of the bridge.And the next moment he was standing over it, staggering and swaying on shaky legs, clutching at the air for support, and saying in a voice he did not recognize:—
“还想挨揍吗？喂，还想挨揍吗？” “D’ye want any more?Say, d’ye want any more?”
他还在说，说了又说——质问着，哀求着，威胁着，想知道它还想不想挨揍了——当时他感觉自己的兄弟们把手放在他身上，轻拍他的背，设法给他穿衣服。接着他便眼前一黑，不省人事了。 He was still saying it, over and over,—demanding, entreating, threatening, to know if it wanted any more,—when he felt the fellows of his gang laying hands on him, patting him on the back and trying to put his coat on him.And then came a sudden rush of blackness and oblivion.
桌上的镀锡闹钟滴答滴答地响着，但马丁把脸埋在臂弯里，没有听见。他什么也没有听见。他什么也不想。他一定是再次体验了那种如几年前昏死在八街桥那样昏死的生活。黑暗和空白持续了整整一分钟之久。然后，像一个复活的人一样跳了起来，眼睛放着光，汗从脸上流下来，大声嚷道： The tin alarm-clock on the table ticked on, but Martin Eden, his face buried on his arms, did not hear it.He heard nothing.He did not think.So absolutely had he relived life that he had fainted just as he fainted years before on the Eighth Street Bridge.For a full minute the blackness and the blankness endured.Then, like one from the dead, he sprang upright, eyes flaming, sweat pouring down his face, shouting:—
“我打垮你啦，奶酪脸！我等了十一年，可我终于打垮了你！” “I licked you, Cheese-Face!It took me eleven years, but I licked you!”
他的双膝在发抖，觉得头晕，摇摇晃晃地回到床边，无力地坐在床沿上。他依然被过去所掌控着。他环顾房内，困惑又惊恐，弄不清自己在哪里，直到他瞥见角落里那堆稿子。然后，记忆之轮掠过了四年时光，他才意识到现在，意识到他翻开的书和他从书中获得的那个世界，意识到他的梦想和抱负，意识到他对于一位苍白的女神般的姑娘的爱恋，她，敏感优雅，惹人怜爱，哪怕只看见片刻他所过过的生活——他所涉足过的一切肮脏生活的片刻，她准会吓坏的。 His knees were trembling under him, he felt faint, and he staggered back to the bed, sinking down and sitting on the edge of it.He was still in the clutch of the past.He looked about the room, perplexed, alarmed, wondering where he was, until he caught sight of the pile of manuscripts in the corner.Then the wheels of memory slipped ahead through four years of time, and he was aware of the present, of the books he had opened and the universe he had won from their pages, of his dreams and ambitions,and of his love for a pale wraith of a girl, sensitive and sheltered and ethereal, who would die of horror did she witness but one moment of what he had just lived through—one moment of all the muck of life through which he had waded.
他站起身来，让自己对着镜子。 He arose to his feet and confronted himself in the looking-glass.
“你是从污泥里爬起来的，马丁·伊登，”他庄严地说。“你在光明中清洁自己的眼睛，使自己跻身于群星之间，做着所有生物做过的事，实行‘弃暗投明’，还从一切存在的力量中获取最优秀的遗产。” “And so you arise from the mud, Martin Eden,” he said solemnly.“And you cleanse your eyes in a great brightness, and thrust your shoulders among the stars, doing what all life has done, letting the ‘ape and tiger die’ and wresting highest heritage from all powers that be.”
他更仔细地看着自己，笑了。 He looked more closely at himself and laughed.
“有一点儿歇斯底里和几分戏剧性，是吗？”他问。“哎，不要紧。你打垮了奶酪脸，你也会打垮那些编辑的，哪怕需要两个十一年。你不能就此停住。你得继续前进。一定要有个结果，你知道的。” “A bit of hysteria and melodrama, eh?” he queried.“Well, never mind.You licked Cheese-Face, and you’ll lick the editors if it takes twice eleven years to do it in.You can’t stop here.You’ve got to go on.It’s to a finish, you know.”
第十六章 CHAPTER XVI
闹钟响了，马丁突然从睡梦中惊醒，这响声很突然，突然得会让一个体格不那么结实的人头痛的。虽然睡得正酣，但他还是立即醒了，像一只猫一样，而且他很迫切地要醒来，很高兴那五个小时无意识的状态已经过去。他憎恨睡眠让他遗忘一切。要做的事情太多了，要过的生活太丰富了。他吝惜睡眠从他那里夺走的每一分的生活，闹钟还未停止咔嗒声，他已经连头带耳浸在洗脸盆里，叫冷水激得直打激灵。 The alarm-clock went off, jerking Martin out of sleep with a suddenness that would have given headache to one with less splendid constitution.Though he slept soundly, he awoke instantly, like a cat, and he awoke eagerly, glad that the five hours of unconsciousness were gone.He hated the oblivion of sleep.There was too much to do, too much of life to live.He grudged every moment of life sleep robbed him of, and before the clock had ceased its clattering he was head and ears in the washbasin and thrilling to the cold bite of the water.
但他没有按预定的日程行事。没有未完成小说等着他动手去写，也没有要构思的新小说。昨晚他读书到很晚，现在已经差不多是吃早饭的时候了。他尽力想读一章菲斯克的书，但是他的脑子乱糟糟的，又把书合上了。今天见证着他新的奋斗的开始，有一段时间他不会再写作了。他领略到一种类似于一个人离开家和家人时的哀愁。他看到角落里的书稿。就是它们。他正要离开它们，这些可怜的、不体面的、到处都不受欢迎的孩子们。他走过去，开始在它们中间仔细翻找，这一段那一段地读着他最得意的片段。他很看得起“坛子”，高声地读着，正如他看待“冒险”一样。那篇前一天完成的最新作品“欢乐”，因为没有邮票便扔在角落里，则赢得了他最由衷的赞赏。 But he did not follow his regular programme.There was no unfinished story waiting his hand, no new story demanding articulation.He had studied late, and it was nearly time for breakfast.He tried to read a chapter in Fiske, but his brain was restless and he closed the book.To-day witnessed the beginning of the new battle, wherein for some time there would be no writing.He was aware of a sadness akin to that with which one leaves home and family.He looked at the manuscripts in the corner.That was it.He was going away from them, his pitiful, dishonored children that were welcome nowhere.He went over and began to rummage among them, reading snatches here and there, his favorite portions.“The Pot” he honored with reading aloud, as he did “Adventure.”“Joy,” his latest-born, completed the day before and tossed into the corner for lack of stamps, won his keenest approbation.
“我真搞不懂，”他喃喃着，“或许搞不懂的是编辑们吧。这没什么毛病啊。他们每月发表的作品更糟糕。他们发表的所有作品都很糟——总之，差不多每篇都是。” “I can’t understand,” he murmured.“Or maybe it’s the editors who can’t understand.There’s nothing wrong with that.They publish worse every month.Everything they publish is worse—nearly everything, anyway.”
早饭过后他把打字机放到箱子里，带着它到奥克兰去了。 After breakfast he put the type-writer in its case and carried it down into Oakland.
“我欠下了一个月的租金，”他告诉那店里的店员，“你告诉经理一声吧，我要干活去，个把月就能付清。” “I owe a month on it,” he told the clerk in the store.“But you tell the manager I’m going to work and that I’ll be in in a month or so and straighten up.”
他坐着渡船到旧金山，去了一家职业介绍所。“啥活都行，没啥手艺。”他告诉那位代理人，却被一个新来的人打断了。那人穿得相当花哨，像那些生性爱漂亮的工人一样爱打扮。那代理人无精打采地摇摇头。 He crossed on the ferry to San Francisco and made his way to an employment office.“Any kind of work, no trade,” he told the agent; and was interrupted by a new-comer, dressed rather foppishly, as some workingmen dress who have instincts for finer things.The agent shook his head despondently.
“没活干啊？”那个人说。 “Nothin’ doin’ eh?” said the other.
“我今天正要找个人呢。” “Well, I got to get somebody to-day.”
他转过身来盯着马丁看，马丁呢，也回盯着他，注意到那张浮肿且苍白的脸，英俊但虚弱，知道他是玩过一个通宵来的。 He turned and stared at Martin, and Martin, staring back, noted the puffed and discolored face, handsome and weak, and knew that he had been making a night of it.
“找活干？”那个人问道，“你会做什么？” “Lookin’ for a job?” the other queried.“What can you do?”
“做苦工，做水手，做打字员——速记不行，会骑马，什么活都愿意做，都能应付得了。”马丁答道。 “Hard labor, sailorizing, run a type-writer, no shorthand, can sit on a horse, willing to do anything and tackle anything,” was the answer.
那人点点头。 The other nodded.
“听来倒合我的心意。我叫道森，乔·道森，我正想找一个洗衣工。” “Sounds good to me.My name’s Dawson, Joe Dawson, an’ I’m tryin’ to scare up a laundryman.”
“我做不来。”马丁仿佛瞥见自己熨着女人穿的松软的白色衣物时那可笑的情形了。但他看那人顺眼，又补上一句：“光洗衣服我倒是会。出海时学的。”乔·道森显然思索了一会儿。 “Too much for me.”Martin caught an amusing glimpse of himself ironing fluffy white things that women wear.But he had taken a liking to the other, and he added: “I might do the plain washing.I learned that much at sea.”Joe Dawson thought visibly for a moment.
“听我说，咱们一起商量商量。愿意听吗？” “Look here, let’s get together an’ frame it up.Willin’ to listen?”
马丁点点头。 Martin nodded.
“这是一间小洗衣房，在乡下，属谢利温泉——旅馆，你知道。两个人干活，一个头儿，一个帮手。我是头儿。你不是为我干活，但是你在我手下干活。想想你愿意学着做吗？ “This is a small laundry, up country, belongs to Shelly Hot Springs,—hotel, you know.Two men do the work, boss and assistant.I’m the boss.You don’t work for me, but you work under me.Think you’d be willin’ to learn?”
马丁停了下来去考虑。前景很诱人。干几个月，他也会有自己的时间去学习的。他会一边努力干活，一边努力学习。 Martin paused to think.The prospect was alluring.A few months of it, and he would have time to himself for study.He could work hard and study hard.
“伙食不错，你自己还有一间屋。”乔说。 “Good grub an’ a room to yourself,” Joe said.
那就解决了。他自己一间屋，他就可以不受干扰地点灯到深夜了。 That settled it.A room to himself where he could burn the midnight oil unmolested.
“但是得拼命干活。”那人补充道。 “But work like hell,” the other added.
马丁摸着他鼓起的肩部肌肉示意。“这可是做苦工得来的。” Martin caressed his swelling shoulder-muscles significantly.“That came from hard work.”
“那咱们就谈谈本题吧。”乔抬起手按着他的头好一会儿。“哎呀，这是个机械表。少见的。昨夜我什么都想到了——所有事情——所有事情。这便是想出来的计划。两个人的工钱是一百块，外加膳宿。我一向拿六十，另外一个拿四十。但他是内行。你是新手。若是我训练你，刚开头时我就得干很多属你份上的活。就暂定开头给你三十，以后加到四十。我会很公道的。只要你能干你份上的活，你就拿四十。” “Then let’s get to it.”Joe held his hand to his head for a moment.“Gee, but it’s a stem-winder.Can hardly see.I went down the line last night—everything—everything.Here’s the frame-up.The wages for two is a hundred and board.I’ve ben drawin’ down sixty, the second man forty.But he knew the biz.You’re green.If I break you in, I’ll be doing plenty of your work at first.Suppose you begin at thirty, an’ work up to the forty.I’ll play fair.Just as soon as you can do your share you get the forty.”
“我同意啦，”马丁宣布，伸出手来，给那人握着了。“能预支点吗？——买火车票和杂花。” “I’ll go you,” Martin announced, stretching out his hand, which the other shook.“Any advance?—for rail-road ticket and extras?”
“我全花光了，”这是乔略带遗憾的回答，又一次伸手按着他胀痛的头。“我只剩一张回程的车票啦。” “I blew it in,” was Joe’s sad answer, with another reach at his aching head.“All I got is a return ticket.”
“我就要变成一个穷光蛋了——等到付膳宿费的时候。” “And I’m broke—when I pay my board.”
“那就溜吧。”乔建议。 “Jump it,” Joe advised.
“不行。欠我姐姐的。” “Can’t.Owe it to my sister.”
乔很困惑，吹了一个长长的口哨，绞尽脑汁要想点办法。 Joe whistled a long, perplexed whistle, and racked his brains to little purpose.
“我还有点酒钱，”他绝望地说。“来吧，或许我们能想出点办法。” “I’ve got the price of the drinks,” he said desperately.“Come on, an’ mebbe we’ll cook up something.”
马丁拒绝了。 Martin declined.
“戒酒了？” “Water-wagon?”
这次马丁点头了，乔悔恨道：“我恨不得也能戒掉。” This time Martin nodded, and Joe lamented, “Wish I was.”
“但是不知怎地就是戒不掉，”他辩解道，“像下地狱般地干了一整个星期活之后，我就得喝个痛快。要不，我简直要割破自己的喉咙，要么就烧房子。但是我挺高兴你戒了。坚持着吧。” “But I somehow just can’t,” he said in extenuation.“After I’ve ben workin’ like hell all week I just got to booze up.If I didn’t, I’d cut my throat or burn up the premises.But I’m glad you’re on the wagon.Stay with it.”
马丁知道他和这个人之间有巨大的鸿沟——那是书造成的；但他发现回头跨过这道鸿沟也不难。他一辈子都在劳工世界里过活，对劳工的情谊是他的第二天性。他解决了运输问题，这是对方那胀痛的脑袋所想不出的。他可以利用乔的火车票，把自己的箱子运送到谢利温泉馆。至于他自己，有他的脚踏车。七十英里的路程，他可以在礼拜天骑车过去，礼拜一早上就可以开工了。这期间，他便回家收拾东西。他不用跟谁告别。鲁思全家正在塔霍湖畔谢拉山度过这漫漫长夏。 Martin knew of the enormous gulf between him and this man—the gulf the books had made; but he found no difficulty in crossing back over that gulf.He had lived all his life in the working-class world, and the camaraderie of labor was second nature with him.He solved the difficulty of transportation that was too much for the other’s aching head.He would send his trunk up to Shelly Hot Springs on Joe’s ticket.As for himself, there was his wheel.It was seventy miles, and he could ride it on Sunday and be ready for work Monday morning.In the meantime he would go home and pack up.There was no one to say good-by to.Ruth and her whole family were spending the long summer in the Sierras, at Lake Tahoe.
他礼拜天晚上到了谢利温泉馆，精疲力尽，满身尘土。乔兴高采烈地迎接他。一条湿毛巾绑在胀痛的额头上，他已经干了一整天活了。 He arrived at Shelly Hot Springs, tired and dusty, on Sunday night.Joe greeted him exuberantly.With a wet towel bound about his aching brow, he had been at work all day.
“上礼拜一部分待洗的衣服堆起来了，因为我去找你了，”他解释道，“你的箱子已经运到了。在你的房间。你那鬼东西也能叫箱子。里面装的什么？金砖？” “Part of last week’s washin’ mounted up, me bein’ away to get you,” he explained.“Your box arrived all right.It’s in your room.But it’s a hell of a thing to call a trunk.An’ what’s in it?Gold bricks?”
马丁打开箱子时，乔坐在床上。这是个早点装运箱，希金博特姆先生要了他半块钱才给他的。马丁给它钉上两段绳子当把手，很巧妙地把它变成了一个适合放在行李车上的行李箱子。乔用那一双鼓起的眼睛瞧着他从箱子里取出几件衬衣和几套换洗内衣裤，接着就是书，很多书。 Joe sat on the bed while Martin unpacked.The box was a packing-case for breakfast food, and Mr. Higginbotham had charged him half a dollar for it.Two rope handles, nailed on by Martin, had technically transformed it into a trunk eligible for the baggage-car.Joe watched, with bulging eyes, a few shirts and several changes of underclothes come out of the box, followed by books, and more books.
“直到箱底还是书吗？”他问。 “Books clean to the bottom?” he asked.
马丁点头，继续把书摆到一张餐桌上，这桌子原是摆在屋里当脸盆架用的。 Martin nodded, and went on arranging the books on a kitchen table which served in the room in place of a wash-stand.
“哎呀！”乔大嚷了一声，然后无声地等待他的脑子得出个推论来。他终于想到了。 “Gee!”Joe exploded, then waited in silence for the deduction to arise in his brain.At last it came.
“喂，你对女孩子不——不大有兴趣吧？”他问道。 “Say, you don’t care for the girls—much?” he queried.
“没兴趣，”这是答复，“在迷上书本以前，我惯常追着一大批女孩子。那以后便没时间了。” “No,” was the answer.“I used to chase a lot before I tackled the books.But since then there’s no time.”
“在这儿也不会有一点儿时间的。你能做的就是干活跟睡觉。” “And there won’t be any time here.All you can do is work an’ sleep.”
马丁想到他一夜只睡五个钟头，便笑了。那屋子在洗衣房上边，跟引擎在同一座建筑物里，这引擎既抽水又发电，还带动洗衣机。住在隔壁房间的机修工进来见见新来的伙伴，帮马丁在一条接出来的电线上装了一个灯泡，又牵了一条绳，这样灯泡可以在桌子上方和床中间移来移去。 Martin thought of his five hours’ sleep a night, and smiled.The room was situated over the laundry and was in the same building with the engine that pumped water, made electricity, and ran the laundry machinery.The engineer, who occupied the adjoining room, dropped in to meet the new hand and helped Martin rig up an electric bulb, on an extension wire, so that it travelled along a stretched cord from over the table to the bed.
第二天早上六点一刻，马丁就被叫醒，准备六点三刻吃早饭。洗衣房里正好有一个仆人用的浴盆，他便去洗了个冷水浴，让乔感到震惊。 The next morning, at quarter-past six, Martin was routed out for a quarter-to-seven breakfast.There happened to be a bath-tub for the servants in the laundry building, and he electrified Joe by taking a cold bath.
“哎呀，你真是棒！”当他们在旅馆厨房的角落里坐下吃早饭时，乔说。 “Gee, but you’re a hummer!”Joe announced, as they sat down to breakfast in a corner of the hotel kitchen.
和他们一起的是机修工、花匠、花匠的帮手和两三个马房里的。他们匆匆地、闷闷不乐地吃着饭，甚少谈话，马丁吃着饭听着他们谈话，意识到自己跟他们的状态相距甚远。他们精神贫乏得令他沮丧，他急着要离开他们。所以他像他们一样匆匆咽下他的早饭，那令人恶心的难吃的东西，当他从厨房门走出去的时候，如释重负般吐了一口气。 With them was the engineer, the gardener, and the assistant gardener, and two or three men from the stable.They ate hurriedly and gloomily, with but little conversation, and as Martin ate and listened he realized how far he had travelled from their status.Their small mental caliber was depressing to him, and he was anxious to get away from them.So he bolted his breakfast, a sickly, sloppy affair, as rapidly as they, and heaved a sigh of relief when he passed out through the kitchen door.
这是一间设备齐全的小型蒸汽洗衣房，那里面，凡是机器可以做的工作都由最现代的机器来做。马丁，在受了一点儿指点以后，便去把那一大堆脏衣服分类了，乔则开动捣碎机，调制新的液体肥皂，那是由带腐蚀性的化学药品合成的，迫使他用浴巾包着嘴、鼻孔和眼睛，直到他好像成了一个木乃伊。分类完成后，马丁便帮忙绞衣服。这工作就是把衣服倒进一个每分钟旋转几千次的容器中，利用离心力把衣服上的水甩掉。然后马丁便开始在烘干机和脱水机之间忙来忙去，时而把那些短袜长袜“抖开”。到下午，一个送一个叠，他们用热熨平机把那些短袜长袜熨平。接着便是热熨斗和内衣裤，直至六点钟，乔没把握地摇摇头。 It was a perfectly appointed, small steam laundry, wherein the most modern machinery did everything that was possible for machinery to do.Martin, after a few instructions, sorted the great heaps of soiled clothes, while Joe started the masher and made up fresh supplies of soft-soap, compounded of biting chemicals that compelled him to swathe his mouth and nostrils and eyes in bath-towels till he resembled a mummy.Finished the sorting, Martin lent a hand in wringing the clothes.This was done by dumping them into a spinning receptacle that went at a rate of a few thousand revolutions a minute, tearing the matter from the clothes by centrifugal force.Then Martin began to alternate between the dryer and the wringer, between times “shaking out” socks and stockings.By the afternoon, one feeding and one, stacking up, they were running socks and stockings through the mangle while the irons were heating.Then it was hot irons and underclothes till six o’clock, at which time Joe shook his head dubiously.
“还差得远呢，”他说，“晚饭后还得干。”晚饭后，在灼热的电灯光下他们一直干到十点，直至最后一件内衣也熨好，折好，放进分发室。这是一个酷热的加利福尼亚之夜，虽然窗户都大开着，有个火热的熨烫炉在，房间像个火炉。马丁和乔，脱得只剩内衣裤，赤着胳膊，还是汗流不止，喘不过气来。 “Way behind,” he said.“Got to work after supper.”And after supper they worked until ten o’clock, under the blazing electric lights, until the last piece of under-clothing was ironed and folded away in the distributing room.It was a hot California night, and though the windows were thrown wide, the room, with its red-hot ironing-stove, was a furnace.Martin and Joe, down to undershirts, bare armed, sweated and panted for air.
“像在热带上货呢。”他们上楼时马丁说。 “Like trimming cargo in the tropics,” Martin said, when they went upstairs.
“你能行，”乔答道，“你挺能干，像个好伙计。要是你这么干下去，拿三十块就只是一个月的事了。第二个月你就能拿四十块了。可别告诉我你以前从没熨过东西。我可看得出来。” “You’ll do,” Joe answered.“You take hold like a good fellow.If you keep up the pace, you’ll be on thirty dollars only one month.The second month you’ll be gettin’ your forty.But don’t tell me you never ironed before.I know better.”
“说老实话，在今天以前，我这辈子连一块破布都没熨过。”马丁申明。 “Never ironed a rag in my life, honestly, until to-day,” Martin protested.
当他进了房间，他为自己的疲劳而惊讶，忘了自己已经不停地站着做了十四小时的工。他把闹钟定在六点，算回来五个钟头便是一点。他可以读书读到那个时候。脱掉鞋子，好让肿胀的脚舒服舒服，他拿着书在桌旁坐下了。他翻开菲斯克，接着以前读到的地方读下去。但读第一段就感到费力，于是读第二遍。后来他醒了，感到肌肉僵硬痛楚，而且从窗户吹进来的山风让他觉得好冷。他看了看表。两点钟。他已经睡了四个钟头。他脱了衣服，爬到床上，头一碰枕头便睡着了。 He was surprised at his weariness when he act into his room, forgetful of the fact that he had been on his feet and working without let up for fourteen hours.He set the alarm clock at six, and measured back five hours to one o’clock.He could read until then.Slipping off his shoes, to ease his swollen feet, he sat down at the table with his books.He opened Fiske, where he had left off to read.But he found trouble began to read it through a second time.Then he awoke, in pain from his stiffened muscles and chilled by the mountain wind that had begun to blow in through the window.He looked at the clock.It marked two.He had been asleep four hours.He pulled off his clothes and crawled into bed, where he was asleep the moment after his head touched the pillow.
星期二，同样连续不断的劳作。乔干活迅速，这赢得了马丁的赞赏。乔做起工来抵得上十二个魔鬼。他十分振奋，处于高效状态，在漫长的一天当中，没有片刻不为争取时间而奋斗。他集中精神在他的活计和怎样节省时间上面，他给马丁指出马丁用五个动作才完成的活可以三个动作完成，或是三个动作才完成的活可以用两个动作完成。“消除多余动作。”马丁注视着他的动作并照着做的时候描述道。他本人就是一个好工人，敏捷又灵巧，没人能替得了他那份工作，也没人能比他做得更好，这是他一向引以为傲的一点。结果，他以同样的专心集中精神干活，迫切地抓住他的同伴抛给他的那些提示和指点。他“压平”领子和袖口，把两层厚厚的亚麻布之间的浆搓掉，以免在熨烫时会有气泡，他做得很麻利，得到乔的称赞。 Tuesday was a day of similar unremitting toil.The speed with which Joe worked won Martin’s admiration.Joe was a dozen of demons for work.He was keyed up to concert pitch, and there was never a moment in the long day when he was not fighting for moments.He concentrated himself upon his work and upon how to save time, pointing out to Martin where he did in five motions what could be done in three, or in three motions what could be done in two.“Elimination of waste motion,” Martin phrased it as he watched and patterned after.He was a good workman himself, quick and deft, and it had always been a point of pride with him that no man should do any of his work for him or outwork him.As a result, he concentrated with a similar singleness of purpose, greedily snapping up the hints and suggestions thrown out by his working mate.He “rubbed out” collars and cuffs, rubbing the starch out from between the double thicknesses of linen so that there would be no blisters when it came to the ironing, and doing it at a pace that elicited Joe’s praise.
两人手边总有活干，从不得闲。乔既不等待也不伺候什么，不断地做完一件又一件。他们浆了两百件衬衣，用一个收拢动作抓紧衬衣，于是袖口、领子、肩头和前胸便都在旋转着的右手外面张了开来。此时左手提起衬衣的衣身就不会沾到浆，右手同时沾到浆里——浆很烫，为了绞干它，他们的手不得不插入并不断地插入一桶冷水里。那一晚他们一直干到十点半，为太太小姐们所有饰有褶边的轻巧精致的衣物沾着“精选的浆”。 There was never an interval when something was not at hand to be done.Joe waited for nothing, waited on nothing, and went on the jump from task to task.They starched two hundred white shirts, with a single gathering movement seizing a shirt so that the wristbands, neckband, yoke, and bosom protruded beyond the circling right hand.At the same moment the left hand held up the body of the shirt so that it would not enter the starch, and at the moment the right hand dipped into the starch—starch so hot that, in order to wring it out, their hands had to thrust, and thrust continually, into a bucket of cold water.And that night they worked till half-past ten, dipping “fancy starch”—all the frilled and airy, delicate wear of ladies.
“我宁可在热带干活，也不愿洗衣服。”马丁笑道。 “Me for the tropics and no clothes,” Martin laughed.
“不洗衣服，我就失业了。”乔一本正经地回答。“除了洗衣服，我啥都不懂。” “And me out of a job,” Joe answered seriously.“I don’t know nothin’ but laundrying.”
“可是你洗得很好。” “And you know it well.”
“我本该会的。开始在奥克兰的康特拉科斯塔，我那时才十一岁，把衣服抖开，给热轧滚筒轧平。那是十八年前的事，我从没干过别的活。但这活是我干过的最要命的活。至少该再来一个人。咱们明儿晚上再干吧。总是在星期三晚上开热轧滚筒——轧领子和袖口。 “I ought to.Began in the Contra Costa in Oakland when I was eleven, shakin’ out for the mangle.That was eighteen years ago, an’ I’ve never done a tap of anything else.But this job is the fiercest I ever had.Ought to be one more man on it at least.We work to-morrow night.Always run the mangle Wednesday nights—collars an’ cuffs.”
马丁定好闹钟，坐在桌旁，翻开了菲斯克。他第一段没读完。一行行的字模糊起来，混在一起了，他打瞌睡了。他踱来踱去，用拳头使劲地敲自己的头，但他还是克服不了浓重的睡意。他把书支在眼前，用手指支开眼皮，还是睁着眼睛睡着了。于是，他投降了，几乎不知道自己在干什么，脱掉衣服钻进被窝。他睡了七个小时，睡得很沉，像牲口一样，给闹钟叫醒了，感觉还没睡够。 Martin set his alarm, drew up to the table, and opened Fiske.He did not finish the first paragraph.The lines blurred and ran together and his head nodded.He walked up and down, batting his head savagely with his fists, but he could not conquer the numbness of sleep.He propped the book before him, and propped his eyelids with his fingers, and fell asleep with his eyes wide open.Then he surrendered, and, scarcely conscious of what he did, got off his clothes and into bed.He slept seven hours of heavy, animal-like sleep, and awoke by the alarm, feeling that he had not had enough.
“读了很多了吧？”乔问道。 “Doin’ much readin’?” Joe asked.
马丁摇摇头。 Martin shook his head.
“不要紧。咱们今晚开热轧滚筒，但星期四六点就收工。那你就有机会看书了。” “Never mind.We got to run the mangle to-night, but Thursday we’ll knock off at six.That’ll give you a chance.”
那天马丁在一个大桶里洗羊毛衣物，手工洗，用的是强效软肥皂，工具是一个马车轮子上的车轴，装在一个杆上，这根杆又固定在头顶上的一根弹簧杆上。 Martin washed woollens that day, by hand, in a large barrel, with strong soft-soap, by means of a hub from a wagon wheel, mounted on a plunger-pole that was attached to a spring-pole overhead.
“我的发明，”乔自豪地说，“比搓衣板和你的手强多了，另外，一个星期至少能省下十五分钟，这种活能省十五分钟可不能小看啊。” “My invention,” Joe said proudly.“Beats a washboard an’ your knuckles, and, besides, it saves at least fifteen minutes in the week, an’ fifteen minutes ain’t to be sneezed at in this shebang.”
用热轧滚筒轧领子和袖口也是乔的主意。那天晚上，他们在电灯底下干活的时候，乔解释道。 Running the collars and cuffs through the mangle was also Joe’s idea.That night, while they toiled on under the electric lights, he explained it.
“没有哪家洗衣房这么干过，除了这家。要想在星期六下午三点钟干完活，我就得这么干。但是我知道怎么做，这就是差别。热度要正好，压力要正好，还要轧三遍。看！”他举起一只袖口。“用手或熨衣机都熨不了这么好。” “Something no laundry ever does, except this one.An’ I got to do it if I’m goin’ to get done Saturday afternoon at three o’clock.But I know how, an’ that’s the difference.Got to have right heat, right pressure, and run ’em through three times.Look at that!”He held a cuff aloft.“Couldn’t do it better by hand or on a tiler.”
星期四，乔发火了。一堆额外的“花式浆洗”送来了。 Thursday, Joe was in a rage.A bundle of extra “fancy starch” had come in.
“我不干了，”他宣布，“我受不了了。我彻底不干了。我有什么好处？整个星期像个奴隶似的干活，争分夺秒，他们却把额外的“花式浆洗”往我身上堆。这是个自由的国家，我要告诉那个荷兰胖子我怎么看他。我不会跟他讲粗话。美国式的直来直去我看就够好的了。他居然把额外的‘花式浆洗’推给我！” “I’m goin’ to quit,” he announced.“I won’t stand for it.I’m goin’ to quit it cold.What’s the good of me workin’ like a slave all week, a-savin’ minutes, an’ them a-comin’ an’ ringin’ in fancy-starch extras on me?This is a free country, an’ I’m to tell that fat Dutchman what I think of him.An’ I won’t tell ’m in French.Plain United States is good enough for me.Him a-ringin’ in fancy starch extras!”
“咱们今晚还得干。”转眼他就这么说，颠倒了自己的判断，对命运屈服了。 “We got to work to-night,” he said the next moment, reversing his judgment and surrendering to fate.
那一晚马丁没有读书。他整个星期都没看报，但很奇怪，他并不想看。他对新闻不感兴趣。他太累了，厌倦了，对什么都不感兴趣，尽管他计划要是星期六下午三点钟干完活，他要骑车到奥克兰去。七十英里的路程，星期天下午再骑回来也是一样距离，那他根本休息不上，就要开始第二个星期的工作。要是坐火车的话会好一点，但是来回一趟要两块半，而他却决心要攒钱。 And Martin did no reading that night.He had seen no daily paper all week, and, strangely to him, felt no desire to see one.He was not interested in the news.He was too tired and jaded to be interested in anything, though he planned to leave Saturday afternoon, if they finished at three, and ride on his wheel to Oakland.It was seventy miles, and the same distance back on Sunday afternoon would leave him anything but rested for the second week’s work.It would have been easier to go on the train, but the round trip was two dollars and a half, and he was intent on saving money.
第十七章 CHAPTER XVII
马丁学会了做许多事。在第一个星期当中，有一天下午，他和乔处理了两百件白衬衣。乔开动熨衣机，这个机器里有一个热熨斗钩在一根钢丝上，从而产生压力。用这种方法，他熨了肩头、袖口和领口，使领口和衬衣成直角，再把胸部熨光滑。他一熨完这些衬衣，便把它们抛到他和马丁中间的一个架子上，马丁便拿来“复熨”。这工作包括熨烫衬衣所有没有被浆过的部分。 Martin learned to do many things.In the course of the first week, in one afternoon, he and Joe accounted for the two hundred white shirts.Joe ran the tiler, a machine wherein a hot iron was hooked on a steel string which furnished the pressure.By this means he ironed the yoke, wristbands, and neckband, setting the latter at right angles to the shirt, and put the glossy finish on the bosom.As fast as he finished them, he flung the shirts on a rack between him and Martin, who caught them up and “backed” them.This task consisted of ironing all the unstarched portions of the shirts.
这是件非常累人的活，一个小时接着一个小时，以最快的速度干。旅馆外面宽敞的游廊上，男男女女们穿着凉快的白衣服，啜饮着冰凉的饮料，缓和着血液循环。但洗衣房里空气热得冒烟了。巨大的火炉咆哮着，从赤热到白热，而熨斗在潮湿的衣物上推移着，送出一团团蒸汽。这些熨斗的热度跟家庭主妇们用的可大不相同。用一只湿手指对一个熨斗进行普通测试对于乔和马丁来说太冷了，这种测试也毫无用处。他们全是把熨斗靠近脸颊，凭一种神秘的心灵反应来测定熨斗的温度，这令马丁羡慕却不能了解其中奥妙。当新烧热的熨斗太热的时候，他们便把熨斗挂到铁棒上往冷水里浸一浸。这同样要求有准确而精密的判断。在水里多浸了几分之一秒，合适的温度所产生的微妙细腻的作用便会消失，马丁也惊异于自己训练出的这种精确性——一种自动的精确性，建立在机器般准确无误的标准之上。 It was exhausting work, carried on, hour after hour, at top speed.Out on the broad verandas of the hotel, men and women, in cool white, sipped iced drinks and kept their circulation down.But in the laundry the air was sizzling.The huge stove roared red hot and white hot, while the irons, moving over the damp cloth, sent up clouds of steam.The heat of these irons was different from that used by housewives.An iron that stood the ordinary test of a wet finger was too cold for Joe and Martin, and such test was useless.They went wholly by holding the irons close to their cheeks, gauging the heat by some secret mental process that Martin admired but could not understand.When the fresh irons proved too hot, they hooked them on iron rods and dipped them into cold water.This again required a precise and subtle judgment.A fraction of a second too long in the water and the fine and silken edge of the proper heat was lost, and Martin found time to marvel at the accuracy he developed—an automatic accuracy, founded upon criteria that were machine-like and unerring.
但是他几乎没有时间去惊讶。马丁全部的意识都集中在工作上。无休止地活动，脑和手，一部智能机器，使他成为人的一切，都致力于提供这种智能。他的脑子，已没有空间留给宇宙及宇宙中的重大问题了。他那宽广敞亮的心灵走廊都关上了，并且完全密封了。他灵魂的回声室变成了一个狭小的房间，一个圆锥形的塔，指挥着他的胳膊和肩膀的肌肉，他灵活的十指，以及快速移动的熨斗，大刀阔斧地沿着雾气腾腾的路线推移，就推那么几下，不多一下，每一下就推那么远，半寸也不会多推，沿着那无穷尽的袖子、衣侧、后背和后摆推移，接着把熨好的衬衣抛到承接架上，一点儿都不让它起皱。他那忙乱的灵魂将一件衬衣抛出去的时候，已经在想着第二件衬衣了。他们一直干着，一个钟头接着一个钟头，而外面的整个世界则在加利福尼亚的当头烈日之下热昏过去了。但是在这个高温房间里面没有人热昏。在阳台上凉快的客人们需要干净的衣物。 But there was little time in which to marvel.All Martin’s consciousness was concentrated in the work.Ceaselessly active, head and hand, an intelligent machine, all that constituted him a man was devoted to furnishing that intelligence.There was no room in his brain for the universe and its mighty problems.All the broad and spacious corridors of his mind were closed and hermetically sealed.The echoing chamber of his soul was a narrow room, a conning tower, whence were directed his arm and shoulder muscles, his ten nimble fingers, and the swift-moving iron along its steaming path in broad, sweeping strokes,just so many strokes and no more, just so far with each stroke and not a fraction of an inch farther, rushing along interminable sleeves, sides, backs, and tails, and tossing the finished shirts, without rumpling, upon the receiving frame.And even as his hurrying soul tossed, it was reaching for another shirt.This went on, hour after hour, while outside all the world swooned under the overhead California sun.But there was no swooning in that superheated room.The cool guests on the verandas needed clean linen.
马丁汗如雨下。他喝了大量的水，但白天天气太热，他又干得如此辛苦，喝下去的水透过肌肉间的缝隙全从毛孔里出来了。在海上时，除了少有的间隔时，他干的活通常都会给他充分的机会去思考。船老板是马丁时间的主人；但是在这儿，旅馆老板也是马丁思想的主人。除了折磨神经、摧残肉体的苦工，马丁没有思想。干活之外，不可能思考。他不知道他爱着鲁思。她甚至不存在，因为他那忙乱的灵魂没有时间记起她。只有当他夜晚爬上床时，或是早上去吃早饭时，她才在他疾驰的记忆中宣称自己的存在。 The sweat poured from Martin.He drank enormous quantities of water, but so great was the heat of the day and of his exertions, that the water sluiced through the interstices of his flesh and out at all his pores.Always, at sea, except at rare intervals, the work he performed had given him ample opportunity to commune with himself.The master of the ship had been lord of Martin’s time; but here the manager of the hotel was lord of Martin’s thoughts as well.He had no thoughts save for the nerve-racking, body-destroying toil.Outside of that it was impossible to think.He did not know that he loved Ruth.She did not even exist, for his driven soul had no time to remember her.It was only when he crawled to bed at night, or to breakfast in the morning, that she asserted herself to him in fleeting memories.
“这是个地狱，对不对？”乔有一次这样说。 “This is hell, ain’t it?” Joe remarked once.
马丁点头，但却感到一阵强烈的难受。这句话很明显，不必说。他们干活儿时不说话。说话会扰乱他们的路数，就像这次，就让马丁的熨斗少推了一下，他得多做两个动作才能回复他的路数。 Martin nodded, but felt a rasp of irritation.The statement had been obvious and unnecessary.They did not talk while they worked.Conversation threw them out of their stride, as it did this time, compelling Martin to miss a stroke of his iron and to make two extra motions before he caught his stride again.
星期五早上，洗衣机开动了。一个星期有两次，他们要清洗全旅店的织物——被单、枕套、床罩、桌布和餐巾。这项工作完成以后，他们得对付那些“花式浆洗”了。这是慢工，不能马虎，要很细致，马丁没能轻易地学到。另外，他也不能冒险。弄错了是要倒霉的。 On Friday morning the washer ran.Twice a week they had to put through hotel linen,—the sheets, pillow-slips, spreads, table-cloths, and napkins.This finished, they buckled down to “fancy starch.”It was slow work, fastidious and delicate, and Martin did not learn it so readily.Besides, he could not take chances.Mistakes were disastrous.
“看看这个，”乔说，举起一件薄膜似的紧身胸衣，他一只手就可以团在手心里。“熨焦它的话就要扣掉你二十块工钱。” “See that,” Joe said, holding up a filmy corset-cover that he could have crumpled from view in one hand.“Scorch that an’ it’s twenty dollars out of your wages.”
所以马丁没有熨焦它，他可以缓解一下紧张的肌肉，尽管神经的紧张空前高涨，他同情地听着伙伴的咒骂，他一边做工一边在为那些漂亮东西受罪，女人们穿着它却不用自己洗。“花式浆洗”是马丁的噩梦，也是乔的噩梦。正是“花式浆洗”夺去了他们辛苦节省下来的每一分钟。他们一整天都在做“花式浆洗”。晚上七点，他们又用热轧滚筒熨旅店织物。十点钟，旅店的客人已经睡了，两个洗衣工还在为“花式浆洗”流汗到半夜，到一点，到两点。直到两点半他们才收工。 So Martin did not scorch that, and eased down on his muscular tension, though nervous tension rose higher than ever, and he listened sympathetically to the other’s blasphemies as he toiled and suffered over the beautiful things that women wear when they do not have to do their own laundrying.“Fancy starch” was Martin’s nightmare, and it was Joe’s, too.It was “fancy starch” that robbed them of their hard-won minutes.They toiled at it all day.At seven in the evening they broke off to run the hotel linen through the mangle.At ten o’clock, while the hotel guests slept, the two laundrymen sweated on at “fancy starch” till midnight, till one, till two.At half-past two they knocked off.
星期六上午是“花式浆洗”和一些零碎活，下午三点这一周的工作做完了。 Saturday morning it was “fancy starch,” and odds and ends, and at three in the afternoon the week’s work was done.
“已经成这样了，你不是还要骑七十里到奥克兰吧？”乔问，当时他们坐在台阶上，吸着一口胜利的烟。 “You ain’t a-goin’ to ride them seventy miles into Oakland on top of this?”Joe demanded, as they sat on the stairs and took a triumphant smoke.
“会去。”马丁答道。 “Got to,” was the answer.
“为了什么？——一个姑娘？” “What are you goin’ for?—a girl?”
“不是，为省两块半的火车票钱。我想去图书馆改借几本书。” “No; to save two and a half on the railroad ticket.I want to renew some books at the library.”
“干吗不来回都用快递？每一趟只花两毛五。” “Why don’t you send ’em down an’ up by express?That’ll cost only a quarter each way.”
马丁考虑着。 Martin considered it.
“明天歇歇吧，”乔怂恿道，“你需要休息。我知道我也需要休息。我一点儿力气也没啦。” “An’ take a rest to-morrow,” the other urged.“You need it.I know I do.I’m plumb tuckered out.”
他看起来是这样。一整个星期，不屈不挠，永不休息地争分夺秒，挣脱了拖延，粉碎了障碍，他是一股清泉，拥有无可抵挡的力量，一部高马力的人类马达，一个工作狂，完成了一周的工作，他面临崩溃。他疲倦憔悴，英俊的脸已消瘦，满脸倦容。他无精打采地吸着烟，他的声音特别无力而单调。所有的活力和热情都消逝了。他的完工大吉仿佛是一个可悲的胜利。 He looked it.Indomitable, never resting, fighting for seconds and minutes all week, circumventing delays and crushing down obstacles, a fount of resistless energy, a high-driven human motor, a demon for work, now that he had accomplished the week’s task he was in a state of collapse.He was worn and haggard, and his handsome face drooped in lean exhaustion.He pulled his cigarette spiritlessly, and his voice was peculiarly dead and monotonous.All the snap and fire had gone out of him.His triumph seemed a sorry one.
“下周我们还得照样再干，”他痛苦地说，“这一切又有什么好呢，嘿？有时候我恨不得自己是个流浪汉。他们不干活，但也能活。哎呀！我真想有一杯啤酒；可是我打不起精神去村子里弄一杯。你呆着吧，让快递把书送回去，要不你就是他妈的一个大傻瓜。” “An’ next week we got to do it all over again,” he said sadly.“An’ what’s the good of it all, hey?Sometimes I wish I was a hobo.They don’t work, an’ they get their livin’.Gee!I wish I had a glass of beer; but I can’t get up the gumption to go down to the village an’ get it.You’ll stay over, an’ send your books down by express, or else you’re a damn fool.”
“但是礼拜日一整天叫我在这怎么过呢？”马丁问道。 “But what can I do here all day Sunday?” Martin asked.
“休息。你不知道自己有多累。哎，礼拜日我累得连报纸都没法儿看。我有一回病了——伤寒。在医院住了两个半月。那时候什么都不干。太美了。” “Rest.You don’t know how tired you are.Why, I’m that tired Sunday I can’t even read the papers.I was sick once—typhoid.In the hospital two months an’ a half.Didn’t do a tap of work all that time.It was beautiful.”
“太美了。”过了一分钟他又陶醉地重复道。 “It was beautiful,” he repeated dreamily, a minute later.
马丁洗了个澡，之后他发现那个洗衣工头不见了。马丁断定他多半是去喝酒了，但是走到村子里有半里路，对他来说是很长的一段路程。他脱了鞋子躺在床上想要拿个主意。他没有拿起书。他太累了都感觉不到困，他躺着，没有思考，累得迷迷糊糊，直到晚饭时候。晚饭时乔也没出现，马丁听到花匠说他多半是去酒吧拆柜台了时，便明白了。之后他便马上睡觉去了，到早上才确定自己好好休息了一场。乔还不在，马丁弄到了一份星期天的报纸，到树荫掩映的阴凉处找了个角落躺下了。一上午他不知怎么就过去了。他没睡，没有人打扰他，可是他没有看完那份报纸。吃过饭，下午他又回到那里，看着看着睡着了。 Martin took a bath, after which he found that the head laundryman had disappeared.Most likely he had gone for a glass of beer Martin decided, but the half-mile walk down to the village to find out seemed a long journey to him.He lay on his bed with his shoes off, trying to make up his mind.He did not reach out for a book.He was too tired to feel sleepy, and he lay, scarcely thinking, in a semi-stupor of weariness, until it was time for supper.Joe did not appear for that function, and when Martin heard the gardener remark that most likely he was ripping the slats off the bar, Martin understood.He went to bed immediately afterward, and in the morning decided that he was greatly rested.Joe being still absent, Martin procured a Sunday paper and lay down in a shady nook under the trees.The morning passed, he knew not how.He did not sleep, nobody disturbed him, and he did not finish the paper.He came back to it in the afternoon, after dinner, and fell asleep over it.
星期天就这么过去了，星期一早上他卖命地干活，分拣衣物，而乔，用一条毛巾紧紧地绑着额头，呻吟着，咒骂着，一边开动洗衣机，调着肥皂。 So passed Sunday, and Monday morning he was hard at work, sorting clothes, while Joe, a towel bound tightly around his head, with groans and blasphemies, was running the washer and mixing soft-soap.
“我就是忍耐不住，”他解释道，“一到礼拜六晚上我就得喝酒。” “I simply can’t help it,” he explained.“I got to drink when Saturday night comes around.”
又一个星期过去了，每天晚上在电灯光下都有一场苦战，直到星期六下午三点钟才结束，那时候，乔品尝着枯萎的胜利，然后便溜到村子里，忘却一切。马丁的星期天跟以前一个样子。他在树阴下睡觉，漫无目的地翻着报纸，仰面躺了几个小时，什么也不做，什么也不想。他茫然无所思，尽管他清楚自己并不高兴自己这样。他自我谴责，仿佛他已堕落，或是天性卑劣。他身上一切神圣的东西全部给抹掉了。他没了抱负；没了活力去感受它的刺激。他了无生气。他的灵魂仿佛死掉了。他是一头畜生，只会干活儿的畜生。他看不到阳光透过绿叶照进来所展现的美，那蔚蓝的天穹也不像往日一样对他低语，颤栗着揭示宇宙的广大和秘密。生活是难以忍受的沉闷和乏味，在他嘴里那味道是苦涩的。一幅黑色幕布罩住了他内心视觉的镜子，幻想躺进了一个黑暗的病房，那里没有一丝光线。他嫉妒乔，溜进村子里肆无忌惮地在酒吧里拆柜台，脑子里想入非非，伤感地思考着伤感的问题而得到乐趣，醉得一塌糊涂，辉煌灿烂，忘掉了即将到来的周一早上和一整周要命的苦工。 Another week passed, a great battle that continued under the electric lights each night and that culminated on Saturday afternoon at three o’clock, when Joe tasted his moment of wilted triumph and then drifted down to the village to forget.Martin’s Sunday was the same as before.He slept in the shade of the trees, toiled aimlessly through the newspaper, and spent long hours lying on his back, doing nothing, thinking nothing.He was too dazed to think, though he was aware that he did not like himself.He was self-repelled, as though he had undergone some degradation or was intrinsically foul.All that was god-like in him was blotted out.The spur of ambition was blunted; he had no vitality with which to feel the prod of it.He was dead.His soul seemed dead.He was a beast, a work-beast.He saw no beauty in the sunshine sifting down through the green leaves, nor did the azure vault of the sky whisper as of old and hint of cosmic vastness and secrets trembling to disclosure.Life was intolerably dull and stupid, and its taste was bad in his mouth.A black screen was drawn across his mirror of inner vision, and fancy lay in a darkened sick-room where entered no ray of light.He envied Joe, down in the village, rampant, tearing the slats off the bar, his brain gnawing with maggots, exulting in maudlin ways over maudlin things, fantastically and gloriously drunk and forgetful of Monday morning and the week of deadening toil to come.
第三周过去了，马丁厌恶自己，也厌恶生活。他被一种失败感压制着。编辑们拒绝他的稿子是有理由的。他现在已经清楚地明白了，他笑他自己和他曾做过的梦。鲁思把他的《海洋抒情诗》寄了回来。他满不在乎地读着她的信。她尽自己所能说自己多么喜欢它们，说它们是多么的美。但是她不会说谎，她不会掩饰自己真实的想法。她知道这些诗是失败之作，他从她信里每一行敷衍的，冷淡的语句中读出了她的不赞许。而她是对的。他把这些诗重读一遍之后，更坚信了这一点。美和神奇已离他而去，当他读这些诗时他不知道自己写它们时心里在想什么。他用词的大胆叫他觉得怪诞，他巧妙的措辞很可笑，一切都那么荒谬、不真实、不像话。要是他的意志力足够坚强，他早就当场把《海洋抒情诗》烧掉了。发动机房就在那里，但是费力把它们带到炉子那去，却不值得。他的所有力气都用到给别人洗衣服上面去了。他再没力气做自己的事了。 A third week went by, and Martin loathed himself, and loathed life.He was oppressed by a sense of failure.There was reason for the editors refusing his stuff.He could see that clearly now, and laugh at himself and the dreams he had dreamed.Ruth returned his “Sea Lyrics” by mail.He read her letter apathetically.She did her best to say how much she liked them and that they were beautiful.But she could not lie, and she could not disguise the truth from herself.She knew they were failures, and he read her disapproval in every perfunctory and unenthusiastic line of her letter.And she was right.He was firmly convinced of it as he read the poems over.Beauty and wonder had departed from him, and as he read the poems he caught himself puzzling as to what he had had in mind when he wrote them.His audacities of phrase struck him as grotesque, his felicities of expression were monstrosities, and everything was absurd, unreal, and impossible.He would have burned the “Sea Lyrics” on the spot, had his will been strong enough to set them aflame.There was the engine-room, but the exertion of carrying them to the furnace was not worth while.All his exertion was used in washing other persons’ clothes.He did not have any left for private affairs.
他决定等到星期天，便振作起来给鲁思回封信。但是星期六下午，干完活后，他洗了个澡，要忘却一切的愿望又淹没了他。“我看还是去走走，看看乔怎么样吧。”他这样为自己辩解，同时他也明白自己在说谎。但是他没有精力去考虑这句谎话。要是他有精力的话，他也会拒绝考虑这句谎言，因为他要忘记一切。他慢悠悠地、漫不经心地往村子里去了，当他接近那间酒吧时，便不由自主地加快了脚步。 He resolved that when Sunday came he would pull himself together and answer Ruth’s letter.But Saturday afternoon, after work was finished and he had taken a bath, the desire to forget overpowered him.“I guess I’ll go down and see how Joe’s getting on,” was the way he put it to himself; and in the same moment he knew that he lied.But he did not have the energy to consider the lie.If he had had the energy, he would have refused to consider the lie, because he wanted to forget.He started for the village slowly and casually, increasing his pace in spite of himself as he neared the saloon.
“我原以为你还在戒酒呢。”乔跟他打招呼。 “I thought you was on the water-wagon,” was Joe’s greeting.
马丁不愿找借口，但是叫了威士忌，斟满自己的酒杯之后把酒瓶递了过去。 Martin did not deign to offer excuses, but called for whiskey, filling his own glass brimming before he passed the bottle.
“别整夜喝呀。”他粗鲁地说。 “Don’t take all night about it,” he said roughly.
乔拿着酒瓶磨蹭着，马丁不等他了，举起酒杯一口喝光又倒满了。 The other was dawdling with the bottle, and Martin refused to wait for him, tossing the glass off in a gulp and refilling it.
“现在我可以等你啦，”他板着脸说，“可是你还是快点吧。” “Now, I can wait for you,” he said grimly; “but hurry up.”
乔赶快喝起来，他们一起喝着。 Joe hurried, and they drank together.
“是干活逼得吧？”乔问。 “The work did it, eh?” Joe queried.
马丁拒绝讨论这件事情。 Martin refused to discuss the matter.
“这简直是个地狱，我知道，”乔接着说，“可是我不愿意看见你开戒。来，祝你好运！” “It’s fair hell, I know,” the other went on, “but I kind of hate to see you come off the wagon, Mart.Well, here’s how!”
马丁默不作声地继续喝，咬着牙叫酒，咬着牙请人喝酒，吓坏了酒吧老板，这是一个柔弱的乡下青年，长着一双水汪汪的蓝眼睛，头发从中间分梳着。 Martin drank on silently, biting out his orders and invitations and awing the barkeeper, an effeminate country youngster with watery blue eyes and hair parted in the middle.
“他们这样役使咱们这些穷鬼做工，真是太可恶了。”乔说着，“我要是没喝酒，我准会放肆起来把洗衣房给他烧掉。我喝了酒就救了他们，我可以告诉你。” “It’s something scandalous the way they work us poor devils,” Joe was remarking.“If I didn’t bowl up, I’d break loose an’ burn down the shebang.My bowlin’ up is all that saves ’em, I can tell you that.”
但是马丁没有答话。又喝了几杯，他脑子里喝醉的蛆虫开始爬动了。啊！这才是生活，这三个星期以来他第一次感受到生活的气息。他的梦想又都回来了。幻想从漆黑的房子里出来了，引诱着他，像火焰般明亮。他幻想的镜子似银子般清澈，有如一个发光耀眼的肖像的重写本。神奇和美与他同行，手牵着手，一切力量都是他的。他想告诉乔，但是乔有他自己的幻想，一些绝对可靠的计划，他要摆脱洗衣被奴役的命运，他要成为一间大型蒸汽洗衣房的老板。 But Martin made no answer.A few more drinks, and in his brain he felt the maggots of intoxication beginning to crawl.Ah, it was living, the first breath of life he had breathed in three weeks.His dreams came back to him.Fancy came out of the darkened room and lured him on, a thing of flaming brightness.His mirror of vision was silver-clear, a flashing, dazzling palimpsest of imagery.Wonder and beauty walked with him, hand in hand, and all power was his.He tried to tell it to Joe, but Joe had visions of his own, infallible schemes whereby he would escape the slavery of laundry-work and become himself the owner of a great steam laundry.
“我要告诉你，马丁，我的洗衣房不会有童工——没有你那样苦的生活。下午六点以后绝不会有一个人做工。你听我说！要有足够的机器和足够的人手，只在适当的时间干活儿，马丁，你来帮我，我让你当洗衣房的监工——整个厂房，厂房的全部。这是我的计划。我要戒酒，攒两年钱——攒了钱就——” “I tell yeh, Mart, they won’t be no kids workin’ in my laundry—not on yer life.An’ they won’t be no workin’ a livin’ soul after six P.M.You hear me talk!They’ll be machinery enough an’ hands enough to do it all in decent workin’ hours, an’ Mart, s’help me, I’ll make yeh superintendent of the shebang—the whole of it, all of it.Now here’s the scheme.I get on the water-wagon an’ save my money for two years—save an’ then—”
但是马丁转身走开了，留下他跟酒吧老板唠叨，直到那位大人物被叫去拿酒给两位刚走进来的农夫，马丁请他们喝酒。马丁出手大方地请每个人喝，农夫们，一个马夫，旅馆花匠的帮手，酒吧老板，还有一个鬼鬼祟祟的流浪汉，他像个影子似的溜进来，又像个影子似的在酒吧柜台一头游荡。 But Martin turned away, leaving him to tell it to the barkeeper, until that worthy was called away to furnish drinks to two farmers who, coming in, accepted Martin’s invitation.Martin dispensed royal largess, inviting everybody up, farm-hands, a stableman, and the gardener’s assistant from the hotel, the barkeeper, and the furtive hobo who slid in like a shadow and like a shadow hovered at the end of the bar.
第十八章 CHAPTER XVIII
星期一早上，乔为了第一车送去洗衣房的衣服叹气。 Monday morning, Joe groaned over the first truck load of clothes to the washer.
“我说呀。”他开始说。 “I say,” he began.
“别跟我说。”马丁吼道。 “Don’t talk to me,” Martin snarled.
“对不起，乔。”中午收工吃午饭时，他说。 “I’m sorry, Joe,” he said at noon, when they knocked off for dinner.
泪水从乔眼里涌出来。 Tears came into the other’s eyes.
“没什么，老伙计，”他说，“咱们是在地狱，咱们自己也没办法。你知道，我很喜欢你。这才叫人伤心。一开头我就跟你投缘。” “That’s all right, old man,” he said.“We’re in hell, an’ we can’t help ourselves.An’, you know, I kind of like you a whole lot.That’s what made it—hurt.I cottoned to you from the first.”
马丁摇着他的手。 Martin shook his hand.
“咱们辞工吧，”乔提议道，“咱们丢下活去流浪吧。我还从没试过，可这一定很容易。而且什么事也不用干。只要想一想，啥事也不用做啊。有一回我病了，伤寒，住在医院里，太美了。我恨不得再病一场呢。” “Let’s quit,” Joe suggested.“Let’s chuck it, an’ go hoboin’.I ain’t never tried it, but it must be dead easy.An’ nothin’ to do.Just think of it, nothin’ to do.I was sick once, typhoid, in the hospital, an’ it was beautiful.I wish I’d get sick again.”
那一个星期过得很慢。旅馆住满了人，额外的“花式浆洗”尽往他们身上堆。他们创造了英勇的奇迹。每天晚上他们在电灯光下奋战到很晚，吃饭时匆匆吞下，甚至在早饭之前还要多做半个钟头的工。马丁不再洗冷水澡了。每一刻都在赶、赶、赶，乔是时间最能干的放牧人，他细心地看管着它们，从不丢掉一个，像吝啬鬼数金子一样计算着时间，他疯狂地干活，干得发了疯，他是一部狂热的机器，由另一部能干的机器辅助，这部机器以为自己曾经是个人，叫马丁·伊登。 The week dragged on.The hotel was full, and extra “fancy starch” poured in upon them.They performed prodigies of valor.They fought late each night under the electric lights, bolted their meals, and even got in a half hour’s work before breakfast.Martin no longer took his cold baths.Every moment was drive, drive, drive, and Joe was the masterful shepherd of moments, herding them carefully, never losing one, counting them over like a miser counting gold, working on in a frenzy, toil-mad, a feverish machine, aided ably by that other machine that thought of itself as once having been one Martin Eden, a man.
然而只有极少的片刻间马丁才能思考。思想的房间已关了门，连窗户都钉上了木板，他便是那影子般的看门人。他是个影子。乔是对的。他们两人都是影子，而这是对苦工的无限期拘禁。或者，这莫非是个梦？有时候，在蒸汽氤氲、热气腾腾的高热中，他手拿沉重的熨斗在那些白色衣物上来回推移时，他突然觉得这是个梦。在一段很短的时间内，也许是在一千年之后，他会醒过来，在他那个小房间里，那张有墨水污痕的桌子边，他接着前一天搁了笔的地方继续写。也许这也是个梦吧，醒过来便是交班的时候，那时他便从倾斜的水手舱的床铺上下来，走到甲板上，在热带星光之下，把着舵轮，感受着凉爽的信风吹过他的身体。 But it was only at rare moments that Martin was able to think.The house of thought was closed, its windows boarded up, and he was its shadowy caretaker.He was a shadow.Joe was right.They were both shadows, and this was the unending limbo of toil.Or was it a dream?Sometimes, in the steaming, sizzling heat, as he swung the heavy irons back and forth over the white garments, it came to him that it was a dream.In a short while, or maybe after a thousand years or so, he would awake, in his little room with the ink-stained table, and take up his writing where he had left off the day before.Or maybe that was a dream, too, and the awakening would be the changing of the watches, when he would drop down out of his bunk in the lurching forecastle and go up on deck, under the tropic stars, and take the wheel and feel the cool tradewind blowing through his flesh.
星期六还有三点钟那毫无价值的胜利一起到来。 Came Saturday and its hollow victory at three o’clock.
“我看我得下去弄杯啤酒喝喝。”乔用那种古怪单调的语气说，这表示他周末的崩溃。 “Guess I’ll go down an’ get a glass of beer,” Joe said, in the queer, monotonous tones that marked his week-end collapse.
马丁仿佛突然醒来了。他打开工具箱，给脚踏车上好油，给链子涂上石墨，调整好轴承。乔去酒吧的半路上，马丁经过他身边，他低低地俯身在车把上面，双腿有节奏地用力蹬着那九十六齿的齿轮，他的脸正迎着那七十里的路途、斜坡和尘土。那晚他在奥克兰过夜，星期天又骑了七十里回来。星期一早上，他满身疲惫地开始新一周的工作，但是他保持着清醒的状态。 Martin seemed suddenly to wake up.He opened the kit bag and oiled his wheel, putting graphite on the chain and adjusting the bearings.Joe was halfway down to the saloon when Martin passed by, bending low over the handle-bars, his legs driving the ninety-six gear with rhythmic strength, his face set for seventy miles of road and grade and dust.He slept in Oakland that night, and on Sunday covered the seventy miles back.And on Monday morning, weary, he began the new week’s work, but he had kept sober.
第五周过去了，又到第六周，这期间他像一部机器似的过活、做工，只是心里还有某些东西的一点儿火花，一点儿灵魂的微光，驱使着他，在每个周末走完那一百四十里路。但这并不是休息。像一部超级机器般，帮忙熄灭那一点点灵魂的微光，而这是他往日生活留给他仅有的东西。第七周周末，并非存心如此，而是因为太虚弱抗拒不了，他和乔一起游荡到村子里，淹没了生活，直到星期一早上才找回生活。 A fifth week passed, and a sixth, during which he lived and toiled as a machine, with just a spark of something more in him, just a glimmering bit of soul, that compelled him, at each week-end, to scorch off the hundred and forty miles.But this was not rest.It was super-machinelike, and it helped to crush out the glimmering bit of soul that was all that was left him from former life.At the end of the seventh week, without intending it, too weak to resist, he drifted down to the village with Joe and drowned life and found life until Monday morning.
周末，他又去蹬那一百四十英里路，拿更大的精力消耗带来的麻木，去消除太大的精力消耗带来的麻木。到了第三个月末，他第三次同乔去了村子里。他忘却了一切，又了活过来，既然活着，他清清楚楚地看见他把自己变成了畜生——不是因为喝酒，而是因为做工。喝酒是结果，不是原因。它不可避免地跟着苦工，就像黑夜跟着白天而来。变成做苦工的畜生是不能让他攀到高处的，这是威士忌对他的耳语，他点头称是。威士忌是聪明的。它道出了秘密。 Again, at the week-ends, he ground out the one hundred and forty miles, obliterating the numbness of too great exertion by the numbness of still greater exertion.At the end of three months he went down a third time to the village with Joe.He forgot, and lived again, and, living, he saw, in clear illumination, the beast he was making of himself—not by the drink, but by the work.The drink was an effect, not a cause.It followed inevitably upon the work, as the night follows upon the day.Not by becoming a toil-beast could he win to the heights, was the message the whiskey whispered to him, and he nodded approbation.The whiskey was wise.It told secrets on itself.
他要来了纸笔，给周围每个人都要了酒，当他们举杯祝他健康的时候，他靠着酒吧柜台潦草地写着。 He called for paper and pencil, and for drinks all around, and while they drank his very good health, he clung to the bar and scribbled.
“一封电报，乔，”他说，“念念吧。” “A telegram, Joe,” he said.“Read it.”
乔醉眼朦胧，好奇地瞄着电报。但是他看到的东西似乎使他清醒了。他用责备的眼神看着对方，眼泪从眼中涌出，流到脸上。 Joe read it with a drunken, quizzical leer.But what he read seemed to sober him.He looked at the other reproachfully, tears oozing into his eyes and down his cheeks.
“你不回来我这儿了吗，马丁？”他绝望地问道。 “You ain’t goin’ back on me, Mart?” he queried hopelessly.
马丁点点头，叫来一个游手好闲的家伙拿电报稿到电报局去。 Martin nodded, and called one of the loungers to him to take the message to the telegraph office.
“等等，”乔含糊地喃喃着，“让我想想。” “Hold on,” Joe muttered thickly.“Lemme think.”
他扶住柜台，双腿在下面摇摆着，在他思考的时候，马丁用胳膊扶住他。 He held on to the bar, his legs wobbling under him, Martin’s arm around him and supporting him, while he thought.
“改写成两个洗衣工好啦，”他突然说。“喏，让我来。” “Make that two laundrymen,” he said abruptly.“Here, lemme fix it.”
“你为什么辞工啊？”马丁问道。 “What are you quitting for?” Martin demanded.
“跟你一样的原因。” “Same reason as you.”
“可是我打算出海去。你不能做这个。” “But I’m going to sea.You can’t do that.”
“不管它，”他答道，“可我总还可以流浪去。” “Nope,” was the answer, “but I can hobo all right, all right.”
马丁彻底地打量了他一会儿，然后叫道： Martin looked at him searchingly for a moment, then cried:—
“天哪，我看你是对的！当流浪汉总比当一头做苦工的畜生好。哎，老兄，你能活下去的。而且那比你从前的生活好多了。” “By God, I think you’re right!Better a hobo than a beast of toil.Why, man, you’ll live.And that’s more than you ever did before.”
“我曾经住过医院，”乔纠正道，“太美了。伤寒——我告诉过你吗？” “I was in hospital, once,” Joe corrected.“It was beautiful.Typhoid—did I tell you?”
当马丁把电报改成“两个洗衣工”时，乔接着说： While Martin changed the telegram to “two laundrymen,” Joe went on:—
“我在医院的时候可从没想过要喝酒。好笑，是么？但是当我整个星期像奴隶一样干活时，我就想喝。留意过厨师们拼命地喝么？——还有面包师傅也一样么？都是因为做工。他们当然要去喝。哎，让我付一半的电报费吧。” “I never wanted to drink when I was in hospital.Funny, ain’t it?But when I’ve ben workin’ like a slave all week, I just got to bowl up.Ever noticed that cooks drink like hell?—an’ bakers, too?It’s the work.They’ve sure got to.Here, lemme pay half of that telegram.”
“我掷骰子来决定吧。”马丁提议道。 “I’ll shake you for it,” Martin offered.
“来吧，诸位，喝呀。”乔叫唤着，这时他们把骰子摇得哗哗响，掷在湿乎乎的柜台上。 “Come on, everybody drink,” Joe called, as they rattled the dice and rolled them out on the damp bar.
星期一早上，乔怀着期待发了狂。他不理会他胀痛的头，对他的工作也不感兴趣。整群的时间偷偷溜走了，消失了，因为他们心不在焉的放牧人正望向窗外的阳光和树木。 Monday morning Joe was wild with anticipation.He did not mind his aching head, nor did he take interest in his work.Whole herds of moments stole away and were lost while their careless shepherd gazed out of the window at the sunshine and the trees.
“只要瞧着这个！”他叫着，“全是我的！免费的。我可以躺在那些树下，睡他一千年，只要我愿意。啊，来吧，马丁，咱们不干了。多等一会儿有什么好处。外面是一个什么也不用做的地方，我弄到一张去那儿的票——可不是来回票，他娘的！” “Just look at it!” he cried.“An’ it’s all mine!It’s free.I can lie down under them trees an’ sleep for a thousan’ years if I want to.Aw, come on, Mart, let’s chuck it.What’s the good of waitin’ another moment.That’s the land of nothin’ to do out there, an’ I got a ticket for it—an’ it ain’t no return ticket, b’gosh!”
几分钟之后，在把脏衣服装满一车准备去洗的时候，乔发现了旅馆老板的衬衣。他知道上面的记号，突然荣耀地意识到自己获得的自由，他把衬衣扔到地上，用脚踩着它。 A few minutes later, filling the truck with soiled clothes for the washer, Joe spied the hotel manager’s shirt.He knew its mark, and with a sudden glorious consciousness of freedom he threw it on the floor and stamped on it.
“我恨不得你在那里头呢，你这个荷兰猪头！”他大声叫道。“在里头，就在我踩着的地方！尝尝滋味！一下！又一下！该死的！劝劝我呀，来人！劝劝我呀！” “I wish you was in it, you pig-headed Dutchman!” he shouted.“In it, an’ right there where I’ve got you!Take that!an’ that!an’ that!damn you!Hold me back, somebody!Hold me back!”
马丁大笑，拉着他去做工了。星期二晚上新来的洗衣工到了，这个星期剩下的时间都花费在指引他们走上正轨。乔坐在旁边解释他那一套系统，但是不再干活了。 Martin laughed and held him to his work.On Tuesday night the new laundrymen arrived, and the rest of the week was spent breaking them into the routine.Joe sat around and explained his system, but he did no more work.
“一点儿也不干了，”他宣布，“一点儿也不干了。要是他们乐意可以开除我，他们要这么办的话，我就走人。再没有活是我的啦，非常感谢啊。我坐火车去啦，树底下躺着去啦。干活吧，奴隶们！没错。奴隶和血汗！奴隶和血汗！等你们死了，也会跟我一样腐烂的，怎么过活又有什么关系？——呃？告诉我——到底有什么关系？” “Not a tap,” he announced.“Not a tap.They can fire me if they want to, but if they do, I’ll quit.No more work in mine, thank you kindly.Me for the freight cars an’ the shade under the trees.Go to it, you slaves!That’s right.Slave an’ sweat!Slave an’ sweat!An’ when you’re dead, you’ll rot the same as me, an’ what’s it matter how you live?—eh?Tell me that—what’s it matter in the long run?”
星期六他们领了工钱。到了分手的地方。 On Saturday they drew their pay and came to the parting of the ways.
“我要是劝你改变主意跟我一道走，也没什么用了吧？”乔绝望地问。 “They ain’t no use in me askin’ you to change your mind an’ hit the road with me?”Joe asked hopelessly.
马丁摇摇头。他站在脚踏车旁边，准备动身。他们握了握手，乔握着他的手好一会儿，说道： Martin shook his head.He was standing by his wheel, ready to start.They shook hands, and Joe held on to his for a moment, as he said:—
“我会再看见你的，马丁，在你跟我死掉之前。那是肯定的。我从骨子里这么想。再见，马丁，好好过活吧。我喜欢你喜欢得要命，你知道的。” “I’m goin’ to see you again, Mart, before you an’ me die.That’s straight dope.I feel it in my bones.Good-by, Mart, an’ be good.I like you like hell, you know.”
他一个人孤独地站在路中央，看着马丁，直到他转了一个弯，看不见了。 He stood, a forlorn figure, in the middle of the road, watching until Martin turned a bend and was gone from sight.
“他是个挺好的印第安人，那小伙子，”他喃喃着，“挺好的印第安人。” “He’s a good Indian, that boy,” he muttered.“A good Indian.”
然后他自己便慢慢地沿着大路走向水槽，那里有六七个空车厢停在侧线上等着上行的货车。 Then he plodded down the road himself, to the water tank, where half a dozen empties lay on a side-track waiting for the up freight.
第十九章 CHAPTER XIX
鲁思和她的家人又都回到家了，马丁也回到了奥克兰，能经常见到她。拿到学位以后，鲁思便不再钻研学业了；而他，已经耗尽了他全身心的活力，不再写作。这给了他们彼此更多的时间，在过去是没有的，他们的亲密感也迅速倍增。 Ruth and her family were home again, and Martin, returned to Oakland, saw much of her.Having gained her degree, she was doing no more studying; and he, having worked all vitality out of his mind and body, was doing no writing.This gave them time for each other that they had never had before, and their intimacy ripened fast.
最初，马丁什么也不做，除了休息。他睡得很多，花很长时间在沉思默想上，什么也不做。他像个从一次可怕的苦难中恢复过来的人。他复苏的最初迹象是当他发觉自己对日报不只是厌倦，还有一点儿兴趣的时候。然后他又开始阅读了——轻松的小说和诗歌；几天后他便完全投入自己荒废已久的菲斯克了。他强壮的身体和健康创造了新的活力，他有着青春的所有韧性与弹力。 At first, Martin had done nothing but rest.He had slept a great deal, and spent long hours musing and thinking and doing nothing.He was like one recovering from some terrible bout if hardship.The first signs of reawakening came when he discovered more than languid interest in the daily paper.Then he began to read again—light novels, and poetry; and after several days more he was head over heels in his long-neglected Fiske.His splendid body and health made new vitality, and he possessed all the resiliency and rebound of youth.
当他宣布他一修养好就准备再次出海的时候，鲁思明显表现出的失望。 Ruth showed her disappointment plainly when he announced that he was going to sea for another voyage as soon as he was well rested.
“你为什么要再去呢？”她问。 “Why do you want to do that?” she asked.
“为钱，”这是回答，“我要去赚一笔钱，让我能向编辑们再次进攻的钱。钱是战斗的原动力，就我而言是——钱和忍耐。” “Money,” was the answer.“I’ll have to lay in a supply for my next attack on the editors.Money is the sinews of war, in my case—money and patience.”
“可是如果你要的只是钱，你为什么不留在洗衣房呢？” “But if all you wanted was money, why didn’t you stay in the laundry?”
“因为洗衣房把我变成了一个牲口。那种工作做得太多逼得我不得不喝酒。” “Because the laundry was making a beast of me.Too much work of that sort drives to drink.”
她盯着他，眼中带着恐怖的神色。 She stared at him with horror in her eyes.
“你的意思是——”她颤声说。 “Do you mean—?” she quavered.
他要避开这个问题原是很容易的；但是他的自然冲动却要求诚实，他也记得往日不管发生什么事情也要诚实的决心。 It would have been easy for him to get out of it; but his natural impulse was for frankness, and he remembered his old resolve to be frank, no matter what happened.
“对，”他答道，“就是那样。喝了好几次。” “Yes,” he answered.“Just that.Several times.”
她颤抖着，避开了他。 She shivered and drew away from him.
“在我所认识的人中没有人这样做——从没这样做过。” “No man that I have ever known did that—ever did that.”
“那么他们也从没在谢利温泉馆的洗衣房里干过活。”他苦笑着。“苦活是一件好事。它对于人类的健康是必要的，正如所有牧师所说，老天也知道我从没害怕过劳动。可是世上却有好过头的事，那儿的洗衣房就是其中一种。这就是我为什么要再出海一趟。我想这会是我最后的一次了，因为当我回来的时候，我就要打进文坛了。这一点我是有把握的。” “Then they never worked in the laundry at Shelly Hot Springs,” he laughed bitterly.“Toil is a good thing.It is necessary for human health, so all the preachers say, and Heaven knows I’ve never been afraid of it.But there is such a thing as too much of a good thing, and the laundry up there is one of them.And that’s why I’m going to sea one more voyage.It will be my last, I think, for when I come back, I shall break into the magazines.I am certain of it.”
她沉默了，不表同情，他闷闷不乐地望着她，知道要她理解他所经历过的生活是多么不可能。 She was silent, unsympathetic, and he watched her moodily, realizing how impossible it was for her to understand what he had been through.
