“早晚我要把它写出来——《苦干使人堕落》或是《工人阶层酗酒的心理研究》，或是诸如此类的题目。” “Some day I shall write it up—@The Degradation of Toil@ or the @Psychology of Drink in the Working-class@， or something like that for a title.”
自从他们第一次见面以来，他们之间的距离从没有像那天那样远。他直率的坦白带着反抗精神，使她反感。但是比起令她反感的原因，她更为这反感的情绪所震惊。这表明她离他有多近，一旦接受，它便为他们进一步的亲密铺平了道路。怜悯之情也被唤起，还有天真的理想化的改造思想。她要挽救这位离他很远的原生态的年轻人。她要把他从早期环境的诅咒中拯救出来，不管他愿不愿意她也要拯救他。影响她的这一切像是一种极高贵的意识；她做梦也没想过藏在这背后和下面的是对爱情的嫉妒和渴求。 Never, since the first meeting, had they seemed so far apart as that day.His confession, told in frankness, with the spirit of revolt behind, had repelled her.But she was more shocked by the repulsion itself than by the cause of it.It pointed out to her how near she had drawn to him, and once accepted, it paved the way for greater intimacy.Pity, too, was aroused, and innocent, idealistic thoughts of reform.She would save this raw young man who had come so far.She would save him from the curse of his early environment, and she would save him from himself in spite of himself.And all this affected her as a very noble state of consciousness; nor did she dream that behind it and underlying it were the jealousy and desire of love.
他们经常在那秋色宜人的日子里骑着脚踏车外出，他们在山上高声朗诵诗歌，时而他读，时而她读，高雅而令人振奋的诗歌把人的思想引向更高处。克己、牺牲、忍耐、勤恳和刻苦上进是她间接向他宣扬的原则——这些抽象的品格在她心里都体现在她父亲和巴特勒先生身上，还有安德鲁·卡内基，他从一个贫穷的移民男孩发展成为一位世界闻名的著作者。这一切都为马丁所欣赏和受用。现在，他越加清楚地理解她的心理过程了，她的灵魂不再像过去那样是一个封闭的奇迹了。他跟她在知识上是平等的。但是意见不同并不能影响他对她的爱。他的爱比从前更炽烈，因为他爱的就是她这个人，甚至她身体的娇弱在他眼里也是一种魅力。他读过病弱的伊丽莎白·巴雷特的故事，许多年来，她的双脚都不曾沾过地面，直到那光辉的一天，当她和布朗宁私奔的时候，她笔直地站在地上，站在空旷的天空下；布朗宁为她所做的，马丁确定自己也能为鲁思做。但是首先，她必须爱他。剩下的就容易了。他会给她力量和健康。他瞥见了他们的生活，在未来的日子里，以工作、舒适和普遍的优裕生活为背景，他看见自己和鲁思诵读并讨论着诗歌，她靠在地上一大推垫子中间，给他大声朗读者。这便是他们未来生活的基调。他常常看见那一幅特别的图景。有时候是她依偎着他，而他在朗读，一只胳膊搂着她，她的头靠在他肩上。有时候，他们又一起沉浸于那些印在书页上美丽篇章。跟着，她也热爱自然，凭着丰富的想象力他改变了他们读书的场景——有时候他们在峭壁环绕、与世隔绝的山谷中读书，或是在高山上的草地上，或是又来到灰白的沙丘附近，他们的脚下是一圈滚滚的波涛，或是在遥远的热带火山岛上，那里瀑布奔流而下，成了一片迷蒙的雾，像一幅幅随风飘动的烟云般的雾纱，直垂到海里。 They rode on their wheels much in the delightful fall weather, and out in the hills they read poetry aloud, now one and now the other, noble, uplifting poetry that turned one’s thoughts to higher things.Renunciation, sacrifice, patience, industry, and high endeavor were the principles she thus indirectly preached—such abstractions being objectified in her mind by her father, and Mr. Butler, and by Andrew Carnegie, who, from a poor immigrant boy had arisen to be the book-giver of the world.All of which was appreciated and enjoyed by Martin.He followed her mental processes more clearly now, and her soul was no longer the sealed wonder it had been.He was on terms of intellectual equality with her.But the points of disagreement did not affect his love.His love was more ardent than ever, for he loved her for what she was, and even her physical frailty was an added charm in his eyes.He read of sickly Elizabeth Barrett, who for years had not placed her feet upon the ground, until that day of flame when she eloped with Browning and stood upright, upon the earth, under the open sky; and what Browning had done for her, Martin decided he could do for Ruth.But first, she must love him.The rest would be easy.He would give her strength and health.And he caught glimpses of their life, in the years to come, wherein, against a background of work and comfort and general well-being, he saw himself and Ruth reading and discussing poetry, she propped amid a multitude of cushions on the ground while she read aloud to him.This was the key to the life they would live.And always he saw that particular picture.Sometimes it was she who leaned against him while he read, one arm about her, her head upon his shoulder.Sometimes they pored together over the printed pages of beauty.Then, too, she loved nature, and with generous imagination he changed the scene of their reading—sometimes they read in closed-in valleys with precipitous walls, or in high mountain meadows,and, again, down by the gray sand-dunes with a wreath of billows at their feet, or afar on some volcanic tropic isle where waterfalls descended and became mist, reaching the sea in vapor veils that swayed and shivered to every vagrant wisp of wind.
但在前景中的常常是美的主人，他和鲁思，永远在诵读着，分享着，而在大自然这个背景之外的总是一个朦胧模糊的背景，其中有工作、成功和赚得的钱，这使他们摆脱全世界和世上的宝藏获得自由。 But always, in the foreground, lords of beauty and eternally reading and sharing, lay he and Ruth, and always in the background that was beyond the background of nature, dim and hazy, were work and success and money earned that made them free of the world and all its treasures.
“我应该提醒我的小女儿当心一点啦。”有一天，她的母亲警告她。 “I should recommend my little girl to be careful,” her mother warned her one day.
“我知道你指的是什么。但那是不能的。他不是——” “I know what you mean.But it is impossible.He is; not—”
鲁思脸红了，但这是少女的羞红，当她第一次跟一个母亲谈论人生中神圣的事情时，她的母亲也同样持着神圣的态度。 Ruth was blushing, but it was the blush of maidenhood called upon for the first time to discuss the sacred things of life with a mother held equally sacred.
“与你般配的人。”她的母亲替她说完了那句话。 “Your kind.”Her mother finished the sentence for her.
鲁思点点头。 Ruth nodded.
“我是不想说的，但是他确实不是。他粗鲁、野蛮、强壮——太强壮了。他没有——” “I did not want to say it, but he is not.He is rough, brutal, strong—too strong.He has not—”
她迟疑着，说不下去了。跟母亲谈这样的事情，是一种新体验。她的母亲再次替她补充了她的想法。 She hesitated and could not go on.It was a new experience, talking over such matters with her mother.And again her mother completed her thought for her.
“你想说的是，他过着不干净的生活。” “He has not lived a clean life, is what you wanted to say.”
鲁思又点点头，她又满脸绯红。 Again Ruth nodded, and again a blush mantled her face.
“是这样的，”她说，“这不是他的错，但他太过——” “It is just that,” she said.“It has not been his fault, but he has played much with—”
“高调？” “With pitch?”
“是的，很高调。他吓着我了。有时候我确实很怕他，当他以那种轻松自由的方式谈论他做过的事情——好像没关系似的。其实是有关系的，不是吗？” “Yes, with pitch.And he frightens me.Sometimes I am positively in terror of him, when he talks in that free and easy way of the things he has done—as if they did not matter.They do matter, don’t they?”
她们手挽着手坐着，在谈话间歇的时候，母亲拍拍她的手，等着她说下去。 They sat with their arms twined around each other, and in the pause her mother patted her hand and waited for her to go on.
“可我对他非常感兴趣，”她接着说，“可以说，他是我的弟子。然而，他也是我的第一个男朋友——但严格来说又不是朋友；是弟子和朋友的结合体吧。有时候，当他吓到我的时候，他又似乎是我——像一些‘兄弟会’里的女孩——养着玩的一只牛头狗，猛拉着链子，龇着牙，威胁着要挣脱链子。” “But I am interested in him dreadfully,” she continued.“In a way he is my protégé.Then, too, he is my first boy friend—but not exactly friend; rather protégé and friend combined.Sometimes, too, when he frightens me, it seems that he is a bulldog I have taken for a plaything, like some of the ‘frat’ girls, and he is tugging hard, and showing his teeth, and threatening to break loose.”
她母亲又等着她说下去。 Again her mother waited.
“他吸引着我，我想，就像那只牛头狗。他也有很多长处；可是他身上有不少我不喜欢的东西——从另一方面看。你瞧，我一直在思索。他说粗话、吸烟、喝酒、用拳头打架（他这么告诉过我，他喜欢这个；他是这么说的）。他的所为全是一个男人不当为的——一个我愿意他做我的——”她的声音放得很低——“丈夫的男人。再说，他太强壮了。我的王子应该是高挑的、颀长的、微黑的——一位优雅迷人的王子。不，我不会冒险爱上马丁·伊登。那会是我最坏的命运。” “He interests me, I suppose, like the bulldog.And there is much good in him, too; but there is much in him that I would not like in—in the other way.You see, I have been thinking.He swears, he smokes, he drinks, he has fought with his fists (he has told me so, and he likes it; he says so).He is all that a man should not be—a man I would want for my—” her voice sank very low—“husband.Then he is too strong.My prince must be tall, and slender, and dark—a graceful, bewitching prince.No, there is no danger of my failing in love with Martin Eden.It would be the worst fate that could befall me.”
“可那并不是我谈到的事情，”她的母亲含糊地说，“你有没有考虑过他呢？他在各方面都是这么不合适，你知道，但假如他爱上你呢？” “But it is not that that I spoke about,” her mother equivocated.“Have you thought about him?He is so ineligible in every way, you know, and suppose he should come to love you?”
“但是他确实——已经爱上了。”她叫道。 “But he does—already,” she cried.
“这是在意料之中的，”莫尔斯太太轻轻地说，“如果是一个了解你的人呢？” “It was to be expected,” Mrs. Morse said gently.“How could it be otherwise with any one who knew you?”
“奥尔尼讨厌我！”她激动地叫道。 “Olney hates me!” she exclaimed passionately.
“我也讨厌奥尔尼。但他在身边的时候我就感觉那像是一只猫。我感觉他一定讨厌我，即使我没这么感觉，他在我看来，无论如何也是可恶的。但是和马丁·伊登在一起我很快乐。以前没有人曾爱过我——我的意思是，没有一个男人那样爱我。被人那样爱着是很甜蜜的。你知道我是什么意思吧，亲爱的妈妈。发觉你已是一个真真正正的女人，我很愉快。”她把脸伏到母亲的膝上，抽咽着。“你觉得我很可怕，我知道，但是我是诚实的，我怎么想的便怎么告诉你。” “And I hate Olney.I feel always like a cat when he is around.I feel that I must be nasty to him, and even when I don’t happen to feel that way, why, he’s nasty to me, anyway.But I am happy with Martin Eden.No one ever loved me before—no man, I mean, in that way.And it is sweet to be loved—that way.You know what I mean, mother dear.It is sweet to feel that you are really and truly a woman.”She buried her face in her mother’s lap, sobbing.“You think I am dreadful, I know, but I am honest, and I tell you just how I feel.”
不可思议的是，莫尔斯太太悲喜交加。她的女儿，那个文学学士的女孩儿不见了；代替她的是一个成年的女儿。实验已经成功了。鲁思本性中那个出奇的空洞已经被填满，没有带来危险或惩罚。这位粗鲁的海员成了一件工具，尽管鲁思不爱他，但他使她意识到自己的女人的情怀。 Mrs. Morse was strangely sad and happy.Her child-daughter, who was a bachelor of arts, was gone; but in her place was a woman-daughter.The experiment had succeeded.The strange void in Ruth’s nature had been filled, and filled without danger or penalty.This rough sailor-fellow had been the instrument, and, though Ruth did not love him, he had made her conscious of her womanhood.
“他的手在颤抖，”鲁思承认，她的脸因为害羞仍然伏在母亲膝上。“这是最有趣最滑稽的，但是我也为他感到难过。而当他的手抖得太厉害，眼睛闪着太强的光时，哎，我便开导他，关于他的人生，关于他想要改进的错误方法。然而他是崇拜我的，我知道。他的眼睛和双手是不会撒谎的。这叫我觉得自己已经成长起来了，一想到这个，只要一想到这个；而且我觉得我拥有了理应属于我的东西——那使我像其他女孩儿们——以及——以及其他年轻女人们一样。我也知道以前我和她们不一样，我知道这让你担心了。你以为你没有让我知道你的烦恼，但是我却明白，我还要——‘做好’，像马丁·伊登所说的那样。” “His hand trembles,” Ruth was confessing, her face, for shame’s sake, still buried.“It is most amusing and ridiculous, but I feel sorry for him, too.And when his hands are too trembly, and his eyes too shiny, why, I lecture him about his life and the wrong way he is going about it to mend it.But he worships me, I know.His eyes and his hands do not lie.And it makes me feel grown-up, the thought of it, the very thought of it; and I feel that I am possessed of something that is by rights my own—that makes me like the other girls—and—and young women.And, then, too, I knew that I was not like them before, and I knew that it worried you.You thought you did not let me know that dear worry of yours, but I did, and I wanted to—‘to make good,’ as Martin Eden says.”
这对母亲和女儿来说是神圣的时刻。她们在暮色中交谈的时候，眼睛都湿润了，鲁思天真无邪，坦率真诚，她的母亲心怀同情，善于接纳，却也冷静地解释并引导着。 It was a holy hour for mother and daughter, and their eyes were wet as they talked on in the twilight, Ruth all white innocence and frankness, her mother sympathetic, receptive, yet calmly explaining and guiding.
“他比你年轻四岁呢，”她说，“他在社会上没有地位。他既没职业也没薪金。他是不切实际的。爱上了你，凭常识来说，他应该做点什么事以让他有结婚的权利，而不是到处卖弄他那些小说，做着幼稚的梦。马丁·伊登，我恐怕他永远不会成熟。他并不负起责任来，在这世上去做一个男人应做的工作，像你父亲，或是我们所有的朋友那样，巴特勒先生便是其中一个。马丁·伊登，我担心他永远不会成为一个会赚钱的人。然而这个世界如此安排，金钱对于幸福是必要的——噢，不，并不是指大量的财产，但是要有足够的金钱，才可以过得舒适体面。他——他从没和你说过吗？” “He is four years younger than you,” she said.“He has no place in the world.He has neither position nor salary.He is impractical.Loving you, he should, in the name of common sense, be doing something that would give him the right to marry, instead of paltering around with those stories of his and with childish dreams.Martin Eden, I am afraid, will never grow up.He does not take to responsibility and a man’s work in the world like your father did, or like all our friends, Mr. Butler for one.Martin Eden, I am afraid, will never be a money-earner.And this world is so ordered that money is necessary to happiness—oh, no, not these swollen fortunes, but enough of money to permit of common comfort and decency.He—he has never spoken?”
“他半个字也没提过。他没有打算过；即使他有打算，我也不会让他这么做的，因为，你知道的，我并不爱他。” “He has not breathed a word.He has not attempted to; but if he did, I would not let him, because, you see, I do not love him.”
“这叫我高兴。我当然不愿看见我的女儿，我唯一的女儿，如此干净纯洁的女儿，去爱一个像他那样的人。世上有的是高贵的男人，干净、真诚、阳刚的男人。等待他们吧。总有一天你会遇到这样一个人的，而且你会爱上他，也会被他爱着，你和他在一起会很幸福，就像你父亲和我彼此都幸福一样。有一点你必须时常记在心里——” “I am glad of that.I should not care to see my daughter, my one daughter, who is so clean and pure, love a man like him.There are noble men in the world who are clean and true and manly.Wait for them.You will find one some day, and you will love him and be loved by him, and you will be happy with him as your father and I have been happy with each other.And there is one thing you must always carry in mind—”
“好的，妈妈。” “Yes, mother.”
莫尔斯太太的声音低沉而悦耳地说道：“那就是小孩子。” Mrs. Morse’s voice was low and sweet as she said, “And that is the children.”
“我——已经考虑过孩子的问题，”鲁思承认道，一面回忆起过去烦扰她的那些放肆的想法，因为得谈论这些事情，她的脸又泛起了少女的羞红。 “I—have thought about them,” Ruth confessed, remembering the wanton thoughts that had vexed her in the past, her face again red with maiden shame that she should be telling such things.
“就是因为孩子，马丁·伊登就不可能，”莫尔斯太太一针见血地接下去。“他们的血统应当洁净，而他，依我看来，并不洁净。你父亲曾经告诉过我海员们的生活，而——而你是懂得的。” “And it is that, the children, that makes Mr. Eden impossible,” Mrs. Morse went on incisively.“Their heritage must be clean, and he is, I am afraid, not clean.Your father has told me of sailors’ lives, and—and you understand.”
鲁思捏着母亲的手表示同意，她觉得自己的确了解，尽管她的观念中只是一些模糊遥远的、可怕的、超乎她想象的东西。 Ruth pressed her mother’s hand in assent, feeling that she really did understand, though her conception was of something vague, remote, and terrible that was beyond the scope of imagination.
“你知道我做什么事都会告诉你的，”她开始说，“——只是，有时候你得问我，就像这次一样。我曾想过要告诉你，可我不知道怎么说。这是一种错误的谦逊，我知道的，可你问我的话，我就容易开口。有时候，像这次一样，你得问我，你得给我一个机会。” “You know I do nothing without telling you,” she began.“—Only, sometimes you must ask me, like this time.I wanted to tell you, but I did not know how.It is false modesty, I know it is that, but you can make it easy for me.Sometimes, like this time, you must ask me, you must give me a chance.”
“啊，妈妈，你也是女人！”她们站起来的时候，她欣喜地叫道，拉着母亲的手，站得笔直，在暮色中面对着她，意识到她们之间是一种妙不可言的平等关系。 “Why, mother, you are a woman, too!” she cried exultantly, as they stood up, catching her mother’s hands and standing erect, facing her in the twilight, conscious of a strangely sweet equality between them.
“要不是我们的这番谈话，我是不会这样看你的。我得知道我是个女人，才知道你也是个女人。” “I should never have thought of you in that way if we had not had this talk.I had to learn that I was a woman to know that you were one, too.”
“我们都是女人，”她母亲说，把她拉到怀里亲吻她。“我们都是女人。”她们走出屋子时，她又说了一遍，她们用胳膊互相搂着腰，她们的心里洋溢着一种新的伙伴之情。 “We are women together,” her mother said, drawing her to her and kissing her.“We are women together,” she repeated, as they went out of the room, their arms around each other’s waists, their hearts swelling with a new sense of companionship.
“我们的小女孩已经长成一个女人了。”一个钟头后，莫尔斯太太骄傲地跟她丈夫说。 “Our little girl has become a woman,” Mrs. Morse said proudly to her husband an hour later.
“这是说，”注视了妻子好一会儿，他说，“这是说，她在谈恋爱了。” “That means,” he said, after a long look at his wife, “that means she is in love.”
“不，不过她是被爱着了，”这是一个含笑的回答，“实验已经成功了。她终于觉醒了。” “No, but that she is loved,” was the smiling rejoinder.“The experiment has succeeded.She is awakened at last.”
“那么我们就得摆脱他。”莫尔斯先生以一种实事求是、公事公办的口吻斩钉截铁地说。 “Then we’ll have to get rid of him.” Mr. Morse spoke briskly, in matter-of-fact, businesslike tones.
但他的太太摇摇头。“不必这样。鲁思说他几天后就要去出海了。他回来的时候，她已经不在这儿了。我们要将她送到克拉拉姑母家去。再说，在东部住上一年，气候、人、想法和一切东西都会变，这正是她所需要的。” But his wife shook her head.“It will not be necessary.Ruth says he is going to sea in a few days.When he comes back, she will not be here.We will send her to Aunt Clara’s.And, besides, a year in the East, with the change in climate, people, ideas, and everything, is just the thing she needs.”
第二十章 CHAPTER XX
写作的欲望又在马丁心里活跃起来。在他的脑中，小说和诗歌正自发地蹦向创作之途，他要把它们记下，以便将来把它们写出来。但是他没有写。这是他的一次小小的假期，他早已决定把它用于休息和爱情，而在这两方面他都进行得很顺利。他很快便活力洋溢，每天都去见鲁思，见面的时候，她又体验到了他往日那种气魄与健康的冲击。 The desire to write was stirring in Martin once more.Stories and poems were springing into spontaneous creation in his brain, and he made notes of them against the future time when he would give them expression.But he did not write.This was his little vacation; he had resolved to devote it to rest and love, and in both matters he prospered.He was soon spilling over with vitality, and each day he saw Ruth, at the moment of meeting, she experienced the old shock of his strength and health.
“当心啊，”她的母亲又一次警告她，“我担心你跟马丁·伊登见面次数太多。” “Be careful,” her mother warned her once again.“I am afraid you are seeing too much of Martin Eden.”
但是鲁思很有把握地笑了。她对自己是有把握的，几天后他就会出海去。然后，等他回来的时候，她已远游到东部去了。然而，马丁的气魄和健康有着一种魔力。他也早被告知她打算到东部旅行的事，他觉得需要加紧了。但他不知道怎么跟鲁思这样的女孩儿谈情说爱。而且，由于他有着与那些跟她绝不相同的女孩和女人交往的丰富经验，对他也不利。她们懂得爱情，懂得生活和卖弄风情，而她对于这些却一点儿都不懂。她惊人的天真使他震惊，冻结着他嘴边一切热烈的言辞，使他不由自主地深信自己的卑微。另一点对他也不利。他以前从未恋爱过。在他过去的浮华日子里，他是喜欢过女人的，也为其中几个着迷过，但是他不知道爱她们意味着什么。他以一种傲慢的、满不在乎的方式吹一声口哨，她们就来到他身边。她们是消遣物，是附属品，是男人们游戏的一部分，充其量也只是一小部分而已。而现在，他第一次成了一个温柔胆怯且不自信的追求者。他不懂得怎样爱，也不懂得怎样表达，只是心惊胆战，因为他所爱的人是那样天真无邪。 But Ruth laughed from security.She was sure of herself, and in a few days he would be off to sea.Then, by the time he returned, she would be away on her visit East.There was a magic, however, in the strength and health of Martin.He, too, had been told of her contemplated Eastern trip, and he felt the need for haste.Yet he did not know how to make love to a girl like Ruth.Then, too, he was handicapped by the possession of a great fund of experience with girls and women who had been absolutely different from her.They had known about love and life and flirtation, while she knew nothing about such things.Her prodigious innocence appalled him, freezing on his lips all ardors of speech, and convincing him, in spite of himself, of his own unworthiness.Also he was handicapped in another way.He had himself never been in love before.He had liked women in that turgid past of his, and been fascinated by some of them, but he had not known what it was to love them.He had whistled in a masterful, careless way, and they had come to him.They had been diversions, incidents, part of the game men play, but a small part at most.And now, and for the first time, he was a suppliant, tender and timid and doubting.He did not know the way of love, nor its speech, while he was frightened at his loved one’s clear innocence.
在认识这个变化多端的世界的过程中，在永远变化着的局面中急转着，他学到了一条行为准则，大致是：玩新游戏时，一定要让对方先动手。这已经使他占据有利地位一千次了，同时也把他训练成了一个观察者。他懂得怎样观察新事物，等待有一个弱点暴露，有一个入口出现。这就像在斗拳时找个突破口进攻一样。当这么一个突破口出现的时候，凭借长期的经验，他懂得抓住它并且尽力一搏。 In the course of getting acquainted with a varied world, whirling on through the ever changing phases of it, he had learned a rule of conduct which was to the effect that when one played a strange game, he should let the other fellow play first.This had stood him in good stead a thousand times and trained him as an observer as well.He knew how to watch the thing that was strange, and to wait for a weakness, for a place of entrance, to divulge itself.It was like sparring for an opening in fist-fighting.And when such an opening came, he knew by long experience to play for it and to play hard.
因此，他便等待着鲁思，观察着她，想吐露他的爱意却又不敢。他怕吓到她，他对自己也没把握。若是他知道的话，他对她这条路倒是走对了。爱情在表达清楚之前已来到世界上，在少年时期它已学会了自己永不能忘的各种方法与手段。正是以这种古老原始的方法，马丁向鲁思求爱了。开头，他并不知道自己在干这么一回事，后来他明白了。他的手触到她的手比他能说出的任何话语都有力得多，他的气魄对她想象力的冲击比任何书本上的诗歌和千万代情人所说的情话都诱人。凡是他的舌头所能表达的，也许能部分地引起她的兴趣；但是手的接触，那短暂的接触，却能直达她的本能。她的判断力和她一样年轻，但是她的本能却和她的种族一样老成，甚至更老成。当爱情年轻的时候，它们也曾是年轻的，而它们比习俗、观念和一切新生的东西都高明。因此，她的判断力没有起作用。没有必要使用它，马丁不时地唤起她的恋爱本能，而她却没有意识到它的威力。另一方面，他爱她，就像白天一样明白，她有意识地乐于看到他向她表露爱意——闪着温柔光芒的眼睛，颤动的双手，和那晒黑的皮肤下常常暗暗涌现的红潮。她甚至更近了一步，羞怯地挑逗着他，但做得很巧妙，因此他从不曾有过怀疑，又做得在有意无意间，连她也很少怀疑过自己。这些证明了她的力量，宣布她成为了一个女人，这使她激动不已，她折磨他，戏弄他，从中感受到夏娃般的快乐。 So he waited with Ruth and watched, desiring to speak his love but not daring.He was afraid of shocking her, and he was not sure of himself.Had he but known it, he was following the right course with her.Love came into the world before articulate speech, and in its own early youth it had learned ways and means that it had never forgotten.It was in this old, primitive way that Martin wooed Ruth.He did not know he was doing it at first, though later he divined it.The touch of his hand on hers was vastly more potent than any word he could utter, the impact of his strength on her imagination was more alluring than the printed poems and spoken passions of a thousand generations of lovers.Whatever his tongue could express would have appealed, in part, to her judgment; but the touch of hand, the fleeting contact, made its way directly to her instinct.Her judgment was as young as she, but her instincts were as old as the race and older.They had been young when love was young, and they were wiser than convention and opinion and all the new-born things.So her judgment did not act.There was no call upon it, and she did not realize the strength of the appeal Martin made from moment to moment to her love-nature.That he loved her, on the other hand, was as clear as day, and she consciously delighted in beholding his love-manifestations—the glowing eyes with their tender lights, the trembling hands, and the never failing swarthy flush that flooded darkly under his sunburn.She even went farther, in a timid way inciting him, but doing it so delicately that he never suspected, and doing it half-consciously, so that she scarcely suspected herself.She thrilled with these proofs of her power that proclaimed her a woman, and she took an Eve-like delight in tormenting him and playing upon him.
由于缺乏经验，也因为过于热情，马丁说不出话来，他接着用碰触的方法不知不觉地笨拙地求爱。碰到他的手，她是快乐的，甚至比快乐更怡人。马丁不知道这一点，但他知道她并不反感。不是说除了见面和分别时他们的手常有接触；可是在推脚踏车时，在把那些要带到山上的诗集捆到车上时，在肩并肩品读那些书籍时，他们的手也有机会碰触。而且在他们俯身欣赏书中的佳句时，也有这样的机会，她的发丝拂着他的面颊，肩头碰着肩头。想到那不知从哪儿来的无端的冲动暗示她想要揉乱他的头发，她便暗自笑了；而他则非常渴望，在两人读书读累的时候，把头枕在她的膝上，闭着双眼想象属于他们的未来。过去，在谢尔芒德公园和舒特逊公园周日野餐的时候，他的头曾枕过许多女人的膝，通常，他任性地熟睡了，而那些女孩子为他遮阳，俯身看着他，爱抚他，想知道他为什么那样傲慢地忽视她们对他的爱。把头枕在一个女孩子膝上是世上最容易办到的事情，而现在，现在他发现鲁思的膝头无法接近，也不可能枕到。然而他的谨慎，正是他的追求的力量所在。正是因为谨慎，他从未吓到鲁思。尽管由于她的挑剔和胆怯，她却从未意识到两人交往的危险倾向。她不自不觉地微微向他靠近，越发接近，而他感觉到这日益增加的亲近，渴望冒一次险却又担心。 Tongue-tied by inexperience and by excess of ardor, wooing unwittingly and awkwardly, Martin continued his approach by contact.The touch of his hand was pleasant to her, and something deliciously more than pleasant.Martin did not know it, but he did know that it was not distasteful to her.Not that they touched hands often, save at meeting and parting; but that in handling the bicycles, in strapping on the books of verse they carried into the hills, and in conning the pages of books side by side, there were opportunities for hand to stray against hand.And there were opportunities, too, for her hair to brush his cheek, and for shoulder to touch shoulder, as they leaned together over the beauty of the books.She smiled to herself at vagrant impulses which arose from nowhere and suggested that she rumple his hair; while he desired greatly, when they tired of reading, to rest his head in her lap and dream with closed eyes about the future that was to be theirs.On Sunday picnics at Shellmound Park and Schuetzen Park, in the past, he had rested his head on many laps, and, usually, he had slept soundly and selfishly while the girls shaded his face from the sun and looked down and loved him and wondered at his lordly carelessness of their love.To rest his head in a girl’s lap had been the easiest thing in the world until now, and now he found Ruth’s lap inaccessible and impossible.Yet it was right here, in his reticence, that the strength of his wooing lay.It was because of this reticence that he never alarmed her.Herself fastidious and timid, she never awakened to the perilous trend of their intercourse.Subtly and unaware she grew toward him and closer to him, while he, sensing the growing closeness, longed to dare but was afraid.
有一次他冒险了，一天下午，当他发现她在昏暗的起居室里头痛得厉害的时候。 Once he dared, one afternoon, when he found her in the darkened living room with a blinding headache.
“什么办法都不起作用，”她回答了他的询问，“而且我连头痛粉也不能吃。霍尔医生不让我吃。” “Nothing can do it any good,” she had answered his inquiries.“And besides, I don’t take headache powders.Doctor Hall won’t permit me.”
“我想我能治你的病，而且不用药，”马丁答道，“当然，我也不一定有把握，可我想试试看。只不过是按摩。我开头是从日本人那学到这玩意儿的。你知道他们是一个按摩师人种。之后我又学过一次，从夏威夷人那里，有点儿不一样。他们把它叫做‘罗密——罗密’。它能治药物能治的病，也能治一些药物不能治的病。” “I can cure it, I think, and without drugs,” was Martin’s answer.“I am not sure, of course, but I’d like to try.It’s simply massage.I learned the trick first from the Japanese.They are a race of masseurs, you know.Then I learned it all over again with variations from the Hawaiians.They call it lomi-lomi.It can accomplish most of the things drugs accomplish and a few things that drugs can’t.”
他的手刚刚触到她的头，她就深深地叹了一口气。 Scarcely had his hands touched her head when she sighed deeply.
“感觉很好。”她说。 “That is so good,” she said.
半个小时后，她又说话了，问道：“你不累吗？” She spoke once again, half an hour later, when she asked, “Aren’t you tired?”
这一问只不过是敷衍，她知道答案是什么。跟着，她便昏昏欲睡了，一面默想着他使人舒服的镇痛力量。生命从他指尖流出，驱赶着病痛，或者，至少她这样觉得，直到疼痛有所缓和，她睡着了，他悄悄溜了出去。 The question was perfunctory, and she knew what the answer would be.Then she lost herself in drowsy contemplation of the soothing balm of his strength: Life poured from the ends of his fingers, driving the pain before it, or so it seemed to her, until with the easement of pain, she fell asleep and he stole away.
那天傍晚，她打电话给他，向他道谢。 She called him up by telephone that evening to thank him.
“我一直睡到吃晚饭，”她说，“你完全治好我啦，伊登先生，我不知道该怎么感谢你呢。” “I slept until dinner,” she said.“You cured me completely, Mr. Eden, and I don’t know how to thank you.”
他回应她时，觉得很温暖，语无伦次，十分欢喜，在整个通话中，他的心里一直跳跃着关于布朗宁和体弱的伊丽莎白·巴雷特的记忆。做过的事情可以再做一遍的，他，马丁·伊登，能做而且愿意为鲁思·莫尔斯做。他回到自己的屋子，去读那本翻开放在床上的斯宾塞的《社会学》去了。但是他读不下去。爱情折磨着他，征服了他的意志，纵使他早抱有决心，他发觉自己坐在那张墨迹斑斑的小桌旁。他那晚写成的十四行诗是他五十首爱情诗组的第一首，这部爱情诗组是他用两个月时间完成的。他在写作的时候，心里想着《葡萄牙人的十四行情诗》，他是在产生伟大作品的最佳情况下，也是在生活的重大关头，在他甜蜜的为爱疯狂的痛楚之中写作的。 He was warm, and bungling of speech, and very happy, as he replied to her, and there was dancing in his mind, throughout the telephone conversation, the memory of Browning and of sickly Elizabeth Barrett.What had been done could be done again, and he, Martin Eden, could do it and would do it for Ruth Morse.He went back to his room and to the volume of Spencer’s “@Sociology@” lying open on the bed.But he could not read.Love tormented him and overrode his will, so that, despite all determination, he found himself at the little ink-stained table.The sonnet he composed that night was the first of a love-cycle of fifty sonnets which was completed within two months.He had the “Love-sonnets from the Portuguese” in mind as he wrote, and he wrote under the best conditions for great work, at a climacteric of living, in the throes of his own sweet love-madness.
没有跟鲁思在一起的许多时间，他在写《爱情组诗》，在家读书，或是到公共阅览室去，在那里，他深入地接触当下的流行杂志以及它们的方针和内容的性质。和鲁思在一起的时光令他恼火，因为他拥有希望，却得不到结果。这是他治好她的头痛一星期之后的事，诺曼提出到梅里特湖做一次月夜航行，阿瑟和奥尔尼都赞同。马丁是唯一一个会驾船的人，他不得不帮忙。在船尾，鲁思坐在他旁边，那三个年轻人则在中舱聊天，正为联谊会的事争论不已。 The many hours he was not with Ruth he devoted to the “Love-cycle,” to reading at home, or to the public reading-rooms, where he got more closely in touch with the magazines of the day and the nature of their policy and content.The hours he spent with Ruth were maddening alike in promise and in inconclusiveness.It was a week after he cured her headache that a moonlight sail on Lake Merritt was proposed by Norman and seconded by Arthur and Olney.Martin was the only one capable of handling a boat, and he was pressed into service.Ruth sat near him in the stern, while the three young fellows lounged amidships, deep in a wordy wrangle over “frat” affairs.
月亮还未升起，鲁思凝望着星光灿烂的天空，也没有和马丁交谈，突然有一种孤独之感。她瞟了他一眼。一阵风吹来，船倾斜了，直至甲板被水打湿，他，一手把定舵杆，一手操纵主帆，使船头轻轻向风行驶，同时凝视着前方，想找出已在不远的北岸。他没有察觉到她的注视，她专注地看着她，思量着是什么样的奇怪而扭曲的灵魂在牵引着他，使他这样一个拥有显著能力的青年把时间浪费在写小说和诗歌上面，而这注定会归于平庸和失败。 The moon had not yet risen, and Ruth, gazing into the starry vault of the sky and exchanging no speech with Martin, experienced a sudden feeling of loneliness.She glanced at him.A puff of wind was heeling the boat over till the deck was awash, and he, one hand on tiller and the other on main-sheet, was luffing slightly, at the same time peering ahead to make out the near-lying north shore.He was unaware of her gaze, and she watched him intently, speculating fancifully about the strange warp of soul that led him, a young man with signal powers, to fritter away his time on the writing of stories and poems foredoomed to mediocrity and failure.
她的目光流连在他那在星光下朦胧可见的结实的喉头，溜到他那挺立的头颅上，往日想把手放在他脖子上的欲望又回来了。她所厌恶的力量吸引着她。她的孤独感越加明显，她感到疲倦了。她在那倾斜的船上的座位叫她烦恼，她记起了他为她治好的头痛病，还有他带给她的舒服的休息。他就坐在她旁边，挨着她，那船似乎要让她靠到他身上。于是，她心里涌起了要依偎着他的冲动，想让自己靠着他的力量休息一下——一种模糊的、半成形的冲动，她还在考虑当中便已经左右着她，使她向他靠了过去。或者这是由于船的倾斜吧？她不知道。她永远都不知道。她只知道她依偎着他，这种舒服与安适是很惬意的。也许是船的过错吧，但是她并没有设法恢复原状。她轻轻地靠着他的肩膀，但是当他挪动了身体让她靠得舒服点的时候，她依然靠着，继续靠着。 Her eyes wandered along the strong throat, dimly seen in the starlight, and over the firm-poised head, and the old desire to lay her hands upon his neck came back to her.The strength she abhorred attracted her.Her feeling of loneliness became more pronounced, and she felt tired.Her position on the heeling boat irked her, and she remembered the headache he had cured and the soothing rest that resided in him.He was sitting beside her, quite beside her, and the boat seemed to tilt her toward him.Then arose in her the impulse to lean against him, to rest herself against his strength—a vague, half-formed impulse, which, even as she considered it, mastered her and made her lean toward him.Or was it the heeling of the boat?She did not know.She never knew.She knew only that she was leaning against him and that the easement and soothing rest were very good.Perhaps it had been the boat’s fault, but she made no effort to retrieve it.She leaned lightly against his shoulder, but she leaned, and she continued to lean when he shifted his position to make it more comfortable for her.
这是一种疯狂的行为，但是她拒绝去想这疯狂的行为。她不再是她自己，只是一个女人，女人需要依靠；尽管她这么轻轻地靠着，她的需要也仿佛满足了。她不再疲倦。马丁没有说话。若是他说了，魔力就会消失。不过他对爱情的谨慎延长了它。他晕晕忽忽的。他不明白正在发生着的这一切。这太妙了，只能算是精神错乱。他克服了一个疯狂的欲望，放开帆索和舵柄拥她入怀。他的直觉告诉他这是不该做的事，他很庆幸帆索和舵柄使他的手不得空，抗拒了那个诱惑。然而他已不那么巧妙地使船头顺风行驶了，不顾脸面地让风从帆边漏过去，以延长船驶向北岸的航程。一到北岸就得掉转船头，身体的接触便会分开。他巧妙地驶着船，延阻船的行进，而没有引起那些争论者的注意，在心里原谅了他过去那些艰难的航行，正是它们使这奇妙的一晚成为可能，它们给了他控制海洋、船和风的本领，这样他才能让她坐在身边，让她那可爱的身体靠在他肩上。 It was a madness, but she refused to consider the madness.She was no longer herself but a woman, with a woman’s clinging need; and though she leaned ever so lightly, the need seemed satisfied.She was no longer tired.Martin did not speak.Had he, the spell would have been broken.But his reticence of love prolonged it.He was dazed and dizzy.He could not understand what was happening.It was too wonderful to be anything but a delirium.He conquered a mad desire to let go sheet and tiller and to clasp her in his arms.His intuition told him it was the wrong thing to do, and he was glad that sheet and tiller kept his hands occupied and fended off temptation.But he luffed the boat less delicately, spilling the wind shamelessly from the sail so as to prolong the tack to the north shore.The shore would compel him to go about, and the contact would be broken.He sailed with skill, stopping way on the boat without exciting the notice of the wranglers, and mentally forgiving his hardest voyages in that they had made this marvellous night possible, giving him mastery over sea and boat and wind so that he could sail with her beside him, her dear weight against him on his shoulder.
当初升的月亮的第一道光芒射到帆上，以珍珠般的光辉照耀着全船的时候，鲁思便离开他了。甚至在她挪动之际，她感觉到他也在挪开。避免被人发觉的心情是一样的。这段插曲是默默地、暗地里的亲密。她离开他坐着，脸颊发烧，而全部矜持的力量又回来了。她做了一件不愿为她的兄弟们或是奥尔尼看见的错事。那她为什么这么做呢？她这一辈子从没做过这样的事，尽管她以前也曾和年轻男人们一起月夜航行。她从未想过要做这样的事情。她感到万分羞愧，为自己萌动中的女人心事所左右着。她偷瞟了马丁一眼，他正在忙着让船驶上另一条航线，她该恨他，为了他使她做出了一件丢人又可耻的事。而他，所有男人中就他一个！也许她母亲是对的，她是见他见得太多了。她决定，这样的事再也不会发生了，以后她要少见他。她还抱着一个不切实际的想法，打算到他们单独在一起的时候，便向他解释，对他撒个谎，随意提一下，说是在月亮升起之前她突然感到头晕。接着，她又记起了月亮露脸之前，他们两个怎样各自挪开，她知道他会明白那是句谎话。 When the first light of the rising moon touched the sail, illuminating the boat with pearly radiance, Ruth moved away from him.And, even as she moved, she felt him move away.The impulse to avoid detection was mutual.The episode was tacitly and secretly intimate.She sat apart from him with burning cheeks, while the full force of it came home to her.She had been guilty of something she would not have her brothers see, nor Olney see.Why had she done it?She had never done anything like it in her life, and yet she had been moonlight-sailing with young men before.She had never desired to do anything like it.She was overcome with shame and with the mystery of her own burgeoning womanhood.She stole a glance at Martin, who was busy putting the boat about on the other tack, and she could have hated him for having made her do an immodest and shameful thing.And he, of all men!Perhaps her mother was right, and she was seeing too much of him.It would never happen again, she resolved, and she would see less of him in the future.She entertained a wild idea of explaining to him the first time they were alone together, of lying to him, of mentioning casually the attack of faintness that had overpowered her just before the moon came up.Then she remembered how they had drawn mutually away before the revealing moon, and she knew he would know it for a lie.
在随后飞奔而来的日子里，她不再是她自己了，却成了一个陌生的、莫名其妙的人，任性地判断，不屑于自我分析，拒绝看向未来或是考虑自己，也不管自己正飘向哪里。令人困惑的神秘使她狂热，她时而害怕时而陶醉，堕入了永恒的困惑之中。但有一个想法根深蒂固，保证了她的安全。她不会让马丁说出他的爱。只要她做到这一点，一切都会不成问题。几天后他就会出海去了。即使他说出来了，一切也还是不成问题。不会有万一，因为她不爱他。当然，他会有半小时的痛苦，而她则会有半小时的尴尬，因为这会是她第一次面对求婚。想到这个，她甜蜜地颤抖。有一个成熟的男人向她求婚，她成了一个真真正正的女人了。这对于构成她性别的基础的东西是个诱惑。一切构成她的生命和她这个人的结构，都在颤动，战栗起来了。这个念头在她心里扑腾着，有如一只为火光所吸引的飞蛾。她甚至于想到马丁的求婚，还替他想好了他要说的话；她还预演了自己如何拒绝他，她要用好意使它显得不那么生硬，还要劝告他做一个真正的高贵的男子汉。特别是他必须戒烟。她会特别强调这一点。但是不可以，她一定不能让他说出来。她会阻止他，她跟母亲说过她会的。两颊烧得通红，她遗憾地打发走了这个求婚场面。她第一次面对求婚应该推迟至一个较适当的时间和一个更有资格的求婚者。 In the days that swiftly followed she was no longer herself but a strange, puzzling creature, wilful over judgment and scornful of self-analysis, refusing to peer into the future or to think about herself and whither she was drifting.She was in a fever of tingling mystery, alternately frightened and charmed, and in constant bewilderment.She had one idea firmly fixed, however, which insured her security.She would not let Martin speak his love.As long as she did this, all would be well.In a few days he would be off to sea.And even if he did speak, all would be well.It could not be otherwise, for she did not love him.Of course, it would be a painful half hour for him, and an embarrassing half hour for her, because it would be her first proposal.She thrilled deliciously at the thought.She was really a woman, with a man ripe to ask for her in marriage.It was a lure to all that was fundamental in her sex.The fabric of her life, of all that constituted her, quivered and grew tremulous.The thought fluttered in her mind like a flame-attracted moth.She went so far as to imagine Martin proposing, herself putting the words into his mouth; and she rehearsed her refusal, tempering it with kindness and exhorting him to true and noble manhood.And especially he must stop smoking cigarettes.She would make a point of that.But no, she must not let him speak at all.She could stop him, and she had told her mother that she would.All flushed and burning, she regretfully dismissed the conjured situation.Her first proposal would have to be deferred to a more propitious time and a more eligible suitor.
第二十一章 CHAPTER XXI
一个美丽的秋日到来了，在季节变迁的那种寂静里它显得温暖、慵懒而又悸动不安。在加利福尼亚的小阳春里，太阳带着朦胧的光圈，丝丝微风轻轻拂过，未惊起沉睡的空气。群山深处藏着层层紫色的薄雾，那不是水汽而是色彩编成的织物。圣弗朗西斯科置于其中，就如高地上一团迷蒙的烟雾。夹在中间的海湾映出熔化金属般的凝重光泽，水上的帆船或是静静停着或是随着懒洋洋的波浪飘荡。远处的塔马尔帕斯山在银色的雾霭中几乎无法看清，它巍峨地耸立在金门旁边。金门在西沉的斜阳下披着一层淡淡的金色。更远处是苍茫广阔的太平洋，水天相接之处升起大团翻滚的云朵，它们向岸边横扫过来，预示着第一阵狂风呼啸的冬日气息。 Came a beautiful fall day, warm and languid, palpitant with the hush of the changing season, a California Indian summer day, with hazy sun and wandering wisps of breeze that did not stir the slumber of the air.Filmy purple mists, that were not vapors but fabrics woven of color, hid in the recesses of the hills.San Francisco lay like a blur of smoke upon her heights.The intervening bay was a dull sheen of molten metal, whereon sailing craft lay motionless or drifted with the lazy tide.Far Tamalpais, barely seen in the silver haze, bulked hugely by the Golden Gate, the latter a pale gold pathway under the westering sun.Beyond, the Pacific, dim and vast, was raising on its sky-line tumbled cloud-masses that swept landward, giving warning of the first blustering breath of winter.
夏天即将被抹去。但夏天又徘徊着，在群山间慢慢消退慢慢衰弱；它把山谷的紫色染得更深，并用日益衰微之力和逐渐消退的狂喜纺出一层雾霭；它已经活过，而且活得很精彩，因此它是怀着平静的满足死去的。在群山之间，在他们最喜欢的小丘上，马丁和鲁思肩并肩坐着，他们的脑袋靠向同一本书的书页。他大声读着那个爱过布朗宁的女子写的十四行情诗，那样的爱没有几个人得到过。 The erasure of summer was at hand.Yet summer lingered, fading and fainting among her hills, deepening the purple of her valleys, spinning a shroud of haze from waning powers and sated raptures, dying with the calm content of having lived and lived well.And among the hills, on their favorite knoll, Martin and Ruth sat side by side, their heads bent over the same pages, he reading aloud from the love-sonnets of the woman who had loved Browning as it is given to few men to be loved.
但那朗读渐渐变得没精打采了。环绕着他们的那种即将消逝的美有着太大的魔力。这幸福的一年活得像一个美丽而毫无悔意的放荡之人，现在它也正如此地逝去，空气里满载着回忆里的那些狂喜和满足。它进入了他们的体内，恍惚如梦，慵懒倦怠，削弱坚毅的品质，给道德或理性盖上了一层朦胧的紫色雾霭。马丁满怀柔情，股股暖流一次次涌遍全身。他的脑袋跟她的靠得很近，当那些游荡着的风之精灵将她的头发拨起并触到他的脸庞时，那书页便在他的眼前浮动起来。 But the reading languished.The spell of passing beauty all about them was too strong.The golden year was dying as it had lived, a beautiful and unrepentant voluptuary, and reminiscent rapture and content freighted heavily the air.It entered into them, dreamy and languorous, weakening the fibres of resolution, suffusing the face of morality, or of judgment, with haze and purple mist.Martin felt tender and melting, and from time to time warm glows passed over him.His head was very near to hers, and when wandering phantoms of breeze stirred her hair so that it touched his face, the printed pages swam before his eyes.
“我觉得你一个字都没读进去。”她说。那一次他连读到哪儿都不知道了。 “I don’t believe you know a word of what you are reading,” she said once when he had lost his place.
他用激情燃烧的眼神看着她，正要露出窘态，此时却想到了一句反驳的话。 He looked at her with burning eyes, and was on the verge of becoming awkward, when a retort came to his lips.
“我觉得你也没懂。上一首十四行诗是关于什么的呀？” “I don’t believe you know either.What was the last sonnet about?”
“我不知道，”她率真地笑起来，“我已经忘了。我们别读了吧。这天气太美了。” “I don’t know,” she laughed frankly.“I’ve already forgotten.Don’t let us read any more.The day is too beautiful.”
“这将是我们近期内最后一次到山里来了，”他神色凝重地宣布，“海面上正酝酿着一场风暴。” “It will be our last in the hills for some time,” he announced gravely.“There’s a storm gathering out there on the sea-rim.”
书本从他的手中滑下来掉在地上，他们悠然坐着，静默无声，眺望那边梦幻般的港湾，那是他们的眼睛梦见的而不是看见的。鲁思斜斜瞥了一眼他的脖子。她没有向他靠过去。她是被自身以外的某种力量牵过去的，这种力量比地心引力还强大，如命运一样强大。靠过去只需一英寸而已，她没有考虑就完成了这个动作。她的肩膀碰到了他的肩膀，轻轻地，仿佛一只蝴蝶点着一朵花，他也是那么轻轻地挨着她。她感到他的肩膀靠着自己的，他全身穿过一阵激灵。那是她该抽回身来的时候了。但是她已经变得像机器人一样了。她的动作已经不受她自己意识的控制——一股美妙的疯狂主宰了她，她完全没有想到要控制，也不会去控制。他的手臂偷偷地伸到她背后揽住了她。她在痛苦的欢乐之中等待它缓缓前行。她等待着，也不知道等的是什么，呼吸急促，嘴唇又干又烫，脉搏跳动强烈，一股期待的狂热充斥在她全身的血液中。搂着她的那支手臂抬高了些，将她拉向他去，慢慢地充满爱抚地将她拥了过去。她再也等不下去了。她疲倦地叹了口气，完全出于她自己的一种冲动，未经思考，如痉挛一般，她把自己的头靠在他的胸上。他迅速低下头来，当他的嘴唇靠过来时，她的嘴唇飞快地迎了上去。 The book slipped from his hands to the ground, and they sat idly and silently, gazing out over the dreamy bay with eyes that dreamed and did not see.Ruth glanced sidewise at his neck.She did not lean toward him.She was drawn by some force outside of herself and stronger than gravitation, strong as destiny.It was only an inch to lean, and it was accomplished without volition on her part.Her shoulder touched his as lightly as a butterfly touches a flower, and just as lightly was the counter-pressure.She felt his shoulder press hers, and a tremor run through him.Then was the time for her to draw back.But she had become an automaton.Her actions had passed beyond the control of her will—she never thought of control or will in the delicious madness that was upon her.His arm began to steal behind her and around her.She waited its slow progress in a torment of delight.She waited, she knew not for what, panting, with dry, burning lips, a leaping pulse, and a fever of expectancy in all her blood.The girdling arm lifted higher and drew her toward him, drew her slowly and caressingly.She could wait no longer.With a tired sigh, and with an impulsive movement all her own, unpremeditated, spasmodic, she rested her head upon his breast.His head bent over swiftly, and, as his lips approached, hers flew to meet them.
这一定就是爱情，在赋予她的那片刻理性里，她想。如果这不是爱情，那就太可耻了。这只能是爱情了。她爱这个手臂搂着她、嘴唇吻着她的男人。她依偎着他，身子缩了缩，向他靠得更近了。过了一会儿，她从他的怀里半挣脱出来，突然欢跃地伸出手去，把两只手都放在了马丁·伊登被太阳晒黑的脖子上。爱情和欲望得到满足的痛是如此剧烈，她不禁发出一阵轻微的呻吟，松开了手，半昏迷地躺在他的怀里。 This must be love, she thought, in the one rational moment that was vouchsafed her.If it was not love, it was too shameful.It could be nothing else than love.She loved the man whose arms were around her and whose lips were pressed to hers.She pressed more, tightly to him, with a snuggling movement of her body.And a moment later, tearing herself half out of his embrace, suddenly and exultantly she reached up and placed both hands upon Martin Eden’s sunburnt neck.So exquisite was the pang of love and desire fulfilled that she uttered a low moan, relaxed her hands, and lay half-swooning in his arms.
他们一个字也没说，很久都没说一个字。他两次俯下身去吻她，每次她的嘴唇都会羞涩地迎上去，而她的身体则会欢乐地向他挨靠。她紧紧和他相拥，无法使自己放开。他坐着，双臂半托住她，凝望着那个跨越海湾的巨大城市，但眼睛看不清东西，只是一片模糊。有那么一会儿，他的脑海里什么也没有。只有色彩、光线和股股脉动的暖流，正如这天气一般温暖，正如他的爱情一般热烈。他俯身向她。她正在说话。 Not a word had been spoken, and not a word was spoken for a long time.Twice he bent and kissed her, and each time her lips met his shyly and her body made its happy, nestling movement.She clung to him, unable to release herself, and he sat, half supporting her in his arms, as he gazed with unseeing eyes at the blur of the great city across the bay.For once there were no visions in his brain.Only colors and lights and glows pulsed there, warm as the day and warm as his love.He bent over her.She was speaking.
“你是从什么时候爱上我的？”她轻轻地问。 “When did you love me?” she whispered.
“从一开始，从最一开始，从我看到你的那第一刻。那时我因对你的爱而疯狂，那以后的所有时间里我只有爱得更加疯狂。此刻，我最为疯狂，亲爱的。我几乎成了一个疯子，快乐得忘乎所以。” “From the first, the very first, the first moment I laid eye on you.I was mad for love of you then, and in all the time that has passed since then I have only grown the madder.I am maddest, now, dear.I am almost a lunatic, my head is so turned with joy.”
“我真高兴我是个女人，马丁——亲爱的。”她长长地叹了口气说。 “I am glad I am a woman, Martin—dear,” she said, after a long sigh.
他一次次将她紧紧拥抱，又问： He crushed her in his arms again and again, and then asked:—
“那你呢？你最初是从什么时候知道的呢？ “And you?When did you first know?”
“啊，我一直都知道，几乎从一开始就知道。” “Oh, I knew it all the time, almost, from the first.”
“我一直以来都像蝙蝠一样盲目！”他叫起来，话音里透出一股懊恼。 “And I have been as blind as a bat!” he cried, a ring of vexation in his voice.
“我从来都没有如此梦想过，直到刚才，直到我吻了你。” “I never dreamed it until just how, when I—when I kissed you.”
“我不是这个意思。”她把身体部分地抽了回来，望着他。“我是说我知道你几乎从一开始就爱上了。” “I didn’t mean that.”She drew herself partly away and looked at him.“I meant I knew you loved almost from the first.”
“那你呢？”他问。 “And you?” he demanded.
“我是突然发现的。”她慢慢地说起来，眼睛暖暖的，扑闪着，柔情满溢，淡淡的红晕爬上她的脸颊，不肯散去。“我从来没有意识到，直到刚才你用手臂搂住我的那一刻。我也从来没有想过要和你结婚，马丁，直到刚才。你是怎么让我爱上你的？” “It came to me suddenly.”She was speaking very slowly, her eyes warm and fluttery and melting, a soft flush on her cheeks that did not go away.“I never knew until just now when—you put your arms around me.And I never expected to marry you, Martin, not until just now.How did you make me love you?”
“我不知道，”他大笑起来，“就是通过爱你吧，我爱你爱得那么努力，石头做的心也都能融化了，更不用说如你这般一个活生生的女人的心。” “I don’t know,” he laughed, “unless just by loving you, for I loved you hard enough to melt the heart of a stone, much less the heart of the living, breathing woman you are.”
“这和我想象的爱情是如此不同。”她说了一句不相关的。 “This is so different from what I thought love would be,” she announced irrelevantly.
“你原以为爱情会是怎样的呢？” “What did you think it would be like?”
“我原以为爱情不会像这样。”那一刻她直视着他的眼睛，但当她继续说下去的时候，又垂下了眼睑：“你看，我原来并不知道爱情会是怎样的。” “I didn’t think it would be like this.”She was looking into his eyes at the moment, but her own dropped as she continued, “You see, I didn’t know what this was like.”
他主动要将她再一次拽到自己怀里，但仅仅是环着她的那只手臂试探性地动了一下，因为他担心自己太贪心。接着，他感到她的身体屈服了，她被又一次紧紧搂在他怀里，一对嘴唇贴上了另一对嘴唇。 He offered to draw her toward him again, but it was no more than a tentative muscular movement of the girdling arm, for he feared that he might be greedy.Then he felt her body yielding, and once again she was close in his arms and lips were pressed on lips.
“我的家人会说什么呢？”在一次停顿中她问道，带着突然而来的忧虑。 “What will my people say?” she queried, with sudden apprehension, in one of the pauses.
“我不知道。不管什么时候，如果我们想知道就很容易就能找到答案。” “I don’t know.We can find out very easily any time we are so minded.”
“但如果妈妈反对呢？我肯定自己不敢告诉她。” “But if mamma objects?I am sure I am afraid to tell her.”
“让我也来告诉她。”他勇敢地主动提议，“我想你妈妈不喜欢我，但我会让她回心转意的。一个能赢得你芳心的人能赢得任何事物。如果我们不能——” “Let me tell her,” he volunteered valiantly.“I think your mother does not like me, but I can win her around.A fellow who can win you can win anything.And if we don’t—”
“嗯？” “Yes?”
“有什么关系，我们还有彼此呢。不过，要让你妈妈赞成我们结婚也没什么难的。她太爱你了。” “Why, we’ll have each other.But there’s no danger not winning your mother to our marriage.She loves you too well.”
“我真不想让她伤心。”鲁思忧伤地说。 “I should not like to break her heart,” Ruth said pensively.
他想向她保证母亲们的心并不是那么容易就会被伤到，可说出来的却是：“爱情是世界上最伟大的。” He felt like assuring her that mothers’ hearts were not so easily broken, but instead he said, “And love is the greatest thing in the world.”
“你知道吗，马丁，你有时候叫我害怕。我现在就感到很害怕，当我想到你，想到你一直以来是怎样一个人。你对我一定要非常非常好。要记住，我毕竟只是个孩子。我之前从没恋爱过。” “Do you know, Martin, you sometimes frighten me.I am frightened now, when I think of you and of what you have been.You must be very, very good to me.Remember, after all, that I am only a child.I never loved before.”
“我也没有。我们在一起都是孩子。我们比大多数人都幸运，因为我们都是彼此的初恋。” “Nor I.We are both children together.And we are fortunate above most, for we have found our first love in each other.”
“但那怎么可能！”她叫起来，激动地迅速从他怀里抽出身来。 “But that is impossible!” she cried, withdrawing herself from his arms with a swift, passionate movement.
“对你来说不可能啊。你当过水手，我听说水手是——是——” “Impossible for you.You have been a sailor, and sailors, I have heard, are—are—”
她说话犹豫起来，渐渐没了声音。 Her voice faltered and died away.
“着迷于在每个港口娶一个妻子？”他提示说，“你想说的是这个吗？” “Are addicted to having a wife in every port?” he suggested.“Is that what you mean?”
“是的。”她小声回答。 “Yes,” she answered in a low voice.
“可那不是爱情，”他用权威的口吻说，“我去过很多港口，但我从来连和爱情的短暂接触都没有过，直到第一次遇见你的那个晚上。你知道吗，当我说了晚安并离开之后，我差点被抓起来了。” “But that is not love.” he spoke authoritatively.“I have been in many ports, but I never knew a passing touch of love until I saw you that first night.Do you know, when I said good night and went away, I was almost arrested.”
“抓起来？” “Arrested?”
“是的。警察以为我喝醉了，我也觉得自己醉了——迷醉于对你的爱。” “Yes.The policeman thought I was drunk; and I was, too—with love for you.”
“可是你刚说我们是孩子，我说对你而言这不可能。我们已经脱离正题了。” “But you said we were children, and I said it was impossible, for you, and we have strayed away from the point.”
“我说了，除了你我没爱上过任何人，”他回答，“你是我的初恋，我独一无二的初恋。” “I said that I never loved anybody but you,” he replied.“You are my first, my very first.”
“然而，你当过水手。”她反驳道。 “And yet you have been a sailor,” she objected.
“但那并没有阻止我第一个就爱上你。” “But that doesn’t prevent me from loving you the first.”
“那就是你有过女人——别的女人——噢！” “And there have been women—other women—oh!”
让马丁·伊登感到无比惊奇的是，她突然大哭起来，好一番亲吻和爱抚才止住她的眼泪。在这一段时间里，他的脑中一直出现吉卜林的诗句：“上校夫人和朱迪·格雷迪骨子里是姐妹。”这话没错，他想，尽管他读过的那些小说让他相信别的说法。那些小说造就了他这样的观点，就是在上层社会力只有正式的求婚才行得通。而在他所来自的那个下层社会，小伙子们和姑娘们通过身体接触来赢得对方，这是完全可以的；但对于上流社会的高雅人士而言，用类似的方式求爱简直不可想象。然而，那些小说是错误的。这里就有一个证据。那些对劳动阶层的姑娘很有效的无声的亲吻和爱抚，对劳动阶层之上的姑娘一样有效。她们都是一样的血肉，骨子里终归是姐妹。如果他记得起斯宾塞的诗，他或许也能对自己有这样的认识。当他把鲁思搂在怀里抚慰她时，想着上校夫人和朱迪·格雷迪在骨子里是极其相似的，并从中得到了慰藉。这想法将鲁思带得离他更近了，使她变得可以企及。她珍贵的玉体和任何人的躯体是一样的，也和他的一样。他们的婚姻没有什么阻碍。阶级的不同是唯一的不同，而阶级又是外在的。它是可以摆脱的。他曾经读到过一个奴隶崛起为一个穿紫袍的罗马皇帝。既然那样都可以，那么他也可以上升到鲁思的阶层。在她的纯洁、神圣和文雅之下，以及那美丽超凡的灵魂之外，就人类的基本方面，她就跟莉齐·康诺利一样，跟所有莉齐·康诺利之类的姑娘一样。一切对她们而言可能的事物，对鲁思也是可能的。她能爱，能恨，或许也会歇斯底里；她当然也会嫉妒，正如她现在就是在嫉妒，在他的怀里发出她最后几声抽泣。 And to Martin Eden’s supreme surprise, she burst into a storm of tears that took more kisses than one and many caresses to drive away.And all the while there was running through his head Kipling’s line: “And the Colonel’s lady and Judy O’Grady are sisters under their skins.”It was true, he decided; though the novels he had read had led him to believe otherwise.His idea, for which the novels were responsible, had been that only formal proposals obtained in the upper classes.It was all right enough, down whence he had come, for youths and maidens to win each other by contact; but for the exalted personages up above on the heights to make love in similar fashion had seemed unthinkable.Yet the novels were wrong.Here was a proof of it.The same pressures and caresses, unaccompanied by speech, that were efficacious with the girls of the working-class, were equally efficacious with the girls above the working-class.They were all of the same flesh, after all, sisters under their skins; and he might have known as much himself had he remembered his Spencer.As he held Ruth in his arms and soothed her, he took great consolation in the thought that the Colonel’s lady and Judy O’Grady were pretty much alike under their skins.It brought Ruth closer to him, made her possible.Her dear flesh was as anybody’s flesh, as his flesh.There was no bar to their marriage.Class difference was the only difference, and class was extrinsic.It could be shaken off.A slave, he had read, had risen to the Roman purple.That being so, then he could rise to Ruth.Under her purity, and saintliness, and culture, and ethereal beauty of soul, she was, in things fundamentally human, just like Lizzie Connolly and all Lizzie Connollys.All that was possible of them was possible of her.She could love, and hate, maybe have hysterics; and she could certainly be jealous, as she was jealous now, uttering her last sobs in his arms.
“再说，我比你年龄大，大三岁。”她突然说，同时睁大了她的眼睛抬头看着他。 “Besides, I am older than you,” she remarked suddenly, opening her eyes and looking up at him, “three years older.”
“别闹了，你还只是个孩童，我比你大四十岁呢，就经验上来说。”他回应道。 “Hush, you are only a child, and I am forty years older than you, in experience,” was his answer.
事实上，当从爱情方面来说的话，他们在一起就跟孩子一样，在对爱的表达上他们就如两个孩子一般天真、稚气，尽管在实际上她接受过充分的大学教育，而他的脑子里则充满了理性的哲学和生活的现实经验。 In truth, they were children together, so far as love was concerned, and they were as naive and immature in the expression of their love as a pair of children, and this despite the fact that she was crammed with a university education and that his head was full of scientific philosophy and the hard facts of life.
他们一直坐着过完了这美好而短暂的一天。他们像所有恋人一样说着说不完的话，诧异于爱情的美妙，惊叹将他们抛到一起的命运是多么神奇，并武断地认为他们相爱的程度以前从没有恋人达到过。他们坚持一次又一次地回过头去倾诉他们对彼此的第一印象，并做着毫无希望的尝试，要去准确分析他们对彼此的感觉以及这感觉有多么强烈。 They sat on through the passing glory of the day, talking as lovers are prone to talk, marvelling at the wonder of love and at destiny that had flung them so strangely together, and dogmatically believing that they loved to a degree never attained by lovers before.And they returned insistently, again and again, to a rehearsal of their first impressions of each other and to hopeless attempts to analyze just precisely what they felt for each other and how much there was of it.
大团的云朵在西边的地平线上迎接下沉的夕阳，天际变成了玫瑰色，而顶空也发出同样温暖的光芒。玫瑰色的光芒照遍他们全身，将他们淹没，那时她唱起：“再见，甜蜜的日子。”她轻柔地歌唱，依偎在他的怀里。她的手捧在他的手里，他们的心也捧在彼此的手里。 The cloud-masses on the western horizon received the descending sun, and the circle of the sky turned to rose, while the zenith glowed with the same warm color.The rosy light was all about them, flooding over them, as she sang, “Good-by, Sweet Day.”She sang softly, leaning in the cradle of his arm, her hands in his, their hearts in each other’s hands.
第二十二章 CHAPTER XXII
当鲁思回来的时候，莫尔斯太太无需凭借一个母亲的直觉就读懂了鲁思脸上显示的一切。她脸颊上久不散去的红晕说出了这个简单的故事，她那双明亮的大眼睛就表达得更清楚了，里头映射出她内心无可置疑的喜悦之情。 Mrs. Morse did not require a mother’s intuition to read the advertisement in Ruth’s face when she returned home.The flush that would not leave the cheeks told the simple story, and more eloquently did the eyes, large and bright, reflecting an unmistakable inward glory.
“发生什么事了？”直到鲁思上床睡觉，莫尔斯太太才找到机会问。 “What has happened?” Mrs. Morse asked, having bided her time till Ruth had gone to bed.
“你知道了？”鲁思问，嘴唇在颤抖。 “You know?”Ruth queried, with trembling lips.
作为回答，她的母亲伸出一只胳膊搂住了她，一只手轻轻地抚摸着她的头发。 For reply, her mother’s arm went around her, and a hand was softly caressing her hair.
“他没有提出来。”她突然说。“我并不想让它发生，我也决不会让他提出来——只不过他没有提出来。” “He did not speak,” she blurted out.“I did not intend that it should happen, and I would never have let him speak—only he didn’t speak.”
“但他若没有提出来，那就不可能有什么事发生了，对吗？” “But if he did not speak, then nothing could have happened, could it?”
“但事情确实发生了，照样还是发生了。” “But it did, just the same.”
“天哪，孩子，你在叽里咕噜说些什么呀？”莫尔斯太太完全糊涂了。“我想我还不明白到底发生了什么。发生什么了？” “In the name of goodness, child, what are you babbling about?”Mrs. Morse was bewildered.“I don’t think I know what happened, after all.What did happen?”
鲁思惊讶地看着她母亲。 Ruth looked at her mother in surprise.
“我以为你知道了呢。哎，我们订婚了，马丁和我。” “I thought you knew.Why, we’re engaged, Martin and I.”
莫尔斯太太带着怀疑和懊恼，大笑起来。 Mrs. Morse laughed with incredulous vexation.
“没有，他没提。”鲁思解释道。“他只是爱着我，仅此而已。我跟你一样惊讶。他一个字也没有说。他只是用胳膊搂住我而已。接着——接着我就身不由己了。他吻了我，我吻了他。我没法控制。我就是非得那样了。之后我就明白了，我爱他。” “No, he didn’t speak,” Ruth explained.“He just loved me, that was all.I was as surprised as you are.He didn’t say a word.He just put his arm around me.And—and I was not myself.And he kissed me, and I kissed him.I couldn’t help it.I just had to.And then I knew I loved him.”
她停了下来，满怀期望地等待着她母亲祝福的吻，可莫尔斯太太却只是冷冷地沉默着。 She paused, waiting with expectancy the benediction of her mother’s kiss, but Mrs. Morse was coldly silent.
“这是一场可怕的意外，我知道。”鲁思重新开了口，声音越来越小。“我不知道你要怎样才会原谅我。但是我无法控制这一切。我做梦也没想到我会爱上他，直到那一刻。你一定得替我告诉父亲。” “It is a dreadful accident, I know,” Ruth recommenced with a sinking voice.“And I don’t know how you will ever forgive me.But I couldn’t help it.I did not dream that I loved him until that moment.And you must tell father for me.”
“不告诉你父亲不是更好吗？让我见见马丁·伊登，跟他说说，解释一下。他会明白的，会放你走的。” “Would it not be better not to tell your father?Let me see Martin Eden, and talk with him, and explain.He will understand and release you.”
“不！不要！”鲁思一惊，大叫起来。 “No! no!” Ruth cried, starting up.
“我不想被放走。我爱他，爱是十分甜蜜的。我打算和他结婚——当然，如果你们同意的话。” “I do not want to be released.I love him, and love is very sweet.I am going to marry him—of course, if you will let me.”
“鲁思，亲爱的，你父亲和我，我们为你另做了打算——啊，不，不，不是给你选好对象或这类的任何事情。我们的打算不过是把你嫁给一个来自你自己所在的生活阶层的人，一个善良而体面的绅士。如果你爱上了这样一个人，就由你自己来选。” “We have other plans for you, Ruth, dear, your father and I—oh, no, no; no man picked out for you, or anything like that.Our plans go no farther than your marrying some man in your own station in life, a good and honorable gentleman, whom you will select yourself, when you love him.”
“但是我已经爱上马丁了。”这是她悲伤的抗议。 “But I love Martin already,” was the plaintive protest.
“我们不会通过任何方式影响你的选择；但你是我们的女儿，我们无法忍受眼看着你结下这样一桩婚。除了野蛮和粗鲁他什么都给不了你，却能换到你所有的高雅和美丽。无论如何他都配不上你。他没法养活你。对于财富我们并没有任何愚蠢的观念，但生活舒适是另一回事，我们的女儿至少应该嫁给一个能够给她提供舒适生活的人，而不是一个身无分文的冒险者，一个水手，一个牛仔，一个走私犯，天知道还有什么。除了这一切以外，他头脑简单，又没有责任心。” “We would not influence your choice in any way; but you are our daughter, and we could not bear to see you make a marriage such as this.He has nothing but roughness and coarseness to offer you in exchange for all that is refined and delicate in you.He is no match for you in any way.He could not support you.We have no foolish ideas about wealth, but comfort is another matter, and our daughter should at least marry a man who can give her that—and not a penniless adventurer, a sailor, a cowboy, a smuggler, and Heaven knows what else, who, in addition to everything, is hare-brained and irresponsible.”
鲁思沉默了。她承认每一个字都是真的。 Ruth was silent.Every word she recognized as true.
“他把时间浪费在他的写作上，企图完成那些天才和受过大学教育的少数精英才偶有完成之事。一个想着结婚的人应该为结婚做准备。但是他没有。正如我说的，我知道你也同意我的说法：他没有责任心。他不就应该如此吗？这是水手的作风。他从不知节省和克制。这些年的挥霍浪费标明了他这一点。当然，这不是他的错，但那也改变不了他的本性。你有没有想过他这些年不可避免地过着淫乱无度的生活？你想过这些吗，女儿？你知道婚姻意味着什么。” “He wastes his time over his writing, trying to accomplish what geniuses and rare men with college educations sometimes accomplish.A man thinking of marriage should be preparing for marriage.But not he.As I have said, and I know you agree with me, he is irresponsible.And why should he not be?It is the way of sailors.He has never learned to be economical or temperate.The spendthrift years have marked him.It is not his fault, of course, but that does not alter his nature.And have you thought of the years of licentiousness he inevitably has lived?Have you thought of that, daughter?You know what marriage means.”
鲁思一阵哆嗦，紧紧抱住了她的母亲。 Ruth shuddered and clung close to her mother.
“我想过。”鲁思好久才考虑好怎么表达自己的想法。“这确实很可怕。想起这个我就恶心。我告诉过你，我爱上他是一场可怕的意外，可是我无法控制我自己。难道你能阻止自己去爱父亲吗？那么这对我也是一样的。有一种东西，既存在于我体内，也存在于他体内——我从来不知道它的存在，直至今日——但是它确实存在，它令我爱上他。我从来没有想过要爱他，但是你看，我爱上他了。”她说完了，语气里带着一种隐约的胜利之感。 “I have thought.”Ruth waited a long time for the thought to frame itself.“And it is terrible.It sickens me to think of it.I told you it was a dreadful accident, my loving him; but I can’t help myself.Could you help loving father?Then it is the same with me.There is something in me, in him—I never knew it was there until to-day—but it is there, and it makes me love him.I never thought to love him, but, you see, I do,” she concluded, a certain faint triumph in her voice.
她们谈了很久，几乎没谈出什么结果，最后两个人同意等上不定的一段时间，而不采取任何行动。 They talked long, and to little purpose, in conclusion agreeing to wait an indeterminate time without doing anything.
那晚稍迟一些的时候，莫尔斯太太相应地承认了自己计划中的失误，并和她丈夫一起得出了同样的结论， The same conclusion was reached, a little later that night, between Mrs. Morse and her husband, after she had made due confession of the miscarriage of her plans.
“不太可能出现别的结果。”莫尔斯先生评论说。“这个当水手的小伙子是她接触过的唯一一个男人。不管怎样她迟早会觉醒的；看吧，她真的觉醒了！这个当水手的小伙子是目前唯一能接触到的男人，那么她当然会立刻就爱上他，或者以为是爱上了他，那结果也一样。” “It could hardly have come otherwise,” was Mr. Morse’s judgment.“This sailor-fellow has been the only man she was in touch with.Sooner or later she was going to awaken anyway; and she did awaken, and look！ here was this sailor-fellow, the only accessible man at the moment, and of course she promptly loved him, or thought she did, which amounts to the same thing.”
莫尔斯太太暗自下了决心要慢慢地间接地影响鲁思，而不是和她对着干。有足够的时间来做这件事，因为马丁不具备结婚的条件。 Mrs. Morse took it upon herself to work slowly and indirectly upon Ruth, rather than to combat her.There would be plenty of time for this, for Martin was not in position to marry.
“让她看看自己想要他具备的所有一切。”莫尔斯太太提议说。“她对他的了解越多，她对他的爱就会也少，我打赌。让她做充分的对比。特意请一些年轻人到家里来。姑娘和小伙子，各种各样的青年，那些聪明的男子，那些有所成就或者正要做出一番成就的男子，她本阶层的男子，那些绅士们。她可以拿他们来跟他比比。他们会让他丑态毕露。毕竟，他只是个二十一岁的毛头小伙子。鲁思也不过是个孩子。这是他们两人之间一场短暂的幼年之恋,随着年龄的增长他们会从中摆脱出来的。 “Let her see all she wants of him,” was Mr. Morse’s advice.“The more she knows him, the less she’ll love him, I wager.And give her plenty of contrast.Make a point of having young people at the house.Young women and young men, all sorts of young men, clever men, men who have done something or who are doing things, men of her own class, gentlemen.She can gauge him by them.They will show him up for what he is.And after all, he is a mere boy of twenty-one.Ruth is no more than a child.It is calf love with the pair of them, and they will grow out of it.”
于是，这场风波就平息下去了。在家庭内部，鲁思和马丁订婚的事已经被承认了，但并没有对外宣布。一家人都觉得以后也不会有这个必要。同时，大家默认订婚阶段会很长。他们既没要马丁去工作，也没叫他停止写作。他们没想过要去帮助他改进自己。他则相当于协助怂恿了他们这些不友好的计划，因为他那些念头里最不可能有的就是工作这一条。 So the matter rested.Within the family it was accepted that Ruth and Martin were engaged, but no announcement was made.The family did not think it would ever be necessary.Also, it was tacitly understood that it was to be a long engagement.They did not ask Martin to go to work, nor to cease writing.They did not intend to encourage him to mend himself.And he aided and abetted them in their unfriendly designs, for going to work was farthest from his thoughts.
“我不知道你会不会喜欢我做的这件事！”几天后他跟鲁思说，“我觉得和我姐姐一起吃住太贵了，我打算自己一个人住。我已经在北奥克兰租了几间小屋子，环境僻静等等其他好处，你知道，我买了一只煤油炉子用来做饭。” “I wonder if you’ll like what I have done!” he said to Ruth several days later.“I’ve decided that boarding with my sister is too expensive, and I am going to board myself.I’ve rented a little room out in North Oakland, retired neighborhood and all the rest, you know, and I’ve bought an oil-burner on which to cook.”
鲁思高兴得不得了。那煤油炉子尤其令她满意。 Ruth was overjoyed.The oil-burner especially pleased her.
“巴特勒先生就是那样开始的。”她说。 “That was the way Mr. Butler began his start,” she said.
听到她赞扬那位受人景仰的绅士，马丁暗暗皱了皱眉头，继续说道：“我给我所有的手稿都盖了章，并重新寄到编辑们那里去。我今天就搬进去，明天就开始工作。” Martin frowned inwardly at the citation of that worthy gentleman, and went on: “I put stamps on all my manuscripts and started them off to the editors again.Then to-day I moved in, and to-morrow I start to work.”
“一份工作？”她叫起来，透露出浑身满溢的那种惊喜，更紧地依偎着他，抓着他的手微笑着。 “A position!” she cried, betraying the gladness of her surprise in all her body, nestling closer to him, pressing his hand, smiling.
“你从来没跟我说过。是份什么工作？” “And you never told me!What is it?”
他摇了摇头。 He shook his head.
“我刚是要说我打算继续写作。”她的脸沉了下去，他急忙接着说道：“不要误会我。我这次不会再写那些光怪陆离的想法了。这次将会是一个冷静、平淡、朴素的现实的想法。这总比再到海上去好，在奥克兰一个没有技能的人能找到的任何工作都不会赚到比我这份工作更多的钱。” “I meant that I was going to work at my writing.”Her face fell, and he went on hastily.“Don’t misjudge me.I am not going in this time with any iridescent ideas.It is to be a cold, prosaic, matter-of-fact business proposition.It is better than going to sea again, and I shall earn more money than any position in Oakland can bring an unskilled man.”
“你看，我从事的这份工作已经让我有了一些头绪。我还没有竭尽全力地工作过，我还没有从事过写作，至少没有写过用来发表的文章。我做过的所有事情就是爱你和思考。我也读过一些东西，但那不过是我思考的一部分，我读过的主要都是杂志。我自己、这个世界、我在其中所处的地位以及我赢得一个与你相称的地位的可能性，这些我都大概地推想过。另外，我读过斯宾塞的《文体哲学》，发现了我自身——或者更确切地说，我写作上的许多问题。就那一点来讲，每个月杂志上发表的大部分文章也存在问题。” “You see, this vacation I have taken has given me perspective.I haven’t been working the life out of my body, and I haven’t been writing, at least not for publication.All I’ve done has been to love you and to think.I’ve read some, too, but it has been part of my thinking, and I have read principally magazines.I have generalized about myself, and the world, my place in it, and my chance to win to a place that will be fit for you.Also, I’ve been reading Spencer’s @Philosophy of Style@， and found out a lot of what was the matter with me—or my writing, rather; and for that matter with most of the writing that is published every month in the magazines.”
“不过，这一切的结果是——我的思考、阅读和爱的结果是——我将搬到格拉布街去。我将搁下长篇巨制，写一些用以赚钱的小文章——笑话、短篇报道、专题特写、幽默的诗歌以及轻松的抒情诗——所有这些需求量似乎相当大的胡编乱诌。还有一些同时给多家报社供稿的联合协会、短篇故事报刊供稿协会以及周日增刊供稿协会。我可以尽量写，好好推敲，写出他们想要的东西来，以此挣的钱将抵得上一份优厚的薪水。有自由作家这回事，你知道，他们一个月能赚四五百美元之多呢。我并不指望能跟他们一样，但我将赚到足够好好过日子的钱，并给自己留下充裕的时间，干其他任何工作我都不会有那么多的自由时间。” “But the upshot of it all—of my thinking and reading and loving—is that I am going to move to Grub Street.I shall leave masterpieces alone and do hack-work—jokes, paragraphs, feature articles, humorous verse, and society verse—all the rot for which there seems so much demand.Then there are the newspaper syndicates, and the newspaper short-story syndicates, and the syndicates for the Sunday supplements.I can go ahead and hammer out the stuff they want, and earn the equivalent of a good salary by it.There are free-lances, you know, who earn as much as four or five hundred a month.I don’t care to become as they; but I’ll earn a good living, and have plenty of time to myself, which I wouldn’t have in any position.”
“那么我就会有空闲的时间来从事学习和真正的工作。辛劳于这些事的同时，我还会尝试着手写我的鸿篇巨制，我会学习，为写出鸿篇巨制做好准备。啊，我竟然已经想得那么远了，我自己都感到惊讶呢。刚开始写作的时候，我没有任何东西可写，除了一些我自己既不明白也不欣赏的微不足道的经历。但那时我还没有思考过。真的没有。我甚至连用来思考的词汇都没有。我那些经历就像许许多多毫无意义的画面。可是，随着我逐渐增加我的知识和词汇，我从那些经历中看到了画面以外的某些东西。我保留了那些画面，并发现了其中的含义。那是我开始写出好作品的时候，我写了《冒险》、《乐》、《罐子》、《生命的红酒》、《拥攘的大街》、《爱情组诗》，还有《海上抒情诗》。我将写出更多那样的作品，更好的作品，但我要用空闲时间来写。现在，我要脚踏实地。写卖文作品和赚钱是第一位的，之后才是鸿篇巨制的创作。为了证明给你看，我昨晚为那些幽默逗乐类周刊写了六个笑话。正要上床的时候，一个试手写八行两韵诗的念想忽然袭上我的心头——写一首幽默的，才不到一个小时，我就写好了四首。这些一篇应该能值一美元。上床之前稍作思考就有四美元了。” “Then, I’ll have my spare time for study and for real work.In between the grind I’ll try my hand at masterpieces, and I’ll study and prepare myself for the writing of masterpieces.Why, I am amazed at the distance I have come already.When I first tried to write, I had nothing to write about except a few paltry experiences which I neither understood nor appreciated.But I had no thoughts.I really didn’t.I didn’t even have the words with which to think.My experiences were so many meaningless pictures.But as I began to add to my knowledge, and to my vocabulary, I saw something more in my experiences than mere pictures.I retained the pictures and I found their interpretation.That was when I began to do good work, when I wrote ‘Adventure,’ ‘Joy,’ ‘The Pot,’ ‘The Wine of Life,’ ‘The Jostling Street,’ the ‘Love-cycle,’ and the ‘Sea Lyrics.’ I shall write more like them, and better; but I shall do it in my spare time.My feet are on the solid earth, now.Hack-work and income first, masterpieces afterward.Just to show you, I wrote half a dozen jokes last night for the comic weeklies; and just as I was going to bed, the thought struck me to try my hand at a triolet—a humorous one; and inside an hour I had written four.They ought to be worth a dollar apiece.Four dollars right there for a few afterthoughts on the way to bed.”
“当然这都毫无价值，不过是些又枯燥又卑贱的苦活儿。但是，比起为了每月的六十美元记账，没完没了地把长串毫无意义的数字加来加去，直到死了为止，这就不似那么枯燥、那么卑贱了。还有，写卖文作品可以让我接触到文学的东西，给我时间去尝试更大篇幅的作品。 “Of course it’s all valueless, just so much dull and sordid plodding; but it is no more dull and sordid than keeping books at sixty dollars a month, adding up endless columns of meaningless figures until one dies.And furthermore, the hack-work keeps me in touch with things literary and gives me time to try bigger things.”
“可是这些大篇幅的作品，这些鸿篇巨制，又有什么用呢？”鲁思问， “But what good are these bigger-things, these masterpieces?” Ruth demanded.
“你又不能把它们卖出去。”“啊，不，我能卖出去的。”他开始要说，但是被她打断了。 “You can’t sell them.”“Oh, yes, I can,” he began; but she interrupted.
“你说的所有这些作品，你自称优秀的作品，连其中的一篇都没有卖出去。靠那些卖不出去的杰作我们是结不成婚的。” “All those you named, and which you say yourself are good—you have not sold any of them.We can’t get married on masterpieces that won’t sell.”
“那我们就靠能卖出去的八行两韵诗来结婚。”他顽固地声称，边用胳膊搂住她，把这个毫无赞同之意的爱人拽向自己。 “Then we’ll get married on triolets that will sell,” he asserted stoutly, putting his arm around her and drawing a very unresponsive sweetheart toward him.
“听听这个，”他用努力装出来的欢快口吻继续说，“这不是艺术，但这是一个美元。” “Listen to this,” he went on in attempted gayety.“It’s not art, but it’s a dollar.
“他进来，在我出去的时候，借一点食物，这是他来此的原因。他空手而归。于是，我进来时，他已出去。” “He came inWhen I was out,To borrow some tinWas why he came in,And he went without;So I was inAnd he was out.”
读这段顺口溜时他带着活泼欢快的节奏，与此相冲突的是，读完时他脸上显出一副沮丧的表情。他没有从鲁思那里得到一丝微笑。她正望着他，表情严肃，忧心忡忡。 The merry lilt with which he had invested the jingle was at variance with the dejection that came into his face as he finished.He had drawn no smile from Ruth.She was looking at him in an earnest and troubled way.
“这也许能换来一美元，”她说，“但这是给小丑的一美元，给一个小丑的赏钱。难道你看不出来么，马丁，这整个儿就是件贬低人身份的事。我希望我所爱和尊重的男人能比一个写笑话歪诗的骗子强些、有地位些。” “It may be a dollar,” she said, “but it is a jester’s dollar, the fee of a clown.Don’t you see, Martin, the whole thing is lowering.I want the man I love and honor to be something finer and higher than a perpetrator of jokes and doggerel.”
“你希望他像——比如说巴特勒先生？”他提示道。 “You want him to be like—say Mr. Butler?” he suggested.
“我知道你不喜欢巴特勒先生。”她开口了。 “I know you don’t like Mr. Butler,” she began.
“巴特勒先生很不错，”他打断说，“我不喜欢的只是他的消化不良。可是替我自己说一句，我看不出写笑话或者写歪诗与操作一台打字机、做记录或者管几堆账本有什么区别。这都是达到目的的一种手段而已。你的理论是为了成为一个成功的律师或一个生意人我要从管账本开始。而我的理论则是为了发展成一名有能力的作家我要从写卖文作品开始。” “Mr. Butler’s all right,” he interrupted.“It’s only his indigestion I find fault with.But to save me I can’t see any difference between writing jokes or comic verse and running a type-writer, taking dictation, or keeping sets of books.It is all a means to an end.Your theory is for me to begin with keeping books in order to become a successful lawyer or man of business.Mine is to begin with hack-work and develop into an able author.”
“这是有区别的。”她坚持说。 “There is a difference,” she insisted.
“有什么区别呢？” “What is it?”
“还用说吗，你的佳作，你自称为佳作的那些东西，你卖不出去呀。你已经尽力了，这一点你知道的——但那些编辑是不会买这些的。” “Why, your good work, what you yourself call good, you can’t sell.You have tried, you know that,—but the editors won’t buy it.”
“给我点时间，亲爱的。”他恳求道，“写卖文作品只不过是权宜之计，我不会拿它当真的。给我两年的时间。到那时我会成功的，那些编辑会乐意买我的佳作的。我知道自己在说什么，我对我自己有信心。我知道自己有什么能耐，现在我知道文学是什么了，我知道众多小人物倾泻而出的那些平庸不堪的胡诌之作，我知道两年之后我将会走上成功的大道。至于做生意，我永远也不会成功的。我不支持这项事业。它让我觉得无聊、愚蠢、唯利是图、尔虞我诈。无论如何我都不适合做生意。我能当上的永远也超不过一名小职员，靠一名小职员的那点微薄收入你和我怎么能过得快乐呢？我想把世界上所有最好的东西都给你，除非有更好的东西时，我才会不想给你这些东西。我一定会争取到的，争取到这所有的一切。一个成功作家的收入看起来比巴特勒先生的要少。不管是到哪儿一本畅销书都能挣到五万至十万美元——有时候多些有时候少些，但一般来说，都跟这数目差不离。” “Give me time, dear,” he pleaded.“The hack-work is only makeshift, and I don’t take it seriously.Give me two years.I shall succeed in that time, and the editors will be glad to buy my good work.I know what I am saying; I have faith in myself.I know what I have in me; I know what literature is, now; I know the average rot that is poured out by a lot of little men; and I know that at the end of two years I shall be on the highroad to success.As for business, I shall never succeed at it.I am not in sympathy with it.It strikes me as dull, and stupid, and mercenary, and tricky.Anyway I am not adapted for it.I’d never get beyond a clerkship, and how could you and I be happy on the paltry earnings of a clerk?I want the best of everything in the world for you, and the only time when I won’t want it will be when there is something better.And I’m going to get it, going to get all of it.The income of a successful author makes Mr. Butler look cheap.A ‘best-seller’ will earn anywhere between fifty and a hundred thousand dollars—sometimes more and sometimes less; but, as a rule, pretty close to those figures.”
她继续沉默着，她的失望表现得很明显。 She remained silent; her disappointment was apparent.
“怎么样？”他问。 “Well?” he asked.
“我也有过别的希望和打算。我曾以为，而且我现在还是这么认为，你最好还是学习速记——你已经会用打字机了——然后到我父亲的公司去工作。你头脑很好，我相信你会是一名成功的律师。” “I had hoped and planned otherwise.I had thought, and I still think, that the best thing for you would be to study shorthand—you already know type-writing—and go into father’s office.You have a good mind, and I am confident you would succeed as a lawyer.”
第二十三章 CHAPTER XXIII
鲁思对他当一名作家的能力没什么信心，这没有改变或降低她在马丁眼中的地位。在他度过的这个短暂假期里，他花了好多时间来分析自己，因此对自己很了解了。他发现自己对美的热爱胜于对名的热爱，而他对名的渴望绝大部分还是为了鲁思。正是出于这个原因他对名的渴望才会那么强烈。为了让自己所爱的女人替他骄傲，将他视为才俊，他想成为世人眼里了不起的人，用他自己的话说就是“成功”。 That Ruth had little faith in his power as a writer, did not alter her nor diminish her in Martin’s eyes.In the breathing spell of the vacation he had taken, he had spent many hours in self-analysis, and thereby learned much of himself.He had discovered that he loved beauty more than fame, and that what desire he had for fame was largely for Ruth’s sake.It was for this reason that his desire for fame was strong.He wanted to be great in the world’s eyes; “to make good,” as he expressed it, in order that the woman he loved should be proud of him and deem him worthy.
至于他自己，他对美怀着强烈的喜爱，为美服务的喜悦对他而言就是足够的报酬。而他对鲁思的爱又胜过对美的爱。他把爱情当成世界上最美好的事物。是爱情让他发生了彻底的改变，让他从粗野的水手变成了一名学生，一位艺术家。因此，对他来说，三者之中最美好、最伟大的，比学习和艺术还要崇高的，就是爱情。他早就发现自己的思想已经超越了鲁思的，正如超越了她的兄弟和父亲的思想一样。尽管她享有大学教育的种种优势，但面对她的文学学士学位，他的才智之力仍使她黯然失色，他这一年左右的自学和知识装备给了他一种对世界、艺术和生活的深刻理解，这种理解她永远也不可能获得。 As for himself, he loved beauty passionately, and the joy of serving her was to him sufficient wage.And more than beauty he loved Ruth.He considered love the finest thing in the world.It was love that had worked the revolution in him, changing him from an uncouth sailor to a student and an artist; therefore, to him, the finest and greatest of the three, greater than learning and artistry, was love.Already he had discovered that his brain went beyond Ruth’s, just as it went beyond the brains of her brothers, or the brain of her father.In spite of every advantage of university training, and in the face of her bachelorship of arts, his power of intellect overshadowed hers, and his year or so of self-study and equipment gave him a mastery of the affairs of the world and art and life that she could never hope to possess.
这一切他都意识到了，但这既并不影响他对鲁思的爱，也不影响鲁思对他的爱。爱情是如此美好而崇高，他又是一位如此忠诚的恋人，以至于他不会让非难指责玷污了爱情。鲁思对艺术、正确的行为、法国大革命或是平等的选举权有不同的见解，但爱情跟这些又有什么关系呢？这些都是理性思考的过程，但爱情不在理智的范围之内，它是超越于理智的。他不能小看爱情。他对爱情顶礼膜拜。爱情处在理性谷地之外的山峰之巅。它是生命存在的升华形式，是生活的顶峰。它罕有出现。多亏他钟爱的那些采用科学研究派哲学家，他懂得了爱情的生物学意义。但是借由同样科学细致的推理过程，他得出了一个结论，就是人类有机体在爱情当中实现了其最高目标，爱情是不可质疑的，而必须被当成生活的最高奖励来接受。因此，他把恋人当成万物之上的赐福，想到“上帝自己的恋人也疯狂”，她高于一切尘世之物，高于财富和理性判断，高于公众舆论和赞美，高于生命本身，会“为了一个吻而甘愿死去”，他就感到快乐。 All this he realized, but it did not affect his love for her, nor her love for him.Love was too fine and noble, and he was too loyal a lover for him to besmirch love with criticism.What did love have to do with Ruth’s divergent views on art, right conduct, the French Revolution, or equal suffrage?They were mental processes, but love was beyond reason; it was superrational.He could not belittle love.He worshipped it.Love lay on the mountain-tops beyond the valley-land of reason.It was a sublimates condition of existence, the topmost peak of living, and it came rarely.Thanks to the school of scientific philosophers he favored, he knew the biological significance of love; but by a refined process of the same scientific reasoning he reached the conclusion that the human organism achieved its highest purpose in love, that love must not be questioned, but must be accepted as the highest guerdon of life.Thus, he considered the lover blessed over all creatures, and it was a delight to him to think of “God’s own mad lover,” rising above the things of earth, above wealth and judgment, public opinion and applause, rising above life itself and “dying on a kiss.”
其中大部分马丁早就找到答案了，而另一些则是他后来才明白的。同时他还要工作，除了去看望鲁思，他没有任何消遣活动，活得像斯巴达人一样清苦。他每月交两块半美元的房租，从一位葡萄牙女房东那里租到一间小屋子。女房东名叫玛丽亚·席尔瓦，是个剽悍的寡妇，她工作卖力，脾气比较暴躁，不知怎地养了一大群孩子。为了忘却悲伤和疲劳，她时不时灌上一加仑又稀又酸的葡萄酒，这酒是她用十五美分从街角的杂货店兼酒吧买来的。从一开始厌恶她和她那污秽不堪的舌头，马丁渐渐敬佩起她来，因为他看到了她的勇敢拼搏。那小房子里只有四间屋子，去掉马丁租走的那间还剩三间。其中一间是客厅，一条生染的地毯使其显出几分欢快，而一张白贴和她众多孩子中死去的那个的遗像又让客厅显出几分哀伤。客厅严格规定是用来接待客人的。百叶窗总是拉下的，她那群赤脚的孩子从未被允许进入客厅这个神圣的区域，除非遇上全国性的大事。她做饭，大家在厨房吃饭，除了星期天以外的所有日子，她还在那里洗衣服、浆衣服、熨衣服，因为她的大部分收入都来自帮那些更宽裕的邻居们洗衣服。剩下一间卧室，跟马丁住的那间一样狭小，她和她那七个小家伙就挤在这个小房间里睡觉。他们是如何做到的，对于马丁来说，这永远是个谜。透过一层薄薄的隔板墙他每天夜晚都听到她那边的每一个细节：上床、孩子的哭喊和争吵、轻声细语的唠叨，还有鸟儿们带着睡意吱吱叫的声音。玛丽亚的另一个收入来源是她那几头奶牛，共有两头，她每天早晚都要挤奶。这两头牛是偷偷靠着那几块空地和长在公共人行道两侧的青草活下来的，照看它们的总是她那几个穿得破破烂烂的孩子里头的一两个，他们警觉地看守着，主要就是留意围场的巡逻员。 Much of this Martin had already reasoned out, and some of it he reasoned out later.In the meantime he worked, taking no recreation except when he went to see Ruth, and living like a Spartan.He paid two dollars and a half a month rent for the small room he got from his Portuguese landlady, Maria Silva, a virago and a widow, hard working and harsher tempered, rearing her large brood of children somehow, and drowning her sorrow and fatigue at irregular intervals in a gallon of the thin, sour wine that she bought from the corner grocery and saloon for fifteen cents.From detesting her and her foul tongue at first, Martin grew to admire her as he observed the brave fight she made.There were but four rooms in the little house—three, when Martin’s was subtracted.One of these, the parlor, gay with an ingrain carpet and dolorous with a funeral card and a death-picture of one of her numerous departed babes, was kept strictly for company.The blinds were always down, and her barefooted tribe was never permitted to enter the sacred precinct save on state occasions.She cooked, and all ate, in the kitchen, where she likewise washed, starched, and ironed clothes on all days of the week except Sunday; for her income came largely from taking in washing from her more prosperous neighbors.Remained the bedroom, small as the one occupied by Martin, into which she and her seven little ones crowded and slept.It was an everlasting miracle to Martin how it was accomplished, and from her side of the thin partition he heard nightly every detail of the going to bed, the squalls and squabbles, the soft chattering, and the sleepy, twittering noises as of birds.Another source of income to Maria were her cows, two of them, which she milked night and morning and which gained a surreptitious livelihood from vacant lots and the grass that grew on either side the public side walks, attended always by one or more of her ragged boys, whose watchful guardianship consisted chiefly in keeping their eyes out for the poundmen.
马丁在他自己的那间小屋子里生活、睡觉、学习、写作、做家务。在仅有的那一扇窗前，对着小小的前门廊，有一张厨房用的桌子，既当书桌，又当图书馆，还用来充当打字机的台架。床靠着后墙，占去了整个房间三分之二的空间。桌子的一侧放着个花哨的抽屉柜，做出来是为了盈利而不是为了实用，上面那层薄薄的镶饰每天都在脱落。这个抽屉柜放在一个角落里，对面的另一个角落，也就是桌子的另一侧就是厨房——杂物箱上放着煤油炉子，箱内装着盘子和烹调用具，墙上有一个存放食物的架子，地板上放着一桶水。马丁必须得到厨房的水槽里去打水，他的房间里没有水龙头。在没有足够柴火供他做饭的那些日子里，从抽屉柜上剥落下来的镶饰板就是一种特大丰收。床铺上方悬着他的自行车，它被一个滑轮链子吊到了天花板。起初他想把它放在地下室里，但是席尔瓦的那帮小家伙弄松了车上的轴承，扎破了车胎，将他赶了出去。后来他试图把自行车放在那个小门廊里，直到一场东南方向袭来的狂风暴雨将车轮子浸泡了整整一夜。然后他把车搬回自己的房间里，悬挂在顶上。 In his own small room Martin lived, slept, studied, wrote, and kept house.Before the one window, looking out on the tiny front porch, was the kitchen table that served as desk, library, and type-writing stand.The bed, against the rear wall, occupied two-thirds of the total space of the room.The table was flanked on one side by a gaudy bureau, manufactured for profit and not for service, the thin veneer of which was shed day by day.This bureau stood in the corner, and in the opposite corner, on the table’s other flank, was the kitchen—the oil-stove on a dry-goods box, inside of which were dishes and cooking utensils, a shelf on the wall for provisions, and a bucket of water on the floor.Martin had to carry his water from the kitchen sink, there being no tap in his room.On days when there was much steam to his cooking, the harvest of veneer from the bureau was unusually generous.Over the bed, hoisted by a tackle to the ceiling, was his bicycle.At first he had tried to keep it in the basement; but the tribe of Silva, loosening the bearings and puncturing the tires, had driven him out.Next he attempted the tiny front porch, until a howling southeaster drenched the wheel a night-long.Then he had retreated with it to his room and slung it aloft.
一个小衣橱里装着他的衣服以及他积存起来的书籍，因为无论桌上还是桌下都腾不出放书的空间来。在阅读的同时，他养成了记笔记的习惯。他做了那么多的笔记，要不是他拉起了几根晾衣绳来挂笔记，这狭小的屋子里就没有他可容身的空间了。即便如此，屋里还是挤得连他穿行走动都十分困难。不先关上衣橱门他就没法打开房门，反过来也是一样。无论如何他要直线穿过房间是完全不可能的。从房门走到床头是一条弯来折去的路线，他从来都做不到在黑暗里走完这条路线而不发生碰撞。解决了门扇间相互碰撞的难题后，他必须急转向右绕开厨房。接着，他又转向左边以避开床脚，但是这一转若转得幅度太大又会撞上桌角。倏地一倾一倒，他终止了拐弯，躺在一个有点像运河结构的右侧。“运河”的一岸是床，另一岸是桌子。当房间里仅有的一张椅子放在桌前通常放的地方时，这“运河”根本不能通航。椅子不用的时候就置在床上，尽管做饭的时候，他偶尔也坐到椅子上——一边看书一边煮开水。他甚至变得有技巧到能够一边煎牛排一边写下一两个段落。再者，构成厨房的那个小角落是那么狭窄，他能够坐着就伸手拿到任何他想要的东西。事实上，坐着做饭反而方便；站起来时，他总是自己碍着自己的道。 A small closet contained his clothes and the books he had accumulated and for which there was no room on the table or under the table.Hand in hand with reading, he had developed the habit of making notes, and so copiously did he make them that there would have been no existence for him in the confined quarters had he not rigged several clothes-lines across the room on which the notes were hung.Even so, he was crowded until navigating the room was a difficult task.He could not open the door without first closing the closet door, and vice versa.It was impossible for him anywhere to traverse the room in a straight line.To go from the door to the head of the bed was a zigzag course that he was never quite able to accomplish in the dark without collisions.Having settled the difficulty of the conflicting doors, he had to steer sharply to the right to avoid the kitchen.Next, he sheered to the left, to escape the foot of the bed; but this sheer, if too generous, brought him against the corner of the table.With a sudden twitch and lurch, he terminated the sheer and bore off to the right along a sort of canal, one bank of which was the bed, the other the table.When the one chair in the room was at its usual place before the table, the canal was unnavigable.When the chair was not in use, it reposed on top of the bed, though sometimes he sat on the chair when cooking, reading a book while the water boiled, and even becoming skilful enough to manage a paragraph or two while steak was frying.Also, so small was the little corner that constituted the kitchen, he was able, sitting down, to reach anything he needed.In fact, it was expedient to cook sitting down; standing up, he was too often in his own way.
