他有一个能消化任何东西的理想肠胃，同时他还知道各式各样既有营养又便宜的食物。豌豆汤是他菜谱上常见的一道菜，土豆和大豆也是一样，后者大大，是黄褐色，可做成墨西哥风味。大米至少每天在马丁的餐桌上出现一次。美国家庭主妇从来不像他那样做米饭，而且永远也学不来那样做米饭。干果比新鲜水果便宜，他通常都有一罐干果，做好了的，在手头备着，因为它们代替着他面包上的黄油。偶尔，他会给他的餐桌添块圆形牛排或者一碗排骨汤。不加奶油和牛奶的咖啡，他每天喝两次，晚上用来代替茶。不过，无论咖啡还是茶他都煮得特别好。 In conjunction with a perfect stomach that could digest anything, he possessed knowledge of the various foods that were at the same time nutritious and cheap.Pea-soup was a common article in his diet, as well as potatoes and beans, the latter large and brown and cooked in Mexican style.Rice, cooked as American housewives never cook it and can never learn to cook it, appeared on Martin’s table at least once a day.Dried fruits were less expensive than fresh, and he had usually a pot of them, cooked and ready at hand, for they took the place of butter on his bread.Occasionally he graced his table with a piece of round-steak, or with a soup-bone.Coffee, without cream or milk, he had twice a day, in the evening substituting tea; but both coffee and tea were excellently cooked.
他必须得节省。他的假期已经差不多花光了他在洗衣店挣到的所有的钱，而他的“市场”还遥不可及，在几个星期过去之前他是没有希望收到他那些卖文作品的报酬的。除了去看望鲁思或者拜访姐姐格特鲁德之外，他都过着隐居生活，每天要完成普通人花至少三天才能完成的工作。他睡觉睡不足五小时，只有体格如钢铁般强健的人才能比得过他，因为马丁每天都是连续苦干十九个小时。他从未浪费过一丁点儿的时间。镜子上贴着一些定义和发音的列单；刮胡子、穿衣服，或是梳头的时候，他就默记这些列单。煤油炉子上方的墙上也贴着这样的列单，他忙着做饭或洗刷碗碟的时候同样也会默记这些列单。新的列单不断替换着旧的列单。在阅读中遇到的每一个陌生或不太熟悉的单词，他都会马上记下来。然后，等积累了足够的数量，他就把它们打印出来，固定到墙上或者镜子上。他甚至把它们放在口袋里，利用上街时的零碎时间或在肉铺、杂货店等着买东西的时间来复习它们。 There was need for him to be economical.His vacation had consumed nearly all he had earned in the laundry, and he was so far from his market that weeks must elapse before he could hope for the first returns from his hack-work.Except at such times as he saw Ruth, or dropped in to see his sister Gertude, he lived a recluse, in each day accomplishing at least three days’ labor of ordinary men.He slept a scant five hours, and only one with a constitution of iron could have held himself down, as Martin did, day after day, to nineteen consecutive hours of toil.He never lost a moment.On the looking-glass were lists of definitions and pronunciations; when shaving, or dressing, or combing his hair, he conned these lists over.Similar lists were on the wall over the oil-stove, and they were similarly conned while he was engaged in cooking or in washing the dishes.New lists continually displaced the old ones.Every strange or partly familiar word encountered in his reading was immediately jotted down, and later, when a sufficient number had been accumulated, were typed and pinned to the wall or looking-glass.He even carried them in his pockets, and reviewed them at odd moments on the street, or while waiting in butcher shop or grocery to be served.
他进一步深入到事物的实质。读到那些成功作家的作品时，他记下他们取得的每一样成就，并找出他们是用了怎样的技巧来实现的——叙述的技巧、说明的技巧、风格上的技巧、观点上的技巧、对比手法和妙语警句。他把这些也都做成单子以便学习。他不是光学个样子。他寻找的是那些原理。他从众多作家当中挑出那些有效的、吸引人的独特风格列成单子，直到他能够在诸多这样的单子里归纳出一个普适性的原理。如此准备之后，他要赶紧找出全新的、他自己独有的风格，并对它们进行恰当的权衡、比较和评价。他还用同样的方式收集感染力强的短语的列单，那些短语都是鲜活的语言，它们像酸一样刺痛人又像火一样灼伤人，或者在日常语言的荒漠之中发出融融的光芒，馥郁芬芳。他总是寻觅着那藏在背后的深处的原则。他想要知道好文章是如何写出来的。这样以后他就能自己写出好文章来了。光是美的精致表面并不能让他满足。他把自己那拥挤的小卧室当成实验室来解剖美，屋里弥漫着做饭的油烟味，屋外是席尔瓦家那帮孩子的吵闹声。解剖和研习了美的结构之后，他离获得创造美的能力就更近了。 He went farther in the matter.Reading the works of men who had arrived, he noted every result achieved by them, and worked out the tricks by which they had been achieved—the tricks of narrative, of exposition, of style, the points of view, the contrasts, the epigrams; and of all these he made lists for study.He did not ape.He sought principles.He drew up lists of effective and fetching mannerisms, till out of many such, culled from many writers, he was able to induce the general principle of mannerism, and, thus equipped, to cast about for new and original ones of his own, and to weigh and measure and appraise them properly.In similar manner he collected lists of strong phrases, the phrases of living language, phrases that bit like acid and scorched like flame, or that glowed and were mellow and luscious in the midst of the arid desert of common speech.He sought always for the principle that lay behind and beneath.He wanted to know how the thing was done; after that he could do it for himself.He was not content with the fair face of beauty.He dissected beauty in his crowded little bedroom laboratory, where cooking smells alternated with the outer bedlam of the Silva tribe; and, having dissected and learned the anatomy of beauty, he was nearer being able to create beauty itself.
他有这样的天性，以至于他只能在理解的前提下才能动手去做。他不能在黑暗中盲目工作，不知道自己在创造什么，把创作结果的好坏对错交托给运气和自己的天才福星。他对投机得到的结果没有耐心。他想要知道为什么和怎么做。他靠的是谨慎而富有创造力的天才，在他开始写故事或诗歌之前，故事或诗歌本身就已经存在于他的脑海之中了。他看得到结尾，而且实现那个结尾的方法也已经在他意识掌控之中。若非如此，那些努力是注定要失败的。另一方面，他欣赏单词之间、短语之间偶然出现的效果，它们轻盈自在地进入他脑子里，后来经受住了所有美和力的考验，发展出极多难以言传的隐含意义。面对这些，他俯首弯腰，惊讶万分。他知道任何人的精心创作都创造不出这些。他寻找那些藏在美的深处，使美成为可能的原理。然而，无论在此过程中他对美有怎样深入的剖析，他始终意识到美最深处的奥秘是他所无法参透的，也没有哪一个前人参透过它。他从斯宾塞的作品里充分地了解到，人永远都不能获得任何一件事物的终极知识，美的奥秘并不亚于生命的奥秘——不，美和生命两者的纤维往往是互相交织在一起的，而他自己不过是这一团无法领悟的纤维中的一小撮而已。 He was so made that he could work only with understanding.He could not work blindly, in the dark, ignorant of what he was producing and trusting to chance and the star of his genius that the effect produced should be right and fine.He had no patience with chance effects.He wanted to know why and how.His was deliberate creative genius, and, before he began a story or poem, the thing itself was already alive in his brain, with the end in sight and the means of realizing that end in his conscious possession.Otherwise the effort was doomed to failure.On the other hand, he appreciated the chance effects in words and phrases that came lightly and easily into his brain, and that later stood all tests of beauty and power and developed tremendous and incommunicable connotations.Before such he bowed down and marvelled, knowing that they were beyond the deliberate creation of any man.And no matter how much he dissected beauty in search of the principles that underlie beauty and make beauty possible, he was aware, always, of the innermost mystery of beauty to which he did not penetrate and to which no man had ever penetrated.He knew full well, from his Spencer, that man can never attain ultimate knowledge of anything, and that the mystery of beauty was no less than that of life—nay, more that the fibres of beauty and life were intertwisted, and that he himself was but a bit of the same nonunderstandable fabric, twisted of sunshine and star-dust and wonder.
其实，就是带着这样的思索他写了一篇题为《星尘》的文章，里头他激情澎湃地表达了对那些重要批评家的指摘，而不是对批评原理的指摘。这篇文章写得才华横溢、深刻透彻、富有哲理，而且巧妙地融入了幽默诙谐的元素。跟往常一样，文章一寄出去就立刻被各个杂志社退回来了。但他已经想清楚了这一切，他要从容地走自己的路。他养成了一个习惯，就一个主题先酝酿思考，等自己想法成熟之后再冲到打字机前把它一口气写出来。这一作品没能见报的事实他并没有太在意。这篇文章是长期思考过程的最终成果，是散乱思想线索的整合，是深埋在他脑海里的所有资料的最后归纳。写下这样一篇文章是他有意识的努力。通过这样的努力，他解放了自己的思想，使它准备好去接受新鲜的材料和问题。这跟那些男人女人一种普遍的习惯很相似。他们被真实或假想的悲伤所困扰，定期打破他们沉默，滔滔不绝地倾吐长期以来所遭受的痛苦，“发表他们的言论”，直到说完最后一个字。 In fact, it was when filled with these thoughts that he wrote his essay entitled “Star-dust,” in which he had his fling, not at the principles of criticism, but at the principal critics.It was brilliant, deep, philosophical, and deliciously touched with laughter.Also it was promptly rejected by the magazines as often as it was submitted.But having cleared his mind of it, he went serenely on his way.It was a habit he developed, of incubating and maturing his thought upon a subject, and of then rushing into the type-writer with it.That it did not see print was a matter a small moment with him.The writing of it was the culminating act of a long mental process, the drawing together of scattered threads of thought and the final generalizing upon all the data with which his mind was burdened.To write such an article was the conscious effort by which he freed his mind and made it ready for fresh material and problems.It was in a way akin to that common habit of men and women troubled by real or fancied grievances, who periodically and volubly break their long-suffering silence and “have their say” till the last word is said.
第二十四章 CHAPTER XXIV
几周过去了。马丁花光了钱，而出版商的稿酬还跟以前一样遥遥无期。他所有的重要稿件都被退回来了，又重新寄出去。他那些卖文作品也好不到哪里去。他的小厨房里再也添不起多样的食物了。他陷入了窘境，只剩下半袋大米和几磅干杏子，米饭和杏子在他的菜单上一天出现三次，接连五天都是如此。接着他自己赊下的帐让他吓了一大跳。当马丁的账单积到三美元八十美分这样一个巨额总数时，那个葡萄牙裔的杂货店老板不再让他赊账了。之前，他一直都是付现金给那老板的。 The weeks passed.Martin ran out of money, and publishers’ checks were far away as ever.All his important manuscripts had come back and been started out again, and his hack-work fared no better.His little kitchen was no longer graced with a variety of foods.Caught in the pinch with a part sack of rice and a few pounds of dried apricots, rice and apricots was his menu three times a day for five days hand-running.Then he startled to realize on his credit.The Portuguese grocer, to whom he had hitherto paid cash, called a halt when Martin’s bill reached the magnificent total of three dollars and eighty-five cents.
“因为，你知道，”杂货店老板说，“你要是找不到工作，我就得赔钱了。” “For you see,” said the grocer, “you no catcha da work, I losa da mon’.”
马丁没话可以回应。根本就解释不了。一个身强力壮的小伙子，来自劳动阶层却过于懒惰而不肯工作，给这样的人赊账并不符合做生意的原则。 And Martin could reply nothing.There was no way of explaining.It was not true business principle to allow credit to a strong-bodied young fellow of the working-class who was too lazy to work.
“你要是找着了工作，我就再给你食物吃。”杂货店老板向马丁保证说。“没有工作就没有饭吃。这是做买卖呢。”然后，为了显示这纯粹是出于生意上的先见之明而不是偏见，他说：“请你喝一杯吧，算店里的——好朋友还是好朋友。” “You catcha da job, I let you have mora da grub,” the grocer assured Martin.“No job, no grub.Thata da business.”And then, to show that it was purely business foresight and not prejudice, “Hava da drink on da house—good friends justa da same.”
于是马丁轻松自在地把酒喝了，以显示他跟店老板是好朋友，然后没吃晚饭就上床去睡觉了。 So Martin drank, in his easy way, to show that he was good friends with the house, and then went supperless to bed.
马丁之前去买蔬菜的那个水果店是由一个美国人经营的。他做生意的原则观念很弱，让马丁的账单积到了五美元才停止他赊账。面包店老板到两美元就不让再赊了，肉铺老板到四美元就不让再赊了。马丁把他欠下的债加起来，发现自己向所有人总共欠了十四美元八十美分。他那台打字机的租期也快满了，但是他估摸着还能靠赊账再租两个月，那就是八美元。等到那时，他所有能赊的账就都赊了。 The fruit store, where Martin had bought his vegetables, was run by an American whose business principles were so weak that he let Martin run a bill of five dollars before stopping his credit.The baker stopped at two dollars, and the butcher at four dollars.Martin added his debts and found that he was possessed of a total credit in all the world of fourteen dollars and eighty-five cents.He was up with his type-writer rent, but he estimated that he could get two months’ credit on that, which would be eight dollars.When that occurred, he would have exhausted all possible credit.
从水果店最后买的东西是一袋土豆。整整一个星期他就吃土豆，每天三餐除了土豆什么也没有。偶尔在鲁思家吃一顿饭帮助他保持体力，虽然他发现要克制自己不再多吃实在够折磨人的。一看到这么多食物摊在面前，他的胃口就一发不可收。尽管内心的羞愧令他十分难受，但他还是经常赶着饭点去拜访他姐姐，敢吃多少就吃多少——比他在莫尔斯家餐桌上胆子大，吃得多。 The last purchase from the fruit store had been a sack of potatoes, and for a week he had potatoes, and nothing but potatoes, three times a day.An occasional dinner at Ruth’s helped to keep strength in his body, though he found it tantalizing enough to refuse further helping when his appetite was raging at sight of so much food spread before it.Now and again, though afflicted with secret shame, he dropped in at his sister’s at meal-time and ate as much as he dared—more than he dared at the Morse table.
他每天都工作着，邮差却每天都递送给他被退回的稿件。他再也没钱买邮票了，于是那些稿子就在桌下积了一大堆。有一天他四十个小时都没能吃上一点食物。他不能指望到鲁思家蹭饭吃，因为她出门了，到圣·拉斐尔家做客两个星期。由于实在太羞愧，他也不能到他姐姐家去。不幸到极点的是，邮差在他下午的那轮递送里给他带来了五份退稿。之后，马丁穿上外套到奥克兰去了，回来的时候大衣没有了，但他的口袋里有五个美元叮当作响。他付给四家店老板每人一美元还债，并在他的厨房里煎了牛排和洋葱，煮了咖啡，炖了一大锅西梅干。吃过晚饭之后，他在他的餐桌兼书桌前坐了下来，在午夜前完成了一篇他命名为《高利贷的尊严》的文章。文章打出来之后，他就把它丢到桌下，因为那五美元已经一分都不剩了，买不起邮票。 Day by day he worked on, and day by day the postman delivered to him rejected manuscripts.He had no money for stamps, so the manuscripts accumulated in a heap under the table.Came a day when for forty hours he had not tasted food.He could not hope for a meal at Ruth’s, for she was away to San Rafael on a two weeks’ visit; and for very shame’s sake he could not go to his sister’s.To cap misfortune, the postman, in his afternoon round, brought him five returned manuscripts.Then it was that Martin wore his overcoat down into Oakland, and came back without it, but with five dollars tinkling in his pocket.He paid a dollar each on account to the four tradesmen, and in his kitchen fried steak and onions, made coffee, and stewed a large pot of prunes.And having dined, he sat down at his table-desk and completed before midnight an essay which he entitled “The Dignity of Usury.”Having typed it out, he flung it under the table, for there had been nothing left from the five dollars with which to buy stamps.
后来他又当掉了他的手表，再后来是他的自行车。他给他所有的稿子都贴了邮票，寄出去了，这样他可以用来买食物的钱又少了。他对卖文作品感到失望。没有人想买。他拿自己的卖文之作跟他在报纸、周刊和廉价杂志里找出来的文章进行比较，觉得自己的写得更好，而且比平常之作好得多。然而，他的文章就是卖不出去。后来他发现大多数报纸都发表一大堆可称为“流行版”的东西。他找到了那家供稿协会的地址。他寄到那里的作品被退了回来，一同寄回来的还有一张模式化的便条，通知他说需要的所有稿子都是由协会人员提供的。 Later on he pawned his watch, and still later his wheel, reducing the amount available for food by putting stamps on all his manuscripts and sending them out.He was disappointed with his hack-work.Nobody cared to buy.He compared it with what he found in the newspapers, weeklies, and cheap magazines, and decided that his was better, far better, than the average; yet it would not sell.Then he discovered that most of the newspapers printed a great deal of what was called “plate” stuff, and he got the address of the association that furnished it.His own work that he sent in was returned, along with a stereotyped slip informing him that the staff supplied all the copy that was needed.
在一家大型少年期刊上，他注意到有整栏整栏的故事和轶闻。这是一个机会。可他那些短文又被退了会来。尽管他一次又一次地努力，却从来也没能成功地登出过一篇文章。后来，这都没所谓了，他才得知那些协会编辑和副编辑通过自己供稿来增加他们的工资。那些诙谐搞笑的周刊退回了他的笑话和幽默短诗，他给大杂志写的轻松抒情诗也没有找到可刊登之处。接下来是报纸上的微型小故事。他知道自己能够写得比发表出来的那些好。于是他设法找到了两家报业联合协会的地址，给它们寄去了大量的微型小故事。当他写了二十篇却连一篇都没有被刊登出来时，他放弃了。然而，他还是每天都读日报和周刊上的那些微型小故事，许许多多的小故事，里头没有一篇能够和他写的相媲美。心灰意冷之中，他得出结论：他根本就没有任何判断能力，他被自己所写的那些东西施了催眠术，他是个自欺欺人的冒充者。 In one of the great juvenile periodicals he noted whole columns of incident and anecdote.Here was a chance.His paragraphs were returned, and though he tried repeatedly he never succeeded in placing one.Later on, when it no longer mattered, he learned that the associate editors and sub-editors augmented their salaries by supplying those paragraphs themselves.The comic weeklies returned his jokes and humorous verse, and the light society verse he wrote for the large magazines found no abiding-place.Then there was the newspaper storiette.He knew that he could write better ones than were published.Managing to obtain the addresses of two newspaper syndicates, he deluged them with storiettes.When he had written twenty and failed to place one of them, he ceased.And yet, from day to day, he read storiettes in the dailies and weeklies, scores and scores of storiettes, not one of which would compare with his.In his despondency, he concluded that he had no judgment whatever, that he was hypnotized by what he wrote, and that he was a self-deluded pretender.
冷酷无情的“编辑机器”还是照常顺利运作着。他把邮票跟他的稿子一起装好，丢进了邮筒里。在之后的三个星期到一个月之间，邮递员陆续登门把稿子送回给他。想必那一头肯定不会有任何活着的有热度的编辑。那里全都是轮子、轮齿和注油杯——一个由机器人操作的巧妙装置。他已经绝望到了怀疑编辑到底存不存在的地步。他从来没有发现有任何一个编辑存在的迹象。他写的所有东西都被毫无理由地拒绝了，从这点来看，说编辑是虚构的事物似乎也可信，他们是那些办公室勤杂工、排字工和印刷工编出来、传出来的。 The inhuman editorial machine ran smoothly as ever.He folded the stamps in with his manuscript, dropped it into the letter-box, and from three weeks to a month afterward the postman came up the steps and handed him the manuscript.Surely there were no live, warm editors at the other end.It was all wheels and cogs and oil-cups—a clever mechanism operated by automatons.He reached stages of despair wherein he doubted if editors existed at all.He had never received a sign of the existence of one, and from absence of judgment in rejecting all he wrote it seemed plausible that editors were myths, manufactured and maintained by office boys, typesetters, and pressmen.
他和鲁思一起度过的时光是他唯一拥有的快乐时光，但两人并非都快乐。总有一种令人苦恼的不安之感折磨着他，比起他得到她的爱之前的那些往昔，这感觉现在更加折磨人。因为现在他得到了她的爱，而离得到她却比从前更遥远。他要求给他两年的时间；时间飞逝，他却一事无成。何况他一直意识到一件事实：她不赞成他正在做的事情。她没有直接说。但是她间接地让他了解到这一点，就如她直接说出来一样清晰明确。尽管脾气不好的女人的怨恨之处对于她来说只是失望，但她对他不是怨恨，而是不满。她失望是因为这个她要进行塑造的男人拒绝被塑造。在一定程度上，她发现他这块黏土富有可塑性，然后它开始变得顽固了，拒绝被塑造成他父亲或者巴特勒先生的形象。 The hours he spent with Ruth were the only happy ones he had, and they were not all happy.He was afflicted always with a gnawing restlessness, more tantalizing than in the old days before he possessed her love; for now that he did possess her love, the possession of her was far away as ever.He had asked for two years; time was flying, and he was achieving nothing.Again, he was always conscious of the fact that she did not approve what he was doing.She did not say so directly.Yet indirectly she let him understand it as clearly and definitely as she could have spoken it.It was not resentment with her, but disapproval; though less sweet-natured women might have resented where she was no more than disappointed.Her disappointment lay in that this man she had taken to mould, refused to be moulded.To a certain extent she had found his clay plastic, then it had developed stubbornness, declining to be shaped in the image of her father or of Mr. Butler.
他身上的伟大和坚强，她看不到；或许还更糟糕，她产生了误解。他这块陶土有如此的可塑性，以至于他能够生活在任何一个人类生活的圈子里。她认为他倔强任性、顽固不化，那是因为她不能够把他塑造得跟她那个生活圈子相适应，而那又是她唯一知道的一个生活圈子。她不能理解他飞翔一般灵动的思想，当他的思想超越了她的，她就觉得变化无常。没有其他任何人的思想能超越她的。她总能够理解她父亲、母亲、兄弟和奥尔尼的思想。因此当她不能理解马丁的思想时，她就认定问题出现在马丁身上。自身狭隘却试图充当襟怀开阔者的导师，这是一个古老的悲剧。 What was great and strong in him, she missed, or, worse yet, misunderstood.This man, whose clay was so plastic that he could live in any number of pigeonholes of human existence, she thought wilful and most obstinate because she could not shape him to live in her pigeonhole, which was the only one she knew.She could not follow the flights of his mind, and when his brain got beyond her, she deemed him erratic.Nobody else’s brain ever got beyond her.She could always follow her father and mother, her brothers and Olney; wherefore, when she could not follow Martin, she believed the fault lay with him.It was the old tragedy of insularity trying to serve as mentor to the universal.
“你在正统思想的圣坛前顶礼膜拜。”他曾经告诉她，那次他们讨论了普拉普斯和万德沃特。“我承认，作为用来引证的权威，他们两个是极为出色的——两位美国最前列的文学评论家。美国这片土地上每一位教学的老师都敬仰万德沃特，将其视为美国批评学界的领袖。但是我读了他的东西，觉得那似乎淋漓尽致、恰如其分地展现了一个无聊之人。怎么不是呢，他不过是个沉闷的老八股，多亏吉利特·伯吉斯这么评价他。普拉普斯也好不到哪里去。比如他的《毒芹苔》就写得很美。一个逗号都没用错地方，那调子——啊！——确实崇高，如此崇高。 “You worship at the shrine of the established,” he told her once, in a discussion they had over Praps and Vanderwater.“I grant that as authorities to quote they are most excellent—the two foremost literary critics in the United States.Every school teacher in the land looks up to Vanderwater as the Dean of American criticism.Yet I read his stuff, and it seems to me the perfection of the felicitous expression of the inane.Why, he is no more than a ponderous bromide, thanks to Gelett Burgess.And Praps is no better.His @Hemlock Mosses@， for instance is beautifully written.Not a comma is out of place; and the tone—ah!—is lofty, so lofty.
他是美国稿酬最高的评论家。不过，万分遗憾！他根本算不上评论家。在英国，人家的评论做得更出色。” He is the best-paid critic in the United States.Though, Heaven forbid!he’s not a critic at all.They do criticism better in England.
“可是关键在于他们吹奏的是大众的调子，他们吹奏的那么美妙、那么高尚、那么自得。他们的评论让我想到《英国周日报》。他们就是庸俗大众的代言人。他们给你们那些英文教授撑腰，你们那些教授又给他们撑腰。他们任何一者的脑袋里都没有独创性的见解。他们只知道那些正统思想——事实上，他们自己代表了正统思想。他们头脑愚笨，正统思想很容易烙到他们身上，就跟啤酒厂的名称印到啤酒瓶上一样容易。他们的作用是抓住所有上大学的年轻人，除去他们脑中有可能存在的任何一丁点闪光的独创性，再给他们打上正统思想的印戳。” “But the point is, they sound the popular note, and they sound it so beautifully and morally and contentedly.Their reviews remind me of a @British Sunday@.They are the popular mouthpieces.They back up your professors of English, and your professors of English back them up.And there isn’t an original idea in any of their skulls.They know only the established,—in fact, they are the established.They are weak minded, and the established impresses itself upon them as easily as the name of the brewery is impressed on a beer bottle.And their function is to catch all the young fellows attending the university, to drive out of their minds any glimmering originality that may chance to be there, and to put upon them the stamp of the established.”
“我认为我比你更接近于真理，”她回答，“我站在正统思想这一边，而你却像一个反传统的南太平洋岛民一样四处抨击别人。” “I think I am nearer the truth,” she replied, “when I stand by the established, than you are, raging around like an iconoclastic South Sea Islander.”
“传教士才会打碎偶像呢。”他大笑道。“不幸的是，所有的传教士都跑到异教徒当中去了，因此没有一个留在本教来打破这些旧偶像——万德沃特先生和普拉普斯先生。” “It was the missionary who did the image breaking,” he laughed.“And unfortunately, all the missionaries are off among the heathen, so there are none left at home to break those old images, Mr. Vanderwater and Mr. Praps.”
“还有那些大学教授也是。”她补充说。 “And the college professors, as well,” she added.
他使劲摇了摇头，说：“不，那些教自然科学的教师应当存在。他们是真正了不起的。不过那些教英文的教授十个里头有九个都是心胸狭隘的学舌鹦鹉，将这帮人的脑袋破一破会是件好事。” He shook his head emphatically.“No; the science professors should live.They’re really great.But it would be a good deed to break the heads of nine-tenths of the English professors—little, microscopic-minded parrots!”
这话是对教授们相当尖刻的批评，而鲁思听起来则是一种亵渎。她忍不住要拿那些教授来跟马丁比较。前者整洁利落，具有学者风度，衣着合体，说起话来声音抑扬顿挫，谈吐风雅高尚；而后者是个几乎难以形容的小伙子，那个她不知为何就爱上的人。他的衣服从来没有合过他的身；他结实的肌肉说明他工作极其辛苦；他说着说着就会变得很激动，就会用咒骂来代替平静的陈述，用激烈的言辞来代替冷静的自制。前者至少收入丰厚，而且都是些绅士——是的，她强迫自己面对这一现实。而他却一分钱都赚不到，他比不上他们。 Which was rather severe on the professors, but which to Ruth was blasphemy.She could not help but measure the professors, neat, scholarly, in fitting clothes, speaking in well-modulated voices, breathing of culture and refinement, with this almost indescribable young fellow whom somehow she loved, whose clothes never would fit him, whose heavy muscles told of damning toil, who grew excited when he talked, substituting abuse for calm statement and passionate utterance for cool self-possession.They at least earned good salaries and were—yes, she compelled herself to face it—were gentlemen; while he could not earn a penny, and he was not as they.
她并不是通过马丁的言辞和论点本身来权衡和评价它们的。她通过外层表象的对比得出的结论：马丁的论点是错误的。真的，她都是无意识的。而那些教授，他们的文学评判是正确的，因为他们获得了成功。马丁的文学评判是错误的，因为他的作品卖不出去。用他自己的话来说就是，他的作品是成功的，但他却是不成功的。再说，似乎没有道理是他对。就在很短的一段时间之前，他站在这个同样的屋子里，被人介绍，又脸红又别扭，惶恐地望着他周围的那些小摆设，生怕自己晃动的肩膀会打碎它们。他问斯温伯恩的死是在多久之前，还自夸地宣称他读过《精益求精》和《生命的圣歌》。 She did not weigh Martin’s words nor judge his argument by them.Her conclusion that his argument was wrong was reached—unconsciously, it is true—by a comparison of externals.They, the professors, were right in their literary judgments because they were successes.Martin’s literary judgments were wrong because he could not sell his wares.To use his own phrase, they made good, and he did not make good.And besides, it did not seem reasonable that he should be right—he who had stood, so short a time before, in that same living room, blushing and awkward, acknowledging his introduction, looking fearfully about him at the bric-a-brac his swinging shoulders threatened to break, asking how long since Swinburne died, and boastfully announcing that he had read @Excelsior@ and the @Psalm of Life@.
无意之中，鲁思自己证明了他的观点：她对正统思想顶礼膜拜。马丁跟着她的思路走，却不允许走得更远。他爱她不是因为她对普拉普斯、万德沃特和那些英文教授有怎样的看法。他逐渐意识到，而且是信心日益坚定地意识到，自己拥有的思维领域和知识广度是她永远也无法理解的，她甚至连它们的存在都无法知道。 Unwittingly, Ruth herself proved his point that she worshipped the established.Martin followed the processes of her thoughts, but forbore to go farther.He did not love her for what she thought of Praps and Vanderwater and English professors, and he was coming to realize, with increasing conviction, that he possessed brain-areas and stretches of knowledge which she could never comprehend nor know existed.
在音乐方面，她觉得他不讲道理；至于歌剧方面，那就不仅是不讲道理了，简直就是顽固不化。 In music she thought him unreasonable, and in the matter of opera not only unreasonable but wilfully perverse.
“你觉得怎样？”一天晚上在看完歌剧回家的路上，她问他。 “How did you like it?” she asked him one night, on the way home from the opera.
那个晚上，为了约她出来，他花了一个月辛辛苦苦从食物上攒出来的钱。她等着他说些相关的评论，却是徒然。而她自己还在颤抖，为刚刚所看到的、听到的那些而激动不已。于是，她问了这个问题。 It was a night when he had taken her at the expense of a month’s rigid economizing on food.After vainly waiting for him to speak about it, herself still tremulous and stirred by what she had just seen and heard, she had asked the question.
“我喜欢序曲部分，”他回答，“真是妙极了。” “I liked the overture,” was his answer.“It was splendid.”
“是的，可歌剧本身如何呢？” “Yes, but the opera itself?”
“也很美妙。我想说，管弦乐队演奏得很美妙，可是如果那些蹦来蹦去的人能闭上嘴或者从舞台上离开，我就更喜欢了。” “That was splendid too; that is, the orchestra was, though I’d have enjoyed it more if those jumping-jacks had kept quiet or gone off the stage.”
鲁思惊呆了。 Ruth was aghast.
“你不是指塔卓兰尼或巴瑞罗吧？”她问。 “You don’t mean Tetralani or Barillo?” she queried.
“全都是——整一帮人。” “All of them—the whole kit and crew.”
“可他们都是伟大的艺术家啊。”她抗议道。 “But they are great artists,” she protested.
“他们也一样用他们夸张到滑稽的不真实的表演破坏了音乐。” “They spoiled the music just the same, with their antics and unrealities.”
“难道你不喜欢巴瑞罗的歌喉吗？”鲁思又问。 “But don’t you like Barillo’s voice?” Ruth asked.
“他们说，他仅次于卡罗素。” “He is next to Caruso, they say.”
“我当然喜欢他，我甚至更喜欢塔卓兰尼。她的嗓音很美妙——至少我是这么觉得。” “Of course I liked him, and I liked Tetralani even better.Her voice is exquisite—or at least I think so.”
“可是——可是——”鲁思都结巴了，“那我就不明白你的意思了。 你称赞他们的歌喉，却又说他们破坏了音乐。” “But, but—” Ruth stammered.“I don’t know what you mean, then.You admire their voices, yet say they spoiled the music.”
“正是如此，为了在演唱会上听他们唱歌，我愿意付出任何代价；可是为了不在管弦乐队演奏中听到他们的歌声，我愿意付出更大的代价。恐怕我是个不可救药的现实主义者吧。伟大的歌唱家并不是伟大的演员。听到巴瑞罗用天使般的声音唱一段爱情歌剧，听到塔卓兰尼像另一个天使般回答，听到绚烂多彩的音乐如一场彻底的狂欢伴随着这一切——实在是令人陶醉，心醉神迷。我不是承认这一点。我是坚信这一点。可当我看到他们的人时，整个效果都被破坏了——塔卓兰尼身高五英尺十英寸，体重却有一百九十英磅，而巴瑞罗身高不足五英尺四英寸，脸上油亮亮的，还有一个矮胖铁匠的胸脯。看看他们这一对，装腔作势，抓着胸脯，像疯人院里的神经病一样在空中挥舞他们的手臂。这时候指望我把这所有一切都当成一个恋爱场面的忠实展现来接受——一位窈窕动人的公主和一位英俊潇洒的王子，啊，我接受不了，就是这样。这是荒唐的、愚蠢可笑的、毫不真实的。问题就出在这里。它不真实。别告诉我这个世界上会有任何人是这么谈恋爱的。怎么可能！如果我是这样跟你谈恋爱的话，你早就扇我耳光了。” “Precisely that.I’d give anything to hear them in concert, and I’d give even a bit more not to hear them when the orchestra is playing.I’m afraid I am a hopeless realist.Great singers are not great actors.To hear Barillo sing a love passage with the voice of an angel, and to hear Tetralani reply like another angel, and to hear it all accompanied by a perfect orgy of glowing and colorful music—is ravishing, most ravishing.I do not admit it.I assert it.But the whole effect is spoiled when I look at them—at Tetralani, five feet ten in her stocking feet and weighing a hundred and ninety pounds, and at Barillo, a scant five feet four, greasy-featured, with the chest of a squat, undersized blacksmith, and at the pair of them, attitudinizing, clasping their breasts, flinging their arms in the air like demented creatures in an asylum;and when I am expected to accept all this as the faithful illusion of a love-scene between a slender and beautiful princess and a handsome, romantic, young prince—why, I can’t accept it, that’s all.It’s rot; it’s absurd; it’s unreal.That’s what’s the matter with it.It’s not real.Don’t tell me that anybody in this world ever made love that way.Why, if I’d made love to you in such fashion, you’d have boxed my ears.”
“可是你理解错了。”鲁思反驳道。“每一种艺术都有它的局限性。”（她匆忙回忆着自己在大学听过的一场关于艺术传统的演讲。）“例如油画，画布上只有二维的空间，而你却接受假想出来的三维空间，那是画家的艺术使他能够在画布上展现这一幻象。再比如写作，作家必须无所不能。你理所当然地接受作者对女主人公隐秘心理活动的描写，可是自始至终你都知道女主人公在进行这些心理活动时，她是独自一人的。无论是作者还是其他任何人都无法听到这些想法。还有舞台表演、雕塑和歌剧也是如此，每一种艺术形式都是如此。某些无法调和的东西必须被接受。” “But you misunderstand,” Ruth protested.“Every form of art has its limitations.”(She was busy recalling a lecture she had heard at the university on the conventions of the arts.) “In painting there are only two dimensions to the canvas, yet you accept the illusion of three dimensions which the art of a painter enables him to throw into the canvas.In writing, again, the author must be omnipotent.You accept as perfectly legitimate the author’s account of the secret thoughts of the heroine, and yet all the time you know that the heroine was alone when thinking these thoughts, and that neither the author nor any one else was capable of hearing them.And so with the stage, with sculpture, with opera, with every art form.Certain irreconcilable things must be accepted.”
“是的，我懂，”马丁回答说，“一切艺术都有它们的传统。”（他的这个用词让鲁思大吃一惊。他仿佛亲身到大学里学过，而不是在艰苦的条件下从图书馆的书堆里漫无目的地浏览学到的。）“但即使是传统也必须具有真实性。那些画在平纸板上的树木，把它们放到舞台的两侧，我们就当它们是森林。这是一种具有充分真实感的传统。可是，另一方面，我们不会把海洋的场景当成森林。我们做不到。这有悖于我们的常识。你不会，或者更确切地说，你不应该把今天晚上那两个疯子的胡乱叫喊和痛苦的扭摆当成对爱情的有力展现。” “Yes, I understood that,” Martin answered.“All the arts have their conventions.”(Ruth was surprised at his use of the word.It was as if he had studied at the university himself, instead of being ill-equipped from browsing at haphazard through the books in the library.) “But even the conventions must be real.Trees, painted on flat cardboard and stuck up on each side of the stage, we accept as a forest.It is a real enough convention.But, on the other hand, we would not accept a sea scene as a forest.We can’t do it.It violates our senses.Nor would you, or, rather, should you, accept the ravings and writhings and agonized contortions of those two lunatics to-night as a convincing portrayal of love.”
“但是你没有把自己抬得比所有音乐鉴赏家还高吧？”她抗议了。 “But you don’t hold yourself superior to all the judges of music?”she protested.
“不，没有，一刻也没有。我只是行使我作为个人的权利而已。为什么对我来说塔卓兰尼女士如大象般笨拙的跳动破坏了管弦乐队的演奏，为了解释这一点，我刚刚已经说了我的想法。这世上的那些音乐鉴赏家也许都是正确的。不过，我就是我，我不会让自己的品味屈从于人们众口一词的评判。如果我不喜欢一样事物，我就是不喜欢它，如此而已。天底下没有那样的道理说，因为我的大部分同类都喜欢它，或者自认为喜欢它，我就要装出一副也喜欢它的样子。我不能就跟着潮流去喜欢或不喜欢一些事物。” “No, no, not for a moment.I merely maintain my right as an individual.I have just been telling you what I think, in order to explain why the elephantine gambols of Madame Tetralani spoil the orchestra for me.The world’s judges of music may all be right.But I am I, and I won’t subordinate my taste to the unanimous judgment of mankind.If I don’t like a thing, I don’t like it, that’s all; and there is no reason under the sun why I should ape a liking for it just because the majority of my fellow-creatures like it, or make believe they like it.I can’t follow the fashions in the things I like or dislike.”
“可是你知道，音乐是一种训练出来的东西，”鲁思争辩着，“而歌剧就更是训练出来的了。难道就不是因为——” “But music, you know, is a matter of training,” Ruth argued; “and opera is even more a matter of training.May it not be—”
“因为我在歌剧方面没有受过训练？”他马上插了句。 “That I am not trained in opera?” he dashed in.
她点点头。 She nodded.
“正是如此。”他赞同地说，“我认为我在年幼时没有迷上它是一种幸运。如果我在那时就迷上了，那今天晚上我可能也会流下感伤的泪水，之前那两个人小丑般夸张而滑稽的表演可能就增添了他们嗓音中的美，以及伴奏的管弦音乐的美。你是对的。这主要就是个训练的问题。现在我年龄已经太大了。我除了真实的事物其他一概不要。一个没有说服力的虚幻形象就如一个明显的谎言，对我而言，当矮小的巴瑞罗激情荡漾地把壮实的塔卓兰尼（她也是激情满怀）拽到怀里，并告诉塔卓兰尼他对她的爱慕之情是多么强烈时，大歌剧就如一个明显的谎言。” “The very thing,” he agreed.“And I consider I am fortunate in not having been caught when I was young.If I had, I could have wept sentimental tears to-night, and the clownish antics of that precious pair would have but enhanced the beauty of their voices and the beauty of the accompanying orchestra.You are right.It’s mostly a matter of training.And I am too old, now.I must have the real or nothing.An illusion that won’t convince is a palpable lie, and that’s what grand opera is to me when little Barillo throws a fit, clutches mighty Tetralani in his arms (also in a fit), and tells her how passionately he adores her.”
鲁思又一次通过外在表象的比较，并以她对正统思想的信仰为依据来衡量马丁的思想。他是谁呀，凭什么他是对的而所有有教养的人都是错的呢？他的话语和想法没有对她产生任何影响。正统思想在她身上已经是如此根深蒂固，她无法再对革命性的思想怀有任何同情之感。她向来都听惯了音乐，从小就喜爱歌剧，她周围的所有人也都喜爱歌剧。马丁·伊登有什么权利从他的爵士乐和劳动阶级歌曲中冒出来对世界音乐妄加评论呢？他就是最近才从中冒出来的。他令她心生怨怒。走在他身边的时候，她隐约感到有一股怒气。即使是最好的情况下，当她的心灵最柔软的时候，她也认为他的观点是突然产生的想法，是随性的无缘由的玩笑话。但是，在门口，当他把她搂在怀里以恋人的身份跟她深情吻别时，一瞬间涌起对他的爱让她忘记了这一切。的稍后，她躺在枕头上失眠了。她感到很困惑，正是她近来经常有的那种困惑：自己为什么会爱上如此奇特的一个人呢？自己怎么会不顾家人的反对爱上他呢？ Again Ruth measured his thoughts by comparison of externals and in accordance with her belief in the established.Who was he that he should be right and all the cultured world wrong?His words and thoughts made no impression upon her.She was too firmly intrenched in the established to have any sympathy with revolutionary ideas.She had always been used to music, and she had enjoyed opera ever since she was a child, and all her world had enjoyed it, too.Then by what right did Martin Eden emerge, as he had so recently emerged, from his rag-time and working-class songs, and pass judgment on the world’s music?She was vexed with him, and as she walked beside him she had a vague feeling of outrage.At the best, in her most charitable frame of mind, she considered the statement of his views to be a caprice, an erratic and uncalled-for prank.But when he took her in his arms at the door and kissed her good night in tender lover-fashion, she forgot everything in the outrush of her own love to him.And later, on a sleepless pillow, she puzzled, as she had often puzzled of late, as to how it was that she loved so strange a man, and loved him despite the disapproval of her people.
第二天，马丁·伊登把卖文作品丢到一边，奋战一番，反复敲打，写成了一篇文章。他给它取了个题目叫《幻想的哲学》。一张邮票开启了它的旅程，而在接下来的几个月里，它注定还要被贴上许多邮票，去开始许多旅程。 And next day Martin Eden cast hack-work aside, and at white heat hammered out an essay to which he gave the title, “@The Philosophy of Illusion@.”A stamp started it on its travels, but it was destined to receive many stamps and to be started on many travels in the months that followed.
第二十五章 CHAPTER XXV
玛丽亚·席尔瓦很穷，贫穷的种种她都知道得清清楚楚。而对于鲁思，贫穷是一个表示生活条件不舒适的词。那就是她对贫穷的全部了解。她知道马丁很穷。她在自己的脑海中把马丁的状况和亚伯拉罕·林肯、巴特勒先生以及其他一些已获得成功的人们的少年时代联系在一起。尽管她也知道贫穷绝不是什么美事，但作为养尊处优的中产阶层，她觉得贫穷是有益的，它是一种有力的鞭挞，激励所有受苦役却不甘堕落、尚未绝望的人去争取成功。因此，当她得知马丁穷到连他的手表和大衣都当了时，她并不烦忧。她甚至将其视为形势有希望的一面，认为这迟早会唤醒马丁，迫使他放弃写作。 Maria Silva was poor, and all the ways of poverty were clear to her.Poverty, to Ruth, was a word signifying a not-nice condition of existence.That was her total knowledge on the subject.She knew Martin was poor, and his condition she associated in her mind with the boyhood of Abraham Lincoln, of Mr. Butler, and of other men who had become successes.Also, while aware that poverty was anything but delectable, she had a comfortable middle-class feeling that poverty was salutary, that it was a sharp spur that urged on to success all men who were not degraded and hopeless drudges.So that her knowledge that Martin was so poor that he had pawned his watch and overcoat did not disturb her.She even considered it the hopeful side of the situation, believing that sooner or later it would arouse him and compel him to abandon his writing.
鲁思从来没有读懂马丁脸上的饥饿。他的脸变得越来越瘦，两颊上原本浅浅的凹陷已经变得很深了。事实上，注意到他脸上的这一变化时，她感到很满意。从他身上除去了许多无用的肌肉和太像野兽一般的活力，他的脸变得精致了。它们既诱惑着她，又令她感到厌恶。有时候，当跟他在一起的时候，她发现他的眼中闪着一种不寻常的光芒。她倾慕这种光芒，因为它使马丁看上去更像一位诗人、一位学者——他想要成为那样的人，她也希望他成为那样的人。可是玛丽亚·席尔瓦从他那凹陷的双颊和燃烧的目光中读出了一个不同的故事。她注意到，随着马丁钱财的增多或减少，它们每天都在发生变化。她看到他出门时穿着大衣，回来时却没有穿。尽管那天天气阴冷，可她看出他的脸颊微微鼓了一些，眼睛里那股饥饿的火焰也消失了。同样地，她也发现他的自行车和手表不见了，而每一件东西不见了之后，她看到他的活力又充沛了。 Ruth never read hunger in Martin’s face, which had grown lean and had enlarged the slight hollows in the cheeks.In fact, she marked the change in his face with satisfaction.It seemed to refine him, to remove from him much of the dross of flesh and the too animal-like vigor that lured her while she detested it.Sometimes, when with him, she noted an unusual brightness in his eyes, and she admired it, for it made him appear more the poet and the scholar—the things he would have liked to be and which she would have liked him to be.But Maria Silva read a different tale in the hollow cheeks and the burning eyes, and she noted the changes in them from day to day, by them following the ebb and flow of his fortunes.She saw him leave the house with his overcoat and return without it, though the day was chill and raw, and promptly she saw his cheeks fill out slightly and the fire of hunger leave his eyes.In the same way she had seen his wheel and watch go, and after each event she had seen his vigor bloom again.
还有他的辛勤刻苦她也看在眼里，她知道深夜里他的灯要点到什么时候。他是在工作呢！她知道他工作得比自己还卖力，虽然他做的是不同的工作。她也吃惊地发现他吃得越少就工作得越卖力。当她觉得他饿得实在厉害的时候，有时会装作无意地给他送去一长条刚烤的面包，开玩笑说他做不出这么好的面包，以此来笨拙地掩饰她送面包的行为。还有些时候，她会派其中一个孩子给他送去一大罐热汤。她内心经过一番挣扎，这样把食物从自己亲生骨肉的口中夺走到底应不应该呢？马丁也不是不感恩，因为他是如此了解穷人的生活。如果这个世界上确实还有仁慈的话，这就是了。 Likewise she watched his toils, and knew the measure of the midnight oil he burned.Work!She knew that he outdid her, though his work was of a different order.And she was surprised to behold that the less food he had, the harder he worked.On occasion, in a casual sort of way, when she thought hunger pinched hardest, she would send him in a loaf of new baking, awkwardly covering the act with banter to the effect that it was better than he could bake.And again, she would send one of her toddlers in to him with a great pitcher of hot soup, debating inwardly the while whether she was justified in taking it from the mouths of her own flesh and blood.Nor was Martin ungrateful, knowing as he did the lives of the poor, and that if ever in the world there was charity, this was it.
有一天，当她用家里所剩下的食物喂饱了她那群孩子后，玛丽亚又用她最后的十五美分买了一加仑廉价葡萄酒。马丁正好到她厨房里去打水，便被邀请坐下来喝一杯。他敬了一杯，祝她身体健康。她回敬了一杯。然后她又喝了一杯祝他事业有成，而他则祝愿詹姆斯·格兰特会现身，付给她洗衣服的工钱。詹姆斯·格兰特是一个四处流浪的木匠，他时不时地会欠账，一共欠了玛丽亚三美元。 On a day when she had filled her brood with what was left in the house, Maria invested her last fifteen cents in a gallon of cheap wine.Martin, coming into her kitchen to fetch water, was invited to sit down and drink.He drank her very-good health, and in return she drank his.Then she drank to prosperity in his undertakings, and he drank to the hope that James Grant would show up and pay her for his washing.James Grant was a journeymen carpenter who did not always pay his bills and who owed Maria three dollars.
玛丽亚和马丁都空着肚子在喝这酸酸的新酿的葡萄酒。这酒立刻就进入了他们的脑袋。他们是完全不一样的人，但他们都在各自的痛苦中感到孤单。虽然他们的痛苦都被默默地忽略了，但这条纽带却将他们牵到了一起。得知马丁去过亚速尔群岛，玛丽亚惊呆了，十一岁之前她一直住在那里。一听马丁去过夏威夷群岛，她就更加吃惊了，她和她家人从亚速尔群岛移居之后就是搬到了那里。但是让她感到最为惊讶的是，他告诉她他去过毛伊岛，她是在那个特殊的小岛上长大成人、结婚出嫁的。卡胡卢伊，那是她第一次遇见她丈夫的地方——马丁他竟去过那里两次！是的，她记得那些运糖的轮船，他当过那些船上的水手——呦，呦，这个世界真小！还有怀卢库！那个地方也是！他会不会认识那个种植园里的头头呢？是的，跟他喝过几杯酒。 Both Maria and Martin drank the sour new wine on empty stomachs, and it went swiftly to their heads.Utterly differentiated creatures that they were, they were lonely in their misery, and though the misery was tacitly ignored, it was the bond that drew them together.Maria was amazed to learn that he had been in the Azores, where she had lived until she was eleven.She was doubly amazed that he had been in the Hawaiian Islands, whither she had migrated from the Azores with her people.But her amazement passed all bounds when he told her he had been on Maui, the particular island whereon she had attained womanhood and married.Kahului, where she had first met her husband,—he, Martin, had been there twice!Yes, she remembered the sugar steamers, and he had been on them—well, well, it was a small world.And Wailuku!That place, too!Did he know the head-luna of the plantation?Yes, and had had a couple of drinks with him.
于是，他们开始缅怀过去，将他们的饥饿浸没在酸酸的新葡萄酒里。对马丁来说，未来似乎并不那么暗淡无望。成功就在他面前颤动。他就要将它抓住了。他审视着自己眼前这个饱受苦难的女人那皱纹深嵌的脸，想起她的热汤和新鲜出炉的长条面包，感到体内涌起一股最为温暖的感激和博爱之情。 And so they reminiscenced and drowned their hunger in the raw, sour wine.To Martin the future did not seem so dim.Success trembled just before him.He was on the verge of clasping it.Then he studied the deep-lined face of the toil-worn woman before him, remembered her soups and loaves of new baking, and felt spring up in him the warmest gratitude and philanthropy.
“玛丽亚，”他忽然大声说道，“你会想要什么呢？” “Maria,” he exclaimed suddenly.“What would you like to have?”
她望着他，困惑不已。 She looked at him, bepuzzled.
“你现在想要什么呢，就现在，如果你能够得到的话？” “What would you like to have now, right now, if you could get it?”
“鞋子，每个孩子都要——七双鞋子。” “Shoe alla da roun’ for da childs—seven pairs da shoe.”
“你会有的。”他宣布，而她则郑重其事地点了点头。“但我指的是一个大愿望，你想要的大件的东西。” “You shall have them,” he announced, while she nodded her head gravely.“But I mean a big wish, something big that you want.”
她的眼中闪烁着和善的光芒。他是要跟玛丽亚开玩笑呢，近来很少有人跟她开玩笑了。 Her eyes sparkled good-naturedly.He was choosing to make fun with her, Maria, with whom few made fun these days.
“好好想想。”她正要开口说时，他提醒道。 “Think hard,” he cautioned, just as she was opening her mouth to speak.
“好的，”她回答，“我仔细想想。我想要一所房子，这所房子——整栋都归我，不用付每月七美元的房租。” “Alla right,” she answered.“I thinka da hard.I lika da house, dis house—all mine, no paya da rent, seven dollar da month.”
“你会得到这所房子的，”他应允了，“很快就能得到了。现在许个大大的愿望。就当我是上帝，我跟你说你想要任何东西都会给你。那么你许愿要一样东西吧，我听着。” “You shall have it,” he granted, “and in a short time.Now wish the great wish.Make believe I am God, and I say to you anything you want you can have.Then you wish that thing, and I listen.”
玛丽亚非常认真地想了一会儿。 Maria considered solemnly for a space.
“你不会被吓到吧？”她用警告的语气问。 “You no ’fraid?” she asked warningly.
“不会，不会，”他大笑起来，“我都不会被吓到。尽管说吧。” “No, no,” he laughed, “I’m not afraid.Go ahead.”
“非常非常大呢。”她再次警告道。 “Most verra big,” she warned again.
“没关系。尽管说好了。” “All right.Fire away.”
“好吧，那——”她跟个孩子似的深深吸了口气，仿佛她要尽最大的可能说出她想要从生活中得到的一切。“我想要一个养奶牛的大牧场——一个很好的奶牛大牧场。有好多的奶牛，好多的牧地，好多的牧草。我希望它能在圣里安附近，我姐姐住在那里。我会在奥克兰买牛奶。我会挣好多钱。乔和尼克就不用放牛了。他们可以去上学。或许他们不久后还能成为优秀的工程师，造铁路。对，我想要一个养奶牛的大牧场。” “Well, den—” She drew a big breath like a child, as she voiced to the uttermost all she cared to demand of life.“I lika da have one milka ranch—good milka ranch.Plenty cow, plenty land, plenty grass.I lika da have near San Le-an; my sister liva dere.I sella da milk in Oakland.I maka da plentee mon.Joe an’ Nick no runna da cow.Dey go-a to school.Bimeby maka da good engineer, worka da railroad.Yes, I lika da milka ranch.”
她停顿了下来，用亮闪闪的眼睛望着马丁。 She paused and regarded Martin with twinkling eyes.
“你一定会有的。”他马上回答道。 “You shall have it,” he answered promptly.
她点点头，礼貌地用嘴唇碰了碰酒杯，敬那位礼物的送出者，尽管她知道这礼物永远也不会被送出。他的用心是好的，她在心里感激他的这番用意，就跟礼物真的送给了她一样。 She nodded her head and touched her lips courteously to the wine-glass and to the giver of the gift she knew would never be given.His heart was right, and in her own heart she appreciated his intention as much as if the gift had gone with it.
“不，玛丽亚，”他继续说，“尼克和乔不用再去卖牛奶了，所有的孩子都能够去上学，一年到头都有鞋子穿。那将会是个一流的奶牛场——一应俱全。会有一所用来住的房子，一个马厩，当然，还有几个牛棚。那里会有鸡，有猪，有蔬菜，有果树，以及类似的所有一切。奶牛会有很多，足以请上一两个雇工。到时除了照顾孩子你什么事都不用做了。因此，如果找得到一个好男人，你就可以再嫁，让他去照看农场，活个轻松自在。” “No, Maria,” he went on; “Nick and Joe won’t have to peddle milk, and all the kids can go to school and wear shoes the whole year round.It will be a first-class milk ranch—everything complete.There will be a house to live in and a stable for the horses, and cow-barns, of course.There will be chickens, pigs, vegetables, fruit trees, and everything like that; and there will be enough cows to pay for a hired man or two.Then you won’t have anything to do but take care of the children.For that matter, if you find a good man, you can marry and take it easy while he runs the ranch.”
从他的未来送出这样一份厚礼之后，马丁转身拿出自己仅有的一套体面衣裳到当铺去了。他这么做是困境中的绝望之举，因为这将使他无法再跟鲁思见面。他没有第二套漂亮衣服可以上得了台面。尽管他仍然可以到肉铺和面包店去，甚至可以偶尔去一趟他姐姐家，但要穿着这么寒酸的衣服到莫尔斯家里去，他是做梦也不敢的。 And from such largess, dispensed from his future, Martin turned and took his one good suit of clothes to the pawnshop.His plight was desperate for him to do this, for it cut him off from Ruth.He had no second-best suit that was presentable, and though he could go to the butcher and the baker, and even on occasion to his sister’s, it was beyond all daring to dream of entering the Morse home so disreputably apparelled.
他继续卖力工作，觉得痛苦而近乎无望。他似乎开始意识到第二场仗他也输了，他将不得不去找份活干了。他这样做就能使每个人都满意——杂货店老板、他姐姐、鲁思，甚至玛丽亚，他已经欠了她一个月的房租钱。他那台打字机也已经欠了两个月的租金了，出租商一直吵着要求他交租或者把机器还回去。绝望之下，他几乎只能投降了。他打算跟命运休战直到获得新的机会，便参加了铁路邮政所的文职考试。让他大为吃惊的是，他考了第一名。工作有着落了，尽管谁也不知道什么时候会通知他上岗。 He toiled on, miserable and well-nigh hopeless.It began to appear to him that the second battle was lost and that he would have to go to work.In doing this he would satisfy everybody—the grocer, his sister, Ruth, and even Maria, to whom he owed a month’s room rent.He was two months behind with his type-writer, and the agency was clamoring for payment or for the return of the machine.In desperation, all but ready to surrender, to make a truce with fate until he could get a fresh start, he took the civil service examinations for the Railway Mail.To his surprise, he passed first.The job was assured, though when the call would come to enter upon his duties nobody knew.
就在这个时候，在他处于最低谷的时候，那台向来运作顺畅的“编辑机器”出了问题。肯定是某个轮齿打滑了，或者某个油杯的油用干了。因为有天上午邮差给他送来了一封薄薄的短信件。马丁瞥了一眼信封的左上角，看到是《洲际月刊》的名称和地址。他的心猛地一跳，他忽然觉得要晕厥过去了，伴随着这种下沉的感觉，他的膝盖奇怪地颤抖起来。他跌跌撞撞地走进自己的房间，坐在床上，信封还没有拆开。那一刻他才明白，为什么人们会因为接到异乎寻常的好消息而突然死去。 It was at this time, at the lowest ebb, that the smooth-running editorial machine broke down.A cog must have slipped or an oil-cup run dry, for the postman brought him one morning a short, thin envelope.Martin glanced at the upper left-hand corner and read the name and address of the @Transcontinental Monthly@.His heart gave a great leap, and he suddenly felt faint, the sinking feeling accompanied by a strange trembling of the knees.He staggered into his room and sat down on the bed, the envelope still unopened, and in that moment came understanding to him how people suddenly fall dead upon receipt of extraordinarily good news.
这当然是个好消息啦。薄薄的信封里没有稿子，因此这必然是一封采用通知了。他知道《洲际月刊》收到的是哪个故事。是那篇《钟声》，他的一篇惊悚故事，足足有五千字。既然一流杂志都是一经采用就支付稿费，那里头就是一张支票了。每个字两美分——一千字二十美元，那这就是张一百美元的支票了。一百美元呢！在他拆开信封的时候，他欠下的所有账都一笔笔地涌现在他的脑海里——杂货店老板3.85美元,肉铺老板4美元，面包店老板2美元，水果店老板5美元，总共是14.85美元。然后还有房租费2.50美元，并预付下个月的2.50美元；两个月的打印机租金8美元，也预付一个月4美元；一共是31.85美元。最好还要加上他那些典当物的赎金和利息，付给当铺老板——手表5.50美元，大衣5.50美元，自行车7.75美元，一套衣服5.50美元(百分之六十的利息，可那又算得了什么呢。）———大总数是56.10美元。 Of course this was good news.There was no manuscript in that thin envelope, therefore it was an acceptance.He knew the story in the hands of the Transcontinental.It was “The Ring of Bells,” one of his horror stories, and it was an even five thousand words.And, since first-class magazines always paid on acceptance, there was a check inside.Two cents a word—twenty dollars a thousand; the check must be a hundred dollars.One hundred dollars!As he tore the envelope open, every item of all his debts surged in his brain—$3.85 to the grocer; butcher $4.00 flat; baker, $2.00; fruit store, $5.00; total, $14.85.Then there was room rent, $2.50; another month in advance, $2.50; two months’ type-writer, $8.00; a month in advance, $4.00; total, $31.85.And finally to be added, his pledges, plus interest, with the pawnbroker—watch, $5.50; overcoat, $5.50; wheel, $7.75; suit of clothes, $5.50 (60 % interest, but what did it matter?)—grand total, $56.10.
他看到——仿佛就在他跟前的空气里能看到——那些发光的数字：一个总数经过一次次相减给出一个43.90美元的剩余数字。等他还清了每一笔债，赎回了每一件典当物，他口袋里还会有一笔43.90美元的大钱叮当作响。除此之外，他还预付了一个月的房租和打字机的租费。 He saw, as if visible in the air before him, in illuminated figures, the whole sum, and the subtraction that followed and that gave a remainder of $43.90.When he had squared every debt, redeemed every pledge, he would still have jingling in his pockets a princely $43.90.And on top of that he would have a month’s rent paid in advance on the type-writer and on the room.
这时他已经抽出了那单张的信纸，信是由打字机打出来。他把它展开。没有支票。他仔细瞧了瞧信封里头，又把它拿到灯光下看，却无法相信自己眼睛。他颤抖着，着急地撕开了信封。没有支票。他读着信，一行行地匆匆浏览，从编辑对他故事的赞美飞快奔向信的主旨：说明为什么没有寄出支票。他没有找到这样的说明，但是他找到了一样令他顿时颓然的东西。信从他手中滑了下来。他的眼睛失去了光泽，他躺倒在枕头上，将毯子拉过来盖住自己，一直盖到下巴。 By this time he had drawn the single sheet of type-written letter out and spread it open.There was no check.He peered into the envelope, held it to the light, but could not trust his eyes, and in trembling haste tore the envelope apart.There was no check.He read the letter, skimming it line by line, dashing through the editor’s praise of his story to the meat of the letter, the statement why the check had not been sent.He found no such statement, but he did find that which made him suddenly wilt.The letter slid from his hand.His eyes went lack-lustre, and he lay back on the pillow, pulling the blanket about him and up to his chin.
《钟声》才值五美元——五千个字才值五美元。不是两美分一个字，而是十个字一美分！而且编辑对它大加赞美。故事发表的时候，他才会收到支票。最低稿费每个字两美分，采用即付——都是一派胡言。这是个谎言，它将他引入歧途。早知如此，他绝不会去尝试写作的。他会去工作——为了鲁思而工作。他回忆他最初尝试写作的那一天，惊奇地发现自己竟浪费了那么多时间——全是为了这十个字一美分的结果。他曾经读到过有其他稿酬丰厚的作家，那肯定也都是谎话。他那些关于写作的二手信息是错误的，这就是证据。 Five dollars for “The Ring of Bells”—five dollars for five thousand words!Instead of two cents a word, ten words for a cent!And the editor had praised it, too.And he would receive the check when the story was published.Then it was all poppycock, two cents a word for minimum rate and payment upon acceptance.It was a lie, and it had led him astray.He would never have attempted to write had he known that.He would have gone to work—to work for Ruth.He went back to the day he first attempted to write, and was appalled at the enormous waste of time—and all for ten words for a cent.And the other high rewards of writers, that he had read about, must be lies, too.His second-hand ideas of authorship were wrong, for here was the proof of it.
《洲际月刊》单册售价是二十五美分，它那高雅华美的封面表明它属于一流的杂志。它是一家正儿八经的体面杂志，从创刊以来一直连续出版。你瞧，每期杂志的封面上都印着一位世界级伟大作家的评语，声明着《洲际月刊》的神圣使命。而这些话都出自文坛巨星之口，他们都是在这份每期封面都相同的杂志里崭露头角的。然而，《洲际月刊》这份受天之启示的高雅杂志竟然给的稿费是五千字五美元。马丁记得，最近有位在国外去世的大作家，死的时候穷困潦倒。考虑到作家们收到的“巨额”稿费，这也就没什么好奇怪的了。 The @Transcontinental@ sold for twenty-five cents, and its dignified and artistic cover proclaimed it as among the first-class magazines.It was a staid, respectable magazine, and it had been published continuously since long before he was born.Why, on the outside cover were printed every month the words of one of the world’s great writers, words proclaiming the inspired mission of the @Transcontinental@ by a star of literature whose first coruscations had appeared inside those self-same covers.And the high and lofty, heaven-inspired @Transcontinental@ paid five dollars for five thousand words!The great writer had recently died in a foreign land—in dire poverty, Martin remembered, which was not to be wondered at, considering the magnificent pay authors receive.
好吧，是他上了当。在作家以及支付给他们的稿费上，报社撒了谎，而他竟为此浪费了两年时间。但他现在不会再上这个当了。一句话他也不会再写了。他会去做鲁思想要他做的那些事，做大家都想要他做的那些事——找一份工作。去工作的念头让他想起了乔——那个在无所事事、流荡的乔。马丁重重地叹了一口，充满了羡慕之情。那么多天都是每天工作十九小时，这在他身上发生了强烈的反应。可是，乔没有恋爱，没有任何爱的负担，而且他可以在那个无事可做的地方到处闲混。而马丁呢，他有奋斗的目标，而且他就要去工作了。他明天一大早就去找工作。他还会让鲁思知道，他已经改过自新了，他愿意到他父亲的办公室去工作。 Well, he had taken the bait, the newspaper lies about writers and their pay, and he had wasted two years over it.But he would disgorge the bait now.Not another line would he ever write.He would do what Ruth wanted him to do, what everybody wanted him to do—get a job.The thought of going to work reminded him of Joe—Joe, tramping through the land of nothing-to-do.Martin heaved a great sigh of envy.The reaction of nineteen hours a day for many days was strong upon him.But then, Joe was not in love, had none of the responsibilities of love, and he could afford to loaf through the land of nothing-to-do.He, Martin, had something to work for, and go to work he would.He would start out early next morning to hunt a job.And he would let Ruth know, too, that he had mended his ways and was willing to go into her father’s office.
五千字才五美元，十个字才一分钱，这就是艺术在市场上的价钱。其中的失望，其中的谎言，其中的耻辱，在他想来已是到了极至。在他闭着的眼皮下，燃烧着几个火焰般的数字——“3.85美元”，那是他欠杂货店老板的钱。他打了个寒颤，觉得自己的骨头里一阵疼痛。特别是他的腰，疼得厉害。他的头也很疼，头顶疼，后脑勺疼，里头的脑子疼，似乎在膨胀着。而他的眉毛处更是疼得难以忍受。眉毛下面，他的眼睑底下，挥之不去是那个无情的“3.85美元”。他睁开眼睛想避开它，可是房间里那个白色的光芒仿佛要灼伤他的眼球，使他不得不闭上眼睛，然后那个“3.85美元”就又一次出现在了他面前。 Five dollars for five thousand words, ten words for a cent, the market price for art.The disappointment of it, the lie of it, the infamy of it, were uppermost in his thoughts; and under his closed eyelids, in fiery figures, burned the “$3.85” he owed the grocer.He shivered, and was aware of an aching in his bones.The small of his back ached especially.His head ached, the top of it ached, the back of it ached, the brains inside of it ached and seemed to be swelling, while the ache over his brows was intolerable.And beneath the brows, planted under his lids, was the merciless “$3.85.”He opened his eyes to escape it, but the white light of the room seemed to sear the balls and forced him to close his eyes, when the “$3.85” confronted him again.
五千字才五美元，十个字才一美分——这个特别的念想在他的脑子里“住”了下来。他无法逃避这个念想，就像他无法逃避他眼皮底下的那个“3.85美元”一样。后者似乎发生了什么变化。他好奇地望着，直到代替它燃烧的变成了一个“2.00美元”。啊，他想，那是欠面包店老板的。下一个出现的数目是“2.50美元”。这个数字把他困住了，他深深地思索着，仿佛生死就悬在对它的解答上。他欠了某个人两美元五十美分，那是肯定的，但到底是欠谁的呢？找出其答案是专横而恶毒的宇宙交给他的任务。他的思绪就如无尽的长廊，他在里头游走，打开各种各样装着零碎记忆和知识的房间及卧室，寻找答案，却是白费力气。恍如过了几个世纪，他这才轻轻松松、毫不费力地记起来，那是欠玛丽亚的。他如释重负，将自己的灵魂转移到他眼睑下令人备受折磨的屏幕前。他把问题解决了，现在他可以休息了。但并不是如此，那个“2.50美元”渐渐消失了，在它原来的地方燃烧着一个“8.00美元”。那是欠谁的啊？他必须再沿着自己的思绪郁闷地走上一圈，把答案找出了。 Five dollars for five thousand words, ten words for a cent—that particular thought took up its residence in his brain, and he could no more escape it than he could the “$3.85” under his eyelids.A change seemed to come over the latter, and he watched curiously, till “$2.00” burned in its stead.Ah, he thought, that was the baker.The next sum that appeared was “$2.50.”It puzzled him, and he pondered it as if life and death hung on the solution.He owed somebody two dollars and a half, that was certain, but who was it?To find it was the task set him by an imperious and malignant universe, and he wandered through the endless corridors of his mind, opening all manner of lumber rooms and chambers stored with odds and ends of memories and knowledge as he vainly sought the answer.After several centuries it came to him, easily, without effort, that it was Maria.With a great relief he turned his soul to the screen of torment under his lids.He had solved the problem; now he could rest.But no, the “$2.50” faded away, and in its place burned “$8.00.”Who was that?He must go the dreary round of his mind again and find out.
他不知道自己在这场探寻中跋涉了多久，但似乎是过了好长好长的一段时间他才在一阵敲门声中回过神来。是玛丽亚，她问他是不是病了。他用一个自己都认不出来的模模糊糊的声音回答，说他只是打个盹而已。他惊讶地发现房间里已经是夜色漆黑了。他下午两点就收到信了。他意识到自己生病了。 How long he was gone on this quest he did not know, but after what seemed an enormous lapse of time, he was called back to himself by a knock at the door, and by Maria’s asking if he was sick.He replied in a muffled voice he did not recognize, saying that he was merely taking a nap.He was surprised when he noted the darkness of night in the room.He had received the letter at two in the afternoon, and he realized that he was sick.
之后那个“8.00美元”又开始在他的眼睑下慢慢燃烧起来。于是他让自己回到了奴役之中。不过，他变聪明了。他没必要在他的脑子了游走一整圈。他刚才当了回傻瓜。他拖出来一根杠杆，让他的脑子里的那些东西围着他转，一个巨大的命运轮盘，一个记忆的旋转木马，一个智慧的滚动球体。它转得越来越快，直到它的漩涡将他吸了进去。他被抛到里面，旋转着穿过一片片黑色的混沌。 Then the “$8.00” began to smoulder under his lids again, and he returned himself to servitude.But he grew cunning.There was no need for him to wander through his mind.He had been a fool.He pulled a lever and made his mind revolve about him, a monstrous wheel of fortune, a merry-go-round of memory, a revolving sphere of wisdom.Faster and faster it revolved, until its vortex sucked him in and he was flung whirling through black chaos.
极其自然地，他发现自己站在一个碾压机跟前，压上了浆了袖口。可是他注意到那些袖口上印着数字。这是用来标记衣物的新方法吧，他这么想，直到靠近了些看发现一只袖口上标着“3.85美元”。这时他才明白那是欠杂货店老板的账单，而那些在碾压机滚筒上飞快滚过的是他的账单。他想出了一个狡猾的主意。他要把账单都丢到地板上，那么就不用还这些债了。想到就干，他恶狠狠地把那些袖口揉成一团一团的，扔到肮脏不堪的地板上。那堆东西变得越来越大。虽然每张账单都复制了一千份，但他只认出了一张两美元五十美分的账单，那是他欠玛丽亚的。那说明玛丽亚是不会逼着他还债的，但他大方地决定他唯一会还的就是欠玛丽亚的帐。于是他开始从那堆丢出去的袖口里搜寻她的账单。他不顾一切地搜寻着，找了好几年。直到酒店经理——一个胖胖的荷兰人——进来的时候，他还在搜寻。他的脸上满是怒火，他叫嚷着，高亮的嗓门震得天摇地动：“我要从你的工资里扣除这些袖口的本钱。”那堆袖口变成了一座山，马丁知道他注定要干上一千年的苦力才能还清这些袖口钱。好吧，除了杀死经理、烧掉洗衣房没有别的办法了。可是壮硕的经理打败了他，抓着他的颈项将他拎上又拎下。他把马丁揪到熨衣板上，揪到炉子上、碾压机上，揪到外面的洗衣房里，揪到绞衣机和洗衣机上。马丁被晃得直到牙齿打颤，脑袋发痛，他惊讶于这个荷兰人的强壮。 Quite naturally he found himself at a mangle, feeding starched cuffs.But as he fed he noticed figures printed in the cuffs.It was a new way of marking linen, he thought, until, looking closer, he saw “$3.85” on one of the cuffs.Then it came to him that it was the grocer’s bill, and that these were his bills flying around on the drum of the mangle.A crafty idea came to him.He would throw the bills on the floor and so escape paying them.No sooner thought than done, and he crumpled the cuffs spitefully as he flung them upon an unusually dirty floor.Ever the heap grew, and though each bill was duplicated a thousand times, he found only one for two dollars and a half, which was what he owed Maria.That meant that Maria would not press for payment, and he resolved generously that it would be the only one he would pay; so he began searching through the cast-out heap for hers.He sought it desperately, for ages, and was still searching when the manager of the hotel entered, the fat Dutchman.His face blazed with wrath, and he shouted in stentorian tones that echoed down the universe, “I shall deduct the cost of those cuffs from your wages!”The pile of cuffs grew into a mountain, and Martin knew that he was doomed to toil for a thousand years to pay for them.Well, there was nothing left to do but kill the manager and burn down the laundry.But the big Dutchman frustrated him, seizing him by the nape of the neck and dancing him up and down.He danced him over the ironing tables, the stove, and the mangles, and out into the wash-room and over the wringer and washer.Martin was danced until his teeth rattled and his head ached, and he marvelled that the Dutchman was so strong.
然后，他发现自己又站在碾压机前了，这次是接一个编辑从另一边喂过来的袖口。每只袖口都是一张支票，马丁紧张地查看着，满怀热切的期望，但这些支票都是空白的。他站在那里，接这些空白支票接了大概一百万年，一张都没有漏掉，唯恐错过了哪一张填好的。最后他终于找到了一张填好的。他用颤抖的手把它拿到灯光下。那是一张五美元的支票。“哈哈！哈哈！”碾压机对面的那个编辑大笑起来。 And then he found himself before the mangle, this time receiving the cuffs an editor of a magazine was feeding from the other side.Each cuff was a check, and Martin went over them anxiously, in a fever of expectation, but they were all blanks.He stood there and received the blanks for a million years or so, never letting one go by for fear it might be filled out.At last he found it.With trembling fingers he held it to the light.It was for five dollars.“Ha!Ha!” laughed the editor across the mangle.
“哼，既然如此，我要杀了你。”马丁说。他跑到洗衣房里去拿斧子，发现乔正在浆稿子。他试图让乔停下来，就用斧头向他挥去。可这武器在半空中挺住了，因为马丁发现自己又回到了熨衣间，处在一片暴风雪之中。不，那落下来的不是雪，而是大额支票，金额最小的也有一千美元。他开始收集整理那些支票，每一百张捆成一扎，每一扎都用双股线捆得牢牢的。 “Well, then, I shall kill you,” Martin said.He went out into the wash-room to get the axe, and found Joe starching manuscripts.He tried to make him desist, then swung the axe for him.But the weapon remained poised in mid-air, for Martin found himself back in the ironing room in the midst of a snow-storm.No, it was not snow that was falling, but checks of large denomination, the smallest not less than a thousand dollars.He began to collect them and sort them out, in packages of a hundred, tying each package securely with twine.
他从这一任务中抬起头来，看到乔站在他面前，正在拿熨斗、浆过衬衫及稿子玩杂耍。他时不时地伸出手，添一捆支票到那些被抛起的各式物品中。抛掷物急剧增多，变成一个穿过屋顶的巨型圆圈，超出了视线。马丁朝他砍去，可是斧子被他一把抓走，加入了那个飞动的圆圈中。然后他抓起马丁，把马丁也扔了上去。马丁穿过屋顶去抓那些稿子，于是到他下来的时候他已经抓了大大的一抱。可刚刚下来他又被抛上去了，第二次、第三次……他在这个圆圈里飞了无数回。他能够听从到远处传来的一个高音童声，它在唱着：“跟我一起跳华尔兹，再转一圈，威利，一圈一圈又一圈。” He looked up from his task and saw Joe standing before him juggling flat-irons, starched shirts, and manuscripts.Now and again he reached out and added a bundle of checks to the flying miscellany that soared through the roof and out of sight in a tremendous circle.Martin struck at him, but he seized the axe and added it to the flying circle.Then he plucked Martin and added him.Martin went up through the roof, clutching at manuscripts, so that by the time he came down he had a large armful.But no sooner down than up again, and a second and a third time and countless times he flew around the circle.From far off he could hear a childish treble singing: “Waltz me around again, Willie, around, around, around.”
他从那一条由支票、上浆衬衫和上浆稿子组成的银河里重新找出了那把斧子，准备下去的时候杀了乔。可是他没有再下来。反而是玛丽亚，她透过薄薄的隔板墙听到了他的呻吟，于是凌晨两点的时候到他房里来，在他的身体上敷上“热熨斗”，在他疼痛的眼睛上放上湿布。 He recovered the axe in the midst of the Milky Way of checks, starched shirts, and manuscripts, and prepared, when he came down, to kill Joe.But he did not come down.Instead, at two in the morning, Maria, having heard his groans through the thin partition, came into his room, to put hot flat-irons against his body and damp cloths upon his aching eyes.
第二十六章 CHAPTER XXVI
那天早上，马丁·伊登没出去找工作。近傍晚时，他才从精神混乱中清醒过来，用疼痛的眼睛注视着房间的四周。席尔瓦家那群孩子中有一个正看护着他。那孩子叫玛丽，八岁，看到马丁恢复了意识，大叫起来。玛丽亚从厨房急匆匆地赶到了房间里。她将她那只因劳作而长满老茧的手放到他滚烫的前额上，搭了搭他的脉搏。 Martin Eden did not go out to hunt for a job in the morning.It was late afternoon before he came out of his delirium and gazed with aching eyes about the room.Mary, one of the tribe of Silva, eight years old, keeping watch, raised a screech at sight of his returning consciousness.Maria hurried into the room from the kitchen.She put her work-calloused hand upon his hot forehead and felt his pulse.
“你想吃点东西吗？”她问。 “You lika da eat?” she asked.
他摇了摇头。他现在最不想的就是吃东西，他真怀疑自己这辈子曾经饿过。 He shook his head.Eating was farthest from his desire, and he wondered that he should ever have been hungry in his life.
“我生病了，玛丽亚，”他虚弱地说，“是什么病呢？你知道吗？” “I’m sick, Maria,” he said weakly.“What is it?Do you know?”
“是流感。”她回答，“两三天你就会全好了。你现在最好还是别吃东西吧。过不了多久就可以吃很多东西了，也许明天就可以了。” “Grip,” she answered.“Two or three days you alla da right.Better you no eat now.Bimeby plenty can eat, to-morrow can eat maybe.”
马丁对生病不太习惯，当玛丽亚和她家那小姑娘离开之后，他试图起床穿衣服。凭借最大的意志力，他才从床上爬起来，可后脑勺疼得厉害，眼睛也疼得睁不开。他意识不清，只能靠到桌上，动弹不得。半个小时之后他才好不容易躺回床上。躺在那里，闭上眼睛，分析自己身上各种疼痛和疲惫，他觉得很满足。玛丽亚几次走进来给他换额头上用来冷敷的布块。其他时候，她就让他安安静静地躺着。她很聪明，不会拿话茬吵他。这让他很感激。他一边还自己咕哝着：“玛丽亚，你会有一个奶牛大农场的，一定给你，一定给你。” Martin was not used to sickness, and when Maria and her little girl left him, he essayed to get up and dress.By a supreme exertion of will, with rearing brain and eyes that ached so that he could not keep them open, he managed to get out of bed, only to be left stranded by his senses upon the table.Half an hour later he managed to regain the bed, where he was content to lie with closed eyes and analyze his various pains and weaknesses.Maria came in several times to change the cold cloths on his forehead.Otherwise she left him in peace, too wise to vex him with chatter.This moved him to gratitude, and he murmured to himself, “Maria, you getta da milka ranch, all righta, all right.”
接着他记起了那个被久久埋藏在过去的昨天。 Then he remembered his long-buried past of yesterday.
从他收到《洲际月刊》那封来信起似乎已经过了一辈子；从结束那一切、放弃那一切起，仿佛已经过了一辈子。新的一页打开了。他已经使出过自己的全力了，不遗余力地，而现在，他躺下了。要不是他让自己挨饿，是不会患上流感的。他已经被整垮了，他没有力气把那些侵入自己体内的病毒赶出去。这就是结果。 It seemed a life-time since he had received that letter from the @Transcontinental@, a life-time since it was all over and done with and a new page turned.He had shot his bolt, and shot it hard, and now he was down on his back.If he hadn’t starved himself, he wouldn’t have been caught by La Grippe.He had been run down, and he had not had the strength to throw off the germ of disease which had invaded his system.This was what resulted.
“写一整图书馆的书，却丢了自己的性命，这对一个人来说有什么好处呢？”他大声问道。 “What does it profit a man to write a whole library and lose his own life?” he demanded aloud.
“这里没有我的容身之处。我的世界里再也不会有文学这东西了。我就该到会计室去管账，拿月薪，和鲁思组建一个小家庭。” “This is no place for me.No more literature in mine.Me for the counting-house and ledger, the monthly salary, and the little home with Ruth.”
两天以后，他吃了一个鸡蛋、两片面包，喝了一杯茶，并要了他的邮件，却发现自己的眼睛还是疼得没法读信。 Two days later, having eaten an egg and two slices of toast and drunk a cup of tea, he asked for his mail, but found his eyes still hurt too much to permit him to read.
“你给我读读，玛丽亚，”他说，“不用管那些很长的大封信件。把它们丢到桌子底下好了。给我读读那些小封的信件。” “You read for me, Maria,” he said.“Never mind the big, long letters.Throw them under the table.Read me the small letters.”
“我不会读，”她回答，“特里萨，她在上学，她会读。” “No can,” was the answer.“Teresa, she go to school, she can.”
于是特里萨·席尔瓦，一个九岁的孩子，拆开他的信，读给他听。他心不在焉地听完一封打字机租借处寄来的长长的讨债信，脑子里正忙着想找工作的各种办法。突然他被震惊到了，清醒过来。 So Teresa Silva, aged nine, opened his letters and read them to him.He listened absently to a long dun from the type-writer people, his mind busy with ways and means of finding a job.Suddenly he was shocked back to himself.
“‘我们愿意向你出价四十美元，来买你故事的所有连载权，’”特里萨慢慢地读出来，“条件是你同意我们在建议改动之处做一些修改。” “‘We offer you forty dollars for all serial rights in your story,’” Teresa slowly spelled out, “‘provided you allow us to make the alterations suggested.’”
“那是哪家杂志？”马丁大叫道。 “What magazine is that?” Martin shouted.
“拿过来，把它给我！” “Here, give it to me!”
这会儿，他能看着信读了，他没意识到这个动作产生的疼痛。是《白鼠》杂志要给他四十美元的稿费，买下的那个故事是《漩涡》，是他早期写的另一个恐怖故事。他把信通读了一遍又一遍。编辑直白地告诉他，他对故事的构思处理得不够恰当，不过他们要买的就是故事的构思，因为它很有创意。如果能把故事删掉三分之一，他们就会买下它，收到他答复的时候给他四十美元。 He could see to read, now, and he was unaware of the pain of the action.It was the @White Mouse@ that was offering him forty dollars, and the story was “The Whirlpool,” another of his early horror stories.He read the letter through again and again.The editor told him plainly that he had not handled the idea properly, but that it was the idea they were buying because it was original.If they could cut the story down one-third, they would take it and send him forty dollars on receipt of his answer.
他要了笔和墨水，写信告诉编辑，如果需要的话他可以把故事的三个三分之一都删去，并让他马上把四十美元寄过来。 He called for pen and ink, and told the editor he could cut the story down three-thirds if he wanted to, and to send the forty dollars right along.
信由特里萨投到信箱里了，马丁躺在那儿，思索着。这终究不是个谎言。《白鼠》就是一采用稿子就立刻付钱的。《漩涡》这故事有三千字。删掉三分之一，就还剩两千字。给四十美元的话，那就是两美分一个字。稿子一经采用立刻付酬，每一个字两美分——报纸上说的是真话。他原本以为《白鼠》是一家三流的杂志呢。很明显他不了解那些杂志。他把《洲际月刊》当成了一家一流杂志，可它付的稿酬是十个字一美分。他曾把《白鼠》归到毫不重要的那类杂志社里头，可它付的稿酬比《洲际月刊》高出二十倍，而且一采用就付钱。 The letter despatched to the letter-box by Teresa, Martin lay back and thought.It wasn’t a lie, after all.The @White Mouse@ paid on acceptance.There were three thousand words in “@The Whirlpool@.”Cut down a third, there would be two thousand.At forty dollars that would be two cents a word.Pay on acceptance and two cents a word—the newspapers had told the truth.And he had thought the @White Mouse@ a third-rater!It was evident that he did not know the magazines.He had deemed the @Transcontinental@ a first-rater, and it paid a cent for ten words.He had classed the @White Mouse@ as of no account, and it paid twenty times as much as the @Transcontinental@ and also had paid on acceptance.
好吧，有一件事是肯定的了：等他病好了，他不会出去找工作。跟《漩涡》一样的精彩故事在他脑袋里还有很多呢，每个四十美元的话，他可以赚到的钱比做任何工作都多得多。就在他以为那一仗打输的时候，仗打赢了。他已经证明了自己的事业。道路很清楚。从《白鼠》开始，他要把杂志一家一家都添进他的雇主单子里。卖文作品可以放到一边。说到卖文作品，那已经浪费了他很多时间，却没给他挣到过一美元的稿费。他要专心致志地写作，写优秀的作品。他要将自己的才华统统施展出来。他希望鲁思可以在那里一起分享他的喜悦。他翻了一遍那些放在床上的信件，发现有一封是鲁思寄来的。信中满是甜蜜的“斥责”，她纳闷是什么让他这么久都没去找她。他怀着爱慕之情重新读了一遍这封信，久久注视着她的字迹，爱她写的一笔一划，最后还吻了她的签名。 Well, there was one thing certain: when he got well, he would not go out looking for a job.There were more stories in his head as good as “The Whirlpool,” and at forty dollars apiece he could earn far more than in any job or position.Just when he thought the battle lost, it was won.He had proved for his career.The way was clear.Beginning with the @White Mouse@ he would add magazine after magazine to his growing list of patrons.Hack-work could be put aside.For that matter, it had been wasted time, for it had not brought him a dollar.He would devote himself to work, good work, and he would pour out the best that was in him.He wished Ruth was there to share in his joy, and when he went over the letters left lying on his bed, he found one from her.It was sweetly reproachful, wondering what had kept him away for so dreadful a length of time.He reread the letter adoringly, dwelling over her handwriting, loving each stroke of her pen, and in the end kissing her signature.
回信的时候，他直言不讳地告诉她，他没有去看她是因为他最好的衣服也已经进了当铺。他告诉她，他生病了，但已经差不多恢复健康了，而且十天或者两周以内（就是信寄到纽约再寄回来的时间内）他就能赎回他的衣服跟她在一起了。 And when he answered, he told her recklessly that he had not been to see her because his best clothes were in pawn.He told her that he had been sick, but was once more nearly well, and that inside ten days or two weeks (as soon as a letter could travel to New York City and return) he would redeem his clothes and be with her.
可是鲁思等不了十天或者两个星期。况且她的恋人生病了。第二天下午，她在阿瑟的陪伴下，坐着莫尔斯家的马车到达了。这让席尔瓦家那帮孩子以及街上所有那些顽童乐翻了天，却让玛丽亚又惊又慌。她扇了那群小席尔瓦们的耳光，因为他们在小小的门廊上围住了来客。她尽力用比平日更糟糕的英语为自己的外表着装而道歉。她的袖子卷起着，手臂上全是肥皂沫，腰间系着一口湿湿的麻布袋，说明她正在做的是什么事。这样两位富贵的年轻人问着要见她的房客，她慌张极了，以至于忘了请他们到小客厅里坐下。进入马丁的房间，他们要先穿过厨房。由于正洗着很多衣服，那儿又热又湿、水汽弥漫。激动之中，玛丽亚把卧室门跟卧室厕所的门弄得卡到一起了。有五分钟，成团的水汽、肥皂泡沫和尘土的气味就通过半开的房门直往病房里涌。 But Ruth did not care to wait ten days or two weeks.Besides, her lover was sick.The next afternoon, accompanied by Arthur, she arrived in the Morse carriage, to the unqualified delight of the Silva tribe and of all the urchins on the street, and to the consternation of Maria.She boxed the ears of the Silvas who crowded about the visitors on the tiny front porch, and in more than usual atrocious English tried to apologize for her appearance.Sleeves rolled up from soap-flecked arms and a wet gunny-sack around her waist told of the task at which she had been caught.So flustered was she by two such grand young people asking for her lodger, that she forgot to invite them to sit down in the little parlor.To enter Martin’s room, they passed through the kitchen, warm and moist and steamy from the big washing in progress.Maria, in her excitement, jammed the bedroom and bedroom-closet doors together, and for five minutes, through the partly open door, clouds of steam, smelling of soap-suds and dirt, poured into the sick chamber.
鲁思成功地右拐左拐再右拐，穿过桌子和床之间的狭窄通道，来到了马丁跟前。不过阿瑟转得过猛，撞到了一些瓶瓶罐罐，那是马丁做饭的角落，于是乒乒乓乓响成一片。阿瑟没有久留。鲁思占去了仅有的那把椅子。完成了他的职责，阿瑟就出去了，站在大门口。席尔瓦家那七个孩子都对他十分好奇，把他围在中间，仿佛观看街边橱窗里的奇珍异品一样盯着他。马车四周围满了十多个街区跑来的孩子，他们热切地等待着发生什么悲剧性的可怕结局。只有举行婚礼和葬礼的时候，才能在他们的大街上看到马车。这回既没有婚事也没有丧事，那么肯定是什么超出他们经历的事，值得好好等一等。 Ruth succeeded in veering right and left and right again, and in running the narrow passage between table and bed to Martin’s side; but Arthur veered too wide and fetched up with clatter and bang of pots and pans in the corner where Martin did his cooking.Arthur did not linger long.Ruth occupied the only chair, and having done his duty, he went outside and stood by the gate, the centre of seven marvelling Silvas, who watched him as they would have watched a curiosity in a side-show.All about the carriage were gathered the children from a dozen blocks, waiting and eager for some tragic and terrible dénouement.Carriages were seen on their street only for weddings and funerals.Here was neither marriage nor death: therefore, it was something transcending experience and well worth waiting for.
马丁一直都疯狂地想着要见鲁思。他本质上是个多情的人，他比平常人更需要同情。他正苦于没有他人的同情——同情对他而言就是思想上的理解。然而，他还没有发现鲁思的同情在很大程度上是一种出于情感和言行得体考虑的同情，源于其温柔善良的本性，而不是她对同情对象的理解。因此，当马丁抓着她的手开心地向她诉说时，她的爱促使她也反过来抓紧了他的手；一看到他的无助和他脸上留下的那些受苦的印记，她的眼睛湿润了，变得泪光闪闪。 Martin had been wild to see Ruth.His was essentially a love-nature, and he possessed more than the average man’s need for sympathy.He was starving for sympathy, which, with him, meant intelligent understanding; and he had yet to learn that Ruth’s sympathy was largely sentimental and tactful, and that it proceeded from gentleness of nature rather than from understanding of the objects of her sympathy.So it was while Martin held her hand and gladly talked, that her love for him prompted her to press his hand in return, and that her eyes were moist and luminous at sight of his helplessness and of the marks suffering had stamped upon his face.
他告诉鲁思他收到了两封稿件接受信，来自《洲际月刊》的那封让他失望透顶，而来自《白鼠》的那封让他欢欣不已，可是，鲁思并没有真正理解他。她听到他说的这些话，知道它们字面的意思，但是她无法跟他一起感受他的失望和喜悦。她不能从自己的身份中脱离出来。她对卖故事给杂志社不感兴趣。对她来说重要的是她的婚事。可她并没有意识到这一点，正如她不会意识到自己渴望马丁找一份工作是出于本能的母性冲动，是在为将来当上母亲做准备。如果用坦率直白的语言告诉她这些，他肯定会脸红的。她可能会变得很生气，宣称自己唯一的兴趣在于她所爱之人，她希望他能够充分施展他的才能。因此，当马丁向她倾吐内心的想法，为自己选择的事业在这世上获得第一次成功而欢欣鼓舞时，鲁思注意到的仅仅是单词本身而已。她不时环顾房间的四周，为自己所看到的这些而感到震惊。 But while he told her of his two acceptances, of his despair when he received the one from the @Transcontinental@, and of the corresponding delight with which he received the one from the @White Mouse@, she did not follow him.She heard the words he uttered and understood their literal import, but she was not with him in his despair and his delight.She could not get out of herself.She was not interested in selling stories to magazines.What was important to her was matrimony.She was not aware of it, however, any more than she was aware that her desire that Martin take a position was the instinctive and preparative impulse of motherhood.She would have blushed had she been told as much in plain, set terms, and next, she might have grown indignant and asserted that her sole interest lay in the man she loved and her desire for him to make the best of himself.So, while Martin poured out his heart to her, elated with the first success his chosen work in the world had received, she paid heed to his bare words only, gazing now and again about the room, shocked by what she saw.
鲁思第一次见到贫穷那张邋遢不堪的脸。在她看来，忍饥挨饿的恋人似乎总是很浪漫，可是她完全不知道那些忍饥挨饿的恋人是怎么过日子的。她做梦也不会想到会是这样。她的目光不停地从房间转移到他身上，然后又移回去。脏衣服的水汽和味道跟着她从厨房一道进入了房间，让人觉得恶心。如果那个讨厌的女人经常洗衣服的话，马丁一定满身是这种气味啦，鲁思想。堕落是如此容易感染。当她看着马丁的时候，她仿佛看到了他周围的环境留在他身上的污迹。她从来没见过他不刮胡子，而现在他脸上长着三天都没刮的胡子，这让她很反感。这不仅使他显出一副阴郁的样子，就跟席尔瓦家的房子一样，从里到外都暗沉沉、脏兮兮的，而且她所厌恶的那种野兽般的力量在他身上也似乎更加突出了。他现在的状况是这样的：那两封稿件被接受的通知信使他得到了证实，他骄傲地跟她讲述着这两封信的事。要是再晚一点，他就会投降了，就会去工作了。如今他会继续在一所糟糕的房子里呆着，一边写作，一边挨饿，这样再过上一个月。 For the first time Ruth gazed upon the sordid face of poverty.Starving lovers had always seemed romantic to her,—but she had had no idea how starving lovers lived.She had never dreamed it could be like this.Ever her gaze shifted from the room to him and back again.The steamy smell of dirty clothes, which had entered with her from the kitchen, was sickening.Martin must be soaked with it, Ruth concluded, if that awful woman washed frequently.Such was the contagiousness of degradation.When she looked at Martin, she seemed to see the smirch left upon him by his surroundings.She had never seen him unshaven, and the three days’ growth of beard on his face was repulsive to her.Not alone did it give him the same dark and murky aspect of the Silva house, inside and out, but it seemed to emphasize that animal-like strength of his which she detested.And here he was, being confirmed in his madness by the two acceptances he took such pride in telling her about.A little longer and he would have surrendered and gone to work.Now he would continue on in this horrible house, writing and starving for a few more months.
“那是什么味道呢？”她忽然问。 “What is that smell?”she asked suddenly.
“玛丽亚洗那些衣服有的会发臭，我想，”他回答，“我已经渐渐习惯那些气味了。” “Some of Maria’s washing smells, I imagine,” was the answer.“I am growing quite accustomed to them.”
“不，不，不是那个。是别的什么东西。一种叫人恶心的霉味。” “No, no; not that.It is something else.A stale, sickish smell.”
回答之前马丁嗅了嗅那里的空气。 Martin sampled the air before replying.
“我闻不出任何其他的东西，除了陈旧烟草的味道。”他宣布说。 “I can’t smell anything else, except stale tobacco smoke,” he announced.
“就是那味道。真叫人难受。你怎么抽那么多烟呢，马丁？” “That’s it.It is terrible.Why do you smoke so much, Martin?”
“我也不知道，只是我孤单的时候会比平时抽得多。而且这个习惯已经养成那么久了。我从年纪很小的时候就学会抽烟了。” “I don’t know, except that I smoke more than usual when I am lonely.And then, too, it’s such a long-standing habit.I learned when I was only a youngster.”
“这不是个好习惯，你知道的，”她责备道，“这真是臭气熏天。” “It is not a nice habit, you know,” she reproved.“It smells to heaven.”
“那是烟草劣质的原因。我只买得起最便宜的。不过等着我拿到那四十美元吧。到时我会抽一个连天使都不觉得难闻的牌子。那不算坏了吧，三天里收到两封采用通知信？那四十五美元能把我所有的债都还清。” “That’s the fault of the tobacco.I can afford only the cheapest.But wait until I get that forty-dollar check.I’ll use a brand that is not offensive even to the angels.But that wasn’t so bad, was it, two acceptances in three days?That forty-five dollars will pay about all my debts.”
“作为两年工作的报酬？”她反问。 “For two years’ work?”she queried.
“不，那是不足一周的活赚到的钱。请把放在桌上另一头的那本书传给我，那本灰色封面的账本。”他打开账本，飞快地翻起了书页。“就是，我没弄错。《钟声》写了四天，《漩涡》写了两天。那就是工作一周赚四十五美元，一个月一百八十美元。那比我能拿到的任何工资都多。更何况，我才刚刚开始呢。我要买给你我希望你拥有的一切，每月一千美元并不算多。每月五百美元工资的话就太少了。四十五美元不过是开头而已。等着吧，我会有大进步的。那时看我飞黄腾达吧。” “No, for less than a week’s work.Please pass me that book over on the far corner of the table, the account book with the gray cover.”He opened it and began turning over the pages rapidly.“Yes, I was right.Four days for ‘The Ring of Bells,’ two days for ‘The Whirlpoo@.’ That’s forty-five dollars for a week’s work, one hundred and eighty dollars a month.That beats any salary I can command.And, besides, I’m just beginning.A thousand dollars a month is not too much to buy for you all I want you to have.A salary of five hundred a month would be too small.That forty-five dollars is just a starter.Wait till I get my stride.Then watch my smoke.”
鲁思理解错了他那句俚语，又回到了抽烟的话题上。 Ruth misunderstood his slang, and reverted to cigarettes.
“你已经抽得够多的了，香烟的牌子不会带来任何改观。那是抽烟本身就不好，无论什么牌子都没用。你就是个烟囱、一座活火山、一个会活动的大烟筒。你真是太让人丢脸了，马丁，亲爱的，你知道自己确实是那样的。” “You smoke more than enough as it is, and the brand of tobacco will make no difference.It is the smoking itself that is not nice, no matter what the brand may be.You are a chimney, a living volcano, a perambulating smoke-stack, and you are a perfect disgrace, Martin dear, you know you are.”
她向他依偎过去，眼神中带着恳求的意味。他看着她娇嫩的脸，望着她晶莹纯澈的眼睛，像过去一样觉得自己配不上她。 She leaned toward him, entreaty in her eyes, and as he looked at her delicate face and into her pure, limpid eyes, as of old he was struck with his own unworthiness.
“我希望你别再抽烟了，”她轻声说，“求你了，为了——我。” “I wish you wouldn’t smoke any more,” she whispered.“Please, for—my sake.”
“好，我不会再抽了，”他大声回答，“你要我做什么事我都会去做，亲爱的，你知道这一点。” “All right, I won’t,” he cried.“I’ll do anything you ask, dear love, anything; you know that.”
一种巨大的诱惑向她袭来。在她坚持不肯让步的时候，她曾多次看到他本性中宽厚随和的一面。她可以肯定，如果自己要求他放弃尝试写作，他会答应她的。就在这迅速流逝的短暂瞬间，话都已颤抖着到了她嘴边。但是她没有说出来。她不够勇敢，没什么胆子。反而，她向他靠了过去，迎着他，在他的臂弯里喃喃地说： A great temptation assailed her.In an insistent way she had caught glimpses of the large, easy-going side of his nature, and she felt sure, if she asked him to cease attempting to write, that he would grant her wish.In the swift instant that elapsed, the words trembled on her lips.But she did not utter them.She was not quite brave enough; she did not quite dare.Instead, she leaned toward him to meet him, and in his arms murmured:—
“你知道，这其实并不是为了我，马丁，而是为了你自己。我非常肯定抽烟会伤害你的身体，再说了，做任何东西的奴隶都不是件好事，做烟毒的奴隶则是最不好的了。” “You know, it is really not for my sake, Martin, but for your own.I am sure smoking hurts you; and besides, it is not good to be a slave to anything, to a drug least of all.”
“我会永远做你的奴隶。”他笑着说。 “I shall always be your slave,” he smiled.
“那样的话，我就要开始发号施令了。” “In which case, I shall begin issuing my commands.”
她调皮地望着他，尽管在内心深处已经后悔自己没有说出自己最大的愿望。 She looked at him mischievously, though deep down she was already regretting that she had not preferred her largest request.
“我活着就是为了服从您的命令，女王陛下。” “I live but to obey, your majesty.”
“好，那么我的第一条命令是：你得天天刮胡子。瞧瞧你，都把我的脸扎成什么样了。” “Well, then, my first commandment is, Thou shalt not omit to shave every day.Look how you have scratched my cheek.”
于是一切就在爱抚和恋人的欢笑中结束了。不过她已经提了一个要求，她不能指望一次提太多。她迫使他不再抽烟了，从中她感到一种女性的骄傲。下次她会劝服他找一份工作，他不是说愿意做她要求的任何事情吗？ And so it ended in caresses and love-laughter.But she had made one point, and she could not expect to make more than one at a time.She felt a woman’s pride in that she had made him stop smoking.Another time she would persuade him to take a position, for had he not said he would do anything she asked?
她从他的身旁离开，探索起这间屋子来。她仔细查看着头顶晾衣绳上的笔记，琢磨着他用滑轮把自行车悬挂在天花板下的秘密。桌子底下那一大堆手稿叫她好不伤心，在她看来，那代表着大量浪费掉的时间。煤油炉子倒是赢得了她的赞赏，可一看食物架，她发现上头是空的。 She left his side to explore the room, examining the clothes-lines of notes overhead, learning the mystery of the tackle used for suspending his wheel under the ceiling, and being saddened by the heap of manuscripts under the table which represented to her just so much wasted time.The oil-stove won her admiration, but on investigating the food shelves she found them empty.
“怎么回事，你什么吃的东西都没有，可怜的宝贝，”她带着善良的怜悯之情说，“你一定在挨饿呢。” “Why, you haven’t anything to eat, you poor dear,” she said with tender compassion.“You must be starving.”
“我把我的食物存放在玛丽亚的箱子和储藏室里了，”他撒了谎，“那里会保存得更好。我没有挨饿的担忧。看看这个。” “I store my food in Maria’s safe and in her pantry,” he lied.“It keeps better there.No danger of my starving.Look at that.”
