她回到他身边，见他在手肘处弯起手臂，他衬衫袖子下的二头肌动了起来，鼓成一块肌肉，结结实实的。这一幕让她很反感。在情感上，她讨厌它。但是她的脉搏、她的血液以及她身体的每一根纤维都热爱它，渴望它。跟过去一样，她无法解释地向他依偎过去，而不是远离他。接下来的那一刻，当他用胳膊紧紧抱住她时，她那关注于生活表象的大脑产生了一种抵触，而她的心——那颗关注于生活本身的女人的心——却获得了胜利的狂喜。就是在这样的时候，她觉得自己对马丁的爱情是最为伟大的，因为当马丁用强壮的胳膊将她搂住，抱紧，用它们狂热的拥抱将她弄疼的时候，那种感觉几乎使她开心得要昏过去。在这种时刻，她为背叛自己的标准、违背自己崇高的理想找到了理由，最重要的是，为暗中忤逆她的父母找到了理由。他们不希望她嫁给这个男人。他们为她爱上马丁而感到震惊。有时，当她不在他身边，头脑冷静理智的时候，这也让她自己感到吃惊，和他在一起的时候，她爱他——事实上，这有时是一种带着懊恼和担忧的爱。不过，爱还是爱，一种强于她自己的爱。 She had come back to his side, and she saw him double his arm at the elbow, the biceps crawling under his shirt-sleeve and swelling into a knot of muscle, heavy and hard.The sight repelled her.Sentimentally, she disliked it.But her pulse, her blood, every fibre of her, loved it and yearned for it, and, in the old, inexplicable way, she leaned toward him, not away from him.And in the moment that followed, when he crushed her in his arms, the brain of her, concerned with the superficial aspects of life, was in revolt; while the heart of her, the woman of her, concerned with life itself, exulted triumphantly.It was in moments like this that she felt to the uttermost the greatness of her love for Martin, for it was almost a swoon of delight to her to feel his strong arms about her, holding her tightly, hurting her with the grip of their fervor.At such moments she found justification for her treason to her standards, for her violation of her own high ideals, and, most of all, for her tacit disobedience to her mother and father.They did not want her to marry this man.It shocked them that she should love him.It shocked her, too, sometimes, when she was apart from him, a cool and reasoning creature.With him, she loved him—in truth, at times a vexed and worried love; but love it was, a love that was stronger than she.
“这个‘流感’算不上什么，”他正说着，“有一点难受，让人头疼得厉害，可没法跟断骨热相比。” “This La Grippe is nothing,” he was saying.“It hurts a bit, and gives one a nasty headache, but it doesn’t compare with break-bone fever.”
“那种病你也得过？”她心不在焉地问，还在沉醉那上天赐予的自我辩解中，她正在他的怀抱中寻求着为自己辩解的理由。 “Have you had that, too?”she queried absently, intent on the heaven-sent justification she was finding in his arms.
就这样，她用心不在焉的问题领着他继续说下去，直到他的话一下子让她惊呆了。 And so, with absent queries, she led him on, till suddenly his words startled her.
他是在夏威夷群岛的其中一个小岛上感染了断骨热，那里住着一个由三十位麻风病人组成的秘密群体。 He had had the fever in a secret colony of thirty lepers on one of the Hawaiian Islands.
“可是你为什么会去哪里呢？”她问。 “But why did you go there?”she demanded.
如此粗心大意不爱护身体简直就跟犯罪一样。 Such royal carelessness of body seemed criminal.
“因为我不知道呀，”他回答，“我根本没想到会有麻风病人。抛下那艘纵帆船上了海滩以后，就往内陆走以便找个藏身之所。连着三天我都靠吃番石榴、金桃娘果子和香蕉维生，这些都是长在热带雨林里的野生植物。第四天我找到了一条小路——仅适合徒步行走的小路。它延往内陆，伸向高处。这正是我想要找的路，路上有新近的行走痕迹。有一段路是顺着山脊的顶部延伸的，那山脊窄得就跟刀刃一般。在山顶处，那小道不足三英尺宽，山脊的两边都是一落万丈的峭壁。要有足够的弹药，一个人就能抵挡住十万大军。” “Because I didn’t know,” he answered.“I never dreamed of lepers.When I deserted the schooner and landed on the beach, I headed inland for some place of hiding.For three days I lived off guavas, ohia-apples, and bananas, all of which grew wild in the jungle.On the fourth day I found the trail—a mere foot-trail.It led inland, and it led up.It was the way I wanted to go, and it showed signs of recent travel.At one place it ran along the crest of a ridge that was no more than a knife-edge.The trail wasn’t three feet wide on the crest, and on either side the ridge fell away in precipices hundreds of feet deep.One man, with plenty of ammunition, could have held it against a hundred thousand.
“那是通往藏身地的唯一一条路。找到那条小路三个小时以后，我就到达了那里。那是一个口袋形状的小山谷，周围都是岩浆冷却形成的山峰。那里到处都是种着芋艿和果树的梯田，还有八间或十间草屋。但一看到那些居民我就知道我闯进了什么地方。看他们一眼就足够了。” “It was the only way in to the hiding-place.Three hours after I found the trail I was there, in a little mountain valley, a pocket in the midst of lava peaks.The whole place was terraced for taro-patches, fruit trees grew there, and there were eight or ten grass huts.But as soon as I saw the inhabitants I knew what I’d struck.One sight of them was enough.”
“那你是怎么做的？”鲁思问。她气都不敢喘，只是听着，就像一位苔丝狄蒙娜，既害怕又着迷。 “What did you do?”Ruth demanded breathlessly, listening, like any Desdemona, appalled and fascinated.
“我什么也做不了。他们的首领是一个善良的老头子，病得已经相当严重了，但他还是像国王一样继续统治着。之前他发现了那个小山谷，找到了那个定居之所——这一切都是犯法的。不过他有枪，还有足够的弹药。为了猎杀野牛和野猪，那些夏威夷土著人都训练过，都是神枪手。没办法，马丁·伊登是逃不了了。他只能呆在那儿——呆了三个月。” “Nothing for me to do.Their leader was a kind old fellow, pretty far gone, but he ruled like a king.He had discovered the little valley and founded the settlement—all of which was against the law.But he had guns, plenty of ammunition, and those Kanakas, trained to the shooting of wild cattle and wild pig, were dead shots.No, there wasn’t any running away for Martin Eden.He stayed—for three months.”
“那你是怎么逃出来的呢？” “But how did you escape?”
“要是没有那儿的一个姑娘，我可能现在都还呆在那里呢。她有一半的中国血统，四分之一的白人血统，以及四分之一的夏威夷人血统。她很美丽，而且受过很好的教育。她真是个可怜的人儿。在火奴鲁鲁她母亲有一百万左右的财产。喏，最终这个姑娘把我放走了。你瞧，是她母亲出资建的那个寨子，所以她不怕因放走我而受惩罚。可是她要我先发誓，永远也不把那个藏身地泄露出去。我就一直都没说出去。这是我第一次说起那件事。那个姑娘仅有麻风病初期的症状而已。她右手的手指有些轻微的弯曲，她胳膊上有一个小斑点。仅此而已。我猜她现在已经死了。” “I’d have been there yet, if it hadn’t been for a girl there, a half-Chinese, quarter-white, and quarter-Hawaiian.She was a beauty, poor thing, and well educated.Her mother, in Honolulu, was worth a million or so.Well, this girl got me away at last.Her mother financed the settlement, you see, so the girl wasn’t afraid of being punished for letting me go.But she made me swear, first, never to reveal the hiding-place; and I never have.This is the first time I have even mentioned it.The girl had just the first signs of leprosy.The fingers of her right hand were slightly twisted, and there was a small spot on her arm.That was all.I guess she is dead, now.”
“可是难道你不害怕吗？你没有感染上那种可怕的疾病，难道不会因此而感到高兴吗？” “But weren’t you frightened?And weren’t you glad to get away without catching that dreadful disease?”
“好吧，”他坦白道，“起初我有一点点害怕，可之后就习惯了。不过我曾为那个可怜的姑娘感到惋惜。这是我忘记了害怕。她是如此美丽，灵魂和外貌都很美丽，她只不过受到了轻微的感染。可她却注定要呆在那里了，过着野蛮人的原始生活，慢慢地腐烂死去。麻风病远比你能想象到的要可怕。” “Well,” he confessed, “I was a bit shivery at first; but I got used to it.I used to feel sorry for that poor girl, though.That made me forget to be afraid.She was such a beauty, in spirit as well as in appearance, and she was only slightly touched; yet she was doomed to lie there, living the life of a primitive savage and rotting slowly away.Leprosy is far more terrible than you can imagine it.”
“真是个可怜的人儿，”鲁思柔声低语地说，“她会放你离开可真是个奇迹啊。” “Poor thing,” Ruth murmured softly.“It’s a wonder she let you get away.”
“你指什么意思呢？”马丁不识趣地问。 “How do you mean?”Martin asked unwittingly.
“因为她肯定是爱上你了，”鲁思说，声音还是那么轻柔，“坦白说吧，现在，不是吗？” “Because she must have loved you,” Ruth said, still softly.“Candidly, now, didn’t she?”
在洗衣房里的工作和他现在过的室内生活使马丁原来晒黑的皮肤变白了，再加上挨饿和生病他的脸就更苍白了。此时这张苍白的脸上泛起了一阵红晕。他正要开口说却被鲁思打断了。 Martin’s sunburn had been bleached by his work in the laundry and by the indoor life he was living, while the hunger and the sickness had made his face even pale; and across this pallor flowed the slow wave of a blush.He was opening his mouth to speak, but Ruth shut him off.
“没关系，不要回答了，没必要回答。”她笑起来。 “Never mind, don’t answer; it’s not necessary,” she laughed.
可是在他看来她的笑声似乎有些生硬，而且她的目光是冰冷的。在那个冲动的瞬间他想起了自己曾经在北太平洋上经历的一场大风暴。顿时他眼前就升起了那场风暴的画面——那是一场发生在夜晚的风暴，晴朗无云的天空中挂着一轮圆月，广阔的海洋在月光下闪着冷冷清光。接着他看到了麻风病人藏身地的那个姑娘，想起那是出于对他的爱她才放他走的。 But it seemed to him there was something metallic in her laughter, and that the light in her eyes was cold.On the spur of the moment it reminded him of a gale he had once experienced in the North Pacific.And for the moment the apparition of the gale rose before his eyes—a gale at night, with a clear sky and under a full moon, the huge seas glinting coldly in the moonlight.Next, he saw the girl in the leper refuge and remembered it was for love of him that she had let him go.
“她很高尚，”他简单说道，“她救了我的命。” “She was noble,” he said simply.“She gave me life.”
那就是整件事情，可是他听到鲁思喉咙里隐约发出一阵干涩的抽噎，而且他注意到她把脸转开了凝望着窗户外头。当她再转回来的时候，她已经平静下来了，她的眼睛里一点发生过大波折的迹象都没用。 That was all of the incident, but he heard Ruth muffle a dry sob in her throat, and noticed that she turned her face away to gaze out of the window.When she turned it back to him, it was composed, and there was no hint of the gale in her eyes.
“我太傻了，”她哀伤地说，“可是我没办法。我是那么爱你，马丁，我是真的真的太爱你了。我要慢慢变得更有包容心，可是现在我忍不住要嫉妒那些已化成幽魂的女子，你知道你的过去充满了女子的幽魂。” “I’m such a silly,” she said plaintively.“But I can’t help it.I do so love you, Martin, I do, I do.I shall grow more catholic in time, but at present I can’t help being jealous of those ghosts of the past, and you know your past is full of ghosts.”
“肯定是的，”她不许他出声辩解，“不可能是别的样子。可怜的阿瑟正在催我过去呢。他已经等累了。此刻该说再见了，亲爱的。” “It must be,” she silenced his protest.“It could not be otherwise.And there’s poor Arthur motioning me to come.He’s tired waiting.And now good-by, dear.”
“有一种复方，是药剂师们调制出来的，可以帮人戒烟，”她从门口转过身来说，“我会寄一些给你的。” “There’s some kind of a mixture, put up by the druggists, that helps men to stop the use of tobacco,” she called back from the door, “and I am going to send you some.”
门已经关上了，却又打开。 The door closed, but opened again.
“我真的爱你，真的。”她小声对他说，这次她是真的走了。 “I do, I do,” she whispered to him; and this time she was really gone.
玛丽亚用崇拜的目光目送鲁思上了马车。而且她的目光还十分敏锐，注意到了鲁思衣服的质料和裁法（那是一种不知名的裁法，能产生一种神秘的美丽效应）。那群孩子失望地盯着马车，直到它从视线中消失，然后他们把目光转到了玛丽亚身上。突然间她成了这条街上最重要的人物。可是她其中的一个孩子毁了她的名气，他宣布说那两位富贵的来访者是来看他们家房客的。之后，玛丽亚又回到了她过去默默无闻的状态。而马丁却发现那些无关紧要的街坊邻居人都开始用很尊敬的态度对他。至于玛丽亚，马丁在她心目中的身价上升了百分之一百。如果那个葡萄牙裔的杂货店老板有亲眼见证下午这场“马车拜访”的话，他会让马丁再多赊三美元八十五美分的账。 Maria, with worshipful eyes that none the less were keen to note the texture of Ruth’s garments and the cut of them (a cut unknown that produced an effect mysteriously beautiful), saw her to the carriage.The crowd of disappointed urchins stared till the carriage disappeared from view, then transferred their stare to Maria, who had abruptly become the most important person on the street.But it was one of her progeny who blasted Maria’s reputation by announcing that the grand visitors had been for her lodger.After that Maria dropped back into her old obscurity and Martin began to notice the respectful manner in which he was regarded by the small fry of the neighborhood.As for Maria, Martin rose in her estimation a full hundred per cent, and had the Portuguese grocer witnessed that afternoon carriage-call he would have allowed Martin an additional three-dollars-and-eighty-five-cents’ worth of credit.
第二十七章 CHAPTER XXVII
马丁的幸运太阳要升起来了。鲁思探望过后的第二天，他收到了纽约一家八卦周刊寄来的一张三美元的支票，算是支付他三篇短诗的稿费。又过了两天，一家在芝加哥出版的报社接受了他的那篇《寻宝者》，答应发表之后付十美元作为稿费。稿费有点少，但是这是他写的第一篇文章，是他在刊物上表达自己思想的第一次尝试。最重要的是，这周结束之前，那篇写少年冒险的连载故事，即他第二次尝试写的作品，被一家自称《青春和岁月》的年轻人月刊采用了。确实，这个连载故事有两万一千字，而他们愿意在发表的时候给他十六美元的稿费，也就是差不多一千字七十五美分。不过另一点同样属实，即这是他尝试写下的第二件作品，而且他自己也完全清楚这件作品很拙劣，毫无价值。 The sun of Martin’s good fortune rose.The day after Ruth’s visit, he received a check for three dollars from a New York scandal weekly in payment for three of his triolets.Two days later a newspaper published in Chicago accepted his “Treasure Hunters,” promising to pay ten dollars for it on publication.The price was small, but it was the first article he had written, his very first attempt to express his thought on the printed page.To cap everything, the adventure serial for boys, his second attempt, was accepted before the end of the week by a juvenile monthly calling itself @Youth and Age@.It was true the serial was twenty-one thousand words, and they offered to pay him sixteen dollars on publication, which was something like seventy-five cents a thousand words; but it was equally true that it was the second thing he had attempted to write and that he was himself thoroughly aware of its clumsy worthlessness.
不过即便是他最早期的作品也没有被标上那种平庸的拙劣。它们的特点是由于着力过猛而显得拙劣——是一个新手用攻城槌砸蝴蝶或用巨战木棍描绘小插图时表现出的那种拙劣。因此能低价售出自己的早期作品马丁就很高兴了。他知道它们值多少，他没用多久就明白了这个道理。他把希望寄托在自己后期的作品上。他努力想要成为的不仅是一名小说杂志写手。他试图以艺术技巧为工具来武装自己。另一方面，他却并未舍弃作品中的力量。他的目标一直都很明确，就是通过避免过分着力来提升自己的力量。他也没有脱离自己对现实的热爱。他的作品是现实主义的，尽管他竭力将幻想和想象之美融入到作品中去。他追求的是一种充满激情的现实主义，贯穿着人类的理想与信念。他想要的是生活的本来面貌，保留其中所有的精神探索和心灵追求。 But even his earliest efforts were not marked with the clumsiness of mediocrity.What characterized them was the clumsiness of too great strength—the clumsiness which the tyro betrays when he crushes butterflies with battering rams and hammers out vignettes with a war-club.So it was that Martin was glad to sell his early efforts for songs.He knew them for what they were, and it had not taken him long to acquire this knowledge.What he pinned his faith to was his later work.He had striven to be something more than a mere writer of magazine fiction.He had sought to equip himself with the tools of artistry.On the other hand, he had not sacrificed strength.His conscious aim had been to increase his strength by avoiding excess of strength.Nor had he departed from his love of reality.His work was realism, though he had endeavored to fuse with it the fancies and beauties of imagination.What he sought was an impassioned realism, shot through with human aspiration and faith.What he wanted was life as it was, with all its spirit-groping and soul-reaching left in.
在阅读的过程中，他已经发现小说分为两派。一派将人视为神，忽略他世俗的本源；另一派则把人视为土块，忽略他天授的梦想和神赐的潜能。照马丁的判断，“神派”和“土派”都是错的，错在视角和目的太过单一。有一种接近于事实的折中观点，但它讨好不了“神派”，同时又对“土派”所描写的那种兽式野性提出了挑战。马丁认为就是他那篇名为《冒险》的故事到达了他以小说反应现实的理想境界，但鲁思觉得那故事写得太累赘了。在《天神与土块》一文中，他阐述了自己对这个主题整体全面的看法。 He had discovered, in the course of his reading, two schools of fiction.One treated of man as a god, ignoring his earthly origin; the other treated of man as a clod, ignoring his heaven-sent dreams and divine possibilities.Both the god and the clod schools erred, in Martin’s estimation, and erred through too great singleness of sight and purpose.There was a compromise that approximated the truth, though it flattered not the school of god, while it challenged the brute-savageness of the school of clod.It was his story, “Adventure,” which had dragged with Ruth, that Martin believed had achieved his ideal of the true in fiction; and it was in an essay, “God and Clod,” that he had expressed his views on the whole general subject.
然而《冒险》以及所有他自认为最优秀的作品却还在向各编辑们行乞。除了已经换来的稿酬，他早期的那些作品在他眼里一文不值。他的恐怖小说已经卖出去了两部，但他并不认为那是什么高雅之作，也不是他最优秀的作品。对他来说它们其实都是想象出来的荒诞之作，尽管也充满了现实的魅力，而这才是它们的力量所在。他将这种荒诞不羁与现实的糅合看成一个小把戏——顶多就是一个巧妙的小把戏。伟大的文学是不可能存在于这样一个领域里的。它们的艺术技巧是高超的，但如果艺术技巧脱离了人性，那他就不会认可其中的价值。一直以来这个小把戏给他那些艺术技巧带上了一张人性的面具，他在大约六篇恐怖故事里用过这小把戏。那是他到达《冒险》、《喜悦》、《罐子》和《生命之酒》这些高峰之前写的。 But “Adventure,” and all that he deemed his best work, still went begging among the editors.His early work counted for nothing in his eyes except for the money it brought, and his horror stories, two of which he had sold, he did not consider high work nor his best work.To him they were frankly imaginative and fantastic, though invested with all the glamour of the real, wherein lay their power.This investiture of the grotesque and impossible with reality, he looked upon as a trick—a skilful trick at best.Great literature could not reside in such a field.Their artistry was high, but he denied the worthwhileness of artistry when divorced from humanness.The trick had been to fling over the face of his artistry a mask of humanness, and this he had done in the half-dozen or so stories of the horror brand he had written before he emerged upon the high peaks of “Adventure,” “Joy,” “The Pot,” and “The Wine of Life.”
那些八行两韵诗给他带来了三美元的收入。他用这些钱勉强维持着生计，直至《白鼠》的支票寄到。他在疑心重重的葡萄牙裔杂货店老板那里兑现了第一张支票，付了账上的一美元，把剩下的两美元分别付给了面包店和水果店的老板。马丁还没有富到可以买肉，当《白鼠》的支票寄到时他手头已经很紧了。对于这张支票的兑现他拿不定主意。他这辈子从来也没进过一家银行，更不用说是去办业务了。他有一种天真而稚气的渴望，那就是走进奥克兰的一家大银行，甩出他那张签了字的四十美元支票。另一方面，切合实际的常识告诉他，他应该从那杂货店老板那儿兑现支票，以便给他留下个印象，那以后就能增加赊账的额度了。马丁很不情愿地同意了杂货店老板的要求，付清了他所有的欠账，收了一口袋叮当作响的硬币作为找头。同时，他也付清了欠其他商人的债，赎回了他的衣服和自行车，付了一个月的打印机租金，还付了玛丽亚逾期一个月的租金，并预付了一个月。这样他口袋里就只剩下大概三美元的余额了，那是备着应急的。 The three dollars he received for the triolets he used to eke out a precarious existence against the arrival of the @White Mouse@ check.He cashed the first check with the suspicious Portuguese grocer, paying a dollar on account and dividing the remaining two dollars between the baker and the fruit store.Martin was not yet rich enough to afford meat, and he was on slim allowance when the @White Mouse@ check arrived.He was divided on the cashing of it.He had never been in a bank in his life, much less been in one on business, and he had a naive and childlike desire to walk into one of the big banks down in Oakland and fling down his indorsed check for forty dollars.On the other hand, practical common sense ruled that he should cash it with his grocer and thereby make an impression that would later result in an increase of credit.Reluctantly Martin yielded to the claims of the grocer, paying his bill with him in full, and receiving in change a pocketful of jingling coin.Also, he paid the other tradesmen in full, redeemed his suit and his bicycle, paid one month’s rent on the type-writer, and paid Maria the overdue month for his room and a month in advance.This left him in his pocket, for emergencies, a balance of nearly three dollars.
就其本身而言，这项小小的钱款似乎成了一笔大财富。一取回他衣服，他就去找鲁思了。路上他忍不住捣鼓得自己口袋里那一小把银币叮叮当当响。他都没有钱那么久了，就像一个快饿死的人又被救活了，他不能让还没吃完的食物离开他的视线。马丁无法让自己的手离开那钱。他既不吝啬也不贪婪，但那钱代表的不止是几美元几美分而已。它代表了成功，硬币上印的那几只老鹰对他来说就是那么多长了翅膀的胜利。 In itself, this small sum seemed a fortune.Immediately on recovering his clothes he had gone to see Ruth, and on the way he could not refrain from jingling the little handful of silver in his pocket.He had been so long without money that, like a rescued starving man who cannot let the unconsumed food out of his sight, Martin could not keep his hand off the silver.He was not mean, nor avaricious, but the money meant more than so many dollars and cents.It stood for success, and the eagles stamped upon the coins were to him so many winged victories.
他渐渐才发现这是个很美好的世界。在他看来这世界肯定是变得更美好了。连着好几个星期它都是一个非常沉闷、郁的世界。可如今，几乎所有的债都已经还清了，他口袋里还有三美元在叮当作响，脑海里想到的便是成功；阳光明媚而温暖，一场疾风骤雨淋湿了毫无准备的行人，对他而言甚至那也是一件快乐的事。在自己挨饿的时候，他经常想世界上有成千成千的人都在挨饿，他知道有。可现在既然自己已经填饱了肚子，他脑子里也就不会再想到有成千上万人挨饿的事实了。他忘记了那些人。如今身处爱河的他，记起的是世间无数的恋人。无需刻意去想，爱情诗的各种主题就开始在他脑海中翻滚了。他沉醉在一股创作的激情中，下电车时都已经过了他要下的那个十字路口两个街区，他却并不懊恼。 It came to him insensibly that it was a very good world.It certainly appeared more beautiful to him.For weeks it had been a very dull and sombre world; but now, with nearly all debts paid, three dollars jingling in his pocket, and in his mind the consciousness of success, the sun shone bright and warm, and even a rain-squall that soaked unprepared pedestrians seemed a merry happening to him.When he starved, his thoughts had dwelt often upon the thousands he knew were starving the world over; but now that he was feasted full, the fact of the thousands starving was no longer pregnant in his brain.He forgot about them, and, being in love, remembered the countless lovers in the world.Without deliberately thinking about it, motifs for love-lyrics began to agitate his brain.Swept away by the creative impulse, he got off the electric car, without vexation, two blocks beyond his crossing.
他发现莫尔斯家里来了不少人。鲁思的两个表姐妹从圣拉斐尔赶来看望她。莫尔斯太太便以招待她两为借口，继续实施着用年轻人包围鲁思的计划。计划在马丁被迫离开的时候就已经开始了，现在正进行到高潮。她刻意找一些有所成就的男子到家里来。这样，除了两个表兄多萝西和弗洛伦斯外，她还认识了两个大学教授，分别是教拉丁文的和英文的；一位刚从菲律宾回来的年轻军官，他曾是鲁思的校友；一个叫梅尔维尔的小伙子，他是圣弗朗西斯科信托公司总裁约瑟夫·珀金斯的私人秘书。男性中最后还有一位活力四射的银行高层人员，查尔斯·哈普古德，这个三十五岁尚显年轻的男人毕业于斯坦福大学，是尼罗俱乐部和联合俱乐部的成员，在竞选期间他还是一位稳健的共和党发言人——总之，这是个每个方面都在崛起的年轻人。女性之中有一位是画肖像画的，另一位是职业音乐家，还有一位拥有社会学博士学位——由于她在圣弗朗西斯科贫民窟从事社会安置工作，在当地颇有些名气。不过在莫尔斯太太的计划中女性并不重要。她们最多也就是必要的点缀而已。而那些有所成就的男性怎么着都必须请到家里来。 He found a number of persons in the Morse home.Ruth’s two girl-cousins were visiting her from San Rafael, and Mrs. Morse, under pretext of entertaining them, was pursuing her plan of surrounding Ruth with young people.The campaign had begun during Martin’s enforced absence, and was already in full swing.She was making a point of having at the house men who were doing things.Thus, in addition to the cousins Dorothy and Florence, Martin encountered two university professors, one of Latin, the other of English; a young army officer just back from the Philippines, one-time school-mate of Ruth’s; a young fellow named Melville, private secretary to Joseph Perkins, head of the San Francisco Trust Company;and finally of the men, a live bank cashier, Charles Hapgood, a youngish man of thirty-five, graduate of Stanford University, member of the Nile Club and the Unity Club, and a conservative speaker for the Republican Party during campaigns—in short, a rising young man in every way.Among the women was one who painted portraits, another who was a professional musician, and still another who possessed the degree of Doctor of Sociology and who was locally famous for her social settlement work in the slums of San Francisco.But the women did not count for much in Mrs. Morse’s plan.At the best, they were necessary accessories.The men who did things must be drawn to the house somehow.
“讲话的时候别太激动了。”在介绍开始之前，鲁思告诫马丁。这将会是场严峻的考验。 “Don’t get excited when you talk,” Ruth admonished Martin, before the ordeal of introduction began.
起初他表现得有些拘谨，因感到自身的笨拙而局促不安，尤其是他的肩膀，又想耍过去的老花招，威胁着要破坏家具或摆设。同时，这一群人也让他忸怩不自在。他从来没有接触过如此高层的人物，更别说这么多人了。梅尔维尔——那个银行高层人士，让他十分感兴趣。他决定一有机会就要研究研究这个人物。马丁的敬畏之下潜藏着一个刚毅而骄傲的自我，他感到有一种强烈地冲动要拿这些男人和女人来衡量自己，找出那些他们已经从书本和生活中学到而自己却还没有学到的东西。 He bore himself a bit stiffly at first, oppressed by a sense of his own awkwardness, especially of his shoulders, which were up to their old trick of threatening destruction to furniture and ornaments.Also, he was rendered self-conscious by the company.He had never before been in contact with such exalted beings nor with so many of them.Melville, the bank cashier, fascinated him, and he resolved to investigate him at the first opportunity.For underneath Martin’s awe lurked his assertive ego, and he felt the urge to measure himself with these men and women and to find out what they had learned from the books and life which he had not learned.
鲁思的目光不时移到他身上，看看他进展如何。见到马丁已经轻轻松松认识她的表姐妹，她又是惊讶又是高兴。他肯定没有变得过于亢奋，坐下来之后他那肩膀所造成的困扰就消除了。鲁思认为她们是聪明的女孩，表面上看很了不得。她几乎无法理解后来上床睡觉时她们对马丁那番夸赞。而另一方面马丁却发现在这种环境里开开玩笑、善意地斗斗嘴，都是很简单的事。他在自己本身的阶层中就是一个机智幽默之人，在舞会和周日野餐会上也会欢乐地搞搞恶作剧，逗人发笑。这个傍晚，成功就站在他身后，拍着他的肩膀告诉他干得不错，因此他可以大笑也可以逗别人大笑，毫无羞涩之感。 Ruth’s eyes roved to him frequently to see how he was getting on, and she was surprised and gladdened by the ease with which he got acquainted with her cousins.He certainly did not grow excited, while being seated removed from him the worry of his shoulders.Ruth knew them for clever girls, superficially brilliant, and she could scarcely understand their praise of Martin later that night at going to bed.But he, on the other hand, a wit in his own class, a gay quizzer and laughter-maker at dances and Sunday picnics, had found the making of fun and the breaking of good-natured lances simple enough in this environment.And on this evening success stood at his back, patting him on the shoulder and telling him that he was making good, so that he could afford to laugh and make laughter and remain unabashed.
后来证明鲁思的担忧是有理由的。马丁和考德威尔教授一起到了一个很显眼的角落。虽然马丁没有再用他的手乱划动空气，但在鲁思挑剔的眼光看来，他让他的眼睛眨得太频繁了，话说得过快过于热情了，情绪变得太激动，而且他那涌起的血液使他的脸颊涨得太红了。他缺乏礼数和克制，跟与他谈话的年轻英语教授形成了鲜明的对比。 Later, Ruth’s anxiety found justification.Martin and Professor Caldwell had got together in a conspicuous corner, and though Martin no longer wove the air with his hands, to Ruth’s critical eye he permitted his own eyes to flash and glitter too frequently, talked too rapidly and warmly, grew too intense, and allowed his aroused blood to redden his cheeks too much.He lacked decorum and control, and was in decided contrast to the young professor of English with whom he talked.
可是马丁并不注重外表。他很快就看出对方的思维训练有素，也很欣赏他对知识的驾驭能力。而考德威尔教授还并未了解马丁对普通英语教授的看法。马丁想跟他谈论工作，尽管教授一开始似乎反对这么做，但马丁还是成功地说服了他。因为马丁实在不明白一个人为什么不可以谈论他的工作。 But Martin was not concerned with appearances!He had been swift to note the other’s trained mind and to appreciate his command of knowledge.Furthermore, Professor Caldwell did not realize Martin’s concept of the average English professor.Martin wanted him to talk shop, and, though he seemed averse at first, succeeded in making him do it.For Martin did not see why a man should not talk shop.
“这种反对谈论自己工作的做法真是荒唐且毫不公正，”他几周之前就跟鲁思说，“如果不是为了让他们交流自己最好的东西，天底下还有什么道理让男男女女聚到一起呢？而人们最好的东西就是他们感兴趣的东西，他们赖以为生的东西，他们所专长并日以继夜为之辛劳的东西，甚至做梦也会梦见的东西。想象一下巴特勒先生为达到社交礼仪的标准，大谈他对保罗·魏尔兰或德国戏剧或邓南遮小说的看法。我们肯定要无聊死了。举个例子，如果我非得听巴特勒先生说话，我更乐意听他讲他的那些法律。那才是他最好的东西。生命是如此短暂，我只想听自己遇到的每个男人和女人他们最好的东西。” “It’s absurd and unfair,” he had told Ruth weeks before, “this objection to talking shop.For what reason under the sun do men and women come together if not for the exchange of the best that is in them?And the best that is in them is what they are interested in, the thing by which they make their living, the thing they’ve specialized on and sat up days and nights over, and even dreamed about.Imagine Mr. Butler living up to social etiquette and enunciating his views on Paul Verlaine or the German drama or the novels of D’Annunzio.We’d be bored to death.I, for one, if I must listen to Mr. Butler, prefer to hear him talk about his law.It’s the best that is in him, and life is so short that I want the best of every man and woman I meet.”
“可是，”鲁思反驳说，“有些话题是能引起大家普遍兴趣的。” “But,” Ruth had objected, “there are the topics of general interest to all.”
“那你可就不对了。”他急忙接着说道。“社会上的所有人、所有团体，或者确切的说，几乎所有人和所有团体都模仿他们之中的优秀者。可如今，谁是优秀者中最优秀的呢？那些游手好闲的人，那些富有的闲人。通常情况下，他们都不从世上真正干活的人那里去认识事物。听关于那些事物的对话就意味着会非常无聊，因此闲人们定下规矩：那些事都是行内活，不应该到处说。同样他们规定哪些事不是行内活，可以到处谈论，而那些事物就是最新的歌剧、最新的小说、纸牌、台球、鸡尾酒、汽车、马展、钓鳟鱼、钓金枪鱼、打猎大型野兽、游艇出航，诸如此类——反正这些就是闲人们知道的事物。说句大实话，它们就是闲人们的‘行内活’。而其中最滑稽的部分是，许多聪明的人以及所有将会变聪明的人都由着那些闲人们这样压制自己。至于我，我想听一个人身上的精华所在，随你叫它粗鄙的行内活还是任何别的什么。 “There, you mistake,” he had rushed on.“All persons in society, all cliques in society—or, rather, nearly all persons and cliques—ape their betters.Now, who are the best betters?The idlers, the wealthy idlers.They do not know, as a rule, the things known by the persons who are doing something in the world.To listen to conversation about such things would mean to be bored, wherefore the idlers decree that such things are shop and must not be talked about.Likewise they decree the things that are not shop and which may be talked about, and those things are the latest operas, latest novels, cards, billiards, cocktails, automobiles, horse shows, trout fishing, tuna-fishing, big-game shooting, yacht sailing, and so forth—and mark you, these are the things the idlers know.In all truth, they constitute the shop-talk of the idlers.And the funniest part of it is that many of the clever people, and all the would-be clever people, allow the idlers so to impose upon them.As for me, I want the best a man’s got in him, call it shop vulgarity or anything you please.”
鲁思却并不理解。他这番对传统思想的抨击在她看来是一种恣意妄为的观点。 And Ruth had not understood.This attack of his on the established had seemed to her just so much wilfulness of opinion.
于是马丁用他的热忱感染了考德威尔教授，逼着他说出内心的想法。这时鲁思在他两旁边停了下来，她听见马丁说： So Martin contaminated Professor Caldwell with his own earnestness, challenging him to speak his mind.As Ruth paused beside them she heard Martin saying:—
“你肯定不会在加利福尼亚大学发表这些异端的观点吧？” “You surely don’t pronounce such heresies in the University of California?”
考德威尔教授耸耸肩膀。“一方是诚实的纳税人，一方是政治家，你知道怎么回事。萨克拉门托政府给我们拨款，所以我们就给萨克拉门托政府磕头，给大学董事会磕头，给党报磕头，或者说是给两个党派的党报磕头。” Professor Caldwell shrugged his shoulders.“The honest taxpayer and the politician, you know.Sacramento gives us our appropriations and therefore we kowtow to Sacramento, and to the Board of Regents, and to the party press, or to the press of both parties.”
“是的，这很明白。可是你怎么样呢？”马丁追问道，“你定是一条脱离了水的鱼。” “Yes, that’s clear; but how about you?”Martin urged.“You must be a fish out of the water.”
“在大学这个水塘里没几个像我这样的，我想。有时候我确实觉得自己是条出了水塘的鱼，我应该到巴黎去，到潦倒文人聚集的格拉布街去，到一个隐士穴居的洞窟去；或者是跟一群哀伤又狂野的流浪艺人混在一起，喝劣等的红葡萄酒——在圣弗朗西斯科他们叫它“南欧深红”，去法国拉丁区的便宜饭馆吃饭，大声说出对所有创造物的激进看法。真的，我几乎时常觉得自己天生就是个激进分子。可是又有很多问题我还不太确定。面对着自身人性的弱点，我变得懦弱起来。这使我一直都无法全面地把握任何一个问题——人类的问题，那是些至关重要的问题，你知道。” “Few like me, I imagine, in the university pond.Sometimes I am fairly sure I am out of water, and that I should belong in Paris, in Grub Street, in a hermit’s cave, or in some sadly wild Bohemian crowd, drinking claret,—dago-red they call it in San Francisco,—dining in cheap restaurants in the Latin Quarter, and expressing vociferously radical views upon all creation.Really, I am frequently almost sure that I was cut out to be a radical.But then, there are so many questions on which I am not sure.I grow timid when I am face to face with my human frailty, which ever prevents me from grasping all the factors in any problem—human, vital problems, you know.”
他继续说着，而马丁开始意识到自己的嘴里唱起了《贸易风之歌》： And as he talked on, Martin became aware that to his own lips had come the “@ong of the Trade Wind”:—
“正午时我最强劲，可在月光下，我也能吹得船帆鼓鼓。” “I am strongest at noon,But under the moonI stiffen the bunt of the sail.”
他几乎要哼出声来。这下他才明白原来教授让他想起了贸易风——东北贸易风，稳定、清凉而又强劲。他性情温和，值得信赖，同时又带着某种叫人难以捉摸的东西。马丁有种感觉，教授从来也不会说出自己所有的想法，正如他常常觉得贸易风从来也不会使出全力吹起一样，它总是保留着一部分从来也不会使用的力量。马丁想象的本领又一如既往地活跃起来。他的脑子就是个用起来十分便利的仓库，里面存着记住的事实和幻想，它们似乎总是有条有理地展开着待他查看。无论当时那一刻发生了什么，马丁的脑海里马上就会呈现出相关对照或类似的例子，那些例子都是以幻象的形式将自己传达给马丁。这完全是自发的，他的幻象总是跟鲜活的事实相伴而行。比如，鲁思的脸上那瞬间的嫉妒让他的眼前又出现了原已被遗忘的月下风暴。比如，考德威尔教授使他再次看到了东北贸易风驱赶白色浪涛越过紫色海面的场景。当新的幻象出现在他面前，或是展开在他的眼皮下，或是投射在他那意识的荧幕上，他时不时对它们进行鉴别和分类，而不会感到困惑不安。这些幻象来自过去的活动和情感，来自昨日和上一周接触的物品、事件和书本——无论是醒着还是睡着，他的脑袋里都充满了无数的幻象。 He was almost humming the words, and it dawned upon him that the other reminded him of the trade wind, of the Northeast Trade, steady, and cool, and strong.He was equable, he was to be relied upon, and withal there was a certain bafflement about him.Martin had the feeling that he never spoke his full mind, just as he had often had the feeling that the trades never blew their strongest but always held reserves of strength that were never used.Martin’s trick of visioning was active as ever.His brain was a most accessible storehouse of remembered fact and fancy, and its contents seemed ever ordered and spread for his inspection.Whatever occurred in the instant present, Martin’s mind immediately presented associated antithesis or similitude which ordinarily expressed themselves to him in vision.It was sheerly automatic, and his visioning was an unfailing accompaniment to the living present.Just as Ruth’s face, in a momentary jealousy had called before his eyes a forgotten moonlight gale, and as Professor Caldwell made him see again the Northeast Trade herding the white billows across the purple sea, so, from moment to moment, not disconcerting but rather identifying and classifying, new memory-visions rose before him, or spread under his eyelids, or were thrown upon the screen of his consciousness.These visions came out of the actions and sensations of the past, out of things and events and books of yesterday and last week—a countless host of apparitions that, waking or sleeping, forever thronged his mind.
当他听考德威尔教授自在流畅地发表言论时也是如此。那是一个智慧的文化人在谈话，而马丁却看到自己一路回到了过去。他看到自己还是个十足小流氓的场景，戴着一顶“硬边”的斯泰森毡帽，穿着一件方正裁剪的对襟外套，大摇大摆地晃动着肩膀，有一个理想就是粗野到警察所能容忍的极限。他没有向自己掩饰或辩解这些。在他的生命里有那么一段时间，他就是个小混混，一个流氓头子，让警察头疼，叫老实的工人阶层家庭害怕。但是他的理想已经改变了。他扫视了一圈自己周围那些有教养、穿着体面的男男女女，吸进一口文化和风雅的空气到自己的肺里，同时幻象中那个早时年轻的自己也戴着硬边毡帽、穿着方襟外套，神气活现地大步走过这房间，一副凶神恶煞的样子。他看见这个街角流氓的幻象融入到了自己体内，正坐着跟一位真正的大学教授交谈。 So it was, as he listened to Professor Caldwell’s easy flow of speech—the conversation of a clever, cultured man—that Martin kept seeing himself down all his past.He saw himself when he had been quite the hoodlum, wearing a “stiff-rim” Stetson hat and a square-cut, double-breasted coat, with a certain swagger to the shoulders and possessing the ideal of being as tough as the police permitted.He did not disguise it to himself, nor attempt to palliate it.At one time in his life he had been just a common hoodlum, the leader of a gang that worried the police and terrorized honest, working-class householders.But his ideals had changed.He glanced about him at the well-bred, well-dressed men and women, and breathed into his lungs the atmosphere of culture and refinement, and at the same moment the ghost of his early youth, in stiff-rim and square-cut, with swagger and toughness, stalked across the room.This figure, of the corner hoodlum, he saw merge into himself, sitting and talking with an actual university professor.
他终究是从来没有找到过自己永久驻留的地方。无论自己置身何处，他都适应过来了，总能成为最受欢迎的人，因为每到一处，他都能在工作和玩乐中摆正自己的位子，而且他愿意并有能力去争取自己的权利，进而赢得他人的尊敬。但是他从来都没有扎下根过。他能充分融入环境以使同伴满意，却不足以令他自己也满意。他总是被一种不安之感所困扰，总是听到一个来自远方的呼唤，他就一直在生活里游荡，到处寻找，直到他找到了书本、艺术和爱情。终于他到了这里，被这所有的一切所包围。所有跟他一起冒险的同伴之中，他是唯一一个能够使自己有资格进入莫尔斯家的人。 For, after all, he had never found his permanent abiding place.He had fitted in wherever he found himself, been a favorite always and everywhere by virtue of holding his own at work and at play and by his willingness and ability to fight for his rights and command respect.But he had never taken root.He had fitted in sufficiently to satisfy his fellows but not to satisfy himself.He had been perturbed always by a feeling of unrest, had heard always the call of something from beyond, and had wandered on through life seeking it until he found books and art and love.And here he was, in the midst of all this, the only one of all the comrades he had adventured with who could have made themselves eligible for the inside of the Morse home.
不过这些思考和幻象并没有妨碍马丁紧紧跟随考德威尔教授的谈话。他聆听着，一边理解一边评判，发现对方的知识体系十分完整。而他自己则在谈话中时不时地显露出各种知识的缺位和空白以及对某些话题的全而无知。然而，多亏了他的斯宾塞，他发现自己已经掌握了知识体系的大致轮廓。什么时候能把这一轮廓填充完整只是个时间问题。到那时你们大家可都得小心了，他想。马丁觉得自己像是坐在教授的脚边，崇拜着他，汲取着他的知识。可他听着听着却找到了对方思考判断中的一个弱点——这个弱点是如此细碎而难以捕捉，若非它不断出现，马丁可能不会抓住它。一旦抓住了它，马丁就立刻一跃而起，上升到了平等的地位。 But such thoughts and visions did not prevent him from following Professor Caldwell closely.And as he followed, comprehendingly and critically, he noted the unbroken field of the other’s knowledge.As for himself, from moment to moment the conversation showed him gaps and open stretches, whole subjects with which he was unfamiliar.Nevertheless, thanks to his Spencer, he saw that he possessed the outlines of the field of knowledge.It was a matter only of time, when he would fill in the outline.Then watch out, he thought—’ware shoal, everybody!He felt like sitting at the feet of the professor, worshipful and absorbent; but, as he listened, he began to discern a weakness in the other’s judgments—a weakness so stray and elusive that he might not have caught it had it not been ever present.And when he did catch it, he leapt to equality at once.
鲁思再次向他们走了过来，那时马丁正要开始说话。 Ruth came up to them a second time, just as Martin began to speak.
“我要告诉你，你哪里弄错了，或者，更确切地说，是什么削弱了你的观点，”他说，“你缺少生物学的知识。在你的知识体系里没有它的一席之地。哦，我是指对现实进行解读的生物学，从最基本的开始，从实验室、试管和被注入了生命的无机物开始，一直概括衍生到最广泛的美学和社会学。” “I’ll tell you where you are wrong, or, rather, what weakens your judgments,” he said.“You lack biology.It has no place in your scheme of things.—Oh, I mean the real interpretative biology, from the ground up, from the laboratory and the test-tube and the vitalized inorganic right on up to the widest aesthetic and sociological generalizations.”
鲁思吓呆了。她听过考德威尔教授的两次讲座，拿他当储存所有知识的活宝库来膜拜。 Ruth was appalled.She had sat two lecture courses under Professor Caldwell and looked up to him as the living repository of all knowledge.
“我听不太懂你说的。”他疑惑地说。 “I scarcely follow you,” he said dubiously.
马丁却至少还能肯定教授明白了他的意思。 Martin was not so sure but what he had followed him.
“那我就尽量解释解释吧，”他说，“我记得读到过埃及历史方面的某种观点，意思是说不先研究土地问题就无法理解埃及艺术。” “Then I’ll try to explain,” he said.“I remember reading in Egyptian history something to the effect that understanding could not be had of Egyptian art without first studying the land question.”
“一点儿没错。”教授点点头。 “Quite right,” the professor nodded.
“我似乎觉得，如果对生命的本质和构成没有预先的认识，那么反过来就不可能理解土地问题，”马丁接着说道，“在这一点上，所有的问题都是如此。”“如果仅是了解生物体的本质，而不了解组成生物体的原料的本质，我们如何能理解法律与制度、宗教与传统呢？难道文学不比埃及的建筑和雕塑能彰显人性吗？在已知的宇宙中有哪一样事物能够逃脱进化规律的束缚呢？噢，我知道对各种艺术的演变发展已有一种精细的阐述，但它在我看来似乎过于机械。人本身被忽略了。工具、竖琴、音乐、歌唱、舞蹈，人们对所有这些事物的演变发展都已作了美妙的阐述。可人本身是怎样进化的呢？在制造他的第一件工具或发出他的第一声歌唱之前，人类基本的、内在的部分是如何进化的呢？这就是你没有考虑到的，而我称之为生物学。这就是最广泛意义上的生物学。” “And it seems to me,” Martin continued, “that knowledge of the land question, in turn, of all questions, for that matter, cannot be had without previous knowledge of the stuff and the constitution of life.How can we understand laws and institutions, religions and customs, without understanding, not merely the nature of the creatures that made them, but the nature of the stuff out of which the creatures are made?Is literature less human than the architecture and sculpture of Egypt?Is there one thing in the known universe that is not subject to the law of evolution?—Oh, I know there is an elaborate evolution of the various arts laid down, but it seems to me to be too mechanical.The human himself is left out.The evolution of the tool, of the harp, of music and song and dance, are all beautifully elaborated; but how about the evolution of the human himself, the development of the basic and intrinsic parts that were in him before he made his first tool or gibbered his first chant?It is that which you do not consider, and which I call biology.It is biology in its largest aspects.
“我知道自己表达得不够清晰连贯，可我已经尽了力来传达这个想法。我是在你谈话时才产生了这个想法，因此没有事先准备就发表了这通见解。你自己也说因为人性中的弱点，一个人无法将所有的因素都考虑进去。那么反过来，你自己——或者在我看来似乎是如此——就漏掉了生物学这个因素。而偏偏这一因素就是编织一切艺术的原料，它是编织人类一切活动和成就的经纱和纬纱。” “I know I express myself incoherently, but I’ve tried to hammer out the idea.It came to me as you were talking, so I was not primed and ready to deliver it.You spoke yourself of the human frailty that prevented one from taking all the factors into consideration.And you, in turn,—or so it seems to me,—leave out the biological factor, the very stuff out of which has been spun the fabric of all the arts, the warp and the woof of all human actions and achievements.”
令鲁思吃惊的是，马丁并未当即遭到打击，她感觉教授的反应像是对马丁年少轻狂的一种容忍。考德威尔教授一声不响地摆弄着他的手表链，坐了足足一分钟。 To Ruth’s amazement, Martin was not immediately crushed, and that the professor replied in the way he did struck her as forbearance for Martin’s youth.Professor Caldwell sat for a full minute, silent and fingering his watch chain.
“你知道吗，”他最后说，“我曾经受到过同样的批评——批评我的是个非常伟大的人，一位科学家和进化论者，约瑟夫·勒孔特。不过他已经去世了，我原以为不会再有人发现我的弱点，而现在你出来揭露了我。可是说真的——这是坦白——我认为你的见解是有道理的——很有道理，实际上。我太传统了，在解释性分支学科方面不够与时俱进。我只能借口说自己所受的教育存在弊端，加之生性怠惰，这些妨碍了我的工作。我不知道你是否会相信，我曾经还在物理和化学实验室呆过呢。可那是真的。勒孔特是对的，你也是对的，伊登先生，至少在一定程度上如此——我是多么无知啊。” “Do you know,” he said at last, “I’ve had that same criticism passed on me once before—by a very great man, a scientist and evolutionist, Joseph Le Conte.But he is dead, and I thought to remain undetected; and now you come along and expose me.Seriously, though—and this is confession—I think there is something in your contention—a great deal, in fact.I am too classical, not enough up-to-date in the interpretative branches of science, and I can only plead the disadvantages of my education and a temperamental slothfulness that prevents me from doing the work.I wonder if you’ll believe that I’ve never been inside a physics or chemistry laboratory?It is true, nevertheless.Le Conte was right, and so are you, Mr. Eden, at least to an extent—how much I do not know.”
鲁思找了个借口把马丁拉走了。等把他拉开到一边，她才窃窃私语道： Ruth drew Martin away with her on a pretext; when she had got him aside, whispering:—
“你不应该像那样独占了考德威尔教授。也许还有其他人也想跟他交谈呢。” “You shouldn’t have monopolized Professor Caldwell that way.There may be others who want to talk with him.”
“我的不对，”马丁承认，带着深深的懊悔，“可我激起了他的兴致，他是那么有趣我想都没想到别的。你知道吗，他是我平生与之交谈过的人当中最聪明、最有智慧的。我还要告诉你点别的。我曾以为上过大学或处于社会高层的每一个人都跟他一样聪明、有智慧。” “My mistake,” Martin admitted contritely.“But I’d got him stirred up, and he was so interesting that I did not think.Do you know, he is the brightest, the most intellectual, man I have ever talked with.And I’ll tell you something else.I once thought that everybody who went to universities, or who sat in the high places in society, was just as brilliant and intelligent as he.”
“他可是出类拔萃。”她回答。 “He’s an exception,” she answered.
“我也会这么说。现在你想让我跟谁谈话呢？———噢，对了，把那个银行高管带过来吧。” “I should say so.Whom do you want me to talk to now?—Oh, say, bring me up against that cashier-fellow.”
马丁跟他谈了十五分钟。鲁思都没指望她的恋人会表现得那么好。他眼睛没闪，脸颊也没红，他说话时的镇定和泰然自若令她吃惊。可马丁对所有银行高管的评价却大大下跌。那晚剩下的时间里，他都在反复跟这个印象纠缠：银行高管就是陈词滥调者的同义词。他发现那个军官性格温和、单纯，是个身强体健的小伙子，对于自己在生活中的位置感到满意——那是身世和命运决定。当得知他上过两年大学时，马丁感到很困惑，不知道他把学的东西都藏哪里了。即便如此，马丁还是喜欢他多于那个陈腐的银行高管。 Martin talked for fifteen minutes with him, nor could Ruth have wished better behavior on her lover’s part.Not once did his eyes flash nor his cheeks flush, while the calmness and poise with which he talked surprised her.But in Martin’s estimation the whole tribe of bank cashiers fell a few hundred per cent, and for the rest of the evening he labored under the impression that bank cashiers and talkers of platitudes were synonymous phrases.The army officer he found good-natured and simple, a healthy, wholesome young fellow, content to occupy the place in life into which birth and luck had flung him.On learning that he had completed two years in the university, Martin was puzzled to know where he had stored it away.Nevertheless Martin liked him better than the platitudinous bank cashier.
“我倒真的不是反对老调重弹，”他后来跟鲁思说，“可他们说那些陈谷子烂芝麻时一副自命不凡、得意洋洋、高人一等的样子，还要说上好大一通，这才是让我紧张难受的。怎么不是，那个人讲劳工党和民主党合并所花的时间都够我给他讲一整部宗教改革史了。你知道吗，他在词句上做戏法，就像一个专业赌徒在发给他的牌上做戏法。哪天我会向你解释我说的意思。” “I really don’t object to platitudes,” he told Ruth later; “but what worries me into nervousness is the pompous, smugly complacent, superior certitude with which they are uttered and the time taken to do it.Why, I could give that man the whole history of the Reformation in the time he took to tell me that the Union-Labor Party had fused with the Democrats.Do you know, he skins his words as a professional poker-player skins the cards that are dealt out to him.Some day I’ll show you what I mean.”
“我很遗憾你不喜欢他，”这是她的回答，“他是巴特勒先生身边的大红人。巴特勒先生说他稳重而诚实，管他叫磐石或彼得，说只要有了他任何一家银行机构都能办得有声有色。” “I’m sorry you don’t like him,” was her reply.“He’s a favorite of Mr. Butler’s.Mr. Butler says he is safe and honest—calls him the Rock, Peter, and says that upon him any banking institution can well be built.”
“我并不怀疑这一点——就我从他身上看到的和听到的少许事物来判断。可我觉得我对银行的评价没有以前高了。你不介意我这样说出自己内心的想法吧，亲爱的？” “I don’t doubt it—from the little I saw of him and the less I heard from him; but I don’t think so much of banks as I did.You don’t mind my speaking my mind this way, dear?”
“不，不会，这很有趣。” “No, no; it is most interesting.”
“确实，”马丁兴冲冲地接着说道，“我不过是个刚获得了对文明世界第一印象的野蛮人而已。这些印象在文明人看来一定很新鲜有趣吧。” “Yes,” Martin went on heartily, “I’m no more than a barbarian getting my first impressions of civilization.Such impressions must be entertainingly novel to the civilized person.”
“你觉得我的表姐妹们如何？”鲁思问道。 “What did you think of my cousins?” Ruth queried.
“我喜欢她们多于其他女性。她们很风趣，且少有做作。” “I liked them better than the other women.There’s plenty of fun in them along with paucity of pretence.”
“那你喜欢别的女人吗？” “Then you did like the other women?”
他摇摇头。 He shook his head.
“从事社会安置工作的那个女人不过是社会学领域的一只学舌鹦鹉。我发誓，如果你把她从像汤姆林森这样的明星人物中剔除出去，那么就会发现她一点独创性的见解都没有。至于那个肖像画家，她可真是个让人厌烦的家伙。她适合做那个银行高管的妻子。还有那个女音乐家！我才不管她的手指有多灵巧，她的技艺有多精湛，她的演奏有多美妙——事实就是她对音乐一无所知。” “That social-settlement woman is no more than a sociological poll-parrot.I swear, if you winnowed her out between the stars, like Tomlinson, there would be found in her not one original thought.As for the portrait-painter, she was a positive bore.She’d make a good wife for the cashier.And the musician woman!I don’t care how nimble her fingers are, how perfect her technique, how wonderful her expression—the fact is, she knows nothing about music.”
“她演奏得可美了。”鲁思表示反对。 “She plays beautifully,” Ruth protested.
“没错，就音乐的外在形式她毫无疑问是训练有素的，可就音乐的内在灵魂她根本没有去体会过。我问她，音乐对她代表了什么——你知道我总是非常好奇想要了解这个特殊事物，而她却不知道音乐对自己有什么意义，只知道自己热爱音乐，音乐是最伟大的艺术，音乐对她来说比生命还重要。” “Yes, she’s undoubtedly gymnastic in the externals of music, but the intrinsic spirit of music is unguessed by her.I asked her what music meant to her—you know I’m always curious to know that particular thing; and she did not know what it meant to her, except that she adored it, that it was the greatest of the arts, and that it meant more than life to her.”
“你让她们谈‘行内活’呢。”鲁思责备道。 “You were making them talk shop,” Ruth charged him.
“这一点我承认。如果她们连本行都谈论不好，那么想象一下要是让她们谈论其他话题，我该有多受罪。怎么会这样呢，我原本以为在上层人士中，在享有一切文化优势的阶层中——”他停顿了一下，望了一眼自己年少时的那个幻影——他戴着硬边毡帽、穿着方襟外套，走进门来，大摇大摆地穿过房间。“就如我刚才说的，我原以为在这上层社会中的所有男女都聪明非凡，光芒四射。可如今，从我在他们身上见识到的那点东西来判断，他们给我的印象就像是一群傻瓜，大部分都是，而剩下的那些人当中百分之九十都是无聊透顶的家伙。只有考德威尔教授——他与众不同。他才是个真正的人，他身体的每一寸、他大脑的每一个细胞都是。” “I confess it.And if they were failures on shop, imagine my sufferings if they had discoursed on other subjects.Why, I used to think that up here, where all the advantages of culture were enjoyed—” He paused for a moment, and watched the youthful shade of himself, in stiff-rim and square-cut, enter the door and swagger across the room.“As I was saying, up here I thought all men and women were brilliant and radiant.But now, from what little I’ve seen of them, they strike me as a pack of ninnies, most of them, and ninety percent of the remainder as bores.Now there’s Professor Caldwell—he’s different.He’s a man, every inch of him and every atom of his gray matter.”
鲁思的脸亮起来了。 Ruth’s face brightened.
“跟我说说他吧，”她催促道，“不要说那些伟大的了不起的品质——那些我都知道。说说任何你觉得不足的地方吧。我真的很好奇，很想知道。” “Tell me about him,” she urged.“Not what is large and brilliant—I know those qualities; but whatever you feel is adverse.I am most curious to know.”
“我很可能会使自己陷入尴尬的境地。”马丁犹豫了一会儿后幽默地说。“假如是让你先告诉我呢。或许你能在他身上找到的只有优点。” “Perhaps I’ll get myself in a pickle.”Martin debated humorously for a moment.“Suppose you tell me first.Or maybe you find in him nothing less than the best.”
“我上过他教的两门课，我已经认识他两年了，因此我急于听听你的第一印象。” “I attended two lecture courses under him, and I have known him for two years; that is why I am anxious for your first impression.”
“你是说坏印象吗？好吧，那我就说了。我想你认为他该有的那些优秀品质他确实都有。他至少是我见过的知识分子中最优秀的榜样，但他带着一种不为人知的耻辱。” “Bad impression, you mean?Well, here goes.He is all the fine things you think about him, I guess.At least, he is the finest specimen of intellectual man I have met; but he is a man with a secret shame.”
“啊，不，不！”他急得大叫起来。 “Oh, no, no!” he hastened to cry.
“不是什么可鄙或下流的东西。我是指他给我一种印象，仿佛他一个经历过最糟糕的事情，他是那么害怕自己所看到的那些，以至于他迫使自己相信他从来都没看到过那些。可能这种方式的表述不是最清楚吧。我还有另一种表述的方法。一个人已经发现了通往隐秘寺庙的小径，却被禁止走那条小径。或许他已经瞥见过那个寺庙几眼，可是后来却要拼命说服自己它不过是绿洲的一座海市蜃楼。还有一种解释的方法。一个人本可以有所成就却没有对那些事情加以重视，在其内心最深处，他一直后悔自己没有做那些事；他曾经暗地里嘲笑做那些事可以换来的回报，可同时又在内心更深处渴望那些回报和其中的快乐。” “Nothing paltry nor vulgar.What I mean is that he strikes me as a man who has gone to the bottom of things, and is so afraid of what he saw that he makes believe to himself that he never saw it.Perhaps that’s not the clearest way to express it.Here’s another way.A man who has found the path to the hidden temple but has not followed it; who has, perhaps, caught glimpses of the temple and striven afterward to convince himself that it was only a mirage of foliage.Yet another way.A man who could have done things but who placed no value on the doing, and who, all the time, in his innermost heart, is regretting that he has not done them; who has secretly laughed at the rewards for doing, and yet, still more secretly, has yearned for the rewards and for the joy of doing.”
“我可不那么看他。”她说，“就那件事情，我不太明白你所说的。” “I don’t read him that way,” she said.“And for that matter, I don’t see just what you mean.”
“那只是我隐隐约约有的一种感觉。”马丁敷衍道。“我对此说不出个所以然来。这只是一种感觉而已，很可能是错的。你当然比我更了解他啦。” “It is only a vague feeling on my part,” Martin temporized.“I have no reason for it.It is only a feeling, and most likely it is wrong.You certainly should know him better than I.”
那个夜晚，马丁从鲁思家带回了一些奇特的困惑和相互冲突的情感。他对自己的目标以及向上攀爬所跻身的那个人群感到失望。另一方面，他的成功也鼓舞了他。这场攀登要比他预想中的更容易。他超越了这场攀登，而且（他没有用虚伪的谦逊来向自己掩盖它）他超越了和他一起攀登的那些人——当然，除了考德威尔教授这个特例。对于生活和书本，他懂得比他们多。他想不通那些人都把他们受过的教育扔到什么犄角旮旯里去了。他不知道自己拥有非凡的脑力，也不知道用来探测深度和思考终极问题的人在莫尔斯家的客厅里是找不到的。他更不知道那样的人就像孤独的苍鹰一样蔚蓝天空中兀自翱翔，远离尘世及其间越来越繁芜纷扰的群集生活。 From the evening at Ruth’s Martin brought away with him strange confusions and conflicting feelings.He was disappointed in his goal, in the persons he had climbed to be with.On the other hand, he was encouraged with his success.The climb had been easier than he expected.He was superior to the climb, and (he did not, with false modesty, hide it from himself) he was superior to the beings among whom he had climbed—with the exception, of course, of Professor Caldwell.About life and the books he knew more than they, and he wondered into what nooks and crannies they had cast aside their educations.He did not know that he was himself possessed of unusual brain vigor; nor did he know that the persons who were given to probing the depths and to thinking ultimate thoughts were not to be found in the drawing rooms of the world’s Morses;nor did he dream that such persons were as lonely eagles sailing solitary in the azure sky far above the earth and its swarming freight of gregarious life.
第二十八章 CHAPTER XXVIII
但成功已失掉了马丁的地址，她的信使不再来到马丁的门前了。有二十五天之久，他礼拜日和假日也在工作，他为《太阳的耻辱》苦苦耕耘，这是一篇约有三万字的长篇散文。这是对梅特林克派的神秘主义的一次蓄意攻击——一次从实证科学的堡垒向那些奇迹梦想者的攻击，但也保留着许多与确知的事实相兼容的美与奇迹。稍后，他又以两篇短文，《奇迹的梦想者》和《衡量自我的标准》，来继续攻击。为了这些文章，长的短的，他开始从一家杂志到另一家杂志支付着它们的旅费。 But success had lost Martin’s address, and her messengers no longer came to his door.For twenty-five days, working Sundays and holidays, he toiled on “The Shame of the Sun,” a long essay of some thirty thousand words.It was a deliberate attack on the mysticism of the Maeterlinck school—an attack from the citadel of positive science upon the wonder-dreamers, but an attack nevertheless that retained much of beauty and wonder of the sort compatible with ascertained fact.It was a little later that he followed up the attack with two short essays, “The Wonder-Dreamers” and “The Yardstick of the Ego.”And on essays, long and short, he began to pay the travelling expenses from magazine to magazine.
在为《太阳的耻辱》辛劳的二十五天里，他将一些卖文作品卖了六块五毛钱。一则笑话收入了五毛，另一则投给一个高级趣味周刊，弄到了一块钱。然后还有两首幽默诗分别赚到了两块钱和三块钱。结果，商家不再赊账给他（尽管他在杂货店的信誉度已达到五块钱），他的脚踏车和那套衣服又回到了典当铺。出租打字机的人又嚷着要钱，坚称依照合同，严格来说，租金应该提前预付。 During the twenty-five days spent on “The Shame of the Sun,” he sold hack-work to the extent of six dollars and fifty cents.A joke had brought in fifty cents, and a second one, sold to a high-grade comic weekly, had fetched a dollar.Then two humorous poems had earned two dollars and three dollars respectively.As a result, having exhausted his credit with the tradesmen (though he had increased his credit with the grocer to five dollars), his wheel and suit of clothes went back to the pawnbroker.The type-writer people were again clamoring for money, insistently pointing out that according to the agreement rent was to be paid strictly in advance.
为那几次小买卖所鼓励，马丁又回到写卖文作品的工作上来。也许终究这也是谋生之道。桌子底下存着的是报纸短篇小说供稿社退回来的二十篇短篇小说。为了找出为何写不出报纸短篇小说的原因，他把它们重读了一遍，这样一来，他推究出一个完美的公式。他发现报纸短篇小说绝不能是悲剧，绝不能有悲惨的结局，也绝不能有优美的语言，精妙的思想，或真正微妙的感情。它必须要有感情，丰富、纯粹而高贵的感情，那种他少年时在剧院廉价座位上时为其喝彩的感情——那种“为了上帝、祖国与沙皇”的感情，“我尽管穷但我诚实”的感情。 Encouraged by his several small sales, Martin went back to hack-work.Perhaps there was a living in it, after all.Stored away under his table were the twenty storiettes which had been rejected by the newspaper short-story syndicate.He read them over in order to find out how not to write newspaper storiettes, and so doing, reasoned out the perfect formula.He found that the newspaper storiette should never be tragic, should never end unhappily, and should never contain beauty of language, subtlety of thought, nor real delicacy of sentiment.Sentiment it must contain, plenty of it, pure and noble, of the sort that in his own early youth had brought his applause from “nigger heaven”—the “For-God-my-country-and-the-Czar” and “I-may-be-poor-but-I-am-honest” brand of sentiment.
懂得了这些必备方法之后，马丁便斟酌一番《伯爵夫人》的风格，依照公式进行组合。公式包括三部分：（１）一对恋人吵翻了；（２）由于某一行为或事件，他们重归于好；（３）婚礼的钟声。第三部分是一个不变量，但是第一、二部分却可以无穷变化。因此，一对恋人闹翻可能是由于误会对方的动机，由于命运的偶然，由于情敌的妒忌，由于暴怒的双亲，由于狡猾的监护人，由于诡计多端的亲戚，等等等等；他们能重归于好可能由于男方的英勇行为，由于女方同样的行为，由于有一方改变心意，由于狡猾的监护人，诡计多端的亲戚，或是妒忌的情敌，被迫或是自愿坦白，由于某种意想不到的秘密被发现，由于爱人感动着女孩子的心，由于爱人做了长期的高尚的自我牺牲，等等，数也数不尽。在重归于好的过程中女孩子首先求婚更引人入胜，马丁一点儿一点儿地发现了其他痛快的、吸引人的方法。然而结束时婚礼的钟声，他却不能随意更改；即使天空像卷轴一样卷起，星星坠落，婚礼的钟声也还是一定要照常响起。在数量上，公式规定最小量是一千二百字，最大量是一千五百字。 Having learned such precautions, Martin consulted “The Duchess” for tone, and proceeded to mix according to formula.The formula consists of three parts: (1) a pair of lovers are jarred apart; (2) by some deed or event they are reunited; (3) marriage bells.The third part was an unvarying quantity, but the first and second parts could be varied an infinite number of times.Thus, the pair of lovers could be jarred apart by misunderstood motives, by accident of fate, by jealous rivals, by irate parents, by crafty guardians, by scheming relatives, and so forth and so forth;they could be reunited by a brave deed of the man lover, by a similar deed of the woman lover, by change of heart in one lover or the other, by forced confession of crafty guardian, scheming relative, or jealous rival, by voluntary confession of same, by discovery of some unguessed secret, by lover storming girl’s heart, by lover making long and noble self-sacrifice, and so on, endlessly.It was very fetching to make the girl propose in the course of being reunited, and Martin discovered, bit by bit, other decidedly piquant and fetching ruses.But marriage bells at the end was the one thing he could take no liberties with; though the heavens rolled up as a scroll and the stars fell, the wedding bells must go on ringing just the same.In quantity, the formula prescribed twelve hundred words minimum dose, fifteen hundred words maximum dose.
当他在短篇小说艺术上造诣未深之前，马丁想出半打常用格式，好在写小说时常常拿来作参考。这些格式就像数学家所运用的巧妙的表格，可以从上、下、左、右进入，入口由许多条线和许多竖栏组成，从这些表格里，用不着论证或思考，便可以推导出千万种各不相同的结果，而且所有结果都精确可靠。因此，利用这个格式，半小时之内，马丁就可以拟出约摸一打短篇小说的框架，他把这些放在一边，等方便时再填充完整。他发现在一天认真的工作结束之后，上床睡觉前，他就可以填充完一篇。如后来向鲁思坦白的一样，他差不多在睡觉时也能写出来。真正的工夫在于构拟框架，而那只不过是机械的工作。 Before he got very far along in the art of the storiette, Martin worked out half a dozen stock forms, which he always consulted when constructing storiettes.These forms were like the cunning tables used by mathematicians, which may be entered from top, bottom, right, and left, which entrances consist of scores of lines and dozens of columns, and from which may be drawn, without reasoning or thinking, thousands of different conclusions, all unchallengably precise and true.Thus, in the course of half an hour with his forms, Martin could frame up a dozen or so storiettes, which he put aside and filled in at his convenience.He found that he could fill one in, after a day of serious work, in the hour before going to bed.As he later confessed to Ruth, he could almost do it in his sleep.The real work was in constructing the frames, and that was merely mechanical.
他一点儿也不怀疑他的公式的效力，因为当时他已懂得了编者的心意，他肯定地对自己说寄出去的头两篇定会带来支票。它们真带来了支票，每篇四块钱，在第十二天结束时来的。 He had no doubt whatever of the efficacy of his formula, and for once he knew the editorial mind when he said positively to himself that the first two he sent off would bring checks.And checks they brought, for four dollars each, at the end of twelve days.
同时，对于杂志他又有了新的惊人的发现。尽管《洲际月刊》刊出了《钟声》，却没有支票寄来。马丁需要钱，还为此写了信。他收到的只是一个措辞含糊的答复和希望他多投稿件的请求。在等待回信中，他已经挨了两天饿，也就是那时候他把自己的自行车送回到当铺。为那五块钱，他每星期固定写两次信给《洲际月刊》，尽管他收到回复的机会很少。他不知道《洲际月刊》已经朝不保夕地拖了很多年，它只不过是一个四等货色或是十等货色的刊物，没有地位，发行量很不稳定，半靠着小规模的敲竹杠，半靠着打着爱国旗号的求援，还有那些广告，几乎是慈善的施舍。他也不知道《洲际月刊》是编者和业务经理唯一的谋生之道，只有靠着搬家以避交房租和躲避一切躲得了的账单，他们才能从中挤出生活费用。他更想不到，属于他的那五块钱早已被业务经理挪用去粉刷他在阿拉梅达的房子了，他利用工作日的下午自己粉刷。因为他付不起工会规定的工资，还因为他第一次雇佣的那个非公会的工人猛地从梯子上掉下来了，锁骨摔断了，给送进了医院。 In the meantime he was making fresh and alarming discoveries concerning the magazines.Though the @Transcontinental@ had published “The Ring of Bells,” no check was forthcoming.Martin needed it, and he wrote for it.An evasive answer and a request for more of his work was all he received.He had gone hungry two days waiting for the reply, and it was then that he put his wheel back in pawn.He wrote regularly, twice a week, to the @Transcontinental@ for his five dollars, though it was only semi-occasionally that he elicited a reply.He did not know that the @Transcontinental@ had been staggering along precariously for years, that it was a fourth-rater, or tenth-rater, without standing, with a crazy circulation that partly rested on petty bullying and partly on patriotic appealing, and with advertisements that were scarcely more than charitable donations.Nor did he know that the @Transcontinental@ was the sole livelihood of the editor and the business manager, and that they could wring their livelihood out of it only by moving to escape paying rent and by never paying any bill they could evade.Nor could he have guessed that the particular five dollars that belonged to him had been appropriated by the business manager for the painting of his house in Alameda, which painting he performed himself, on week-day afternoons,because he could not afford to pay union wages and because the first scab he had employed had had a ladder jerked out from under him and been sent to the hospital with a broken collar-bone.
马丁把《寻宝者》卖给芝加哥报纸的十块钱还没有到手。那篇文章已经刊登出来了，他已经从中央阅览室的杂志架上证实，但没从编辑那儿得到一句话。他的信也被置之不理。为了确定信被收到，他寄了好几封挂号信。这简直就是抢劫，他得到如此的结论——冷血的偷窃；挨饿的时候，他的商品、货物还被被偷去，卖掉它们是唯一可以得到面包的方法。 The ten dollars for which Martin had sold “Treasure Hunters” to the Chicago newspaper did not come to hand.The article had been published, as he had ascertained at the file in the Central Reading-room, but no word could he get from the editor.His letters were ignored.To satisfy himself that they had been received, he registered several of them.It was nothing less than robbery, he concluded—a cold-blooded steal; while he starved, he was pilfered of his merchandise, of his goods, the sale of which was the sole way of getting bread to eat.
《青年与时代》是一个周刊，已经刊登了他那两万一千字的连载故事的三分之二，却停刊了。得到六十块钱稿酬的所有希望也随之而去了。 @Youth and Age@ was a weekly, and it had published two-thirds of his twenty-one-thousand-word serial when it went out of business.With it went all hopes of getting his sixteen dollars.
使情形更加糟糕的是，他认为他的最佳作品之一，《坛子》，也落了空。他在失意中，狂乱地在杂志堆中找寻着，把它寄到了《巨浪》，旧金山的社会周刊。他把它寄给那个刊物的主要原因，就是因为从奥克兰到那儿只需通过海湾，很快便可以得到答复。两周后，在报摊上最新一期的刊物中，他喜不自胜地看见了他的小说完整地刊印出来了，还有插图，而且刊在了显著地位置上。他心跳加速地回到家，猜想着他们能付多少钱给他这篇最好的作品。而且它被迅速接受并刊登出来，对他来说是件令人愉快的事情。编者没有通知他便刊登出来，则使这个消息更加惊人。等了一个星期，两个星期，又半个星期之后，绝望战胜了羞怯，他便给《巨浪》的编者写信，暗示也许是由于经理的疏忽大意，他的一点儿稿费被忽略了。 To cap the situation, “The Pot,” which he looked upon as one of the best things he had written, was lost to him.In despair, casting about frantically among the magazines, he had sent it to @The Billow@, a society weekly in San Francisco.His chief reason for submitting it to that publication was that, having only to travel across the bay from Oakland, a quick decision could be reached.Two weeks later he was overjoyed to see, in the latest number on the news-stand, his story printed in full, illustrated, and in the place of honor.He went home with leaping pulse, wondering how much they would pay him for one of the best things he had done.Also, the celerity with which it had been accepted and published was a pleasant thought to him.That the editor had not informed him of the acceptance made the surprise more complete.After waiting a week, two weeks, and half a week longer, desperation conquered diffidence, and he wrote to the editor of @The Billow@, suggesting that possibly through some negligence of the business manager his little account had been overlooked.
即使只有五块钱，马丁想，也能买足够的豆子和豌豆汤可以让我写出半打那样的小说，而且可能同样好呢。 Even if it isn’t more than five dollars, Martin thought to himself, it will buy enough beans and pea-soup to enable me to write half a dozen like it, and possibly as good.
回来的是编者一封平淡的信，但它至少使马丁赞赏。 Back came a cool letter from the editor that at least elicited Martin’s admiration.
“我们很感谢您，”信是这样写的，“为了您出色的投稿。本社全体同仁对该稿极为赏识，而如您所见，我们立刻将其发表并刊在显著位置。我们诚挚地希望您喜欢那些插图。 “We thank you,” it ran, “for your excellent contribution.All of us in the office enjoyed it immensely, and, as you see, it was given the place of honor and immediate publication.We earnestly hope that you liked the illustrations.
“再读来信，我们觉得您是为误会所困，以为我们对非特约稿件也会支付稿酬。这不是我们的习惯，不用说尊稿并非特约。自然，收到您的小说时，我们以为您是明白这个情形的。对此不幸之误会我们深表遗憾，对您郑重申明我们不渝的敬意。再次感谢您的供稿，并希望近期接到您更多的稿件……” “On rereading your letter it seems to us that you are laboring under the misapprehension that we pay for unsolicited manuscripts.This is not our custom, and of course yours was unsolicited.We assumed, naturally, when we received your story, that you understood the situation.We can only deeply regret this unfortunate misunderstanding, and assure you of our unfailing regard.Again, thanking you for your kind contribution, and hoping to receive more from you in the near future, we remain, etc.”
还有一则附言，大意是说《巨浪》是不赠阅的，但他们仍很乐意来年免费赠阅。 There was also a postscript to the effect that though @The Billow@ carried no free-list, it took great pleasure in sending him a complimentary subscription for the ensuing year.
那次经验之后，马丁便在他所有稿件的第一页页首注明：“请照一般稿费付酬。” After that experience, Martin typed at the top of the first sheet of all his manuscripts: “Submitted at your usual rate.”
他安慰自己，有一天他们会照我的一般稿酬付费的。 Some day, he consoled himself, they will be submitted at my usual rate.
这期间，他发现自己有一种追求完美的热望，在这种热情控制之下，他改写并润饰了《拥挤的街》、《生命之酒》、《喜悦》、《海洋抒情诗》以及其他早期的作品。像过去一样，每天工作十九个钟头，他还觉得不够。他拼命地写作、读书，完全忘记了戒烟带来的痛苦。鲁思给他的包装华美的戒烟药，他给藏进了衣柜最深处的角落里。特别是在挨饿的日子里，他忍受着没有烟草的痛苦；但不管多少次忍住烟瘾，对烟的渴望依然如往常一样强烈。他把戒烟看作是他获得的最大的成就。鲁思的观点则是他不过做了本该做的事。她给他买了戒烟药，用自己的私房钱，几天之内也就忘记这一切了。 He discovered in himself, at this period, a passion for perfection, under the sway of which he rewrote and polished “The Jostling Street,” “The Wine of Life,” “Joy,” the “Sea Lyrics,” and others of his earlier work.As of old, nineteen hours of labor a day was all too little to suit him.He wrote prodigiously, and he read prodigiously, forgetting in his toil the pangs caused by giving up his tobacco.Ruth’s promised cure for the habit, flamboyantly labelled, he stowed away in the most inaccessible corner of his bureau.Especially during his stretches of famine he suffered from lack of the weed; but no matter how often he mastered the craving, it remained with him as strong as ever.He regarded it as the biggest thing he had ever achieved.Ruth’s point of view was that he was doing no more than was right.She brought him the anti-tobacco remedy, purchased out of her glove money, and in a few days forgot all about it.
他那些机械的小小说，尽管他憎恨它们，嘲笑它们，却是成功的。由于它们，他赎回了所有当掉的东西，付清了大部分账单，还给自己的自行车买了副新轮胎。那些短篇小说至少让他免于断炊之苦，并给了他时间从事颇有抱负的工作；而支持着他的便是从《白鼠》那里得来的四十块钱。那是他的信心所在，他深信那些真正一流的杂志至少会付给一个无名的作者一般的稿酬，即便不会更多。但问题是，怎么能打进一流的杂志里去。他的最佳小说、论文和诗歌一直在那些杂志间乞求着，然而每个月，他却在它们一切形形色色的封面下，读到了许多沉闷的、枯燥的、毫无艺术感的东西。他有时在想，只要有一位编者肯从他那高傲的座位上写给我一行鼓励的字也好啊。即使我的作品与别人不同，即使它不合用，为谨慎起见，为篇幅不够，可其中总有什么地方会有一点点闪光，使他们激动，博得他们的赏识吧。因此，他又拿出一篇或另一篇稿件，比如《冒险》，一读再读，徒然努力，试图为编者的沉默辩护。 His machine-made storiettes, though he hated them and derided them, were successful.By means of them he redeemed all his pledges, paid most of his bills, and bought a new set of tires for his wheel.The storiettes at least kept the pot a-boiling and gave him time for ambitious work; while the one thing that upheld him was the forty dollars he had received from The @White Mouse@.He anchored his faith to that, and was confident that the really first-class magazines would pay an unknown writer at least an equal rate, if not a better one.But the thing was, how to get into the first-class magazines.His best stories, essays, and poems went begging among them, and yet, each month, he read reams of dull, prosy, inartistic stuff between all their various covers.If only one editor, he sometimes thought, would descend from his high seat of pride to write me one cheering line!No matter if my work is unusual, no matter if it is unfit, for prudential reasons, for their pages, surely there must be some sparks in it, somewhere, a few, to warm them to some sort of appreciation.And thereupon he would get out one or another of his manuscripts, such as “Adventure,” and read it over and over in a vain attempt to vindicate the editorial silence.
随着加利福尼亚明媚的春天的到来，他的宽裕日子却告结束。有几个星期之久，他为报章短篇小说供稿社出奇的沉默而忧虑着。后来有一天，他那十篇毫无瑕疵的、机械制造的短篇小说给寄了回来。还有一封短信，大意是说供稿社存稿过多，几个月之内不会再接受稿件。马丁甚至在那十篇短篇小说上也白花了力气。直到最近为止，供稿社还是每篇付给他五块钱，而且是寄一篇用一篇的。所以他觉得那十篇已经卖出去了，靠着银行已有的五十块钱，照此过活。这样他便一下子进入窘迫时期了，在此期间他继续把他早期的作品卖给那些不肯付钱的刊物，而把近期的作品投寄给那些不肯买他稿子的杂志。此外，他又到奥克兰的当铺去了。几则笑话和几首幽默小诗卖给了纽约的周刊，这使他能够勉强度日。就是在这时候，他写了询问信给几家著名的月刊和季刊，他们回复说，他们很少考虑非特约文章，他们大部分的内容都是预约稿件，都是由著名的专家撰写的，他们都是各领域的权威。 As the sweet California spring came on, his period of plenty came to an end.For several weeks he had been worried by a strange silence on the part of the newspaper storiette syndicate.Then, one day, came back to him through the mail ten of his immaculate machine-made storiettes.They were accompanied by a brief letter to the effect that the syndicate was overstocked, and that some months would elapse before it would be in the market again for manuscripts.Martin had even been extravagant on the strength of those ten storiettes.Toward the last the syndicate had been paying him five dollars each for them and accepting every one he sent.So he had looked upon the ten as good as sold, and he had lived accordingly, on a basis of fifty dollars in the bank.So it was that he entered abruptly upon a lean period, wherein he continued selling his earlier efforts to publications that would not pay and submitting his later work to magazines that would not buy.Also, he resumed his trips to the pawn-broker down in Oakland.A few jokes and snatches of humorous verse, sold to the New York weeklies, made existence barely possible for him.It was at this time that he wrote letters of inquiry to the several great monthly and quarterly reviews, and learned in reply that they rarely considered unsolicited articles, and that most of their contents were written upon order by well-known specialists who were authorities in their various fields.
第二十九章 CHAPTER XXIX
这个夏天对马丁来说是一个艰难的夏天。稿件审阅人和编辑们都休假去了，平时三个星期就能给答复的刊物，现在却要拖延到三个月以上。这种僵局给他的安慰便是他可以因此节省邮资。只有那些强盗刊物仍然活跃运行着，马丁把他早期的全部心血，如《采珠》、《海上事业》、《捉鳖》和《东北信风》，都投给他们了。从这些稿子中，他从没得到过一分钱。不错，在半年的通信之后，他取得了一项协定，据此协定，他从《捉鳖》得到了一把安全剃须刀，而《卫城》则因刊登他的《东北信风》答应给他五美元现金和五年的赠阅，算是完成了协议的第二部分。 It was a hard summer for Martin.Manuscript readers and editors were away on vacation, and publications that ordinarily returned a decision in three weeks now retained his manuscript for three months or more.The consolation he drew from it was that a saving in postage was effected by the deadlock.Only the robber-publications seemed to remain actively in business, and to them Martin disposed of all his early efforts, such as “Pearl-diving,” “The Sea as a Career,” “Turtle-catching,” and “The Northeast Trades.”For these manuscripts he never received a penny.It is true, after six months’ correspondence, he effected a compromise, whereby he received a safety razor for “Turtle-catching,” and that @The Acropolis@, having agreed to give him five dollars cash and five yearly subscriptions: for “The Northeast Trades,” fulfilled the second part of the agreement.
拿一首咏史蒂文森的十四行诗，他设法从一位波士顿的编辑那里榨出两美元来，那位编辑正办着一份颇有马修·阿诺德味道的杂志，钱袋子攥得极紧。《仙女与珍珠》是他新写成的一首二百行的巧妙的讽刺诗，刚刚出炉，还冒着热气，便讨得了旧金山一位杂志编辑的欢心，一条大铁路持有这家杂志的股份。那编辑写了信来，提出用车票代替稿酬，马丁回信询问车票是否可以转让。回信说不可以，所以，既然不能转让，他要求退回那首诗。诗给退回来了，编辑表示遗憾，马丁再次把它寄到旧金山，这次是给《大黄蜂》，这是一家自命不凡的月刊，曾被那位创办它的精明的记者捧进了第一流了刊物中去。然而在马丁出世之前《大黄蜂》的光芒就已开始暗淡。那位编者答应付十五美元给那首诗，但是它一经发表出来，稿酬的事好像就给忘了。马丁几次去信，他都置若罔闻，后来马丁去了一封动火的信，这才得到一个答复。这是一位新任编者写来的，他冷漠地通知马丁说，他拒绝为前任编辑的过错负责，还说总之他不怎么看重《仙女与珍珠》。 For a sonnet on Stevenson he managed to wring two dollars out of a Boston editor who was running a magazine with a Matthew Arnold taste and a penny-dreadful purse.“The Peri and the Pearl,” a clever skit of a poem of two hundred lines, just finished, white hot from his brain, won the heart of the editor of a San Francisco magazine published in the interest of a great railroad.When the editor wrote, offering him payment in transportation, Martin wrote back to inquire if the transportation was transferable.It was not, and so, being prevented from peddling it, he asked for the return of the poem.Back it came, with the editor’s regrets, and Martin sent it to San Francisco again, this time to @The Hornet@, a pretentious monthly that had been fanned into a constellation of the first magnitude by the brilliant journalist who founded it.But @The Hornet’s@ light had begun to dim long before Martin was born.The editor promised Martin fifteen dollars for the poem, but, when it was published, seemed to forget about it.Several of his letters being ignored, Martin indicted an angry one which drew a reply.It was written by a new editor, who coolly informed Martin that he declined to be held responsible for the old editor’s mistakes, and that he did not think much of “The Peri and the Pearl” anyway.
但是一家芝加哥杂志《地球》，却给了马丁最残酷的待遇。他一直不愿把《海上抒情诗》拿去发表，直至被饥饿驱使。在被成打的杂志拒绝后，它们来到了《地球》杂志社。这集子共有三十首诗，一首诗他能拿到一美元。第一个月刊登了四首，他很快就接到了一张四美元的支票；但他翻阅杂志的时候，他给那屠杀式的篡改吓坏了。有好几篇，题目都给改了，比如《卷终》被改成《结局》，《外礁之歌》被改成了《珊瑚礁之歌》。还有一篇则换上了一个完全不同的，一个文不对题的题目。他自己拟的《美杜莎的目光》被编者改成了《后退的小路》。然而对诗歌正文的屠杀更怕人。马丁呻吟着，出着汗，两手揪着头发。字句、诗行和小节不可思议地被割裂、调换、篡改。有时还用其他诗句和小节来代替他的原作。他难以相信，一个神智健全的编者竟会如此虐待他的作品，他倒是愿意假设他的诗一定是给办公室杂役或速记员篡改了。马丁立刻写信，请求编者不要再刊登他的诗，并将原稿退还。 But @The Globe@, a Chicago magazine, gave Martin the most cruel treatment of all.He had refrained from offering his “Sea Lyrics” for publication, until driven to it by starvation.After having been rejected by a dozen magazines, they had come to rest in @The Globe@ office.There were thirty poems in the collection, and he was to receive a dollar a　piece for them.The first month four were published, and he promptly received a cheek for four dollars; but when he looked over the magazine, he was appalled at the slaughter.In some cases the titles had been altered: “Finis,” for instance, being changed to “The Finish,” and “The Song of the Outer Reef” to “The Song of the Coral Reef.”In one case, an absolutely different title, a misappropriate title, was substituted.In place of his own, “Medusa Lights,” the editor had printed, “The Backward Track.”But the slaughter in the body of the poems was terrifying.Martin groaned and sweated and thrust his hands through his hair.Phrases, lines, and stanzas were cut out, interchanged, or juggled about in the most incomprehensible manner.Sometimes lines and stanzas not his own were substituted for his.He could not believe that a sane editor could be guilty of such maltreatment, and his favorite hypothesis was that his poems must have been doctored by the office boy or the stenographer.Martin wrote immediately, begging the editor to cease publishing the lyrics and to return them to him.
他写了一封又一封，请求，乞求，威胁，但是他的信总是被漠然处之。一个月又一个月，屠杀继续着，直到那三十首诗全部被刊登出来，而一个月又一个月，该期一经刊出，他便会收到一张支票。 He wrote again and again, begging, entreating, threatening, but his letters were ignored.Month by month the slaughter went on till the thirty poems were published, and month by month he received a check for those which had appeared in the current number.
尽管有着这些形形色色的倒霉事，关于《白鼠》杂志那四十美元支票的记忆总还支撑着他，虽然他被迫写了越来越多的应付差事的文章。他从农业周刊和贸易杂志上发现了面包和黄油地，而在宗教周刊上，他发觉很容易挨饿。在他最低谷的阶段，他的黑色套装也进了典当铺，他在共和党郡委会组织的一次有奖征文中得了个满分——至少他自己是这么认为的。竞赛分三项，他都参加了，当自己被逼进了这么一个窘境的时候，他只好对自己苦笑。他的诗得了十美元的头奖，他的竞选歌曲得了五美元的二等奖，他的论共和党原则的论文得了二十美元的头奖。这叫他很满意，直到他试图去领钱的时候。郡委会出了什么岔子，虽然有一位有钱的银行家和一位参议员都是竞赛的会员，却不见钱来。这件事耽搁下来的时候，他在另一个类似的竞赛中证明了自己了解民主党的原则，还因为他的论文赢得了一等奖。而且，他还领到了二十五美元。但是上一次竞赛中那四十美元他再也没拿到。 Despite these various misadventures, the memory of the @White Mouse@ forty-dollar check sustained him, though he was driven more and more to hack-work.He discovered a bread-and-butter field in the agricultural weeklies and trade journals, though among the religious weeklies he found he could easily starve.At his lowest ebb, when his black suit was in pawn, he made a ten-strike—or so it seemed to him—in a prize contest arranged by the County Committee of the Republican Party.There were three branches of the contest, and he entered them all, laughing at himself bitterly the while in that he was driven to such straits to live.His poem won the first prize of ten dollars, his campaign song the second prize of five dollars, his essay on the principles of the Republican Party the first prize of twenty-five dollars.Which was very gratifying to him until he tried to collect.Something had gone wrong in the County Committee, and, though a rich banker and a state senator were members of it, the money was not forthcoming.While this affair was hanging fire, he proved that he understood the principles of the Democratic Party by winning the first prize for his essay in a similar contest.And, moreover, he received the money, twenty-five dollars.But the forty dollars won in the first contest he never received.
他不得不设想怎样和鲁思见面，由于从北奥克兰步行到她家再走回来需要花费太多时间，因此他决定把黑色套装留在当铺，而不是他的自行车。自行车能让他锻炼身体，还能替他省下时间来工作，同样还能让他跟鲁思见面。一条帆布短裤和一件旧运动衫也算是一套看得过去的骑车装，这样，下午他就能够和鲁思一起骑车了。再说，他也不再有机会在她家里见她，因为莫尔斯太太正全面实行她的娱宾活动。不久前他在那儿见到的，曾叫他觉得高贵的上流人士，现在叫他厌烦了。他们不再高贵。他正处在艰难时期，失意，工作又太辛苦，导致他紧张易怒，而这些人的交谈让他生气。他并非过度地以自我为中心。他用他读过的书本中那些思想家的心胸来度量他们狭隘的心胸。在鲁思家他从没见到一个心胸广阔的人，除了考德威尔教授，而考德威尔教授，他在那儿只见过一次。至于其余的人，都是些傻瓜笨蛋，肤浅、武断、无知。正是他们的无知叫他吃惊。他们是怎么一回事呢？他们所受的教育哪儿去了？他们同他读过同样的书。他们怎么没从那些书上学到一点儿东西呢？ Driven to shifts in order to see Ruth, and deciding that the long walk from north Oakland to her house and back again consumed too much time, he kept his black suit in pawn in place of his bicycle.The latter gave him exercise, saved him hours of time for work, and enabled him to see Ruth just the same.A pair of knee duck trousers and an old sweater made him a presentable wheel costume, so that he could go with Ruth on afternoon rides.Besides, he no longer had opportunity to see much of her in her own home, where Mrs. Morse was thoroughly prosecuting her campaign of entertainment.The exalted beings he met there, and to whom he had looked up but a short time before, now bored him.They were no longer exalted.He was nervous and irritable, what of his hard times, disappointments, and close application to work, and the conversation of such people was maddening.He was not unduly egotistic.He measured the narrowness of their minds by the minds of the thinkers in the books he read.At Ruth’s home he never met a large mind, with the exception of Professor Caldwell, and Caldwell he had met there only once.As for the rest, they were numskulls, ninnies, superficial, dogmatic, and ignorant.It was their ignorance that astounded him.What was the matter with them?What had they done with their educations?They had had access to the same books he had.How did it happen that they had drawn nothing from them?
他知道伟大的心灵和深沉理性的思想者是存在的。他从书本上得到了证据，那些书本给他的教育超出了莫尔斯的水准。他也知道，世上有比莫尔斯那个圈子的人们更聪明的智者。他阅读英国的社会小说，从那里面瞥见了一些谈论政治和哲学的男男女女们。他也读到了在大城市里，甚至在美国也有的沙龙，那是艺术与智慧会集的地方。过去，他愚蠢地以为所有劳动阶级之上的穿着考究的人们都具有智慧的力量和美的活力。对他来说，文化和衣领相勾结，他曾被欺骗，竟相信大学教育和博学是同一件事情。 He knew that the great minds, the deep and rational thinkers, existed.He had his proofs from the books, the books that had educated him beyond the Morse standard.And he knew that higher intellects than those of the Morse circle were to be found in the world.He read English society novels, wherein he caught glimpses of men and women talking politics and philosophy.And he read of salons in great cities, even in the United States, where art and intellect congregated.Foolishly, in the past, he had conceived that all well-groomed persons above the working class were persons with power of intellect and vigor of beauty.Culture and collars had gone together, to him, and he had been deceived into believing that college educations and mastery were the same things.
那么，他就要力求上进，走得更高。而且还要带着鲁思一起。他深爱着她，深信无论到哪里她都会大放异彩。他明白自己曾被早年的环境所妨碍，而现在他也看出她同样被妨碍着。她没有机会施展。他父亲书架上的书，墙上的画，钢琴上弹出的音乐——所有这些都是华而不实的炫耀。对于真正的文学，真正的绘画，真正的音乐，莫尔斯一家和他们那一群人是麻木的。比这些东西更伟大的是生活，对于生活，他们无知得令人绝望。尽管他们有一神论倾向和保守派的思想开明的面具，他们总比解释性的科学落后了两代。他们的精神过程处在中世纪，而他们对于存在和宇宙的根本资料的思索，让他觉得也是同样的形而上学的方法，其幼稚有如最年轻的种族，其古老有如穴居人，而且还要古老——那方法使更新世的第一个猿人害怕黑暗；使第一个轻率的希伯来野蛮人将亚当的肋骨做成夏娃；使笛卡尔从他渺小的自我投影建立起一个理想主义的宇宙体系；使那个有名的英国教士用如此苛刻的讽刺公然抨击进化论，他获得了即刻的喝彩，却让他在历史的篇章里臭名昭著。 Well, he would fight his way on and up higher.And he would take Ruth with him.Her he dearly loved, and he was confident that she would shine anywhere.As it was clear to him that he had been handicapped by his early environment, so now he perceived that she was similarly handicapped.She had not had a chance to expand.The books on her father’s shelves, the paintings on the walls, the music on the piano—all was just so much meretricious display.To real literature, real painting, real music, the Morses and their kind, were dead.And bigger than such things was life, of which they were densely, hopelessly ignorant.In spite of their Unitarian proclivities and their masks of conservative broadmindedness, they were two generations behind interpretative science:their mental processes were mediaeval, while their thinking on the ultimate data of existence and of the universe struck him as the same metaphysical method that was as young as the youngest race, as old as the cave-man, and older—the same that moved the first Pleistocene ape-man to fear the dark;that moved the first hasty Hebrew savage to incarnate Eve from Adam’s rib; that moved Descartes to build an idealistic system of the universe out of the projections of his own puny ego; and that moved the famous British ecclesiastic to denounce evolution in satire so scathing as to win immediate applause and leave his name a notorious scrawl on the page of history.
马丁想着，而且想得更远了，直至他恍然大悟，他见过的这些律师、官员、商人、银行经理，与他所认识的那些劳动阶级成员们之间的不同，正是他们所吃的食物、所穿的衣服和他们所居住的环境不同。毫无疑问，他们都缺少他在自己身上和书本上找到的某种额外的东西。莫尔斯一家已将他们的社会地位所能产生的最佳事物给他展示过了，而他并未为其迷惑。他本人，一个穷人，一个放债者的奴隶，可他知道自己比那些在莫尔斯家见到的人要优秀；等他把那套体面地衣服从当铺赎出来，他就可以像一个生活的主人一样在他们中间周旋，他像一个被罢黜到牧羊人中间的王子，因为受侮辱而战栗。 So Martin thought, and he thought further, till it dawned upon him that the difference between these lawyers, officers, business men, and bank cashiers he had met and the members of the working class he had known was on a par with the difference in the food they ate, clothes they wore, neighborhoods in which they lived.Certainly, in all of them was lacking the something more which he found in himself and in the books.The Morses had shown him the best their social position could produce, and he was not impressed by it.A pauper himself, a slave to the money-lender, he knew himself the superior of those he met at the Morses’; and, when his one decent suit of clothes was out of pawn, he moved among them a lord of life, quivering with a sense of outrage akin to what a prince would suffer if condemned to live with goat-herds.
“你痛恨并且害怕那些社会主义者，”一天傍晚马丁在用餐时对莫尔斯先生说，“可是为什么呢？你既不了解他们，也不了解他们的信条。” “You hate and fear the socialists,” he remarked to Mr. Morse, one evening at dinner; “but why?You know neither them nor their doctrines.”
谈话是由莫尔斯太太引到这方面来的，她惹人厌烦地大赞哈普古德先生。那位银行经理是马丁最讨厌的人，一提到那个满口陈词滥调的家伙他就生气。 The conversation had been swung in that direction by Mrs. Morse, who had been invidiously singing the praises of Mr. Hapgood.The cashier was Martin’s black beast, and his temper was a trifle short where the talker of platitudes was concerned.
“是的，”他曾这样说过，“查理·哈普古德是他们所谓的如日方升的青年——有人这么跟我说。确实是这样。他今生也许能坐上州长的交椅吧，谁知道呢？说不定还能进美国参议院呢。” “Yes,” he had said, “Charley Hapgood is what they call a rising young man—somebody told me as much.And it is true.He’ll make the Governor’s Chair before he dies, and, who knows?maybe the United States Senate.”
“你为什么这么想？”莫尔斯太太曾这样问道。 “What makes you think so?” Mrs. Morse had inquired.
“我听过他的竞选演讲。愚蠢且平凡得如此聪明，还说得头头是道，那些领袖们只好认为他是文档可靠的了，而他的陈词滥调又是这么像那些普通选举人的陈词滥调——哦，对啦，你知道要奉承任何人的话，只要把他的想法巧妙地表达出来，再说给他听就可以。” “I’ve heard him make a campaign speech.It was so cleverly stupid and unoriginal, and also so convincing, that the leaders cannot help but regard him as safe and sure, while his platitudes are so much like the platitudes of the average voter that—oh, well, you know you flatter any man by dressing up his own thoughts for him and presenting them to him.”
“说实话我觉得你在嫉妒哈普古德先生。”鲁思曾附和道。 “I actually think you are jealous of Mr. Hapgood,” Ruth had chimed in.
“上天可是不允许啊！” “Heaven forbid!”
马丁脸上可怕的神情激起了莫尔斯太太耳朵好战性。 The look of horror on Martin’s face stirred Mrs. Morse to belligerence.
“你应该不是真的在说哈普古德先生愚蠢吧？”她冷冰冰地质问。 “You surely don’t mean to say that Mr. Hapgood is stupid?” she demanded icily.
“绝不会胜过一个一般的共和党人，”他回击道，“或是一个一般的民主党人。他们不耍诡计的时候都很愚蠢，而他们当中很少有善于耍诡计的。唯一聪明的共和党人便是那些百万富翁以及他们有心效力的仆从。他们知道哪一面有利，也懂得是什么原因。” “No more than the average Republican,” was the retort, “or average Democrat, either.They are all stupid when they are not crafty, and very few of them are crafty.The only wise Republicans are the millionnaires and their conscious henchmen.They know which side their bread is buttered on, and they know why.”
“我就是一个共和党，”莫尔斯先生不动声色地插了一句，“请问，你把我归为哪类？” “I am a Republican,” Mr. Morse put in lightly.“Pray, how do you classify me?”
“哦，你是一个不自觉的仆从。” “Oh, you are an unconscious henchman.”
“仆从？” “Henchman?”
