“对呀。你办的是公司的事物。你不替劳动阶级办事，也不打刑事官司。你不靠流氓和扒手维持你的收入。你靠那些社会上的大亨们谋生，谁供养某人，谁就是这人的主人。是的，你是一个仆从。你感兴趣的是增进你所服务的资本集团的利益。” “Why, yes.You do corporation work.You have no working-class nor criminal practice.You don’t depend upon wife-beaters and pickpockets for your income.You get your livelihood from the masters of society, and whoever feeds a man is that man’s master.Yes, you are a henchman.You are interested in advancing the interests of the aggregations of capital you serve.”
莫尔斯先生的脸涨得有点儿红了。 Mr. Morse’s face was a trifle red.
“我得说，先生，”他说，“你说话就像一个无赖的社会主义者。” “I confess, sir,” he said, “that you talk like a scoundrelly socialist.”
于是马丁才说出了这番话： Then it was that Martin made his remark:
“你痛恨并且害怕社会主义者；可是为什么呢？你既不了解他们，也不了解他们的信条。” “You hate and fear the socialists; but why?You know neither them nor their doctrines.”
“你的理论听起来确实像是社会主义。”莫尔斯先生答道，而鲁思不安地注视着他们俩，莫尔斯太太呢，眼看着有机会激起他丈夫的反对情绪，高兴地满脸放光。 “Your doctrine certainly sounds like socialism,” Mr. Morse replied, while Ruth gazed anxiously from one to the other, and Mrs. Morse beamed happily at the opportunity afforded of rousing her liege lord’s antagonism.
“就因为我说共和党人愚蠢，主张自由、平等、博爱无非是破灭的气泡，并不能说我就是社会主义者，”马丁微笑着说，“因为我对杰斐逊和那些启发他心灵的不科学的法国人持有怀疑，并不能使我成为社会主义者。相信我，莫尔斯先生，你比我更接近社会主义，我自认是社会主义的敌人。” “Because I say Republicans are stupid, and hold that liberty, equality, and fraternity are exploded bubbles, does not make me a socialist,” Martin said with a smile.“Because I question Jefferson and the unscientific Frenchmen who informed his mind, does not make me a socialist.Believe me, Mr. Morse, you are far nearer socialism than I who am its avowed enemy.”
“现在你是在开玩笑吧。”对方只得这么说。 “Now you please to be facetious,” was all the other could say.
“没开玩笑。我是正正经经地说的。你仍然相信平等，可你还办着公司的事物，而公司，天天忙着埋葬平等。你把我叫做社会主义者只因为我否认平等，揭穿了你在身体力行的东西。共和党人是平等的敌人，虽然他们中的大多数嘴上挂着平等的口号，却斗争着反对平等。他们以平等的名义破坏平等。这就是我说他们愚昧的原因。至于我自己，我是一个个人主义者。我相信赛跑是快的赢，打仗是强的胜。这便是我从生物学得来的，或者说，至少我以为是得来了。如我所说，我是一个个人主义者，个人主义天生就是社会主义永远的敌人。” “Not at all.I speak in all seriousness.You still believe in equality, and yet you do the work of the corporations, and the corporations, from day to day, are busily engaged in burying equality.And you call me a socialist because I deny equality, because I affirm just what you live up to.The Republicans are foes to equality, though most of them fight the battle against equality with the very word itself the slogan on their lips.In the name of equality they destroy equality.That was why I called them stupid.As for myself, I am an individualist.I believe the race is to the swift, the battle to the strong.Such is the lesson I have learned from biology, or at least think I have learned.As I said, I am an individualist, and individualism is the hereditary and eternal foe of socialism.”
“可你常去参加社会主义者的集会。”莫尔斯先生反驳道。 “But you frequent socialist meetings,” Mr. Morse challenged.
“一点儿不错，正如间谍常潜入敌营。此外，你还能怎样了解敌人呢？再说，我在他们的集会中觉得快活。他们是善战的战士，而且，不管对错，他们是读过书的。比起那些平庸的企业老板，他们中的每一个人都更懂得社会学和所有别的什么学。对，我参加过他们的集会有六七次，可是这并没有使我成为一个社会主义者，就像听了查理·哈普古德的演说没有使我成为一个共和党一样。” “Certainly, just as spies frequent hostile camps.How else are you to learn about the enemy?Besides, I enjoy myself at their meetings.They are good fighters, and, right or wrong, they have read the books.Any one of them knows far more about sociology and all the other ologies than the average captain of industry.Yes, I have been to half a dozen of their meetings, but that doesn’t make me a socialist any more than hearing Charley Hapgood orate made me a Republican.”
“我是情不自禁的，”莫尔斯先生无力地说，“可我仍然相信你倾向社会主义。” “I can’t help it,” Mr. Morse said feebly, “but I still believe you incline that way.”
上帝保佑，马丁暗想，他并不懂我在说什么。他一句话都没听懂。他受的教育到底哪儿去了？ Bless me, Martin thought to himself, he doesn’t know what I was talking about.He hasn’t understood a word of it.What did he do with his education, anyway?
这样，在他的发展当中，马丁发现自己面对着经济道德，或阶级道德；很快，这对于他简直就是一个可怕的怪兽。就个人而言，他是一个智慧的道德家，在他看来，比庸俗的自傲更可恶的便是他周围的伦理道德，那是经济的，形而上学的，感情用事的，和效仿他人的道德的古怪的大杂烩。 Thus, in his development, Martin found himself face to face with economic morality, or the morality of class; and soon it became to him a grisly monster.Personally, he was an intellectual moralist, and more offending to him than platitudinous pomposity was the morality of those about him, which was a curious hotchpotch of the economic, the metaphysical, the sentimental, and the imitative.
这种古怪的混乱的混合物，他在自己家里就尝到了。他的妹妹玛丽安过去一直同一个勤奋的年轻机器匠相好，他有德国血统，当完全学会了那门手艺之后，他就自己开了一家自行车修理铺。而且，成了一种低级自行车的代理人之后，他便发达了。玛丽安不久前到马丁家里去看他，告诉他她要订婚的消息，那次，她还开玩笑地给马丁看手相，谈论他的命运。第二次来访时，她带来了赫尔曼·冯·施密特。马丁殷勤招待，并且用流畅优雅的言语向二人表示祝贺，却引起了他妹妹的情人农民意识的不快。马丁朗读了他为纪念玛丽安上次来访所作的六七节诗，更加深了这种坏印象。这是一首社交诗，轻快而精巧，他把它题做《看手相者》。他读完诗，却惊讶地发现他妹妹的脸上并无愉悦的表情。倒是她的眼睛不安地盯着她的未婚夫，而马丁，顺着她的目光，看到了那个重要人物不端正的脸上只有阴沉、愠怒、不以为然的神色。这桩意外的事情过去了，他们提早离开了，马丁也就忘了这一切，尽管有时候他会困惑，任何一个女人，即使是劳动阶级，有人为她写诗，她有什么不满足、不高兴的呢。 A sample of this curious messy mixture he encountered nearer home.His sister Marian had been keeping company with an industrious young mechanic, of German extraction, who, after thoroughly learning the trade, had set up for himself in a bicycle-repair shop.Also, having got the agency for a low-grade make of wheel, he was prosperous.Marian had called on Martin in his room a short time before to announce her engagement, during which visit she had playfully inspected Martin’s palm and told his fortune.On her next visit she brought Hermann von Schmidt along with her.Martin did the honors and congratulated both of them in language so easy and graceful as to affect disagreeably the peasant-mind of his sister’s lover.This bad impression was further heightened by Martin’s reading aloud the half-dozen stanzas of verse with which he had commemorated Marian’s previous visit.It was a bit of society verse, airy and delicate, which he had named “The Palmist.”He was surprised, when he finished reading it, to note no enjoyment in his sister’s face.Instead, her eyes were fixed anxiously upon her betrothed, and Martin, following her gaze, saw spread on that worthy’s asymmetrical features nothing but black and sullen disapproval.The incident passed over, they made an early departure, and Martin forgot all about it, though for the moment he had been puzzled that any woman, even of the working class, should not have been flattered and delighted by having poetry written about her.
几晚之后，玛丽安又来看他，这次是独自一个人。她没浪费什么时间便直入本题，她伤心地责备他所做的事。 Several evenings later Marian again visited him, this time alone.Nor did she waste time in coming to the point, upbraiding him sorrowfully for what he had done.
“怎么啦，玛丽安，”他责难道，“你说话那样子就好像你的亲人给你丢了脸，或者至少是你的兄弟给你丢脸了似的。” “Why, Marian,” he chided, “you talk as though you were ashamed of your relatives, or of your brother at any rate.”
“我就是觉得丢脸。”她冲口而出。 “And I am, too,” she blurted out.
看到她眼里屈辱的泪水，马丁感到困惑了。这情绪无论它怎样，总是真实的。 Martin was bewildered by the tears of mortification he saw in her eyes.The mood, whatever it was, was genuine.
“但是，玛丽安，你的赫尔曼怎么会嫉妒我为我自己的妹妹写诗呢？” “But, Marian, why should your Hermann be jealous of my writing poetry about my own sister?”
“他不是嫉妒，”她抽泣着，“他说这是不正经，淫——秽。” “He ain’t jealous,” she sobbed.“He says it was indecent, ob—obscene.”
马丁吹了一声长而低的口哨，表示怀疑，于是又重新去读那份复写成的《看手相者》。 Martin emitted a long, low whistle of incredulity, then proceeded to resurrect and read a carbon copy of “The Palmist.”
“我看不出来，”他最后说，并把稿子递给她，“你自己念念，告诉我什么地方让你觉得淫秽——是这个词吧？” “I can’t see it,” he said finally, proffering the manuscript to her.“Read it yourself and show me whatever strikes you as obscene—that was the word, wasn’t it?”
“他是这么说的，他应该知道，”她答道，带着一种厌恶的表情推开了稿子，“他还说你应该撕掉它。他说他不要她的女人给写出来，还谁都能读。他说这太丢脸了，他忍受不了。” “He says so, and he ought to know,” was the answer, with a wave aside of the manuscript, accompanied by a look of loathing.“And he says you’ve got to tear it up.He says he won’t have no wife of his with such things written about her which anybody can read.He says it’s a disgrace, an’ he won’t stand for it.”
“你听我说啊，玛丽安，这完全是胡说八道。”马丁开始这么说；之后他突然改变了主意。 “Now, look here, Marian, this is nothing but nonsense,” Martin began; then abruptly changed his mind.
他看到在他面前的是个不开心的姑娘，知道企图说服她的丈夫或是她是毫无用处的，虽然整个情形是荒唐可笑的，他也决定屈服了。 He saw before him an unhappy girl, knew the futility of attempting to convince her husband or her, and, though the whole situation was absurd and preposterous, he resolved to surrender.
“好吧。”他宣布，并把稿子撕成六七片，扔进了废纸篓。 “All right,” he announced, tearing the manuscript into half a dozen pieces and throwing it into the waste-basket.
他心里有数，因为他知道他的原版打印稿正躺在纽约一家杂志社的办公室里。玛丽安和她的丈夫永远不会知道，即使那首精巧的无害的诗刊登出来了，他自己，他们俩或全世界都不会有什么损失。 He contented himself with the knowledge that even then the original type-written manuscript was reposing in the office of a New York magazine.Marian and her husband would never know, and neither himself nor they nor the world would lose if the pretty, harmless poem ever were published.
玛丽安正向废纸篓伸手，却忍住了。 Marian, starting to reach into the waste-basket, refrained.
“我可以吗？” 她乞求着。 “Can I?” she pleaded.
他点点头，若有所思地望着她，在她收拾起那些稿子的碎片，塞进上衣口袋的时候——那是她任务成功的证据。她让他想起利奇·康诺利，虽然在她身上，较之那个他曾见过两次的劳动阶级的姑娘，少了火热、灿烂耀眼的生命力。但她们这一对，服装和姿态是一样的，他又想像她们两个其中之一出现在莫尔斯太太的厅堂里的情景，他心里一乐，笑了起来。快乐褪去，他有一种强烈的寂寞感。他的这个妹妹和莫尔斯太太的厅堂是他走过的旅途的里程碑。他已经把他们落在后面了。他深情地瞟了一眼他周围的那几本书。它们便是他仅余的同伴了。 He nodded his head, regarding her thoughtfully as she gathered the torn pieces of manuscript and tucked them into the pocket of her jacket—ocular evidence of the success of her mission.She reminded him of Lizzie Connolly, though there was less of fire and gorgeous flaunting life in her than in that other girl of the working class whom he had seen twice.But they were on a par, the pair of them, in dress and carriage, and he smiled with inward amusement at the caprice of his fancy which suggested the appearance of either of them in Mrs. Morse’s drawing-room.The amusement faded, and he was aware of a great loneliness.This sister of his and the Morse drawing-room were milestones of the road he had travelled.And he had left them behind.He glanced affectionately about him at his few books.They were all the comrades left to him.
“喂，你说什么？”他吃了一惊，问道。 “Hello, what’s that?” he demanded in startled surprise.
玛丽安重复了一遍她的问题。 Marian repeated her question.
“我干吗不去做工？”他突然笑了，却有一般是勉强的。“你的那位赫尔曼对你说的吧。“ “Why don’t I go to work?”He broke into a laugh that was only half-hearted.“That Hermann of yours has been talking to you.”
她摇了摇头。 She shook her head.
“别骗我。”他命令道，她点头证实了他的判断。 “Don’t lie,” he commanded, and the nod of her head affirmed his charge.
“那么，你告诉你那位赫尔曼叫他管好他自己的事吧；我给他相好的姑娘写诗算他的事情，除此之外，他没权说三道四。懂了么？” “Well, you tell that Hermann of yours to mind his own business; that when I write poetry about the girl he’s keeping company with it’s his business, but that outside of that he’s got no say so.Understand?
“那么你以为我作为一个作家是不会成功的吧，呃？”他接着说，“你以为我一无是处？——以为我跌倒了，是家庭的耻辱么？” “So you don’t think I’ll succeed as a writer, eh?” he went on.“You think I’m no good? —that I’ve fallen down and am a disgrace to the family?”
“我以为你要是有一份工作就会好得多，”她坚决地说，他也看出她是真诚的。“赫尔曼说——” “I think it would be much better if you got a job,” she said firmly, and he saw she was sincere.“Hermann says—”
“该死的赫尔曼！”他好脾气地叫道。 “Damn Hermann!” he broke out good-naturedly.
“我想知道的是你们什么时候结婚。还有，打探一下你的赫尔曼是否允许你接受我送的结婚礼物。” “What I want to know is when you’re going to get married.Also, you find out from your Hermann if he will deign to permit you to accept a wedding present from me.”
她走后，他默想了一下这件意外的事，有一两次竟苦笑起来，他看见他的妹妹和她的未婚夫，所有属于他那个阶级的人以及属于鲁思所在阶级的人，照着渺小的公式过着他们渺小的生活——这些群居动物，群集在一起，按照彼此的意见塑造着他们的生活，因为那些束缚住他们的幼稚的公式而不能成为独立的个体，不能真真正正地过生活。他召唤他们，使他们形成幻象的队伍：伯纳德·希金博特姆与巴特勒先生手挽手，赫尔曼·冯·施密特跟查理·哈普古德脸贴着脸，他把他们一个一个，一对一对做了评判，然后再把他们解散——用他从书本上得来的智慧和道德标准评判他们。徒然问道：伟大的灵魂，伟大的男人和女人在哪呢？在应了他的幻想之召来到他的斗室中的那些轻率的、粗俗的、愚蠢的聪明人中，他没有找到他们。他厌恶他们一定正如喀耳刻厌恶她的猪。当他把最后一个也打发走后，以为只剩他自己时，却进来一个意想不到的不请自来的迟到者。马丁望着他，看见了那硬边帽子，方襟双排扣外套和大摇大摆的肩膀，那是个年轻的无赖，是当年的他。 He mused over the incident after she had gone, and once or twice broke out into laughter that was bitter as he saw his sister and her betrothed, all the members of his own class and the members of Ruth’s class, directing their narrow little lives by narrow little formulas—herd-creatures, flocking together and patterning their lives by one another’s opinions, failing of being individuals and of really living life because of the childlike formulas by which they were enslaved.He summoned them before him in apparitional procession: Bernard Higginbotham arm in arm with Mr. Butler, Hermann von Schmidt cheek by jowl with Charley Hapgood, and one by one and in pairs he judged them and dismissed them—judged them by the standards of intellect and morality he had learned from the books.Vainly he asked: Where are the great souls, the great men and women?He found them not among the careless, gross, and stupid intelligences that answered the call of vision to his narrow room.He felt a loathing for them such as Circe must have felt for her swine.When he had dismissed the last one and thought himself alone, a late-comer entered, unexpected and unsummoned.Martin watched him and saw the stiff-rim, the square-cut, double-breasted coat and the swaggering shoulders, of the youthful hoodlum who had once been he.
“你和其他人一样，小伙子，”马丁嗤之以鼻，“你的道德和知识，跟他们是一个样。你并没有听从自己本意去思想和行动。你的思想，像你的衣服一样，是已经做好的；你的行动随大众的喜好成形。你是你那帮派的头目，只因为别人称赞你是有种的家伙。你打架，你统治着你那个帮派，并非因为你愿意——你知道你其实是鄙弃它的——而只因为别人拍你的肩头表示赞许。你打垮了奶酪脸，是由于你不肯屈服，而你的不肯屈服，一部分是因为你极端粗野，另一部分则是因为你相信你身边的人所相信的，那就是衡量大丈夫的标准在于伤害和折磨同类的身体时所显示出的食肉的残忍性。哼，你这小杂种，你甚至抢走同伴的姑娘，不是因为你需要哪些姑娘，而是因为你周围的那些人，那些决定了你的道德的人的骨髓中，蕴藏着野生种马和雄海豹的本能。那些岁月已经过去了，现在你是怎么想的？” “You were like all the rest, young fellow,” Martin sneered.“Your morality and your knowledge were just the same as theirs.You did not think and act for yourself.Your opinions, like your clothes, were ready made; your acts were shaped by popular approval.You were cock of your gang because others acclaimed you the real thing.You fought and ruled the gang, not because you liked to,—you know you really despised it,—but because the other fellows patted you on the shoulder.You licked Cheese-Face because you wouldn’t give in, and you wouldn’t give in partly because you were an abysmal brute and for the rest because you believed what every one about you believed, that the measure of manhood was the carnivorous ferocity displayed in injuring and marring fellow-creatures’ anatomies.Why, you whelp, you even won other fellows’ girls away from them, not because you wanted the girls, but because in the marrow of those about you, those who set your moral pace, was the instinct of the wild stallion and the bull-seal.Well, the years have passed, and what do you think about it now?”
就像是回答一般，幻象迅速地变形。那硬边帽子和方襟外套消失了，为线条较柔和的衣服替代了；脸上的强硬，眼中的凶光不见了；经过磨练捶打，他的脸正放射出心灵与美和知识交融的光辉。那幻象很像现在的他自己，当他凝视着它时，他注意到映照着它的那盏台灯和它钻研的那本书。他瞥了一眼题目，读到，《美学》。接着，他便与那幻影合而为一，拧开台灯，继续读起《美学》。 As if in reply, the vision underwent a swift metamorphosis.The stiff-rim and the square-cut vanished, being replaced by milder garments; the toughness went out of the face, the hardness out of the eyes; and, the face, chastened and refined, was irradiated from an inner life of communion with beauty and knowledge.The apparition was very like his present self, and, as he regarded it, he noted the student-lamp by which it was illuminated, and the book over which it pored.He glanced at the title and read, @The Science of Aesthetics@.Next, he entered into the apparition, trimmed the student-lamp, and himself went on reading @The Science of Aesthetics@.
第三十章 CHAPTER XXX
在一个美丽的秋日，天气好似去年见证他们定情那天的小阳春天气，马丁读了他的《爱情连环曲》给鲁思听。这是下午的事情，像以前一样，他们骑车到了他们钟爱的群山中的小丘陵里。她时不时以欢乐的呼喊声打断了他的诵读，而现在，他把最后一页稿子和别的稿子放到一起，等着她的评判。 On a beautiful fall day, a day of similar Indian summer to that which had seen their love declared the year before, Martin read his “Love-cycle” to Ruth.It was in the afternoon, and, as before, they had ridden out to their favorite knoll in the hills.Now and again she had interrupted his reading with exclamations of pleasure, and now, as he laid the last sheet of manuscript with its fellows, he waited her judgment.
她迟疑着没说话，终于吞吞吐吐地说了，犹豫着怎么把难堪的想法用刺耳的话说出来。 She delayed to speak, and at last she spoke haltingly, hesitating to frame in words the harshness of her thought.
“我看它们都很美，非常美，”她说；“可是你卖不掉它们，是么？你明白我说的是什么。”她说，差不多是在恳求。“你的作品不实际。一定有什么问题——也许就是市场吧——妨碍着你，让你不能靠它过活。亲爱的，拜托你别误会我。你为我写了这些诗，我感到高兴，也引以为傲，不然的话，我就不算一个真正的女人了。但是它们并不能使我们的婚姻成为可能。你不明白么，马丁？别以为我是势利的。我考虑的是爱情，是我们的未来。自从知道我们相爱，整整一年已经过去了，而我们结婚的日子却没有近一点。别以为我这么谈着结婚，是不知廉耻，因为我真的是拿我的心和我的一切在下赌。如果你真是这么离不开写作的话，你干吗不去报馆做点事呢？干吗不去当个记者？——至少做一段时间？” “I think they are beautiful, very beautiful,” she said; “but you can’t sell them, can you?You see what I mean,” she said, almost pleaded.“This writing of yours is not practical.Something is the matter—maybe it is with the market—that prevents you from earning a living by it.And please, dear, don’t misunderstand me.I am flattered, and made proud, and all that—I could not be a true woman were it otherwise—that you should write these poems to me.But they do not make our marriage possible.Don’t you see, Martin?Don’t think me mercenary.It is love, the thought of our future, with which I am burdened.A whole year has gone by since we learned we loved each other, and our wedding day is no nearer.Don’t think me immodest in thus talking about our wedding, for really I have my heart, all that I am, at stake.Why don’t you try to get work on a newspaper, if you are so bound up in your writing?Why not become a reporter?—for a while, at least?”
“那会破坏我的风格，”他用低沉单调的声音答道，“你想象不到我怎样为风格努力的。” “It would spoil my style,” was his answer, in a low, monotonous voice.“You have no idea how I’ve worked for style.”
“可是那些短篇小说呢，”她反驳道，“你把它们叫做应付差事的文章。你写了很多。它们没破坏你的风格么？” “But those storiettes,” she argued.“You called them hack-work.You wrote many of them.Didn’t they spoil your style?”
“没有，情况不同。短篇小说是整天专心致力于风格之后，精疲力竭时才琢磨出来的。而一个记者的工作，却是从早到晚的卖文章，而且成了生活中极为重要的事情。这是种旋风般的生活，只有眼前的生活，没有过去，也没有未来，当然除了报道的风格之外不会想到其他风格，而这个当然也不是文学。我的风格正在形成、结晶的时候，要是我现在去做一个记者，就等于文学上的自杀。每一部短篇小说，每一部短篇小说的每一个字，都是对我自己，对我的自尊和我对美的尊重的损害，正是这样。我告诉你吧，这叫人恶心。我是有罪的。当它们没有市场的时候，我倒是暗暗高兴，即使是我的衣服进了当铺。可是写《爱情连环曲》时的快乐啊！那是最华丽的创造的快乐！那是对一切的补偿。” “No, the cases are different.The storiettes were ground out, jaded, at the end of a long day of application to style.But a reporter’s work is all hack from morning till night, is the one paramount thing of life.And it is a whirlwind life, the life of the moment, with neither past nor future, and certainly without thought of any style but reportorial style, and that certainly is not literature.To become a reporter now, just as my style is taking form, crystallizing, would be to commit literary suicide.As it is, every storiette, every word of every storiette, was a violation of myself, of my self-respect, of my respect for beauty.I tell you it was sickening.I was guilty of sin.And I was secretly glad when the markets failed, even if my clothes did go into pawn.But the joy of writing the ‘Love-cycle’!The creative joy in its noblest form!That was compensation for everything.”
马丁不知道鲁思对创造的快乐是没有同感的。她运用那个词——他第一次就是从她嘴里听到这个词的。她在大学里攻读学士学位时曾经读到过，研究过；但她却没有独创性，没有创造性，她一身的文化表现不过是人云亦云。 Martin did not know that Ruth was unsympathetic concerning the creative joy.She used the phrase—it was on her lips he had first heard it.She had read about it, studied about it, in the university in the course of earning her Bachelorship of Arts; but she was not original, not creative, and all manifestations of culture on her part were but harpings of the harpings of others.
“编辑修改你的《海洋抒情曲》难道不对么？”她问道。 “May not the editor have been right in his revision of your ‘Sea Lyrics’?” she questioned.
“记住，一位编辑，一定证明了是有资格的，不然的话，他就不能当编辑。” “Remember, an editor must have proved qualifications or else he would not be an editor.”
“那是与既成事物所坚持的相一致的，”他答辩道，对于编辑们的气愤越加强烈起来。“存在的事物不但合理，而且可能是最优的。任何事物的存在，便是它适于存在的充分证明——存在，你听好呀，正如一个普通人不知不觉间便相信的，它不但在当前环境中，而且在一切环境中都适合。不用说，这是他们的无知使他们相信这样的昏话——他们的无知，恰好和魏宁格所描写的模糊的心理过程不相上下。他们自以为有思想，而这些没有思想的人正是少数真正有思想的人的生活的裁判者。” “That’s in line with the persistence of the established,” he rejoined, his heat against the editor-folk getting the better of him.“What is, is not only right, but is the best possible.The existence of anything is sufficient vindication of its fitness to exist—to exist, mark you, as the average person unconsciously believes, not merely in present conditions, but in all conditions.It is their ignorance, of course, that makes them believe such rot—their ignorance, which is nothing more nor less than the henidical mental process described by Weininger.They think they think, and such thinkless creatures are the arbiters of the lives of the few who really think.”
他停了下来，不禁想到他说的话不是鲁思所能理解的。 He paused, overcome by the consciousness that he had been talking over Ruth’s head.
“我确实不知道魏宁格是谁，”她反驳道，“你的话空泛得可怕，我简直听不懂。我说的是编辑的资格——” “I’m sure I don’t know who this Weininger is,” she retorted.“And you are so dreadfully general that I fail to follow you.What I was speaking of was the qualification of editors—”
“我告诉你吧，”他打断了她，“所有的编辑中，有百分之九十九的主要条件是不合格的。他们作为作家是失败的。别以为他们愿意抛弃写作的快乐，看上办公桌上的苦差事，或者去做发行和经理的奴隶。他们尝试过写作，可他们失败了。于是这正好就产生了该死的矛盾。每一扇通往文学成就的大门都给那些看门狗，文学上的失败者把守着。编辑、副编辑、助理编辑中的大多数，为杂志、书刊出版者们审阅稿件中的大多数，几乎所有人都是想写作而失败了的人。然而他们，天底下芸芸众生中最不合适的人，偏偏是他们决定什么应该出版什么不该出版——他们已经证明了自己没有独创性，已经表明他们缺少灵秀的才华，却坐在那儿评判独创性与天才。他们之后还有评论家，也不过是些失败者。别告诉我他们没有做过梦，没有尝试过写诗歌或小说；因为做过尝试的，已经失败了。哎，平庸的评论比鱼肝油还要叫人恶心。可是你知道我对那些评论家和所谓的批评家的看法。确实有伟大的批评家，然而，他们像彗星一样少见。要是我作为一个作家不能成功的话，我可以证明自己是适合做编辑这一行的。无论如何，那儿总有面包奶油和果酱。” “And I’ll tell you,” he interrupted.“The chief qualification of ninety-nine per cent of all editors is failure.They have failed as writers.Don’t think they prefer the drudgery of the desk and the slavery to their circulation and to the business manager to the joy of writing.They have tried to write, and they have failed.And right there is the cursed paradox of it.Every portal to success in literature is guarded by those watch-dogs, the failures in literature.The editors, sub-editors, associate editors, most of them, and the manuscript-readers for the magazines and book-publishers, most of them, nearly all of them, are men who wanted to write and who have failed.And yet they, of all creatures under the sun the most unfit, are the very creatures who decide what shall and what shall not find its way into print—they, who have proved themselves not original, who have demonstrated that they lack the divine fire, sit in judgment upon originality and genius.And after them come the reviewers, just so many more failures.Don’t tell me that they have not dreamed the dream and attempted to write poetry or fiction; for they have, and they have failed.Why, the average review is more nauseating than cod-liver oil.But you know my opinion on the reviewers and the alleged critics.There are great critics, but they are as rare as comets.If I fail as a writer, I shall have proved for the career of editorship.There’s bread and butter and jam, at any rate.”
鲁思反应快，发现了他辩论里的矛盾，反对起恋人的观点来更加振振有辞了。 Ruth’s mind was quick, and her disapproval of her lover’s views was buttressed by the contradiction she found in his contention.
“可是马丁啊，如果是这样的话，如果一切大门都关闭了，如你所下的结论，那么伟大的作家是怎么来的呢？” “But, Martin, if that be so, if all the doors are closed as you have shown so conclusively, how is it possible that any of the great writers ever arrived?”
“他们是做到了不可能的事而成功的，”他答道，“他们的作品炫目辉煌，那些阻挠他们的人都被烧成灰烬了。他们是由于奇迹，由于赢得了一比一千的赌注才成功的。他们成功了，因为他们是卡莱尔所谓的那种遍体鳞伤却不会被压倒的巨人。这就是我必须做的事；我必须做成不可能的事。” “They arrived by achieving the impossible,” he answered.“They did such blazing, glorious work as to burn to ashes those that opposed them.They arrived by course of miracle, by winning a thousand-to-one wager against them.They arrived because they were Carlyle’s battle-scarred giants who will not be kept down.And that is what I must do; I must achieve the impossible.”
“可是，你如果失败了呢？你也得为我考虑呀，马丁。” “But if you fail?You must consider me as well, Martin.”
“如果我失败了？”他注视了她好一会儿，好像她刚说出的想法不可思议似的。然后，智慧照亮了他的眼睛。“如果我失败了，我会做一个编辑，你将是编辑的太太。” “If I fail?”He regarded her for a moment as though the thought she had uttered was unthinkable.Then intelligence illumined his eyes.“If I fail, I shall become an editor, and you will be an editor’s wife.”
她见他说笑，便皱起眉头——漂亮又可爱的皱眉，使他不禁搂住她，吻着她，叫她不再皱眉。 She frowned at his facetiousness—a pretty, adorable frown that made him put his arm around her and kiss it away.
“好了，够了，”她恳求他，她靠着意志力才把自己从他力量的诱惑中挣脱出来，“我已经和我父母谈过了。我从来没有这样坚持自我去对抗他们。我要求他们听从我的想法。我太不孝顺了。他们是反对你的，你知道；可是我反复向他们保证我对你永久不渝的爱，父亲终于同意了，如果你愿意的话，你可以从进他的事务所开始。后来，出于他的本意，他说他愿意一开始就给你足够的薪水，这样我们就可以结婚，还能找个地方有一处房子。我觉得这是他的好意——你不觉得么？” “There, that’s enough,” she urged, by an effort of will withdrawing herself from the fascination of his strength.“I have talked with father and mother.I never before asserted myself so against them.I demanded to be heard.I was very undutiful.They are against you, you know; but I assured them over and over of my abiding love for you, and at last father agreed that if you wanted to, you could begin right away in his office.And then, of his own accord, he said he would pay you enough at the start so that we could get married and have a little cottage somewhere.Which I think was very fine of him—don’t you?”
马丁感到失望，心中有着隐隐的痛，机械地摸着烟草和卷烟纸（这些他早就不带在身上了）想卷一支烟卷，含糊地喃喃着什么，鲁思接着说： Martin, with the dull pain of despair at his heart, mechanically reaching for the tobacco and paper (which he no longer carried) to roll a cigarette, muttered something inarticulate, and Ruth went on.
“坦白地说，总之，但愿别伤害你——我告诉你，是想让你确实地知道他是怎样看待你的——他不喜欢你激进的观点，他还觉得你懒惰。当然啦，我知道你不是那样的。你很刻苦。” “Frankly, though, and don’t let it hurt you—I tell you, to show you precisely how you stand with him—he doesn’t like your radical views, and he thinks you are lazy.Of course I know you are not.I know you work hard.”
马丁心想，怎么刻苦，甚至她也不知道吧。 How hard, even she did not know, was the thought in Martin’s mind.
“好了，那么，”他说，“我的观点呢？你认为它们是激进的吗？” “Well, then,” he said, “how about my views?Do you think they are so radical?”
他注视着她的眼睛，等待着她的答复。 He held her eyes and waited the answer.
“我认为它们，唔，让人心乱。”她答道。 “I think them, well, very disconcerting,” she replied.
她答复了他的问题，他是如此地为生活的灰暗所压迫，他竟忘记了她向他提出的试着去工作的提议了。她呢，既已冒险说了这么多，也愿意等待个答复，直到她又把问题提起的时候。 The question was answered for him, and so oppressed was he by the grayness of life that he forgot the tentative proposition she had made for him to go to work.And she, having gone as far as she dared, was willing to wait the answer till she should bring the question up again.
她没有多久可等。马丁也向她提出了一个自己的问题。他想确知她对他的信赖程度，一个星期之内，双方的问题都得到了答复。马丁念他的《太阳的耻辱》给她听，更加促进了局势发展。 She had not long to wait.Martin had a question of his own to propound to her.He wanted to ascertain the measure of her faith in him, and within the week each was answered.Martin precipitated it by reading to her his “The Shame of the Sun.”
“你干吗不做一个记者呢？”他念完的时候她问。 “Why don’t you become a reporter?” she asked when he had finished.
“你这么喜欢写作，我确定你会成功的。你可以在新闻界发展，并且成名。伟大的特约通讯员，有的是呢。他们薪水高，他们的地盘就是全世界。他们给派到各地去，到非洲的腹地，像斯坦利，或者去访问教皇，或者去不为人知的西藏探险。” “You love writing so, and I am sure you would succeed.You could rise in journalism and make a name for yourself.There are a number of great special correspondents.Their salaries are large, and their field is the world.They are sent everywhere, to the heart of Africa, like Stanley, or to interview the Pope, or to explore unknown Thibet.”
“那么你不喜欢我的论文么？”他答复道，“你相信我在新闻界会有点表现，在文学上便丝毫没有么？” “Then you don’t like my essay?” he rejoined.“You believe that I have some show in journalism but none in literature?”
“不，不；我喜欢你的论文。它读起来很顺畅。可是我怕你的读者们看不懂。至少我是不大明白的。它听起来很美，可是我理解。你的科学术语我就不懂。你是个极端主义者，你知道，亲爱的人啊，在你是明了的东西，对于我们这些人就不一定明了了。” “No, no; I do like it.It reads well.But I am afraid it’s over the heads of your readers.At least it is over mine.It sounds beautiful, but I don’t understand it.Your scientific slang is beyond me.You are an extremist, you know, dear, and what may be intelligible to you may not be intelligible to the rest of us.”
“我想是那些哲学术语叫你不明白。”他能说的就是这句话了。 “I imagine it’s the philosophic slang that bothers you,” was all he could say.
由于刚刚读了他所写成的最成熟的想法，他正兴高采烈，而她的评判却使他目瞪口呆。 He was flaming from the fresh reading of the ripest thought he had expressed, and her verdict stunned him.
“不管它写得多么蹩脚，”他坚持道，“你看不出它里面有什么东西么？——我的意思是它的思想里？” “No matter how poorly it is done,” he persisted, “don’t you see anything in it?—in the thought of it, I mean?”
她摇头。 She shook her head.
“没有，它跟我读过的任何东西都非常不同。我读过梅特林克，我懂得他——” “No, it is so different from anything I have read.I read Maeterlinck and understand him—”
“他的神秘主义思想，你懂得？”马丁冲口而出。 “His mysticism, you understand that?” Martin flashed out.
“对，可是你的文章，看来是对他的一种攻击，我不懂。当然，如果独创性也算数——” “Yes, but this of yours, which is supposed to be an attack upon him, I don’t understand.Of course, if originality counts—”
他用了一个不耐烦的姿势打断了她，跟着却没有说话。他蓦地意识到她在说话，而且已经说了好一会儿了。 He stopped her with an impatient gesture that was not followed by speech.He became suddenly aware that she was speaking and that she had been speaking for some time.
“总之，写作是你的一件玩具，”她说着，“当然你已经跟它玩得够久了。该是时候认真地对待生活了——我们的生活，马丁。到目前为止，你完全是在过你自己的生活。” “After all, your writing has been a toy to you,” she was saying.“Surely you have played with it long enough.It is time to take up life seriously—our life, Martin.Hitherto you have lived solely your own.”
“你要我去工作么？”他问。 “You want me to go to work?” he asked.
“对。父亲已经提出来——” “Yes.Father has offered—”
“这一切我都懂，”他插嘴道，“可是我想知道的是你是否对我已经失去了信心？” “I understand all that,” he broke in; “but what I want to know is whether or not you have lost faith in me?”
她默默地捏着他的手，眼睛暗淡。 She pressed his hand mutely, her eyes dim.
“在你的写作上，亲爱的。”她半耳语地说道。 “In your writing, dear,” she admitted in a half-whisper.
“你读过我许多的作品，”他粗鲁地说了下去，“你觉得怎么样呢？是完全没有希望么？跟别人的作品比起来又怎么样呢？” “You’ve read lots of my stuff,” he went on brutally.“What do you think of it?Is it utterly hopeless?How does it compare with other men’s work?”
“可是，他们卖掉了他们的作品，而你——却不能。” “But they sell theirs, and you—don’t.”
“这并没有回答我的问题。你认为文学根本就不能成为我的职业么？” “That doesn’t answer my question.Do you think that literature is not at all my vocation?”
“那么，我就回答吧。”她使自己硬着心肠说出这话。“我认为你不适合写作。原谅我，亲爱的。是你逼着我说出这话来；你也知道我比你更懂得文学。” “Then I will answer.”She steeled herself to do it.“I don’t think you were made to write.Forgive me, dear.You compel me to say it; and you know I know more about literature than you do.”
“对，你是一位文学学士，”他沉思地说，“你应该懂得的。” “Yes, you are a Bachelor of Arts,” he said meditatively; “and you ought to know.”
“可是，我还有话要说呢，”两人痛苦地停了片刻之后，他接着说，“我明白我心里有什么。没有人比我更明白。我知道我会成功的。我不会给打倒的。我心中燃烧着一些我得通过诗歌、小说和论文表达出来的东西。然而，我并不要求你对它有信心。我不要求你对我有信心，或是对我的写作有信心。我所要求你的，是你爱我，对爱有信心。” “But there is more to be said,” he continued, after a pause painful to both.“I know what I have in me.No one knows that so well as I.I know I shall succeed.I will not be kept down.I am afire with what I have to say in verse, and fiction, and essay.I do not ask you to have faith in that, though.I do not ask you to have faith in me, nor in my writing.What I do ask of you is to love me and have faith in love.”
“一年前我请求过两年时间。还有一年未度过。而凭我的名誉和我的灵魂，我相信这一年过完之前我就会成功的。你记得你很久以前对我说的话吧，说我写作一定得有个学徒阶段。那么，我已经挨过来了。我已经塞满它，并且压缩了它。有你在那终点上等着我，我从没偷过懒。你可知道，我已经不记得安然入睡是怎么一回事了。饱饱地睡觉然后自然醒来，这滋味对我来说已经是几百万年前的事了。现在，我经常是给闹钟叫醒的。不管早睡还是晚睡，我都会上好闹钟；这件工作和熄灯是我最后的有意识的动作。” “A year ago I believed for two years.One of those years is yet to run.And I do believe, upon my honor and my soul, that before that year is run I shall have succeeded.You remember what you told me long ago, that I must serve my apprenticeship to writing.Well, I have served it.I have crammed it and telescoped it.With you at the end awaiting me, I have never shirked.Do you know, I have forgotten what it is to fall peacefully asleep.A few million years ago I knew what it was to sleep my fill and to awake naturally from very glut of sleep.I am awakened always now by an alarm clock.If I fall asleep early or late, I set the alarm accordingly; and this, and the putting out of the lamp, are my last conscious actions.”
“当我昏昏欲睡的时候，我把我正读着的厚重的书换成一本轻松点儿的。而当我对着它打瞌睡的时候，为了把睡意赶走，我用手敲我的头。在什么地方，我曾读到有一个人害怕睡觉。这个故事是基普林写的。这个人弄了一个铁刺，这样他一瞌睡，他的赤身裸体便会扎到铁刺上。那么，我也是这么做的。我看着时间，我决定不到午夜，或是不到一点钟，两点钟，三点钟，我不会把铁刺拿开。这样它一直扎醒我，直到预定的时间。几个月来那铁刺都陪着我一起睡。我拼了命，五个半钟头的睡眠也是奢侈的。现在我只睡四个钟头。我渴望睡眠。有时候我因睡眠不足而头昏脑乱，有时候死亡带着安息与沉睡，对我是个绝对的诱惑，有时候我沉迷于的朗费罗诗句： “When I begin to feel drowsy, I change the heavy book I am reading for a lighter one.And when I doze over that, I beat my head with my knuckles in order to drive sleep away.Somewhere I read of a man who was afraid to sleep.Kipling wrote the story.This man arranged a spur so that when unconsciousness came, his naked body pressed against the iron teeth.Well, I’ve done the same.I look at the time, and I resolve that not until midnight, or not until one o’clock, or two o’clock, or three o’clock, shall the spur be removed.And so it rowels me awake until the appointed time.That spur has been my bed-mate for months.I have grown so desperate that five and a half hours of sleep is an extravagance.I sleep four hours now.I am starved for sleep.There are times when I am light-headed from want of sleep, times when death, with its rest and sleep, is a positive lure to me, times when I am haunted by Longfellow’s lines:
“‘海是平静深沉的；它怀里的一切都在安睡；只一步便万事皆了，一跳，一个水泡，再无其他。’ “‘The sea is still and deep;All things within its bosom sleep;A single step and all is o’er,A plunge, a bubble, and no more.’
“当然，这完全是胡说。这是由于神经衰弱，由于一颗过劳的心。可是问题在于：我干吗要这么做？为了你。要缩短我的学徒阶段。强迫成功早一点到来。我的学徒期现在已满。我知道我的能力。我发誓，我一个月学到的东西比普通大学生一年学到的东西还要多。我知道的，我告诉你。要不是我迫切地需要你的理解，我是不会告诉你的。这不是自夸。我用书本来衡量结果。今天，你的兄弟们，比起我来，比起我在他们睡觉时从书本中得到的知识，简直是无知的野蛮人。很久以前我想出名。现在我可不关心什么名誉了。我要的只是你；我渴望你比渴望食物衣服或受赏识更强烈。我梦想着把我的头枕在你的胸口睡上几万年，这个梦在下一年过完之前就会成真了。” “Of course, this is sheer nonsense.It comes from nervousness, from an overwrought mind.But the point is: Why have I done this?For you.To shorten my apprenticeship.To compel Success to hasten.And my apprenticeship is now served.I know my equipment.I swear that I learn more each month than the average college man learns in a year.I know it, I tell you.But were my need for you to understand not so desperate I should not tell you.It is not boasting.I measure the results by the books.Your brothers, to-day, are ignorant barbarians compared with me and the knowledge I have wrung from the books in the hours they were sleeping.Long ago I wanted to be famous.I care very little for fame now.What I want is you; I am more hungry for you than for food, or clothing, or recognition.I have a dream of laying my head on your breast and sleeping an aeon or so, and the dream will come true ere another year is gone.”
他的力量撞击着她，一波接着一波；在他的意志与她的意志相左最严重的时候，她最强烈地觉得自己被他吸引。他那一向向她倾注的力量现在在他热情的声音里，在他发亮的眼睛里，在他身上汹涌的生命力和智慧里开花。在那一刻，也只有在那一刻，她觉察到她的信心上显现的一道裂缝——从这道裂缝，她看到了那个真正的马丁·伊登，出色，不可征服；而正如驯兽者也有迟疑的时刻一样，她在那一片刻间，也仿佛对于自己驯服这个野蛮的灵魂的能力产生怀疑了。 His power beat against her, wave upon wave; and in the moment his will opposed hers most she felt herself most strongly drawn toward him.The strength that had always poured out from him to her was now flowering in his impassioned voice, his flashing eyes, and the vigor of life and intellect surging in him.And in that moment, and for the moment, she was aware of a rift that showed in her certitude—a rift through which she caught sight of the real Martin Eden, splendid and invincible; and as animal-trainers have their moments of doubt, so she, for the instant, seemed to doubt her power to tame this wild spirit of a man.
“另外一件事，”他接着说，“你是爱我的。可是你为什么爱我呢？我身上驱使着我去写作的东西正是吸引着你的爱情的东西。你爱我，是因为我与你认识的人，并可能爱上的人有所不同。我不是生来坐办公桌和会计室的料，不是为琐碎的生意磨牙，上法庭争辩的料。要我做这些事，要我像那些人一样，做他们所做的工作，呼吸他们所呼吸的空气，发挥他们所发挥的观点，那你就毁灭了我和他们的不同，毁灭了我，毁灭了你爱的东西。我的写作欲望是我身上最重要的东西。如果我是一个呆傻之人，我就不会想着写作，你也不会想要我做你的丈夫了。” “And another thing,” he swept on.“You love me.But why do you love me?The thing in me that compels me to write is the very thing that draws your love.You love me because I am somehow different from the men you have known and might have loved.I was not made for the desk and counting-house, for petty business squabbling, and legal jangling.Make me do such things, make me like those other men, doing the work they do, breathing the air they breathe, developing the point of view they have developed, and you have destroyed the difference, destroyed me, destroyed the thing you love.My desire to write is the most vital thing in me.Had I been a mere clod, neither would I have desired to write, nor would you have desired me for a husband.”
“可是你忘了，”她打断他，她聪敏的心灵正瞥见了一个比方，“有些古怪的发明家，当他们追求永动机这样的幻想之物时，他们的家人正饿着肚子。无疑，他们的妻子是爱他们的，跟他们一起并为他们而受苦，并不是因为他们对于永动机的沉迷，而是不计较他们的沉迷。” “But you forget,” she interrupted, the quick surface of her mind glimpsing a parallel.“There have been eccentric inventors, starving their families while they sought such chimeras as perpetual motion.Doubtless their wives loved them, and suffered with them and for them, not because of but in spite of their infatuation for perpetual motion.”
“不错，”这是回答，“可是也有些发明家，他们并不古怪，他们追求一些实用的事物的时候也在挨饿；有时候，也有记载，他们成功了。当然我并没有追求着任何不可能的东西——” “True,” was the reply.“But there have been inventors who were not eccentric and who starved while they sought to invent practical things; and sometimes, it is recorded, they succeeded.Certainly I do not seek any impossibilities—”
“你说过这是‘做成不可能的事’。”她插嘴道。 “You have called it ‘achieving the impossible,’” she interpolated.
“我是打比方呢。我追求的是前人做过的事——去写作，靠我的写作生活。” “I spoke figuratively.I seek to do what men have done before me—to write and to live by my writing.”
她的沉默，刺激他说了下去。 Her silence spurred him on.
“那么，在你看来，我的目标像永动机一样是幻想之物么？”他问。 “To you, then, my goal is as much a chimera as perpetual motion?” he demanded.
她紧握着他的手，他从中读出了她的答案——那是怜爱的母亲握着受伤的孩子的手。在那一刻，在她看来，他正是那个受伤的孩子，是一个着了迷的人，极力追求着不可能的事情。 He read her answer in the pressure of her hand on his—the pitying mother-hand for the hurt child.And to her, just then, he was the hurt child, the infatuated man striving to achieve the impossible.
临他们的谈话快要结束时，她再度拿她父母的反对提醒他。 Toward the close of their talk she warned him again of the antagonism of her father and mother.
“可是你爱我么？”他问。 “But you love me?” he asked.
“我爱！我爱！”她叫道。 “I do!I do!” she cried.
“我爱的是你，不是他们，他们做什么都不能伤害我。”胜利在他的声音里响起。“因为我信任你的爱情，不怕他们的反对。这世上的一切事情都可能走错路，但爱情不会。爱情不会走错路，除非它是一个弱者，在旅途中畏缩不前、跌跌绊绊。” “And I love you, not them, and nothing they do can hurt me.”Triumph sounded in his voice.“For I have faith in your love, not fear of their enmity.All things may go astray in this world, but not love.Love cannot go wrong unless it be a weakling that faints and stumbles by the way.”
第三十一章 CHAPTER XXXI
马丁在百老汇大街偶然碰到姐姐格特鲁德——事实证明这是一个最幸运然而又令人窘迫不安的偶遇。她在街角等车，先看见了他，注意到了他脸上焦灼、饥饿的神色和他绝望、焦虑的眼神。事实上，他确实是既绝望又焦虑。他刚刚跟当铺老板进行了一次豪无结果的谈话，他原打算用自行车从老板那儿榨出一点额外的贷款。阴沉的秋天来到了，马丁之前已经当掉了自行车，却保留着他那套黑色的外衣。 Martin had encountered his sister Gertrude by chance on Broadway—as it proved, a most propitious yet disconcerting chance.Waiting on the corner for a car, she had seen him first, and noted the eager, hungry lines of his face and the desperate, worried look of his eyes.In truth, he was desperate and worried.He had just come from a fruitless interview with the pawnbroker, from whom he had tried to wring an additional loan on his wheel.The muddy fall weather having come on, Martin had pledged his wheel some time since and retained his black suit.
“还有那套黑色衣服，”了解马丁的每一件财产的当铺老板回答说，“你别告诉我你把它当给了那个犹太人利普卡。因为如果你已经——” “There’s the black suit,” the pawnbroker, who knew his every asset, had answered.“You needn’t tell me you’ve gone and pledged it with that Jew, Lipka.Because if you have—”
那人露出威胁的神气，马丁连忙叫道： The man had looked the threat, and Martin hastened to cry:—
“不，不；我还留着它呢。可我得在办正事时穿呢。” “No, no; I’ve got it.But I want to wear it on a matter of business.”
“好啦，”那位放债人平息了怒气说，“我要了它才能多给你一点儿钱，这也是为了办事。你不会以为我想要他是为了自己的健康吧？” “All right,” the mollified usurer had replied.“And I want it on a matter of business before I can let you have any more money.You don’t think I’m in it for my health?”
“可这自行车值四十块呢，保养得好好的，”马丁争辩着，“可你只给我七块钱当掉它。不，还不够七块钱。六块两毛五；你先把利息扣了。” “But it’s a forty-dollar wheel, in good condition,” Martin had argued.“And you’ve only let me have seven dollars on it.No, not even seven.Six and a quarter; you took the interest in advance.”
“你想多拿钱的话，就拿衣服来。”这回答使马丁离开了那间憋闷的小屋子。他的内心是如此绝望，都反映到了脸上，并触动了他姐姐的怜悯之心。 “If you want some more, bring the suit,” had been the reply that sent Martin out of the stuffy little den, so desperate at heart as to reflect it in his face and touch his sister to pity.
他们刚见面，电讯路的车就来了，停下来载了一群下午上街购物的人。希金博特姆太太从他扶她上车时手臂上的握法察觉出他不会跟她一道走了。她在踏板上回过头来俯视着他。他憔悴的面容又一次触动着她的心。 Scarcely had they met when the Telegraph Avenue car came along and stopped to take on a crowd of afternoon shoppers.Mrs. Higginbotham divined from the grip on her arm as he helped her on, that he was not going to follow her.She turned on the step and looked down upon him.His haggard face smote her to the heart again.
“你不一道来么？”她问。 “Ain’t you comin’?” she asked．
随即，她下了车站在他身旁。 The next moment she had descended to his side.
“我打算走路——运动，你知道。”他解释说。 “I’m walking—exercise, you know,” he explained.
“那我也一道走几段路吧，”她宣布，“这也许对我有好处。这些日子我一直觉得没什么精神。” “Then I’ll go along for a few blocks,” she announced.“Mebbe it’ll do me good.I ain’t ben feelin’ any too spry these last few days.”
马丁瞥了她一眼，证实了她的话，她全身衣着邋遢，身体虚胖，肩膀无力地下垂，疲惫的脸上挂着松弛的皱纹，步履沉重，没有弹力——完全是一幅对自由欢快的人的步伐的讽刺画。 Martin glanced at her and verified her statement in her general slovenly appearance, in the unhealthy fat, in the drooping shoulders, the tired face with the sagging lines, and in the heavy fall of her feet, without elasticity—a very caricature of the walk that belongs to a free and happy body.
“你还是停在这儿吧，”他说，尽管她在第一个街口就已经停了一下，“坐下一辆车吧。” “You’d better stop here,” he said, though she had already come to a halt at the first corner, “and take the next car.”
“我的天呐！——我怎么会这么累！”她喘着气，“要是我的鞋底也像你的鞋底，我也一样能走。你的鞋底太薄，恐怕还不到北奥克兰就会破的。” “My goodness!—if I ain’t all tired a’ready!” she panted.“But I’m just as able to walk as you in them soles.They’re that thin they’ll bu’st long before you git out to North Oakland.”
“我家里还有双好的。”他答道。 “I’ve a better pair at home,” was the answer.
“明天来吃晚饭吧，”她忽然邀请他，“希金博特姆先生到时不在家。他有事儿要去圣莱安德罗。” “Come out to dinner to-morrow,” she invited irrelevantly.“Mr. Higginbotham won’t be there.He’s goin’ to San Leandro on business.”
马丁摇头，但是一听到吃饭，他眼里忍不住露出了贪婪的饿相。 Martin shook his head, but he had failed to keep back the wolfish, hungry look that leapt into his eyes at the suggestion of dinner.
“你一个铜子儿也没有，马丁，所以你才走路的。还说做运动！”她想对他嗤之以鼻，但是最终只是吸了一口气。“来，让我想想。” “You haven’t a penny, Mart, and that’s why you’re walkin’.Exercise!”She tried to sniff contemptuously, but succeeded in producing only a sniffle.“Here, lemme see.”
她在小皮包里摸索着，拿出一个五元的金币塞进他手里。“我想我忘了你今年的生日了，马丁。”她含糊地说。 And, fumbling in her satchel, she pressed a five-dollar piece into his hand.“I guess I forgot your last birthday, Mart,” she mumbled lamely.
马丁的手本能地捏紧了那枚金币。同时他也知道不该接受，他发觉自己正在迟疑不决的痛苦中挣扎着。这一枚金币意味着食物、生活、身体和大脑的光明，继续写作的力量，还有——谁知道呢？——也许能写出什么东西赚回许多金币呢。他的幻觉里清楚地闪耀着刚刚完成的那两篇论文。他看见它们放在桌子底下那一堆退回的稿件上头，因为他没有邮票寄出它们，他还看见了题目，正如他把它们打出来时一样清楚——《神秘的大祭司》和《美的摇篮》。他从没把它们投出去。它们和他在这方面写过的其他文章一样好。只要有邮票就行了！于是，对最终成功的确信在他心头浮起，它是饥饿的有力盟友，他敏捷地将那枚金币溜进口袋。 Martin’s hand instinctively closed on the piece of gold.In the same instant he knew he ought not to accept, and found himself struggling in the throes of indecision.That bit of gold meant food, life, and light in his body and brain, power to go on writing, and—who was to say?—maybe to write something that would bring in many pieces of gold.Clear on his vision burned the manuscripts of two essays he had just completed.He saw them under the table on top of the heap of returned manuscripts for which he had no stamps, and he saw their titles, just as he had typed them— “The High Priests of Mystery,” and “The Cradle of Beauty.”He had never submitted them anywhere.They were as good as anything he had done in that line.If only he had stamps for them!Then the certitude of his ultimate success rose up in him, an able ally of hunger, and with a quick movement he slipped the coin into his pocket.
“我会还你的，格特鲁德，拿一百多倍还你。”他忍住呜咽，喉咙痛苦地收缩着，眼中马上闪出泪光。 “I’ll pay you back, Gertrude, a hundred times over,” he gulped out, his throat painfully contracted and in his eyes a swift hint of moisture.
“记住我的话！”他突然信心百倍地叫道，“在今年过完之前，我会拿一百个这样黄澄澄的小玩意儿放到你手里。我不要求你相信我。你只需等着瞧。” “Mark my words!” he cried with abrupt positiveness.“Before the year is out I’ll put an even hundred of those little yellow-boys into your hand.I don’t ask you to believe me.All you have to do is wait and see.”
她也没有相信。她的怀疑使她不安，她想不到有什么话可讲，便说： Nor did she believe.Her incredulity made her uncomfortable, and failing of other expedient, she said:—
“我知道你在挨饿，马丁。你身上已经全部表现出来了。随时来吃饭吧。希金博特姆先生不在时，我就打发个孩子去叫你。还有马丁——” “I know you’re hungry, Mart.It’s sticking out all over you.Come in to meals any time.I’ll send one of the children to tell you when Mr. Higginbotham ain’t to be there.An’ Mart—”
他等待着，尽管他内心里知道她要说什么，她的思想过程他是看得清清楚楚的。 He waited, though he knew in his secret heart what she was about to say, so visible was her thought process to him.
“你不觉得该是时候找个工作了么？” “Don’t you think it’s about time you got a job?”
“你不觉得我会成功么？”他问。 “You don’t think I’ll win out?” he asked.
她摇头。 She shook her head.
“没有谁相信我，格特鲁德，除了我自己。”他的声音激动，带着反抗的语气。“我已经写出了好的作品，而且有许多，早晚会卖出去的。” “Nobody has faith in me, Gertrude, except myself.”His voice was passionately rebellious.“I’ve done good work already, plenty of it, and sooner or later it will sell.”
“你怎么知道它好呢？” “How do you know it is good?”
“因为——”他支吾起来，因为整个广阔的文学和文学史田野在他脑中鼓动，指出他把自己有信心的原因告诉她是没用的。“因为它比杂志上刊登的百分之九十九的文章都要好。” “Because—” He faltered as the whole vast field of literature and the history of literature stirred in his brain and pointed the futility of his attempting to convey to her the reasons for his faith.“Well, because it’s better than ninety-nine per cent of what is published in the magazines.”
“我希望你听从理性的指引，”她无力地说道，却毫不动摇地相信自己对他那毛病的诊断是正确的。“我希望你听从理性的指引，”她重复道，“明天来吃晚饭。” “I wish’t you’d listen to reason,” she answered feebly, but with unwavering belief in the correctness of her diagnosis of what was ailing him.“I wish’t you’d listen to reason,” she repeated, “an’ come to dinner to-morrow.”
马丁扶她上了车以后，连忙赶到邮局，从五块钱中拿出三块买了邮票；晚些时候，在去莫尔斯家的路上，他进邮局把一大堆又长又大的信封称了重量，贴上了所有的邮票，除了三枚两分钱的。 After Martin had helped her on the car, he hurried to the post-office and invested three of the five dollars in stamps; and when, later in the day, on the way to the Morse home, he stopped in at the post-office to weigh a large number of long, bulky envelopes, he affixed to them all the stamps save three of the two-cent denomination.
后来证明这晚对马丁来说意义非凡，因为晚饭后他遇到了拉斯·布里森登。他是怎么凑巧到那儿的，他是谁的朋友，什么熟人带他去的，马丁都不知道。他也没有好奇心去向鲁思打听他的事情。一句话，马丁觉得布里森登是一个贫血的、傻头傻脑的人，并很快就把他忘掉了。一个钟头之后，他认定了布里森登还是一个乡巴佬，因为他从这间房徘徊到那间房，瞪着那些图画，或是把鼻子贴到从桌上捡起或从书架上抽出来的书籍杂志上。虽然在这个房子里他是位生客，他最后竟让自己脱离人群，缩在一张莫里斯式的大椅子里，专心地读着那本从自己口袋里拿出来的薄薄的书。他一边读书，一边出神地用手指轻轻挠着头发。那一晚马丁没有再注意他，除了有一次，他显然很成功地跟几位年轻女人打趣说笑着。 It proved a momentous night for Martin, for after dinner he met Russ Brissenden.How he chanced to come there, whose friend he was or what acquaintance brought him, Martin did not know.Nor had he the curiosity to inquire about him of Ruth.In short, Brissenden struck Martin as anaemic and feather-brained, and was promptly dismissed from his mind.An hour later he decided that Brissenden was a boor as well, what of the way he prowled about from one room to another, staring at the pictures or poking his nose into books and magazines he picked up from the table or drew from the shelves.Though a stranger in the house he finally isolated himself in the midst of the company, huddling into a capacious Morris chair and reading steadily from a thin volume he had drawn from his pocket.As he read, he abstractedly ran his fingers, with a caressing movement, through his hair.Martin noticed him no more that evening, except once when he observed him chaffing with great apparent success with several of the young women.
很凑巧，马丁离开的时候，在那条通道街上去的便道的半路上追上了布里森登。 It chanced that when Martin was leaving, he overtook Brissenden already half down the walk to the street.
“嗨，是你呀？”马丁说。 “Hello, is that you?” Martin said.
对方无礼地应了一声，却闪在一旁和他一起走。马丁没有再企图跟他搭话，走了几段路，没有人打破沉默。 The other replied with an ungracious grunt, but swung alongside.Martin made no further attempt at conversation, and for several blocks unbroken silence lay upon them.
“吹牛的老笨驴！” “Pompous old ass!”
这一声叫得突兀恶毒，叫马丁吃了一惊。他觉得有趣，同时也觉得更不喜欢那人了。 The suddenness and the virulence of the exclamation startled Martin.He felt amused, and at the same time was aware of a growing dislike for the other.
“你为什么到这样的地方？”又沉默地走了一段路之后，那人突然向他抛过来一句话。 “What do you go to such a place for?” was abruptly flung at him after another block of silence.
“你又是为什么呢？”马丁反问道。 “Why do you?” Martin countered.
“上帝保佑，我可不知道，”他回敬过来，“至少这是我第一次失策。每天有二十四个钟头，我总得把它们消磨掉吧。来喝一杯吧。” “Bless me, I don’t know,” came back.“At least this is my first indiscretion.There are twenty-four hours in each day, and I must spend them somehow.Come and have a drink.”
“好啊。”马丁答道。 “All right,” Martin answered.
下一刻，他便为自己轻率地答应他感到为难了。在家里还有几个钟头的卖文作品等着他在睡觉之前去写，上了床还有一卷韦斯曼等着他，更别说赫伯特·斯宾塞的自传了，那本自传充满着浪漫气氛，犹如一本动人的小说。自己为什么要浪费时间在这个不喜欢的人身上？他想。 The next moment he was nonplussed by the readiness of his acceptance.At home was several hours’ hack-work waiting for him before he went to bed, and after he went to bed there was a volume of Weismann waiting for him, to say nothing of Herbert Spencer’s Autobiography, which was as replete for him with romance as any thrilling novel.Why should he waste any time with this man he did not like? was his thought.
然而，叫他去的不是那人或酒，或与酒相关的一切——明亮的灯光，镜子与杯子炫目的光辉，人们发热涨红的脸孔和喧闹声。而是人们的声音，乐观的人们，显示着成功，花钱买醉。他是寂寞的，这就是他的状况；所以他就像鲣鱼咬住钩上的白布条一般，迅速接受了邀请。自从在谢利温泉馆和乔一起喝过之后，除了跟那个葡萄牙杂货商喝过之外，马丁没有再在酒吧喝过一次酒。精神疲惫并不像体力疲惫那样产生喝酒的渴望，他不需要酒。但现在他有喝酒的欲望，或者是渴望喝酒的氛围。这样的地方便是格罗特酒吧，布里森登和他斜倚在宽大的皮椅上喝着苏格兰威士忌和苏打。 And yet, it was not so much the man nor the drink as was it what was associated with the drink—the bright lights, the mirrors and dazzling array of glasses, the warm and glowing faces and the resonant hum of the voices of men.That was it, it was the voices of men, optimistic men, men who breathed success and spent their money for drinks like men.He was lonely, that was what was the matter with him; that was why he had snapped at the invitation as a bonita strikes at a white rag on a hook.Not since with Joe, at Shelly Hot Springs, with the one exception of the wine he took with the Portuguese grocer, had Martin had a drink at a public bar.Mental exhaustion did not produce a craving for liquor such as physical exhaustion did, and he had felt no need for it.But just now he felt desire for the drink, or, rather, for the atmosphere wherein drinks were dispensed and disposed of.Such a place was the Grotto, where Brissenden and he lounged in capacious leather chairs and drank Scotch and soda.
他们说着话。他们谈到了许多事情，时而布里森登，时而马丁，两人轮流叫着苏格兰威士忌和苏打。马丁酒量很大，却对对方的酒量感到惊奇，而对方的谈吐更是让他吃惊，不时地停下来倾听。很快他就意识到布里森登懂得一切事情，认定这是他遇到的第二个智者。但是他还发现布里森登有着考德威尔所教授缺少的东西——热情，闪光的洞察力与见解，天才的奔放不羁。生动的言辞从他口中奔涌而出。 They talked.They talked about many things, and now Brissenden and now Martin took turn in ordering Scotch and soda.Martin, who was extremely strong-headed, marvelled at the other’s capacity for liquor, and ever and anon broke off to marvel at the other’s conversation.He was not long in assuming that Brissenden knew everything, and in deciding that here was the second intellectual man he had met.But he noted that Brissenden had what Professor Caldwell lacked—namely, fire, the flashing insight and perception, the flaming uncontrol of genius.Living language flowed from him.
他薄薄的嘴唇，像机器的冲模，冲压出精炼犀利的语句；或温柔地噘了起来，抚弄着刚吐出的声音，那薄薄的嘴唇发出轻柔的、天鹅绒般的东西，散发着热情与光辉，有着令人难忘的美，反射着生命的神秘与不可思议的成熟语句；那薄薄的嘴唇又像一个号角，宇宙争吵的喧哗与骚乱响彻其间，像银子一般清澈，像星空一般璀璨的语句，概括了科学的定论还有其他——诗人的语言，卓越的真理，难以捉摸，无法言传，但也在普通语句的微妙而全然难于理解的涵义中得到体现。 His thin lips, like the dies of a machine, stamped out phrases that cut and stung; or again, pursing caressingly about the inchoate sound they articulated, the thin lips shaped soft and velvety things, mellow phrases of glow and glory, of haunting beauty, reverberant of the mystery and inscrutableness of life;and yet again the thin lips were like a bugle, from which rang the crash and tumult of cosmic strife, phrases that sounded clear as silver, that were luminous as starry spaces, that epitomized the final word of science and yet said something more—the poet’s word, the transcendental truth, elusive and without words which could express, and which none the less found expression in the subtle and all but ungraspable connotations of common words.
他，由于某种幻想的神奇，看到了经验论最遥远的岗哨之外，那里是没有语言可以叙述的，然而由于珍贵的语言奇迹，赋予已知的语句以未知的意义，他灌输给马丁的是一些普通的灵魂所不能领会的信息。 He, by some wonder of vision, saw beyond the farthest outpost of empiricism, where was no language for narration, and yet, by some golden miracle of speech, investing known words with unknown significances, he conveyed to Martin’s consciousness messages that were incommunicable to ordinary souls.
马丁忘记了先前对他的厌恶印象。在此书本所能给予的最好东西得以兑现。在此是他可以景仰的一位智者，一个凡人。“我在你脚下的污泥里。”马丁一次又一次地对自己说。 Martin forgot his first impression of dislike.Here was the best the books had to offer coming true.Here was an intelligence, a living man for him to look up to.“I am down in the dirt at your feet,” Martin repeated to himself again and again.
“你研究过生物学的。”他有所暗示地高声说道。 “You’ve studied biology,” he said aloud, in significant allusion.
令他惊奇的是布里森登摇了摇头。 To his surprise Brissenden shook his head.
“可是你所讲的是只有生物学才证实了的真理，”马丁坚持，换来的却是茫然的凝视。“你的结论跟你读过的书应该是一致的。” “But you are stating truths that are substantiated only by biology,” Martin insisted, and was rewarded by a blank stare.“Your conclusions are in line with the books which you must have read.”
“我很高兴听见你这么说，”他答道，“我对知识一知半解，这使我能缩短通向真理的路程，这是最叫人安心的。至于我自己，我从不费力去搞清我是对是错。不管怎样，这是完全没有价值的。人永远不能懂得最终的真理。” “I am glad to hear it,” was the answer.“That my smattering of knowledge should enable me to short-cut my way to truth is most reassuring.As for myself, I never bother to find out if I am right or not.It is all valueless anyway.Man can never know the ultimate verities.”
“你是斯宾塞的弟子！”马丁高兴地叫道。 “You are a disciple of Spencer!” Martin cried triumphantly.
“自成年以来，我就没有读过他的书，那时候我读过的也只是他的《教育论》而已。” “I haven’t read him since adolescence, and all I read then was his @Education@.”
“我恨不能像你一样随意吸取知识。”半小时后马丁叫道。他已经在仔细地分析着布里森登的精神素养。“你是一个纯粹的独断者，所以非常神奇。你独断地述说着一些最近的事实，那是科学通过一个经验的推理才建立起来的。你跳着得到正确的结论。你大大地缩短了通往真理的路。你用光的速度，靠着某种极度理性的过程摸索着到达真理的路。” “I wish I could gather knowledge as carelessly,” Martin broke out half an hour later.He had been closely analyzing Brissenden’s mental equipment.“You are a sheer dogmatist, and that’s what makes it so marvellous.You state dogmatically the latest facts which science has been able to establish only by a posteriori reasoning.You jump at correct conclusions.You certainly short-cut with a vengeance.You feel your way with the speed of light, by some hyperrational process, to truth.”
“是的，那是常常叫约瑟夫神父和达顿修士烦恼的，”布里森登答道。“哦，不，”他补充道，“我是一个无足轻重的人。是命运幸运的戏弄送我到一个天主教神学院接受教育。你知道的东西又是从何而来呢？” “Yes, that was what used to bother Father Joseph, and Brother Dutton,” Brissenden replied.“Oh, no,” he added; “I am not anything.It was a lucky trick of fate that sent me to a Catholic college for my education.Where did you pick up what you know?”
马丁一边回答布里森登，一边忙着观察他，从他瘦长而有贵族气派的脸和下垂的肩膀到搁在旁边椅子上的大衣，口袋里装着许多书，鼓鼓囊囊的。布里森登的脸和瘦长的双手被太阳晒成了棕色——颜色太深了，马丁想。这晒伤的皮肤叫马丁纳闷。很明显，布里森登不是一个在户外干活儿的人。那他是怎么被晒伤的呢？这晒黑的脸有着某种病态的，耐人寻味的东西，马丁再回头观察他的脸时这样想着。他的脸窄窄的，有着高高的颧骨和深陷的脸颊，并饰以一个马丁从未见过的精致漂亮的鹰钩鼻。眼睛的大小却没有什么特色。不大也不小，颜色是一种难以形容的棕色；但是其中隐藏着一种热情，更确切地说是潜伏着一种双重的，矛盾得出奇的表情。傲慢、顽强，甚至过于严厉，同时又引人怜悯。马丁发现自己不知为什么怜悯他，然而不久他就明白了。 And while Martin told him, he was busy studying Brissenden, ranging from a long, lean, aristocratic face and drooping shoulders to the overcoat on a neighboring chair, its pockets sagged and bulged by the freightage of many books.Brissenden’s face and long, slender hands were browned by the sun—excessively browned, Martin thought.This sunburn bothered Martin.It was patent that Brissenden was no outdoor man.Then how had he been ravaged by the sun?Something morbid and significant attached to that sunburn, was Martin’s thought as he returned to a study of the face, narrow, with high cheek-bones and cavernous hollows, and graced with as delicate and fine an aquiline nose as Martin had ever seen.There was nothing remarkable about the size of the eyes.They were neither large nor small, while their color was a nondescript brown; but in them smouldered a fire, or, rather, lurked an expression dual and strangely contradictory.Defiant, indomitable, even harsh to excess, they at the same time aroused pity.Martin found himself pitying him he knew not why, though he was soon to learn.
“哦，我有肺病，”布里森登说他从亚利桑那来的，之后又顺便宣布道，“我在那儿住了两年，靠那儿的气候过活。” “Oh, I’m a lunger,” Brissenden announced, offhand, a little later, having already stated that he came from Arizona.“I’ve been down there a couple of years living on the climate.”
“那你不怕在这种气候中过活是一个冒险吗？” “Aren’t you afraid to venture it up in this climate?”
“怕？” “Afraid?”
他重复马丁的话语时并没有特别地强调。但是马丁从这张克制的脸上看到的是无所畏惧。眼睛眯着像鹰眼一样，他那鹰鼻，鼻孔大张，傲慢、自信、盛气凌人。马丁一见，几乎屏住了呼吸。壮观，这是马丁内心做出的评价，一看到这，他的血液也沸腾了。他高声背诵着： There was no special emphasis of his repetition of Martin’s word.But Martin saw in that ascetic face the advertisement that there was nothing of which it was afraid.The eyes had narrowed till they were eagle-like, and Martin almost caught his breath as he noted the eagle beak with its dilated nostrils, defiant, assertive, aggressive.Magnificent, was what he commented to himself, his blood thrilling at the sight.Aloud, he quoted:—
“‘在命运的棍棒打击下，我虽鲜血淋漓，却绝不低头。’” “‘Under the bludgeoning of ChanceMy head is bloody but unbowed.’”
“你喜欢亨利。”布里森登说。他的表情很快就变得极其亲切温和了。“当然，我不能期望别的。啊，亨利！一个勇敢的人。他站在同时代的押韵诗人——杂志押韵诗人——中就像一位角斗士站在一群宦官中间。” “You like Henley,” Brissenden said, his expression changing swiftly to large graciousness and tenderness.“Of course, I couldn’t have expected anything else of you.Ah, Henley!A brave soul.He stands out among contemporary rhymesters—magazine rhymesters—as a gladiator stands out in the midst of a band of eunuchs.”
“你不喜欢那些杂志。”马丁轻轻责备道。 “You don’t like the magazines,” Martin softly impeached.
“你喜欢么？”如此野蛮的回答叫他吃惊。 “Do you?” was snarled back at him so savagely as to startle him.
“我——我写作，确切地说是试着写，写给那些杂志。”马丁支吾道。 “I—I write, or, rather, try to write, for the magazines,” Martin faltered.
“那还好，”口气略有缓和，“你试着写，可你没有成功。我尊重并钦佩你的失败。我知道你写得是什么。我用半只眼就看得出来，它里面有一种元素使它被那些杂志拒之门外。那就是内容，那些杂志拿到这特别的商品也没用。他们要的是空洞无聊的傻话，天知道，他们得到了，但不是从你那儿。” “That’s better,” was the mollified rejoinder.“You try to write, but you don’t succeed.I respect and admire your failure.I know what you write.I can see it with half an eye, and there’s one ingredient in it that shuts it out of the magazines.It’s guts, and magazines have no use for that particular commodity.What they want is wish-wash and slush, and God knows they get it, but not from you.”
“我写得也不过是应付差事的文章。”马丁申辩道。 “I’m not above hack-work,” Martin contended.
“相反——”布里森登停了一会儿，无礼地打量着马丁那实在的穷相，从破旧的领带和磨成锯齿状的衣领到泛光的袖子，再到微微磨破的袖口，终于停留在马丁深陷的脸颊上。“相反，应付差事的文章你写不出来，它高到你望尘莫及的地步。哎，老兄，我只要说请你吃饭，你肯定会生气。” “On the contrary—” Brissenden paused and ran an insolent eye over Martin’s objective poverty, passing from the well-worn tie and the saw-edged collar to the shiny sleeves of the coat and on to the slight fray of one cuff, winding up and dwelling upon Martin’s sunken cheeks.“On the contrary, hack-work is above you, so far above you that you can never hope to rise to it.Why, man, I could insult you by asking you to have something to eat.”
马丁的脸发烧了，血不由自主地往上涌，布里森登胜利地大笑。 Martin felt the heat in his face of the involuntary blood, and Brissenden laughed triumphantly.
“一个吃饱的人是不会一因为这样的邀请生气的。”他下了结论。 “A full man is not insulted by such an invitation,” he concluded.
“你是一个魔鬼。”马丁生气地嚷道。 “You are a devil,” Martin cried irritably.
“总之，我没有请过你。” “Anyway, I didn’t ask you.”
“你不敢。” “You didn’t dare.”
“哦，这我可不知道。我现在就请你。” “Oh, I don’t know about that.I invite you now.”
布里森登一边说话，一边半欠起身体，好像打算马上就去餐馆似的。 Brissenden half rose from his chair as he spoke, as if with the intention of departing to the restaurant forthwith.
马丁的拳头紧握，血液在太阳穴里咚咚地跳。 Martin’s fists were tight-clenched, and his blood was drumming in his temples.
“博斯科！他活吞了它们！他活吞了它们！”布里森登叫着，模仿着那个吹捧当地有名的吞蛇的牛皮匠的口吻。 “Bosco!He eats ’em alive!Eats ’em alive!”Brissenden exclaimed, imitating the spieler of a locally famous snake-eater.
“我可真的活吞了你。”马丁说，这回反过来是他用无礼的眼神打量着对方为病痛所折磨的身体。 “I could certainly eat you alive,” Martin said, in turn running insolent eyes over the other’s disease-ravaged frame.
“只是以因为我不配么？” “Only I’m not worthy of it?”
“相反，”马丁考虑着，“是因为这点小事不值得。”他爆发出一阵由衷而痛快的大笑。“我承认你捉弄了我，布里森登。我饿着，你也感觉到了，这只是平常现象，没什么丢脸的。你看，我嘲笑那些俗人的寻常小道德；你偶然过来，说了一句尖锐的真话，我马上成了那些小道德的俘虏。” “On the contrary,” Martin considered, “because the incident is not worthy.”He broke into a laugh, hearty and wholesome.“I confess you made a fool of me, Brissenden.That I am hungry and you are aware of it are only ordinary phenomena, and there’s no disgrace.You see, I laugh at the conventional little moralities of the herd; then you drift by, say a sharp, true word, and immediately I am the slave of the same little moralities.”
“你受了伤害。”布里森登断定。 “You were insulted,” Brissenden affirmed.
“片刻之前，的确是这样的。那是年轻时的偏见，你知道。那时候我学到了这些东西，它们使我后来学到的东西打了折扣。我以它们为耻。” “I certainly was, a moment ago.The prejudice of early youth, you know.I learned such things then, and they cheapen what I have since learned.They are the skeletons in my particular closet.”
“可是，你现在已经关上大门把它们禁闭起来了么？” “But you’ve got the door shut on them now?”
“当然啦。” “I certainly have.”
“你肯定？” “Sure?”
“肯定。” “Sure.”
“那么咱们去吃点东西吧。” “Then let’s go and get something to eat.”
“我答应。”马丁答道，争着拿他那两块钱的找头去付眼前的威士忌和苏打的账，但又眼看着那个被布里森登威吓住的侍者把那零钱放回桌上。 “I’ll go you,” Martin answered, attempting to pay for the current Scotch and soda with the last change from his two dollars and seeing the waiter bullied by Brissenden into putting that change back on the table.
马丁苦笑着把钱放回口袋里，有那么一会儿感觉到布里森登的手放在他肩上的亲切重量。 Martin pocketed it with a grimace, and felt for a moment the kindly weight of Brissenden’s hand upon his shoulder.
第三十二章 CHAPTER XXXII
很快，第二天下午，玛丽亚为马丁的第二位客人而感到激动。但这次她可没有张皇失措，因为她把布里森登安排到招待贵宾的体面客厅里，让他坐了下来。 Promptly, the next afternoon, Maria was excited by Martin’s second visitor.But she did not lose her head this time, for she seated Brissenden in her parlor’s grandeur of respectability.
“但愿你不介意我的来访吧？”布里森登开口说。 “Hope you don’t mind my coming?” Brissenden began.
“不，不，不介意。”马丁回答着，同他握手，并挥手请他坐在那里唯一的一把椅子上，而他自己坐在床上。“可你是怎么知道我住在哪儿的？” “No, no, not at all,” Martin answered, shaking hands and waving him to the solitary chair, himself taking to the bed.“But how did you know where I lived?”
“我打电话到莫尔斯家。莫尔斯小姐接的电话。然后我就到这儿了。”他从外衣口袋里拽出一本薄薄的书，掷到了桌子上。“有一本书，是一位诗人写的。你留着读吧。”接着他又回应马丁的反对：“我要书有什么用呢？今早我又吐了一次血。有威士忌么？不，当然没有。等一下。” “Called up the Morses.Miss Morse answered the ’phone.And here I am.”He tugged at his coat pocket and flung a thin volume on the table.“There’s a book, by a poet.Read it and keep it.”And then, in reply to Martin’s protest: “What have I to do with books?I had another hemorrhage this morning.Got any whiskey?No, of course not.Wait a minute.”
他走了出去。马丁注视着他瘦长的身影走下外面的台阶，在他回过身来关上大门的时候，悲痛地发现他那原本宽阔的肩膀现在缩在塌陷的胸膛上方。马丁找出两个无脚杯，便去读那本诗集，是亨利·沃恩·马洛晚期的诗集。 He was off and away.Martin watched his long figure go down the outside steps, and, on turning to close the gate, noted with a pang the shoulders, which had once been broad, drawn in now over, the collapsed ruin of the chest.Martin got two tumblers, and fell to reading the book of verse, Henry Vaughn Marlow’s latest collection.
“没有苏格兰威士忌啦，”布里森登回来时说，“那叫花子除了美国威士忌什么也不卖。不过这儿有一夸脱。” “No Scotch,” Brissenden announced on his return.“The beggar sells nothing but American whiskey.But here’s a quart of it.”
“我叫一个小家伙去买点柠檬来，咱们弄点甜酒喝好啦。”马丁提议道。 “I’ll send one of the youngsters for lemons, and we’ll make a toddy,” Martin offered.
“我很想知道，这样一本书能给马洛赚多少钱？”他拿起那本书接着说。 “I wonder what a book like that will earn Marlow?” he went on, holding up the volume in question.
“大概五十块钱吧，”来了这么一个答复，“不过如果他能收支平衡，或者能骗到一个出版商冒险去出版它，那他就算幸运啦。” “Possibly fifty dollars,” came the answer.“Though he’s lucky if he pulls even on it, or if he can inveigle a publisher to risk bringing it out.”
“那么一个人不能靠写诗过日子了？” “Then one can’t make a living out of poetry?”
马丁的口气和脸色都显得很沮丧。 Martin’s tone and face alike showed his dejection.
“当然不能。哪个傻瓜会期望这个呢？写点押韵的东西是可以的。有布鲁斯，弗吉尼亚·斯普林和塞奇威克。他们都写得很好。然而写诗——你知道沃恩·马洛怎么过日子的？——在宾夕法尼亚一家男校教书，在所有私立的小地狱中这地方是最糟的。就算他还有五十年的寿命，我也不愿和他换位置。然而他的作品放在那一大批同时代押韵诗人的作品中，就像一颗红宝石钻在胡萝卜里。看他得到的评论啊！全部他妈的滚蛋，那些愚蠢的小侏儒！” “Certainly not.What fool expects to?Out of rhyming, yes.There’s Bruce, and Virginia Spring, and Sedgwick.They do very nicely.But poetry—do you know how Vaughn Marlow makes his living?—teaching in a boys’ cramming-joint down in Pennsylvania, and of all private little hells such a billet is the limit.I wouldn’t trade places with him if he had fifty years of life before him.And yet his work stands out from the ruck of the contemporary versifiers as a balas ruby among carrots.And the reviews he gets!Damn them, all of them, the crass manikins!”
“不会写作的人评论会写作的人，实在是评论得太多了，”马丁表示赞同，“哎，那些写史蒂文森和其作品的许多垃圾让我震惊。” “Too much is written by the men who can’t write about the men who do write,” Martin concurred.“Why, I was appalled at the quantities of rubbish written about Stevenson and his work.”
“那些舔尸鬼和怪物！”布里森登咬牙切齿地怒骂。“是的，我知道那些鬼东西——因为他给达米安神父的信就得意洋洋地找他的错，分析他，掂量他——” “Ghouls and harpies!”Brissenden snapped out with clicking teeth.“Yes, I know the spawn—complacently pecking at him for his Father Damien letter, analyzing him, weighing him—”
“用他们那可悲的自我的码尺衡量他。”马丁插嘴道。 “Measuring him by the yardstick of their own miserable egos,” Martin broke in.
“对了，正是这个，好一句话——把真美善大吹大擂一番，最后拍拍他的背说：‘好狗，斐多。’呸！‘那一贯嘁嘁喳喳的小人物’，理查德·里尔夫临死那一晚就是这样称呼他们的。” “Yes, that’s it, a good phrase,—mouthing and besliming the True, and Beautiful, and Good, and finally patting him on the back and saying, ‘Good dog, Fido.’ Faugh!‘The little chattering daws of men,’ Richard Realf called them the night he died.”
“专跟星尘吹毛求疵，”马丁热衷地接起话头，“在那些巨匠流星般划过长空的时候。我曾经写过一篇讽刺他们的文章——那些批评家，或者更确切地叫评论家。” “Pecking at star-dust,” Martin took up the strain warmly; “at the meteoric flight of the master-men.I once wrote a squib on them—the critics, or the reviewers, rather.”
“我来看看。”布里森登迫切地恳求着。 “Let’s see it,” Brissenden begged eagerly.
于是马丁翻出一份复写的《星尘》，布里森登阅读时轻轻笑着，擦着手，都忘了喝他的甜酒。 So Martin unearthed a carbon copy of “Star-dust,” and during the reading of it Brissenden chuckled, rubbed his hands, and forgot to sip his toddy.
“这让我觉得你自己就是那星尘中的一份子，投进了一个盲目的戴着兜帽的小侏儒的世界里，”他看完以后评论道，“不用说第一家杂志就抓住不放了吧？” “Strikes me you’re a bit of star-dust yourself, flung into a world of cowled gnomes who cannot see,” was his comment at the end of it.“Of course it was snapped up by the first magazine?”
马丁翻着他那本稿件登记册。“它已经被二十七家杂志拒绝了。” Martin ran over the pages of his manuscript book.“It has been refused by twenty-seven of them.”
布里森登由衷地大笑不止，但被一阵咳嗽打断了。 Brissenden essayed a long and hearty laugh, but broke down in a fit of coughing.
“喂，你也不用瞒我，说你没写过诗，”他喘着气，“给我看几篇吧。” “Say, you needn’t tell me you haven’t tackled poetry,” he gasped.“Let me see some of it.”
“现在别看了吧，”马丁恳求，“我想和你说说话。我把它们扎成一捆，你可以带回家去。” “Don’t read it now,” Martin pleaded.“I want to talk with you.I’ll make up a bundle and you can take it home.”
布里森登带着《爱情连环曲》和《仙女与珍珠》走了，第二天又来了，跟马丁打招呼道： Brissenden departed with the “Love-cycle,” and “The Peri and the Pearl,” returning next day to greet Martin with:—
“我还要多看几篇。” “I want more.”
不只他断定马丁是个诗人，马丁也了解到布里森登也是个诗人。对方的作品使马丁大受震动。他并没打算拿出去发表，马丁大吃一惊。 Not only did he assure Martin that he was a poet, but Martin learned that Brissenden also was one.He was swept off his feet by the other’s work, and astounded that no attempt had been made to publish it.
“让那些出版社死去吧！”马丁自告奋勇为他投稿，他却这样回答。“为美本身而爱美吧，”这是他的忠告，“别管那些杂志社了。回到你的船上、你的海上去——这是我给你的忠告，马丁·伊登。在这些令人恶心而腐败的人们的城市里你想要什么呢？你浪费时光，为了满足杂志界的需求而竭力使美去当婊子，这等于你在割断自己的喉咙。那天你给我引用的那句话是怎么说的？——哦，对，‘人，最后的蜉蝣。’那么你，最后的蜉蝣要名声做什么呢？要是你得到了，那就是你的毒药。你太单纯，太本色，太理性，依我看你不能靠这些达到成功。我希望你从没卖过一行诗给那些杂志。美是唯一值得去服侍的主人。服侍她，让那些俗人滚蛋吧！成功！如果成功不在你为史蒂文森写的那首赛过亨利的《幻影》的十四行诗里，不在《爱情连环曲》里，不在那些歌咏海洋的诗里，成功究竟有什么用场？ “A plague on all their houses!” was Brissenden’s answer to Martin’s volunteering to market his work for him.“Love Beauty for its own sake,” was his counsel, “and leave the magazines alone.Back to your ships and your sea—that’s my advice to you, Martin Eden.What do you want in these sick and rotten cities of men?You are cutting your throat every day you waste in them trying to prostitute beauty to the needs of magazinedom.What was it you quoted me the other day?—Oh, yes, ‘Man, the latest of the ephemera.’Well, what do you, the latest of the ephemera, want with fame?If you got it, it would be poison to you.You are too simple, too elemental, and too rational, by my faith, to prosper on such pap.I hope you never do sell a line to the magazines.Beauty is the only master to serve.Serve her and damn the multitude!Success!What in hell’s success if it isn’t right there in your Stevenson sonnet, which outranks Henley’s ‘Apparition,’ in that ‘Love-cycle,’ in those sea-poems?
“你得到快乐并不因为你成功了，而是因为你做了。你不会告诉我的。我懂这个。你也懂。美伤害了你。这在你是一个永远的痛，一个不会愈合的伤口，一把燃烧着的刀。你干吗还要跟那些杂志讨价还价呢？让美成为你的目标吧。为什么要把美铸成金币呢？无论如何，你是做不到的；所以我为此激动也没用。你可以读一千年的杂志，但你发现的价值却比不上济慈的一行诗。把名誉和金钱丢开，明天就签个合同上船去，回到你的海上去吧。” “It is not in what you succeed in doing that you get your joy, but in the doing of it.You can’t tell me.I know it.You know it.Beauty hurts you.It is an everlasting pain in you, a wound that does not heal, a knife of flame.Why should you palter with magazines?Let beauty be your end.Why should you mint beauty into gold?Anyway, you can’t; so there’s no use in my getting excited over it.You can read the magazines for a thousand years and you won’t find the value of one line of Keats.Leave fame and coin alone, sign away on a ship to-morrow, and go back to your sea.”
“为的不是名誉，而是爱情，”马丁笑了，“爱情在你的天地中似乎并无地位；在我的天地里，美不过是爱情的随身女仆。” “Not for fame, but for love,” Martin laughed.“Love seems to have no place in your Cosmos; in mine, Beauty is the handmaiden of Love.”
布里森登可怜而又羡慕地瞧着他。“你是这么年轻，马丁，孩子啊，你是这么年轻。你想高高地飞翔，可是你的两翼是用最精细的轻纱做成的，是涂上了最漂亮的颜色的。别烧焦它们呀。然而不用说，你已经把它们烧焦了。应该有一个仪态万方的小姐来解释那《爱情连环曲》，这就是它的耻辱。” Brissenden looked at him pityingly and admiringly.“You are so young, Martin boy, so young.You will flutter high, but your wings are of the finest gauze, dusted with the fairest pigments.Do not scorch them.But of course you have scorched them already.It required some glorified petticoat to account for that ‘Love-cycle,’ and that’s the shame of it.”
“它赞颂女性之外也赞颂爱情。”马丁笑了。 “It glorifies love as well as the petticoat,” Martin laughed.
“疯狂的哲学，”对方反驳，“当我在麻醉的迷梦中漫游时，我也这样向自己保证。可是当心啊。这些资产阶级的城市会害死你的。瞧瞧我遇见你的那个叛逆者的洞穴吧。腐朽远不能成为它的名字。在那样的氛围中，一个人绝不能保持神志清醒。这是堕落。没有人不堕落，男人、女人，他们全部有活跃的胃口，由蚌的高等智慧和艺术冲动所引导——” “The philosophy of madness,” was the retort.“So have I assured myself when wandering in hasheesh dreams.But be aware.These bourgeois cities will kill you.Look at that den of traitors where I met you.Dry rot is no name for it.One can’t keep his sanity in such an atmosphere.It’s degrading.There’s not one of them who is not degrading, man and woman, all of them animated stomachs guided by the high intellectual and artistic impulses of clams—”
他突然中断，注视着马丁。然后，似乎有所预料，他搞清楚了状况。他脸上的表情转变成了惊疑的恐怖。 He broke off suddenly and regarded Martin.Then, with a flash of divination, he saw the situation.The expression on his face turned to wondering horror.
“你还写了那惊人的《爱情连环曲》给她——那个苍白憔悴的女人！” “And you wrote that tremendous ‘Love-cycle’ to her—that pale, shrivelled, female thing!”
下一刻，马丁的右手已经紧扼住他的喉咙，他被摇着，直到牙齿咯咯作响。但是马丁看着他的眼睛，却没有看到丝毫惧色——什么也没有，除了一个古怪而愚弄的恶魔。马丁回过神来，便揪着布里森登的脖颈把他扔到床上，这才放开了手。 The next instant Martin’s right hand had shot to a throttling clutch on his throat, and he was being shaken till his teeth rattled.But Martin, looking into his eyes, saw no fear there,—naught but a curious and mocking devil.Martin remembered himself, and flung Brissenden, by the neck, sidelong upon the bed, at the same moment releasing his hold.
布里森登痛苦地喘息了一会儿，接着开始暗自发笑了。 Brissenden panted and gasped painfully for a moment, then began to chuckle.
“你要是把我摇断气了，你就永远欠我的了。”他说。 “You had made me eternally your debtor had you shaken out the flame,” he said.
“这几天我的脾气正处于一触即发的状态，”马丁道歉，“但愿没伤着你。来，我再弄点甜酒吧。” “My nerves are on a hair-trigger these days,” Martin apologized.“Hope I didn’t hurt you.Here, let me mix a fresh toddy.”
“啊，你这小伙子！”布里森登接着说，“我想知道你是否以你的身体为傲呢。你似魔鬼一样强壮。你是一匹小豹子，一匹小狮子。对，对，你一定会为这体力得到报应的。” “Ah, you young Greek!” Brissenden went on.“I wonder if you take just pride in that body of yours.You are devilish strong.You are a young panther, a lion cub.Well, well, it is you who must pay for that strength.”
“你这是什么意思？”马丁好奇地问，递给他一杯甜酒，“给，喝完这杯会好的。” “What do you mean?” Martin asked curiously, passing aim a glass.“Here, down this and be good.”
“因为——”布里森登啜着他的甜酒，很受用地笑了。“因为女人。她们会一直烦扰你，直到烦死你，就像她们已经烦扰过你一样，不然的话我就是昨天才出娘胎的小娃娃。现在你掐着我的脖子也没用；我还是要说。这一回肯定是你的初恋；可是看在美的份上，下一次品位还得高点。你要一个资产阶级的女儿到底有啥好？别理她们。找一个嘲笑生活，嘲弄死亡，想爱就爱得像火一样热情的了不起的女人。这样的女人有的是，她们会轻易地爱上你，和任何资产阶级温室生活的懦弱产物一样。” “Because—” Brissenden sipped his toddy and smiled appreciation of it.“Because of the women.They will worry you until you die, as they have already worried you, or else I was born yesterday.Now there’s no use in your choking me; I’m going to have my say.This is undoubtedly your calf love; but for Beauty’s sake show better taste next time.What under heaven do you want with a daughter of the bourgeoisie?Leave them alone.Pick out some great, wanton flame of a woman, who laughs at life and jeers at death and loves one while she may.There are such women, and they will love you just as readily as any pusillanimous product of bourgeois sheltered life.”
“懦弱？”马丁抗议道。 “Pusillanimous?” Martin protested.
“正是，懦弱；闲谈那些靠闲谈听来的小道德，而且害怕生活。她们会爱你，马丁，可是她们会更爱她们的小道德。你需要的是生活的壮丽和无拘无束，是伟大自由的灵魂，是绚烂的蝴蝶，而不是灰色的小灯蛾。哦，你也会厌倦她们的，所有的女人，若是你不幸竟活下去的话。然而你不会活下去。你不会回到你的船上和大海上；因此，你将在城市的这些瘟疫区闲荡，直至你的骨头腐烂，于是你也就死掉了。” “Just so, pusillanimous; prattling out little moralities that have been prattled into them, and afraid to live life.They will love you, Martin, but they will love their little moralities more.What you want is the magnificent abandon of life, the great free souls, the blazing butterflies and not the little gray moths.Oh, you will grow tired of them, too, of all the female things, if you are unlucky enough to live.But you won’t live.You won’t go back to your ships and sea; therefore, you’ll hang around these pest-holes of cities until your bones are rotten, and then you’ll die.”
“你可以教训我，可是你不能叫我反驳，”马丁说，“总之，你的性情有你的智慧，我的性情的智慧和你的一样无懈可击。” “You can lecture me, but you can’t make me talk back,” Martin said.“After all, you have but the wisdom of your temperament, and the wisdom of my temperament is just as unimpeachable as yours.”
关于爱情和杂志，还有许多事情，他们看法都不一致，可是他们彼此有好感，在马丁看来，这是一种深深的敬爱。日复一日，他们都在一起，哪怕布里森登只是在马丁那不通气的房间里呆一个小时。布里森登每次来都不忘带一夸脱威士忌，而他们在市里吃饭的时候，他就会在吃饭时喝苏格兰威士忌和苏打水。他总是付两个人的账，由于他马丁才晓得食物的精美，第一次喝到了香槟，而且见识了莱茵酒。 They disagreed about love, and the magazines, and many things, but they liked each other, and on Martin’s part it was no less than a profound liking.Day after day they were together, if for no more than the hour Brissenden spent in Martin’s stuffy room.Brissenden never arrived without his quart of whiskey, and when they dined together down-town, he drank Scotch and soda throughout the meal.He invariably paid the way for both, and it was through him that Martin learned the refinements of food, drank his first champagne, and made acquaintance with Rhenish wines.
然而，布里森登总是一个谜。他有着一张苦行者的脸，气血衰弱，却是一个毫不掩饰的耽于享乐的人。他不怕死，对一切生活方式感到痛苦和愤世嫉俗，然而他快要死了，但他还是热爱生活直到最后。他被一种要活、要刺激的狂热占据着，如他自己曾说过的：“在我所来自的宇宙的尘埃中，在我的小小空间里爬行。”他曾经尝试过毒品，做过许多古怪的事情，都是为了寻求新的刺激和新的感觉。就像他告诉马丁的一样，他曾经不喝水过了三天，完全出于自愿，就是为了去体验这么一种口渴解除时的奇妙的快感。他是怎样一个人，马丁永远不知道。他是一个没有过去的人，他的未来是近在眼前的坟墓，而他的现在是生活痛苦的狂热。 But Brissenden was always an enigma.With the face of an ascetic, he was, in all the failing blood of him, a frank voluptuary.He was unafraid to die, bitter and cynical of all the ways of living; and yet, dying, he loved life, to the last atom of it.He was possessed by a madness to live, to thrill, “to squirm my little space in the cosmic dust whence I came,” as he phrased it once himself.He had tampered with drugs and done many strange things in quest of new thrills, new sensations.As he told Martin, he had once gone three days without water, had done so voluntarily, in order to experience the exquisite delight of such a thirst assuaged.Who or what he was, Martin never learned.He was a man without a past, whose future was the imminent grave and whose present was a bitter fever of living.
第三十三章 CHAPTER XXXIII
马丁肯定是打了败仗。虽然他会节省，可是卖文作品的所得却不能让收支平衡。感恩节的时候，他的黑色套装还在当铺，所以没有接受莫尔斯家的邀请去赴宴。鲁思为他不能到的理由不高兴，结果他决定铤而走险。他告诉她，无论如何他都会去的；他会去旧金山的《洲际月刊》杂志社办公室索取该给他的那五块钱，有了这些钱他可以把那套衣服赎回来。 Martin was steadily losing his battle.Economize as he would, the earnings from hack-work did not balance expenses.Thanksgiving found him with his black suit in pawn and unable to accept the Morses’ invitation to dinner.Ruth was not made happy by his reason for not coming, and the corresponding effect on him was one of desperation.He told her that he would come, after all; that he would go over to San Francisco, to the @Transcontinental@ office, collect the five dollars due him, and with it redeem his suit of clothes.
早上他跟玛丽亚借了一角钱。他原想跟布里森登借的，但是那个漂泊不定的家伙早就没影了。自从上次马丁见过他之后，已经两个星期过去了，他绞尽脑汁也想不出自己怎么得罪了他。那一角钱让他渡到了旧金山，当他在市场街走着的时候，他考虑到要是拿不到钱自己该面对怎样的窘境。那样的话他就没办法回奥克兰去了，在旧金山他认不得一个可以借一角钱的人。 In the morning he borrowed ten cents from Maria.He would have borrowed it, by preference, from Brissenden, but that erratic individual had disappeared.Two weeks had passed since Martin had seen him, and he vainly cudgelled his brains for some cause of offence.The ten cents carried Martin across the ferry to San Francisco, and as he walked up Market Street he speculated upon his predicament in case he failed to collect the money.There would then be no way for him to return to Oakland, and he knew no one in San Francisco from whom to borrow another ten cents.
《洲际月刊》杂志社的门半开着，马丁正要推开门的时候，突然停下来，因为屋里有人大声叫道：“可那不是问题，福特先生。”（福特，马丁从通信中知道这是编辑的名字。）“问题是你准备付钱吗？——现金，付现金，我的意思是。对于《洲际月刊》的前途和明年你想把它办成什么样，我不感兴趣。我想要的是我做了工作就得收钱。现在，我还得告诉你，除非钱到手，否则圣诞节的《洲际月刊》就别想印出来了。祝你好运。拿了钱再来找我。” The door to the @Transcontinental@ office was ajar, and Martin, in the act of opening it, was brought to a sudden pause by a loud voice from within, which exclaimed:—“But that is not the question, Mr. Ford.”(Ford, Martin knew, from his correspondence, to be the editor’s name.) “The question is, are you prepared to pay?—cash, and cash down, I mean?I am not interested in the prospects of the @Transcontinental@ and what you expect to make it next year.What I want is to be paid for what I do.And I tell you, right now, the Christmas @Transcontinental@ don’t go to press till I have the money in my hand.Good day.When you get the money, come and see me.”
门猛地打开了，那人满脸怒容，从马丁身边闪过，喃喃咒骂着，紧攥着拳头沿走廊走下去了。马丁决定不马上进去，在过道里徘徊了一刻钟。然后他才推开门走进去。这是一次新的体验，这是他第一次在一个编辑室里面。那家杂志社显然不需要名片，因为那听差的向里屋传话，说有人要见福特先生。那听差的回来，走到屋子中间就叫他，把他带进那间私人办公室——编辑的办公室。马丁的第一印象便是那房间里乱七八糟，一片混乱。接着，他注意到一个留着连鬓胡子，容貌年轻的男人坐在一张顶盖可卷缩的办公桌前，正好奇地打量着他。马丁惊讶于他脸上沉静安详的表情。很明显，和印刷商的争吵并没有扰乱他的平静。 The door jerked open, and the man flung past Martin, with an angry countenance and went down the corridor, muttering curses and clenching his fists.Martin decided not to enter immediately, and lingered in the hallways for a quarter of an hour.Then he shoved the door open and walked in.It was a new experience, the first time he had been inside an editorial office.Cards evidently were not necessary in that office, for the boy carried word to an inner room that there was a man who wanted to see Mr. Ford.Returning, the boy beckoned him from halfway across the room and led him to the private office, the editorial sanctum.Martin’s first impression was of the disorder and cluttered confusion of the room.Next he noticed a bewhiskered, youthful-looking man, sitting at a roll-top desk, who regarded him curiously.Martin marvelled at the calm repose of his face.It was evident that the squabble with the printer had not affected his equanimity.
“我——我是马丁·伊登。”马丁开始了谈话。（“我要拿我那五块钱。”他原想说的其实是这句。） “I—I am Martin Eden,” Martin began the conversation.(“And I want my five dollars,” was what he would have liked to say.)
可是这是与他打交道的第一位编辑，而且在当时的局面之下，他不想太突然地吓到他。叫他吃惊的是，福特先生口里说着“你说得是真的！”便跳了起来。下一刻，他便热情地双手握着马丁的手。 But this was his first editor, and under the circumstances he did not desire to scare him too abruptly.To his surprise, Mr. Ford leaped into the air with a “You don’t say so!” and the next moment, with both hands, was shaking Martin’s hand effusively.
“我真说不出见到您有多高兴，伊登先生。我经常在想你是什么样子的人。” “Can’t say how glad I am to see you, Mr. Eden.Often wondered what you were like.”
说着他伸直手臂拉开马丁，笑吟吟地打量着马丁那一身次好的衣服，也是他最差的衣服，那衣服破旧得无法修补了，尽管他用玛丽亚的熨斗把裤子细心地熨出了折痕。 Here he held Martin off at arm’s length and ran his beaming eyes over Martin’s second-best suit, which was also his worst suit, and which was ragged and past repair, though the trousers showed the careful crease he had put in with Maria’s flat-irons.
