“不过我承认，我原以为您是一个年纪大得多的人呢。您的故事，您知道，表现出如此的广度和活力，思想如此成熟深刻。一部杰作，那篇小说——我拜读了开头的五六行就知道了。让我告诉您我第一次是怎么读它的吧。但是，先别忙；首先我还是介绍您认识我的同事。” “I confess, though, I conceived you to be a much older man than you are.Your story, you know, showed such breadth, and vigor, such maturity and depth of thought.A masterpiece, that story—I knew it when I had read the first half-dozen lines.Let me tell you how I first read it.But no; first let me introduce you to the staff.”
福特先生一边说着话，一边带他到大办公室去，在那里把他介绍给副编辑怀特先生，一个瘦瘦的羸弱的小个子，他的手似乎异常冷，好像在受着风寒似的，胡子稀疏又细软。 Still talking, Mr. Ford led him into the general office, where he introduced him to the associate editor, Mr. White, a slender, frail little man whose hand seemed strangely cold, as if he were suffering from a chill, and whose whiskers were sparse and silky.
“还有恩兹先生，伊登先生。恩兹先生是我们的业务经理，您知道。” “And Mr. Ends, Mr. Eden.Mr. Ends is our business manager, you know.”
马丁发现自己和一个目光不稳的秃头握着手，那人的脸能够看得见的那一点还挺年轻，而大部分脸孔给雪白的胡子盖住了，胡子修剪得很仔细——是他太太在星期天给修的，同时也给他修理后颈。 Martin found himself shaking hands with a cranky-eyed, bald-headed man, whose face looked youthful enough from what little could be seen of it, for most of it was covered by a snow-white beard, carefully trimmed—by his wife, who did it on Sundays, at which times she also shaved the back of his neck.
三个人围着马丁，一齐说着钦佩的话，直至使人觉得他们好像在打赌，赌谁说得最长久。 The three men surrounded Martin, all talking admiringly and at once, until it seemed to him that they were talking against time for a wager.
“我们经常在想您为什么不光临我们这里。”怀特先生说。 “We often wondered why you didn’t call,” Mr. White was saying.
“我没有车钱，我住在海湾的另一头。”马丁爽快地回答，想向他们表示自己急需钱。 “I didn’t have the carfare, and I live across the Bay,” Martin answered bluntly, with the idea of showing them his imperative need for the money.
不用说，他心想，我那身好看的破衣服本身就能明显地宣传我的需要。一次又一次，一有机会，他便暗示来访的目的。可是他的崇拜者们的耳朵聋了。他们唱着对他的颂歌，告诉他他们第一眼看见他的小说时的想法，接下来的想法，以及他们的太太和家人的想法；但是半点儿也没吐露出打算付稿费的意思。 Surely, he thought to himself, my glad rags in themselves are eloquent advertisement of my need.Time and again, whenever opportunity offered, he hinted about the purpose of his business.But his admirers’ ears were deaf.They sang his praises, told him what they had thought of his story at first sight, what they subsequently thought, what their wives and families thought; but not one hint did they breathe of intention to pay him for it.
“我告诉过您我第一次如何拜读您的大作了吗？”福特先生说。“当然我还没告诉您。那时我正从纽约西来，火车在奥格登停下的时候，下一班的乘务员带来了当时刚出版的《洲际月刊》。” “Did I tell you how I first read your story?” Mr. Ford said.“Of course I didn’t.I was coming west from New York, and when the train stopped at Ogden, the train-boy on the new run brought aboard the current number of the @Transcontinental@.”
我的天！马丁想；你可以坐着普式火车旅行，而我却因为你欠我的那可怜的五块钱饿着肚子。一阵怒火汹涌而来。《洲际月刊》杂志社对他的不公急剧扩大，因为几个月来徒然渴望和贫饿交加的感觉很强烈，而此刻他的饥饿醒了，啃咬着他，使他想起昨天到现在他还没有吃过一点东西，而当时吃得也不够多。此时他发火了。这些家伙甚至不仅是强盗。他们是些偷偷摸摸的窃贼。他们利用谎言和失言骗取了他的小说。哼，他会给他们颜色看看。他做了一个巨大的决定，不拿到钱他不会离开。他记得，要是拿不到钱他就没办法回到奥克兰去了。他努力控制着自己，先不叫他脸上可怕的表情威吓惊动他们。 My God!Martin thought; you can travel in a Pullman while I starve for the paltry five dollars you owe me.A wave of anger rushed over him.The wrong done him by the @Transcontinental@ loomed colossal, for strong upon him were all the dreary months of vain yearning, of hunger and privation, and his present hunger awoke and gnawed at him, reminding him that he had eaten nothing since the day before, and little enough then.For the moment he saw red.These creatures were not even robbers.They were sneak-thieves.By lies and broken promises they had tricked him out of his story.Well, he would show them.And a great resolve surged into his will to the effect that he would not leave the office until he got his money.He remembered, if he did not get it, that there was no way for him to go back to Oakland.He controlled himself with an effort, but not before the wolfish expression of his face had awed and perturbed them.
他们越来越口若悬河了。福特先生重新跟他谈起他第一次读《钟声》的状况，同时恩兹先生也争着复述他侄女对《钟声》的赞赏，说他侄女是阿拉梅达的一个教员。 They became more voluble than ever.Mr. Ford started anew to tell how he had first read “The Ring of Bells,” and Mr. Ends at the same time was striving to repeat his niece’s appreciation of “The Ring of Bells,” said niece being a school-teacher in Alameda.
“我告诉你们我为啥事来的吧，”马丁终于说了，“我就是来拿你们都那么赞赏的那篇小说的稿费。五块钱，我想，这就是你们答应发表时会付给我的报酬。” “I’ll tell you what I came for,” Martin said finally.“To be paid for that story all of you like so well.Five dollars, I believe, is what you promised me would be paid on publication.”
福特先生，在他善变的面孔上做了一个爽快而乐意的默认表情，开始伸手进他的口袋里，接着突然转向恩兹先生，说他把他的钱落在家里了。恩兹先生很不高兴，这是显然的；马丁看到他的手臂突然动了一下，好像要护住他裤袋里的钱。马丁知道了钱就在那里。 Mr. Ford, with an expression on his mobile features of mediate and happy acquiescence, started to reach for his pocket, then turned suddenly to Mr. Ends, and said that he had left his money home.That Mr. Ends resented this, was patent; and Martin saw the twitch of his arm as if to protect his trousers pocket.Martin knew that the money was there.
“很抱歉，”恩兹先生说，“可是我付了钱给印刷商还不到一个钟头，他拿走了我手头所有的零钱。弄到这么拮据，原是我的不小心；账单还没到期，印刷商求我马上预支给他，这是完全出乎意料的。” “I am sorry,” said Mr. Ends, “but I paid the printer not an hour ago, and he took my ready change.It was careless of me to be so short; but the bill was not yet due, and the printer’s request, as a favor, to make an immediate advance, was quite unexpected.”
两人都有所期待地看着怀特先生，但那位先生却笑笑耸耸肩膀。无论如何他的良心是清白的。他来《洲际月刊》是想学编辑杂志，但最后主要学的是财务。《洲际月刊》欠他四个月的薪水，他知道先得安抚印刷商才轮得到副编辑。 Both men looked expectantly at Mr. White, but that gentleman laughed and shrugged his shoulders.His conscience was clean at any rate.He had come into the @Transcontinental@ to learn magazine-literature, instead of which he had principally learned finance.The @Transcontinental@ owed him four months’ salary, and he knew that the printer must be appeased before the associate editor.
“太荒唐了，伊登先生，竟碰到我们这个样子，”福特先生轻轻地开了个头，“完全是大意，我向你保证。但我要告诉您我们会怎么做。明早我们第一件事就是给您寄一张支票。你有伊登先生的地址，是吧，恩兹先生？” “It’s rather absurd, Mr. Eden, to have caught us in this shape,” Mr. Ford preambled airily.“All carelessness, I assure you.But I’ll tell you what we’ll do.We’ll mail you a check the first thing in the morning.You have Mr. Eden’s address, haven’t you, Mr. Ends?”
是的，恩兹先生是有地址，明天早上第一件事就是寄支票。马丁关于银行和支票的知识模模糊糊，但他也看不出什么理由，为啥今天不给他支票，偏要等到明天。 Yes, Mr. Ends had the address, and the check would be mailed the first thing in the morning.Martin’s knowledge of banks and checks was hazy, but he could see no reason why they should not give him the check on this day just as well as on the next.
“那么这就说清楚了，伊登先生，明天我们会给您寄支票。”福特先生说。 “Then it is understood, Mr. Eden, that we’ll mail you the check to-morrow?” Mr. Ford said.
“我今天就需要钱。”马丁冷淡地说。 “I need the money to-day,” Martin answered stolidly.
“真是不幸——要是您改天来……”福特先生温文尔雅地说，却给恩兹先生打断了。他那不稳定的眼神就证明了他急躁的脾气。 “The unfortunate circumstances—if you had chanced here any other day,” Mr. Ford began suavely, only to be interrupted by Mr. Ends, whose cranky eyes justified themselves in his shortness of temper.
“福特先生已经把我们的情形解释过了，”他粗鲁地说，“我也解释过了。支票会寄出——” “Mr. Ford has already explained the situation,” he said with asperity.“And so have I.The check will be mailed—”
“我也解释过了，”马丁打断了他，“我已经解释过，我今天就要钱。” “I also have explained,” Martin broke in, “and I have explained that I want the money to-day.”
那位经理的鲁莽使他的脉搏跳动加快，他警惕地瞧着他，因为他已猜到《洲际月刊》的现款就在那位绅士的裤袋里。 He had felt his pulse quicken a trifle at the business manager’s brusqueness, and upon him he kept an alert eye, for it was in that gentleman’s trousers pocket that he divined the @Transcontinental@’s ready cash was reposing.
“太糟糕了——”福特先生开始说。 “It is too bad—” Mr. Ford began.
但在这个时候，恩兹先生做了一个不耐烦的动作，转过身像要离开的样子。就在同一瞬间，马丁向他扑了过去，用一只手掐着他的喉咙，竟使恩兹先生那依然整洁的白胡须呈四十五度角对着天花板。叫怀特先生和福特先生害怕的是，他们眼看着他们的经理像一块阿斯特拉罕地毯一样摇摆。 But at that moment, with an impatient movement, Mr. Ends turned as if about to leave the room.At the same instant Martin sprang for him, clutching him by the throat with one hand in such fashion that Mr. Ends’ snow-white beard, still maintaining its immaculate trimness, pointed ceilingward at an angle of forty-five degrees.To the horror of Mr. White and Mr. Ford, they saw their business manager shaken like an Astrakhan rug.
“掏出来，你这阻挠青年人才的老混蛋！”马丁告诫着，“掏出来，不然我就从你身上摇出来，就算全是硬币也行啊。”接着，他对那两个受了惊的旁观者说：“滚开！你们要是插手，就有人遭殃啦。” “Dig up, you venerable discourager of rising young talent!” Martin exhorted.“Dig up, or I’ll shake it out of you, even if it’s all in nickels.”Then, to the two affrighted onlookers: “Keep away!If you interfere, somebody’s liable to get hurt.”
恩兹先生被掐得喘不过气来，一直到他喉咙上的手松了一点，他才表示同意掏钱。掏了又掏，他的裤袋共弄出四块一角五分钱。 Mr. Ends was choking, and it was not until the grip on his throat was eased that he was able to signify his acquiescence in the digging-up programme.All together, after repeated digs, its trousers pocket yielded four dollars and fifteen cents.
“把口袋翻出来。”马丁命令道。 “Inside out with it,” Martin commanded.
又掉出一角钱。为求确保，马丁把他强索得来的收获又数了一遍。 An additional ten cents fell out.Martin counted the result of his raid a second time to make sure.
“轮到你啦！”他向福特先生喊道，“我还要七角五分钱。” “You next!” he shouted at Mr. Ford.“I want seventy-five cents more.”
福特先生不敢迟疑地搜遍他的口袋，结果只掏出六角钱。 Mr. Ford did not wait, but ransacked his pockets, with the result of sixty cents.
“真的都掏出来了？”马丁把钱接了过来用威胁的口吻问道，“背心口袋里是什么？” “Sure that is all?” Martin demanded menacingly, possessing himself of it.“What have you got in your vest pockets?”
为表自己的好信用，福特先生把两个口袋都翻了出来。一块硬纸片从其中一个口袋里掉到地上。他拾起了它，正要把它放回去的时候马丁叫道： In token of his good faith, Mr. Ford turned two of his pockets inside out.A strip of cardboard fell to the floor from one of them.He recovered it and was in the act of returning it, when Martin cried:—
“那是什么？——一张渡船票？来，把它给我。值一角钱。这也算抵账啦。现在我一共收到四元九角五分钱，连船票在内。还欠我五分钱呢。” “What’s that?—A ferry ticket?Here, give it to me.It’s worth ten cents.I’ll credit you with it.I’ve now got four dollars and ninety-five cents, including the ticket.Five cents is still due me.”
他狠狠地瞧着怀特先生，发觉这个脆弱的家伙正拿着一个五分的钱币给他。 He looked fiercely at Mr. White, and found that fragile creature in the act of handing him a nickel.
“谢了，”马丁说着，跟他们一起打了个招呼，“再见。” “Thank you,” Martin said, addressing them collectively.“I wish you a good day.”
“强盗！”恩兹先生对着他的背影大骂道。 “Robber!” Mr. Ends snarled after him.
“鬼鬼祟祟的小偷！”马丁回敬道，出去时砰地关上了门。 “Sneak-thief!” Martin retorted, slamming the door as he passed out.
马丁得意洋洋——他是如此得意，当他想起《大黄蜂》还欠他《仙女与珍珠》的十五块钱稿费时，他决定马上去拿回来。可是办《大黄蜂》的却是一帮胡子刮得干干净净，健壮魁梧的年轻人，他们是肆无忌惮的强盗，他们不管什么东西什么人都抢，连他们彼此之间也不例外。打坏了一些办公室的家具之后，那位编辑（以前是学校里的体育健将）在经理——一位广告代理人——和门房的有效协助下终于把马丁弄出了办公室，而且由于先前的推搡，他被迅速地推落到第一个台阶。 Martin was elated—so elated that when he recollected that @The Hornet@ owed him fifteen dollars for “The Peri and the Pearl,” he decided forthwith to go and collect it.But @The Hornet@ was run by a set of clean-shaven, strapping young men, frank buccaneers who robbed everything and everybody, not excepting one another.After some breakage of the office furniture, the editor (an ex-college athlete), ably assisted by the business manager, an advertising agent, and the porter, succeeded in removing Martin from the office and in accelerating, by initial impulse, his descent of the first flight of stairs.
“再来啊，伊登先生；什么时候都欢迎你来。”他们在上面的楼梯上取笑他。 “Come again, Mr. Eden; glad to see you any time,” they laughed down at him from the landing above.
马丁爬起来的时候咧嘴笑了。 Martin grinned as he picked himself up.
“唷！” 他喃喃地回答，“《洲际月刊》那伙人全是些母羊，你们这帮家伙却是斗拳专家。” “Phew!” he murmured back.“The @Transcontinental@ crowd were nanny-goats, but you fellows are a lot of prize-fighters.”
回敬他的又是一阵大笑。 More laughter greeted this.
“我得说，伊登先生，”《大黄蜂》的编辑向下喊道，“作为一个诗人，你倒是算有所作为。你那铁臂金刚的本事是从哪儿学来的——请问？” “I must say, Mr. Eden,” the editor of @The Hornet@ called down, “that for a poet you can go some yourself.Where did you learn that right cross—if I may ask?”
“就是从你学纳尔逊擒拿法那儿学到的，”马丁回答，“总之你会被弄得鼻青眼肿的。” “Where you learned that half-Nelson,” Martin answered.“Anyway, you’re going to have a black eye.”
“但愿你的脖子没有僵硬吧，”那编辑殷勤地问道，“我们出去喝一杯怎么样——不为脖子，只为刚才屋里的一点小争吵？” “I hope your neck doesn’t stiffen up,” the editor wished solicitously: “What do you say we all go out and have a drink on it—not the neck, of course, but the little rough-house?”
“我要是输了，我请客。”马丁同意了。 “I’ll go you if I lose,” Martin accepted.
劫掠者和被劫掠的在一起喝酒了，和和气气地达成一致，即强者必胜，《仙女与珍珠》的十五块钱稿费因此属于《大黄蜂》编辑部。 And robbers and robbed drank together, amicably agreeing that the battle was to the strong, and that the fifteen dollars for “@The Peri and the Pearl@” belonged by right to @The Hornet@’s editorial staff.
第三十四章 CHAPTER XXXIV
鲁思走上玛丽亚家门前的台阶时，阿瑟留在了门口。她听到了打字机快速的咔哒声，马丁招呼她进去的时候，她发现他正在打着稿子的最后一页。她来是想确定一下感恩节宴会他是否会来；但是她还没谈到本题，马丁便投入了他满脑子都在想的话题上了。 Arthur remained at the gate while Ruth climbed Maria’s front steps.She heard the rapid click of the type-writer, and when Martin let her in, found him on the last page of a manuscript.She had come to make certain whether or not he would be at their table for Thanksgiving dinner; but before she could broach the subject Martin plunged into the one with which he was full.
“来，让我给你念念这个。”他叫道，一面把复写好的稿件一页一页整理好。“这是我最新的作品，跟我以前写过的任何一篇都不同。它是这么完全不同，我都有点儿害怕了，不过我自己还是觉得不错的。你来当评判者吧。这是一篇夏威夷的故事。我把它命名为《维基-维基》。” “Here, let me read you this,” he cried, separating the carbon copies and running the pages of manuscript into shape.“It’s my latest, and different from anything I’ve done.It is so altogether different that I am almost afraid of it, and yet I’ve a sneaking idea it is good.You be judge.It’s an Hawaiian story.I’ve called it ‘Wiki-wiki.’”
他的脸上闪着创作的光彩，但她在这间冰冷的屋子里冻得发抖，和他打招呼时也感到他的双手冰冷。他读的时候，她仔细地听着，尽管他不时从她脸上看到的只是不赞同的表情，但是临末他还是问： His face was bright with the creative glow, though she shivered in the cold room and had been struck by the coldness of his hands at greeting.She listened closely while he read, and though he from time to time had seen only disapprobation in her face, at the close he asked:—
“说老实话，你觉得怎么样？” “Frankly, what do you think of it?”
“我——我不知道，”她答道，“它会——你以为它会卖得掉吗？” “I—I don’t know,” she answered.“Will it—do you think it will sell?”
“我看怕是卖不掉，”他承认，“它太强烈了，不合那些杂志的胃口。然而，它是真实的，我保证它是真实的。” “I’m afraid not,” was the confession.“It’s too strong for the magazines.But it’s true, on my word it’s true.”
“既然你知道它们卖不掉，干吗要写这样的东西呢？”她无情地继续说，“你写作的原因是为了谋生，不是么？” “But why do you persist in writing such things when you know they won’t sell?” she went on inexorably.“The reason for your writing is to make a living, isn’t it?”
“对，不错；可是那悲惨的故事使我陶醉。我禁不住要写。它迫使我把它写出来。” “Yes, that’s right; but the miserable story got away with me.I couldn’t help writing it.It demanded to be written.”
“可是那个人物，维基-维基，你干吗要叫他那么粗野地讲话？这肯定会使读者不舒服，这当然也就是编辑们能正当地拒绝你的作品的理由。” “But that character, that Wiki-Wiki, why do you make him talk so roughly?Surely it will offend your readers, and surely that is why the editors are justified in refusing your work.”
“因为真实的维基-维基就是这么讲话的。” “Because the real Wiki-Wiki would have talked that way.”
“可是这不是好的品位。” “But it is not good taste.”
“这是生活，”他直言不讳，“它是实在的。它是真实的。我一定要写我见到的生活。” “It is life,” he replied bluntly.“It is real.It is true.And I must write life as I see it.”
她没有回答，在难堪的沉默中，他们坐了好一会儿。正是因为他爱她，所以不十分理解她，她不能理解他是因为他太宏大，大到超乎她的视野之外。 She made no answer, and for an awkward moment they sat silent.It was because he loved her that he did not quite understand her, and she could not understand him because he was so large that he bulked beyond her horizon.
“哦，我已经从《洲际月刊》那儿收到稿费了。”他说道，极力要把谈话转到一个较为舒服的话题上面。他上次见到那三个胡子的画面，抢到四元九角钱和一张渡船票的情景叫他窃笑。 “Well, I’ve collected from the @Transcontinental@,” he said in an effort to shift the conversation to a more comfortable subject.The picture of the bewhiskered trio, as he had last seen them, mulcted of four dollars and ninety cents and a ferry ticket, made him chuckle.
“那么你是会来的！”她高兴地叫道，“这正是我要来问清楚的。” “Then you’ll come!” she cried joyously.“That was what I came to find out.”
“来？”他心不在焉，喃喃地说道，“哪里？” “Come?” he muttered absently.“Where?”
“嗨，明天来赴宴呀。你知道，你说过要是拿到钱的话，就会把衣服赎出来。” “Why, to dinner to-morrow.You know you said you’d recover your suit if you got that money.”
“我都给忘了，”他低声下气地说，“你看，今天早上那个牲畜巡察拉走了玛丽亚的两头母牛和一头牛犊，而——嗯，刚好玛丽亚一个钱也没有，所以我就得替她赎回她的母牛。《洲际月刊》那五块钱就花在这儿了——《钟声》跑进了牲畜巡察的口袋里。” “I forgot all about it,” he said humbly.“You see, this morning the poundman got Maria’s two cows and the baby calf, and—well, it happened that Maria didn’t have any money, and so I had to recover her cows for her.That’s where the @Transcontinental@ fiver went—‘@The Ring of Bells@’ went into the poundman’s pocket.”
“那么你是不会来了？” “Then you won’t come?”
他低头瞧着他的衣服。 He looked down at his clothing.
“我不能去。” “I can’t.”
失望和怨恨的泪水在她蓝色的眼睛里闪着，但是她什么也没说。 Tears of disappointment and reproach glistened in her blue eyes, but she said nothing.
“明年感恩节我会和你在德梦尼可吃饭，”他愉快地说，“或者在伦敦，或者在巴黎，或者在你所希望的任何一个地方。我知道的。” “Next Thanksgiving you’ll have dinner with me in Delmonico’s,” he said cheerily; “or in London, or Paris, or anywhere you wish.I know it.”
“几天前我在报纸上看到，”她突然宣布道，“铁路邮运部已经下发了几个当地的任命。你考了第一名，不是么？” “I saw in the paper a few days ago,” she announced abruptly, “that there had been several local appointments to the Railway Mail.You passed first, didn’t you?”
他不得不承认给他的派令已经到了，但是他已经放弃了。“我当时对自己有把握——现在也一样，”他末了说，“从现在起一年之后我赚的钱会超过铁路邮运部的十二个职员赚的。你等着瞧吧。” He was compelled to admit that the call had come for him, but that he had declined it.“I was so sure—I am so sure—of myself,” he concluded.“A year from now I’ll be earning more than a dozen men in the Railway Mail.You wait and see.”
“哦。”等他说完的时候，她只说了这么一声。她站起身，戴上手套。“我得走了，马丁。阿瑟等着我呢。” “Oh,” was all she said, when he finished.She stood up, pulling at her gloves.“I must go, Martin.Arthur is waiting for me.”
他把她拥入怀里吻她，但她显然是一个冷淡的情人。她的身体没有绷紧，她的双臂没有抱住他，她的双唇也没有惯常的那种力量。 He took her in his arms and kissed her, but she proved a passive sweetheart.There was no tenseness in her body, her arms did not go around him, and her lips met his without their wonted pressure.
她生气了，当他从大门口回来时得出这样的结论。但这是为什么呢？牲畜巡察拉走了玛丽亚的牛，这真是不幸。但这只是命运的无常。不该责备任何人。他也想不到除了已经做的那样，还有什么别的做法。哦，是的，他是有点儿该受责备的，这是他接下来的想法，因为他拒绝了铁路邮运部的任命。而她也不喜欢《维基-维基》。 She was angry with him, he concluded, as he returned from the gate.But why?It was unfortunate that the poundman had gobbled Maria’s cows.But it was only a stroke of fate.Nobody could be blamed for it.Nor did it enter his head that he could have done aught otherwise than what he had done.Well, yes, he was to blame a little, was his next thought, for having refused the call to the Railway Mail.And she had not liked “Wiki-Wiki.”
他在台阶最高处回过身来，去迎接下午那班信件的邮差。当他接到那一捆长信封的时候，那种一再复发的期望的狂热又袭击着马丁。其中一个信封不长。又短又薄，外面印着《纽约展望》的地址。他拆信的时候停住了。这不会是接受稿子的通知书的。他没有给那家杂志投过稿。也许——想到——一个放肆的想法他的心脏几乎停止了跳动——也许他们是要向他约稿；可是下一秒他就放弃了这个推测，那是绝对不可能的。 He turned at the head of the steps to meet the letter-carrier on his afternoon round.The ever recurrent fever of expectancy assailed Martin as he took the bundle of long envelopes.One was not long.It was short and thin, and outside was printed the address of @The New York Outview@.He paused in the act of tearing the envelope open.It could not be an acceptance.He had no manuscripts with that publication.Perhaps—his heart almost stood still at the—wild thought—perhaps they were ordering an article from him; but the next instant he dismissed the surmise as hopelessly impossible.
这是一封简短而正式的信，由杂志社的编辑签了名的，只是通知他他们收到一封匿名信，随信附上，并告诉他尽可以放心，在任何情况下《展望》编辑部都不会考虑匿名信件的。 It was a short, formal letter, signed by the office editor, merely informing him that an anonymous letter which they had received was enclosed, and that he could rest assured the @Outview@’s staff never under any circumstances gave consideration to anonymous correspondence.
马丁发现那封附上的信是粗糙的手工印刷。信是对马丁文理不通的辱骂，并断言说向各杂志社投稿的“所谓的马丁先生”根本不是什么作家，实际上，他是从旧杂志上抄袭小说，并把他们打印出来，宣称为自己的东西投寄出去。信封盖着圣莱安德罗的邮戳。马丁用不着多想就发现作者是谁了。希金博特姆的文法，希金博特姆的俗语，希金博特姆的心理花样和过程是自始至终都是显而易见的。马丁在每一行中看到的不是漂亮的意大利书写体，而是他姐夫那粗糙的杂货商的字迹。 The enclosed letter Martin found to be crudely printed by hand.It was a hotchpotch of illiterate abuse of Martin, and of assertion that the “so-called Martin Eden” who was selling stories to magazines was no writer at all, and that in reality he was stealing stories from old magazines, typing them, and sending them out as his own.The envelope was postmarked “San Leandro.”Martin did not require a second thought to discover the author.Higginbotham’s grammar, Higginbotham’s colloquialisms, Higginbotham’s mental quirks and processes, were apparent throughout.Martin saw in every line, not the fine Italian hand, but the coarse grocer’s fist, of his brother-in-law.
可是为什么呢？他徒然问道。他做过什么对不起伯纳德·希金博特姆的事情吗？这事儿这么不合理，这么地荒唐。简直无从解释。在这个星期中，一打同样的信由东部不同杂志社的编辑转寄给马丁。编辑们做得很漂亮，马丁做出这样的结论。他们完全不认识他，然而他们中间有几位甚至对他表示同情。很明显，他们痛恨匿名信。他看出要伤害他的恶毒企图失败了。事实上，如果有什么作用的话，那一定是好的，因为至少他的名字已经引起了一部分编辑的注意。也许什么时候他们读到他的一篇稿子，会想起他就是他们曾经收到的匿名信所攻击的那个人。谁能说，这样一回想不会使他们判断的天平倾向他那边呢？ But why?he vainly questioned.What injury had he done Bernard Higginbotham?The thing was so unreasonable, so wanton.There was no explaining it.In the course of the week a dozen similar letters were forwarded to Martin by the editors of various Eastern magazines.The editors were behaving handsomely, Martin concluded.He was wholly unknown to them, yet some of them had even been sympathetic.It was evident that they detested anonymity.He saw that the malicious attempt to hurt him had failed.In fact, if anything came of it, it was bound to be good, for at least his name had been called to the attention of a number of editors.Sometime, perhaps, reading a submitted manuscript of his, they might remember him as the fellow about whom they had received an anonymous letter.And who was to say that such a remembrance might not sway the balance of their judgment just a trifle in his favor?
大概在这个时候，马丁在玛丽亚心中的形象大大降低了。一天早上，他发现玛丽亚在厨房里因痛苦而呻吟着，软弱的泪水沿着她的面颊流了下来，徒然地努力熨着一大批衣服。他马上诊断她得了流感，便给她喝了热威士忌（那是布里森登带来的几瓶喝剩下的），然后吩咐她上床休息。但玛丽亚不听。那些衣服一定得熨完，她抗议道，而且晚上就得送去，否则明天那七个饥饿的小席尔瓦就没饭可吃了。 It was about this time that Martin took a great slump in Maria’s estimation.He found her in the kitchen one morning groaning with pain, tears of weakness running down her cheeks, vainly endeavoring to put through a large ironing.He promptly diagnosed her affliction as La Grippe, dosed her with hot whiskey (the remnants in the bottles for which Brissenden was responsible), and ordered her to bed.But Maria was refractory.The ironing had to be done, she protested, and delivered that night, or else there would be no food on the morrow for the seven small and hungry Silvas.
让她惊讶的是（这是她直到临死那天还不断谈起的事情），她看到马丁·伊登从炉上拿起一个熨斗，又把一件花边的胸褡扔到熨衣板上。这是凯特·弗拉纳根最漂亮的盛装胸衣，除了她，在玛丽亚的世界里再没有比她的穿着更严格更讲究的女人了。而且，弗拉纳根小姐特别交代过那件胸衣一定要在当晚送过去。大家都知道，她和铁匠约翰·柯林斯先生要好，玛丽亚也暗地里知道，弗拉纳根小姐和柯林斯先生第二天要到金门公园去。玛丽亚要抢救那件衣服却力不从心。马丁扶着她蹒跚着走到一把椅子跟前坐下，她用一双鼓起的眼睛看着他。她眼看着只用了她所需时间的四分之一，那件胸衣就给稳妥地烫好了，而且她不得不承认他烫得跟她一样好。 To her astonishment (and it was something that she never ceased from relating to her dying day), she saw Martin Eden seize an iron from the stove and throw a fancy shirt-waist on the ironing-board.It was Kate Flanagan’s best Sunday waist, than whom there was no more exacting and fastidiously dressed woman in Maria’s world.Also, Miss Flanagan had sent special instruction that said waist must be delivered by that night.As every one knew, she was keeping company with John Collins, the blacksmith, and, as Maria knew privily, Miss Flanagan and Mr. Collins were going next day to Golden Gate Park.Vain was Maria’s attempt to rescue the garment.Martin guided her tottering footsteps to a chair, from where she watched him with bulging eyes.In a quarter of the time it would have taken her she saw the shirt-waist safely ironed, and ironed as well as she could have done it, as Martin made her grant.
“我还能烫得更快，”他解释道，“要是你的熨斗再热一点儿的话。” “I could work faster,” he explained, “if your irons were only hotter.”
对于她来说，他挥舞的那个熨斗已经比她敢用的热得多了。 To her, the irons he swung were much hotter than she ever dared to use.
“你喷水喷得完全不对，”他跟着埋怨道，“来，我来教你怎么喷水吧。要的是压力。你要熨得快的话就得有压力。” “Your sprinkling is all wrong,” he complained next.“Here, let me teach you how to sprinkle.Pressure is what’s wanted.Sprinkle under pressure if you want to iron fast.”
他从地下室的木料堆里找到一个装东西的箱子，给它装上盖子，又搜寻了一下小席尔瓦们捡来准备卖给废品商的铁片。把新喷过水的衣服放进箱子里，盖上熨烫板再用熨斗熨，这装置就算完成，可以用了。 He procured a packing-case from the woodpile in the cellar, fitted a cover to it, and raided the scrap-iron the Silva tribe was collecting for the junkman.With fresh-sprinkled garments in the box, covered with the board and pressed by the iron, the device was complete and in operation.
“现在你瞧着我吧，玛丽亚。”他说，脱得只剩一件内衣，紧握着一个他所谓的“真正热”的熨斗。 “Now you watch me, Maria,” he said, stripping off to his undershirt and gripping an iron that was what he called “really hot.”
“他熨完衣服就洗毛料衣物，”她后来这么描述道，“他说，‘玛丽亚，你是个大傻瓜。我给你看看怎么洗毛料衣服吧，’他也就洗给我看了。十分钟内他就做好了那个机器——一个桶，一个轮毂，两根杆子，就是这么个样子。” “An’ when he feenish da iron’ he washa da wools,” as she described it afterward.“He say, ‘Maria, you are da greata fool.I showa you how to washa da wools,’ an’ he shows me, too.Ten minutes he maka da machine—one barrel, one wheel-hub, two poles, justa like dat.”
马丁在谢利温泉馆跟乔学的这个发明。一个旧轮毂固定在一根直立的杆子末端，就构成了一个捣衣槌子。之后，把它与一根连在厨房椽子上的活动杆子连在一起，这样那个轮毂就捣着桶里的衣物，他用一只手就可以把衣物槌个够了。 Martin had learned the contrivance from Joe at the Shelly Hot Springs.The old wheel-hub, fixed on the end of the upright pole, constituted the plunger.Making this, in turn, fast to the spring-pole attached to the kitchen rafters, so that the hub played upon the woollens in the barrel, he was able, with one hand, thoroughly to pound them.
“再用不着玛丽亚去洗那毛料衣服啦，”她的故事常常是这样结束的，“我叫那些小家伙们去弄那杆子，轮毂和水桶就好啦。他是个聪明人呐，马丁·伊登。” “No more Maria washa da wools,” her story always ended.“I maka da kids worka da pole an’ da hub an’ da barrel.Him da smarta man, Mister Eden.”
然而，他娴熟的手法和对她厨房洗衣房的改造工作却使她对他的尊敬下降了一大截。她想像中的他身上的浪漫魅力在现实冰冷的照耀下逐渐暗淡，因为他以前不过是个洗衣工。他所有的书，他的坐着马车来拜访或是带了无数瓶威士忌的贵客，全都不存在了。毕竟，他只不过是一个工人，她那个阶层的一份子，和她地位相同。他更亲切，更容易接近了，然而，他不再神秘了。 Nevertheless, by his masterly operation and improvement of her kitchen-laundry he fell an immense distance in her regard.The glamour of romance with which her imagination had invested him faded away in the cold light of fact that he was an ex-laundryman.All his books, and his grand friends who visited him in carriages or with countless bottles of whiskey, went for naught.He was, after all, a mere workingman, a member of her own class and caste.He was more human and approachable, but, he was no longer mystery.
马丁跟家人的疏远还继续着。在希金博特姆先生无缘无故的攻击之后，赫尔曼·冯·施米特先生也出手了。很幸运，马丁卖掉了几篇短篇小说，几首幽默诗和几则笑话之后，获得了一时的繁荣。他不但付清了一部分账单，而且还剩下足够的钱把他的黑色套装和自行车赎了回来。后者由于曲轴歪了，需要修理了，于是作为对他未来妹夫的友好表示，他把脚踏车送到冯·施米特的店里。 Martin’s alienation from his family continued.Following upon Mr. Higginbotham’s unprovoked attack, Mr. Hermann von Schmidt showed his hand.The fortunate sale of several storiettes, some humorous verse, and a few jokes gave Martin a temporary splurge of prosperity.Not only did he partially pay up his bills, but he had sufficient balance left to redeem his black suit and wheel.The latter, by virtue of a twisted crank-hanger, required repairing, and, as a matter of friendliness with his future brother-in-law, he sent it to Von Schmidt’s shop.
当天下午，脚踏车由一个小伙计送来，马丁很高兴。冯·施米特也想表示友好，这便是马丁从这不寻常的优待而得到的结论。修理车子通常一定要自己去取的。但他检查车子的时候，发现根本没有修理过。之后，他便打了电话给她妹妹的未婚夫，才知道那个人“无论在任何状态、情形或形式”之下，都不愿同他打交道。 The afternoon of the same day Martin was pleased by the wheel being delivered by a small boy.Von Schmidt was also inclined to be friendly, was Martin’s conclusion from this unusual favor.Repaired wheels usually had to be called for.But when he examined the wheel, he discovered no repairs had been made.A little later in the day he telephoned his sister’s betrothed, and learned that that person didn’t want anything to do with him in “any shape, manner, or form.”
“赫尔曼·冯·施米特，”马丁高兴地答道，“我倒是很乐意揍一顿你那荷兰式的鼻子呢。” “Hermann von Schmidt,” Martin answered cheerfully, “I’ve a good mind to come over and punch that Dutch nose of yours.”
“你来我店里，”对方答复道，“我就叫警察。我也让你试试看。哦，我了解你，不过你别来跟我惹是生非。我不想和你这样的人来往。你是个游手好闲的家伙，正是这样，我可不是迷迷糊糊的。别以为我要娶你妹妹你就能揩我的油。你干吗不去干活，老老实实过日子呢，啊？回答我呀。” “You come to my shop,” came the reply, “an’ I’ll send for the police.An’ I’ll put you through, too.Oh, I know you, but you can’t make no rough-house with me.I don’t want nothin’ to do with the likes of you.You’re a loafer, that’s what, an’ I ain’t asleep.You ain’t goin’ to do no spongin’ off me just because I’m marryin’ your sister.Why don’t you go to work an’ earn an honest livin’, eh?Answer me that.”
马丁的人生哲学显示了力量，驱散了他的怒气，他吹了一个长长的口哨，流露出怀疑的娱乐意味，挂上了电话。但是在乐趣之后，随之而来的是一种反作用，他被孤独折磨着。没有一个人理解他，没有一个人似乎对他有点儿用处，除了布里森登，然而布里森登失踪了，只有天知道他在哪儿。 Martin’s philosophy asserted itself, dissipating his anger, and he hung up the receiver with a long whistle of incredulous amusement.But after the amusement came the reaction, and he was oppressed by his loneliness.Nobody understood him, nobody seemed to have any use for him, except Brissenden, and Brissenden had disappeared, God alone knew where.
马丁离开水果店，抱着买来的东西回家的时候，暮色降临了。拐角处一辆电车停了下来，看见一个瘦长而熟悉的身影下了车，他的心欢快地跳动起来。是布里森登，在电车开动之前，飞快地一瞥之后，马丁注意到那大衣的口袋，一个装满了书，另一个鼓鼓囊囊地塞着一瓶一夸脱装的威士忌。 Twilight was falling as Martin left the fruit store and turned homeward, his marketing on his arm.At the corner an electric car had stopped, and at sight of a lean, familiar figure alighting, his heart leapt with joy.It was Brissenden, and in the fleeting glimpse, ere the car started up, Martin noted the overcoat pockets, one bulging with books, the other bulging with a quart bottle of whiskey.
第三十五章 CHAPTER XXXV
布里森登对自己长时间的销声匿迹并没有什么解释，马丁也没有向他打听。透过那杯甜酒所升腾起的蒸汽，看见对面朋友那憔悴的脸，他感到满足。 Brissenden gave no explanation of his long absence, nor did Martin pry into it.He was content to see his friend’s cadaverous face opposite him through the steam rising from a tumbler of toddy.
“我也没偷懒。”听见马丁说到他已经完成的作品之后布里森登宣布道。 “I, too, have not been idle,” Brissenden proclaimed, after hearing Martin’s account of the work he had accomplished.
他从里面一件衣服的口袋里掏出一篇稿子递给马丁，马丁看着那个题目便好奇地浏览起来。 He pulled a manuscript from his inside coat pocket and passed it to Martin, who looked at the title and glanced up curiously.
“是的，就是它，”布里森登大笑，“相当漂亮的题目吧，啊？‘蜉蝣’——就是这么一个词。就是从你那里来的，跟你同类的人，永远直立，有活力的无机物，最新形式的蜉蝣，在温度表的微小空间里趾高气扬地走着的那有体温的生物。它走进了我的头脑中，我只得把它写出来才能摆脱它。你觉得怎么样，告诉我吧。” “Yes, that’s it,” Brissenden laughed.“Pretty good title, eh?‘Ephemera’—it is the one word.And you’re responsible for it, what of your man, who is always the erected, the vitalized inorganic, the latest of the ephemera, the creature of temperature strutting his little space on the thermometer.It got into my head and I had to write it to get rid of it.Tell me what you think of it.”
马丁的脸先是发红，一读下去就变得苍白了。这是完美的艺术。形式击败了内容，如果可以叫做胜利的话，在那里可以想象得到的内容的每一个细节都能够用最完美的结构表达出来，以至于马丁的头脑中充满了喜悦，眼中溢满了激情的泪水，又有一阵阵寒气在他的脊背上起伏。这是一首长诗，有六七百行，是一部奇妙的、惊人的、不染尘俗的作品。它精彩至极，几乎不可能存在；然而它就在那里，用黑色的墨水写在一张张白纸上。它抒写的是人及人的灵魂在其终极意义上的探索，测探着空间的深渊，以证实最遥远的恒星和彩虹光谱。它是想象力的狂欢宴会，在一个垂死者的头颅里痛饮，垂死者无声地啜泣着，衰弱的心脏却在狂跳。那首诗以壮丽的旋律徘徊于星际冲突阴冷的骚乱中，徘徊于星群的攻击中，徘徊于黑暗的太空中冰冷的恒星的冲击和星云的燃烧中；而透过这一切，人类微弱细小的声音，像一只银梭无力地不停穿行着，在行星的呼啸声和天体的撞击声中不过是个哀怨的啁啾声。 Martin’s face, flushed at first, paled as he read on.It was perfect art.Form triumphed over substance, if triumph it could be called where the last conceivable atom of substance had found expression in so perfect construction as to make Martin’s head swim with delight, to put passionate tears into his eyes, and to send chills creeping up and down his back.It was a long poem of six or seven hundred lines, and it was a fantastic, amazing, unearthly thing.It was terrific, impossible; and yet there it was, scrawled in black ink across the sheets of paper.It dealt with man and his soul-gropings in their ultimate terms, plumbing the abysses of space for the testimony of remotest suns and rainbow spectrums.It was a mad orgy of imagination, wassailing in the skull of a dying man who half sobbed under his breath and was quick with the wild flutter of fading heart-beats.The poem swung in majestic rhythm to the cool tumult of interstellar conflict, to the onset of starry hosts, to the impact of cold suns and the flaming up of nebular in the darkened void; and through it all, unceasing and faint, like a silver shuttle, ran the frail, piping voice of man, a querulous chirp amid the screaming of planets and the crash of systems.
“在文学中，像这样的东西是没有的，”当马丁终于能说话的时候，他说道，“太了不起了！——了不起！它印入了我的头脑里。我陶醉其中了。那个伟大的而又极小的问题——我无法让它摆脱我的思想。人类那探求的、永恒的、反复的、微弱细小的哭号声依然在我耳边响着。这好像是在大象的吼声和狮子的咆哮当中，一只蚊虫的死亡进行曲。微小的欲望无法满足它。此刻，我让自己变成一个傻瓜，可是那东西已经迷惑了我。你是——我不知道你是什么——你是了不起的，就是这样。可是你是怎么写成它的呢？你是怎么办到的呢？” “There is nothing like it in literature,” Martin said, when at last he was able to speak.“It’s wonderful!—wonderful!It has gone to my head.I am drunken with it.That great, infinitesimal question—I can’t shake it out of my thoughts.That questing, eternal, ever recurring, thin little wailing voice of man is still ringing in my ears.It is like the dead-march of a gnat amid the trumpeting of elephants and the roaring of lions.It is insatiable with microscopic desire.I now I’m making a fool of myself, but the thing has obsessed me.You are—I don’t know what you are—you are wonderful, that’s all.But how do you do it?How do you do it?”
马丁暂停了他狂热的言辞，但又重新开始说。 Martin paused from his rhapsody, only to break out afresh.
“我永远不再写作了。我只会在泥土里乱画。你已经给我看了真正的巧匠的作品了。天才！这是比天才还高明的呀。它胜过天才。它是疯狂了的真理。它是真实的，老兄，每一行都是。我真想知道你是否晓得这个呢，你这个独断论者！科学骗不了你。这是冷笑的真理，是从宇宙的黑铁模印出来的，用有力的声音韵律织入一幅光彩美丽的织物。现在，我说不出别的话了。我被征服了，粉碎了。是的，我也一定会的。我替你把它卖出去吧。” “I shall never write again.I am a dauber in clay.You have shown me the work of the real artificer-artisan.Genius!This is something more than genius.It transcends genius.It is truth gone mad.It is true, man, every line of it.I wonder if you realize that, you dogmatist.Science cannot give you the lie.It is the truth of the sneer, stamped out from the black iron of the Cosmos and interwoven with mighty rhythms of sound into a fabric of splendor and beauty.And now I won’t say another word.I am overwhelmed, crushed.Yes, I will, too.Let me market it for you.”
布里森登咧嘴笑了。“在基督教的天下中，没有一家杂志敢刊登它——你知道的。” Brissenden grinned.“There’s not a magazine in Christendom that would dare to publish it—you know that.”
“我不懂那类事情。我只知道，在基督教的天下中，没有一家杂志不抢它。它们不是每天都能获得你这样的作品的。这不仅仅是年度之作。它是世纪之作。” “I know nothing of the sort.I know there’s not a magazine in Christendom that wouldn’t jump at it.They don’t get things like that every day.That’s no mere poem of the year.It’s the poem of the century.”
“就这一说法我愿意和你打赌。” “I’d like to take you up on the proposition.”
“好了，别又愤世嫉俗了，”马丁劝他，“杂志编辑不是完全蠢笨的。我知道的。我愿意跟你打赌。你要什么我就赌什么，我赌《蜉蝣》第一次或者第二次寄出去就会被接受的。” “Now don’t get cynical,” Martin exhorted.“The magazine editors are not wholly fatuous.I know that.And I’ll close with you on the bet.I’ll wager anything you want that ‘Ephemera’ is accepted either on the first or second offering.”
“只是有一件事情我不能接受你的意见。”布里森登停了一会儿。“这篇作品是很重要的——我写过的最重要的作品。我知道的。它是我的天鹅之歌。我为它极其骄傲。我爱慕它。它比威士忌还要好。它是我梦想着的——伟大而完美的作品——当我还是一个单纯的青年，充满着甜蜜的幻想和纯洁的理想的时候。现在，我用最后一点力气得到了它，我绝不能让它被那一群猪猡蹂躏和玷污。不，我能打赌。它是我的。我创造出它来，我已经跟你分享它啦。” “There’s just one thing that prevents me from taking you.”Brissenden waited a moment.“The thing is big—the biggest I’ve ever done.I know that.It’s my swan song.I am almighty proud of it.I worship it.It’s better than whiskey.It is what I dreamed of—the great and perfect thing—when I was a simple young man, with sweet illusions and clean ideals.And I’ve got it, now, in my last grasp, and I’ll not have it pawed over and soiled by a lot of swine.No, I won’t take the bet.It’s mine.I made it, and I’ve shared it with you.”
“可是，为世界上其余的人想想吧，”马丁抗议道，“美的功能在于创造快乐。” “But think of the rest of the world,” Martin protested.“The function of beauty is joy-making.”
“它是我的美。” “It’s my beauty.”
“别自私啊。” “Don’t be selfish.”
“我不自私。”布里森登冷静地笑了，他一高兴，他那薄嘴唇就会是那个样子。“我像一头饿极的公猪一样不自私呢。” “I’m not selfish.”Brissenden grinned soberly in the way he had when pleased by the thing his thin lips were about to shape.“I’m as unselfish as a famished hog.”
马丁竭力想要他放弃那个决定，却没有结果。马丁告诉他他对那些杂志的憎恨是偏激狂热的，他的行为比放火烧掉以弗所的戴安娜神庙的青年还要卑劣一千倍。处在谴责的暴风雨之下，布里森登满意地啜着他的甜酒，认定对方所说的一切是十分正确的，除了关于杂志编辑的是一个例外。他对他们的憎恨是无止境的，一说到他们，他斥责的声音便超过了马丁。 In vain Martin strove to shake him from his decision.Martin told him that his hatred of the magazines was rabid, fanatical, and that his conduct was a thousand times more despicable than that of the youth who burned the temple of Diana at Ephesus.Under the storm of denunciation Brissenden complacently sipped his toddy and affirmed that everything the other said was quite true, with the exception of the magazine editors.His hatred of them knew no bounds, and he excelled Martin in denunciation when he turned upon them.
“我希望你用打字机帮我打出来，”他说，“你懂得的比任何速记员都要好过一千倍。现在我要给你一点儿忠告了。”他从外衣口袋里掏出一叠厚厚的稿子。“这是你的《太阳的耻辱》。我不止读了一遍，而是两遍，三遍——我可以给你最高的恭维。而你对《蜉蝣》说了那一番话之后，我就得保持沉默了。但是我还要说一点：《太阳的耻辱》刊登出来的时候一定会获得成功。它将惹起一场争论，而这在你恰恰等于大登广告。” “I wish you’d type it for me,” he said.“You know how a thousand times better than any stenographer.And now I want to give you some advice.”He drew a bulky manuscript from his outside coat pocket.“Here’s your @Shame of the Sun@.’ I’ve read it not once, but twice and three times—the highest compliment I can pay you.After what you’ve said about ‘Ephemera’ I must be silent.But this I will say: when @The Shame of the Sun@ is published, it will make a hit.It will start a controversy that will be worth thousands to you just in advertising.”
马丁大笑。“我看你的第二个忠告就是要我把它寄给杂志了。” Martin laughed.“I suppose your next advice will be to submit it to the magazines.”
“无论如何也不要——就是说，如果你想看到它被印出来的话。把它寄到一流的出版公司吧。某个出版公司的审稿人可能会为它沉迷为它陶醉的，会做出有利的审稿意见。你是读过书的。它们的精华已经在马丁·伊登的蒸馏器里得到提炼吸收，并被注入到《太阳的耻辱》里，有一天马丁·伊登会成名的，而他的成名就是靠着这一部作品。所以你一定要找一家出版公司——越快越好。” “By all means no—that is, if you want to see it in print.Offer it to the first-class houses.Some publisher’s reader may be mad enough or drunk enough to report favorably on it.You’ve read the books.The meat of them has been transmuted in the alembic of Martin Eden’s mind and poured into @The Shame of the Sun@， and one day Martin Eden will be famous, and not the least of his fame will rest upon that work.So you must get a publisher for it—the sooner the better.”
那晚布里森登很晚才回家去；当他刚刚迈步上车的时候，突然朝马丁转过来，把一个皱皱巴巴的小纸团塞到马丁手里。 Brissenden went home late that night; and just as he mounted the first step of the car, he swung suddenly back on Martin and thrust into his hand a small, tightly crumpled wad of paper.
“来，拿着，”他说，“我今天去赌赛马了，得到可靠情报啦。” “Here, take this,” he said.“I was out to the races to-day, and I had the right dope.”
铃响了，车开动了，剩下马丁在那里猜想着他拿在手里的那个折皱的纸团是什么东西。回到房间里，他摊开了它，发现是一张一百元的支票。 The bell clanged and the car pulled out, leaving Martin wondering as to the nature of the crinkly, greasy wad he clutched in his hand.Back in his room he unrolled it and found a hundred-dollar bill.
他毫不犹豫地拿去用了。他知道他的朋友总是有很多钱，也深信他的成功会帮他还清这笔钱。早上他付清了所有的帐，预付了玛丽亚三个月的房租，赎回了当铺里所有的东西。接着他给玛丽安买了结婚礼物，给鲁思和格特鲁德买了简单而得体的圣诞礼物。最后他带着剩下的钱率领着席尔瓦一家来到了奥克兰。说到履行诺言，他已经迟了一个冬天，但是最终还是履行了，至少每一个席尔瓦都得到了一双鞋子，玛丽亚也有一双。另外还有号角，娃娃和形形色色的玩具，一包包一束束的糖果和坚果塞满了每一个席尔瓦的怀抱。 He did not scruple to use it.He knew his friend had always plenty of money, and he knew also, with profound certitude, that his success would enable him to repay it.In the morning he paid every bill, gave Maria three months’ advance on the room, and redeemed every pledge at the pawnshop.Next he bought Marian’s wedding present, and simpler presents, suitable to Christmas, for Ruth and Gertrude.And finally, on the balance remaining to him, he herded the whole Silva tribe down into Oakland.He was a winter late in redeeming his promise, but redeemed it was, for the last, least Silva got a pair of shoes, as well as Maria herself.Also, there were horns, and dolls, and toys of various sorts, and parcels and bundles of candies and nuts that filled the arms of all the Silvas to overflowing.
正当这一支特殊的队伍跟在他和玛丽亚的身后大踏步地走进一家糖果店寻找最大的手杖糖时，他遇见了鲁思和她的母亲。莫尔斯太太大吃一惊。甚至鲁思也感到不快，因为她是有点儿爱面子的，而她的爱人跟玛丽亚亲密地在一起，带领着一支葡萄牙小叫花的队伍，真是不体面。但是更叫她伤心的是他的不自尊和不自爱。而且，最令人难受的是，从这次邂逅当中，她看出了他要摆脱他工人阶级的出身是不可能的。这事情本身就够丢脸的了，他还恬不知耻地炫耀于全世界——她的世界——未免太过分。尽管她和马丁的婚约一直在保密，他们长期的亲密来往不会不引起闲话的；在店里就有几个她的熟人偷偷瞥着她的爱人和跟着他的那帮人。她缺乏马丁那种广阔的胸襟，不能超越她的环境。她被伤及要害，她敏感的天性正因这耻辱而颤抖。马丁当天晚些时候来到的时候，就是这样的情形，他只好把要送她的礼物留在胸前的口袋里，送礼物这事就推迟到一个合适的场合再说。鲁思淌着眼泪——激动而生气的眼泪——这是对他的启示。看到她痛苦，他更确信自己是个野兽，然而他的灵魂却不明白是怎么回事，为的是什么。他永远不会想到会以他认识的人为耻，而带着席尔瓦们出去买些圣诞礼物在他看来也并不是对鲁思的不体贴。另一方面，在鲁思说明了自己的观点之后，他是明白的；他把这个看成是女性的弱点，它使所有女人苦恼，包括最优秀的女人。 It was with this extraordinary procession trooping at his and Maria’s heels into a confectioner’s in quest if the biggest candy-cane ever made, that he encountered Ruth and her mother.Mrs. Morse was shocked.Even Ruth was hurt, for she had some regard for appearances, and her lover, cheek by jowl with Maria, at the head of that army of Portuguese ragamuffins, was not a pretty sight.But it was not that which hurt so much as what she took to be his lack of pride and self-respect.Further, and keenest of all, she read into the incident the impossibility of his living down his working-class origin.There was stigma enough in the fact of it, but shamelessly to flaunt it in the face of the world—her world—was going too far.Though her engagement to Martin had been kept secret, their long intimacy had not been unproductive of gossip; and in the shop, glancing covertly at her lover and his following, had been several of her acquaintances.She lacked the easy largeness of Martin and could not rise superior to her environment.She had been hurt to the quick, and her sensitive nature was quivering with the shame of it.So it was, when Martin arrived later in the day, that he kept her present in his breast-pocket, deferring the giving of it to a more propitious occasion.Ruth in tears—passionate, angry tears—was a revelation to him.The spectacle of her suffering convinced him that he had been a brute, yet in the soul of him he could not see how nor why.It never entered his head to be ashamed of those he knew, and to take the Silvas out to a Christmas treat could in no way, so it seemed to him, show lack of consideration for Ruth.On the other hand, he did see Ruth’s point of view, after she had explained it; and he looked upon it as a feminine weakness, such as afflicted all women and the best of women.
第三十六章 CHAPTER XXXVI
“来吧，——我带你看看真正的贫民窟。”一月里的某个晚上布里森登跟他说。 “Come on,—I’ll show you the real dirt,” Brissenden said to him, one evening in January.
他一时兴起要带马丁看看“真正的贫民窟”的时候，他们刚一起在旧金山吃过饭，来到轮渡大厦，准备回奥克兰去。他转身飞快地跑着穿过海岸，一个瘦削的影子，披着迎风招展的大衣，后面还有竭力追赶的马丁。在一间酒水批发店，他买了两大瓶一加仑装的陈年葡萄酒，一手拿一瓶上了一辆传道街的电车，马丁跟在他后面，拿着几瓶一夸脱装的威士忌。 They had dined together in San Francisco, and were at the Ferry Building, returning to Oakland, when the whim came to him to show Martin the “real dirt.”He turned and fled across the water-front, a meagre shadow in a flapping overcoat, with Martin straining to keep up with him.At a wholesale liquor store he bought two gallon-demijohns of old port, and with one in each hand boarded a Mission Street car, Martin at his heels burdened with several quart-bottles of whiskey.
他想，要是鲁思现在看到我就不得了了，同时也想知道真正的贫民窟是怎么一回事。 If Ruth could see me now, was his thought, while he wondered as to what constituted the real dirt.
“也许那儿没有人，”布里森登说。同时他们下了车，向右扎进市场街南面工人阶级贫民窟的中心。“要是这样的话，你会错失你寻找已久的东西。” “Maybe nobody will be there,” Brissenden said, when they dismounted and plunged off to the right into the heart of the working-class ghetto, south of Market Street.“In which case you’ll miss what you’ve been looking for so long.”
“那究竟是什么啊？”马丁问。 “And what the deuce is that?”Martin asked.
“人们，智慧的人们，不是我看见你在那家生意人家结交的那些口齿不清的小人物。你读过书，而且你觉得自己是孤独的。好吧，今晚我就叫你见识一些人，他们都读过书，你再也不会孤独了。” “Men, intelligent men, and not the gibbering nonentities I found you consorting with in that trader’s den.You read the books and you found yourself all alone.Well, I’m going to show you to-night some other men who’ve read the books, so that you won’t be lonely any more.”
“我对他们永无休止的争论不感兴趣，”走到一个街区尽头时他说，“我对书本上的哲学也不感兴趣。可是你会发现这些家伙是聪明人，不是资产阶级的猪猡。可是你得当心，不论这世上的什么问题，他们都会和你讲个不停。” “Not that I bother my head about their everlasting discussions,” he said at the end of a block.“I’m not interested in book philosophy.But you’ll find these fellows intelligences and not bourgeois swine.But watch out, they’ll talk an arm off of you on any subject under the sun.”
“但愿诺顿在那儿，”稍后他有点儿喘，坚持不让马丁帮他拿那两个大瓶子，“诺顿是一个理想主义者——哈佛大学毕业的。记忆力超常。理想主义把他引到哲学的无政府主义上了，为此他的家庭把他赶了出来。他父亲是一个铁路公司的总裁，比百万富翁还要富几倍，可儿子却在旧金山饿着肚子，一个月拿二十五块钱，编着一份无政府主义的报纸。” “Hope Norton’s there,” he panted a little later, resisting Martin’s effort to relieve him of the two demijohns.“Norton’s an idealist—a Harvard man.Prodigious memory.Idealism led him to philosophic anarchy, and his family threw him off.Father’s a railroad president and many times millionnaire, but the son’s starving in ’Frisco, editing an anarchist sheet for twenty-five a month.”
马丁对旧金山不怎么熟，对市场街南更是搞不清楚；所以他不知道自己正被带往哪里。 Martin was little acquainted in San Francisco, and not at all south of Market; so he had no idea of where he was being led.
“说说吧，”他说，“先给我讲讲他们的事吧。他们靠什么过活？他们怎么会在那里？” “Go ahead,” he said; “tell me about them beforehand.What do they do for a living?How do they happen to be here?”
“但愿汉密尔顿在那儿。”布里森登停了一会儿，歇了歇手。“斯特朗-汉密尔顿是他的名字——带连字符的，你知道——带有南方血统。他是个流浪者——是我认识的最懒的人，虽然他在一家社会主义合作商店里做职员，或者说勉强做着，一个星期拿六块钱。然而他的的确确是个流浪汉。流浪到城里来的。我看见过他整天坐在一张长椅上，双唇没咬过一口食物，到了晚上，我邀请他到两个街区外的餐馆去吃饭时，他却说：‘太麻烦了，老兄。还是给我买一包烟吧。’他和你一样是个斯宾塞主义者，直至克赖斯把他变成了一个唯物主义一元论者。如果我可以的话，我就从一元论谈起他。诺顿是另一个一元论者——不过他肯定的只是精神。他也能给克赖斯和汉密尔顿所需要的一切。” “Hope Hamilton’s there.”Brissenden paused and rested his hands.“Strawn-Hamilton’s his name—hyphenated, you know—comes of old Southern stock.He’s a tramp—laziest man I ever knew, though he’s clerking, or trying to, in a socialist coöperative store for six dollars a week.But he’s a confirmed hobo.Tramped into town.I’ve seen him sit all day on a bench and never a bite pass his lips, and in the evening, when I invited him to dinner—restaurant two blocks away—have him say, ‘Too much trouble, old man.Buy me a package of cigarettes instead.’He was a Spencerian like you till Kreis turned him to materialistic monism.I’ll start him on monism if I can.Norton’s another monist—only he affirms naught but spirit.He can give Kreis and Hamilton all they want, too.”
“谁是克赖斯？”马丁问。 “Who is Kreis?” Martin asked.
“我们现在要去的就是他的家。他曾经是教授——被大学开除了——平常的故事。他的思想像一个捕兽夹。依照任一老方法过活。我知道他潦倒的时候还做过沿街化缘的苦行僧。肆无忌惮。他偷过死人的寿衣——什么都偷。他——和资产阶级的不同在于他偷却不制造假象。他会谈尼采、叔本华、康德、或任何东西，但这世上的所有东西，连圣母玛丽亚在内，他真正关心的是一元论。海克尔是他的一个锡制小神像。侮辱他的唯一办法就是打海克尔一耳光。” “His rooms we’re going to.One time professor—fired from university—usual story.A mind like a steel trap.Makes his living any old way.I know he’s been a street fakir when he was down.Unscrupulous.Rob a corpse of a shroud—anything.Difference between him—and the bourgeoisie is that he robs without illusion.He’ll talk Nietzsche, or Schopenhauer, or Kant, or anything, but the only thing in this world, not excepting Mary, that he really cares for, is his monism.Haeckel is his little tin god.The only way to insult him is to take a slap at Haeckel.”
“这儿就是他们的老巢了。”布里森登把他的大酒瓶放在楼梯口，准备上楼了。那是普通的街角处的两层楼房，楼下是一家酒吧和一家杂货店。“那帮人就住在这儿——整个楼上都被他们租去了。不过克赖斯是唯一一个有两间房的。走吧。” “Here’s the hang-out.”Brissenden rested his demijohn at the upstairs entrance, preliminary to the climb.It was the usual two-story corner building, with a saloon and grocery underneath.“The gang lives here—got the whole upstairs to themselves.But Kreis is the only one who has two rooms.Come on.”
楼上的过道没有点灯，但布里森登却像一个熟门熟路的幽灵，穿过那漆黑一片。他停下来对马丁说： No lights burned in the upper hall, but Brissenden threaded the utter blackness like a familiar ghost.He stopped to speak to Martin.
“这里有一个家伙——史蒂文斯——一个通神论者。他一张口就搞得很热闹。他现在在一家饭馆里当洗碗工，他对高级雪茄爱不释手。我见过他在一家只需花十美分就能填饱肚子的廉价餐馆里吃饭，却在饭后花了五十美分买雪茄来抽。要是他来的话，我还在口袋里为他准备了几只雪茄。” “There’s one fellow—Stevens—a theosophist.Makes a pretty tangle when he gets going.Just now he’s dish-washer in a restaurant.Likes a good cigar.I’ve seen him eat in a ten-cent hash-house and pay fifty cents for the cigar he smoked afterward.I’ve got a couple in my pocket for him, if he shows up.”
“还有一个叫帕里的家伙，一个澳大利亚人，统计学家，简直就是部活百科全书。不管是问他巴拉圭1903年的粮食总产量，还是1890年英国向中国出口的床单总数，或吉米•布里特对战杀手纳尔逊的拳击战属于哪个重量级，又或者谁是68年全美次中量级冠军，你都会立刻从他口中得到又快又准的答案，如同从投硬币式自动售货机里出来的一样。还有安迪，是个石匠，对每件事情都有自己的见解，象棋也下得不错；还有个叫哈里的面包师，他是个狂热的社会主义者，对工会的力量坚信不疑。顺带说一句，你还记得那次厨师和侍者大罢工么？就是汉密尔顿组织工会促成了那次罢工。一切就是在这儿，在克赖斯的家里都事先准备好了。他鼓捣罢工这件事是出于好玩，可是因为太懒惰而在工会里呆不下去。但只要他愿意，他就能在工会里出人头地。他要不是懒得不可理喻的话，这家伙的潜能可是永无止境的。 “And there’s another fellow—Parry—an Australian, a statistician and a sporting encyclopaedia.Ask him the grain output of Paraguay for 1903, or the English importation of sheetings into China for 1890, or at what weight Jimmy Britt fought Battling Nelson, or who was welter-weight champion of the United States in ’68, and you’ll get the correct answer with the automatic celerity of a slot-machine.And there’s Andy, a stone-mason, has ideas on everything, a good chess-player; and another fellow, Harry, a baker, red hot socialist and strong union man.By the way, you remember Cooks’ and Waiters’ strike—Hamilton was the chap who organized that union and precipitated the strike—planned it all out in advance, right here in Kreis’s rooms.Did it just for the fun of it, but was too lazy to stay by the union.Yet he could have risen high if he wanted to.There’s no end to the possibilities in that man—if he weren’t so insuperably lazy.”
布里森登在黑暗中前进着，直到一缕光线指引着他们走到一道门槛前。敲了敲门，有人过来开了门。之后马丁发现自己已经和克赖斯握着手了。克赖斯是个肌肤浅黑色的英俊男子，牙齿亮白耀眼，留着黑色的八字胡，两只黑色的大眼睛炯炯有神。玛丽是个主妇模样的金发年轻女子，正在后面的小屋里洗着碗。这屋子既当厨房，也当餐厅。前屋则既当卧室也当客厅。上面晾晒着一周积攒下来的衣服，像花彩一样低低地挂着，以至于他刚进来的时候都没发现有两个人正在角落里谈话。他们欢快地和布里森登以及他的大酒瓶打了个招呼。经介绍，马丁知道他们就是安迪和帕里。他加入了他们，并且仔细聆听着帕里讲述他头天晚上观看的职业拳击赛。这时，布里森登得意洋洋地走了过来，手里端着葡萄酒和威士忌苏打，正准备做一大杯甜酒。他号令道：“把那帮家伙叫出来！”安迪立刻到各个房间里把大家都召集起来。 Brissenden advanced through the darkness till a thread of light marked the threshold of a door.A knock and an answer opened it, and Martin found himself shaking hands with Kreis, a handsome brunette man, with dazzling white teeth, a drooping black mustache, and large, flashing black eyes.Mary, a matronly young blonde, was washing dishes in the little back room that served for kitchen and dining room.The front room served as bedchamber and living room.Overhead was the week’s washing, hanging in festoons so low that Martin did not see at first the two men talking in a corner.They hailed Brissenden and his demijohns with acclamation, and, on being introduced, Martin learned they were Andy and Parry.He joined them and listened attentively to the description of a prize-fight Parry had seen the night before; while Brissenden, in his glory, plunged into the manufacture of a toddy and the serving of wine and whiskey-and-sodas.At his command, “Bring in the clan,” Andy departed to go the round of the rooms for the lodgers.
“我们挺幸运的，大多数人都在。”布里森登向马丁耳语道。“诺顿和汉密尔顿都在这儿，去和他们打个招呼吧。据说史蒂文斯现在不在。要是可以的话，我会想办法让他们从一元论讨论起。先等他们两杯酒下肚暖暖身吧。” “We’re lucky that most of them are here,” Brissenden whispered to Martin.“There’s Norton and Hamilton; come on and meet them.Stevens isn’t around, I hear.I’m going to get them started on monism if I can.Wait till they get a few jolts in them and they’ll warm up.”
一开始的谈话略显凌乱。但马丁仍能欣赏到谈话者敏锐的思想。他们都是有主见的人，尽管常常话语间存在着交锋；尽管他们都风趣睿智，但是绝不浅薄。马丁很快发现，无论他们在讨论何种话题，都能灵活地综合运用相关知识，并且对社会和宇宙都有着深层次的、系统性的理解。他们的见解不是任何人为他们预先设想好的；他们都是某种类型或另一种类型的叛逆者，他们的唇间迸出的精妙话语绝不是陈词滥调。讨论的话题范围之广是马丁在莫尔斯家从未见识过的。要不是时间有限，他们可说的话题简直就是无边无际。他们从汉弗莱·沃德夫人的新书聊到萧伯纳的最新剧本；又从戏剧的发展前景谈到对曼斯菲尔德的回忆。他们对早报刊发的社论表示欣赏或鄙弃；他们从讨论新西兰的劳工条件猛然转入亨利·詹姆斯和布兰德·马修斯的作品中，又转入德国在远东的阴谋；他们对德国的选举和倍倍尔最近的演讲争论不休；然后话题又固定到当地的政治状况上，如联合劳工党政府的最新计划和丑闻；还有导致了海岸海员罢工的幕后操纵内幕。他们所掌握的内幕消息之多让马丁感到震惊。他们知道从来没有在报纸上报道过的东西——那些导演着各色政治傀儡秀的幕后操盘手和各种内幕。让马丁吃惊的是，那名女子，玛丽也参与到谈话中，她表现出在他所接触过的少数妇女身上从未见识过的智慧。她和马丁一起讨论着斯温伯恩和罗塞蒂，然后她便把马丁引向了超越他认知深度的法国文学上去了。等到她为梅特林克辩护时，马丁便用他在创作《太阳的耻辱》时深思熟虑出的观点回击了她。 At first the conversation was desultory.Nevertheless Martin could not fail to appreciate the keen play of their minds.They were men with opinions, though the opinions often clashed, and, though they were witty and clever, they were not superficial.He swiftly saw, no matter upon what they talked, that each man applied the correlation of knowledge and had also a deep-seated and unified conception of society and the Cosmos.Nobody manufactured their opinions for them; they were all rebels of one variety or another, and their lips were strangers to platitudes.Never had Martin, at the Morses’, heard so amazing a range of topics discussed.There seemed no limit save time to the things they were alive to.The talk wandered from Mrs. Humphry Ward’s new book to Shaw’s latest play, through the future of the drama to reminiscences of Mansfield.They appreciated or sneered at the morning editorials, jumped from labor conditions in New Zealand to Henry James and Brander Matthews, passed on to the German designs in the Far East，wrangled over the German elections and Bebel’s last speech, and settled down to local politics, the latest plans and scandals in the union labor party administration, and the wires that were pulled to bring about the Coast Seamen’s strike.Martin was struck by the inside knowledge they possessed.They knew what was never printed in the newspapers—the wires and strings and the hidden hands that made the puppets dance.To Martin’s surprise, the girl, Mary, joined in the conversation, displaying an intelligence he had never encountered in the few women he had met.They talked together on Swinburne and Rossetti, after which she led him beyond his depth into the by-paths of French literature.His revenge came when she defended Maeterlinck and he brought into action the carefully-thought-out thesis of @The Shame of the Sun@.
另外有几个人也加入了讨论，空气中弥漫着浓烈的香烟味，就在这时，布里森登挥舞起红色的旗帜。 Several other men had dropped in, and the air was thick with tobacco smoke, when Brissenden waved the red flag.
“克赖斯，你的板斧有了新的战斗对象，”他说，“一个像白玫瑰一样的年轻人，对赫伯特·斯宾塞怀着恋人一般的热情。你要是有本事的话，就把他变成海克尔的信徒吧！” “Here’s fresh meat for your axe, Kreis,” he said; “a rose-white youth with the ardor of a lover for Herbert Spencer.Make a Haeckelite of him—if you can.”
克赖斯仿佛苏醒了过来，像某种带磁性的金属一样闪耀着光芒。诺顿则向马丁投去同情的目光，露出一个甜美的女孩般的微笑，似乎在告诉马丁他将获得足够的保护。 Kreis seemed to wake up and flash like some metallic, magnetic thing, while Norton looked at Martin sympathetically, with a sweet, girlish smile, as much as to say that he would be amply protected.
克赖斯向马丁单刀直入地开始了说教，但是诺顿逐步地进行了干涉，慢慢地演化成了克赖斯和诺顿停下来进行两人之间的争论。马丁听着听着，觉得这样的谈话简直难以令人难以置信。这样的情景在市场街以南的劳工贫民窟里根本是不可能发生的。这些人把书中的知识完全融入了生活中。话语间燃烧着火花和激情，他们被智慧的力量所驱使的模样，就像马丁之前见到的那些被酒精和愤怒所刺激的人一般。他耳之所闻不再是出自康德或斯宾塞这样半传说般的神秘人物笔下枯燥而乏味的哲学文字。而是活生生的，在这两人身上的鲜红的热血之中体现出的哲学，并随着讨论激烈程度的加深愈发显现出来。时不时地有人插几句嘴，所有的人都紧跟着讨论的进展，手上的香烟纷纷熄灭，脸上都露出了警惕而专注的神情。 Kreis began directly on Martin, but step by step Norton interfered, until he and Kreis were off and away in a personal battle.Martin listened and fain would have rubbed his eyes.It was impossible that this should be, much less in the labor ghetto south of Market.The books were alive in these men.They talked with fire and enthusiasm, the intellectual stimulant stirring them as he had seen drink and anger stir other men.What he heard was no longer the philosophy of the dry, printed word, written by half-mythical demigods like Kant and Spencer.It was living philosophy, with warm, red blood, incarnated in these two men till its very features worked with excitement.Now and again other men joined in, and all followed the discussion with cigarettes going out in their hands and with alert, intent faces.
唯心主义从来没有吸引过马丁，但是诺顿的解释却给了他启示。唯心论合乎逻辑的可信性打动了马丁，但是克赖斯和汉密尔顿却对此充耳不闻，他们嘲笑诺顿是形而上学者，诺顿也同样以形而上学者的称号回击他们。他们用现象和本体的理念互相攻击。克赖斯和汉密尔顿攻击诺顿企图用意识本身去解释意识。诺顿则攻击他们俩玩弄文字游戏，思考时从词语到理论，而不是从实际到理论。这两人听到此处被吓了一跳。他们的推理模式的主要信条是从事实出发，再把事实冠以一些名词术语。 Idealism had never attracted Martin, but the exposition it now received at the hands of Norton was a revelation.The logical plausibility of it, that made an appeal to his intellect, seemed missed by Kreis and Hamilton, who sneered at Norton as a metaphysician, and who, in turn, sneered back at them as metaphysicians.Phenomenon and noumenon were bandied back and forth.They charged him with attempting to explain consciousness by itself.He charged them with word-jugglery, with reasoning from words to theory instead of from facts to theory.At this they were aghast.It was the cardinal tenet of their mode of reasoning to start with facts and to give names to the facts.
当诺顿一头扎入了康德的复杂世界中时，克赖斯提醒他德国所有的小哲学学派在消亡过后都转战到了牛津。过了一会儿，诺顿又提醒了他们汉密尔顿的俭省原则，他们随即声称他们的每一个推理过程都是顺应着这一规律来的。马丁抱着膝，沉浸在这热烈的氛围中。但是，诺顿并不是斯宾塞主义者，他也在试图理解马丁哲学的精髓，他在向两个对手说话的同时也尽量同马丁交谈着。 When Norton wandered into the intricacies of Kant, Kreis reminded him that all good little German philosophies when they died went to Oxford.A little later Norton reminded them of Hamilton’s Law of Parsimony, the application of which they immediately claimed for every reasoning process of theirs.And Martin hugged his knees and exulted in it all.But Norton was no Spencerian, and he, too, strove for Martin’s philosophic soul, talking as much at him as to his two opponents.
“你知道伯克利的问题谁也未曾回答出来。”他直面向马丁发难。“赫伯特•斯宾塞的回答最为接近，但仍然存在着不小的距离。即使斯宾塞最坚定的追随者也难于再进一步了。那天我读了萨里比的一篇论文，他所能说出的最好的话不过是：赫伯特•斯宾塞尽最大可能地回答了伯克利的问题。” “You know Berkeley has never been answered,” he said, looking directly at Martin.“Herbert Spencer came the nearest, which was not very near.Even the stanchest of Spencer’s followers will not go farther.I was reading an essay of Saleeby’s the other day, and the best Saleeby could say was that Herbert Spencer nearly succeeded in answering Berkeley.”
“你知道休谟怎么说的么？”汉密尔顿问道。 “You know what Hume said?” Hamilton asked.
诺顿点点头，但是汉密尔顿为了让大家明白，还是说了出来。“他说伯克利的观点虽然无可辩驳，但是却没有信服力。” Norton nodded, but Hamilton gave it for the benefit of the rest.“He said that Berkeley’s arguments admit of no answer and produce no conviction.”
“那是休谟的一家之见。”诺顿回答道。“休谟的想法和你的一模一样，唯一的区别是：他很聪明，承认了伯克利的问题是无法回答的。” “In his, Hume’s, mind,” was the reply.“And Hume’s mind was the same as yours, with this difference: he was wise enough to admit there was no answering Berkeley.”
尽管诺顿从不失去理智，却非常敏感且容易冲动，克赖斯和汉密尔顿则像一对冷血的野蛮人，寻找着他的弱点并反复攻击。夜色渐深，诺顿不断遭受着攻击，说他是个形而上学者。他怕自己会跳起来，紧紧地攥着椅子；他灰色的眼睛闪亮着，女孩般的面孔变得严厉而坚定，并对反方展开了一通大反击。 Norton was sensitive and excitable, though he never lost his head, while Kreis and Hamilton were like a pair of cold-blooded savages, seeking out tender places to prod and poke.As the evening grew late, Norton, smarting under the repeated charges of being a metaphysician, clutching his chair to keep from jumping to his feet, his gray eyes snapping and his girlish face grown harsh and sure, made a grand attack upon their position.
“好吧，你们这些海克尔主义者，就算我的推理像个行医者，可是，请问你们又是怎么推理的呢？”你们的论据毫无立足之地，你们总是用实证科学把毫无科学依据的教条推入它没有权利进入的地方。早在唯物一元论学派出现很久之前，你们的依据就已经被推翻了，所以现在毫无基础可言。推翻它的人是约翰·洛克。两百年前——甚至在更早以前，在他的论文《论人的理解》中，他就证实了没有与生俱来的意念。其中最精彩的部分正是你们所声称的。今晚你们一再声称没有与生俱来的意念。 “All right, you Haeckelites, I may reason like a medicine man, but, pray, how do you reason?You have nothing to stand on, you unscientific dogmatists with your positive science which you are always lugging about into places it has no right to be.Long before the school of materialistic monism arose, the ground was removed so that there could be no foundation.Locke was the man, John Locke.Two hundred years ago—more than that, even in his @Essay concerning the Human Understanding@, he proved the non-existence of innate ideas.The best of it is that that is precisely what you claim.To-night, again and again, you have asserted the non-existence of innate ideas.
“那是什么意思？它的意思是你永远无法知道终极的现实。你出生的时候脑子里空无一物。表象，或者说现象，是你的心灵从五种感官中所获得的所有内容。因此本体，是你出生时所没有的东西，是无法进入——” “And what does that mean?It means that you can never know ultimate reality.Your brains are empty when you are born.Appearances, or phenomena, are all the content your minds can receive from your five senses.Then noumena, which are not in your minds when you are born, have no way of getting in—”
“我反对——”克赖斯开始插嘴道。 “I deny—” Kreis started to interrupt.
“等我把话说完。”诺顿呵斥道。“你只不过知道力与物质的作用和两者的相互作用，因为它们以某种形式触动了你的感官。你看，如果仅是为了辩论，我愿意承认物质是存在的，因为我打算用你自己的论据来驳倒你。我没有别的办法来达到这个目的，因为你们俩都先天无法理解哲学的抽象性。” “You wait till I’m done,” Norton shouted.“You can know only that much of the play and interplay of force and matter as impinges in one way or another on our senses.You see, I am willing to admit, for the sake of the argument, that matter exists; and what I am about to do is to efface you by your own argument.I can’t do it any other way, for you are both congenitally unable to understand a philosophic abstraction.”
“那么，根据你们的实证科学，你们对于物质又作何理解呢？你们只能感知它的现象，它的表象。你们只知道它的变化，或者说是这些变化导致了你们意识的变化。实证科学只能解释现象，而你们却愚蠢到要去做本体论者，去研究本体。然而单从实证科学的定义出发，科学只关心现象。有人曾经说过，从现象得来的知识是无法超越现象的。” “And now, what do you know of matter, according to your own positive science?You know it only by its phenomena, its appearances.You are aware only of its changes, or of such changes in it as cause changes in your consciousness.Positive science deals only with phenomena, yet you are foolish enough to strive to be ontologists and to deal with noumena.Yet, by the very definition of positive science, science is concerned only with appearances.As somebody has said, phenomenal knowledge cannot transcend phenomena.”
“即使你们消灭了康德，你们也回答不了伯克利的问题。也许，必然地，在你们肯定科学证明了上帝并不存在，或者在几乎证明了物质存在的时候就已经认定伯克利错了。——你们知道我承认物质的现实性只是为了让你们能够理解我的观点。你们要是乐意，就做实证科学家去吧；但是本体论在实证科学中无立足之地，所以就别谈什么实证科学了。斯宾塞的怀疑主义是对的，但是如果斯宾塞——” “You cannot answer Berkeley, even if you have annihilated Kant, and yet, perforce, you assume that Berkeley is wrong when you affirm that science proves the non-existence of God, or, as much to the point, the existence of matter.—You know I granted the reality of matter only in order to make myself intelligible to your understanding.Be positive scientists, if you please; but ontology has no place in positive science, so leave it alone.Spencer is right in his agnosticism, but if Spencer—”
但是已经到了去赶最后一班渡轮回奥克兰的时候了。布里森登和马丁找空溜了出来，留下诺顿还侃侃而谈，而克赖斯和汉密尔顿则像两条猎犬一样，等他一说完就立刻扑上前去。 But it was time to catch the last ferry-boat for Oakland, and Brissenden and Martin slipped out, leaving Norton still talking and Kreis and Hamilton waiting to pounce on him like a pair of hounds as soon as he finished.
“你让我对神仙般的世界有了一瞥，”马丁在渡轮上说，“与那样的人见面使我的生活有了价值。我的头脑被完全调动起来了。之前我从未欣赏过唯心主义，尽管现在我仍然接受不了。我知道我永远是个现实主义者。估计我天生如此。但是我挺想回答克赖斯和汉密尔顿几句，也想对诺顿发表一些见解。我并不认为斯宾塞已经被打倒了。我激动得像个小孩第一次见到马戏团似的。看来我还得多读点书。我得看点萨里比的作品。我依然坚持斯宾塞是无懈可击的。下次我就要自己亲自上阵了。” “You have given me a glimpse of fairyland,” Martin said on the ferry-boat.“It makes life worthwhile to meet people like that.My mind is all worked up.I never appreciated idealism before.Yet I can’t accept it.I know that I shall always be a realist.I am so made, I guess.But I’d like to have made a reply to Kreis and Hamilton, and I think I’d have had a word or two for Norton.I didn’t see that Spencer was damaged any.I’m as excited as a child on its first visit to the circus.I see I must read up some more.I’m going to get hold of Saleeby.I still think Spencer is unassailable, and next time I’m going to take a hand myself.”
布里森登已经进入了梦乡。他艰难地呼吸着，下巴埋在围巾里，顶着他那凹陷的胸口，身子裹在长大衣里，随着渡船推进器的震动而摇晃着。 But Brissenden, breathing painfully, had dropped off to sleep, his chin buried in a scarf and resting on his sunken chest, his body wrapped in the long overcoat and shaking to the vibration of the propellers.
第三十七章 CHAPTER XXXVII
第二天早上，马丁做的第一件事恰恰与布里森登的建议和命令相违背。他把《太阳的耻辱》装好，寄给了《卫城》杂志。他相信自己能找到杂志发表文章。他觉得一旦作品得到杂志的认可，他本人就能吸引出版社。他也把《蜉蝣》用信封装好寄给了一家杂志社。尽管布里森登对杂志充满成见，马丁认为那是一种显而易见的偏执，并且认定那首伟大的诗歌会发表的。不过，他并不打算不经过对方同意就发表。他打算让一家高级杂志接受后，再以此努力与布里森登理论，并获得他的同意。 The first thing Martin did next morning was to go counter both to Brissenden’s advice and command. @The Shame of the Sun@ he wrapped and mailed to @The Acropolis@.He believed he could find magazine publication for it, and he felt that recognition by the magazines would commend him to the book-publishing houses.“Ephemera” he likewise wrapped and mailed to a magazine.Despite Brissenden’s prejudice against the magazines, which was a pronounced mania with him, Martin decided that the great poem should see print.He did not intend, however, to publish it without the other’s permission.His plan was to get it accepted by one of the high magazines, and, thus armed, again to wrestle with Brissenden for consent.
从那天早上起，马丁开始创作起另一篇小说，那小说早在几星期前就有了雏形，并不断喧闹着要他创作出来，一直令他心烦。显然这篇小说将是一个出彩的航海故事，充满了二十世纪的冒险主义和浪漫精神，描绘着真实世界里真实条件下的真实人物。但是跌宕起伏的故事之下还隐藏着另外的东西——一方面，肤浅的读者体会不到这些含义，另一方面却丝毫不会减少他们对作品的兴趣和喜爱。正是这些东西，而不仅仅是故事本身，促使马丁创作这篇小说。就此而言，总是那些伟大而普遍的主题给他提供情节灵感。找到了这样的主题后，他便开始揣摩设定独特的人物和独特的环境，以及用来表达那具有普遍意义的东西的时间和地点。他决定把这篇小说命名为《过期》，他相信这部小说将不会超过六万字——对于他旺盛的创作精力而言，这不过是小菜一碟。第一天，他为自己写作时的得心应手感到高兴。他不再担心自己尖锐锋利的棱角会溜出来毁坏作品了。经过长达数月的紧张实践和研究，他已经获得了回报。他现在已经能老练地专注于从事自己规划的事情的大方面了。他创作着，一个小时接一个小时。他前所未有地觉得自己对生命和生命中的事物有了无限确定的认识。《过期》所描写的故事对于它特有的角色和事件而言将会显得真实，但马丁有信心它也能描述出对于一切时代、一切海洋和一切生活都真实、伟大而重要的东西——这多亏了赫伯特·斯宾塞，他一边想着，一边把身子往桌子后靠了一会儿。是的，多亏了赫伯特·斯宾塞，是他把进化论这把生存的万能钥匙放到了马丁手中。 Martin began, that morning, a story which he had sketched out a number of weeks before and which ever since had been worrying him with its insistent clamor to be created.Apparently it was to be a rattling sea story, a tale of twentieth-century adventure and romance, handling real characters, in a real world, under real conditions.But beneath the swing and go of the story was to be something else—something that the superficial reader would never discern and which, on the other hand, would not diminish in any way the interest and enjoyment for such a reader.It was this, and not the mere story, that impelled Martin to write it.For that matter, it was always the great, universal motif that suggested plots to him.After having found such a motif, he cast about for the particular persons and particular location in time and space wherewith and wherein to utter the universal thing. @Overdue@ was the title he had decided for it, and its length he believed would not be more than sixty thousand words—a bagatelle for him with his splendid vigor of production.On this first day he took hold of it with conscious delight in the mastery of his tools.He no longer worried for fear that the sharp, cutting edges should slip and mar his work.The long months of intense application and study had brought their reward.He could now devote himself with sure hand to the larger phases of the thing he shaped; and as he worked, hour after hour, he felt, as never before, the sure and cosmic grasp with which he held life and the affairs of life. @Overdue@ would tell a story that would be true of its particular characters and its particular events; but it would tell, too, he was confident, great vital things that would be true of all time, and all sea, and all life—thanks to Herbert Spencer, he thought, leaning back for a moment from the table.Ay, thanks to Herbert Spencer and to the master-key of life, evolution, which Spencer had placed in his hands.
他意识到自己正在创作着伟大的作品。“它会成功的！它会成功的！”这句话不断地在他脑海中回响。 He was conscious that it was great stuff he was writing.“It will go!It will go!” was the refrain that kept, sounding in his ears.
它当然会成功。他终于要创作出各个杂志争先抢后想要的作品了。整个故事如闪电般在他眼前展现开来。他暂时放下这个念头，留足时间先在笔记本里写下了一段话。这段话后来成为了《过期》的最后一段。可整本书的构思已经在他的脑海里完成了，早在他写到结局的前几个星期，这部作品本身就已经在他脑中结尾了。他把最后尚未完成的故事与其他海洋作家的故事进行比较，觉得自己的故事比别人的不知要强过多少倍。“只有一个人能够与它媲美，”他大声地喃喃自语道，“那人就是康拉德。这书甚至能让康拉德吃惊，和我握手，并对我说：‘马丁，我的孩子，写得好！’” Of course it would go.At last he was turning out the thing at which the magazines would jump.The whole story worked out before him in lightning flashes.He broke off from it long enough to write a paragraph in his note-book.This would be the last paragraph in @Overdue@; but so thoroughly was the whole book already composed in his brain that he could write, weeks before he had arrived at the end, the end itself.He compared the tale, as yet unwritten, with the tales of the sea-writers, and he felt it to be immeasurably superior.“There’s only one man who could touch it,” he murmured aloud, “and that’s Conrad.And it ought to make even him sit up and shake hands with me, and say, ‘Well done, Martin, my boy.’”
他辛苦地写了一整天，最后一刻忽然想起还要去莫尔斯家参加晚宴。多亏了布里森登，他的黑色礼服才能从当铺里赎出来。现在他又有资格参加宴会了。进城之后，他跑进图书馆花了很长一些时间找到了萨里比的书籍。他找出那本《生命周期》，并在车上读起了诺顿提到的那篇批判斯宾塞的文章。马丁一边读着,一边忍不住怒从中来。他的脸变得通红，牙关紧咬，拳头不自觉地攥了起来，刚松开，又攥了起来，仿佛在紧捏着什么令人厌恶的东西，恨不得把它捏死。下车后，他就像一个怒汉一样在人行道上大踏步地走着，直到恶狠狠地按响了莫尔斯家的门铃时，他才猛然意识到自己的行为好笑，不禁莞尔，顿时心情好转，。但当他一进门，一股强大的抑郁感却突然笼罩了他。他一下子从高空跌落，而那天一整天他都乘着灵感的翅膀在高空中飞翔。“中产阶级者”、“市侩老巢”——布里森登极具讽刺意味的词语在他的脑海里一再闪现。但是那又怎样？他愤怒地责问道。他要娶的人是鲁思，不是她的家人。 He toiled on all day, recollecting, at the last moment, that he was to have dinner at the Morses’.Thanks to Brissenden, his black suit was out of pawn and he was again eligible for dinner parties.Down town he stopped off long enough to run into the library and search for Saleeby’s books.He drew out @The Cycle of Life@, and on the car turned to the essay Norton had mentioned on Spencer.As Martin read, he grew angry.His face flushed, his jaw set, and unconsciously his hand clenched, unclenched, and clenched again as if he were taking fresh grips upon some hateful thing out of which he was squeezing the life.When he left the car, he strode along the sidewalk as a wrathful man will stride, and he rang the Morse bell with such viciousness that it roused him to consciousness of his condition, so that he entered in good nature, smiling with amusement at himself.No sooner, however, was he inside than a great depression descended upon him.He fell from the height where he had been up-borne all day on the wings of inspiration.“Bourgeois,” “trader’s den”—Brissenden’s epithets repeated themselves in his mind.But what of that? he demanded angrily.He was marrying Ruth, not her family.
他仿佛觉得鲁思从没有这么美丽，这么超凡脱俗，这么空灵动人，同时又这么健康过。她两颊嫣红，双眼一次又一次地吸引着他的目光——那双眼睛让他第一次读到了永恒。最近他已经忘记了永恒，他读的科学著作把他带离了永恒。然而在这里，在鲁思的眼睛里，他读到了一种凌驾于一切言语论证之上的、无法用词汇表达的理论。他看见一切辩论都在她眼前仓皇而逃，因为他在那里看见了爱情。他自己的眼里也溢满了爱情，而爱情是不需要回答的。那就是他激情的信条。 It seemed to him that he had never seen Ruth more beautiful, more spiritual and ethereal and at the same time more healthy.There was color in her cheeks, and her eyes drew him again and again—the eyes in which he had first read immortality.He had forgotten immortality of late, and the trend of his scientific reading had been away from it; but here, in Ruth’s eyes, he read an argument without words that transcended all worded arguments.He saw that in her eyes before which all discussion fled away, for he saw love there.And in his own eyes was love; and love was unanswerable.Such was his passionate doctrine.
在进去用餐前与鲁思一同度过的半个小时里，他觉得无比幸福，对生活感到无比满足。然而一到餐桌上，一天的辛苦工作所带来的不可避免的反应和疲惫感却紧紧地左右着他。他意识到自己目光怠倦，心情烦躁不安。他还记得当初正是在这张桌子旁，他第一次与文明人一同用餐，当时还自以为那就是高雅、高尚的生活氛围。可现在他却对它嗤之以鼻，时常觉得十分无趣。他眼前浮现出了他当时那可悲的模样，那是很久以前的事了——一个忸怩的粗汉，在忧惧痛苦中浑身的毛孔都冒着汗，为餐桌上的繁文缛节弄得不知所措，受着如魔鬼一般的侍者的折磨，竭尽全力想要攀上这个让人头晕眼花的上层社会，到最后却决定坦诚地做自己，绝不卖弄风雅，不懂装懂。 The half hour he had with her, before they went in to dinner, left him supremely happy and supremely satisfied with life.Nevertheless, at table, the inevitable reaction and exhaustion consequent upon the hard day seized hold of him.He was aware that his eyes were tired and that he was irritable.He remembered it was at this table, at which he now sneered and was so often bored, that he had first eaten with civilized beings in what he had imagined was an atmosphere of high culture and refinement.He caught a glimpse of that pathetic figure of him, so long ago, a self-conscious savage, sprouting sweat at every pore in an agony of apprehension, puzzled by the bewildering minutiae of eating-implements, tortured by the ogre of a servant, striving at a leap to live at such dizzy social altitude, and deciding in the end to be frankly himself, pretending no knowledge and no polish he did not possess.
他瞥了鲁思一眼以寻求慰藉，正像个突然害怕沉船，急于寻找救生衣的乘客一样。是的，他已经有所收获了——他得到了爱情和鲁思。其他的一切都没有经受住书本的考验。但是鲁思和爱情却通过了考验，他还为此找到了生物学上的支持理论。爱情是生命最崇高的表达方式。为了爱情，大自然一直忙于设计着他，也忙着设计着所有正常的人。为了这一任务，大自然已经花了上万个世纪——咳，上十万乃至上百万个世纪——而他则是大自然的最佳杰作。大自然让爱情成为他生命中最强大的东西，赐予了他想象力，把爱情的力量无限放大，让他在短暂的一生里结伴、狂欢、融化。他的手在桌子底下摸索着身旁的鲁思的手，一股浓浓的暖意在两人的手上传递着。她匆匆看了他一眼，眼里洋溢着幸福和柔情。他的眼中也流露着一样的神情，一阵激动遍及全身。他还不知道鲁思眼中的幸福与柔情有多少是被她看见的他的眼神所唤起的。 He glanced at Ruth for reassurance, much in the same manner that a passenger, with sudden panic thought of possible shipwreck, will strive to locate the life preservers.Well, that much had come out of it—love and Ruth.All the rest had failed to stand the test of the books.But Ruth and love had stood the test; for them he found a biological sanction.Love was the most exalted expression of life.Nature had been busy designing him, as she had been busy with all normal men, for the purpose of loving.She had spent ten thousand centuries—ay, a hundred thousand and a million centuries—upon the task, and he was the best she could do.She had made love the strongest thing in him, increased its power a myriad per cent with her gift of imagination, and sent him forth into the ephemera to thrill and melt and mate.His hand sought Ruth’s hand beside him hidden by the table, and a warm pressure was given and received.She looked at him a swift instant, and her eyes were radiant and melting.So were his in the thrill that pervaded him; nor did he realize how much that was radiant and melting in her eyes had been aroused by what she had seen in his.
马丁的桌子斜对面，莫尔斯先生的右侧，坐着当地高级法院的布朗特法官。马丁见过他几面，却对他没什么好感。法官正和鲁思的父亲讨论工会政治、当地局势和社会主义。莫尔斯先生正企图就社会主义的问题挖苦马丁一番。布朗特法官终于带着父亲般的慈爱和怜悯望着对桌的马丁。马丁暗自好笑。 Across the table from him, cater-cornered, at Mr. Morse’s right, sat Judge Blount, a local superior court judge.Martin had met him a number of times and had failed to like him.He and Ruth’s father were discussing labor union politics, the local situation, and socialism, and Mr. Morse was endeavoring to twit Martin on the latter topic.At last Judge Blount looked across the table with benignant and fatherly pity.Martin smiled to himself.
“随着年岁的增长，你会抛弃它的，年青人。”他安慰地说。“对这类年轻时会犯的毛病，时间是最好的治愈方式。”他转向莫尔斯先生，说道：“我认为讨论对于这类毛病是没有用处的，讨论只会让病人坚持己见。” “You’ll grow out of it, young man,” he said soothingly.“Time is the best cure for such youthful distempers.”He turned to Mr. Morse.“I do not believe discussion is good in such cases.It makes the patient obstinate.”
“的确如此。”对方郑重地表示同意。“但是时不时地提醒一下病人他的病情也是有好处的。” “That is true,” the other assented gravely.“But it is well to warn the patient occasionally of his condition.”
马丁开心地笑了，但却是强颜欢笑。那天太漫长、太难熬了，他的反应都令他觉得加倍痛苦。 Martin laughed merrily, but it was with an effort.The day had been too long, the day’s effort too intense, and he was deep in the throes of the reaction.
“毫无疑问您两位都是出色的医生，”他说，“但是如果你们愿意听听病人的意见，那么就让他来告诉你们，你们都是不称职的诊断者。事实上，你们自己倒是患上了你们自认为在我身上看到的病症。至于我，我倒是免疫的。你们血管里涌动着的半吊子社会主义哲学于我毫无用处。” “Undoubtedly you are both excellent doctors,” he said; “but if you care a whit for the opinion of the patient, let him tell you that you are poor diagnosticians.In fact, you are both suffering from the disease you think you find in me.As for me, I am immune.The socialist philosophy that riots half-baked in your veins has passed me by.”
“高明，高明。”法官喃喃自语道。“绝妙的辩论妙计，这就叫反客为主。” “Clever, clever,” murmured the judge.“An excellent ruse in controversy, to reverse positions.”
“这可是从你那儿学来的。”马丁的眼里冒着火，却按捺住自己的情绪。“你知道，法官，我听过你的竞选演讲。你以某种‘憨匿’的过程——顺带说一句，‘憨匿’是我自己喜欢的一种说法，别人是听不明白的——你以某种憨匿的过程说服自己相信你是赞同竞争制度和强者生存法则的，但同时你却使用权力并竭尽所能批准各种剥夺强者力量的措施。” “Out of your mouth.”Martin’s eyes were sparkling, but he kept control of himself.“You see, Judge, I’ve heard your campaign speeches.By some henidical process—henidical, by the way is a favorite word of mine which nobody understands—by some henidical process you persuade yourself that you believe in the competitive system and the survival of the strong, and at the same time you indorse with might and main all sorts of measures to shear the strength from the strong.”
“我的年轻人——” “My young man—”
“记住，我听过你的竞选演讲。”马丁警告道。“那可都是有记录的。你对州际贸易规章、铁路信托规章、标准石油规章和保护森林资源的立场，以及你对无数种限制措施所采取的立场，无一不是社会主义性质的表现。” “Remember, I’ve heard your campaign speeches,” Martin warned.“It’s on record, your position on interstate commerce regulation, on regulation of the railway trust and Standard Oil, on the conservation of the forests, on a thousand and one restrictive measures that are nothing else than socialistic.”
“你是在告诉我你并不赞成限制这种种肆无忌惮的权力滥用么？” “Do you mean to tell me that you do not believe in regulating these various outrageous exercises of power?”
“这不是问题的关键。我想告诉你，你是一个糟糕的诊断者。我想告诉你，我并没有受到社会主义细菌的感染。我想告诉你，是你自己正在遭到社会主义细菌的削弱和糟蹋。而我呢，我从骨子里就对社会主义深恶痛绝，正如我对你们那杂交的民主也恨之入骨一样——你们的民主不过是在某些字眼的掩盖下如假面舞会一般的伪社会主义，是经不起字典检验的。” “That’s not the point.I mean to tell you that you are a poor diagnostician.I mean to tell you that I am not suffering from the microbe of socialism.I mean to tell you that it is you who are suffering from the emasculating ravages of that same microbe.As for me, I am an inveterate opponent of socialism just as I am an inveterate opponent of your own mongrel democracy that is nothing else than pseudo-socialism masquerading under a garb of words that will not stand the test of the dictionary.”
“我是个反动分子，一个彻头彻尾的反动分子。你们生活在一种被谎言的面纱笼罩着的社会组织中，你们不够敏锐，无法看透那层面纱的笼罩，因此你们难以理解我的立场。你们假装相信强者生存、强者统治的理论。而我是实实在在地相信。这就是我们之间的区别。我还是个无足轻重的青年时——也就是几个月之前——我也曾相信过同样的理论。你看，你和你们的主张曾经让我印象深刻。但是，生意人顶多是没有魄力的统治者，只知道一天到晚在谋取钱财的食槽里哼哼唧唧，拱来拱去。可是不好意思，我已经掉转头去相信贵族统治了。我是这屋子里唯一一个个人主义者。我对国家不抱希望，只希望那骑在马背之上的强者能够把国家从腐朽无能的统治中拯救出来。” “I am a reactionary—so complete a reactionary that my position is incomprehensible to you who live in a veiled lie of social organization and whose sight is not keen enough to pierce the veil.You make believe that you believe in the survival of the strong and the rule of the strong.I believe.That is the difference.When I was a trifle younger,—a few months younger,—I believed the same thing.You see, the ideas of you and yours had impressed me.But merchants and traders are cowardly rulers at best; they grunt and grub all their days in the trough of money-getting, and I have swung back to aristocracy, if you please.I am the only individualist in this room.I look to the state for nothing.I look only to the strong man, the man on horseback, to save the state from its own rotten futility.”
“尼采是正确的，我不愿意浪费时间来跟你们解释尼采是谁，但是他是正确的。世界属于强者——属于高贵的人，属于不在赚钱发财的猪槽里打滚的人。世界属于真正的贵族，属于金发碧眼的伟大野兽，属于从不妥协的人，属于真正有有决断力的人。他们会将你们这些社会主义者——这些害怕社会主义，自以为是个人主义的社会主义者——吃得精光。你们那卑贱底下的奴性道德永远也拯救不了你们——啊，这些对于你们而言都太高深难懂了，我知道，我也不想再用这些来烦你们了。但是你们要记住一件事，在奥克兰，个人主义者还不到半打，可是马丁•伊登却是其中一个。” “Nietzsche was right.I won’t take the time to tell you who Nietzsche was, but he was right.The world belongs to the strong—to the strong who are noble as well and who do not wallow in the swine-trough of trade and exchange.The world belongs to the true nobleman, to the great blond beasts, to the noncompromisers, to the ‘yes-sayers.’And they will eat you up, you socialists—who are afraid of socialism and who think yourselves individualists.Your slave-morality of the meek and lowly will never save you.—Oh, it’s all Greek, I know, and I won’t bother you any more with it.But remember one thing.There aren’t half a dozen individualists in Oakland, but Martin Eden is one of them.”
他做出个说话完毕的姿势，然后转向鲁思。 He signified that he was done with the discussion, and turned to Ruth.
“我今天有点激动，”他低声说，“我现在心中所想只是爱情，不是说话。” “I’m wrought up to-day,” he said in an undertone.“All I want to do is to love, not talk.”
莫尔斯先生开口说话了，他却没有听。 He ignored Mr. Morse, who said:—
“我可没有被你说服。所有的社会主义者都是阴谋家。那就是鉴别他们的方法。” “I am unconvinced.All socialists are Jesuits.That is the way to tell them.”
“我们还是可以把你变成个优秀的共和党人的。”布朗特法官说。 “We’ll make a good Republican out of you yet,” said Judge Blount.
“在那之前，马背上的英雄就会到来的。”马丁心平气和地反击道，又转身和鲁思说话去了。 “The man on horseback will arrive before that time,” Martin retorted with good humor, and returned to Ruth.
但是莫尔斯先生并不满意。他不喜欢这未来的女婿，既懒惰又不愿意正经地找个正当工作。他看不起他的思想，也不理解他的天性。于是他把话题转向了赫伯特•斯宾塞。布朗特法官给予了他有力的支持。马丁一听见那位哲学家的名字，就立刻把耳朵竖了起来。只听法官一本正经志满意得地对斯宾塞进行了抨击。莫尔斯先生时不时地朝马丁瞟上几眼，仿佛在说：“孩子，你听听。” But Mr. Morse was not content.He did not like the laziness and the disinclination for sober, legitimate work of this prospective son-in-law of his, for whose ideas he had no respect and of whose nature he had no understanding.So he turned the conversation to Herbert Spencer.Judge Blount ably seconded him, and Martin, whose ears had pricked at the first mention of the philosopher’s name, listened to the judge enunciate a grave and complacent diatribe against Spencer.From time to time Mr. Morse glanced at Martin, as much as to say, “There, my boy, you see.”
“乌鸦嘴。”马丁低声说了一句，继续和鲁思与阿瑟谈话去了。 “Chattering daws,” Martin muttered under his breath, and went on talking with Ruth and Arthur.
但是那漫长的一天和整晚与“真正的贫民”的谈话让他的心情难以平静。而且，他在车上读到的那些让他生气的东西还在他心里燃烧着。 But the long day and the “real dirt” of the night before were telling upon him; and, besides, still in his burnt mind was what had made him angry when he read it on the car.
“你怎么了？”鲁思注意到他难以抑制自己的怒火，突然间问道。 “What is the matter?” Ruth asked suddenly alarmed by the effort he was making to contain himself.
“世上没有上帝，只有不可知之物，而赫伯特•斯宾塞就是它的先知。”布朗特法官这时正说着。 “There is no god but the Unknowable, and Herbert Spencer is its prophet,” Judge Blount was saying at that moment.
马丁立刻转向他。 Martin turned upon him.
