“不值钱的论断。”他冷冷地说道。“我第一次是在市政厅公园里听到这话，说话的是一个工人，我倒觉得他对这话的理解更深刻一点。从那以后，我多次听见过这话，每次那讨好卖乖的劲儿都令我作呕。你该为自己感到惭愧。从你的嘴里听到那高贵的伟人的名字简直就像一颗露珠掉落到了脏水池子里。你真叫人恶心。” “A cheap judgment,” he remarked quietly.“I heard it first in the City Hall Park, on the lips of a workingman who ought to have known better.I have heard it often since, and each time the clap-trap of it nauseates me.You ought to be ashamed of yourself.To hear that great and noble man’s name upon your lips is like finding a dew-drop in a cesspool.You are disgusting.”
这话简直就像是晴天霹雳。布朗特法官用一脸中了风似的表情瞪着他，屋子里鸦雀无声。莫尔斯先生满心窃喜。他看出他的女儿受惊了。这正是他一心想要的——把这个他所不喜欢的人内在的暴徒之气给引出来。 It was like a thunderbolt.Judge Blount glared at him with apoplectic countenance, and silence reigned.Mr. Morse was secretly pleased.He could see that his daughter was shocked.It was what he wanted to do—to bring out the innate ruffianism of this man he did not like.
鲁思的手在桌子底下恳求似地寻找着马丁的手，但是马丁已经热血沸腾了。这些身居高位者虚假作态的学者气令马丁怒火中烧。这可是高等法院的法官啊！不过是几年之前，他还在泥沼之中仰望这些光辉人物，甚至视若神灵。 Ruth’s hand sought Martin’s beseechingly under the table, but his blood was up.He was inflamed by the intellectual pretence and fraud of those who sat in the high places.A Superior Court Judge!It was only several years before that he had looked up from the mire at such glorious entities and deemed them gods.
布朗特法官镇定下来，试图继续说下去。他对马丁装出一副彬彬有礼的样子，而马丁清楚这是因为在座的太太小姐们缘故。这更让他愤怒了。难道世界上就没有诚实可言了么？ Judge Blount recovered himself and attempted to go on, addressing himself to Martin with an assumption of politeness that the latter understood was for the benefit of the ladies.Even this added to his anger.Was there no honesty in the world?
“你不能和我谈论斯宾塞。”他喊叫着。“你对斯宾塞的理解还比不上他的英国同胞。不过我知道，这并不是你的错。这只是表现了这个时代可鄙的无知。我今晚在来的路上就遇到了一个这样的例子。我读到了一篇萨里比写的关于斯宾塞的文章。你应该读一读。所有人都能弄到这本书。任何一个书店都能买到，公共图书馆也可以借到。和萨里比在这个问题上搜集的材料相比，你应该为自己表现出的对那位高贵的人的无知和诋毁感到羞愧。这可是创纪录的可耻，足以叫你的过往的可耻相形见绌。” “You can’t discuss Spencer with me,” he cried.“You do not know any more about Spencer than do his own countrymen.But it is no fault of yours, I grant.It is just a phase of the contemptible ignorance of the times.I ran across a sample of it on my way here this evening.I was reading an essay by Saleeby on Spencer.You should read it.It is accessible to all men.You can buy it in any book-store or draw it from the public library.You would feel ashamed of your paucity of abuse and ignorance of that noble man compared with what Saleeby has collected on the subject.It is a record of shame that would shame your shame.”
“一个连污染他呼吸过的空气都不配的学究式哲学家说过‘他是一知半解型的哲学家。’我认为你连斯宾塞的书都没读到十页。可是就有这么些个批评家，应该比你有学识，可是读过的斯宾塞比你还少，却公开挑战斯宾塞的信徒们，要他们从他所有的作品中挑出一条他的思想来——从斯宾塞的作品里找他的思想！这可是在整个科学研究界和现代思想界打下了自己烙印的天才赫伯特•斯宾塞。他是心理学之父；他掀起了教育学的革命，因此法国农民的孩子们才得以按照斯宾塞制定的准则接受读写算的教育。那些渺小如蚊蚋的人类蚕食着他的理论应用到从技术上而获得的黄油面包，却叮咬着他死后的名声。他们大脑里仅存的那一点点有价值的东西主要还是靠斯宾塞得来的。毫无疑问，要是没有斯宾塞，他们的大多数正确的知识都会不存在，而那点知识还是鹦鹉学舌般得来的。” “‘The philosopher of the half-educated,’ he was called by an academic Philosopher who was not worthy to pollute the atmosphere he breathed.I don’t think you have read ten pages of Spencer, but there have been critics, assumably more intelligent than you, who have read no more than you of Spencer, who publicly challenged his followers to adduce one single idea from all his writings—from Herbert Spencer’s writings, the man who has impressed the stamp of his genius over the whole field of scientific research and modern thought;the father of psychology; the man who revolutionized pedagogy, so that to-day the child of the French peasant is taught the three R’s according to principles laid down by him.And the little gnats of men sting his memory when they get their very bread and butter from the technical application of his ideas.What little of worth resides in their brains is largely due to him.It is certain that had he never lived, most of what is correct in their parrot-learned knowledge would be absent.”
可是像牛津大学费尔班克斯校长那样的人——他的地位比你还高，布朗特法官——竟然说后世的人会把斯宾塞抛到一边，只把他看作诗人，梦想家，而不是思想家。他们都是一帮胡言乱语没有头脑的蠢货！他们中有人说《第一原则》并非完全没有文学魅力。还有人说斯宾塞是个勤奋的实干家而不是具有独创性的思想家。统统都是胡说八道！统统都是胡说八道！” “And yet a man like Principal Fairbanks of Oxford—a man who sits in an even higher place than you, Judge Blount—has said that Spencer will be dismissed by posterity as a poet and dreamer rather than a thinker.Yappers and blatherskites, the whole brood of them! @First Principles@ is not wholly destitute of a certain literary power,’ said one of them.And others of them have said that he was an industrious plodder rather than an original thinker.Yappers and blatherskites!Yappers and blatherskites!”
在一片死寂中，马丁突然住了口。鲁思全家都把布朗特法官视作地位显赫、有权有势的大官，马丁这番大放厥词把他们都吓坏了。接下来的晚宴如同葬礼一般。法官和莫尔斯先生把对话限制在了彼此之间，其他的对话也都断断续续的。过了一会儿，当鲁思和马丁独处的时候，两人便吵了起来。 Martin ceased abruptly, in a dead silence.Everybody in Ruth’s family looked up to Judge Blount as a man of power and achievement, and they were horrified at Martin’s outbreak.The remainder of the dinner passed like a funeral, the judge and Mr. Morse confining their talk to each other, and the rest of the conversation being extremely desultory.Then afterward, when Ruth and Martin were alone, there was a scene.
“你简直叫人难以忍受！”她哭了。 “You are unbearable,” she wept.
但是他余怒未消，不停地喃喃自语：“畜生！畜生！” But his anger still smouldered, and he kept muttering, “The beasts!The beasts!”
她指责他侮辱了法官，他立刻反驳道： When she averred he had insulted the judge, he retorted:—
“就因为我说出了他的真实面貌？” “By telling the truth about him?”
“我不管他真不真，”她坚持道，“礼貌分寸总得讲的，你没有特权侮辱任何人。” “I don’t care whether it was true or not,” she insisted.“There are certain bounds of decency, and you had no license to insult anybody.”
“那布朗特法官又有什么特权侮辱真理呢？”马丁质问道。“侮辱真理自然比侮辱一个像法官这样的小人要严重的多。他的行为甚于不礼貌。他诽谤了一个已经逝去的高贵而伟大的人物。啊，畜生！畜生！” “Then where did Judge Blount get the license to assault truth?” Martin demanded.“Surely to assault truth is a more serious misdemeanor than to insult a pygmy personality such as the judge’s.He did worse than that.He blackened the name of a great, noble man who is dead.Oh, the beasts!The beasts!”
那团怒火又在他心中燃烧起来，鲁思感到害怕不已。她从未见过他如此生气，那脾气来得那么莫名其妙，那么不可理喻，她简直无法理解。然而，在她的恐惧之中，还有着不可遏制被他的魅力深深吸引着的感情，那感情过去吸引着她，现在依然吸引着她——逼着她向他倒去，在疯狂的高潮时刻伸出她的手搂住了他的脖子。那天晚上发生的事伤害了她，冒犯了她，可是她还是在他低喃着“畜生!畜生！”的时候在他的怀里发抖。当她仍在他的怀里时，他说：“我再也不会到你家里的饭桌上来惹麻烦了，亲爱的。他们不喜欢我，我也不应该出现去惹他们讨厌。而且他们也同样令我生厌。呸！这些人真叫人恶心。想想看，我竟然曾经天真地做过梦，以为这些身居高位、住在豪宅、受过教育、有着银行存款的人都是高贵的人。” His complex anger flamed afresh, and Ruth was in terror of him.Never had she seen him so angry, and it was all mystified and unreasonable to her comprehension.And yet, through her very terror ran the fibres of fascination that had drawn and that still drew her to him—that had compelled her to lean towards him, and, in that mad, culminating moment, lay her hands upon his neck.She was hurt and outraged by what had taken place, and yet she lay in his arms and quivered while he went on muttering, “The beasts!The beasts!”And she still lay there when he said: “I’ll not bother your table again, dear.They do not like me, and it is wrong of me to thrust my objectionable presence upon them.Besides, they are just as objectionable to me.Faugh!They are sickening.And to think of it, I dreamed in my innocence that the persons who sat in the high places, who lived in fine houses and had educations and bank accounts, were worth while!”
第三十八章 CHAPTER XXXVIII
“来，我们到地方分会去。” “Come on, let’s go down to the local.”
布里森登如是说。他半小时前才吐了血，现在还处在眩晕中——这已经是他三天里第二次吐血了。他手上依旧握着威士忌酒杯，手指颤抖着将杯里的酒一饮而尽。 So spoke Brissenden, faint from a hemorrhage of half an hour before—the second hemorrhage in three days.The perennial whiskey glass was in his hands, and he drained it with shaking fingers.
“我要社会主义有何用？”马丁问道。 “What do I want with socialism?” Martin demanded.
“非党员可以演讲五分钟，”病怏怏的布里森登怂恿着他，“上去发表一番吧。告诉他们为什么你不需要社会主义。告诉他们你对他们以及他们的贫民窟道德的看法。拿尼采抨击他们，让他们为此与你争辩。粉碎他们。这会对他们有好处。他们需要辩论，你也一样。你瞧，我倒希望能在死之前看见你成为社会主义者。那将是你活下去的理由。社会主义正是你未来失望之时能拯救你的东西。” “Outsiders are allowed five-minute speeches,” the sick man urged.“Get up and spout.Tell them why you don’t want socialism.Tell them what you think about them and their ghetto ethics.Slam Nietzsche into them and get walloped for your pains.Make a scrap of it.It will do them good.Discussion is what they want, and what you want, too.You see, I’d like to see you a socialist before I’m gone.It will give you a sanction for your existence.It is the one thing that will save you in the time of disappointment that is coming to you.”
“我怎么也想不通你竟然会是个社会主义者。”马丁深思着。“你厌恶草莽之众。当然，这群愚民那里没有什么能打动你那充满审美意识的灵魂。”布里森登正在斟另一杯酒，马丁伸出一根手指头指着酒杯指责道。“社会主义似乎没办法救你的命。” “I never can puzzle out why you, of all men, are a socialist,” Martin pondered.“You detest the crowd so.Surely there is nothing in the canaille to recommend it to your aesthetic soul.”He pointed an accusing finger at the whiskey glass which the other was refilling.“Socialism doesn’t seem to save you.”
“我已经病入膏肓，”他答道，“可对你来说这不一样。你还身体强壮，还有许多值得活下去的东西，所以无论如何你必须和生活铐在一起。至于我，你不明白我为什么是个社会主义者。让我来告诉你吧。因为社会主义是不可避免的；因为现行的腐朽的、不合理的制度是不能长久的；因为你那马背上的人也已经不合时宜了。奴隶们不会支持该理论的。他们人数众多，不管他们愿不愿意，早在你的骑士跨上马背之前就已经被他们拉下马来了。你摆脱不了他们，只能忍受一整套的奴隶道德。我承认，这种混乱算不上好事。但是一切都已在酝酿中，你只能把它强咽下去。无论如何，你的尼采思想早已过时了。过去的已经过去，谁还说历史会重演谁就是骗子。当然了，我不喜欢乌合之众，但是像我这样的可怜人又能如何？马背上的英雄已经不存在了，可无论谁来统治都比现在这些胆小的猪猡的统治强。好吧，不管怎样。我已经有点晕得撑不住了，要是再坐下去，怕是要醉倒了。你也知道的，医生说过——该死的医生！我还要逗逗他。” “I’m very sick,” was the answer.“With you it is different.You have health and much to live for, and you must be handcuffed to life somehow.As for me, you wonder why I am a socialist.I’ll tell you.It is because Socialism is inevitable; because the present rotten and irrational system cannot endure; because the day is past for your man on horseback.The slaves won’t stand for it.They are too many, and willy-nilly they’ll drag down the would-be equestrian before ever he gets astride.You can’t get away from them, and you’ll have to swallow the whole slave-morality.It’s not a nice mess, I’ll allow.But it’s been a-brewing and swallow it you must.You are antediluvian anyway, with your Nietzsche ideas.The past is past, and the man who says history repeats itself is a liar.Of course I don’t like the crowd, but what’s a poor chap to do?We can’t have the man on horseback, and anything is preferable to the timid swine that now rule.But come on, anyway.I’m loaded to the guards now, and if I sit here any longer, I’ll get drunk.And you know the doctor says—damn the doctor!I’ll fool him yet.”
那是周日晚上，他们发现小厅里挤满了奥克兰的社会主义者，大都是劳动阶级的成员。讲话者是个聪明的犹太人，赢得了马丁的钦佩，同时也引起了他的敌意。那人塌陷下去的窄小的肩膀和萎缩的胸膛都表明了他的确是在拥挤的贫民窟中长大的。他让马丁有个强烈的印象：尽管羸弱困苦的奴隶们为反对那一小撮颐指气使的统治者进行了多年的斗争，却还是要受他们的统治，直到世界末日。马丁认为这个萎缩的小个子生灵是一种象征。 他是这整个悲惨的、懦弱无能的群体的突出代表，按照生物学的规律，他们将在生命逼仄破碎的境地里自生自灭。他们不是“适者”。尽管他们有着狡猾的哲学和蚂蚁般善于合作的天性，但是大自然为了优选之民而放弃了他们。大自然在她丰盈的手培育出的万物众生中只选拔出最优秀的那些。人类也用和大自然一样的方式在培养跑马和黄瓜。毋庸置疑，宇宙的创造者本可设计出更好的方法，但是这个特定宇宙里的生物只能忍受这个特定的方式。当然，他们在被消灭的时候可以蠕动挣扎，正如社会主义者们在蠕动挣扎一样。台上的那个发言人和正汗流浃背的人群即使在现在也在挣扎，他们聚在一起商量着新的办法以减少生活的刑罚，战胜宇宙适者生存的法则。 It was Sunday night, and they found the small hall packed by the Oakland socialists, chiefly members of the working class.The speaker, a clever Jew, won Martin’s admiration at the same time that he aroused his antagonism.The man’s stooped and narrow shoulders and weazened chest proclaimed him the true child of the crowded ghetto, and strong on Martin was the age-long struggle of the feeble, wretched slaves against the lordly handful of men who had ruled over them and would rule over them to the end of time.To Martin this withered wisp of a creature was a symbol.He was the figure that stood forth representative of the whole miserable mass of weaklings and inefficients who perished according to biological law on the ragged confines of life.They were the unfit.In spite of their cunning philosophy and of their antlike proclivities for cooperation, Nature rejected them for the exceptional man.Out of the plentiful spawn of life she flung from her prolific hand she selected only the best.It was by the same method that men, aping her, bred race-horses and cucumbers.Doubtless, a creator of a Cosmos could have devised a better method; but creatures of this particular Cosmos must put up with this particular method.Of course, they could squirm as they perished, as the socialists squirmed, as the speaker on the platform and the perspiring crowd were squirming even now as they counselled together for some new device with which to minimize the penalties of living and outwit the Cosmos.
马丁就这样想着。当布里森登劝他去教训他们一顿的时候，他上台也如此讲了。他服从指令，按照习惯走上讲台，向主席致了意。开始时他的声音低沉而犹豫，把他在听犹太人讲话时在他脑子里萌生的想法整理了一下。这种会议只给每个发言人五分钟时间，但是当马丁的五分钟用完时，他讲的正起劲，对他们教义的攻击也才讲了到一半。但是他的讲话引起了大家的兴趣，听众们纷纷鼓掌要求主席延长马丁的讲话时间。他们欣赏他，认为他是个值得用智慧的头脑去对待的敌手，于是听得非常仔细，一字不落。马丁的演讲感情炽烈，信心满满，他毫无保留地攻击了奴隶们和他们的道德以及战略，直言不讳地向他的听众暗示他们就是那些奴隶。他援引了斯宾塞和马尔萨斯的话，阐述了生物发展的法则。 So Martin thought, and so he spoke when Brissenden urged him to give them hell.He obeyed the mandate, walking up to the platform, as was the custom, and addressing the chairman.He began in a low voice, haltingly, forming into order the ideas which had surged in his brain while the Jew was speaking.In such meetings five minutes was the time allotted to each speaker; but when Martin’s five minutes were up, he was in full stride, his attack upon their doctrines but half completed.He had caught their interest, and the audience urged the chairman by acclamation to extend Martin’s time.They appreciated him as a foeman worthy of their intellect, and they listened intently, following every word.He spoke with fire and conviction, mincing no words in his attack upon the slaves and their morality and tactics and frankly alluding to his hearers as the slaves in question.He quoted Spencer and Malthus, and enunciated the biological law of development.
“因此，”他迅速总结道，“没有任何奴隶性的国家是能长久的。古老的发展观仍然奏效。正如我之前指出的，在生存竞争中，强者和他们的后代更适于生存，而弱者和他们的后代则要被粉碎，注定会消灭。其结果是，强者和他们的后代生存了下来，只要斗争仍在继续，他们的力量会一代比一代更强大。这就是发展。可是你们这些奴隶——我承认身为奴隶是很悲惨的——你们这些奴隶梦想着一个发展法则被消灭，弱者和无能者却不会被消灭的社会，那里每个无能的人每天想吃多少顿就能吃上多少顿；他们都能结婚，养育后代——强者弱者都是如此。结果将会怎样？人的力量和生命的价值不是一代一代地增加。相反，倒是一代一代地削弱了。这就是复仇女神带给你们的奴隶哲学的报应。你们那奴隶治、奴隶有、奴隶享的社会必然会随着构成它的生命的削弱和溃散而垮掉的。 “And so,” he concluded, in a swift résumé, “no state composed of the slave-types can endure.The old law of development still holds.In the struggle for existence, as I have shown, the strong and the progeny of the strong tend to survive, while the weak and the progeny of the weak are crushed and tend to perish.The result is that the strong and the progeny of the strong survive, and, so long as the struggle obtains, the strength of each generation increases.That is development.But you slaves—it is too bad to be slaves, I grant—but you slaves dream of a society where the law of development will be annulled, where no weaklings and inefficients will perish, where every inefficient will have as much as he wants to eat as many times a day as he desires, and where all will marry and have progeny—the weak as well as the strong.What will be the result?No longer will the strength and life-value of each generation increase.On the contrary, it will diminish.There is the Nemesis of your slave philosophy.Your society of slaves—of, by, and for, slaves—must inevitably weaken and go to pieces as the life which composes it weakens and goes to pieces.
记住，我阐述的是生物科学，而不是伤感的伦理道德。没有一个奴隶的社会能够经得起——” “Remember, I am enunciating biology and not sentimental ethics.No state of slaves can stand—”
“那么美国会怎样呢？”听众里有人叫了起来。 “How about the United States?” a man yelled from the audience.
“它会怎么样？”马丁反驳，“当年的十三个殖民地推翻了他们的统治者，建立了一个所谓的北美共和国。奴隶成了自己的主人。再也没有手握利剑的奴隶主了。但是没有某种意义上的主人你们过不下去，于是出现了一批新的主人——不是那种伟大的、精力充沛的、高贵的人，而是像蜘蛛一样精明的生意人和放债人。他们重新奴役了你们——可是并不是坦率地奴役，像那些真诚的、高贵的人那样用他们坚实的高尚力量，而是像蜘蛛一样用阴谋、谎言和甜言蜜语阴险地统治你们。他们收买你们的奴隶法官，使你们的奴隶法制腐化，用比最残忍的奴役还可怕的方式对待你们的奴隶子女。在美国的今天，有两百万的你们的子女在这种生意人的寡头垄断专制之下做苦力。有一千万的人缺吃少住，过着贫困的生活。” “And how about it?” Martin retorted.“The thirteen colonies threw off their rulers and formed the Republic so-called.The slaves were their own masters.There were no more masters of the sword.But you couldn’t get along without masters of some sort, and there arose a new set of masters—not the great, virile, noble men, but the shrewd and spidery traders and money-lenders.And they enslaved you over again—but not frankly, as the true, noble men would do with weight of their own right arms, but secretly, by spidery machinations and by wheedling and cajolery and lies.They have purchased your slave judges, they have debauched your slave legislatures, and they have forced to worse horrors than chattel slavery your slave boys and girls.Two million of your children are toiling to-day in this trader-oligarchy of the United States.Ten millions of you slaves are not properly sheltered nor properly fed.”
“不过话说回来。我已经说过奴隶社会是不能长久的。因为就其本质而言，这样的社会必须消灭发展规律。奴隶社会一旦开始组建，就会立刻蜕变。你们谈论起消灭发展规律倒是很容易，但是让你们保留自己力量的新发展规律又在哪里？提出来。已经提出来了么？那就说说看呀。” “But to return.I have shown that no society of slaves can endure, because, in its very nature, such society must annul the law of development.No sooner can a slave society be organized than deterioration sets in.It is easy for you to talk of annulling the law of development, but where is the new law of development that will maintain your strength?Formulate it.Is it already formulated?Then state it.”
马丁在一片吵吵嚷嚷中回到了座位。一二十个人纷纷站着起来，嚷着要求主席同意他们发言。他们都受到喧闹的鼓掌声的鼓励，演讲的时候无不带着火焰般的热情，手舞足蹈，回答了对他们的攻击。这是一个疯狂的夜晚——但是是智力的疯狂，是思想的交锋。有些人偏离了话题，但是大多数的发言者直接反击了马丁的观点。他们用一些他从未听过的思路震撼了他，启发了他。他们并没有提出什么新的生物学规律，但却提出了从新的角度运用旧的规律。他们谈得如此激烈以致常常不够礼貌，主席不止一次要敲击桌子以维持秩序。 Martin took his seat amidst an uproar of voices.A score of men were on their feet clamoring for recognition from the chair.And one by one, encouraged by vociferous applause, speaking with fire and enthusiasm and excited gestures, they replied to the attack.It was a wild night—but it was wild intellectually, a battle of ideas.Some strayed from the point, but most of the speakers replied directly to Martin.They shook him with lines of thought that were new to him; and gave him insights, not into new biological laws, but into new applications of the old laws.They were too earnest to be always polite, and more than once the chairman rapped and pounded for order.
碰巧那天晚上在听众中坐了一个不懂规矩的新手记者。他是在那到处是新闻的日子里被派来的，一心一意只想搞到具有轰动性的新闻。他是个不大能干的新手记者。他只知道捡便宜和信口开河。他没有思想，听不懂他们的讨论。事实上，他还有一种高人一大等的自得感，觉得自己比这些满嘴胡言的工人阶级疯子要高尚得多。而且，他对那些身居高位并掌控着国家政策和报纸喉舌的人非常钦佩。另外，他还有一个理想，即出人头地，当个完美的记者，哪怕无中生有也要弄出点名堂——甚至是大名堂。 It chanced that a cub reporter sat in the audience, detailed there on a day dull of news and impressed by the urgent need of journalism for sensation.He was not a bright cub reporter.He was merely facile and glib.He was too dense to follow the discussion.In fact, he had a comfortable feeling that he was vastly superior to these wordy maniacs of the working class.Also, he had a great respect for those who sat in the high places and dictated the policies of nations and newspapers.Further, he had an ideal, namely, of achieving that excellence of the perfect reporter who is able to make something—even a great deal—out of nothing.
他不懂得这场谈话的意义。他也没必要懂得。革命这类字眼已经给了他线索。就像一个古生物学家能凭借一块骨骼化石建造出一副完整的骨架一样，他也能够仅凭革命这一个词就构思出整个发言。那天晚上他就是那样做的，且干得很漂亮。由于马丁的发言最轰动，他便把所有的话都写进了马丁的嘴里，把他写成了那场大辩论中的无政府主义元凶，把他反动的个人主义改造成了最阴险的红色社会主义的宣泄。这个新人记者是个艺术家，他大笔一挥，添加了些地方色彩——目光疯狂满头长发的人，神经质的退化的人，激情四溢而发抖的声音，高举着紧攥的拳头，背景声音则是愤怒的人们口中发出的咒骂声、叫喊声和低沉的咆哮声。 He did not know what all the talk was about.It was not necessary.Words like revolution gave him his cue.Like a paleontologist, able to reconstruct an entire skeleton from one fossil bone, he was able to reconstruct a whole speech from the one word revolution.He did it that night, and he did it well; and since Martin had made the biggest stir, he put it all into his mouth and made him the arch-anarch of the show, transforming his reactionary individualism into the most lurid, red-shirt socialist utterance.The cub reporter was an artist, and it was a large brush with which he laid on the local color—wild-eyed long-haired men, neurasthenia and degenerate types of men, voices shaken with passion, clenched fists raised on high, and all projected against a background of oaths, yells, and the throaty rumbling of angry men.
第三十九章 CHAPTER XXXIX
在他的小屋里，马丁一边喝着咖啡，一边读着次日早上的报纸。他发现自己上了头版头条，这实在是次新奇的经历。他还惊讶地了解到自己成了奥克兰社会主义者最臭名昭著的头目。他匆匆读完了那新人记者为他编造的激烈的发言，虽然一开始为那番胡编乱造感到生气，最后却大笑着把报纸丢到了一边。 Over the coffee, in his little room, Martin read next morning’s paper.It was a novel experience to find himself head-lined, on the first page at that; and he was surprised to learn that he was the most notorious leader of the Oakland socialists.He ran over the violent speech the cub reporter had constructed for him, and, though at first he was angered by the fabrication, in the end he tossed the paper aside with a laugh.
“那家伙要么是喝醉了，要么就是恶意诽谤。”那天下午他坐在床上说。布里森登那时已经来了，无精打采地瘫坐在那把唯一的椅子上。 “Either the man was drunk or criminally malicious,” he said that afternoon, from his perch on the bed, when Brissenden had arrived and dropped limply into the one chair.
“那你管他做什么？”布里森登问。“你肯定不会希望那些读到这报纸的资产阶级猪猡们赞同你的观点吧？” “But what do you care?” Brissenden asked.“Surely you don’t desire the approval of the bourgeois swine that read the newspapers?”
马丁思考了一会儿，然后说： Martin thought for a while, then said:—
“不，他们赞不赞同我真的不在乎，一点儿也不在乎。但另一方面，很有可能我和鲁思一家的关系会因此变得有些尴尬。她父亲总声称我是个社会主义者，这篇讨厌的文章更会让他对此深信不疑。我倒不在乎他的意见——那又怎样？我想念给你听听我今天刚写的东西。文章的名字叫《过期》，当然了，才写完了差不多一半。” “No, I really don’t care for their approval, not a whit.On the other hand, it’s very likely to make my relations with Ruth’s family a trifle awkward.Her father always contended I was a socialist, and this miserable stuff will clinch his belief.Not that I care for his opinion—but what’s the odds?I want to read you what I’ve been doing to-day.It’s @Overdue@, of course, and I’m just about halfway through.”
他正朗读着，玛丽亚突然推开门，把一个年轻人引了进来。那人衣着整洁，匆匆打量了马丁一眼，又注意到了角落里的煤油炉子和厨房，然后目光又飘回到马丁身上。 He was reading aloud when Maria thrust open the door and ushered in a young man in a natty suit who glanced briskly about him, noting the oil-burner and the kitchen in the corner before his gaze wandered on to Martin.
“坐。”布里森登说。 “Sit down,” Brissenden said.
马丁在床上给年轻人腾出个座位，等着他开口道明来意。 Martin made room for the young man on the bed and waited for him to broach his business.
“伊登先生，我昨晚听了你的演讲，现在来采访你。”他开口道。 “I heard you speak last night, Mr. Eden, and I’ve come to interview you,” he began.
布里森登忍不住大笑起来。 Brissenden burst out in a hearty laugh.
“社会主义兄弟？”记者边问边匆忙看一眼布里森登，估量着那形容枯槁的将死之人的赤化程度。 “A brother socialist?” the reporter asked, with a quick glance at Brissenden that appraised the color-value of that cadaverous and dying man.
“难道那篇报道就是他写的，”马丁轻声说，“哎，还是个孩子而已！” “And he wrote that report,” Martin said softly.“Why, he is only a boy!”
“你为什么不揍他一顿？”布里森登问，“我愿意出一千美元，只要我的肺恢复五分钟的健康。” “Why don’t you poke him?” Brissenden asked.“I’d give a thousand dollars to have my lungs back for five minutes.”
那新人记者因为自己被这样当面毫不客气地讨论着，感到有点狼狈。但是他因那篇对社会主义者集会的精彩报道而受到了表扬，进而被指派着对马丁·伊登本人进行采访——就是那个对社会构成威胁的组织的头目。 The cub reporter was a trifle perplexed by this talking over him and around him and at him.But he had been commended for his brilliant description of the socialist meeting and had further been detailed to get a personal interview with Martin Eden, the leader of the organized menace to society.
“您应该不反对我给您拍张照片吧，伊登先生？”他问，“我带了一个摄影师，就在门外，你看，他说最好趁太阳没有再往下斜的时候就给您拍照。我们可以等拍完再谈。” “You do not object to having your picture taken, Mr. Eden?” he said.“I’ve a staff photographer outside, you see, and he says it will be better to take you right away before the sun gets lower.Then we can have the interview afterward.”
“摄影师？”布里森登思忖着，“揍他一顿，马丁。揍他一顿!” “A photographer,” Brissenden said meditatively.“Poke him, Martin!Poke him!”
“看来我真的老了，”马丁回答道，“我知道应该揍他一顿，可我还真没有那心情。大概无所谓吧。” “I guess I’m getting old,” was the answer.“I know I ought, but I really haven’t the heart.It doesn’t seem to matter.”
“替他妈妈教训他。”布里森登怂恿道。 “For his mother’s sake,” Brissenden urged.
“那倒值得考虑考虑了，”马丁回答，“但是好像这家伙还不值得我耗费大力气。你知道，揍人可是要费力气的。另外，揍不揍他又有什么要紧呢？” “It’s worth considering,” Martin replied; “but it doesn’t seem worthwhile enough to rouse sufficient energy in me.You see, it does take energy to give a fellow a poking.Besides, what does it matter?”
“没错——这才是处理的方法。”新人记者轻描淡写地说，虽然他已经开始紧张地盯着房门了。 “That’s right—that’s the way to take it,” the cub announced airily, though he had already begun to glance anxiously at the door.
“不过他写的东西没有一句是真话。”马丁继续说，眼睛继续只看着布里森登。 “But it wasn’t true, not a word of what he wrote,” Martin went on, confining his attention to Brissenden.
“你明白，那只不过是一般性的描写。”新人记者大着胆子说，“况且，那也是很好的宣传。那很划算的，那对你可是种优惠。” “It was just in a general way a description, you understand,” the cub ventured, “and besides, it’s good advertising.That’s what counts.It was a favor to you.”
“这可是很好的宣传啊，马丁老弟。”布里森登郑重重复道。 “It’s good advertising, Martin, old boy,” Brissenden repeated solemnly.
“原来对我还有优惠呢——想想看！”马丁也附和道。 “And it was a favor to me—think of that!” was Martin’s contribution.
“让我想想——您是在哪儿出生的呢，伊登先生？”新人提问了，还装出很期待、很仔细听的样子。 “Let me see—where were you born, Mr. Eden?” the cub asked, assuming an air of expectant attention.
“他连笔记都不记，”布里森登说，“他都靠脑子来记了。” “He doesn’t take notes,” said Brissenden.“He remembers it all.”
“我用脑子记就够了。”新人努力装出不担心的样子。“好记者不会因为笔记而受到困扰。” “That is sufficient for me.”The cub was trying not to look worried.“No decent reporter needs to bother with notes.”
“用脑子记就够了——昨晚也是。”布里森登可不是沉默主义的信徒，突然改变了态度。“马丁，你要是不动手，我可要亲自动手了，哪怕下一刻就摔死在地上。” “That was sufficient—for last night.”But Brissenden was not a disciple of quietism, and he changed his attitude abruptly.“Martin, if you don’t poke him, I’ll do it myself, if I fall dead on the floor the next moment.”
“打他一顿屁股怎么样？”马丁问。 “How will a spanking do?” Martin asked.
布里森登公正地考虑了一会儿，点点头。 Brissenden considered judicially, and nodded his head.
不一会儿，马丁已经坐到了床边，新人记者已经脸朝下趴在他的膝盖上了。 The next instant Martin was seated on the edge of the bed with the cub face downward across his knees.
“别咬人，”马丁警告他，“不然我打你脸了。这脸还挺漂亮，打坏了就太可惜了。” “Now don’t bite,” Martin warned, “or else I’ll have to punch your face.It would be a pity, for it is such a pretty face.”
马丁挥起的手落下，然后就快速而有节奏地揍了起来。新人记者挣扎着、咒骂着、扭动着、但是没有动口咬。布里森登严肃地看着，尽管有那么一小会儿他激动起来，抓起威士忌酒瓶，恳求道：“来，让我也砸他一下。” His uplifted hand descended, and thereafter rose and fell in a swift and steady rhythm.The cub struggled and cursed and squirmed, but did not offer to bite.Brissenden looked on gravely, though once he grew excited and gripped the whiskey bottle, pleading, “Here, just let me swat him once.”
“抱歉，我的手累了，”马丁终于停了下来，说，“我都打得麻木了。” “Sorry my hand played out,” Martin said, when at last he desisted.“It is quite numb.”
他把记者放直，让他坐在床边。 He uprighted the cub and perched him on the bed.
“你这样我会叫人把你抓起来的。”记者吼叫着，通红的脸上挂满了孩子似的愤怒的眼泪。“我会让你付出代价，走着瞧。” “I’ll have you arrested for this,” he snarled, tears of boyish indignation running down his flushed cheeks.“I’ll make you sweat for this.You’ll see.”
“小白脸，”马丁评论道，“他还没意识到自己已经在走下坡路了。像他那样拿自己的同胞来捏造谎言是不诚实、不公平的，也不是男子汉的作为，他自己竟然浑然不觉。” “The pretty thing,” Martin remarked.“He doesn’t realize that he has entered upon the downward path.It is not honest, it is not square, it is not manly, to tell lies about one’s fellow-creatures the way he has done, and he doesn’t know it.”
“得靠我们来告诉他。”布里森登接下去说。 “He has to come to us to be told,” Brissenden filled in a pause.
“是的，我受到他的诽谤和伤害，杂货店老板毫无疑问再也不会赊账给我了。 “Yes, to me whom he has maligned and injured. My grocery will undoubtedly refuse me credit now.
更糟糕的是，这个可怜的孩子将会继续堕落下去，直到他成为一个顶级的新闻记者加头等流氓。 The worst of it is that the poor boy will keep on this way until he deteriorates into a first-class newspaper man and also a first-class scoundrel.”
“或许还有补救的余地，”布里森登说，“保不准你这个不算高明的手法能拯救他。刚才为什么不让我砸他一酒瓶子呢？我也想帮助他一下呢。” “But there is yet time,” quoth Brissenden.“Who knows but what you may prove the humble instrument to save him.Why didn’t you let me swat him just once?I’d like to have had a hand in it.”
“我要把你们都抓起来，你们两个，大—大—坏蛋！”那堕落的灵魂抽泣着。 “I’ll have you arrested, the pair of you, you b-b-big brutes,” sobbed the erring soul.
“不，他那张嘴长得太好看，也太脆弱。”马丁伤心地摇了摇头。“我可不想让自己的手白白受累。这年轻人已经没到了没法改造的地步了。他最终会成为一个成功的大记者。他没有良心。光凭这条就够他出人头地的了。” “No, his mouth is too pretty and too weak.”Martin shook his head lugubriously.“I’m afraid I’ve numbed my hand in vain.The young man cannot reform.He will become eventually a very great and successful newspaper man.He has no conscience. That alone will make him great.”
那新人记者就这样胆战心惊地出了门，生怕布里森登还会用手里攥着的酒瓶从背后砸他。 With that the cub passed out the door in trepidation to the last for fear that Brissenden would hit him in the back with the bottle he still clutched.
马丁从第二天早上的报纸上读到了许多关于自己却连他自己都不知道的东西。“我们是社会的死敌，”他发现自己在一个采访专栏里说，“不，我们不是无政府主义者，而是社会主义者。”当记者指出这两个派别没什么区别时，马丁耸耸肩，默认了。他的脸被描写成了两边不对称的形状，并且还有一些别的堕落的特征。尤其引人注意的是他那暴徒般的双手和充血的眼里露出的凶光。 In the next morning’s paper Martin learned a great deal more about himself that was new to him.“We are the sworn enemies of society,” he found himself quoted as saying in a column interview.“No, we are not anarchists but socialists.”When the reporter pointed out to him that there seemed little difference between the two schools, Martin had shrugged his shoulders in silent affirmation.His face was described as bilaterally asymmetrical, and various other signs of degeneration were described.Especially notable were his thuglike hands and the fiery gleams in his blood-shot eyes.
他还了解到他每天晚上都到市政公园里向工人们发表演讲，并且他成了那些蛊惑群众的无政府主义者和煽动者中听众最多，发言最为反动的一个。那新人记者还给他那贫困的小屋、煤油炉子、唯一的椅子和与他为伴的骷髅般的流浪汉来了个特写，写得仿佛那汉子是在某个边塞的地牢里单独关了二十年后才放出来似的。 He learned, also, that he spoke nightly to the workmen in the City Hall Park, and that among the anarchists and agitators that there inflamed the minds of the people he drew the largest audiences and made the most revolutionary speeches.The cub painted a high-light picture of his poor little room, its oil-stove and the one chair, and of the death’s-head tramp who kept him company and who looked as if he had just emerged from twenty years of solitary confinement in some fortress dungeon.
那新人记者的确花了不少功夫。他四处打听，除了摸清一点马丁的家庭史，还弄到了一张希金博特姆现金商店的照片，照片上伯纳德•希金博特姆站在前面。这位先生被描写成了一位聪明而有尊严的商人，对小舅子的社会主义观点和小舅子本人都感到不耐烦。据他所说，马丁的特点就是懒散，无所事事，给他工作也不去做，迟早是要进班房的。他还采访了玛丽安的丈夫赫尔曼·冯·施米特。他管马丁叫家族中的害群之马，并和他断绝关系。“他想从我这儿揩油，但是被我立刻制止了，”赫尔曼·冯·施米特对记者说，“他清楚地知道从我这里他捞不到什么好处。不干活的人干不了什么好事，相信我。” The cub had been industrious.He had scurried around and nosed out Martin’s family history, and procured a photograph of Higginbotham’s Cash Store with Bernard Higginbotham himself standing out in front.That gentleman was depicted as an intelligent, dignified businessman who had no patience with his brother-in-law’s socialistic views, and no patience with the brother-in-law, either, whom he was quoted as characterizing as a lazy good-for-nothing who wouldn’t take a job when it was offered to him and who would go to jail yet.Hermann Von Schmidt, Marian’s husband, had likewise been interviewed.He had called Martin the black sheep of the family and repudiated him.“He tried to sponge off of me, but I put a stop to that good and quick,” Von Schmidt had said to the reporter.“He knows better than to come bumming around here.A man who won’t work is no good, take that from me.”
这次马丁真的生气了。布里森登把这事当个大笑话，却安慰不了马丁。马丁知道这下很难向鲁思解释清楚。至于鲁思的父亲，马丁知道他肯定会因为这事而喜出望外，并且竭力借此解除他们俩的婚约。很快他就明白那老人如何充分利用这件事。那天下午他收到了一封来自鲁思的信。马丁预感到了灾难，从邮递员手上接过信，就立刻在门口拆开信封读了起来。他一边读着，一边无意识地摸着口袋，想像往日一样掏出烟叶和棕色纸来卷烟抽。没想到口袋早已空空如也，而他却还找着卷烟的材料。 This time Martin was genuinely angry.Brissenden looked upon the affair as a good joke, but he could not console Martin, who knew that it would be no easy task to explain to Ruth.As for her father, he knew that he must be overjoyed with what had happened and that he would make the most of it to break off the engagement.How much he would make of it he was soon to realize.The afternoon mail brought a letter from Ruth.Martin opened it with a premonition of disaster, and read it standing at the open door when he had received it from the postman.As he read, mechanically his hand sought his pocket for the tobacco and brown paper of his old cigarette days.He was not aware that the pocket was empty or that he had even reached for the materials with which to roll a cigarette.
那封信里没有热情。也没有愤怒的迹象。但是整封信从第一句话到最后一句话都带着受伤和失望的语气。她曾对他有过更大的期望。她以为他已经过了那个疯狂无知的青年时期，而她对他的爱已经足以让他过上严肃而正派的生活。现在她的父母都态度坚决，要她解除婚约。她也只好承认他们是有道理的。他们俩这种关系绝不会幸福。从一开始就注定不幸福。整封信里她只表示了一次遗憾，对马丁的不快。“如果你一开始愿意安定下来找个工作，并且努力有所作为，那就好了。”她写道。“但是你不愿意。你过去的生活太狂野太放纵。但是我知道那不能怪你。你只能按照你的天性和早期受到的教育来做人。所以马丁，我不怪你。请记住，这只不过是个错误。正如我的父母所认定的，我们注定不是一对，我们应该高兴，因为发现得还不算太晚。”……“别再想来见我了，那没用”她在信中最后说。“如果我们见面的话都不会开心，我母亲也是一样。我觉得自己已经给她带来了许多痛苦和担忧。我得花好多日子才能弥补她为我伤的心。” It was not a passionate letter.There were no touches of anger in it.But all the way through, from the first sentence to the last, was sounded the note of hurt and disappointment.She had expected better of him.She had thought he had got over his youthful wildness, that her love for him had been sufficiently worth while to enable him to live seriously and decently.And now her father and mother had taken a firm stand and commanded that the engagement be broken.That they were justified in this she could not but admit.Their relation could never be a happy one.It had been unfortunate from the first.But one regret she voiced in the whole letter, and it was a bitter one to Martin.“If only you had settled down to some position and attempted to make something of yourself,” she wrote.“But it was not to be.Your past life had been too wild and irregular.I can understand that you are not to be blamed.You could act only according to your nature and your early training.So I do not blame you, Martin.Please remember that. It was simply a mistake.As father and mother have contended, we were not made for each other, and we should both be happy because it was discovered not too late.”… “There is no use trying to see me,” she said toward the last.“It would be an unhappy meeting for both of us, as well as for my mother.I feel, as it is, that I have caused her great pain and worry.I shall have to do much living to atone for it.”
他又从头到尾把信认真看了一遍，然后坐下来写回信。他概括了一下他在那次社会主义聚会上的发言，指出他所说的话和报纸上所写的全然不同。在信的结尾，他又变身成了上帝的情人，激情四溢地表白爱情。“请回复我，”他说，“在你的回信中就告诉我一件事。你爱我么？就这一个问题，回答这一个问题就够了。” He read it through to the end, carefully, a second time, then sat down and replied.He outlined the remarks he had uttered at the socialist meeting, pointing out that they were in all ways the converse of what the newspaper had put in his mouth.Toward the end of the letter he was God’s own lover pleading passionately for love.“Please answer,” he said, “and in your answer you have to tell me but one thing.Do you love me?That is all—the answer to that one question.”
但是第二天没有回信，第三天也没有。《过期》原封不动躺在桌子上，每天桌子底下的退稿都与日俱增。马丁的睡眠第一次遭到了失眠的干扰。他整晚辗转反侧，夜不能寐。他到莫尔斯家里拜访了三次，每次都被应门的仆人拦在门外。布里森登卧病在旅馆里，身体虚弱，不能行动。尽管马丁常常和他在一起，但是没有拿自己的烦恼去叨扰他。 But no answer came the next day, nor the next. @Overdue@ lay untouched upon the table, and each day the heap of returned manuscripts under the table grew larger.For the first time Martin’s glorious sleep was interrupted by insomnia, and he tossed through long, restless nights.Three times he called at the Morse home, but was turned away by the servant who answered the bell.Brissenden lay sick in his hotel, too feeble to stir out, and, though Martin was with him often, he did not worry him with his troubles.
因为马丁遇到的麻烦还有很多。那新人记者的行为带来的后果远远大于马丁的预期。葡萄牙杂货商拒绝再让他赊账。蔬菜商是个自以为荣的美国人，管马丁叫做卖国贼，拒绝再和他做生意——他的爱国情结甚至促使他划掉了马丁的欠账乃至不允许他还的程度。左邻右舍的闲言碎语里也展露出了这种感受，反对马丁的义愤越来越严重。没有人愿意和一个社会主义卖国贼有任何牵连。可怜的玛利亚也疑惑了，害怕了，但是她还对他很忠实。附近的孩子们不再因为过去拜访马丁的大马车而对他心生敬畏，躲在安全距离以外叫他“二流子”和“懒汉”。但席尔瓦家的孩子仍然忠实地捍卫着他，为了他的荣誉不止一次大打出手，鼻青眼肿成了家常便饭，玛利亚也更加惶恐，更加烦恼了。 For Martin’s troubles were many.The aftermath of the cub reporter’s deed was even wider than Martin had anticipated.The Portuguese grocer refused him further credit, while the greengrocer, who was an American and proud of it, had called him a traitor to his country and refused further dealings with him—carrying his patriotism to such a degree that he cancelled Martin’s account and forbade him ever to attempt to pay it.The talk in the neighborhood reflected the same feeling, and indignation against Martin ran high.No one would have anything to do with a socialist traitor.Poor Maria was dubious and frightened, but she remained loyal.The children of the neighborhood recovered from the awe of the grand carriage which once had visited Martin, and from safe distances they called him “hobo” and “bum.”The Silva tribe, however, stanchly defended him, fighting more than one pitched battle for his honor, and black eyes and bloody noses became quite the order of the day and added to Maria’s perplexities and troubles.
有一回，马丁在奥克兰的大街上遇到了格特鲁德，从她那儿听到了一些他预料到的事情——伯纳德•希金博特姆因为他拖垮了全家在公众面前的形象而大为光火，并且不准他再进他的屋子。 Once, Martin met Gertrude on the street, down in Oakland, and learned what he knew could not be otherwise—that Bernard Higginbotham was furious with him for having dragged the family into public disgrace, and that he had forbidden him the house.
“你为什么不离开这儿呢，马丁？”格特鲁德请求他，“到别的地方找个工作安定下来吧。等过一段时间风头过去了再回来。” “Why don’t you go away, Martin?” Gertrude had begged.“Go away and get a job somewhere and steady down.Afterwards, when this all blows over, you can come back.”
马丁摇摇头，但却没有解释。他能怎么解释呢？他和家人之间横亘着一个可怕的智力鸿沟，这使他大为吃惊。他难以跨越那道鸿沟向家人解释自己的立场——社会主义式的尼采的立场。在英语里，甚至在一切语言里都找不到足够的词汇去向他们解释清楚他的态度和行为。他们给他定义的良好行为的最高境界就是找个工作。那是他们第一个也是最后一个词汇。也是他们全部的词汇。找工作！干活去！可怜愚昧的奴隶们，他这样想着。他的姐姐还在说话。无怪乎世界属于强者。奴隶们都为自己成为奴隶而心满意足。一份工作对于他们来说就是黄金神物了，值得他们五体投地，顶礼膜拜。 Martin shook his head, but gave no explanations.How could he explain?He was appalled at the awful intellectual chasm that yawned between him and his people.He could never cross it and explain to them his position,—the Nietzschean position, in regard to socialism.There were not words enough in the English language, nor in any language, to make his attitude and conduct intelligible to them.Their highest concept of right conduct, in his case, was to get a job.That was their first word and their last.It constituted their whole lexicon of ideas.Get a job!Go to work!Poor, stupid slaves, he thought, while his sister talked.Small wonder the world belonged to the strong.The slaves were obsessed by their own slavery.A job was to them a golden fetich before which they fell down and worshipped.
格特鲁德要给他钱，他又摇摇头，尽管他知道那天他得上典当铺那儿换钱去。 He shook his head again, when Gertrude offered him money, though he knew that within the day he would have to make a trip to the pawnbroker.
“现在别到伯纳德那儿去，”她告诫他，“等过几个月，他冷静下来，要是你愿意的话，可以让他把开送货车的工作给你。需要我的时候就叫我，我会立刻来的。千万记住了。” “Don’t come near Bernard now,” she admonished him.“After a few months, when he is cooled down, if you want to, you can get the job of drivin’ delivery-wagon for him.Any time you want me, just send for me an’ I’ll come.Don’t forget.”
她走了，他能听见她哭泣的声音。望着她沉重的身影和蹒跚的脚步，一种悲凉的辛酸划过他的心间。看着她慢慢远去，他那尼采式的大厦仿佛在动摇了。抽象的奴隶阶级倒没有什么，但是这一概念用在自己家人身上就让人觉得不是很满意了。而且，如果有哪个奴隶正受着强者的欺辱的话，那就是他的姐姐格特鲁德。这个难解的矛盾让他残忍地大笑起来。他是一个多么忠诚的尼采信徒，那智慧的头脑竟第一次因为情绪或情感的波动而动摇了——是的，被奴隶道德自己动摇了，因为他对姐姐的悲悯便真的是奴隶道德了。真正高贵的人是超越了悲悯和同情的。悲悯和同情产生于关押奴隶的地窖里，不过只是一群可怜者和软弱者的痛苦和汗水罢了。 She went away weeping audibly, and he felt a pang of sorrow shoot through him at sight of her heavy body and uncouth gait.As he watched her go, the Nietzschean edifice seemed to shake and totter.The slave-class in the abstract was all very well, but it was not wholly satisfactory when it was brought home to his own family.And yet, if there was ever a slave trampled by the strong, that slave was his sister Gertrude.He grinned savagely at the paradox.A fine Nietzsche-man he was, to allow his intellectual concepts to be shaken by the first sentiment or emotion that strayed along—ay, to be shaken by the slave-morality itself, for that was what his pity for his sister really was.The true noble men were above pity and compassion.Pity and compassion had been generated in the subterranean barracoons of the slaves and were no more than the agony and sweat of the crowded miserables and weaklings.
第四十章 CHAPTER XL
《过期》仍然被遗忘在桌上。他寄出去的所有稿件现在都躺在桌下。只有一份手稿他还在坚持往外寄送，那就是布里森登的《蜉蝣》。他的自行车和黑色套装又进了当铺。打字机行的人又开始担心租金的事了。但是这类事情再也烦不着马丁了。他在寻找新的方向，在此之前，他的生活只好暂停一下。 @Overdue@ still continued to lie forgotten on the table.Every manuscript that he had had out now lay under the table.Only one manuscript he kept going, and that was Brissenden’s “Ephemera.”His bicycle and black suit were again in pawn, and the type-writer people were once more worrying about the rent.But such things no longer bothered him.He was seeking a new orientation, and until that was found his life must stand still.
几周之后，他等待的东西终于出现了。他在街上遇见了鲁思。那是真的，她由她的弟弟诺曼陪着。说实话，两人都不理他，诺曼还挥手企图赶他走。 After several weeks, what he had been waiting for happened.He met Ruth on the street.It was true, she was accompanied by her brother, Norman, and it was true that they tried to ignore him and that Norman attempted to wave him aside.
“你要是敢骚扰我姐姐，我就叫警察，”诺曼威胁道，“她不想和你说话，你要是硬来就是侮辱她。” “If you interfere with my sister, I’ll call an officer,” Norman threatened.“She does not wish to speak with you, and your insistence is insult.”
“如果你要坚持，那就叫那个警察好了，然后你的名字就会登在报纸上。”马丁严厉地回答他，“现在你让开，如果你想就去叫警察吧。我要和鲁思说会儿话。” “If you persist, you’ll have to call that officer, and then you’ll get your name in the papers,” Martin answered grimly.“And now, get out of my way and get the officer if you want to.I’m going to talk with Ruth.”
“我要听你亲口说。”马丁对鲁思说。 “I want to have it from your own lips,” he said to her.
她脸色苍白，浑身发抖，但是她还是强忍着，满脸疑惑地望着他。 She was pale and trembling, but she held up and looked inquiringly.
“我在信里问的那个问题。”他提示她。 “The question I asked in my letter,” he prompted.
诺曼打了个不耐烦的手势，但是马丁立刻瞪了他一眼，制止了他。 Norman made an impatient movement, but Martin checked him with a swift look.
她摇摇头。 She shook her head.
“一切都是你自愿的么？”他问。 “Is all this of your own free will?” he demanded.
“是。”她的声音低沉而坚决，显得非常从容。“是我自己的意愿。你让我丢脸，让我羞于见我的朋友们。我清楚她们都在议论我。这些就是我能告诉你的一切。你让我很不开心，我再也不愿见到你了。” “It is.”She spoke in a low, firm voice and with deliberation.“It is of my own free will.You have disgraced me so that I am ashamed to meet my friends.They are all talking about me, I know.That is all I can tell you.You have made me very unhappy, and I never wish to see you again.”
“朋友！流言！报纸上的谎报！这些东西肯定不会比爱情强吧！我只能相信你从未爱过我！“ “Friends!Gossip!Newspaper misreports!Surely such things are not stronger than love!I can only believe that you never loved me.”
一阵红晕驱散了她脸上的苍白。 A blush drove the pallor from her face.
“我们经过了这么多事情你居然还这样说！”她虚弱地说，“马丁，你不知道自己在说什么，我不是一般人。”“听到了吧，她再也不想和你有任何关系了。”诺曼脱口而出，准备带她离开。 “After what has passed?” she said faintly.“Martin, you do not know what you are saying. I am not common.”“You see, she doesn’t want to have anything to do with you,” Norman blurted out, starting on with her.
马丁站到一旁让他们走过去，一边无意识地在上衣口袋里摸索着烟叶和卷烟纸，却没找到。 Martin stood aside and let them pass, fumbling unconsciously in his coat pocket for the tobacco and brown papers that were not there.
到北奥克兰还有很远的路程。但是直到走上了台阶进了屋子，马丁才发现自己是一路走回来的。他发现自己正坐在床边，凝视着四周，就像一个刚醒来的梦游症患者。他看到《过期》正躺在桌上，于是拉过椅子伸手去拿笔。他的天性里有一种逻辑强迫力，促使他把事情完成为止。这是一件还没完成的事情。这件事因为一些别的事情而耽搁了，还没完成。既然别的事情已经做完，他就该致力于这件事，直到其完成为止。他不知道之后再要干什么。他只知道自己正面临着生命中一个重要的转折期。一个阶段已经结束，他要郑重其事地做好最后收尾的工作。他对未来毫无兴趣。他不久就会知道未来他将会怎样。不管是什么都无关紧要了。任何事情都无所谓了。 It was a long walk to North Oakland, but it was not until he went up the steps and entered his room that he knew he had walked it.He found himself sitting on the edge of the bed and staring about him like an awakened somnambulist.He noticed @Overdue@ lying on the table and drew up his chair and reached for his pen.There was in his nature a logical compulsion toward completeness.Here was something undone.It had been deferred against the completion of something else.Now that something else had been finished, and he would apply himself to this task until it was finished.What he would do next he did not know.All that he did know was that a climacteric in his life had been attained.A period had been reached, and he was rounding it off in workman-like fashion.He was not curious about the future.He would soon enough find out what it held in store for him.Whatever it was, it did not matter.Nothing seemed to matter.
一连五天他都在辛苦创作《过期》，哪儿也不去，谁也不见，吃得也很少。第六天早上，邮递员给他送来了一封薄薄的信，来自《帕提农》的编辑。他只瞥了一眼就知道《蜉蝣》已经被采用了。“本刊已将此诗交由卡特赖特•布鲁斯先生，”编辑接着说，“他高度赞赏此诗，本刊也爱不释手。因本刊七月号已经排定，因此我们诚挚地告知您，欲将此诗刊于本刊八月号，以示发稿之荣幸。请向布里森登先生转致本刊荣幸之感及诚挚谢意。请在回信中附上布里森登先生的照片及小传。若本刊稿酬不合意，烦请即刻电报告知先生所认为合适的数目。” For five days he toiled on at “Overdue,” going nowhere, seeing nobody, and eating meagrely.On the morning of the sixth day the postman brought him a thin letter from the editor of @The Parthenon@.A glance told him that “Ephemera” was accepted.“We have submitted the poem to Mr. Cartwright Bruce,” the editor went on to say, “and he has reported so favorably upon it that we cannot let it go.As an earnest of our pleasure in publishing the poem, let me tell you that we have set it for the August number, our July number being already made up.Kindly extend our pleasure and our thanks to Mr. Brissenden.Please send by return mail his photograph and biographical data.If our honorarium is unsatisfactory, kindly telegraph us at once and state what you consider a fair price.”
他们提出的稿酬是三百五十美元，所以马丁认为不必要再电报告知了。不过还得布里森登同意才行。嗯，毕竟他还是对的。这就是一个真正有眼光的杂志编辑。即使这首诗算得上世纪之作，这个稿酬也算高的了。至于卡特赖特•布鲁斯，马丁知道他是为数不多的布里森登还算尊重的评论家之一。 Since the honorarium they had offered was three hundred and fifty dollars, Martin thought it not worth while to telegraph.Then, too, there was Brissenden’s consent to be gained.Well, he had been right, after all.Here was one magazine editor who knew real poetry when he saw it.And the price was splendid, even though it was for the poem of a century.As for Cartwright Bruce, Martin knew that he was the one critic for whose opinions Brissenden had any respect.
马丁坐电车进了城。凝视那经过的房屋和横街时，他意识到了一阵遗憾，他并没有因为自己朋友的成功和自己显著的胜利而兴高采烈。美国的一个评论家赞赏了这首诗，而他关于好作品总会被好杂志赏识的观点也得到了证明。但是他心里的热情已经没有了源泉。他发现他自己更渴望见到布里森登，而不是为了告诉他这个好消息。《帕提农》接受了稿件的事情提醒了他，在他忙于创作《过期》的这五天里，他都没有收到布里森登的消息，甚至都没有想起过他。马丁这才第一次意识到自己昏了头，为忘了朋友而惭愧起来。但是这股惭愧觉也来得并不强烈。《过期》的艺术创作已经夺走了他大部分的激情，除此之外他已经麻木了。所以在别的事情上，他都处于恍惚中。这会儿他也仍然是大脑一片空白。外面，电车奔驰而过，外面的一切生活似乎都显得遥远而模糊，即使他刚才经过的教堂宏伟的石头尖塔突然砸到他头上，摔成碎片，他也不会在意，更不要说大吃一惊了。 Martin rode down town on an electric car, and as he watched the houses and cross-streets slipping by he was aware of a regret that he was not more elated over his friend’s success and over his own signal victory.The one critic in the United States had pronounced favorably on the poem, while his own contention that good stuff could find its way into the magazines had proved correct.But enthusiasm had lost its spring in him, and he found that he was more anxious to see Brissenden than he was to carry the good news.The acceptance of @The Parthenon@ had recalled to him that during his five days’ devotion to @Overdue@ he had not heard from Brissenden nor even thought about him.For the first time Martin realized the daze he had been in, and he felt shame for having forgotten his friend.But even the shame did not burn very sharply.He was numb to emotions of any sort save the artistic ones concerned in the writing of @Overdue@.So far as other affairs were concerned, he had been in a trance.For that matter, he was still in a trance.All this life through which the electric car whirred seemed remote and unreal, and he would have experienced little interest and less shook if the great stone steeple of the church he passed had suddenly crumbled to mortar-dust upon his head.
到了旅店，他匆匆走上布里森登的房间，然后又匆匆走了下来。房间是空的。行李也都不见了。 At the hotel he hurried up to Brissenden’s room, and hurried down again.The room was empty.All luggage was gone.
“布里森登先生留下什么地址没有？”他问旅店办事员，那人好奇地打量了他一会儿。 “Did Mr. Brissenden leave any address?” he asked the clerk, who looked at him curiously for a moment.
“你没听说么？”他问。 “Haven’t you heard?” he asked.
马丁摇了摇头。 Martin shook his head.
“怎么会呢，报纸上都是他的事呀。他被发现死在了床上。是自杀。子弹射穿了他的脑袋。” “Why, the papers were full of it.He was found dead in bed.Suicide.Shot himself through the head.”
“他被埋了么？”马丁听见自己的声音，像是从别人嘴里发出来的，从很远的地方问着问题。 “Is he buried yet?” Martin seemed to hear his voice, like some one else’s voice, from a long way off, asking the question.
“没有，尸体检查之后就运到东部去了。他的家人委托律师处理的。” “No.The body was shipped East after the inquest.Lawyers engaged by his people saw to the arrangements.”
“我不得不说，动作真快。”马丁评论道。 “They were quick about it, I must say,” Martin commented.
“这我就不知道了。都是五天前的事情了。” “Oh, I don’t know.It happened five days ago.”
“五天前？” “Five days ago?”
“是的，五天前。” “Yes, five days ago.”
“噢。”马丁说完就转身离去了。 “Oh,” Martin said as he turned and went out.
在街角，他走进了西联电讯公司，给《帕提农》发了一封电报，通知他们发表那首诗。他口袋里只有五分钱坐车回家，所以他让收报人为这封电报付费。 At the corner he stepped into the Western Union and sent a telegram to @The Parthenon@, advising them to proceed with the publication of the poem.He had in his pocket but five cents with which to pay his carfare home, so he sent the message collect.
一回到家，他又开始了写作。日以继夜，他都坐在桌子边不停地写。他哪儿也没去，除了当铺。也不运动，饿了的时候有东西煮就煮一点，按部就班地吃点。没东西煮就不煮了，按部就班地饿着肚子。那故事早就一章章地安排好了剧情，他却考虑了一下，打算安排一个增加气势的开头，尽管那意味着不得不增加两万多字。这不是什么重要的非得完成的事情，但是他的艺术信条逼着他要把这件事做好。他昏头昏脑地写着，和周围的世界完全脱节，仿佛一个前世被写作困住的幽灵。他想起来有人说过幽灵是已经死去但是还没意识到已经死去的人的灵魂。于是他停下笔开始思考，是不是他已经死去，但是还没意识到而已。 Once in his room, he resumed his writing.The days and nights came and went, and he sat at his table and wrote on.He went nowhere, save to the pawnbroker, took no exercise, and ate methodically when he was hungry and had something to cook, and just as methodically went without when he had nothing to cook.Composed as the story was, in advance, chapter by chapter, he nevertheless saw and developed an opening that increased the power of it, though it necessitated twenty thousand additional words.It was not that there was any vital need that the thing should be well done, but that his artistic canons compelled him to do it well.He worked on in the daze, strangely detached from the world around him, feeling like a familiar ghost among these literary trappings of his former life.He remembered that some one had said that a ghost was the spirit of a man who was dead and who did not have sense enough to know it; and he paused for the moment to wonder if he were really dead did unaware of it.
终于到了《过期》要写完的日子了。打字机行的代理人已经来取机器了，正坐在床边等着。而马丁则坐在唯一的椅子上写完了最后一章的最后几页。“完了。”最后他用大写字母打出。对他而言，一切的确都结束了。他如释重负地看着打字机被抬出门，然后回到床上躺下。因为饥饿，他已经快昏倒了。他的嘴唇已经有三十六个小时没碰过食物了，但他一点也没察觉到。他仰面躺着，双眼紧闭，什么都不想，眩晕和麻木慢慢涌上来，淹没了他的知觉。在半癫狂的状态下，他开始高声喃喃背诵起布里森登喜欢朗诵给他听的一个无名诗人的诗句。玛利亚在门外焦急地听着，为他那单调的声音感到担心。那些诗句于她没有什么意义，她担心的是他那样的自言自语。“我的歌已唱完”是这首诗的主题。 Came the day when @Overdue@ was finished.The agent of the type-writer firm had come for the machine, and he sat on the bed while Martin, on the one chair, typed the last pages of the final chapter.“Finis,” he wrote, in capitals, at the end, and to him it was indeed finis.He watched the type-writer carried out the door with a feeling of relief, then went over and lay down on the bed.He was faint from hunger.Food had not passed his lips in thirty-six hours, but he did not think about it.He lay on his back, with closed eyes, and did not think at all, while the daze or stupor slowly welled up, saturating his consciousness.Half in delirium, he began muttering aloud the lines of an anonymous poem Brissenden had been fond of quoting to him.Maria, listening anxiously outside his door, was perturbed by his monotonous utterance.The words in themselves were not significant to her, but the fact that he was saying them was.“I have done,” was the burden of the poem.
“‘我的歌声已尽，诗琴已被收起。歌声与歌唱即将逝去，如空灵飘渺的影子笼罩在，紫苜蓿上。我的歌声已尽，诗琴已被收起。我曾如早起画眉般高歌，在露水沾湿的灌木里鸣啭。此刻我却喑哑无声，如厌倦歌唱的红雀，因为我喉里再没有歌曲，我已终结那歌唱的日子。我的歌声已尽，诗琴已被收起。’” “‘I have done—Put by the lute.Song and singing soon are overAs the airy shades that hoverIn among the purple clover.I have done—Put by the lute.Once I sang as early thrushesSing among the dewy bushes;Now I’m mute.I am like a weary linnet,For my throat has no song in it;I have had my singing minute.I have done.Put by the lute.’”
玛利亚再也受不了了，急忙走到炉子旁，盛了一大碗汤，用勺子从锅底捞出一大堆肉末和蔬菜放进汤里。马丁起身开始吃起来，一边吃一边还安慰玛利亚，说他没有说梦话，也没有发烧。 Maria could stand it no longer, and hurried away to the stove, where she filled a quart-bowl with soup, putting into it the lion’s share of chopped meat and vegetables which her ladle scraped from the bottom of the pot.Martin roused himself and sat up and began to eat, between spoonfuls reassuring Maria that he had not been talking in his sleep and that he did not have any fever.
玛利亚离开后，他仍然百无聊赖地坐在床边，肩膀耷拉着，两眼无神地发呆，什么都看不进去。直到一本被拆封的杂志把一道光芒射进他暗淡的脑子里。那份杂志是早上送到的。他认定那是《帕提农》，八月刊的《帕提农》，上面一定有《蜉蝣》。要是布里森登能看见就好了！ After she left him he sat drearily, with drooping shoulders, on the edge of the bed, gazing about him with lack-lustre eyes that saw nothing until the torn wrapper of a magazine, which had come in the morning’s mail and which lay unopened, shot a gleam of light into his darkened brain.It is @The Parthenon@, he thought, the August @Parthenon@, and it must contain “Ephemera.”If only Brissenden were here to see!
他翻阅着杂志，突然间停住了。《蜉蝣》以特刊的形式被登出，装饰着华丽的花式标题和比尔兹利风格的边框。标题的一旁是布里森登的照片，另一旁是英国大使约翰·伐流爵士的照片。一篇编辑写的介绍性短文引用了约翰·伐流爵士的话，说美国没有诗人，《蜉蝣》的出版等于是《帕提农》在向他宣告。“看啊，约翰·伐流爵士。”卡特赖特被描写成了美国最伟大的评论家，杂志引用他的话说：“《蜉蝣》是美国迄今为止最伟大的诗歌。”最后，编辑的前言是这样结束的：“我们的头脑尚未完全明白《蜉蝣》的杰出之处，也许永远也无法明白。但是我们对此诗常读常新，感慨于用词与构思的精妙，惊讶于布里森登先生丰富的文思从何而来，惊异于他是如何铸就了这篇诗文。”接下来就是那首诗。 He was turning the pages of the magazine, when suddenly he stopped.“Ephemera” had been featured, with gorgeous head-piece and Beardsley-like margin decorations.On one side of the head-piece was Brissenden’s photograph, on the other side was the photograph of Sir John Value, the British Ambassador.A preliminary editorial note quoted Sir John Value as saying that there were no poets in America, and the publication of “Ephemera” was @The Parthenon@’s.“There, take that, Sir John Value!”Cartwright Bruce was described as the greatest critic in America, and he was quoted as saying that “Ephemera” was the greatest poem ever written in America.And finally, the editor’s foreword ended with: “We have not yet made up our minds entirely as to the merits of “Ephemera”; perhaps we shall never be able to do so.But we have read it often, wondering at the words and their arrangement, wondering where Mr. Brissenden got them, and how he could fasten them together.”Then followed the poem.
“你真是死得好啊，布里斯老兄。”马丁喃喃道，任由那杂志从他的膝盖间滑落到地上。 “Pretty good thing you died, Briss, old man,” Martin murmured, letting the magazine slip between his knees to the floor.
那本杂志的廉价和庸俗直叫人想吐，可马丁却又冷淡地发现自己并不很想呕吐。他倒是希望自己能生气，但是连生气的力气都没有了。他太麻木了。体内的血液太粘稠，流速不足以达到发火所需要的程度。毕竟，那又有什么关系呢？这种现象正和布里森登所谴责的资产阶级社会的丑恶相合拍。 The cheapness and vulgarity of it was nauseating, and Martin noted apathetically that he was not nauseated very much.He wished he could get angry, but did not have energy enough to try.He was too numb.His blood was too congealed to accelerate to the swift tidal flow of indignation.After all, what did it matter?It was on a par with all the rest that Brissenden had condemned in bourgeois society.
“可怜的布里，”马丁反省道，“他永远都不会原谅我了。” “Poor Briss,” Martin communed; “he would never have forgiven me.”
他努力打起精神，捧起了一个原来用来装打字纸的箱子。他扫了一眼目录，拿出布里森登以前写的十一首诗。他把那些诗横着竖着来回地撕，最后扔进了垃圾箱。他懒散地撕着，弄完又坐回床边茫然地望着眼前。 Rousing himself with an effort, he possessed himself of a box which had once contained type-writer paper.Going through its contents, he drew forth eleven poems which his friend had written.These he tore lengthwise and crosswise and dropped into the waste basket.He did it languidly, and, when he had finished, sat on the edge of the bed staring blankly before him.
他不知道自己坐了多久。直到突然间，在他茫然的视野里，他看到一条白色的平行光线。很诡异的光线。他看着那道光线越发地清晰，原来是太平洋白色浪涛之间一道浓雾笼罩的珊瑚礁。接下来，在浪花之中，他看见了一条小独木船，一艘带平衡翼的独木船。在船尾处，他看见一个腰间挂着红色腰布的青铜色年轻的神灵，正挥动着闪闪发光的船桨。他认出来了。他是莫提，塔提酋长的小儿子。地点是塔希提岛。那烟雾笼罩的珊瑚礁外就是美丽的帕帕拉的土地。酋长的草屋就坐落在河口处。那会儿已经是傍晚时分，莫提正打完渔回家。他在等着大浪送他飞过珊瑚礁。这时马丁看到了自己，就像过去经常坐在独木舟的前头一样，手里握着桨，等待着莫提的命令，准备在那碧绿的大潮形成的高墙从他们身后打来的时候猛划。然后，马丁发现自己不再是看客了，而是真的坐在了船上。莫提一声大叫，两个人都开始在飞旋的碧绿高墙的峭壁上竞相奋力划桨。船下海浪嘶嘶地咆哮着，空气如同喷着水气的喷头，弥漫着飞溅的浪花，海涛的喧嚣声久久地回响着。不一会儿，独木船已经漂浮在平静的礁湖里了。莫提哈哈大笑，揉去溅进眼里的海水，两人一同把船划进了用碎珊瑚铺成的海滩旁。那儿，在夕阳里，椰子树的绿叶间露出了一片金黄色，那便是塔提草屋的墙面。 How long he sat there he did not know, until, suddenly, across his sightless vision he saw form a long horizontal line of white.It was curious.But as he watched it grow in definiteness he saw that it was a coral reef smoking in the white Pacific surges.Next, in the line of breakers he made out a small canoe, an outrigger canoe.In the stern he saw a young bronzed god in scarlet hip-cloth dipping a flashing paddle.He recognized him.He was Moti, the youngest son of Tati, the chief, and this was Tahiti, and beyond that smoking reef lay the sweet land of Papara and the chief’s grass house by the river’s mouth.It was the end of the day, and Moti was coming home from the fishing.He was waiting for the rush of a big breaker whereon to jump the reef.Then he saw himself, sitting forward in the canoe as he had often sat in the past, dipping a paddle that waited Moti’s word to dig in like mad when the turquoise wall of the great breaker rose behind them.Next, he was no longer an onlooker but was himself in the canoe, Moti was crying out, they were both thrusting hard with their paddles, racing on the steep face of the flying turquoise.Under the bow the water was hissing as from a steam jet, the air was filled with driven spray, there was a rush and rumble and long-echoing roar, and the canoe floated on the placid water of the lagoon.Moti laughed and shook the salt water from his eyes, and together they paddled in to the pounded-coral beach where Tati’s grass walls through the cocoanut-palms showed golden in the setting sun.
画面渐渐消失了。马丁眼前出现了自己肮脏凌乱的房间。他努力想再看一眼塔希提，却失败了。他知道那树丛里有歌声，月光下有姑娘们在起舞，但是他都看不见了。他看得见的只有那凌乱的书桌，打字机留下的空间，还有从未清洁过的窗玻璃。他闭上眼睛呻吟了一声，然后睡去了。 The picture faded, and before his eyes stretched the disorder of his squalid room.He strove in vain to see Tahiti again.He knew there was singing among the trees and that the maidens were dancing in the moonlight, but he could not see them.He could see only the littered writing-table, the empty space where the type-writer had stood, and the unwashed window-pane.He closed his eyes with a groan, and slept.
第四十一章 CHAPTER XLI
马丁一动不动地沉睡了一个晚上，直到上早班的邮差把他唤醒。马丁觉得又累又没精神，漫无目的地翻着信件。一家强盗杂志寄来一个薄信封，装有二十二美元的支票。他已经为这笔钱讨了一年半。他漠然地注视着这个数字。过去那种收到发表商的支票时的激动已经没有了。和以前的支票不同，这份支票不再孕育着他的伟大前程。对他而言，这只不过是一张二十二美元的支票而已，可以买点东西果腹，仅此而已。 He slept heavily all night, and did not stir until aroused by the postman on his morning round.Martin felt tired and passive, and went through his letters aimlessly.One thin envelope, from a robber magazine, contained for twenty-two dollars.He had been dunning for it for a year and a half.He noted its amount apathetically.The old-time thrill at receiving a publisher’s check was gone.Unlike his earlier checks, this one was not pregnant with promise of great things to come.To him it was a check for twenty-two dollars, that was all, and it would buy him something to eat.
同一批邮件里还有一张支票，从一家纽约周刊寄来，是几个月前被采用的一首幽默诗歌的稿酬。支票是十美元的。他突然产生了一个想法，他静静地思考着。他不知道自己将来要做什么，也不觉得要急着做什么事。此时此刻，他必须得活下去。更何况他还欠着一堆债。如果给堆在桌下的那一大堆稿子全贴上邮票，重新打发它们去旅行，这项投资会不会有什么回报呢？说不定其中一两篇能被采用。那样也能帮他活下去了。他决定做这笔投资后，就到奥克兰的银行兑了支票，买了十美元的邮票。一想到要到自己那令人窒息的小屋里煮早餐，他就觉得厌烦不已。第一次他拒绝考虑自己的债务问题。他知道在自己屋里用十五或二十美分就可以煮一顿丰盛的早餐。但他却走进了论坛咖啡馆，点了一顿两美元的早餐。他给了侍者一个二十五美分的硬币，又花了五十美分买了一包埃及香烟。这是鲁思要求他戒烟后，他第一次抽烟。不过现在他已经找不到不抽的理由了，除此之外，他还很想抽。钱又有什么关系呢？五美分他就能买一包度浪牌烟叶和一些卷烟纸，够他卷上四十支烟——但是那又怎样？此刻钱除了能立刻买到的东西之外，对他已经毫无意义了。他没有海图，也没有船舵，更没有海港可以停泊，而随波逐流意味着不必费力去生活——生活只让他痛苦。 Another check was in the same mail, sent from a New York weekly in payment for some humorous verse which had been accepted months before.It was for ten dollars.An idea came to him, which he calmly considered.He did not know what he was going to do, and he felt in no hurry to do anything.In the meantime he must live.Also he owed numerous debts.Would it not be a paying investment to put stamps on the huge pile of manuscripts under the table and start them on their travels again?One or two of them might be accepted.That would help him to live.He decided on the investment, and, after he had cashed the checks at the bank down in Oakland, he bought ten dollars’ worth of postage stamps.The thought of going home to cook breakfast in his stuffy little room was repulsive to him.For the first time he refused to consider his debts.He knew that in his room he could manufacture a substantial breakfast at a cost of from fifteen to twenty cents.But, instead, he went into the Forum Café and ordered a breakfast that cost two dollars.He tipped the waiter a quarter, and spent fifty cents for a package of Egyptian cigarettes.It was the first time he had smoked since Ruth had asked him to stop.But he could see now no reason why he should not, and besides, he wanted to smoke.And what did the money matter?For five cents he could have bought a package of Durham and brown papers and rolled forty cigarettes—but what of it?Money had no meaning to him now except what it would immediately buy.He was chartless and rudderless, and he had no port to make, while drifting involved the least living, and it was living that hurt.
日子过得飞快，他规律地每晚睡上八个小时。尽管现在，他一边等待更多的支票，一边到日本料理店去吃饭，十美分就能吃上一顿饭。他消瘦的身体开始胖起来，凹陷的双颊也丰满起来。他再也不用短暂的睡眠、过度的工作和学习来折磨自己了。他什么都不写，书本也不再打开。他常常散步，花很长时间在山上和安静的公园里闲逛。他既没有朋友也没有熟人，他也不结交新朋友。他一点儿兴趣都没有。他在等待某种不知道从哪里来的冲动，能让他这停滞的生活重新启动。与此同时，他的生活一直都那么一无所成，毫无计划，空洞而无所事事。 The days slipped along, and he slept eight hours regularly every night.Though now, while waiting for more checks, he ate in the Japanese restaurants where meals were served for ten cents, his wasted body filled out, as did the hollows in his cheeks.He no longer abused himself with short sleep, overwork, and overstudy.He wrote nothing, and the books were closed.He walked much, out in the hills, and loafed long hours in the quiet parks.He had no friends nor acquaintances, nor did he make any.He had no inclination.He was waiting for some impulse, from he knew not where, to put his stopped life into motion again.In the meantime his life remained run down, planless, and empty and idle.
有一次，他去了一趟旧金山，去看“真正的贫民窟”。但是，走上楼梯口的最后一刻，他退缩了，转身就逃进了人群蜂拥的贫民窟。一想到要听人讨论哲学他就害怕。他悄悄地逃走了，生怕哪个“真正的贫民”碰巧认出他来。 Once he made a trip to San Francisco to look up the “real dirt.”But at the last moment, as he stepped into the upstairs entrance, he recoiled and turned and fled through the swarming ghetto.He was frightened at the thought of hearing philosophy discussed, and he fled furtively, for fear that some one of the “real dirt” might chance along and recognize him.
有时，他也读读杂志和报纸，看看《蜉蝣》受到了怎样的虐待。这首诗引起了轰动。但那是怎样的轰动啊？人人都读这首诗，人人都在讨论它到底算不算一首真正的诗。当地的报纸都讨论了起来，每天都有一些充满学识的批评、吹毛求疵的社论以及一本正经的读者来信出现在专栏上。海伦·德拉·德尔马（她是在天花乱坠的口号和震声响天的鼓声中被捧成了美国最伟大的女诗人）拒绝在她的诗歌宝座旁给布里森登留一席之地。她给公众写了数不尽的信，证明他不是个诗人。 Sometimes he glanced over the magazines and newspapers to see how “Ephemera” was being maltreated.It had made a hit.But what a hit!Everybody had read it, and everybody was discussing whether or not it was really poetry.The local papers had taken it up, and daily there appeared columns of learned criticisms, facetious editorials, and serious letters from subscribers.Helen Della Delmar (proclaimed with a flourish of trumpets and rolling of tomtoms to be the greatest woman poet in the United States) denied Brissenden a seat beside her on Pegasus and wrote voluminous letters to the public, proving that he was no poet.
《帕提农》在下一期刊物里为自己是引起这轰动背后的刊物而洋洋得意，嘲讽着约翰•伐流爵士，用无情的商业手段利用着布里森登的死亡这个话题。一份自称发行量达到五十万份的报纸发表了一首海伦·德拉·德尔马自发原创的诗歌，诗中充满了对布里森登的嘲讽和讥笑。同时，她还罪恶地创作了另一首模仿布里森登的讽刺性作品。 @The Parthenon@ came out in its next number patting itself on the back for the stir it had made, sneering at Sir John Value, and exploiting Brissenden’s death with ruthless commercialism.A newspaper with a sworn circulation of half a million published an original and spontaneous poem by Helen Della Delmar, in which she gibed and sneered at Brissenden.Also, she was guilty of a second poem, in which she parodied him.
马丁不止一次庆幸布里森登已经逝去。他是那么仇恨乌合之众，而此刻他所有最美好最神圣的东西却被扔给这些人。对美的无情宰割每天都在上演着。这个国家里的每一个蠢货都在借着布里森登的伟大所引起的热潮而大发厥词，把自己干瘪的身影强塞进公众的眼里。一家报纸说：“不久前，我们收到了一位绅士的一首诗，这首诗和布里森登的作品很相像，只是更加出色。”另外一家报纸则一本正经地指责海伦•德拉•德尔马不该写那首模仿诗，说：“不过毫无疑问，德尔马小姐写那首诗时是带着嘲弄的心情的，而不是带着伟大的诗人对待别人——或许是最伟大的人——应有的尊重。然而，不管德尔马小姐是否对创作了《蜉蝣》这部作品的人存在妒忌之心，她却肯定像千万读者一样被这首诗给迷住了，总有一天她也会想写出像他那样的诗句。” Martin had many times to be glad that Brissenden was dead.He had hated the crowd so, and here all that was finest and most sacred of him had been thrown to the crowd.Daily the vivisection of Beauty went on.Every nincompoop in the land rushed into free print, floating their wizened little egos into the public eye on the surge of Brissenden’s greatness.Quoth one paper: “We have received a letter from a gentleman who wrote a poem just like it, only better, some time ago.”Another paper, in deadly seriousness, reproving Helen Della Delmar for her parody, said: “But unquestionably Miss Delmar wrote it in a moment of badinage and not quite with the respect that one great poet should show to another and perhaps to the greatest.However, whether Miss Delmar be jealous or not of the man who invented ‘Ephemera,’ it is certain that she, like thousands of others, is fascinated by his work, and that the day may come when she will try to write lines like his.”
牧师们开始布道鼓吹反对《蜉蝣》。有个牧师因为坚定地维护那首诗的大部分内容竟以异端罪被逐出了教会。这首伟大的诗歌也给这个世界带来了轻松愉快。俏皮诗作者和漫画家尖笑着抓住它，社会新闻周刊的人物专栏也把它当笑料，说是查理•福雷山姆私底下告诉阿奇•詹宁斯，读上五行《蜉蝣》就足以逼得人去殴打残疾人，读上十行《蜉蝣》就足够让他跳河自杀了。 Ministers began to preach sermons against “Ephemera,” and one, who too stoutly stood for much of its content, was expelled for heresy.The great poem contributed to the gayety of the world.The comic verse-writers and the cartoonists took hold of it with screaming laughter, and in the personal columns of society weeklies jokes were perpetrated on it to the effect that Charley Frensham told Archie Jennings, in confidence, that five lines of “Ephemera” would drive a man to beat a cripple, and that ten lines would send him to the bottom of the river.
马丁没有笑，也没有气得咬牙切齿。这一切在他身上的效果是巨大的悲伤。在一切能使他崩溃的事物中，爱情处于最顶端。与此相比，杂志王国和可亲可爱的公众的崩溃的确算不了什么。布里森登对于杂志界的判断完全正确，而马丁自己却白白花了多年的艰辛才明白过来。杂志界的确是布里森登所说的那样，而且更甚。好了，他的歌已经唱完了，他安慰着自己。他赶着马车追逐着一颗星星，结果却落在了传播疾病的泥沼中。关于塔希提岛的幻觉——那么纯洁、美丽的塔希提——越来越频繁地出现在他的脑海里。那里有低矮的保莫图思群岛，也有高耸的马克萨斯群岛。他常常看到自己正在做生意的大帆船上或是脆弱的独桅快艇上，在黎明的时候穿越帕皮提的环形礁石，开始扬帆远航，经过产珍珠的珊瑚礁，驶往努卡西瓦和泰欧黑湾。在那里，塔马瑞会杀猪欢迎他的到来，而他围着花环的女儿们会握住他的双手，伴着歌声和笑声为他戴上花环。南海在呼唤着他，他知道自己早晚会响应那呼唤的。 Martin did not laugh; nor did he grit his teeth in anger.The effect produced upon him was one of great sadness.In the crash of his whole world, with love on the pinnacle, the crash of magazinedom and the dear public was a small crash indeed.Brissenden had been wholly right in his judgment of the magazines, and he, Martin, had spent arduous and futile years in order to find it out for himself.The magazines were all Brissenden had said they were and more.Well, he was done, he solaced himself.He had hitched his wagon to a star and been landed in a pestiferous marsh.The visions of Tahiti—clean, sweet Tahiti—were coming to him more frequently.And there were the low Paumotus, and the high Marquesas;he saw himself often, now, on board trading schooners or frail little cutters, slipping out at dawn through the reef at Papeete and beginning the long beat through the pearl-atolls to Nukahiva and the Bay of Taiohae, where Tamari, he knew, would kill a pig in honor of his coming, and where Tamari’s flower-garlanded daughters would seize his hands and with song and laughter garland him with flowers.The South Seas were calling, and he knew that sooner or later he would answer the call.
现在他过着随波逐流的生活，在知识的王国里受尽长期的磨难后，他在休息着、恢复着。当《帕提农》那三百五十美元的支票转寄给他后，他将其转给了当地那位照料布里森登身后事的律师，让他转交给他的家人。马丁得到了一张收到支票的收据，同时自己也写了一张欠布里森登一百美元的收据寄了过去。 In the meantime he drifted, resting and recuperating after the long traverse he had made through the realm of knowledge.When @The Parthenon@ check of three hundred and fifty dollars was forwarded to him, he turned it over to the local lawyer who had attended to Brissenden’s affairs for his family.Martin took a receipt for the check, and at the same time gave a note for the hundred dollars Brissenden had let him have.
不久，马丁就停止光顾日本料理店了。在他决意放弃战斗的时候，命运却出现了转机。但是却来得太迟。他毫不激动地打开了一封来自《千年盛世》的厚厚的信封，看了看面值为三百美元的支票，发现是采用《冒险》这篇文章的稿酬。他在世界上欠下的每一笔债，包括高利贷的当铺债务，加起来也不超过一百元。他偿还了每一笔钱，并从布里森登的律师那儿赎回了那张借据，口袋里仍然剩下一百多块钱。他在裁缝那儿订做了一套衣服，去城里最好的餐厅里用餐。他仍然在玛利亚家的小屋子里休息，但是那一身新衣服使得附近的孩子不再躲在柴垛顶上或者骑在后门栅栏上叫他“二流子”和“懒汉”。 The time was not long when Martin ceased patronizing the Japanese restaurants.At the very moment when he had abandoned the fight, the tide turned.But it had turned too late.Without a thrill he opened a thick envelope from @The Millennium@, scanned the face of a check that represented three hundred dollars, and noted that it was the payment on acceptance for “Adventure.”Every debt he owed in the world, including the pawnshop, with its usurious interest, amounted to less than a hundred dollars.And when he had paid everything, and lifted the hundred-dollar note with Brissenden’s lawyer, he still had over a hundred dollars in pocket.He ordered a suit of clothes from the tailor and ate his meals in the best cafés in town.He still slept in his little room at Maria’s, but the sight of his new clothes caused the neighborhood children to cease from calling him “hobo” and “tramp” from the roofs of woodsheds and over back fences.
《沃伦月刊》用二百五十美元买了他的夏威夷短篇小说《维基，维基》；《北方评论》采用了他的论文《美的摇篮》；《麦金托什杂志》采用了他为玛丽安写的诗《看手相者》。编辑和读者都已经度完暑假归来，稿件的处理也快了起来。但是令马丁疑惑的是，不知他们为何一时兴，突然广泛地采用起他们两年来一直拒绝的稿子。他之前从来没有发表过任何东西。他只在奥克兰小有名气，此外没有人认识他。而在奥克兰自认为认识他的那几个人里面，他都是个臭名昭著的赤色分子，社会主义者。没有人能解释为何他的存货有了销路。实在是造化弄人。 “Wiki-Wiki,” his Hawaiian short story, was bought by @Warren’s Monthly@ for two hundred and fifty dollars.The @Northern Review@ took his essay, “The Cradle of Beauty,” and @Mackintosh’s Magazine@ took “The Palmist”—the poem he had written to Marian.The editors and readers were back from their summer vacations, and manuscripts were being handled quickly.But Martin could not puzzle out what strange whim animated them to this general acceptance of the things they had persistently rejected for two years.Nothing of his had been published.He was not known anywhere outside of Oakland, and in Oakland, with the few who thought they knew him, he was notorious as a red-shirt and a socialist.So there was no explaining this sudden acceptability of his wares.It was sheer jugglery of fate.
在被多家杂志社拒绝之后，马丁接受了过去不肯接受的布里森登的建议，开始拿出《太阳的耻辱》去一家家杂志社拜访。在被拒绝了几次之后，稿子终于被欣格垂-达恩利公司接受了，并答应在秋天出版这本书。当马丁要求预支版税时，对方回复说他们没有这种先例，而且这种性质的书一般销路不畅，他们还怀疑这书能否卖到一千册。马丁按照这个销量估摸了一下这本书能带给他的收益。按一美元一本卖的话，加上十五美分的版税，那么这本书能带给他一百五十美元。他决定了如果他还要继续写作，他就只写小说。《冒险》只有《太阳的耻辱》四分之一的长度，但是却从《千年盛世》那里得到了两倍的收入。他很久以前在报纸上读到的那段话果然说得没错。一流的杂志会立刻支付稿酬，并且还给的挺多。《千年盛世》给他的不是一个字两美分，而是四美分。更何况，他们只刊登优秀的作品，他的作品不就是这样么？想到这里，马丁咧嘴一笑。 After it had been refused by a number of magazines, he had taken Brissenden’s rejected advice and started, @The Shame of the Sun@ on the round of publishers.After several refusals, Singletree, Darnley & Co. accepted it, promising fall publication.When Martin asked for an advance on royalties, they wrote that such was not their custom, that books of that nature rarely paid for themselves, and that they doubted if his book would sell a thousand copies.Martin figured what the book would earn him on such a sale.Retailed at a dollar, on a royalty of fifteen per cent, it would bring him one hundred and fifty dollars.He decided that if he had it to do over again he would confine himself to fiction.“Adventure,” one-fourth as long, had brought him twice as much from @The Millennium@.That newspaper paragraph he had read so long ago had been true, after all.The first-class magazines did not pay on acceptance, and they paid well.Not two cents a word, but four cents a word, had @The Millennium@ paid him.And, furthermore, they bought good stuff, too, for were they not buying his?This last thought he accompanied with a grin.
他写信给欣格垂-达恩利公司，建议他们把《太阳的耻辱》以一百美元的版权费卖断，但是他们不愿冒这个风险。这会儿马丁也不缺钱花，因为他后期的几篇故事被采用并获得了稿费。实际上，他还开了一个银行账户，不仅不欠一分钱，他还有了好几百美元的存款。《过期》在被几家杂志社拒绝之后，最后卖给了梅雷迪思—洛厄尔公司。马丁还记得格特鲁德给他的那五美元以及他要还她一百倍的决心，因此他写信要求预支五百美元的版税。让他感到意外的是，这个公司立刻给他寄回了一张五百元的支票和一张合同。他把五百元全部兑换成了五元的金币，然后给格特鲁德打电话说想见她。 He wrote to Singletree, Darnley & Co., offering to sell out his rights in @The Shame of the Sun@ for a hundred dollars, but they did not care to take the risk.In the meantime he was not in need of money, for several of his later stories had been accepted and paid for.He actually opened a bank account, where, without a debt in the world, he had several hundred dollars to his credit. @Overdue@, after having been declined by a number of magazines, came to rest at the Meredith-Lowell Company.Martin remembered the five dollars Gertrude had given him, and his resolve to return it to her a hundred times over; so he wrote for an advance on royalties of five hundred dollars.To his surprise a check for that amount, accompanied by a contract, came by return mail.He cashed the check into five-dollar gold pieces and telephoned Gertrude that he wanted to see her.
格特鲁德急匆匆地赶来，进屋子的时候还气喘吁吁。预感到可能又有麻烦了，她把手边仅有的几美元塞进了手挎包里。她以为弟弟遇到了什么不好的事情，一见到马丁就立刻踉跄着扑进他怀里，抽泣着，同时不声不响地把包塞进他手里。 She arrived at the house panting and short of breath from the haste she had made.Apprehensive of trouble, she had stuffed the few dollars she possessed into her hand-satchel; and so sure was she that disaster had overtaken her brother, that she stumbled forward, sobbing, into his arms, at the same time thrusting the satchel mutely at him.
“我本来想亲自去，”他说，“但是我不想和希金博特姆先生起冲突，我要是去了肯定得吵起来。” “I’d have come myself,” he said.“But I didn’t want a row with Mr. Higginbotham, and that is what would have surely happened.”
“过段时间他就会好的，”她向他保证，同时在猜测着马丁到底遇到了什么麻烦，“但是你最好先找个工作安定下来。伯纳德喜欢看见别人老老实实地工作。报纸上的那些东西气得他直跳脚。我从来没见过他发这么大脾气。” “He’ll be all right after a time,” she assured him, while she wondered what the trouble was that Martin was in.“But you’d best get a job first an’ steady down.Bernard does like to see a man at honest work.That stuff in the newspapers broke ’m all up.I never saw ’m so mad before.”
“我不会找工作，”马丁笑着说，“你就这么和他说。我不需要工作，这就是证明。” “I’m not going to get a job,” Martin said with a smile.“And you can tell him so from me.I don’t need a job, and there’s the proof of it.”
他把那一百枚金币都倒进了她的裙兜里，金灿灿的钱币叮当作响。 He emptied the hundred gold pieces into her lap in a glinting, tinkling stream.
“你还记得我没有车费的时候你给我的那五块钱么？”看，这就是那五块钱，还有它的九十九个兄弟，年龄不同，大小一样。” “You remember that fiver you gave me the time I didn’t have carfare?Well, there it is, with ninety-nine brothers of different ages but all of the same size.”
如果格特鲁德到这儿的时候心里害怕的话，那么她现在已经是惊慌失措了。她的害怕已是事实。她没有怀疑。她相信自己的判断。她惊恐地看着马丁，在金币的重压之下她沉重的两腿开始发软，就像被火烧了似的。 If Gertrude had been frightened when she arrived, she was now in a panic of fear.Her fear was such that it was certitude.She was not suspicious.She was convinced.She looked at Martin in horror, and her heavy limbs shrank under the golden stream as though it were burning her.
“这钱都是你的了。”马丁大笑起来。 “It’s yours,” he laughed.
她大哭起来，开始悲叹：“我可怜的弟弟啊，我可怜的弟弟啊！” She burst into tears, and began to moan, “My poor boy, my poor boy!”
马丁一时之间没反应过来。然后才明白她为什么难过，便把梅雷迪思—洛厄尔公司寄来的信和发票递给她看。她磕磕绊绊地读着信，时不时地停下来抹泪。读完之后，她说： He was puzzled for a moment.Then he divined the cause of her agitation and handed her the Meredith-Lowell letter which had accompanied the check.She stumbled through it, pausing now and again to wipe her eyes, and when she had finished, said:—
“这是不是意味着你的钱是光明正大挣来的？” “An’ does it mean that you come by the money honestly?”
“比中彩票还来得正大光明，这都是我自己挣的。” “More honestly than if I’d won it in a lottery.I earned it.”
慢慢地，信任回到了她的心里，她又认真把信读了一遍。马丁花了好一会儿才向她解释清楚这笔交易是什么性质的，怎么成为他的收入的，又花了更多的功夫才让她明白那些钱是给她的，他不需要钱。 Slowly faith came back to her, and she reread the letter carefully.It took him long to explain to her the nature of the transaction which had put the money into his possession, and longer still to get her to understand that the money was really hers and that he did not need it.
“我给你存进银行里去。”她最后说。 “I’ll put it in the bank for you,” she said finally.
“你别这么干。这就是你的，你想怎么花怎么花。你要是不收的话我就给玛丽安了。她知道该怎么花钱。我建议你请个佣人，自己好好地休息休息。” “You’ll do nothing of the sort.It’s yours, to do with as you please, and if you won’t take it, I’ll give it to Maria.She’ll know what to do with it.I’d suggest, though, that you hire a servant and take a good long rest.”
“我会把这一切都告诉伯纳德的。”她临走的时候宣布说。 “I’m goin’ to tell Bernard all about it,” she announced, when she was leaving.
马丁眨眨眼，笑了。 Martin winced, then grinned.
“那就告诉他吧，”他说,“说不定不久他又会请我去吃饭了。” “Yes, do.” he said.“And then, maybe, he’ll invite me to dinner again.”
“是的，他当然会——我很肯定他会的。”她高兴地叫了起来，并把他拉到身边亲吻他，拥抱他。 “Yes, he will—I’m sure he will!” she exclaimed fervently, as she drew him to her and kissed and hugged him.
第四十二章 CHAPTER XLII
一天，马丁意识到自己很寂寞。他身体强壮健康，却无所事事。写作和学习的中止，布里森登的逝去，与鲁思的分手，这一切都在他的生命里戳了个大洞。而他也不肯坐在咖啡馆里抽着埃及香烟，把生活固定在悠闲的活法上，。没错，南海还在召唤着他，但他有种感觉，在美国的游戏还没有结束。他有两本书快要出版了，还有更多的书可能会寻找到出版的机会。他还能赚一些钱，他想等到攒够满满一口袋钱带到南海去。他知道在马克萨斯群岛有一个峡谷和一道海湾，只要花上一千智利元就能买到。那道峡谷从被陆地包围的马蹄铁形海湾开始蜿蜒，一直到云朵环绕的令人晕眩的峰顶，约摸有一万英亩。峡谷里满是热带水果、野鸡、野猪，偶然还会出现成群的野牛。而山巅之上还有成群的野山羊，它们会受到一群群野狗的侵扰。这整片土地就是一片荒野。这里荒无人烟。而他只需花一千智利元就能买到这个海湾。 One day Martin became aware that he was lonely.He was healthy and strong, and had nothing to do.The cessation from writing and studying, the death of Brissenden, and the estrangement from Ruth had made a big hole in his life; and his life refused to be pinned down to good living in cafés and the smoking of Egyptian cigarettes.It was true the South Seas were calling to him, but he had a feeling that the game was not yet played out in the United States.Two books were soon to be published, and he had more books that might find publication.Money could be made out of them, and he would wait and take a sackful of it into the South Seas.He knew a valley and a bay in the Marquesas that he could buy for a thousand Chili dollars.The valley ran from the horseshoe, land-locked bay to the tops of the dizzy, cloud-capped peaks and contained perhaps ten thousand acres.It was filled with tropical fruits, wild chickens, and wild pigs, with an occasional herd of wild cattle, while high up among the peaks were herds of wild goats harried by packs of wild dogs.The whole place was wild.Not a human lived in it. And he could buy it and the bay for a thousand Chili dollars.
他记忆中，那海湾风景壮丽，水深得连最大的船只都可以停泊，又很安全，《南太平洋指南》把它介绍为周围几百英里之内最好的船舶检修处。他想买一艘帆船——像游艇那样，用铜皮包裹起来，行驶起来犹如有巫师——用来到岛屿之间做椰子干和珍珠生意。他要把海湾和峡谷打造成自己的大本营。他还想要修建一座类似塔提家的那种草屋，让草屋、峡谷和大帆船里都满是黑皮肤的仆人。他要在那儿宴请泰欧黑的商务代办、来来往往的商船船长和所有南太平洋流浪汉中头号人物。他要像王公贵族一样大宴宾客。他也要忘掉自己读过的书，忘掉那个实为幻觉的世界。 The bay, as he remembered it, was magnificent, with water deep enough to accommodate the largest vessel afloat, and so safe that the @South Pacific Directory@ recommended it to the best careening place for ships for hundreds of miles around.He would buy a schooner—one of those yacht-like, coppered crafts that sailed like witches—and go trading copra and pearling among the islands.He would make the valley and the bay his headquarters.He would build a patriarchal grass house like Tati’s, and have it and the valley and the schooner filled with dark-skinned servitors.He would entertain there the factor of Taiohae, captains of wandering traders, and all the best of the South Pacific riffraff.He would keep open house and entertain like a prince.And he would forget the books he had opened and the world that had proved an illusion.
为了达成这些目的，他必须呆在加利福尼亚，等着自己的口袋装满钱。钱已经源源不断地流进来了。只要一本书有了销路，就有可能让他他卖掉那一整堆的稿件。他还可以把小说和诗歌集结成书，保证能把那峡谷、海湾和大帆船买到手。他再也不会写东西了。这是他早决定好的。但是在等着书一本本出版的同时，他总得做点事，而不是像沉浸在类似什么都不在乎的恍惚中，浑浑噩噩，什么都不做。 To do all this he must wait in California to fill the sack with money.Already it was beginning to flow in.If one of the books made a strike, it might enable him to sell the whole heap of manuscripts.Also he could collect the stories and the poems into books, and make sure of the valley and the bay and the schooner.He would never write again.Upon that he was resolved.But in the meantime, awaiting the publication of the books, he must do something more than live dazed and stupid in the sort of uncaring trance into which he had fallen.
某个周日早晨，他听说砌砖工野餐会要在贝陵公园举行，就去了那里。他早年经常参加工人阶级的野餐会，对情形都非常熟悉。他一走进公园，往日的苦辣酸甜都禁不住涌向心头。毕竟，这些劳动人民是他的同类。他是在他们之间出生和长大的，虽然他曾走失过一阵子，但终究又回到了他们之中。 He noted, one Sunday morning, that the Bricklayers’ Picnic took place that day at Shell Mound Park, and to Shell Mound Park he went.He had been to the working-class picnics too often in his earlier life not to know what they were like, and as he entered the park he experienced a recrudescence of all the old sensations.After all, they were his kind, these working people.He had been born among them, he had lived among them, and though he had strayed for a time, it was well to come back among them.
“这不是马丁吗？”他听见有人说，紧接着就有一只温暖的大手搭在他肩上， “If it ain’t Mart!” he heard some one say, and the next moment a hearty hand was on his shoulder.
“这么些日子你都到哪儿去了？是去出海了么？快来，喝一杯。” “Where you ben all the time?Off to sea?Come on an’ have a drink.”
