他发现自己又回到了老朋友之中——那些老朋友，不过少了几张旧面孔，多了几张新面孔。这些人并不是砌砖工，但跟以前一样都是来参加星期天的野餐会的，跳舞，打架滋事，找找乐子。马丁跟他们一起喝着酒，开始觉得自己重新像个真正的人了。他觉得自己当初离开他们的举动就像傻子一样。他十分肯定如果他没有去读书，没有去和那些身居高位者打交道，而是一直跟这些人在一起，他会更幸福。但是，那啤酒的味道却不如往昔了。啤酒的味道也不似往昔的味道了。一定是布里森登毁了他对高泡沫啤酒的胃口，马丁下结论，又猜想着，那些书是否已经破坏了他跟这些少时的朋友间的友谊。他决心不那么纵容自己，便起身到舞池去跳舞。他在那里碰见水暖工吉米正在跟一个金发高个的女孩跳舞。那女孩一见马丁便立刻丢下吉米。 It was the old crowd in which he found himself—the old crowd, with here and there a gap, and here and there a new face.The fellows were not bricklayers, but, as in the old days, they attended all Sunday picnics for the dancing, and the fighting, and the fun.Martin drank with them, and began to feel really human once more.He was a fool to have ever left them, he thought; and he was very certain that his sum of happiness would have been greater had he remained with them and let alone the books and the people who sat in the high places.Yet the beer seemed not so good as of yore.It didn’t taste as it used to taste.Brissenden had spoiled him for steam beer, he concluded, and wondered if, after all, the books had spoiled him for companionship with these friends of his youth.He resolved that he would not be so spoiled, and he went on to the dancing pavilion.Jimmy, the plumber, he met there, in the company of a tall, blond girl who promptly forsook him for Martin.
“哎呀，还是跟从前一样啊。”马丁和那女孩转着圈跳起华尔兹来，大家对吉米大笑起来，吉米解释道，“我才不在乎呢。看到马丁回来了，我高兴死了。你看他那华尔兹跳的，嗯？像丝绸一样。难怪姑娘们喜欢他。” “Gee, it’s like old times,” Jimmy explained to the gang that gave him the laugh as Martin and the blonde whirled away in a waltz.“An’ I don’t give a rap.I’m too damned glad to see ’m back.Watch ’m waltz, eh?It’s like silk.Who’d blame any girl?”
但是马丁把那金发女孩还给了吉米。三个人和六七个朋友一起看着舞池子里的一对对舞伴转着的圈子，彼此开着玩笑，乐呵的。大家看见马丁回来都很开心。在他们眼里，他并没有出版过什么书，身上也没有什么虚构的价值。大家都是因为他本人而喜欢他。他觉得自己像个流放归来的王子，一颗寂寞的心灵沐浴在真情实意中渐渐含苞待放。他玩得很疯狂，很尽兴。而且他口袋里有钱，就像当年出海归来刚发工资一样，挥霍着手中的钱。 But Martin restored the blonde to Jimmy, and the three of them, with half a dozen friends, watched the revolving couples and laughed and joked with one another.Everybody was glad to see Martin back.No book of his been published; he carried no fictitious value in their eyes.They liked him for himself.He felt like a prince returned from excile, and his lonely heart burgeoned in the geniality in which it bathed.He made a mad day of it, and was at his best.Also, he had money in his pockets, and, as in the old days when he returned from sea with a pay-day, he made the money fly.
有一回，他在舞池里见到了莉齐·康诺利。一个年轻工人正搂着她从他身边走过。之后，他在舞场里跳舞，又看见她坐在一张茶点桌旁边。两人一番惊讶和问候之后，他便领着她去到操场，在那里他们可以不必用高声谈话来压倒音乐声。从他对她说话的那一刻起，她就已经成了他的人了。这点他很清楚。她那谦卑而又傲慢的眼神，那得意的身姿和妩媚的一举一动，那听他说话时专注的神情，无不流露出了这一点。她再也不是他以前所认识的那个小姑娘了。如今她已出落成了一个女人。马丁注意到，她大胆野性的美更进了一步，野性依然不减，但大胆和火辣却温和了些。“美人，绝代的美人。”马丁为她倾倒了，自己低声喃喃地说。他知道她属于他，只要他说一声“来”，她就会义无反顾地跟着他到世界的任何地方。 Once, on the dancing-floor, he saw Lizzie Connolly go by in the arms of a young workingman; and, later, when he made the round of the pavilion, he came upon her sitting by a refreshment table.Surprise and greetings over, he led her away into the grounds, where they could talk without shouting down the music.From the instant he spoke to her, she was his.He knew it.She showed it in the proud humility of her eyes, in every caressing movement of her proudly carried body, and in the way she hung upon his speech.She was not the young girl as he had known her.She was a woman, now, and Martin noted that her wild, defiant beauty had improved, losing none of its wildness, while the defiance and the fire seemed more in control.“A beauty, a perfect beauty,” he murmured admiringly under his breath.And he knew she was his, that all he had to do was to say “Come,” and she would go with him over the world wherever he led.
这些念头才刚闪过他的脑海，头一边就挨了重重一击，几乎被打倒在地。那是一个男人的拳头，他打得太愤怒，也太急促。那一拳原本想打在马丁的下巴上，却打偏了。马丁摇摇晃晃地转过身子，只见那拳头又狠狠挥了过来。他便顺势一弯腰，那一拳落了空，那人身子转了过去。马丁左手一个勾拳，落到那人身上，落拳加上自己的身体重量使那人旋转起来。那人侧身倒地，又翻身跳起，疯狂地扑了上来。马丁看到他那气急败坏的脸色，心里满是纳闷，到底是什么事让他这么气急败坏。可是他一边想，一边左手又使出全身力气挥出了一个直拳。那人头着地打了个跟斗，瘫倒在那里。吉米和那一帮的其他人急忙向他们跑来。 Even as the thought flashed through his brain he received a heavy blow on the side of his head that nearly knocked him down.It was a man’s fist, directed by a man so angry and in such haste that the fist had missed the jaw for which it was aimed.Martin turned as he staggered, and saw the fist coming at him in a wild swing.Quite as a matter of course he ducked, and the fist flew harmlessly past, pivoting the man who had driven it.Martin hooked with his left, landing on the pivoting man with the weight of his body behind the blow.The man went to the ground sidewise, leaped to his feet, and made a mad rush.Martin saw his passion-distorted face and wondered what could be the cause of the fellow’s anger.But while he wondered, he shot in a straight left, the weight of his body behind the blow.The man went over backward and fell in a crumpled heap.Jimmy and others of the gang were running toward them.
马丁浑身激动不已。从前的日子又回来了：结梁子、跳舞、打架、说说笑笑。他一边机警地盯着对手，一边瞥了莉齐一眼。平时小伙子们打架的时候女人们都会尖叫，可是莉齐没有。她屏住呼吸饶有兴趣地看着，身子微微前倾，一只手压在胸前，双颊绯红，眼里满是惊讶和崇拜。 Martin was thrilling all over.This was the old days with a vengeance, with their dancing, and their fighting, and their fun.While he kept a wary eye on his antagonist, he glanced at Lizzie.Usually the girls screamed when the fellows got to scrapping, but she had not screamed.She was looking on with bated breath, leaning slightly forward, so keen was her interest, one hand pressed to her breast, her cheek flushed, and in her eyes a great and amazed admiration.
那人已经站起身来，想要挣脱拽住他的那几条胳臂。 The man had gained his feet and was struggling to escape the restraining arms that were laid on him.
“她在等我回来！”他对周围的人解释道。“她在等我回来，可这个新到的家伙却跑来插足。把我放开，告诉你们，我得给他点颜色瞧瞧。” “She was waitin’ for me to come back!” he was proclaiming to all and sundry.“She was waitin’ for me to come back, an’ then that fresh guy comes buttin’ in.Let go o’ me, I tell yeh. I’m goin’ to fix ’m.”
“你凭什么生气？”吉米一边质问着，一边帮忙劝架。“这人是马丁·伊登。他的拳头可厉害着呢。告诉你吧，你要是惹恼了他，他能把你活活吃了。” “What’s eatin’ yer?”Jimmy was demanding, as he helped hold the young fellow back.“That guy’s Mart Eden.He’s nifty with his mits, lemme tell you that, an’ he’ll eat you alive if you monkey with ’m.”
“我不能让他就那么把她从我身边偷走。”对方插嘴道。 “He can’t steal her on me that way,” the other interjected.
“他连荷兰飞人都干掉了。你总认识荷兰飞人吧，”吉米继续劝解，“他五个回合就把荷兰飞人打趴下了。你要是跟他打，连一分钟也撑不住。知道不？” “He licked the Flyin’ Dutchman, an’ you know him,” Jimmy went on expostulating.“An’ he did it in five rounds.You couldn’t last a minute against him.See?”
这番劝告似乎缓解了紧张的气氛，那气冲冲的年轻人瞪大眼睛打量了马丁一会儿。 This information seemed to have a mollifying effect, and the irate young man favored Martin with a measuring stare.
“他看起来可不像那块料。”他冷笑着，但笑得没什么底气。 “He don’t look it,” he sneered; but the sneer was without passion.
“当初荷兰飞人也是那么想的，”吉米向他担保，“行了，咱别再提这事了。姑娘多的是呢，算了吧。” “That’s what the Flyin’ Dutchman thought,” Jimmy assured him.“Come on, now, let’s get outa this.There’s lots of other girls. Come on.”
那青年接受了劝告，领着一群人往舞池奔去了。 The young fellow allowed himself to be led away toward the pavilion, and the gang followed after him.
“他是谁？”马丁问莉齐， “Who is he?” Martin asked Lizzie.
“他这么胡闹究竟是为了什么？” “And what’s it all about, anyway?”
当年对打架的那种强烈执着的狂热已经不再。马丁发现自己太爱自我分析了，他再也不能像以前那样心无杂念，独来独往，淳朴野蛮地活下去了。 Already the zest of combat, which of old had been so keen and lasting, had died down, and he discovered that he was self-analytical, too much so to live, single heart and single hand, so primitive an existence.
莉齐脑袋一甩。 Lizzie tossed her head.
“哦，他谁也不是，”她说，“不过陪陪我罢了。” “Oh, he’s nobody,” she said.“He’s just ben keepin’ company with me.”
“我得有人陪，你知道的，”她停了一会儿，说道，“我越来越寂寞，但是我从来没有忘记过你。”她低下声音，眼睛直直地盯着前面。“为了你我随时可以把他甩掉。” “I had to, you see,” she explained after a pause.“I was gettin’ pretty lonesome.But I never forgot.”Her voice sank lower, and she looked straight before her.“I’d throw ’m down for you any time.”
马丁看着她头扭到一边，知道只要他一伸手就可以把她揽过来。但他却在心里沉思着优美的合乎语法的英语究竟有什么真正的价值，因此忘记了回复她的话。 Martin looking at her averted face, knowing that all he had to do was to reach out his hand and pluck her, fell to pondering whether, after all, there was any real worth in refined, grammatical English, and, so, forgot to reply to her.
“你把他打了个落花流水。”她笑了笑，试探着说。 “You put it all over him,” she said tentatively, with a laugh.
“不过他倒也是个结实的小伙子，”他坦诚道，“要不是别人把他劝走了，他可能还得带给我许多麻烦呢。” “He’s a husky young fellow, though,” he admitted generously.“If they hadn’t taken him away, he might have given me my hands full.”
“有天晚上我看见你和一个女的在一起，那是谁呢？”她突然问道。 “Who was that lady friend I seen you with that night?” she asked abruptly.
“啊，只是一个女性朋友。”他答道。 “Oh, just a lady friend,” was his answer.
“那已是很久很久以前了，”她沉思地说，“好像都有一千年了呢。” “It was a long time ago,” she murmured contemplatively.“It seems like a thousand years.”
但是马丁没有接这个话题。而是把谈话引到了别的地方。他们在餐馆吃午饭。他在那儿点了美酒和昂贵精美的佳肴，吃过便和她跳舞。他不再跟别人跳，只跟她跳，直到她筋疲力尽为止。他是个很好的舞者，她跟他一圈一圈地跳着，感到如天堂般幸福。她的头依偎在他肩上，恨不得能这样一直跳下去。下午他们钻进了树林。按古老的好习俗，她在树林里坐了下来，让他四肢舒展地躺着，把头枕在她腿上。他躺在那儿打盹，她用手抚摩着他的头发，低头看他闭上的眼睛，尽情地爱抚着他。他突然睁开眼睛，看出了她满脸的柔情蜜意。她的目光往下一闪，睁得很大，带着不顾一切的温情直勾勾地看着他的眼睛。 But Martin went no further into the matter.He led the conversation off into other channels.They had lunch in the restaurant, where he ordered wine and expensive delicacies and afterward he danced with her and with no one but her, till she was tired.He was a good dancer, and she whirled around and around with him in a heaven of delight, her head against his shoulder, wishing that it could last forever.Later in the afternoon they strayed off among the trees, where, in the good old fashion, she sat down while he sprawled on his back, his head in her lap.He lay and dozed, while she fondled his hair, looked down on his closed eyes, and loved him without reserve.Looking up suddenly, he read the tender advertisement in her face.Her eyes fluttered down, then they opened and looked into his with soft defiance.
“我这几年一直都规规矩矩。”她低声说着，几乎像在说悄悄话。 “I’ve kept straight all these years,” she said, her voice so low that it was almost a whisper.
在他心底里，马丁知道那是一个奇迹般的事实。一种巨大的诱惑从他心里升起。他是有能力让她幸福的。他自己得不到幸福的垂青，可他为什么不能让她幸福呢？他可以和她结婚，带她到马克萨斯草墙砌成的堡垒居住。这个愿望很强烈，但是更强烈的是他毅然否定那愿望的天性。尽管他并不愿意承认这个事实，但他仍然忠实于爱情。往日年少轻狂的日子已经一去不返。他再也回不到那些日子，而那些日子也不再回到他的身边。他变了——直到现在他才知道自己的变化有多大。 In his heart Martin knew that it was the miraculous truth.And at his heart pleaded a great temptation.It was in his power to make her happy.Denied happiness himself, why should he deny happiness to her?He could marry her and take her down with him to dwell in the grass-walled castle in the Marquesas.The desire to do it was strong, but stronger still was the imperative command of his nature not to do it.In spite of himself he was still faithful to Love.The old days of license and easy living were gone.He could not bring them back, nor could he go back to them.He was changed—how changed he had not realized until now.
“我不是结婚过日子的人，莉齐。”他淡淡地说。 “I am not a marrying man, Lizzie,” he said lightly.
抚摩他头发的手明显停止了摩挲，接着又温柔地抚摩起来。他注意到她的脸色变得僵硬了，但却是下定了决心似的僵硬，因为她脸上还有温柔的红晕，依然容光焕发，依然沉醉美丽。 The hand caressing his hair paused perceptibly, then went on with the same gentle stroke.He noticed her face harden, but it was with the hardness of resolution, for still the soft color was in her cheeks and she was all glowing and melting.
“我不是那意思——”她刚一开口，又犹豫了，“或者说我并不在乎。” “I did not mean that—” she began, then faltered.“Or anyway I don’t care.”
“我不在乎，”她重复说，“能成为你的朋友，我已经感到很骄傲了。我可以为你做任何事。我猜这就是我命中注定的。” “I don’t care,” she repeated.“I’m proud to be your friend.I’d do anything for you.I’m made that way, I guess.”
马丁直起身子。他抓住了她的手。他的握手不慌不忙地，有温度但却没有激情，很温暖，却叫她心里不禁打了一个冷颤。 Martin sat up.He took her hand in his.He did it deliberately, with warmth but without passion; and such warmth chilled her.
“我们别谈这个了吧。”她说。 “Don’t let’s talk about it,” she said.
“你是个高贵而了不起的女人，”他说，“应该是我为认识你而骄傲，而我确实感到骄傲，很骄傲。你是我那漆黑的世界里的一缕光明。我对你应当规规矩矩，就像你一向规规矩矩一样。” “You are a great and noble woman,” he said.“And it is I who should be proud to know you.And I am, I am.You are a ray of light to me in a very dark world, and I’ve got to be straight with you, just as straight as you have been.”
“我不在乎你是否对我规规矩矩，你爱怎么对我就怎么对我，你可以把我甩到地上，再踩在我身上。在这个世界上，只有你才可以这样对我。”她的眼光又发出那种目空一切的光芒。“我从小就一无是处，从那时起我就没怎么照顾过自己。” “I don’t care whether you’re straight with me or not.You could do anything with me.You could throw me in the dirt an’ walk on me.An’ you’re the only man in the world that can,” she added with a defiant flash.“I ain’t taken care of myself ever since I was a kid for nothin’.”
“正因为你如此，我才不能对你如此轻率，”他温情脉脉地说，“你心地宽厚，也叫我不禁随着你一起心地宽厚。我不打算结婚，而且也不打算光恋爱不结婚，虽然以前曾经那么做过。我很抱歉，今天到这里来遇见了你，可现在已经无可奈何。我从没有想到会出现这样的局面。 “And it’s just because of that that I’m not going to,” he said gently.“You are so big and generous that you challenge me to equal generousness.I’m not marrying, and I’m not—well, loving without marrying, though I’ve done my share of that in the past.I’m sorry I came here to-day and met you.But it can’t be helped now, and I never expected it would turn out this way.”
“可是听我说，莉齐，我不知道该怎么开始告诉你我有多喜欢你。我不仅是喜欢，而且是佩服你，尊敬你。你非常了不起，而且善良得非常了不起。可是光说又有什么用？我还想为你做一件事。你生活一直困难，我想让你过得好一些。（此时莉齐眼里闪现出了喜悦的光芒，却又立刻暗淡了下来。）我有把握很快就会得到一笔钱——很多钱。” “But look here, Lizzie.I can’t begin to tell you how much I like you.I do more than like you.I admire and respect you.You are magnificent, and you are magnificently good.But what’s the use of words?Yet there’s something I’d like to do.You’ve had a hard life; let me make it easy for you.”(A joyous light welled into her eyes, then faded out again.) “I’m pretty sure of getting hold of some money soon—lots of it.”
在那一瞬间他已放弃了峡谷、海湾、草墙堡垒和白色大帆船。说到底，那些东西又算得了什么？他还可以像过去那样，去当水手，无论上什么船、去什么地方都行。 In that moment he abandoned the idea of the valley and the bay, the grass-walled castle and the trim, white schooner.After all, what did it matter?He could go away, as he had done so often, before the mast, on any ship bound anywhere.
“我想把那钱转送给你。你总有什么想要的东西吧——上个学，读商业学院什么的。可能你想学着当个速记员。我都可以为你安排。也许你的父母还健在——我可以给钱让他们开个杂货店什么的。任何你想要的东西，你只要说出来我都可以给你办到。” “I’d like to turn it over to you.There must be something you want—to go to school or business college.You might like to study and be a stenographer.I could fix it for you.Or maybe your father and mother are living—I could set them up in a grocery store or something.Anything you want, just name it, and I can fix it for you.”
她默不作声,一动不动地坐着，眼睛直勾勾地望着前面。眼里没有眼泪，喉咙却疼痛起来，那哽咽的声音马丁能强烈地感觉到，他的喉咙也不禁疼痛起来。他后悔说了刚才的话。比起她向他奉献的东西，他的所能给她的好像太俗气了——不过是钱而已。钱是可以随便放弃而无关紧要的身外之物，但是她向他奉献的却是她自己，与之相伴的是耻辱、难堪、罪孽，以及她进入天堂的希望。 She made no reply, but sat, gazing straight before her, dry-eyed and motionless, but with an ache in the throat which Martin divined so strongly that it made his own throat ache.He regretted that he had spoken.It seemed so tawdry what he had offered her—mere money—compared with what she offered him.He offered her an extraneous thing with which he could part without a pang, while she offered him herself, along with disgrace and shame, and sin, and all her hopes of heaven.
“不说了。”她声音哽咽了，却装作是咳嗽。她站起身来。“算了，我们回家去吧，我很疲惫了。” “Don’t let’s talk about it,” she said with a catch in her voice that she changed to a cough.She stood up.“Come on, let’s go home.I’m all tired out.”
一天已经过去，寻欢作乐的人们差不多都走光了。但是当马丁和莉齐走出林子时，发现有群人还在等着他们。马丁立刻明白了。他遇到麻烦了。那群人是被他打的那人的保缥。他们一起从公园大门走了出去，另外还有一群人三三两两跟在后面。那是丽齐的小伙子纠合来报复夺女友之恨的。几个巡警和特别警官怕出什么乱子，也紧紧地跟在后面，准备随时制止。然后两群人分别上了去旧金山的火车。马丁告诉吉米他要在十六路站下车，再转乘去奥克兰的电车。莉齐非常安静，对迫在眉睫的骚乱漠不关心。火车开进了十六路站，等在那儿的电车已经在等客人了，售票员正不耐烦地敲着锣。 The day was done, and the merrymakers had nearly all departed.But as Martin and Lizzie emerged from the trees they found the gang waiting for them.Martin knew immediately the meaning of it.Trouble was brewing.The gang was his body-guard.They passed out through the gates of the park with, straggling in the rear, a second gang, the friends that Lizzie’s young man had collected to avenge the loss of his lady.Several constables and special police officers, anticipating trouble, trailed along to prevent it, and herded the two gangs separately aboard the train for San Francisco.Martin told Jimmy that he would get off at Sixteenth Street Station and catch the electric car into Oakland.Lizzie was very quiet and without interest in what was impending.The train pulled in to Sixteenth Street Station, and the waiting electric car could be seen, the conductor of which was impatiently clanging the gong.
“电车已经到了，”吉米给马丁出主意，“冲到车上去，我们来挡住他们。现在就走！冲上车去！” “There she is,” Jimmy counselled.“Make a run for it, an’ we’ll hold ’em back.Now you go!Hit her up!”
寻仇的人群看到这场景一时不知如何是好，也立刻冲下火车追了上来。坐在车上的清醒平静的奥克兰乘客们几乎没注意到外面正有一个小伙子和一个姑娘急匆匆地跑来赶车，并且在靠外的边上找到了座位。他们也没有把这对人和吉米联系起来，吉米已经跳上踏板，向驾驶员叫嚷着： The hostile gang was temporarily disconcerted by the manoeuvre, then it dashed from the train in pursuit.The staid and sober Oakland folk who sat upon the car scarcely noted the young fellow and the girl who ran for it and found a seat in front on the outside.They did not connect the couple with Jimmy, who sprang on the steps, crying to the motorman:—
“加足马力，老兄，开出去！” “Slam on the juice, old man, and beat it outa here!”
紧接着吉米便猛地一转身，车上的乘客们看见他一拳打在一个要想跳上车来的人脸上。但是沿着整个电车的一侧，已有许多拳头打在了许多脸上。吉米和他的同伴们沿着又长又低矮的台阶排成了一行，迎击了进攻的人。电车在一声响亮的锣声中开动了。吉米的人赶走了最后的袭击者，又跳下车去结束了这场战斗。电车一路飞驰而去，把这场混战远远地抛在了后面。目瞪口呆的乘客们做梦也没有想到，坐在靠外的角落里座位上的那个文静的青年和漂亮的女工竟会是这场骚乱的原因。 The next moment Jimmy whirled about, and the passengers saw him land his fist on the face of a running man who was trying to board the car.But fists were landing on faces the whole length of the car.Thus, Jimmy and his gang, strung out on the long, lower steps, met the attacking gang.The car started with a great clanging of its gong, and, as Jimmy’s gang drove off the last assailants, they, too, jumped off to finish the job.The car dashed on, leaving the flurry of combat far behind, and its dumfounded passengers never dreamed that the quiet young man and the pretty working-girl sitting in the corner on the outside seat had been the cause of the row.
马丁刚才还在欣赏这场打斗，往日那种参加斗殴时刺激的感觉仿佛又重回心头。但是那快感迅速消失，他被一种巨大的悲凉感压得喘不过气来。他觉得自己已经老了——比起这些个无忧无虑逍遥自在的昔日的玩伴们，他已经老了许多个世纪。他走得太远，再也回不来了。他们这种生活方式当年也是他的生活方式，现在却令他感到反感。他对这一切都感到失望。他已经俨然成了个局外人。正如高泡沫啤酒已经淡而无味，跟他们的友谊也一样淡而无味了。他和他们距离太远。在他和他们之间，成千上万翻开的书本构筑了巨大的鸿沟。他把自己放逐了。他在辽阔智慧的王国里漫游得太远，已经无法回头了。可另一方面，他还是人，他喜爱社交的天性和对友谊的渴求还是需要得到满足。他还没找到新的归宿。那些朋友不可能了解他，他的家人不可能了解他，资产阶级不可能了解他，就连身边这个他很尊重的姑娘也不可能了解他。她也不可能了解他对她的尊重。他思前想后，悲凉之中掺进了几分辛酸。 Martin had enjoyed the fight, with a recrudescence of the old fighting thrills.But they quickly died away, and he was oppressed by a great sadness.He felt very old—centuries older than those careless, care-free young companions of his others days.He had travelled far, too far to go back.Their mode of life, which had once been his, was now distasteful to him.He was disappointed in it all.He had developed into an alien.As the steam beer had tasted raw, so their companionship seemed raw to him.He was too far removed.Too many thousands of opened books yawned between them and him.He had exiled himself.He had travelled in the vast realm of intellect until he could no longer return home.On the other hand, he was human, and his gregarious need for companionship remained unsatisfied.He had found no new home.As the gang could not understand him, as his own family could not understand him, as the bourgeoisie could not understand him, so this girl beside him, whom he honored high, could not understand him nor the honor he paid her.His sadness was not untouched with bitterness as he thought it over.
“跟他和好吧。”分手的时候他劝莉齐，这时他俩已来到了六号路和市场街附近莉齐居住的工人棚屋前。他指的是那被他侵犯了男友地位的青年人。 “Make it up with him,” he advised Lizzie, at parting, as they stood in front of the workingman’s shack in which she lived, near Sixth and Market.He referred to the young fellow whose place he had usurped that day.
“我做不到——现在做不到了。”她说。 “I can’t—now,” she said.
“啊，去做吧。”他故作欢喜地说。“你只要吹一声口哨，他就会立刻跑来的。” “Oh, go on,” he said jovially.“All you have to do is whistle and he’ll come running.”
“我不是那意思。”她简单地说。 “I didn’t mean that,” she said simply.
他明白她的意思了。 And he knew what she had meant.
他正打算道声晚安，她却向他偎依过来。偎依得并不迫切，也不挑逗，却是一往情深的卑微。他从心底里被感动了。一种宽厚的容忍之情从他心底油然而生。他伸出双臂拥抱了她，亲吻了她，他明白那压在他唇上的吻是人类所能得到的最真诚的吻。 She leaned toward him as he was about to say good night.But she leaned not imperatively, not seductively, but wistfully and humbly.He was touched to the heart.His large tolerance rose up in him.He put his arms around her, and kissed her, and knew that upon his own lips rested as true a kiss as man ever received.
“我的上帝呀！”她抽泣起来，“我可以为你死去，为你死去。” “My God!” she sobbed.“I could die for you.I could die for you.”
她突然挣开他，跑上台阶。他眼里立刻一阵湿润。 She tore herself from him suddenly and ran up the steps.He felt a quick moisture in his eyes.
“马丁·伊登，”他沉思着，“你不是野兽，可你是个他妈的可怜的尼采信徒。如果你可以让她那颗战栗的心充满幸福，你就应该娶了她的。可你却办不到，办不到。真他妈的丢脸。” “Martin Eden,” he communed.“You’re not a brute, and you’re a damn poor Nietzscheman.You’d marry her if you could and fill her quivering heart full with happiness.But you can’t, you can’t.And it’s a damn shame.”
“‘可怜的老流浪汉解释他那可怜的老溃疡，’”他想起了他的诗人亨雷，喃喃自语道，“‘我觉得，生命是一个大错误，一种耻辱。’生命是——一个大错误，一种耻辱。” “‘A poor old tramp explains his poor old ulcers,’” he muttered, remembering his Henly.“‘Life is, I think, a blunder and a shame.’ It is—a blunder and a shame.”
第四十三章 CHAPTER XLIII
《太阳的耻辱》在十月的时候出版了。当马丁割断快递包裹绳时，出版社赠送的那半打样书散落了一桌，一种沉重的悲哀笼罩了他。他想，如果这书的出版在短短几个月以前，他会是多么地欢畅得意。他对比着当时那可能出现的喜悦和现在这毫不关心的淡漠。他的书，他的第一本书，然而他的脉搏并没有因此而有丝毫加速，他只是感到悲凉。如今此事于他已毫无意义。此事最大的作用就是能带来一笔钱，而他并不十分在乎钱。 @The Shame of the Sun@ was published in October.As Martin cut the cords of the express package and the half-dozen complimentary copies from the publishers spilled out on the table, a heavy sadness fell upon him.He thought of the wild delight that would have been his had this happened a few short months before, and he contrasted that delight that should have been with his present uncaring coldness.His book, his first book, and his pulse had not gone up a fraction of a beat, and he was only sad.It meant little to him now.The most it meant was that it might bring some money, and little enough did he care for money.
他拿着一本书来到厨房，赠给玛利亚。 He carried a copy out into the kitchen and presented it to Maria.
“这书是我写的，”为了消除玛利亚的疑惑，马丁解释道，“我就是在那间屋子里写的，我猜你做的那些菜汤也给我的写作帮了忙呢。拿着吧，这书送给你了。只当个纪念就行，你明白。” “I did it,” he explained, in order to clear up her bewilderment.“I wrote it in the room there, and I guess some few quarts of your vegetable soup went into the making of it.Keep it.It’s yours.Just to remember me by, you know.”
他没有自夸，也没有炫耀。他唯一的目的就是要让她高兴，让她为自己感到骄傲，也证明她长期以来对他的信任没有错。她把书放在前厅的家用圣经上。她的房客所著的这本书是圣物，是象征友谊的信物。这本书冲淡了他曾做过洗衣工这一事实带给她的震撼。她虽然一句话都读不懂，但她明白这本书的每一句都很了不起。她是个单纯、实在又勤劳的女人，对信念有着巨大的天分。 He was not bragging, not showing off.His sole motive was to make her happy, to make her proud of him, to justify her long faith in him.She put the book in the front room on top of the family Bible.A sacred thing was this book her lodger had made, a fetich of friendship.It softened the blow of his having been a laundryman, and though she could not understand a line of it, she knew that every line of it was great.She was a simple, practical, hard-working woman, but she possessed faith in large endowment.
正如接到《太阳的耻辱》时的无动于衷一样，他在读剪报社每周寄来的评论时也是内心波澜不惊。显然，那书很畅销。这意味着更多的金币进了他的钱袋中。他可以安顿好莉齐，兑现他的所有承诺，剩下的钱仍够建造他那草墙围起的堡垒。 Just as emotionlessly as he had received @The Shame of the Sun@ did he read the reviews of it that came in weekly from the clipping bureau.The book was making a hit, that was evident.It meant more gold in the money sack.He could fix up Lizzie, redeem all his promises, and still have enough left to build his grass-walled castle.
欣格垂-达恩利公司出版此书时很谨慎，第一版印刷了一千五百本。但是关于这本书的书评才刚发表，第二版就开始了印刷，这次的印刷量翻了一番。第二版书还没有发出时，第三版的定单就来了，要求印刷五千本。一家伦敦的公司发来电报接洽，想出版英语版。紧接着又相继传来消息，要求出版这本书的法语、德语以及斯堪的纳维亚语的译本。此时此刻正是攻击梅特林克学派的最佳时机。一场激烈的论战随之而来。萨里比和海克尔发现他们的观点与书中的一致，因此他们都支持《太阳的耻辱》，并为它辩护。克鲁克斯和华莱士则持反对意见，而奥利弗·洛奇爵士则试图在两种观点中寻求一个折衷点，以便符合他那独特的宇宙理论。梅特林克的信徒们在神秘主义的旗帜的号召下聚集了起来。切斯特顿对这一问题发表了一系列自诩不偏袒的评论性文章，却引来了全世界的嘲讽。而萧伯纳则发出了一阵排炮，几乎把这整个事件、争论以及参加争论的人都打了个落花流水。更不用说战场上还挤满了许多名不见经传的英雄豪杰，闹了个尘土漫天，大汗淋漓，喧闹不堪。 Singletree, Darnley & Co. had cautiously brought out an edition of fifteen hundred copies, but the first reviews had started a second edition of twice the size through the presses; and ere this was delivered a third edition of five thousand had been ordered.A London firm made arrangements by cable for an English edition, and hot-footed upon this came the news of French, German, and Scandinavian translations in progress.The attack upon the Maeterlinck school could not have been made at a more opportune moment.A fierce controversy was precipitated.Saleeby and Haeckel indorsed and defended @The Shame of the Sun@, for once finding themselves on the same side of a question.Crookes and Wallace ranged up on the opposing side, while Sir Oliver Lodge attempted to formulate a compromise that would jibe with his particular cosmic theories.Maeterlinck’s followers rallied around the standard of mysticism.Chesterton set the whole world laughing with a series of alleged non-partisan essays on the subject, and the whole affair, controversy and controversialists, was well-nigh swept into the pit by a thundering broadside from George Bernard Shaw.Needless to say the arena was crowded with hosts of lesser lights, and the dust and sweat and din became terrific.
“此书大获成功，实在绝妙非凡,”欣格垂-达恩利公司在给马丁的信上这样说道，“哲学评论竟然能像小说一样走俏。先生选题精彩绝伦，一切促成因素都出乎意料地顺利。我们甚至无需向你保证我们正在未雨绸缪。在美国和加拿大，此书已售出四万多册。印数两万册的新版亦在印刷之中。为尽量满足需求，我们正在加班加点赶印。虽然如此，我们仍然为了促进市场需求花费了不少心思。我们已投入五千元用于广告宣传。这本书势必将创下新的销售记录。” “It is a most marvellous happening,” Singletree, Darnley & Co. wrote Martin, “a critical philosophic essay selling like a novel.You could not have chosen your subject better, and all contributory factors have been unwarrantedly propitious.We need scarcely to assure you that we are making hay while the sun shines.Over forty thousand copies have already been sold in the United States and Canada, and a new edition of twenty thousand is on the presses.We are overworked, trying to supply the demand.Nevertheless we have helped to create that demand.We have already spent five thousand dollars in advertising.The book is bound to be a record-breaker.”
“我社在此信中已冒昧同此信寄出先生另一作品的合同，一式两份。敬请注意，我们已将您的版税报酬增至百分之二十。该报酬已是稳当的出版社所敢出的最高价了。 先生如果同意本提议，请即在表中相关空格处填写新书书名。该书性质我社未规定，任何主题的任何书籍均可行。若先生有写成之书则更好。此时正是趁热打铁出的最好时机。” “Please find herewith a contract in duplicate for your next book which we have taken the liberty of forwarding to you.You will please note that we have increased your royalties to twenty per cent, which is about as high as a conservative publishing house dares go.If our offer is agreeable to you, please fill in the proper blank space with the title of your book.We make no stipulations concerning its nature.Any book on any subject.If you have one already written, so much the better.Now is the time to strike.The iron could not be hotter.”
“我社接到先生签好的合同后将立即预付五千元版税。诚如我社对先生信心十足，打算为先生开创写作事业的大好局面。我社亦愿意与先生磋商签定一份多年合同，比如十年，十年之间凡由先生写成作品一律由我社以书籍形式出版。其他事宜，容后速议。” “On receipt of signed contract we shall be pleased to make you an advance on royalties of five thousand dollars.You see, we have faith in you, and we are going in on this thing big.We should like, also, to discuss with you the drawing up of a contract for a term of years, say ten, during which we shall have the exclusive right of publishing in book-form all that you produce.But more of this anon.”
马丁放下信，在大脑里计算了一下，发现十五美分乘以六万是九千元。他签署了新合同，并在空白处填上《欢乐的轻烟》，连同他在发现写作报纸小小说的公式之前所创作的的二十篇小小说一同寄给了出版社。于是，欣格垂-达恩利公司以美国邮递公司所能达到的最快回函速度寄来了一张五千元的支票。 Martin laid down the letter and worked a problem in mental arithmetic, finding the product of fifteen cents times sixty thousand to be nine thousand dollars.He signed the new contract, inserting @The Smoke of Joy@ in the blank space, and mailed it back to the publishers along with the twenty storiettes he had written in the days before he discovered the formula for the newspaper storiette.And promptly as the United States mail could deliver and return, came Singletree, Darnley & Co.’s check for five thousand dollars.
“玛利亚，我想让你今天下午两点左右跟我一起进城去，”收到支票的那天上午，马丁说，“或者最好在两点钟的时候到十四号街和百老汇大街交叉处的十字路口等我。我会过去找你。” “I want you to come down town with me, Maria, this afternoon about two o’clock,” Martin said, the morning the check arrived.“Or, better, meet me at Fourteenth and Broadway at two o’clock.I’ll be looking out for you.”
玛利亚在约定的时间到达了那里。她费尽心思所能想到解开这个谜团的唯一解释是：给她买鞋。但马丁带她经过鞋店时并没有进去，而是径直走进了地产公司，这让她明显地大失所望。但是在那儿发生的一切将永远如梦般留在她的记忆里。有礼的先生们跟马丁谈话时仁慈地微笑着看她；打字机滴滴答答地敲着；她在正式的文件上签了名；她自己的房东也到了，也签了名。一切手续办妥后，她出了店门来到人行道上，她的房东对她说：“好，玛利亚，这个月你不用付我七元五角的房租了。” At the appointed time she was there; but shoes was the only clew to the mystery her mind had been capable of evolving, and she suffered a distinct shock of disappointment when Martin walked her right by a shoe-store and dived into a real estate office.What happened thereupon resided forever after in her memory as a dream.Fine gentlemen smiled at her benevolently as they talked with Martin and one another; a type-writer clicked; signatures were affixed to an imposing document; her own landlord was there, too, and affixed his signature; and when all was over and she was outside on the sidewalk, her landlord spoke to her, saying, “Well, Maria, you won’t have to pay me no seven dollars and a half this month.”
玛利亚大吃了一惊，说不出话来。 Maria was too stunned for speech.
“下个月也不用付了，再下个月也不用付了，再下个月也一样。”房东说。 “Or next month, or the next, or the next,” her landlord said.
她前言不搭后语地向她的房东表达着感激之情，仿佛受到了恩惠似的。直到她回到北奥克兰自己家里，和伙伴们讨论过，又找那葡萄牙商人咨询了一番后，她才真正明白过来，自己已成为那幢居住了多年，付了多年房租的小屋的主人了。 She thanked him incoherently, as if for a favor.And it was not until she had returned home to North Oakland and conferred with her own kind, and had the Portuguese grocer investigate, that she really knew that she was the owner of the little house in which she had lived and for which she had paid rent so long.
“你怎么不再来买我的东西呢？”那天晚上葡萄牙商人见马丁从车上下来，便立刻上前打招呼。马丁解释说他自己已不再自己做饭吃了，然后主人便请他进门去喝了酒。他发现那是杂货店库存的最好的酒。 “Why don’t you trade with me no more?” the Portuguese grocer asked Martin that evening, stepping out to hail him when he got off the car; and Martin explained that he wasn’t doing his own cooking any more, and then went in and had a drink of wine on the house.He noted it was the best wine the grocer had in stock.
“玛利亚，”马丁那天晚上宣布，“我要离开你了。你自己也马上要离开这里了。你可以当房东，把这房子租出去。你有个在圣莱安德罗或是海沃德做奶品生意的弟弟。我要你明天就把所有的脏衣服都送回去，不用再洗了。明白么？别洗了。到圣利安德罗、海沃德或是别的什么地方去找到你的弟弟，让他来见我。我会在奥克兰的大都会旅馆等他，他见到了好奶牛场是能鉴别的。” “Maria,” Martin announced that night, “I’m going to leave you.And you’re going to leave here yourself soon.Then you can rent the house and be a landlord yourself.You’ve a brother in San Leandro or Haywards, and he’s in the milk business.I want you to send all your washing back unwashed—understand?—unwashed, and to go out to San Leandro to-morrow, or Haywards, or wherever it is, and see that brother of yours.Tell him to come to see me.I’ll be stopping at the Metropole down in Oakland.He’ll know a good milk-ranch when he sees one.”
于是玛利亚变成了房东，又成了奶牛场唯一的老板。她还请了两个雇员帮她做事，还开了一个银行户头。尽管她的孩子们都已穿上了鞋，上学读书，账户里的钱却稳步地增长着。很少有人遇见过自己所梦想的童话般的白马王子，虽然玛利亚从没做过白马王子的梦，但是辛苦工作、头脑单纯的她却接待了那个童话中的王子，他当初假扮成洗衣工。 And so it was that Maria became a landlord and the sole owner of a dairy, with two hired men to do the work for her and a bank account that steadily increased despite the fact that her whole brood wore shoes and went to school.Few persons ever meet the fairy princes they dream about; but Maria, who worked hard and whose head was hard, never dreaming about fairy princes, entertained hers in the guise of an ex-laundryman.
与此同时，全世界都已开始询问：“这个马丁·伊登到底是个什么样的人？”马丁拒绝给他的出版公司任何个人的传记资料，但却无法拒绝来自报纸的邀请。奥克兰是他的家乡，记者们也已打听出了几十个能够提供有关他资料的人。他们把他是什么样的人、不是什么样的人，所有他干过的事以及大部分他没有干过的事都曝光在了公众眼前，以飨读者，还配上了各种抢拍的镜头和照片。照片是从当地一个摄影师那里弄到手的。那人曾经给马丁拍过照，现在他立即给那些照片申请了专利，还上市出售。一开始，由于他对所有的杂志以及资产阶级事物的极度厌恶，马丁也曾与对他的公开大肆宣传斗争过，可最后却屈服了，因为不斗争远比斗争容易。他发现自己无法拒绝那些千里迢迢赶来采访他的特派记者们。况且一天有那么多个小时，他也不再忙于写作和读书，时间总得打发过去；于是他便向那些他认为无实际意义的东西投降了。他接受了采访，发表了有关文学和哲学的见解，甚至还接受资本家发出的宴会邀请。他在一种怪异的舒适平和心境里安定了下来，他再也不在乎了。他原谅了一切人，甚至包括那个把他描绘成赤色分子的新手记者。他还允许那记者作了一整版的报道，摆好姿势让他照了许多相片。 In the meantime the world had begun to ask: “Who is this Martin Eden?”He had declined to give any biographical data to his publishers, but the newspapers were not to be denied.Oakland was his own town, and the reporters nosed out scores of individuals who could supply information.All that he was and was not, all that he had done and most of what he had not done, was spread out for the delectation of the public, accompanied by snapshots and photographs—the latter procured from the local photographer who had once taken Martin’s picture and who promptly copyrighted it and put it on the market.At first, so great was his disgust with the magazines and all bourgeois society, Martin fought against publicity; but in the end, because it was easier than not to, he surrendered.He found that he could not refuse himself to the special writers who travelled long distances to see him.Then again, each day was so many hours long, and, since he no longer was occupied with writing and studying, those hours had to be occupied somehow; so he yielded to what was to him a whim, permitted interviews, gave his opinions on literature and philosophy, and even accepted invitations of the bourgeoisie.He had settled down into a strange and comfortable state of mind.He no longer cared.He forgave everybody, even the cub reporter who had painted him red and to whom he now granted a full page with specially posed photographs.
他偶然还会见到莉齐，她显然对他所获得的成功和荣誉感到惋惜。这事扩大了他俩之间的隔阂。也许是为了缩小差距，她接受了他的建议去上夜校和商业学院，还请了一个收费高得吓人的有名的女衣裁缝给她做衣服。有目共睹，她一天比一天进步了，直到马丁怀疑起自己的做法是否正确，因为他知道她这一切的迁就和努力都是为了他。她在努力让自己在他眼里变得有分量——具有他似乎重视的那种分量。但是他并没有给她希望，他还是像个哥哥一样对待她，也很少跟她见面。 He saw Lizzie occasionally, and it was patent that she regretted the greatness that had come to him.It widened the space between them.Perhaps it was with the hope of narrowing it that she yielded to his persuasions to go to night school and business college and to have herself gowned by a wonderful dressmaker who charged outrageous prices.She improved visibly from day to day, until Martin wondered if he was doing right, for he knew that all her compliance and endeavor was for his sake.She was trying to make herself of worth in his eyes—of the sort of worth he seemed to value.Yet he gave her no hope, treating her in brotherly fashion and rarely seeing her.
在他红遍天的时候，梅雷迪思-洛厄尔公司迫不及待地把他的《过期》推上了市场。由于是小说，它在销售量上取得了比《太阳的耻辱》更大的成功。他得到了前所未有的荣耀，两本书同时在每周的畅销书排行榜上名列榜首。《过期》不但赢得了小说读者的青睐，而且以他处理海洋情节时那宏大的气魄和精湛的技艺，这本小说吸引了细读过《太阳的耻辱》的人们。首先，他曾经极其精彩地攻击过神秘主义文学，之后，他又成功地提供了自己所剖析的那种文学作品，从而证明了自己是集作家与评论家于一身的罕见的天才。 @Overdue@ was rushed upon the market by the Meredith-Lowell Company in the height of his popularity, and being fiction, in point of sales it made even a bigger strike than @The Shame of the Sun@.Week after week his was the credit of the unprecedented performance of having two books at the head of the list of best-sellers.Not only did the story take with the fiction-readers, but those who read @The Shame of the Sun@ with avidity were likewise attracted to the sea-story by the cosmic grasp of mastery with which he had handled it.First he had attacked the literature of mysticism, and had done it exceeding well; and, next, he had successfully supplied the very literature he had exposited, thus proving himself to be that rare genius, a critic and a creator in one.
金钱和荣誉向他源源不断地涌来，他就像动人的彗星一样划过了文学的天空。他对自己引起这番骚动与其说是感到有趣，还不如说是感到好笑。有一件小事令他不解，一件如果人们知道了就会困惑整个世界的小事。不过人们感到困惑的只会是他的不解，而不是那件令他觉得越来越大的小事。布朗特法官邀请他去吃饭。这就是那小事的开端，或者说那就是不久之后会变成大事的那件小事的开端。他曾经侮辱过布朗特法官，对他的态度极其恶劣，可布朗特法官却在街上遇见他时，请他去吃饭。马丁暗自思忖，他在莫尔斯家曾经无数次地见到过布朗特法官，那时候他从没有请他吃饭。那时候他为什么不请他吃饭呢？他问自己。他自己并没有变，他还是那个马丁·伊登。那么，这变化是怎么来的？是因为他写的那些东西已经在书本的封面与封底之间出现了么？可那些东西在当时早就已经完成，而不是后来才完成的。在布朗特法官按一般人的意见嘲弄他的斯宾塞和他的智力时，他那些成就已经取得了。因此布朗特法官邀请他吃饭并不是因为他具有任何真正的价值，而是因为一种完全虚幻的价值。 Money poured in on him, fame poured in on him; he flashed, comet-like, through the world of literature, and he was more amused than interested by the stir he was making.One thing was puzzling him, a little thing that would have puzzled the world had it known.But the world would have puzzled over his bepuzzlement rather than over the little thing that to him loomed gigantic.Judge Blount invited him to dinner.That was the little thing, or the beginning of the little thing, that was soon to become the big thing.He had insulted Judge Blount, treated him abominably, and Judge Blount, meeting him on the street, invited him to dinner.Martin bethought himself of the numerous occasions on which he had met Judge Blount at the Morses’ and when Judge Blount had not invited him to dinner.Why had he not invited him to dinner then?he asked himself.He had not changed.He was the same Martin Eden.What made the difference?The fact that the stuff he had written had appeared inside the covers of books?But it was work performed.It was not something he had done since.It was achievement accomplished at the very time Judge Blount was sharing this general view and sneering at his Spencer and his intellect.Therefore it was not for any real value, but for a purely fictitious value that Judge Blount invited him to dinner.
马丁苦笑了一下，接受了邀请，同时也为自己的自满感到奇怪。晚宴上有六七个地位显赫的大人物和他们的女眷。马丁则发现自己成了个宴会上炙手可热的人物。布朗特法官私下请求他允许把他的名字列入思提克司俱乐部，这建议得到了汉威尔法官的强烈支持。思提克司俱乐部是个非常挑剔的俱乐部，被允许加入的人不但需要足够的钱财，而且还要有卓越的成就。马丁婉言谢绝了，但他比任何时候都困惑了。 Martin grinned and accepted the invitation, marvelling the while at his complacence.And at the dinner, where, with their womankind, were half a dozen of those that sat in high places, and where Martin found himself quite the lion, Judge Blount, warmly seconded by Judge Hanwell, urged privately that Martin should permit his name to be put up for the Styx—the ultra-select club to which belonged, not the mere men of wealth, but the men of attainment.And Martin declined, and was more puzzled than ever.
他忙着处理他那一大堆旧稿。编辑们的稿约令他穷于应付。有人发现他原来是个风格作家，他的风格之中大有文章。《北方评论》在发表了他的《美的摇篮》之后给他写信，要他写六七篇类似的论文，他正想把他过去写成的稿子拿去应付时，《伯顿杂志》早抱着投机的态度，约了他五篇稿子，每篇五百元。他回信说他可以满足要求，但每篇得要一千元。他记得所有这些稿子都曾被现在吵着要他稿子的杂志社拒绝过。而且都拒绝得冷酷、机械、老套。他们曾经叫他汗流浃背，他现在也要叫他们流点汗才行。《神秘的大祭司》、《奇迹梦想者》、《自我的尺度》、《幻象的哲学》、《艺术与生物学》、《上帝与土块》、《批评家与试管》、《星尘》和《高利贷的尊严》就是这样与读者见面的。这些作品引起了轰动、震撼和抱怨，很长时间后才平息下来。 《神秘的大祭司》、《奇迹梦想者》、《自我的尺度》、《幻象的哲学》、《艺术与生物学》、《上帝与土块》、《批评家与试管》、《星尘》和《高利贷的尊严》就是这样与读者见面的。这些作品引起了轰动、震撼和抱怨，很长时间后才平息下来。 He was kept busy disposing of his heap of manuscripts.He was overwhelmed by requests from editors.It had been discovered that he was a stylist, with meat under his style.The @Northern Review@, after publishing “The Cradle of Beauty”, had written him for half a dozen similar essays, which would have been supplied out of the heap, had not @Burton’s Magazine@, in a speculative mood, offered him five hundred dollars each for five essays.He wrote back that he would supply the demand, but at a thousand dollars an essay.He remembered that all these manuscripts had been refused by the very magazines that were now clamoring for them.And their refusals had been cold-blooded, automatic, stereotyped.They had made him sweat, and now he intended to make them sweat. @Burton’s Magazine@ paid his price for five essays, and the remaining four, at the same rate, were snapped up by @Mackintosh’s Monthly@, @The Northern Review@ being too poor to stand the pace.Thus went out to the world “The High Priests of Mystery,” “The Wonder-Dreamers,” “The Yardstick of the Ego,” “Philosophy of Illusion,” “God and Clod,” “Art and Biology,” “Critics and Test-tubes,” “Star-dust,” and “The Dignity of Usury,”—to raise storms and rumblings and mutterings that were many a day in dying down.
编辑们给他写信，让他提出大纲。他按要求做了，但都是按照已经写成的作品写的提纲。他坚决拒绝写任何新作品的要求。一想到提笔写作他就抓狂。他曾亲眼看见布里森登的作品被群众撕成碎片。虽然他现在受到欢呼，但仍心有余悸，无法对群氓表示任何尊重。他的名声似乎是一种耻辱，是对布里森登的一种背叛。它叫他畏缩，但他决心继续走下去，好把钱袋装满。 Editors wrote to him telling him to name his own terms, which he did, but it was always for work performed.He refused resolutely to pledge himself to any new thing.The thought of again setting pen to paper maddened him.He had seen Brissenden torn to pieces by the crowd, and despite the fact that him the crowd acclaimed, he could not get over the shock nor gather any respect for the crowd.His very popularity seemed a disgrace and a treason to Brissenden.It made him wince, but he made up his mind to go on and fill the money-bag.
他接到的编辑们的来信，大体都是这样：“约在一年前本刊曾不幸婉绝先生惠寄之爱情诗集。我们当时虽有深刻印象，却碍于已有安排，忍痛割爱。如目前该稿仍在先生手中，且愿赏光惠寄，我刊将乐于按先生条件全部发表，并以最优厚稿酬将该稿整理成诗集出版。” He received letters from editors like the following: “About a year ago we were unfortunate enough to refuse your collection of love-poems.We were greatly impressed by them at the time, but certain arrangements already entered into prevented our taking them.If you still have them, and if you will be kind enough to forward them, we shall be glad to publish the entire collection on your own terms.We are also prepared to make a most advantageous offer for bringing them out in book-form.”
马丁重新整理了他的悲剧无韵诗，并把它寄去。寄出之前他再读了一遍，那剧本的幼稚、浅薄和业余性给他留下了深刻的印象，可他仍然寄了出去。出版之后，那编辑后悔了一辈子。读者们义愤填膺，不肯相信那剧本是马丁写的。他们认为那距离马丁的高超水平太远了。他们断言那不是他的作品，而是那杂志拙劣的仿作，再不然就是马丁·伊登学大仲马，在成功的高峰期请枪手越俎代庖愚弄大众的。但是当马丁解释说那是他写作初期的作品，而且那家杂志社得不到作品总不罢休时，读者便哈哈大笑。那杂志社吃了个大亏，编辑因此被撤职。那部悲剧再没有出单行本，虽然马丁已把预支的版税装进了腰包。 Martin recollected his blank-verse tragedy, and sent it instead.He read it over before mailing, and was particularly impressed by its sophomoric amateurishness and general worthlessness.But he sent it; and it was published, to the everlasting regret of the editor.The public was indignant and incredulous.It was too far a cry from Martin Eden’s high standard to that serious bosh.It was asserted that he had never written it, that the magazine had faked it very clumsily, or that Martin Eden was emulating the elder Dumas and at the height of success was hiring his writing done for him.But when he explained that the tragedy was an early effort of his literary childhood, and that the magazine had refused to be happy unless it got it, a great laugh went up at the magazine’s expense and a change in the editorship followed.The tragedy was never brought out in book-form, though Martin pocketed the advance royalties that had been paid.
《科尔曼周刊》花了将近三百元给马丁拍来了一封很长的电报，请求他提供二十篇稿子，每篇一千元。该杂志希望他游历全美，选择任何感兴趣的题目写文章，费用全由杂志社承担。电报的主要内容涉及假定的话题，用以表明他选择题材范围之广泛自由。唯一的限制就是旅行只能在美国国内。马丁拍了电报去表示难以从命，并表示了歉意，电报由收方付费。 @Coleman’s Weekly@ sent Martin a lengthy telegram, costing nearly three hundred dollars, offering him a thousand dollars an article for twenty articles.He was to travel over the United States, with all expenses paid, and select whatever topics interested him.The body of the telegram was devoted to hypothetical topics in order to show him the freedom of range that was to be his.The only restriction placed upon him was that he must confine himself to the United States.Martin sent his inability to accept and his regrets by wire “collect.”
《沃伦月刊》刊登的《维基，维基》立即取得了成功。那书每一页的四边都留了很大的空白，还有精美的装饰。该书在度假期间很走红，像野火燎原一样迅速热销。评论家们一致相信该书将与两个伟大作家的两本经典著作《瓶中妖魔》和《驴皮记》并驾齐驱。 @Wiki-Wiki@, published in @Warren’s Monthly@, was an instantaneous success.It was brought out forward in a wide-margined, beautifully decorated volume that struck the holiday trade and sold like wildfire.The critics were unanimous in the belief that it would take its place with those two classics by two great writers, @The Bottle Imp@ and @The Magic Skin@.
不过，读者对《欢乐的轻烟》的反应颇为冷淡，且满是疑惑。因为那些小小说的大胆和反传统精神打击了资产阶级的道德和偏见；该书的法文译本却随即风靡了巴黎，这时英美两国的受读者欢迎度才又跟了上去，销售量之大，使得马丁在销售他的第三本书时逼迫那谨慎保守的欣格垂-达恩利公司给他二十五美分的版税，第四本书则要了足足三十美分。后两部书由他已经写成的全部小说编集而成。那些小说有的已经连载过，有的正在连载。《钟声》和他的恐怖小说编成了一集，另外一集则包括了《冒险》、《坛子》、《生命之酒》、《漩涡》、《拥挤的街》和其他四个短篇小说。梅雷迪思-洛厄尔公司抢走了他的全部论文，马克西米连公司则得到了他的《海洋抒情曲》和《爱情连环曲》，后者还在《女土家庭伴侣》上连载，获得了异常优厚的稿酬。 The public, however, received the @Smoke of Joy@ collection rather dubiously and coldly.The audacity and unconventionality of the storiettes was a shock to bourgeois morality and prejudice;but when Paris went mad over the immediate translation that was made, the American and English reading public followed suit and bought so many copies that Martin compelled the conservative house of Singletree, Darnley & Co. to pay a flat royalty of twenty-five per cent for a third book, and thirty per cent flat for a fourth.These two volumes comprised all the short stories he had written and which had received, or were receiving, serial publication.“The Ring of Bells” and his horror stories constituted one collection; the other collection was composed of “Adventure,” “The Pot,” “The Wine of Life,” “The Whirlpool,” “The Jostling Street@,” and four other stories.The Lowell-Meredith Company captured the collection of all his essays, and the Maxmillian Company got his “Sea Lyrics” and the “Love-cycle,” the latter receiving serial publication in the @Ladies’ Home Companion@ after the payment of an extortionate price.
马丁处理完了所有的文稿，长吁了一口气，如释重负。干草打墙的堡垒和铜皮裹的白色大帆船已经离他不远了。是的，无论如何，他已经明白了布里森登所坚持争辩的道理：有价值的东西进不了杂志。但他的成功却又证明了布里森登的错误。 Martin heaved a sigh of relief when he had disposed of the last manuscript.The grass-walled castle and the white, coppered schooner were very near to him.Well, at any rate he had discovered Brissenden’s contention that nothing of merit found its way into the magazines.His own success demonstrated that Brissenden had been wrong.
不过说到底他又隐约觉得布里森登也未必错。以书本形式出版的《太阳的耻辱》对他的成功所起的作用要比其他作品大得多，其他作品的作用其实很次要。它们都曾四处碰壁，多次被杂志所拒绝和抛弃。《太阳的耻辱》的出版引起了一场争论，一场于他有利的山崩地裂般的大讨论。没有《太阳的耻辱》就没有山崩地裂。没有《太阳的耻辱》轰动性的畅销，也就没有随后而来的其他的山崩地裂。欣格垂-达恩利公司见证了这场奇迹的诞生。因为担心不好销售，他们第一版只印了一千五百本。他们都是经验丰富的出版商。可随之而来的成功却使他们比谁都更加目瞪口呆。对他们来说，那确实是个奇迹，而且他们的震惊感一直没有消失，他们给他的每一封信都表示对那神秘的初次成功肃然起敬。他们无法解释这一切。事情就是那样发生了，跟他们所有的经验都唱了反调。 And yet, somehow, he had a feeling that Brissenden had been right, after all. @The Shame of the Sun@ had been the cause of his success more than the stuff he had written.That stuff had been merely incidental.It had been rejected right and left by the magazines.The publication of @The Shame of the Sun@ had started a controversy and precipitated the landslide in his favor.Had there been no @Shame of the Sun@ there would have been no landslide, and had there been no miracle in the go of @The Shame of the Sun” there would have been no landslide.@Singletree, Darnley & Co. attested that miracle.They had brought out a first edition of fifteen hundred copies and been dubious of selling it.They were experienced publishers and no one had been more astounded than they at the success which had followed.To them it had been in truth a miracle.They never got over it, and every letter they wrote him reflected their reverent awe of that first mysterious happening.They did not attempt to explain it.There was no explaining it.It had happened.In the face of all experience to the contrary, it had happened.
所以这就是马丁质疑他走红的正当性的原因。资本家买了他的书，把金子装进了他的囊中，他对资产阶级并不了解，他不清楚那些资本家怎么可能理解或者欣赏他写的东西。对于成千上万赞扬他、买他书的人来说，马丁与生俱来的人格魅力和力量毫无意义。他只是一时的狂热，是一位得到诸神首肯并震撼帕纳苏斯山的冒险者。成千上万的人读他的书，赞扬他，但是他们对他的书一样的无知，正因为这种无知，他们纵情于布里森登的《蜉蝣》中，并把他击得粉碎，他们是一群奉承讨好而不是毒害他的虎狼之众。奉承或者毒害，于他只是运气问题。有一件事他确信无疑：《蜉蝣》永远比他的所有作品伟大，永远比他内在拥有的所有东西伟大。《蜉蝣》是世纪之诗。那么乌合之众给他的赞扬当然只是悲哀的赞扬，因为那群乌合之众已经将《蜉蝣》推入泥淖中。他深深地叹息，却又表示满足。他高兴的是，最后一份手稿已经卖出，他即将完成他的事业。 So it was, reasoning thus, that Martin questioned the validity of his popularity.It was the bourgeoisie that bought his books and poured its gold into his money-sack, and from what little he knew of the bourgeoisie it was not clear to him how it could possibly appreciate or comprehend what he had written.His intrinsic beauty and power meant nothing to the hundreds of thousands who were acclaiming him and buying his books.He was the fad of the hour, the adventurer who had stormed Parnassus while the gods nodded.The hundreds of thousands read him and acclaimed him with the same brute non-understanding with which they had flung themselves on Brissenden’s “Ephemera” and torn it to pieces—a wolf-rabble that fawned on him instead of fanging him.Fawn or fang, it was all a matter of chance.One thing he knew with absolute certitude: “Ephemera” was infinitely greater than anything he had done.It was infinitely greater than anything he had in him.It was a poem of centuries.Then the tribute the mob paid him was a sorry tribute indeed, for that same mob had wallowed “Ephemera” into the mire.He sighed heavily and with satisfaction.He was glad the last manuscript was sold and that he would soon be done with it all.
第四十四章 CHAPTER XLIV
莫尔斯先生和马丁在大都会旅馆的办公室见了面。莫尔斯究竟只是碰巧偶尔在那里办别的事，还是有意过来想请他吃饭，马丁也没法确定，虽然他更倾向于第二种假设。总而言之，他受到莫尔斯先生——鲁思爸爸的邀请吃饭。莫尔斯先生曾经不让他进门，还解除了他俩的婚约。 Mr. Morse met Martin in the office of the Hotel Metropole.Whether he had happened there just casually, intent on other affairs, or whether he had come there for the direct purpose of inviting him to dinner, Martin never could quite make up his mind, though he inclined toward the second hypothesis.At any rate, invited to dinner he was by Mr. Morse—Ruth’s father, who had forbidden him the house and broken off the engagement.
马丁并不生气。他甚至没有摆着架子。他对莫尔斯先生很容忍，而且还在猜想吃如此普通的馅饼会是什么滋味。他没有拒绝邀请。而是含糊地将它推迟，而且询问了他家里人的情况，尤其是莫尔斯夫人和鲁思的情况。他说起她的名字毫不犹豫，十分自然，虽然他暗自也吃了一惊，自己心里竟没有紧张，没有像过去所熟悉的那样脉搏加速，热血沸腾。 Martin was not angry.He was not even on his dignity.He tolerated Mr. Morse, wondering the while how it felt to eat such humble pie.He did not decline the invitation.Instead, he put it off with vagueness and indefiniteness and inquired after the family, particularly after Mrs. Morse and Ruth.He spoke her name without hesitancy, naturally, though secretly surprised that he had had no inward quiver, no old, familiar increase of pulse and warm surge of blood.
很多人邀请他赴宴，他也接受了其中的一些。有的人为了邀请他吃饭，争相求人引荐。他继续为即将变成大事的小事感到不解。伯纳德·希金博特姆邀请他吃饭。他更加困惑了。他仍然记得那些饿得要死却没人邀请他去吃饭的日子。那正是他需要饭吃的日子，也因为没饭吃，身体变得虚弱，消瘦，也因为极度的饥荒，体重下降。这真是个悖论。当他需要饭吃的时候，没有一个人愿意给他；而如今，他自己可以买上十万顿饭，也没了胃口，但请他吃饭的人确是排山倒海般地来了。但是，这是为什么？这真是没有道理，他是无功受禄啊。他一点没变。他的所有作品甚至在当初都已完成了。莫尔斯夫妇曾经骂他是个懒汉，推卸责任，还让鲁思催促他在办公室当个职员。而且他们已经知道他写的作品。鲁思已经把他的一份份手稿交给他们。他们已经读过。让他的名字出现在所有报纸上的正是原来那些作品，也正是因为他的名字出现在这些报纸上，莫尔斯夫妇才想邀请他。 He had many invitations to dinner, some of which he accepted.Persons got themselves introduced to him in order to invite him to dinner.And he went on puzzling over the little thing that was becoming a great thing.Bernard Higginbotham invited him to dinner.He puzzled the harder.He remembered the days of his desperate starvation when no one invited him to dinner.That was the time he needed dinners, and went weak and faint for lack of them and lost weight from sheer famine.That was the paradox of it.When he wanted dinners, no one gave them to him, and now that he could buy a hundred thousand dinners and was losing his appetite, dinners were thrust upon him right and left.But why?There was no justice in it, no merit on his part.He was no different.All the work he had done was even at that time work performed.Mr. and Mrs. Morse had condemned him for an idler and a shirk and through Ruth had urged that he take a clerk’s position in an office.Furthermore, they had been aware of his work performed.Manuscript after manuscript of his had been turned over to them by Ruth.They had read them.It was the very same work that had put his name in all the papers, and, it was his name being in all the papers that led them to invite him.
有一件事是确定的：莫尔斯夫妇并不在意马丁本人或他的作品。因此现在他们想要的不是他本人或其作品，而是他的名气，因为他现在不是一般人了，而且——为什么不是这样呢？——因为他有大约十万美元。那就是资本主义社会评价一个人的方法，不然他以为自己是谁？但是他很骄傲。他鄙视同这种衡量标准。他希望人们以他自身的价值或者他的作品来评价他，毕竟作品是自己的一种表达。莉齐就是这样评价他的。对她来说，他的作品根本不值得一提。她注重的是他，就是他这个人。水电工吉米和那帮老朋友都是这么评价他的。这一点在他当年跟他们大交道时已有足够的证明；贝陵公园的那个星期天也证明如此。 他的作品无足轻重。他们所喜欢的，愿意为其出手的正是他们的同伴马丁·伊登，一个好哥们。 One thing was certain: the Morses had not cared to have him for himself or for his work.Therefore they could not want him now for himself or for his work, but for the fame that was his, because he was somebody amongst men, and—why not?—because he had a hundred thousand dollars or so.That was the way bourgeois society valued a man, and who was he to expect it otherwise?But he was proud.He disdained such valuation.He desired to be valued for himself, or for his work, which, after all, was an expression of himself.That was the way Lizzie valued him.The work, with her, did not even count.She valued him, himself.That was the way Jimmy, the plumber, and all the old gang valued him.That had been proved often enough in the days when he ran with them; it had been proved that Sunday at Shell Mound Park.His work could go hang.What they liked, and were willing to scrap for, was just Mart Eden, one of the bunch and a pretty good guy.
还有鲁思。她曾经喜欢过这个人，这点毋庸置疑。然而，尽管她很喜欢他，但她也更在意资本主义社会的价值观。她曾经反对他写作，主要是因为这对他来说不能赚钱。她对他的《爱情连环曲》就是那样评价的。她也劝过他去找份工作。没错，她把“工作”提炼成了“职位”二字，但那其实是一回事，那原本的说法总横亘在他心里。他曾把自己的全部作品都读给她听——诗歌、小说、散文——《维基—维基》、《太阳的耻辱》，他所有的一切。她却总坚持地劝他去找一份工作，去干活——老天呀！——仿佛为了配得上她，他没有努力工作，剥夺睡眠，榨干了自己的生活似的。 Then there was Ruth.She had liked him for himself, that was indisputable.And yet, much as she had liked him she had liked the bourgeois standard of valuation more.She had opposed his writing, and principally, it seemed to him, because it did not earn money.That had been her criticism of his “Love-cycle.”She, too, had urged him to get a job.It was true, she refined it to “position,” but it meant the same thing, and in his own mind the old nomenclature stuck.He had read her all that he wrote—poems, stories, essays—“Wiki-Wiki,” @The Shame of the Sun@, everything.And she had always and consistently urged him to get a job, to go to work—good God!—as if he hadn’t been working, robbing sleep, exhausting life, in order to be worthy of her.
于是，小事变得更大了。他健康、正常、按时吃饭、睡眠充足，可那越来越大的小事却困住了他。这句话萦绕在他的脑子里。在希金博特姆现金商店楼上举行的一顿丰盛的周日晚宴上，他坐在伯纳德·希金博特姆的对面，好不容易控制住自己，才没叫出声来： So the little thing grew bigger.He was healthy and normal, ate regularly, slept long hours, and yet the growing little thing was becoming an obsession.Work performed.The phrase haunted his brain.He sat opposite Bernard Higginbotham at a heavy Sunday dinner over Higginbotham’s Cash Store, and it was all he could do to restrain himself from shouting out:—
“作品早创作完了！你现在来请我吃饭。那时你让我挨饿，不许我来你家，因为我不去找工作而诅咒我。而我的作品早完成了，都完成了。现在我一说话，你都恭恭敬敬听着，就算有想法了话到嘴边也压住不说，只听我说，无论我说什么你都恭恭敬敬听着。我告诉你，你的那帮人都是堕落的剥削者，你也没有勃然大怒，只是哼哼哈哈地承认我的话大有道理。这是为什么？就因为我有了名气，也因为我有了很多钱。而不是因为我是马丁·伊登，一个还算不错、也不算太蠢的家伙。即使我告诉你月亮是生奶酪做的，你也会赞同，至少不会表示反驳，因为我有钱，我的钱堆成了小山。可是我的作品很久以前就都完成了。我告诉你，那些作品早就完成了，可那时你当我是你脚下的泥土，往我身上吐唾沫。” “It was work performed!And now you feed me, when then you let me starve, forbade me your house, and damned me because I wouldn’t get a job.And the work was already done, all done.And now, when I speak, you check the thought unuttered on your lips and hang on my lips and pay respectful attention to whatever I choose to say.I tell you your party is rotten and filled with grafters, and instead of flying into a rage you hum and haw and admit there is a great deal in what I say.And why?Because I’m famous; because I’ve a lot of money.Not because I’m Martin Eden, a pretty good fellow and not particularly a fool.I could tell you the moon is made of green cheese and you would subscribe to the notion, at least you would not repudiate it, because I’ve got dollars, mountains of them.And it was all done long ago; it was work performed, I tell you, when you spat upon me as the dirt under your feet.”
马丁·伊登没有叫出来。那想法啃咬着他的脑子，无休止地折磨着他，他却微笑着，而且成功地表现了宽容之情。他一讲完话，伯纳德·希金博特姆便接过话茬，打开了话匣子。他自己就是一个成功的范例，而且为此深感骄傲。他白手起家。他没有靠任何人帮助。他也不欠任何人的情。他履行了一个公民应尽的义务，还拉扯大了一大子家人。这才有了希金博特姆现金商店，那是他的才能和勤劳的丰碑。他对希金博特姆现金商店的爱就如同一些人对他们妻子的爱一般。他对马丁敞开了心扉，大谈特谈他是如何聪明机敏，如何苦心经营才建立起了这家商店。还有他对商店未来发展的计划，雄心勃勃的计划。这附近一带正在迅速发展。这个商店的规模实在太小。如果他有更多的空间，他可以采用一二十条省工又省钱的改进方法。他现在还想干。他正在竭尽全力，为了有一天能把店旁边的土地弄到手，再建一套两层式的房屋而努力。他可以把楼上租出去，把两套楼房的楼下当做新的希金博特姆现金商店。他说到那块横跨两套楼房的新招牌时，眼里放出了光芒。 But Martin did not shout out.The thought gnawed in his brain, an unceasing torment, while he smiled and succeeded in being tolerant.As he grew silent, Bernard Higginbotham got the reins and did the talking.He was a success himself, and proud of it.He was self-made.No one had helped him.He owed no man.He was fulfilling his duty as a citizen and bringing up a large family.And there was Higginbotham’s Cash Store, that monument of his own industry and ability.He loved Higginbotham’s Cash Store as some men loved their wives.He opened up his heart to Martin, showed with what keenness and with what enormous planning he had made the store.And he had plans for it, ambitious plans.The neighborhood was growing up fast.The store was really too small.If he had more room, he would be able to put in a score of labor-saving and money-saving improvements.And he would do it yet.He was straining every effort for the day when he could buy the adjoining lot and put up another two-story frame building.The upstairs he could rent, and the whole ground-floor of both buildings would be Higginbotham’s Cash Store.His eyes glistened when he spoke of the new sign that would stretch clear across both buildings.
马丁忘记了听他说话。那人唧唧呱呱的声音早已被他脑子里的不断重复的“那时作品早就已完成”给淹没了。那叠句叫他发疯，他试图摆脱它。 Martin forgot to listen.The refrain of “Work performed,” in his own brain, was drowning the other’s clatter.The refrain maddened him, and he tried to escape from it.
“你刚才说那得花多少钱？”他突然问道。 “How much did you say it would cost?” he asked suddenly.
他姐夫正大谈着附近地区的商业发展机会，听到马丁的提问就立刻住嘴了。他刚才并没有说起那得花多少钱。但是他是知道的。他已经计算过一二十次了。 His brother-in-law paused in the middle of an expatiation on the business opportunities of the neighborhood.He hadn’t said how much it would cost.But he knew.He had figured it out a score of times.
“按现在的木料价格来看，”他说，“四千元就够了。” “At the way lumber is now,” he said, “four thousand could do it.”
“包括招牌？” “Including the sign?”
“没算招牌。房子一修起来，招牌总得挂的。” “I didn’t count on that.It’d just have to come, onc’t the buildin’ was there.”
“地皮呢？” “And the ground?”
“还得要三千。” “Three thousand more.”
他身子向前倾斜，舔着自己的嘴唇，手指头紧张地聚拢又松开，一边望着马丁开支票。支票递到他的面前，他瞟了一眼数目——七千。 He leaned forward, licking his lips, nervously spreading and closing his fingers, while he watched Martin write a check.When it was passed over to him, he glanced at the amount-seven thousand dollars.
“可是我最多只能出百分之六的利息。”他的嗓子沙哑了。 “I—I can’t afford to pay more than six per cent,” he said huskily.
马丁几乎笑出声来，却问道： Martin wanted to laugh, but, instead, demanded:—
“那是多少钱？” “How much would that be?”
“我算算看，百分之六——六七——四百二十块。” “Lemme see.Six per cent—six times seven—four hundred an’ twenty.”
“那就是每月三十五块，对吧？” “That would be thirty-five dollars a month, wouldn’t it?”
希金博特姆点了点头。 Higginbotham nodded.
“好，如果你不反对的话，我们就这样安排。”马丁瞥了一眼格特鲁德。“如果你把这每月三十五元用来雇人做饭、洗衣服、做清洁，这笔钱的本钱就归你。只要你保证格特鲁德不再做苦工，这七千元就是你的了。这笔交易怎么样？” “Then, if you’ve no objection, well arrange it this way.”Martin glanced at Gertrude.“You can have the principal to keep for yourself, if you’ll use the thirty-five dollars a month for cooking and washing and scrubbing.The seven thousand is yours if you’ll guarantee that Gertrude does no more drudgery.Is it a go?”
希金博特姆先生实在难以接受这笔交易。不让他的妻子做家务活，那简直是对他那节俭的灵魂的无礼冒犯。那豪华的礼物成了糖衣药丸，很苦的药丸。他的妻子居然不用干活！他难以咽下这口气。 Mr. Higginbotham swallowed hard.That his wife should do no more housework was an affront to his thrifty soul.The magnificent present was the coating of a pill, a bitter pill.That his wife should not work!It gagged him.
“那好，”马丁说，“这每月三十五块我来付，那么——” “All right, then,” Martin said.“I’ll pay the thirty-five a month, and—”
马丁把手伸过桌子，要从伯纳鲁德手上取回支票。可支票已经被伯纳德·希金博特姆的手紧紧抓住，希金博特叫道： He reached across the table for the check.But Bernard Higginbotham got his hand on it first, crying:
“我接受！我接受！” “I accept!I accept!”
马丁登上电车时，感到非常难受和疲惫。他抬头看看那神气十足的招牌。 When Martin got on the electric car, he was very sick and tired.He looked up at the assertive sign.
“猪猡！”他吼叫道，“猪猡，猪猡！” “The swine,” he groaned.“The swine, the swine.”
《麦金托什杂志》在显著的位置刊登了《看手相者》，还由伯蒂埃配了画，温思配了两幅插图，赫尔曼·冯·施米特已经忘记了他曾说过这诗是下流的东西。他反倒宣布他的妻子才是这首诗的灵感，还特意让这消息传到了记者耳朵里，接着接受了一个报社作家的采访。那作家带来了一个报社摄影师和一个美工师。这次专访的结果在星期日增刊上占了一大版，满是照片和玛丽安理想化的画像。还加上了许多马丁·伊登和他的家人之间亲切的家长里短。《看手相者》正文经过《麦金托什杂志》特许，以大号字体全文刊载。这在邻近地区引起了很大的轰动。正经人家的主妇们都以结识伟大作家的妹妹为荣，即使不认识她的人也急忙设法和她建立起友谊。赫尔曼·冯·施米特在他的小修理店里得意地笑了，他决定再订购一套新车床。“比做广告还强呢，”他告诉玛丽安，“一分钱也没花。” When @Mackintosh’s Magazine@ published “The Palmist,” featuring it with decorations by Berthier and with two pictures by Wenn, Hermann von Schmidt forgot that he had called the verses obscene.He announced that his wife had inspired the poem, saw to it that the news reached the ears of a reporter, and submitted to an interview by a staff writer who was accompanied by a staff photographer and a staff artist.The result was a full page in a Sunday supplement, filled with photographs and idealized drawings of Marian, with many intimate details of Martin Eden and his family, and with the full text of “The Palmist” in large type, and republished by special permission of @Mackintosh’s Magazine@.It caused quite a stir in the neighborhood, and good housewives were proud to have the acquaintances of the great writer’s sister, while those who had not made haste to cultivate it.Hermann von Schmidt chuckled in his little repair shop and decided to order a new lathe.“Better than advertising,” he told Marian, “and it costs nothing.”
“我们最好请他来吃顿晚饭。”她建议道。 “We’d better have him to dinner,” she suggested.
马丁来吃晚饭了。他让自己和那个经营肉类批发的胖子和他更胖的老婆融洽相处。那是邻近地区的重要人物，对像赫尔曼·冯·施米特这样正处在上升期的年轻人大有益处。然而，没有像他妻舅马丁·伊登这样的大人物做诱饵，那样的人是请不进门的。另外一个吞下了诱饵前来赴宴的人是阿萨自行车公司太平洋沿岸各代销店的总监。冯·施米特想要讨好他，取悦他，因为他想从他那儿获得在奥克兰的自行车代销权。正因如此，赫尔曼·冯·施米特才发现马丁·伊登这样一个妻舅对他竟成了一笔可观的人际资产。可是在内心深处他却怎么也想不通到底为什么会这样。等到夜深人静，他的妻子入睡之后，他便把马丁的书和诗都翻了个遍，得到的结论是全世界都是傻瓜，连这种东西也买。 And to dinner Martin came, making himself agreeable with the fat wholesale butcher and his fatter wife—important folk, they, likely to be of use to a rising young man like Hermann Von Schmidt.No less a bait, however, had been required to draw them to his house than his great brother-in-law.Another man at table who had swallowed the same bait was the superintendent of the Pacific Coast agencies for the Asa Bicycle Company.Him Von Schmidt desired to please and propitiate because from him could be obtained the Oakland agency for the bicycle.So Hermann von Schmidt found it a goodly asset to have Martin for a brother-in-law, but in his heart of hearts he couldn’t understand where it all came in.In the silent watches of the night, while his wife slept, he had floundered through Martin’s books and poems, and decided that the world was a fool to buy them.
马丁身子往后靠着，得意地望着冯·施米特的脑袋。他在内心的深处对这局面却明察秋毫。他幻想着揍这脑袋一顿，一拳又一拳地揍个正着，差不多要把它揍得掉下来才行——那傻啦吧唧的荷兰佬！不过那家伙有一点却叫他喜欢。他尽管穷，尽管下了决心往上爬，却雇了一个人把玛丽安的繁重的家务活给接了过去。马丁跟阿萨公司的地区代理商总监谈完话，便趁晚饭后把他跟赫尔曼一起拉到了一边去。他给了赫尔曼经济上的支持，让他在奥克兰开个设备齐全的最好的自行车店。他还进一步跟赫尔曼私下谈话，要他留心物色一下，准备经营一家带车库的汽车代销店。因为他完全有能力把两个铺子都经营得很成功。 And in his heart of hearts Martin understood the situation only too well, as he leaned back and gloated at Von Schmidt’s head, in fancy punching it well-nigh off of him, sending blow after blow home just right—the chuckle-headed Dutchman!One thing he did like about him, however.Poor as he was, and determined to rise as he was, he nevertheless hired one servant to take the heavy work off of Marian’s hands.Martin talked with the superintendent of the Asa agencies, and after dinner he drew him aside with Hermann, whom he backed financially for the best bicycle store with fittings in Oakland.He went further, and in a private talk with Hermann told him to keep his eyes open for an automobile agency and garage, for there was no reason that he should not be able to run both establishments successfully.
分别的时候，玛丽安用双臂搂住了马丁的脖子，热泪盈眶地告诉他她非常爱他，而且一如既往地爱他。他确实感到她说那话时有点吞吞吐吐，可她流了更多的泪，亲了他更多次，又支支吾吾地说了些不连贯的话，掩饰了过去。马丁把这样的举动理解为请求原谅，因为她当初也曾经对他缺乏信心，要求他去找工作。 With tears in her eyes and her arms around his neck, Marian, at parting, told Martin how much she loved him and always had loved him.It was true, there was a perceptible halt midway in her assertion, which she glossed over with more tears and kisses and incoherent stammerings, and which Martin inferred to be her appeal for forgiveness for the time she had lacked faith in him and insisted on his getting a job.
“他的钱是绝对管不住的，那是必定的，”赫尔曼·冯·施米特对他的妻子透露道，“我一提起利息他就发火，他说连本钱也滚蛋吧，我若是再对他谈利息，他就要把我这荷兰脑袋敲掉。他就是这么说的——我这荷兰脑袋。不过，他虽然做生意不行，人倒是蛮好的。他给了我机会，是个好人。” “He can’t never keep his money, that’s sure,” Hermann von Schmidt confided to his wife.“He got mad when I spoke of interest, an’ he said damn the principal and if I mentioned it again, he’d punch my Dutch head off.That’s what he said—my Dutch head.But he’s all right, even if he ain’t no business man.He’s given me my chance, an’ he’s all right.”
马丁的宴会邀请接踵而来，来得越多，他越觉得疑惑不已。在阿登俱乐部的宴会上他占了贵宾席，跟他在一起的都是他平生所读到过或听见过的知名人士。他们告诉他他们在《洲际月刊》上读到他的《钟声》、在《大黄蜂》上读到他的《仙女与珍珠》时，并且早就认定了他会成功。天呀！他暗自思忖：可我那时却是衣不蔽体、食不果腹。那时你们怎么不来请我吃饭呢？那时才是时候。那时我那些作品已经完成了。如果你们现在是因为我已经写成的作品而宴请我，那你们为什么不在我最需要的时候来宴请我呢？《钟声》和《仙女与珍珠》一字未改。不，你们不是因为我已经完成的作品而宴请我，而是因为别人都在宴请我而宴请我，因为宴请我是一件光荣的事情。 Invitations to dinner poured in on Martin; and the more they poured, the more he puzzled.He sat, the guest of honor, at an Arden Club banquet, with men of note whom he had heard about and read about all his life; and they told him how, when they had read “The Ring of Bells” in the @Transcontinental@, and “The Peri and the Pearl” in @The Hornet@, they had immediately picked him for a winner.My God!and I was hungry and in rags, he thought to himself.Why didn’t you give me a dinner then?Then was the time.It was work performed.If you are feeding me now for work performed, why did you not feed me then when I needed it?Not one word in “The Ring of Bells,” nor in “@The Peri and the Pearl@” has been changed.No; you’re not feeding me now for work performed. You are feeding me because everybody else is feeding me and because it is an honor to feed me.
你们现在宴请我，是因为你们都是群居动物；因为你们是群氓的一部分；因为此时此刻群氓心态的一个盲目的冲动就是宴请我。在这一切之中，马丁·伊登和马丁·伊登完成的作品究竟有什么作用呢？他痛苦地问自己。然后他站起身来对于一个聪明风趣的祝酒辞作出了聪明风趣的回答。 You are feeding me now because you are herd animals; because you are part of the mob; because the one blind, automatic thought in the mob-mind just now is to feed me.And where does Martin Eden and the work Martin Eden performed come in in all this?He asked himself plaintively, then arose to respond cleverly and wittily to a clever and witty toast.
日子就这样一直过下去。无论他在什么地方——在出版俱乐部，在红木俱乐部，在绯午后茶会还是在文学集会上——总有人会提起《钟声》和《仙女与珍珠》刚出版的时候。那叫他发疯的而他不曾提出的问题总要在他心里出现：那时候你们为什么不请我吃饭？作品那时已经完成了呀！《钟声》和《仙女与珍珠》一字未改啊！那时它们跟现在一样精彩，一样有价值呀。你们并不是因为它们才请我吃饭的，也不是因为我其他的作品。你们请我是因为请我吃饭目前很时髦，因为整个群氓集体正在为请马丁吃饭而发狂。 So it went.Wherever he happened to be—at the Press Club, at the Redwood Club, at pink teas and literary gatherings—always were remembered “The Ring of Bells” and “The Peri and the Pearl” when they were first published.And always was Martin’s maddening and unuttered demand: Why didn’t you feed me then?It was work performed.“@The Ring of Bells@” and “@The Peri and the Pearl@” are not changed one iota.They were just as artistic, just as worthwhile, then as now.But you are not feeding me for their sake, nor for the sake of anything else I have written.You’re feeding me because it is the style of feeding just now, because the whole mob is crazy with the idea of feeding Martin Eden.
在这样的时刻，他便常常突然看见一个身穿方襟短外衣、头戴斯特森硬檐毡帽的年轻流氓从人群中摇摇摆摆地走了出来。有天下午，他在奥克兰的加林纳社就见到他。那时他刚离开座位穿过讲台走向前去。他看见那年轻的流氓从巨大的厅堂后面的大门口神气十足地走了进来，身穿方襟短外衣，头戴硬檐毡帽。马丁看得如此认真专注，五百来个衣着时髦的名媛也都转过头去看他在看什么。可她们只看见了座位正中空空的走道。马丁看见那年轻的粗汉沿着走道过来了，猜想着他是否会脱掉他从没见他脱下过的硬檐帽。那人沿着吊道笔直地走来了，走上了讲台。马丁想起他面前的路，差不多为自己那年轻的幻影哭了出来。那人摇摇摆摆穿过讲台，直往马丁走来，然后在马丁的意识前沿消失了。五百个名媛用戴了手套的手轻轻地鼓起掌来，想要鼓励她们的客人，那腼腆的伟人。马丁把那幻影从他的头脑里摇掉，笑了笑，开始了他的演讲。 And often, at such times, he would abruptly see slouch in among the company a young hoodlum in square-cut coat and under a stiff-rim Stetson hat.It happened to him at the Gallina Society in Oakland one afternoon.As he rose from his chair and stepped forward across the platform, he saw stalk through the wide door at the rear of the great room the young hoodlum with the square-cut coat and stiff-rim hat.Five hundred fashionably gowned women turned their heads, so intent and steadfast was Martin’s gaze, to see what he was seeing.But they saw only the empty centre aisle.He saw the young tough lurching down that aisle and wondered if he would remove the stiff-rim which never yet had he seen him without.Straight down the aisle he came, and up the platform.Martin could have wept over that youthful shade of himself, when he thought of all that lay before him.Across the platform he swaggered, right up to Martin, and into the foreground of Martin’s consciousness disappeared.The five hundred women applauded softly with gloved hands, seeking to encourage the bashful great man who was their guest.And Martin shook the vision from his brain, smiled, and began to speak.
学校巡视员，一个好老头，在路边叫住了马丁。他想起了他，回忆了在他办公室里跟他的几次会见，那时马丁因为打架被学校开除了。 The Superintendent of Schools, good old man, stopped Martin on the street and remembered him, recalling seances in his office when Martin was expelled from school for fighting.
“很久前我在一份杂志上读到了你的《钟声》，”他说，“写得像爱伦·坡的作品一样好。棒极了，我那时就说，棒极了！” “I read your ‘Ring of Bells’ in one of the magazines quite a time ago,” he said.“It was as good as Poe.Splendid, I said at the time, splendid!”
是的，之后的几个月里，在马路上你两次从我身边走过，都没有认出我来——马丁几乎这样叫出声来。那两次我都在挨饿，常常往当铺跑。可那时我的作品已经完成了。你那时根本不认识我。你现在为什么又来认我呢？ Yes, and twice in the months that followed you passed me on the street and did not know me, Martin almost said aloud.Each time I was hungry and heading for the pawnbroker.Yet it was work performed.You did not know me then.Why do you know me now?
“那天我还在对我的老伴说，”对方还在讲，“请你出来吃顿饭会不会是个好主意呢？她非常赞成。是的，她对我的提议非常赞成。” “I was remarking to my wife only the other day,” the other was saying, “wouldn’t it be a good idea to have you out to dinner some time?And she quite agreed with me.Yes, she quite agreed with me.”
“吃饭？”马丁的声音非常尖锐，几乎像咆哮一样。 “Dinner?” Martin said so sharply that it was almost a snarl.
“什么？啊，是的是的，吃饭，你知道——跟我们吃一顿便饭，跟你的老学监，你这个小鬼。”他有点紧张地说，捶了一下马丁，装作开玩笑、挺友好的样子。 “Why, yes, yes, dinner, you know—just pot luck with us, with your old superintendent, you rascal,” he uttered nervously, poking Martin in an attempt at jocular fellowship.
马丁感到莫名其妙，继续沿着大街走着。他在街角站住了，向四面茫然地望了望。 Martin went down the street in a daze.He stopped at the corner and looked about him vacantly.
“哼，真有意思！”他终于自言自语地说，“那老家伙害怕我呢。” “Well, I’ll be damned!” he murmured at last.“The old fellow was afraid of me.”
第四十五章 CHAPTER XLV
有一天，克赖斯来拜访马丁。克赖斯是一个“真正的贫民”。马丁放下心来，听他讲一个相当想入非非的计划的闪光点，这细节能使他怀着小说家的兴趣而不是投资人的兴趣去听。分析到中途，克赖斯停了足够长的时间向马丁解释他在《太阳的耻辱》里简直是个木头人。 Kreis came to Martin one day—Kreis, of the “real dirt”; and Martin turned to him with relief, to receive the glowing details of a scheme sufficiently wild-catty to interest him as a fictionist rather than an investor.Kreis paused long enough in the midst of his exposition to tell him that in most of his @Shame of the Sun@ he had been a chump.
“可我到这儿来并不是来侃哲学的，”克赖斯接着说，“我想知道你肯不肯在这桩笔生意上投资一千元。” “But I didn’t come here to spout philosophy,” Kreis went on.“What I want to know is whether or not you will put a thousand dollars in on this deal?”
“不，无论如何我也不会傻到那种程度，”马丁回答说，“但我会告诉你我的打算。你曾经给了我一生中最精彩的一夜。你给了我用金钱买不到的东西。现在我有钱了，而钱对于我来说没什么意义。我认为你那笔生意没什么价值，但我愿意给你一千元，作为你给我的无价的一夜的回报。你需要钱。我的钱又多得用不完。你需要钱。你就来向我要。没必要耍花样要钱。拿走就好。” “No, I’m not chump enough for that, at any rate,” Martin answered.“But I’ll tell you what I will do.You gave me the greatest night of my life. You gave me what money cannot buy.Now I’ve got money, and it means nothing to me.I’d like to turn over to you a thousand dollars of what I don’t value for what you gave me that night and which was beyond price.You need the money.I’ve got more than I need.You want it. You came for it. There’s no use scheming it out of me. Take it.”
克瑞斯没有显露出一点惊讶之情。他把支票折好放进了口袋。 Kreis betrayed no surprise.He folded the check away in his pocket.
“这个价的话，我倒愿意签个合同，为你提供许多那样的夜晚。”他说。 “At that rate I’d like the contract of providing you with many such nights,” he said.
“太晚了，”马丁摇摇头，“那晚对于我来说是唯一的。那时我简直上了天堂。虽然我知道那对你们来说很平常。可那对我却大不相同。我永远也不会生活在那样的高度了。我已经厌倦了哲学。我再也不想听到任何关于哲学的东西。” “Too late.” Martin shook his head.“That night was the one night for me.I was in paradise.It’s commonplace with you, I know.But it wasn’t to me.I shall never live at such a pitch again.I’m done with philosophy.I want never to hear another word of it.”
“这可是我有生以来靠哲学赚到的第一笔钱，”克赖斯说着，走到门口时又站住了，“可是紧接着市场就垮掉了。” “The first dollar I ever made in my life out of my philosophy,” Kreis remarked, as he paused in the doorway.“And then the market broke.”
有一天莫尔斯太太在街上坐车从马丁身边经过，微笑着向他点了点头。马丁脱帽微笑着回了礼。这个小插曲对他没有影响。要是一个月以前他一定会反感，或者会出于好奇而揣测她那时的思想状态。可现在事情便再也激不起他的想法。他转瞬就忘了此事。就像路过了中央银行大楼或市政厅便立即忘记它们一样，那事一过，他也就忘了。可是他的思维却异常活跃。他的思想总绕着一个圆圈转来转去。那圆圈的中心是“作品早完成了”；那念头像一大堆不死的蛆虫啃咬着他的大脑。早晨醒来时面对的是它们。晚上咬啮他的梦的也是它们。周围生活里进入他感官每件事都立即和“作品早已完成”联系了起来。他顺着无情的逻辑推下去，结论是他自己已无足轻重，什么也不是。流氓马丁·伊登和水手马丁·伊登都是真实的，可那都是过去的他。但是著名的作家马丁·伊登却已不存在了！著名作家马丁·伊登，是这个群氓心理产生的一团迷雾，是由群氓心理硬塞进流氓和水手马·伊登的躯体里去的。可那骗不了他。他并不是群氓顶礼膜拜并供奉的那个太阳神话。他比任何人都清楚。 Mrs. Morse drove by Martin on the street one day, and smiled and nodded.He smiled back and lifted his hat.The episode did not affect him.A month before it might have disgusted him, or made him curious and set him to speculating about her state of consciousness at that moment.But now it was not provocative of a second thought. He forgot about it the next moment.He forgot about it as he would have forgotten the Central Bank Building or the City Hall after having walked past them.Yet his mind was preternaturally active.His thoughts went ever around and around in a circle.The centre of that circle was “work performed”; it ate at his brain like a deathless maggot.He awoke to it in the morning. It tormented his dreams at night. Every affair of life around him that penetrated through his senses immediately related itself to “work performed.”He drove along the path of relentless logic to the conclusion that he was nobody, nothing.Mart Eden, the hoodlum, and Mart Eden, the sailor, had been real, had been he; but Martin Eden! the famous writer, did not exist.Martin Eden, the famous writer, was a vapor that had arisen in the mob-mind and by the mob-mind had been thrust into the corporeal being of Mart Eden, the hoodlum and sailor.But it couldn’t fool him.He was not that sun-myth that the mob was worshipping and sacrificing dinners to.He knew better.
他浏览杂志上有关自己的文章，细读里面对他的描述，甚至觉得无法把那些描写与自己联系起来。他是那个曾经活过、爱过、激动过的马丁；他是那个曾经性情随和、容忍生活中的弱点的马丁；他是那个曾经在水手舱当过水手，曾经在异国他乡漂泊，曾经带领一帮人打架的马丁。他是那个刚开始见到免费图书馆书架上那成千上万的藏书时目瞪口呆的马丁；那个在后来的日子里在书城之中钻研出了门道并掌握了知识的马丁；那个曾经点着灯熬夜读书，带着铁刺睡觉，自己也写过几本书的马丁。但他唯一没有的是：他没有那所有的群氓都想填塞的那个硕大无比的胃。 He read the magazines about himself, and pored over portraits of himself published therein until he was unable to associate his identity with those portraits.He was the fellow who had lived and thrilled and loved; who had been easy-going and tolerant of the frailties of life; who had served in the forecastle, wandered in strange lands, and led his gang in the old fighting days.He was the fellow who had been stunned at first by the thousands of books in the free library, and who had afterward learned his way among them and mastered them; he was the fellow who had burned the midnight oil and bedded with a spur and written books himself.But the one thing he was not was that colossal appetite that all the mob was bent upon feeding.
不过，杂志上有些东西也令他觉得好笑。所有的杂志都在争抢他。《沃伦月刊》向订阅者宣传它总在发现新作家；其中马丁·伊登就是他们向读者大众极力推荐的。《白鼠》杂志宣称马丁·伊登是他们发现的；发表同样消息的还有《北方评论》和《麦金托什杂志》，可他们却被《地球》弄得不敢言语了，因为《地球》胜利地指出了埋藏在他们的文献中那份被窜改得面目全非的《海洋抒情曲》。逃脱了债务又重整旗鼓的《青年与时代》提出了马丁更早的一篇作品，并宣称这篇文章除了农民的孩子外没人读过。《洲际月刊》发表了一篇有说服力的庄严声明，说他们当初是如何物色到马丁·伊登的，《大黄蜂》却展示了他们出版的《仙女与珍珠》，进行了激烈的反驳。在这一片吵嚷声中欣格垂-达恩利公司那温和的声明被淹没了。 何况欣格垂出版社没有可以用来发表响亮声明的杂志。 There were things, however, in the magazines that amused him.All the magazines were claiming him. @Warren’s Monthly@ advertised to its subscribers that it was always on the quest after new writers, and that, among others, it had introduced Martin Eden to the reading public.The @White Mouse@ claimed him; so did The @Northern Review@ and @Mackintosh’s Magazine@, until silenced by @The Globe@, which pointed triumphantly to its files where the mangled “Sea Lyrics” lay buried. @Youth and Age@, which had come to life again after having escaped paying its bills, put in a prior claim, which nobody but farmers’ children ever read.The @Transcontinental@ made a dignified and convincing statement of how it first discovered Martin Eden, which was warmly disputed by @The Hornet@, with the exhibit of “The Peri and the Pearl.”The modest claim of Singletree, Darnley & Co. was lost in the din.Besides, that publishing firm did not own a magazine wherewith to make its claim less modest.
报纸计算着马丁的稿酬。有几家杂志通过某种方式把他的巨额稿酬泄露了出去，于是奥克兰的部长们便来友好地拜访了他；求职信也塞满了他的信箱。而比所有这些更糟的则是女人。他的照片广泛刊登，于是有了专门的作家拿他那青铜色的结实面庞、身上的伤疤、结实的肩膀、沉静清澈的双眼、苦行僧式的凹陷的面颊大做文章。这最终让他想起了自己狂野的少年时代，微笑起来。在他遇到的妇女中，他不时发现有人在打量他，品评他，垂青他。他暗暗觉得好笑。他想起了布里森登的警告，更加忍俊不禁了。女人是无法毁掉他的，这一点可以肯定。他早已越过了那道坎。 The newspapers calculated Martin’s royalties.In some way the magnificent offers certain magazines had made him leaked out, and Oakland ministers called upon him in a friendly way, while professional begging letters began to clutter his mail.But worse than all this were the women.His photographs were published broadcast, and special writers exploited his strong, bronzed face, his scars, his heavy shoulders, his clear, quiet eyes, and the slight hollows in his cheeks like an ascetic’s.At this last he remembered his wild youth and smiled.Often, among the women he met, he would see now one, now another, looking at him, appraising him, selecting him.He laughed to himself.He remembered Brissenden’s warning and laughed again.The women would never destroy him, that much was certain.He had gone past that stage.
有一回他送莉齐去夜校。莉齐看见一位穿着华丽的长袍、长得很漂亮的资产阶级女人瞟了他一眼。那一眼瞟得太久了，意味太深远了。莉齐知道那是什么意思，她气得身体都僵硬了。马丁注意到了，并且注意到了起因，便告诉她这种事他早已司空见惯，并不放在心上。 Once, walking with Lizzie toward night school, she caught a glance directed toward him by a well-gowned, handsome woman of the bourgeoisie.The glance was a trifle too long, a shade too considerative.Lizzie knew it for what it was, and her body tensed angrily.Martin noticed, noticed the cause of it, told her how used he was becoming to it and that he did not care anyway.
“你应当注意的，”她回答的时候满眼怒火，“你生病了，这是问题所在。” “You ought to care,” she answered with blazing eyes.“You’re sick.That’s what’s the matter.”
“我现在最健康，我的体重比过去增加了五磅呢。” “Never healthier in my life.I weigh five pounds more than I ever did.”
“不是指你身体。我是你的脑子。是你那思维的机器出了毛病。连我这样的小角色也看出来了。” “It ain’t your body.It’s your head.Something’s wrong with your think-machine.Even I can see that, an’ I ain’t nobody.”
他走在她身旁，思考着。 He walked on beside her, reflecting.
“只要能治好你这病，我在所不惜，”她冲动地叫喊起来，“女人那样看你，你就得小心，尤其是像你这样的人。太不正常了。你如果是个娘娘腔那倒没什么，可你生来不是那样的人。上帝保佑，要是出现一个能叫你喜欢的人，我倒是心甘情愿，而且很高兴。” “I’d give anything to see you get over it,” she broke out impulsively.“You ought to care when women look at you that way, a man like you.It’s not natural.It’s all right enough for sissy-boys.But you ain’t made that way.So help me, I’d be willing an’ glad if the right woman came along an’ made you care.”
他把莉齐留在夜校，一个人回到了大都会旅馆。 When he left Lizzie at night school, he returned to the Metropole.
一进屋他就倒在一张莫里斯安乐椅上，茫然地直望前面。他没有打盹。他也没有想事情。他的大脑里一片空白，除了偶尔有一些回忆镜头带着形状、色彩和闪光浮现在他眼前。他看到了那些镜头，却几乎没有意识到——如同对待梦境一样。可他又没有睡着。有一次他醒了过来，看了看表。才八点整。他没事可做，睡觉又太早。他脑子里又一片空白，眼前又有影像形成、消逝。那些影像都模糊不清。它们总是犹如被阳光穿透的层层树叶和灌木丛的乱枝。 Once in his rooms, he dropped into a Morris chair and sat staring straight before him.He did not doze.Nor did he think.His mind was a blank, save for the intervals when unsummoned memory pictures took form and color and radiance just under his eyelids.He saw these pictures, but he was scarcely conscious of them—no more so than if they had been dreams.Yet he was not asleep.Once, he roused himself and glanced at his watch.It was just eight o’clock.He had nothing to do, and it was too early for bed.Then his mind went blank again, and the pictures began to form and vanish under his eyelids.There was nothing distinctive about the pictures.They were always masses of leaves and shrub-like branches shot through with hot sunshine.
敲门声惊醒了他。他没有睡着，那声音让他瞬间想到是不是有人来送电报、信件或是洗衣房的仆役送来洗好的衣物。他嘴里说“请进”的时候心里正想着乔，猜想着他在什么地方。 A knock at the door aroused him.He was not asleep, and his mind immediately connected the knock with a telegram, or letter, or perhaps one of the servants bringing back clean clothes from the laundry.He was thinking about Joe and wondering where he was, as he said, “Come in.”
他依旧在思考着，而没有向门口转过身去。他听见门轻轻关上。然后是长久的沉静。他忘记了曾经有过敲门声，仍茫然地望着前面，却听见了女人的抽泣。当他转过身时，他注意到那哭声抽搐、压抑、难以控制，那么不由自主，还带着呜咽。他立即站了起来。 He was still thinking about Joe, and did not turn toward the door.He heard it close softly. There was a long silence.He forgot that there had been a knock at the door, and was still staring blankly before him when he heard a woman’s sob.It was involuntary, spasmodic, checked, and stifled—he noted that as he turned about.The next instant he was on his feet.
“鲁思！”他说，又惊讶又惶惑。 “Ruth!”he said, amazed and bewildered.
